DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Sept. 1, or the 28th day of the seventh month of the year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1715: Louis XIV, known as "Louis the Great" and "the Sun King," dies at the age of 77. His reign from 1643 to 1715, the longest in French history, was characterized by a magnificent court and the expansion of French influence in Europe.
1917: Congress elects Dr. Sun Yat-sen grand marshal of the Army and Navy of the Chinese Military Government.
1920: The French create the state of Lebanon, naming Beirut as the capital.
1923: A massive earthquake in Japan devastates Tokyo and Yokohama, killing more than 300,000 people and leaving millions of others homeless.
1939: Adolf Hitler hurls more than a million German troops into Poland, smashing the Polish defenses. Switzerland, Norway and Finland declare their neutrality.
1944: Journalists in Taiwan celebrate the first Reporters' Day.
1948: Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, sets up a provisional government in China.
1951: The ANZUS Treaty, a mutual defense treaty among Australia, New Zealand and the United States, is signed in San Francisco.
1955: The Central Police School is inaugurated at Kueishan in Taoyuan County, and later becomes Central Police University.
1959: The Law of Compensation for Wrongful Detentions and Convictions, designed to compensate victims of miscarriages of justice, goes into effect.
1963: The Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development is inaugurated to replace the Council for US Aid.
1963: Hualien, an eastern Taiwan city facing the Pacific, is opened as an international port.
1966: Sun Fo (Sun Ko), son of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, is sworn in as president of the Examination Yuan.
1973: Vice President Yen Chia-kan returns to Taipei after a 17-day visit to Latin America.
1974: The Press Council of the Republic of China is inaugurated in Taipei.
1975: The ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica sign a memorandum on economic and technical cooperation.
1976: The second Press Council is inaugurated in Taipei by Wang Ti-wu, chairman of the Taipei Press Association.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo presides at ceremonies marking the 50th anniversary of the Chinese Air Force Academy. He reviews the academy's cadets at the event.
1980: Newly revised customs regulations based on a two-tier duty system go into effect in Taiwan.
1982: Kenting National Park, the first of its kind in the Republic of China, is inaugurated.
1983: A Soviet jet fighter shoots down a Korean Airlines Boeing 747, KAL Flight 007, near Sakhalin Island, killing all 269 on board.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun announces the objectives of the Six-Year National Development Plan, which include public construction projects affecting economics, culture, education and medicine.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui names Premier Lien Chan as his running mate after the ruling Kuomintang nominates him as its presidential candidate.
1996: A 2,536-kilometer railroad linking Beijing and Kowloon is opened to traffic.
1999: The Republic of China becomes the first country in the world to implement a nationwide law requiring compulsory registration of dogs as part of its efforts to improve animal management and protection.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In every particular branch of knowledge there is truth. Where there is truth, there is substance. Where there is substance, there is reality. Where there is reality, there is intelligence."

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC WON'T HIKE GAS PRICES THURSDAY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will not raise gasoline prices Thursday because of Typhoon Talim, which has been ravaging Taiwan since Wednesday evening.

Ho made the comments at the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center when reporters asked her whether the CPC will follow privately run Formosa Petroleum Corp. which announced a gas price hike of almost 10 percent Wednesday.

She said the CPC lost more than NT$3 billion (US$91.6 million) in August, adding: "However, in consideration of the fact that the people are being hit by a typhoon, we will not allow an upward adjustment of gasoline prices today."
The CPC incurred heavy losses in August because world crude oil prices soared 60 percent, she said.

According to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , the impact of rising oil prices on economic growth is not as great as during the second oil crisis of the 1970s as the ratio of crude oil consumption to gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by 25.3 percent since that time.
In the United States and Japan, the ratio has dropped by a even larger margin -- 36.5 percent and 37.2 percent, respectively, according to the DGBAS.

The DGBAS attributed this drop to technological progress, growth in productivity, and the promotion of energy conservation, as well as the development of the service industry, the Internet and the integrated circuit.
Liang Chi-yuan, a research fellow with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research body, estimated that a 10-percent hike in oil prices will cause a dent of 0.27 percent in Taiwan's GDP growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMTRAK APOLOGIZES FOR LISTING TAIWAN AS PROVINCE OF CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By J.L. Chi and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, Amtrak, has made a correction and an apology for its error of listing Taiwan as a province of China in its online billing address form, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) said Wednesday.

As Amtrak had not responded to a protest lodged by a group of Tawianese expatriates in the United States after discovering the error in May of this year, the pro-Taiwan organization in the United States said that it's president, Wu Ming-chi, decided to send a letter to David L. Gunn, president and chief executive officer of Amtrak, in July, requesting that the corporation correct the "grave error" by revising its country listing. He requested that Taiwan be listed simply as "Taiwan," with any reference to China being dropped.

Claiming that Amtrak, as a federal-funded corporation, should adhere to U.S. State Department guidelines, Wu said in the letter that in 1996, the U.S. State department released an unclassified memorandum providing guidelines on U.S. relations with Taiwan.

"The memorandum states that, since the United States has no diplomatic relations with the ROC, U.S. officials need to refer to Taiwan simply as "Taiwan, " he also said, adding that therefore, Amtrak, a corporation created by Congress that relies on federal aid to survive, should correct its terminology in reference to Taiwan as well.
According to the FAPA, the corporation made an apology Aug. 16 for the error and said that it has corrected the error as requested by the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI OFFICIAL, BROKERAGE FIRMS SAID TO HAVE RECEIVED KICKBACKS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By S. C. Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Three Thai manpower brokerage firms and several former Thai labor officials collected kickbacks in sending Thai laborers to Taiwan, an adviser to the Thai parliament's committee on labor said Thursday.
Ikaporn Rakkhwamsuk said they will be the target of a next round of investigations.

He pointed out that initial investigations have shown that a Thai official and several former labor officials collaborated with Taiwan politicians and brokerage firms to exploit 1,700 Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) in southern Taiwan.
The matter only came to light after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers in protest against poor treatment and poor living conditions.

Ikaporn said that Thai officials involved in the matter have close exchanges with Taiwan and its brokerage firms and that they collected 80,000-130,000 Thai baht (about US$2,000-4,250) for each Thai laborer they sent to Taiwan.
He also said that the Thai manpower brokerage firms sent Thai laborers to the KRTC via a Taiwan brokerage firm, which is also considered to have connections with some government officials.
The Thai parliament's committee on labor has already put Thai laborers on the agenda, and it is set to discuss possible directions to take in the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S PLANNED U.S. VISIT: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department declined Wednesday to comment on media reports regarding former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's planned visit to the United Sates.
According to media reports, Lee is expected to visit three U.S. cities, including Los Angeles, Washington and New York, in October of this year.
A State Department official said that he cannot confirm the reports on Lee's possible visit, adding that any visits by Lee would be private in nature as he is now a regular citizen.

Meanwhile, the Washington, D.C.-based National Press Club said the same day that the club's John Zenger Room has been reserved for a meeting scheduled to be held Oct. 16 between Lee and local journalists.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO OPEN SEPT. 13

TEXT.P: The second session of the sixth Legislative Yuan is due to open Sept. 13, and whether the long-stalled arms procurement package and confirmation of the Control Yuan members will be put on the legislative agenda is still a focus of media attention.

An arms procurement bill and its budget to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States as well as the confirmation of the Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian have been stalled for two consecutive sessions due to opposition from the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature.

With the year-end elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, and village and township heads quickly approaching, the ruling and the opposition parties are also expected to unveil a series of bills related to the general public to solicit public support and enhance their chances of winning the elections.
Legislators originally planned to report for the new session Sept. 1-2, but due to Typhoon Talim, which made landfall in eastern Taiwan Thursday morning, this has been postponed to Sept. 2-5.

After the new session kicks off Sept. 13, the legislators will have a general interpellation and review the budget of the central government. During the interpellation period, the legislators will also review livelihood-related bills one day every two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AGAINST TAIWAN'S INCLUSION IN ANY NATION'S MISSILE DEFENSE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By T.L. Tseng and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Beijing opposes the inclusion of Taiwan in any nation's missile defense system and does not support those countries that want to supply such systems to the island, a ranking Chinese official for arms control affairs said Thursday.

Zhang Yan, director-general of the arms control department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, made the remarks while implicitly criticizing the United States' development of a missile defense system at a press conference held by the information office under the State Council.

Developing such missile defense systems might have an impact on international stability and relations among nations as well as regional security and the proliferation of missile technology, the official said, expressing the hope that "the countries concerned" will have "a careful attitude" in this respect.

Without giving a direct response to a question raised regarding whether China will threaten Taiwan with its nuclear weapons, Zheng said that China has promised not to use nuclear weapons to attack other countries ever since it first successfully tested an atomic bomb in 1964.
Furthermore, he said that Beijing has also promised not to use nuclear weapons against those countries and regions that do not possess such weapons.
"These promises remain unchanged and will never change in the future as they are an important policy and stance of China on the nuclear issue," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, DPRK AT APEC SUMMIT WOULD BE 'HISTORIC MOMENT': PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that if both he and North Korean leader Kim Jong Il could attend this year's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in South Korea, it would be an "historic moment."
The president made the remarks when he received a South Korean delegation at the Presidential Office to attend the 30th Taiwan-South Korean economic conference.

Chen thanked South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun for sending an envoy to Taiwan in late July to extend an invitation to him to attend the 2005 APEC summit, which will be held in South Korea's second-largest city, Busan, in November.

Although the chance of participating in the summit is slim in view of past practices, the president reaffirmed that he is very willing to attend the meeting as it is the right of the leaders of member states, and Taiwan should not be the only exception.
Due to Beijing's obstruction, the Republic of China's head of state was unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

The president said that Taiwan, Hong Kong and China became APEC members in 1991 at the same time due to the assistance of South Korea. He said he hopes that South Korea will exercise the same "political wisdom" to help him attend the APEC summit this year.
He stressed that if he and Kim Jong Il could attend the APEC summit, it would be an historic moment, and Roh Moo Hyun will leave a legacy of helping create the breakthrough.

The president noted that bilateral trade between Taiwan and South Korea has grown in recent years at a pace of 30 percent annually, reaching US$16.9 billion in 2004, with South Korea enjoying a trade surplus of US$6.3 billion, becoming the second-largest country with which Taiwan has a trade deficit. South Korea is the fifth-largest trading partner of Taiwan.

The president noted that Taiwan-South Korea relations have been improving over the years, citing as examples the close and friendly relations, the mutual waiving of visas, the resumption of air links and the establishment of a Taiwan representative office in Busan.

On civilian exchanges, people from both countries made a total of 450,000 visits in 2004, two-thirds of which were Taiwanese visiting South Korea, while the remaining third were South Koreans visiting Taiwan, up 60 percent from the previous year.

In view of the close trade exchanges, Chen expressed the hope that the long-disrupted economic ministerial-level consultations between the two countries can be resumed and that a free trade agreement between the two countries can be signed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S NATIONAL WEALTH GREW FROM 2001 TO 2003

TEXT.P: Taiwan's gross national wealth amounted to NT$114 trillion (US$3.48 trillion) in 2003, up from NT$111.05 trillion in 2002 and NT$108.35 trillion in 2001, indicating an upward trend in the accumulation of the country's priceable assets, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The DGBAS's "2003 National Wealth Report" shows that after deducting attritions, Taiwan's net national wealth stood at NT$92.8 trillion, so that the citizens of the Republic of China on average were worth NT$4.12 million, a 2.2 percent increase from 2002. The reported noted that this was the third yearly increase in a row.
It said the 2003 increase came mainly from net overseas assets that amounted to NT$1.8 trillion, of which NT$1.4 trillion was foreign exchange reserves accumulated over the past year.

In terms of family net assets, which in 2003 amounted to NT$54.4 trillion, real estate took the largest share, at 37.7 percent, followed by securities (20.7 percent) and deposits (17.2 percent) , according to the report.

If valued in market prices, the net worth of the family sector's real estate would be NT$22.2 trillion and that of securities, NT$19 trillion, and the family net assets would be worth NT$64.1 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 KILLED, 39 INJURED AS TYPHOON TALIM SWEEPS OVER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two people were killed in Typhoon Talim and 39 injured, the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center said Thursday.

The typhoon, which battered Taiwan overnight with strong winds and torrential rains, weakened after making landfall in eastern Taiwan Thursday morning, the center said, although central and southern Taiwan is bracing for more rain.
A 67-year-old man drowned in a fish pond in Tainan and a 43-year-old man drowned in a dike near his home in Miaoli. The injured were mostly hit by falling billboards or flying objects.

Taiwan Power Co. said that as of 11 a.m., more than 1.45 million households had experienced electricity disruptions due to the typhoon, and the power went out in Changhua, Taichung, Ilan, Taoyuan, Pingtung, Keelung and Hualien.
Currently, 700,000 households have had their electricity restored, Taipower officials said, adding that Taipower will have more repairmen out after the weather improves.
More than 8,600 households in Tainan County were flooded while landslides buried three households. No one was hurt because all members were evacuated earlier.
Heavy rains pounded the mountainous region of Chiayi County, and traffic along several roads was disrupted, and nearly 100 members of 30 households were evacuated to safety.
Six cities and counties sheltered 1,207 people as a "red alert warning" was issued for 426 rivers around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WILL MEET WITH JEB BUSH DURING TRANSIT STOP IN U.S.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will meet with Florida Governor Jeb Bush, President George W. Bush's younger brother, during his transit stop in Miami on his way to Central America in September, a CNA report from Washingtion, D.C. said Thursday.

The U.S. State Department is not expected to oppose a courtesy meeting between President Chen and Jeb Bush during his layover in Miami, a former State Department official was quoted as having told a Central News Agency correspondent in the U.S. capital.

Commenting on the report, a Presidential Office spokesman said the itinerary of President Chen's upcoming visit to Central America will be announced after the date for his meeting with the top leaders of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the region is scheduled.
Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Public Affairs Department of the Presidential Office, said the main purpose of President Chen's forthcoming overseas trip is to attend the ROC-Central America summit.
As to the itinerary of the president's transit stop in the U.S., Chen Wen-tsung said it will be unveiled along with that of the president's Central America trip.

According to Chen Wen-tsung, negotiations with the U.S. over the president's planned layover have proceeded smoothly without any glitches and that the two sides have reached a tacit understanding on certain details.

The upcoming fifth ROC-Central America summit will take place in Nicaragua later this month. The biennial event offers a forum for Taiwan to strengthen strategic alliances with its allies in the region and to accentuate its willingness and capability to be a competent and responsible member of the international community.

The first ROC-Central America summit was held in El Salvador in 1997, with then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui attending. In 2001, Chen traveled to El Salvador to attend the third meeting. The second and fourth summits took place in Taipei in 1999 and 2003.

The Straits Times: Tony Tan taking up positions in GIC and SPH.
New roles to help manage Singapore's reserves and its largest media company await Dr. Tony Tan, who retires from Cabinet today.
He is taking on these tasks in addition to his work at two high-level panels which will steer research and development (R&D) efforts here.
From today, Dr. Tan will hold a newly-created post of executive director at the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation (GIC) and also be its co-deputy chairman, and he also join the Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) board as an indepandent and non-executive director.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Drive R&D by Jurong: Dr. Tan.
Government will drive R&D to make sure Singapore can has the competitive ability to face the competition from China, India and region in next 15 to 20 years, just like Government developed the Jurong Industrial Estate to let Singapore industrialization before.
Dr. Tony Tan, who retires from Cabinet today, will be the deputy chairman of the Research, Innovation and Enterprise Council, or RIEC affer retired. RIEC is headed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: New Orleans Struggles to Evacuate; Mayor says he fears huge death toll; looting persists in city.
Frantic authorities escalated efforts to empty this submerged city Wednesday, with the mayor saying that as many as 100,000 people still needed to be evacuated and federal officials readying plans to transport as many as 23,000 refugees of Hurricane Katrina from the Superdome to Houston's Astrodome.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN LAUDS 'SELF-CONFIDENT' 'TAIKE'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian waded into the war of words about the meaning of the popular term "taike" again Thursday, saying the word has two meanings, one derogatory and the other showing Taiwanese self-confidence.
Literally meaning "guest of or visitor to Taiwan, " "taike" has become the focus of heated debate.

On Aug. 25, while meeting a group of overseas Taiwanese businessmen, Chen made his first public comment about the term "taike, " claiming the 23 million Taiwan people are not "guests of Taiwan" but are "masters of the country."

On Thursday, Chen said some people think it an insult if they are called "taike" while others are proud of the word. The different interpretations show that Taiwan is becoming a healthy, diversified and multicultural society.

Personally, said the president in his "Mood Notes" that appeared on his electronic newspaper, he agrees with those who define "taike" as a new generation of Taiwanese that dare to overthrow old traditions with vibrant vitality by purging the term of all of its negative connotations of the past.
"Taike" has acquired a derogatory and insulting meaning when Taiwan's own culture was persecuted and discriminated against by an "alien regime," Chen wrote in "Mood Notes."

He was referring to the Kuomintang (KMT) regime that moved to Taiwan from China in 1949, starting a long period of dictatorial rule as it insisted on its political legitimacy by, in the words of the president, "promoting Chinese cultural chauvinism."

Chen said that over the past 400 years, Taiwan had been colonized by the Dutch, Spanish, Manchurians, Japanese and the KMT regimes. If every new group of rulers could only impose its own ideology on the people of Taiwan in disregard of their indigenous culture, he said he fears that ethnic divisions in Taiwan will worsen.

Fortunately, he said, with Taiwan's political democratization, its people have rediscovered their rights to be their own masters and they can define their own arts and cultural creations, allowing the term "taike" to take on a new meaning.

Therefore, said the president, he would like to give credit to those who have dared to bring a new meaning to "taike" with courage and creativity. He called this "the first step toward making Taiwan a healthy and multicultural society."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKER MEETS PARAGUAN VICE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Legislator Liao Pen-yen of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union met with Paraguayan Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni and other political figures during his two-day visit to Paraguay.
In addition to Castiglioni, he also met Speaker of the Senate Carlos Filizzola, and Victor Bogado, president of the Chamber of Deputies, to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.

Liao also met with Taiwanese expatriates, telling them that he expressed the hope that Paraguay will facilitate residence applications and investments by Taiwanese during his meeting with Paraguayan officials.
He also vowed to work harder to promote bilateral friendships after his return to Taiwan.

Liao and his wife arrived at Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, Tuesday. Accompanied by David C. Y. Hu, ROC ambassador to the South American country, they first went to "Shopping Mariscal Lopez, " a shopping mall established under the auspices of Taiwan's technical mission.
They also visited a flower shop of the Taiwan technical center in Caacupe to learn about their assistance with growing flowers.
Liao continued his trip to Dominica Republic Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT U.S. IN EARLY OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to visit Washington, D.C. on Oct. 6, a senior researcher from the Heritage Foundation disclosed Wednesday.

Harvey J. Feldman, said that Lee will deliver a speech at the Washington, D.C.-based National Press Club during his upcoming visit and that the club's John Zenger Room has been reserved for the event.

Feldman, who served as director of the Office of Republic of China Affairs in the State Department when Washington shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, said that China is expected to lodge a protest against Lee's upcoming visit to the United States.
However, Feldman claimed that the State Department sees no reason to deter Lee from traveling to the United States as Lee is now a civilian.
A State Department official declined to confirm Lee's planned visit, saying that any visits by Lee would be private in nature as he is now a regular citizen.
Lee's October trip will also take him to Los Angeles and New York, according to Lee's close aides who are currently in the United States to flesh out details of his itinerary.

They said that a pro-Taiwan U.S. state governor, who forged a cordial friendship with Lee during Lee's 12-year presidency, is assisting in arranging Lee's planned U.S. visit, adding that Lee most looks forward to making his mark by visiting the U.S. capital.

If the travel plan is realized, it will be Lee's first trip to the United States since his retirement in May 2000. Lee, an outspoken critic of China's threat to Taiwan and an ardent advocate of Taiwan's separate identity from that of China, has had difficulties visiting countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan even after his retirement.

In addition to meeting with Taiwan expatriates, Lee is scheduled to meet with U.S. politicians, including congressional leaders, the sources said, adding that Lee may also visit his alma mater, Cornell University, during his planned U.S. visit which may last for two weeks.
Lee made a rare visit to Cornell University in 1995 which drew a strong backlash from China as Beijing leaders regarded the trip as a move to promote formal Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE NET ASSETS PER FAMILY IN TAIWAN INCREASED IN 2003

TEXT.P: Thanks to hikes in share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the average net worth of household assets in Taiwan stood at NT$7.98 million (US$243,664.6) in 2003, an increase of NT$690,000 from the 2002 level, according to a report released Thursday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Of the amount, the assets of securities increased to NT$1.6 million, up NT$420,000 from the previous year's level, the DGBAS-issued "2003 National Wealth Report" indicates.
A DGBAS official attributed the increase in the average net assets mainly to hikes in share prices in 2003, which posted growth of more than 30 percent.

According to the report, average deposits and life insurance/retirement pension reserves increased by NT$140,000 and NT$100,000, respectively, while real estate decreased NT$80,000 due to drop in the publicly announced land value.

The report also shows that the net worth of government's assets reached NT$23.8 trillion in 2003, up NT$843 billion or 3.7 percent from the previous year's level, with land taking the lion's share of NT$18.7 trillion.
Meanwhile, public debts amounted to NT$5.2 trillion, representing an increase of NT$254.7 billion in comparison with the 2002 level.
The report also points out that Taiwan's gross national wealth amounted to NT$114 trillion in 2003 and that after deducting depreciation of assets, the net national wealth reached NT$92.8 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF VISITS JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao is currently on a visit to Japan aimed at boosting bilateral cultural exchanges and cooperation.
Yao met with Tokyo film festival executives and Japanese movie producers and directors Thursday to discuss possible cooperative programs.
He also attended a luncheon with Taiwan journalists stationed in Japan. The luncheon was organized by Taiwan's representative office in Japan to celebrate Sept. 1 Journalists Day.

Yao arrived in Japan Tuesday after a visit to South Korea, where he attended a promotion of Taiwan's "new tide" films and met with ministerial-level South Korean officials in charge of movie, broadcasting and media affairs.
In the past two days, he has toured the eco-friendly World Expo in Aichi prefecture in central Japan and he was scheduled to wrap up his Japan visit and return to Taipei Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Higher Death Toll Seen; Police Ordered to Stop Looters
Chaos gripped New Orleans on Wednesday as looters ran wild, food and water supplies dwindled, bodies floated in the floodwaters, the evacuation of the Superdome began and officials said there was no choice but to abandon the city devastated by Hurricane Katrina, perhaps for months.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: National Guard in New Orleans To Try to Stop Lawlessness
National Guard troops in armored vehicles poured into New Orleans Thursday to curb the city's growing lawlessness after Hurricane Katrina.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN TO BEGIN WATER RATIONING AFTER TYPHOON

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County, and Linko in Taipei county in northern Taiwan will begin water rationing early Friday in the wake of Typhoon Talim, Taiwan Water Corp. officials said Thursday.

As expected, the water company said, the heavy rain brought by the typhoon has increased the turbidity of the water in the Shihmen reservoir, which supplies water to Taoyuan and Linko to the extent that the water purification plants cannot handle it.
Water supplies to households in these two places will be cut to every other day until the sediment and silt in the water settle, the officials said.

The problem has plagued these areas since last year and the head of the water company resigned at that time to take political responsibility. However, Taoyuan was subjected to water rationing again after Typhoon Matsa swept the island Aug. 5, and this time the water company's president as well as a vice economic minister, stepped down.
Water officials blame the excessive development of the reservoir's catchment zone and the silting up of the reservoir as the root causes that will take years to rectify.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA STRIVING TO RESCUE 3 HIJACKED TAIWAN FISHING BOATS IN SOMALIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is striving to rescue three Taiwan fishing vessels that have been held by Somalian rebels since mid-August for a ransom of US$1.5 million, a senior official said Thursday.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, the three fishing boats -- the Kaohsiung-based Chungyi No. 218 and the Hsiaoliuchiu-based Hsinlienfa No. 36 and Chengchingfeng -- have not been in contact since they entered a Somalian fishing port Aug. 16 for refueling and maintenance.
The shipowners later came to learn that the three ships had been hijacked by Somalian insurgents and appealed to the MOFA Aug. 24 for assistance, Lu said.

"The MOFA has since been trying every possible means to rescue the three boats and their crews. We have invited officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Fisheries Administration and other relevant agencies for brainstorming sessions, " Lu said, adding that the MOFA is also seeking assistance from international organizations.

The three hijacked boats have 13 Chinese crewmen, 14 Indonesians, 12 Filipinos and four Vietnamese. Lu said the MOFA has informed the representative offices in Taipei of all crewmens' home countries of the incident.
The three ships entered the Somalian port through the arrangement of their Malaysian shipping agent, Lu said, adding that the shipowners are still struggling to raise funds for the ransom.

DOC.HEADLINE: 388 TRAIN PASSENGERS PUT UP IN HOTELS AFTER BEING STRANDED BY TYPHOON

TEXT.P: A total of 388 passengers were stranded at various stations around Taiwan Wednesday night and put up in hotels by the railway company after Typhoon Talim brought rail traffic to a halt.

Trains were disrupted after a fallen tree broke a railway cable near Taichung at the height of the typhoon and 388 passengers on six different trains were stranded at Taichung, Yuanli, Miaoli, Juifang and Hoping stations.
All of them were accommodated in nearby hotels for the night at the expense of the railway company and were given ticket refunds, according to company officials.
Commuter services were resumed Thursday morning, but full service was not restored until later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC ANNUAL MEETING SLATED FOR SEPT. 4 IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 annual meeting of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) is scheduled to be held Sept. 4-6 in Taipei, with over 150 commissioners from 26 countries participating.

Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the opening ceremony of the meeting, while President Chen Shui-bian will receive the OCAC commissioners after the conference, an OCAC official said.

According to the official, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu and Public Construction Commission Chairwoman Kuo Yao-chi will be invited to deliver speeches at the conference.

Following the conference, the commissioners will tour several economic and cultural establishments, such as the Peiyi Freeway, the National Traditional Art Center and the Tungshan river development, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXTENDS SYMPATHIES TO U.S. OVER HURRICANE KATRINA DISASTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has expressed his sincere condolences and sympathy to U.S. President George W. Bush for the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Premier Frank Hsieh and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen have also offered their heartfelt sympathies and concerns to the governors of the four devastated states -- Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said.
"The messages have been conveyed to the White House and the Gulf Coast state governments through our representative office in Washington, D.C.," Lu said.
He said the government will come up with an aid list after the ROC representative office in the United States makes an overall review of the Katrina devastation.

According to Lu, no casualties involving Taiwan expatriates have so far been reported, although some Taiwan expatriates' homes have been destroyed. Lu said the MOFA has mobilized Taiwanese associations and non-government charities such as the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation's U.S. branches, to offer emergency aid to affected Taiwanese expatriates.
Lu said the government will decide on concrete relief programs after the ROC representative offices in Washington and Houston finalize overall assessments.

The U.S. government has launched the most massive relief effort in history to help people devastated by Hurricane Katrina. President Bush said earlier in the day that while thousands more victims still need to be rescued, help is on its way.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SEEKING TO WOO MORE BUSINESSMEN TO INVEST IN TAIWAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: In the face of a decline in investment by overseas Chinese and foreigners in Taiwan during the January-July period, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is seeking to attract more Taiwanese businessmen operating in foreign countries to invest here, a government official said Thursday.

According to statistics released by the MOEA's Investment Commission, overseas Chinese and foreign entrepreneurs invested a total of US$1.72 billion in Taiwan during the first seven months of this year, down 17.37 percent compared with the year-earlier level.

Ou Chia-jui, director-general of the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) , attributed the decrease mainly to a more conservative attitude adopted by foreign investors because of the global economic stagnation.

However, Ou said that a large number of China-based Taiwanese businessmen began to consider seeking other destinations for their investments after Beijing implemented a policy aimed at cooling down its overheated economy.

To inspire Taiwanese manufacturers operating in China to relocate their production facilities back to Taiwan, Ou pointed out that Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang will attend the 11th annual meeting of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce slated for Sept. 20-22 in Taipei to brief the meeting participants on various incentives for domestic and foreign investors.

According to Ou, the IDIC has analyzed various industries suitable for investment by Taiwanese manufacturers operating in Europe, the United States and Asia and has passed on these investment opportunities to overseas Taiwanese manufacturers associations for reference.

Meanwhile, the IDIC has also compiled new investment reference manuals for returning Taiwanese businessmen, Ou said. He added that the manuals contain investment information on such things as incentives, as well land and labor supplies.

Ou further said that the MOEA has formed a task force in charge of wooing foreign investors and that members of the task force will regularly meet with other government agencies and foreign investors to help them solve their investment problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE STATISTICS OFFICIAL DIES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A Chinese statistics official died in Taipei while taking a hot spring bath Thursday, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng said later that day.

Jan said his office has asked its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to relay the bad news to the family of Zhu Xiangdong, who is the deputy director of China's National Bureau of Statistics.

Jan said Zhu was here at the invitation of the Statistics Department of Fujen University in Taipei County on an academic exchange. He collapsed at a hot spring in the Yangmingshan National Park, apparently from heart failure.
He was rushed to the Taipei Municipal Yangming Hospital but could not be resuscitated, according to Jan.
The exact cause of death has yet to be determined by coroners, Jan added.
Jan said the SEF has asked ARATS to convey its condolences to Zhu's family and has promised to help them deal with the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, September 2:
08:00, Lawmakers will begin to report in for a new session at the Legislative Yuan.
09:00, The Ministry of National Defense will celebrate the Armed Forces Day at the Armed Forces Club in Taipei.
09:00, The 2005 National Youth Conference organized by the National Youth Commission will open at the Chungshan Building at Yangmingshan, Taipei.
09:30, President Chen Shui-bian will receive athletes who won medals at the World Games Duisburg 2005 and their coaches at the Presidential Office.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will honor the farmers who grew the rice that won top prize in a national contest in a ceremony at the Taipei Little Dome.
10:30, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will attend a ceremony at the Armed Forces Theater in Taipei marking Armed Forces Day.
11:00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at its Taipei office.
12:00, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will attend a luncheon held by the Ministry of National Defense to celebrate Armed Forces Day at the Armed Forces Club in Taipei.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a weekly news conference at its Taipei office.
16:00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Sept. 2, or the 29th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Thomas Telford, the Scottish engineer and canal and bridge builder, dies.
1841: Hirobumi Ito, the Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1885 to 1901, is born. He helped draft the constitution of 1889.
1861: Prussia concludes commercial treaty with the Ching court at Tientsin, China.
1905: China's Ching court abolishes the civil service examination system and promotes the establishment of public and private schools.
1906: Mahatma Gandhi preaches nonviolence in his campaign for Indian rights at a rally of Indian workers in Johannesburg, South Africa.
1914: Japanese troops land at Lungkou, in China's Shandong province.
1933: The Central Bank of France issues its first state-run lottery.
1937: Baron Pierre de Coubertin, founder of the modern Olympic Games, dies in Switzerland at the age of 74.
1945: Japan formally surrenders to the Allies, ending World War II. The surrender is signed aboard the aircraft carrier USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay, with General Hsu Yung-chang signing for China.
1945: Ho Chi Minh proclaims the independent Democratic Republic of Vietnam in Hanoi, with himself as its president.
1947: The Treaty of Rio de Janeiro, an agreement on mutual assistance, is signed by 19 Central and South American states.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks 11 mainland Chinese warships at Liaolo Bay, Kinmen Island.
1962: The Soviet Union agrees to send arms to Cuba to help it meet threats from "aggressive imperialist elements."
1974: Dr. Y.T. Wang, secretary-general of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, and Dr. T.H. Shen, JCRR consultant, leave for England to attend the Second International Seminar on Change in Agriculture.
1976: The Kuomintang announces the appointment of Liang Yung-chang as deputy secretary general of the party's Central Committee and Wang Wei-nung as acting chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Headquarters.
1980: South Korean President Chun Doo-hwan forms a civilian Cabinet.
1986: Four people are buried in a landslide on Wanshou Mountain in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.
1992: US President George Bush decides to sell 150 F-16A and F-16B jet fighters to the ROC.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Guatemalan President Jorge Antonio Serrano sign a joint communique in Taipei calling for closer bilateral cooperation.
1992: Canadian International Trade Minister Michael Wilson visits Taipei to boost ROC-Canada trade ties. He is the first ministerial-level official to visit the ROC since bilateral ties were severed in 1970.
1992: The ROC Bureau of Entry and Exit announces that members of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in mainland China may apply to visit Taiwan for cultural and academic exchanges.
1993: The Vatican accepts a mainland Chinese invitation for a high level visit to Beijing, the first such meeting since the 1949 communist takeover of the mainland.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan passes an administrative reform package to eradicate corruption and inefficiency in the government.
1996: The Philippines government and Muslim rebels sign a peace pact ending 24 years of war that killed some 125,000 people.
1998: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia fires his deputy Anwar Ibrahim following divisions over economic policy and Malaysia's political future.
1999: Taiwan Province and the US State of Connecticut forge a sisterhood agreement, bringing to 40 the number of sisterhood ties maintained by Taiwan.
2001: Opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao says the government should revamp its budget bill for fiscal 2002 to substantiate conclusions reached at the recent Economic Development Advisory Conference.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is intelligence, there is power. Where there is power, there is influence. Where there is influence, there is creative power. It is only he who possesses absolute truth in the world who can create."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: New Orleans Death Toll May Soar; Survivors Desperate; Looters Brazen.
New Orleans' police and emergency officials worked desperately to prevent complete social disintegration as widespread looting continued for a second day and cresting floodwaters hid untold numbers of dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: SC declares EVAT constitutional
The Supreme Court, by a majority vote, declared constitutional yesterday the Expanded Value-Added Tax (EVAT) Act of 2005 that would increase by at least 10 percent prices of goods and services in the country.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: High court upholds VAT
THE SUPREME Court ruled yesterday that the expanded value-added tax law, the centerpiece of the government's fiscal reform program, was constitutional "in its entirety."
The Philippine Star: SC rules EVAT constitutional
The Supreme Court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the expanded value-added tax (EVAT) law, described as the cornerstone of the government's efforts to escape a looming fiscal crisis.
The Manila Times: SC rules EVAT law legal
THE Supreme Court on Thursday upheld the constitutionality of the expanded value-added tax (EVAT) law, President Arroyo's centerpiece tax reform aimed at shrinking the chronic budget deficit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB CLOSELY MONITORING NEW TYPHOON

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is closely monitoring a new tropical storm in the Pacific Ocean that has gained strength to become a strong typhoon in the last 24 hours.

Typhoon Nabi, the 14th typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, was located more than 1,000 kilometers away from Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi as of 10 a.m. Friday, CWB meteorologists said, adding that Sunday will be the crucial time for determining whether the typhoon will affect the island.

Meanwhile, the weather bureau forecast afternoon thundershowers for Taiwan's western coastal areas and sporadic showers for eastern Taiwan, Penghu Island, and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu for Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: New Orleans to be abandoned for two or three months: mayor
With thousands feared drowned in what could be America's deadliest national disaster in a century, New Orleans' leaders all but surrendered the streets to floodwaters and began turning out the lights on the ruined city-perhaps for months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH URGED TO REITERATE SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN AT MEETING WITH HU
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By C.L. Chi, Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A member of the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday called for President George W. Bush to reiterate during his upcoming meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao Washington's firm stance in support of democratic Taiwan.
Rep. Thomas G. Tancredo (R-Colo.) made the appeal in a letter sent to the president ahead of the scheduled meeting between Bush and Hu in Washington, D.C. Sept. 7.

As Beijing has unilaterally escalated tensions in the Taiwan Strait by threatening for no reason to use force against Taiwan and even the United States, Tancredo also urged the president in the letter to clearly express U.S. concerns about China's conduct during his meeting with Hu.

Furthermore, Tancredo also suggested that Bush remind the Chinese president that the decision by the United States to establish diplomatic relations with China in 1979 was based on a commitment by Beijing to resolve the Taiwan issue peacefully, adding that the passage of an anti-session law by the Chinese National People's Congress in March this year goes against this commitment.

According to the representative, the Chinese government has a responsibility to engage in dialogue with the duly-elected government in Taiwan and should resolve cross-strait differences peacefully and without any preconditions.

It is important for the United States to maintain friendly relations with China, he continued, stressing, however, that Washington should also tell Beijing bluntly that such relations cannot be maintained at the cost of Taiwan's democracy.
The congressman had raised a motion in February of this year and June of last year in the House to request that the U.S. government resume diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: A City of Despair and Lawlessness;Thousands Stranded in New Orleans; Troops Pour In.
Federal and local authorities struggled Thursday to regain control of this ruined and lawless city, where tens of thousands of desperate refugees remained stranded with little hope of rescue and rapidly diminishing supplies of food and drinking water.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Nathan sworn in for 2nd term.
Mr. S R Nathan was sworn in for a second term as President last night, even as the Government affirmed its commitment to continue making the presidency work better.
The functions and powers of the 14-year-old institution have become more accepted by Singaporeans and established in the system of government, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The system of Elected Presidency will be better and better.
The functions and procedures of Singapore's Elected Presidency needs times to improve.
Both of the President S R Nathan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong sworn last night that they will keep to improve the system of Elected Presidency and let the system be more effective.
In his speech, PM Lee said it will take time to fully appreciate how the Elected Presidency mechanism works in practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE OFFICIAL DIES IN HOT SPRING BATH ON YANGMINGSHAN

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese official died of heart failure during a hot spring bath on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei Thursday, the Shihlin District Prosecutors' Office confirmed Friday.

The body of Zhu Xiangdong, a deputy director of Beijing's National Bureau of Statistics, who was visiting Taiwan on an academic exchange program at the invitation of the Central Weather Bureau, was found Thursday afternoon.
Although the autopsy has not been completed, Prosecutor Wang Jen-kuei said Zhu's death looks to be an accident as there are no signs of foul play.

Zhu, visiting Taiwan in his capacity as an adviser to the National Statistical Society of China, went to visit with four other colleagues a meteorological station run by the Central Weather Bureau in Zhuzihu, Yangmingshan in Taipei City's northern suburb Thursday.
After visiting the center, Zhu and his group visited Yangmingshan's famous hot spring, checking into separate hot spring baths at the center's guest house Thursday afternoon.

According to Zhu's companions, they entered his bath after an hour and found him passed out in the hot spring tub. All the windows were closed, which is against the safety regulations, according to prosecutors.
Authorities from Taipei City Hospital, Yangming Branch said Friday that Zhu showed no signs of life when he was rushed to the hospital around 4:30 p.m. Thursday.

Officials from the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation said they have already notified Zhu's family in Beijing and have contacted the Mainland Affairs Council and the Bureau of Immigration for assistance to facilitate the family members' visit to Taiwan.
Zhu, 50, is the highest-ranking mainland Chinese official to pass away in Taiwan since the two rival sides began private exchanges more than a decade ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: ECB: No evidence of wrong doing by Bank of Italy governor.
European Central Bank (ECB) President Jean-Claude Trichet said Thursday in Frankfurt, Germany that there is no evidence that Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio violated any ethical rules in cross-country banking takeover battles. The ECB is not probing his conduct, but will look into his role in the controversial takeover bids for Banca Antonveneta and Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Trichet added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PREPARING FOR NUCLEAR WAR WITH U.S. OVER TAIWAN: DISSIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 1 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A Chinese dissident has warned that China is preparing for nuclear war with the United States over Taiwan and that a split in the Beijing leadership might lead to a conflict in the near future, according to a report carried by the Washington Times Thursday.

In an interview with the newspaper, Wei Jinsheng, a longstanding advocate of political reform in China, who now lives in the United States, also said that President George W. Bush and other U.S. leaders "do not fully understand the chance of a conflict breaking out," urging that they "must do more to avert it. "
He also told the newspaper that he has heard from Chinese officials, including those in the military, that they are concerned about the growing possibility of a nuclear war.
"Recent Chinese militry exercises and a Chinese general's threat to use missiles against U.S. cities are two signs of the danger," the dissident further said,

Pointing out that China may have considered in the past that it was not time for them to confront the United States, Wei said that the Chinese now feel that they need to use these kinds of nuclear threats. "China is very serious about that. The nuclear threat from China is a substantial threat, not theoretical," he added.

Wei also said that the leadership in Beijing has divided into two factions headed separately by incumbent Chinese President Hu Jintao and former President Jiang Zemin, adding that there are elements within the military who think that a war to retake Taiwan should begin as soon as possible.

"Politically, differences between Hu and Vice President Zeng Qinghong, who in the past was a Jiang loyalist, appear to have been resolve temporarily, " Wei said, adding that "the accommodation appears related to a decision to use force in the future against Taiwan. "

"Hu favors a conflict as a way to consolidate power over the military. Growing nationalist sentiment in China also has led to public calls for war over Taiwan, " he also told the newspaper, warning that "many wars in the past have started from such conditions."

Wei told the newspaper that in order to avert war, the Bush administration should put more pressure on Beijing in the area of human rights and trade as well as try to influence the Chinese military by finding and supporting anti-war military leaders and drive a wedge between China and the communist government in North Korea.
"The goal should be to reduce the voice of the people who want to go to war," the paper quoted Wei as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: INGRATIATING CULTURE 'NON-EXISTENT' IN ROC ARMY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed to the public Friday that there is no "individual heroism" or "ingratiating culture" in the armed forces of the Republic of China.

All members of the armed forces share the conviction of loyalty to the country and the people, Chen said while addressing a ceremony in which outstanding soldiers were cited on the eve of Armed Forces Day.

The statement was an indirect response to media criticism about the so-called "sycophant soldiers" at an air force base who reportedly canceled leave to practice songs and dances to welcome the president to their base. Chen later canceled a scheduled visit to the base.
Media discussion about military culture in recent days has "deviated from the proper understanding of the sacred mission of the armed forces," Chen said.

In a prepared speech to be broadcast this evening, Chen reminded the public that they should treasure what they have, which he said has been made possible partly by the armed forces, who have dedicated their time and energy to protecting the land.

He mentioned the importance of upgrading the nation's defensive weapons and the importance of unity in the armed forces and the civilian population. If the nation's military technology cannot be upgraded and if soldiers and civilians cannot unite together, no one can avoid the impact of a possible invasion by the Communist Chinese, he said.

He said he was proud that the military has been successfully "nationalized." But he urged the armed forces not to feel complacent about their achievements. Instead, they should never stop their efforts to seek a "quality" edge over the enemy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LAWMAKERS TO REVIEW ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged legislators across the party spectrum Friday to review the long-stalled arms procurement bill to demonstrate to the world Taiwan's resolve to defend itself.
Chen made the remarks when he spoke at an Armed Forces Day award presentation ceremony in Taipei.

In a goodwill gesture to the opposition parties, the president also said that the government has made pragmatic adjustments to the outlay of three items of the arms procurement package, referring to the listing of one of them in the regular budget instead of the originally proposed special budget.

The arms procurement bill and its budget to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States have been blocked for two consecutive legislative sessions due to opposition from the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature.

The president stressed that faced with 700 missiles aimed by China at Taiwan, the crisis of the military imbalance in the Taiwan Strait, which has tipped toward China, should not be ignored, nor should hopes for goodwill from the enemy or outside assistance be entertained.
He said that fate of the nation lies in itself and that the nation has to build up a credible defense capability to deter and avoid war.

He noted that the United States, Japan and the other Asia-Pacific nations have recently expressed concern about China's military expansion, adding that several advanced weapon systems were used in a recent joint China-Russia military exercise that had Taiwan as its target and was also aimed at flexing its military strength to the United States and Japan.

Chen said the military exercise validated misgivings harbored by the international community on China's military expansion, increased missile deployment and a strengthened missile projectile capability. It also added variables on the developments in the Taiwan Strait situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SENDS GREETINGS TO HANDICAPPED PAINTER OVER BIRTH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sent his congratulations Friday to Yang En-dian, a physically challenged artist who paints with her mouth and feet, over the recent birth of her baby girl.

Chen was represented by Cho Chun-ying, a deputy director-general of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs, who visited Yang at Mingsheng General Hospital in the southern port city of Kaohsiung. Cho presented Yang with a specially designed baby carrier and a "red envelope" containing money as a gift from the president.
The baby carrier is designed so that Yang can bottle-feed her baby with her feet.

Yang, 31, who was born without arms and was abandoned by her parents, gave birth to a healthy baby girl Monday. Yang and her husband, who is not physically challenged, named the infant "Chenteh" (Joan of Arc, the Saint) , hoping that the child will grow up to become a brave woman like the French heroine.

In March 1974, Yang was deserted outside a marketplace in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County. The infant was brought to the Liukuei Christian Orphanage located in the mountains of Kaohsiung County, where under the intensive care of orphanage founder Father Yang and his wife, the infant survived.

Believing that the baby was "sent by the Lord, " Yang named the baby Yang En-dian, meaning "grace and benevolence from God." Little did he know that the baby would grow up to develop a friendship with then-President Chiang Ching-kuo that turned into another legend.

Chiang developed a special attachment to the child and arranged for her to receive surgery in Taipei to help straighten her spine and allow her to stand unaided. He even arranged for her to learn Chinese brush painting and calligraphy.
The child became a celebrity after a picture of her and President Chiang was made into a postage stamp.
Yang did not let the president down and grew up to earn her own living by selling her works.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TRYING TO FORCE TAIWAN TO GIVE UP SOVEREIGNTY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: China's so-called "united front" strategy, with which China has been threatening Taiwan militarily while trying to divide Taiwan society, is aimed at forcing Taiwan to give up its sovereignty, President Chen Shui-bian claimed Friday.

Speaking at a ceremony in which outstanding soldiers were cited, the president urged the men and women in uniform, as well as the general public, to beware of military and psychological threats from across the Taiwan Strait.

He said China's enactment of its anti-secession law in March, which expressly calls for "non-peaceful means" to solve cross-strait disputes should Taiwan move toward independence, and a Chinese general's threat to use nuclear arms, are clear indications of China's attempts to use force to achieve its ultimate goal of unifying Taiwan and China.

On the other hand, the president pointed out that in order to give an impression internationally that it is a peace-loving country, China has spared no efforts to lure Taiwan's opposition politicians and civic groups.

For example, China has allowed duty-free imports of Taiwan fruit and offered a pair of pandas as gifts to the people of Taiwan. "These are aimed at misleading the world and demoralizing Taiwan, " he claimed.
In the face of China's maneuvering, the president called on the military and the public to realize China's militaristic nature, which aims to force Taiwan to abandon its sovereignty and dignity.
He said the government will counter China's strategy by vigorously maintaining the nation's liberal democracy as well as its sovereignty and dignity.
The government will work hard to ensure the maximum long-term interest of the people under a framework of peace, democracy and equality, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 82.58 points to close at 6,116.05.
The bourse opened at 6,081.71 and fluctuated between 6,116.05 and 6,075.35 during trading. A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.33 billion (US$2.22 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.2 percent, construction issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 1.4 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 773 to 168, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE COMES FROM STRENGTH: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: "Peace comes from strength, while war can only be prevented with preparation, " President Chen Shui-bian said Friday in a speech to model military personnel.

Chen noted that it is not only the military but all citizens who are obliged to safeguard the country. Facing an increasing military threat from China, the will of the country's 23 million people to fight is the key to preventing war, he said.

The president made the remarks at a luncheon held to cite model military personnel on the eve of Armed Forces Day. He also praised the officers and soldiers for their dedication to protecting the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE OIL PRICE HIKE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called a temporary halt to the notion of hikes in domestic oil prices Friday, saying that the country should "give it a few more days" to observe the situation before implementing a price rise.

Hsieh said that any gasoline price adjustments should take all factors into consideration, including current oil stocks, the overall domestic economic situation, the market mechanism and the interests of the underprivileged.

The premier made the remarks in reply to questions from reporters about whether the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will increase gasoline prices in the face of a recent spike in international crude oil prices that topped US$70 a barrel a couple of days ago and after CPC's only rival -- Formosa Petroleum -- announced a hike of NT$2.4 per liter two days ago, although that 10-percent hike was withdrawn several hours later.
Hsieh added that as free market forces largely determine prices, the most the government can do is to monitor the situation closely.

Meanwhile, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Friday that although world crude oil prices have been volatile and the U.S. government's offering of loaning some of its strategic stockpiled crude is not seen to address an immediate shortage of gasoline in the wake of Hurricane Katrina's rampage in oil-producing southern U.S. states, whether the domestic fuel prices should be raised is an issue to be decided by experts.
Ho would not speculate as to when or how domestic oil prices should be hiked, saying only that "at least the CPC is not hiking the gasoline prices today."
CPC incurred heavy losses in August when world crude oil prices soared by 60 percent, she said.

According to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) , the impact of rising oil prices on economic growth is not as great as during the second oil crisis of the 1970s, as the ratio of crude oil consumption to gross domestic product (GDP) has dropped by 25.3 percent since that time.
In the United States and Japan, the ratio has dropped by an even larger margin -- 36.5 percent and 37.2 percent, respectively, according to the DGBAS.
Liang Chi-yuan, a research fellow with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research body, estimated that a 10-percent hike in oil prices will cause a dent of 0.27 percent in Taiwan's GDP growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.222 to close at NT$32.529.
A total of US$1.07 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.650 and hit a low of NT$32.520.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 69 points to close at 6,119, with 20,860 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 61 points to end at 6,111, with 262 contracts traded, while December futures gained 40 points to finish at 6,090, with 25 contracts traded. March futures moved up 68 points to close at 6,110, with five contracts traded, while June futures moved up 63 points to close at 6,100, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,050 for September, 6,050 for October, 6,050 for December, 6,042 for March and 6,037 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
September TE futures moved up 3.1 points to close at 251, with 3,355 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 3.1 points to finish at 251, with 32 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures gained 7.2 points to finish at 940, with 1,609 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up eight points to end at 937.4, with 192 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 10 points to close at 941.8, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL RYLA IN TAIWAN TO KICK OFF SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The international Rotary Youth Leadership Awards (RYLA) in Taiwan will kick off Saturday, with 250 youngsters from more than 20 countries participating in the seven-day camp.

Brain Lai, adviser to the International RYLA in Taiwan, which was sponsored by Rotary International District (RID) 3520, said the primary goal of sponsoring the event is "Taiwan walks out and the world flies in, " hoping that the youth from around the world will learn more about Taiwan.

They will also discover the beauty of Taiwan from the perspectives of art, culture, technology and diplomacy, while the domestic participants can immerse themselves in the international environment, enhance global understanding and broaden their horizons.
The RYLA originated in Australia in 1959. It is a training program for youths aged 20-30 aimed at emphasizing leadership, citizenship and personal growth.

The participants have come from the United States, Canada, Germany, Sweden, Poland, Estonia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, India, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Mongolia, Hong Kong, Bolivia, Nigeria, South Africa and Taiwan.

The camp will be held in both Taipei and Hualien and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will deliver a speech on "building a world-class capital -- the Taipei experience." Mark Daniel Maloney, trustee of the Rotary Foundation, will also deliver a speech and Michel Lu, director-general of the Department of Information and Cultural Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will share his experience in diplomatic work.

Moreover, 2004 Sweden Daily Hero Award winner Maria Thornberg will share her experience in social service with the participants. Thornberg gave up a well-paid job in her early 20s to devote herself to taking care of homeless people, drug addicts and AIDS victims.

Steven Hu, a 20-year-old man suffering from cerebral palsy who will enter the Department of Social Work at National Taiwan University this year, will present a speech on behalf of all participants at the opening ceremony.

Other activities will include visits to the National Palace Museum, the Hsiao His Yuan Puppet Theater, and Acer -- one of the top IT companies in the world -- as well as the Taroko National Park and the Kuang-long Museum.
