TEXT.P: THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Local Officials Criticize Federal Government Over Response

Despair, privation and violent lawlessness grew so extreme in New Orleans on Thursday that the flooded city's mayor issued a "desperate S O S" and other local officials lambasted the federal government as responding too slowly to the disaster.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
Amid Chaos, Louisiana Calls for Help

In New Orleans, Thousands Still Wait for Rescue,the governor of Louisiana called for a military force of 40,000 troops to help the effort. Federal officials vowed to do whatever it took to relieve the crisis, but help was coming slowly and sometimes not at all.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$2 MILLION TO U.S. FOR HURRICANE RELIEF

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen donated US$2 million on behalf of the government to the United States Friday for the relief of victims of Hurricane Katrina in the southern U.S. states.
The minister also expressed the government's sympathies to families of those who were killed in the hurricane.

Chen said the states of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida -- all devastated by Katrina -- are closely associated with Taiwan. The state congresses of Louisiana and Mississippi have resolved to support Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group has petrochemical and plastics factories in Louisiana, which further show the country's close ties with the state, according to Chen.
The minister said his office had kept a close eye on the movement of Katrina ever since a warning was issued against it, and had helped Taiwan expatriates in the four states to evacuate to safety.
Chen said President Chen Shui-bian has conveyed his condolences to U.S. President George Bush, while the Foreign Ministry has expressed its sympathies to the governors of the four U.S. states.

DOC.HEADLINE: TARIFFS ON IMPORTED VEGETABLES CUT TO RESTRAIN RISING PRICES

TEXT.P: Ten kinds of imported vegetables were given a 50 percent-tariff cut Friday in an effort to restrain skyrocketing vegetable prices after Typhoon Talim rampaged through Taiwan Thursday.

The imports include scallions, cabbages, broccoli, cauliflowers, lettuce, other leafy green vegetables, cucumbers, tomatoes, sweet peppers and sweetcorn, officials of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said, adding that the tariff cut will remain in place until Sept. 22.

The vegetable shipment to the Taipei wholesale market dropped to 503 tons Friday, a new post-typhoon low. Consequently, the wholesale prices of vegetables surged to a historic high of NT$43.2 (US$1.3) per kilogram, according to statistics from the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co.
By cutting the tariff on the imported vegetables from 20 percent to 10 percent, the COA hopes there will be enough imports to allow reasonable prices to be maintained, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GROPER FARMERS SAY FISH ARE SAFE AFTER HK SUSPENDS SALES

TEXT.P: Fish farmers who raise gropers in Yungan town in Kaohsiung County said Friday that health officials regularly monitor their fish and claimed that their gropers are safe, in spite of Hong Kong officials having found a carcinogen in a sample exported from Taiwan.

The farmers, who raise 8,000 tons of the fish each year in 350 hectares of ponds, made the claim after hearing that Hong Kong had found malachite green, a carcinogen, in a sample from a spotted black groper imported from Taiwan.

Hong Kong's fishery businesses have suspended the sale of this kind of fish. However, a Taiwan official based in Hong Kong has questioned the method used by Hong Kong authorities to come to level such a "serious accusation."

The official demanded that Hong Kong's health authorities offer more details about the report, which was widely carried by the media and could cause much damage not only to Taiwan's fish farmers but also to Taiwan's international image.

A Hong Kong official in charge of food safety said he has asked Taiwan authorities to provide data concerning Taiwan's fish exports to Hong Kong and if necessary, he will send experts to Taiwan to see how Taiwan farmers raise their fish.

Malachite green is a triphenylmethane basic dye that is also used in medicine as an antiseptic. Su You-chia, a Yungan fish farmer, said six or seven years ago some local farmers did use malachite to keep their fish from contracting "white spot disease."
Because malachite is a potent compound, it was banned by the county government, Su said. He added that officials inspect local fish farms every Monday, Wednesday and Friday.

The officials did not just try to prevent fish farmers from using malachite, but also helped them use a legal compound called copper acetate to replace malachite. Residue of copper acetate remains in the fish for only three days.

Su's statements were confirmed by health official Ko Shang-yu, who said Taiwan's fish exporters learned a lesson last year when some of their products were returned after European Union officials found residue of antibiotics in fish from Taiwan.
Ko said Taiwan exporters have since asked professionals to check their fish exports before shipping them abroad.

Su urged the government to help find out which farm in Taiwan has exported the alleged unsafe gropers to Hong Kong and publish all information in this regard so that the interests of other fish farmers will not be affected.
In Taipei, the Council of Agriculture said it has requested Hong Kong to provide data to facilitate investigation by Taiwan officials.
Hsieh Wen-ta, the director of the Fisheries Administration of the agriculture council, urged Taiwan fish farmers not to break the law as the government has long banned the use of malachite.

The agriculture council is calling a meeting of fish farmers in Pingtung, near Kaohsiung, Saturday to discuss the issue. If anyone is found to have used the banned drug, that person will be charged, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TELLS FARMERS TO MAINTAIN EDGE THROUGH IMPROVEMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said on Friday that Taiwan's agricultural sector has to keep improving to maintain its competitiveness in the face of increasing challenges from the world and China.

Hsieh said Taiwan farmers are faced with two threats; first, greater challenges since Taiwan was required to open its markets further as a member of the WTO; and second, many Chinese copycats are taking advantage of agricultural results or stealing skills developed by Taiwanese farmers since Taiwan began exporting agricultural products to China.
He claimed that many fruits grown in several Chinese provinces, such as Guizhou and Yunnan, originated from Taiwan.
Hsieh made the remarks in his address to the opening of the award presentation ceremony for the 2005 best-in-quality rice produced by local farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES PUT AT NT$569 MILLION DUE TO TYPHOON TALIM

TEXT.P: Typhoon Talim, which tore through Taiwan Thursday, brought agricultural losses of NT$569.61 million (US$17.52 million) according to initial estimates, the Council of Agriculture said Friday.
Council officials said crop losses were put at NT$529.75 million, with 10,920 hectares affected. Damages to bananas, pears and lungans bore the brunt.

Poultry losses were estimated at NT$12.26 million, and 52 hogs, 98,000 chickens, and 51,000 ducks died. Fishery losses were put at NT$270,000, farmland and agricultural facility losses were put at NT$17.19 million, poultry facility losses at NT$9.94 million, and fishermen's facility losses at NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DENIES FRIGATE LOST TOUCH WITH CHEN ON TUNGSHA VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense brushed aside media reports Friday that suggested that a frigate in charge of escorting President Chen Shui-bian when he visited the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands in late July had lost contact with the president's minders for three minutes.

Real Admiral Fan Pao-hu made the remarks in response to media reports that when President Chen flew to Tungsha to declare sovereignty over the islands, a satellite communication system on an ROC Navy "Kangting" (Lafayette-class) frigate that was on an escort mission went down, leaving the president unsupervised for three minutes.
Fan said that the ROC Navy has various communication channels and even though one channel did go down, there was no "losing touch" with the president.
He said that weather and other special factors can sometimes affect communications, but that the frigate was always in contact with the president's minders throughout his trip.

Defense ministry officials said that the problem could have been triggered by the frigate changing position at high speed and that no human negligence was involved. For this reason, the defense ministry is not considering any disciplinary action.

The Pratas Islands comprise Tungsha Island and two coral reefs, North Vereker Bank and South Vereker Bank. The archipelago is located in a strategically important position along the major sea route connecting the Pacific and Indian oceans.
The group is 140 nautical miles south of Swatow in Guangdong province, 400 nautical miles northwest of Manila, 170 miles southeast of Hong Kong, and 240 nautical miles southwest of Kaohsiung.

Tungsha Island is a coral atoll with a land area of 2.4 sq. km. Shaped like a horseshoe, it extends 0.9 km from east to west, and 2.7 km from north to south. On June 30, 1989, the Republic of China government set up a national monument on Tungsha Island to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago.

The areas around Tungsha provide excellent fishing grounds, and ROC fishermen visit the region during March and April. In addition to being a source of salt, fish, and minerals, the islands are an outpost for the ROC Navy in the South China Sea. A hospital, power station, satellite tracking station, and runway have been built there.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES CHINA'S PERMISSION FOR OVERFLIGHTS BY TAIWAN CARRIERS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday it welcomes China's approval of the applications by four Taiwan carriers to fly over its airspace.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the remarks after the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) announced earlier in the day that Taiwan's China Airlines, EVA Airways, UNI Airways and Mandarin Airlines will be granted overflight rights from Sept. 5.

"We welcome the CAAC's announcement and hope that this kind of goodwill interaction can be extended into bilateral negotiations for opening direct charter cargo and passenger flights so that these services can become a reality as early as possible," You said.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications unveiled procedural rules for local carriers to apply for China overflights Aug. 15. Shortly afterwards, the ministry allowed the four carriers to file applications with Chinese civil aviation authorities for flying over China's airspace.
China overflights will involve 15 cargo and passenger flight routes to be operated by the four carriers, mainly those to Europe and Southeast Asia, You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUT ASIDE POLITICAL DIFFERENCES TO PROTECT TAIWAN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the nation's ruling and opposition parties Friday to face the reality of the growing military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait, reminding them that "time is not on the side of Taiwan."

On the eve of Armed Forces Day, Chen appealed to the political parties to "rationally and pragmatically" deal with a government request to pass a special budget bill for buying key weapons to boost the nation's defense capabilities.

"While our efforts to defend ourselves are impeded by domestic politics, China is continuing to modernize its armed forces," he said in a TV speech, referring to ruling-opposition fighting on almost every front that has kept the budget bill to buy three military items from being put on the legislative agenda.

Now that the government has shown its utmost flexibility to move the budget for buying Patriot III anti-missile batteries to the regular budget, and the main opposition Kuomintang has sworn in a new chairman, Chen said it is time for all opponents to give up their selfish political calculations and work together to usher in a new era of Taiwan politics.

If a conflict erupts in the Taiwan Strait, not only must Taiwan worry about a growing military imbalance with China, it must also worry about the possibility of international intervention coming too late, the president said.

Some analysts have pointed out that the U.S. is eager to help Taiwan acquire anti-missile and anti-submarine weapons and submarines so that the island will be able to resist China's first strike long enough for the U.S. and its allies to rush to Taiwan's rescue.

Chen said, as Taiwan's top leader, he cannot think about Taiwan's overall security from his personal or partisan perspective, so how to cope with China's military threat is an issue that should not be "over- politicized."

The president also talked about the need to implement an "all-citizens defense program" to counter China's "asymmetrical warfare" strategy. The national defense program will integrate Taiwan into a global defense system, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL COMMERCIAL AIRPLANES ALLOWED TO FLY OVER CHINA FROM SEPT. 5

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) has been permitted by both authorities of the two sides across the Taiwan Strait to operate flight routes over China from Sept. 5, CAL announced Friday.

The first CAL flight to fly over China will be the CI245 cargo flight from Taipei to Vienna, Austria, via Abu Dhabi, the United Arab Emirates, CAL officials said, noting that the flight is scheduled to take off at 00: 01 a.m. Sept. 5, and will fly over Hong Kong, China, Myanmar, Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, Iran and Amman before landing in the United Arab Emirates.
They added that the first passenger flight to fly over China will be CI683 between Taipei and Hanoi, Vietnam.

There will be 52 passenger and cargo flights using the routes over China, including the passenger flights from Taipei to Thailand's Chiang Mai, Hanoi, India's New Delhi, and Vienna, and the cargo flights from Taipei to Europe via Abu Dhabi and New Delhi, as well as cargo flights from Luxembourg to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SCHOOL IN SHANGHAI FOR TAIWANESE FLUNKS ACCREDITATION: MAC

TEXT.P: An official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) confirmed a newspaper report Friday that the Ministry of Education has refused to accredit an elementary school in Shanghai for children of Taiwanese working there.

MAC spokesman You Ying-lung said the Shanghai Taiwanese Compatriots School failed to meet the education ministry's requirements for accreditation -- the principal was too old at 65, its founder applied for accreditation with outdated documents, it failed to present a detailed description of its teaching programs, and it didn't hire enough Taiwanese teachers.
Using the term "Taiwanese compatriots" also falls outside the government's regulations.
The China Times newspaper said "Taiwanese compatriots" was coined by China and is considered derogatory by Taiwan authorities, who prefer the term "Taiwan businessmen."

The paper quoted Liu Liao-ping, the assistant principal of the school, as saying in Shanghai the previous day that the school's founder was trying to convince Taiwan authorities that its name carries no political overtones and he is also asking for Chinese permission to replace the word "compatriots" with "businessmen."
The school, which opened Thursday, has already attracted 120 pupils from Taiwanese families in Shanghai, according to the China Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREWMEN ABOARD THREE HIJACKED TAIWAN FISHING BOATS ARE SAFE

TEXT.P: All crew members aboard the three Taiwan fishing vessels that are being held by a Somalian rebel militia for a ransom of US$1.5 million are safe as of Friday, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the government has given top priority to rescuing the crewmen that include three Taiwanese skippers as well as sailors and fishery workers from China, Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines.
According to Lu, the nation's diplomatic staff stationed in Africa are trying to make contact with Somalian rebel militia leaders by seeking the assistance of major international organizations.
Lu said officials from MOFA, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Fisheries Administration are working together to find out more about the situation and flesh out a rescue plan.
The shipowners are also struggling to raise the ransom, Lu said.

The three fishing boats -- the Kaohsiung-based "Chungyi No. 218" and the Hsiaoliuchiu-based "Hsinlienfa No. 36" and the "Chengchingfeng" -- have not been in contact since they entered a Somalian fishing port Aug. 16 for refueling and maintenance.

The shipowners later came to learn that the three ships had been hijacked by Somalian insurgents and appealed to MOFA Aug. 24 for assistance, Lu said, adding that the three ships entered the Somalian port through the arrangement of their Malaysian shipping agent.

There are about 20 crewmen aboard each of the 95-ton ships, Lu said, adding that altogether, there are 13 Chinese crewmen, 14 Indonesians, 12 Filipinos and four Vietnamese. The only Taiwanese are skippers and several senior officers.

Somalia was plunged into anarchy after strongman Mohamed Siad Barre was ousted in 1991 and the East African country has disintegrated into a patchwork of fiefdoms run by unruly warlords and clan militia chiefs.

Officials from the Fisheries Administration said the agency has posted warnings for fishing regions that are similar to the travel advisories issued by MOFA, advising fishermen where it is dangerous to fish. Somalia, which borders the Indian Ocean, has long been listed as a dangerous fishing area, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONDEMNED FOR REFUSING TO HOST GROUP OF ASIAN CITIES MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Beijing reneged Friday on its designation to host the upcoming meeting of an organization of Asian capital cites, and the group's founder is upset with the break in international protocol.

Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who is the founder of the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC), told a news conference that Beijing's decision flies in the face of all international rules, and he will consult other ANMC members, including Taipei, about which cities should replace Beijing to host to this year's autumn meeting.

The disputes stems from an ANMC decision in its 2004 meeting in Jakarta which gave hosting the 2005 meeting to Beijing and Taipei the hosting for the 2006 meeting after both of them contended for the chance to host the 2005 meeting but neither could get the support of two-thirds of the member cities as required by the group's charter.
The Beijing delegation, which won seven votes against four for Taipei, disagreed with the compromise and refused to sign a comunique to that effect at the time.
Beijing caught the ANMC off guard by declaring its withdrawal in an Aug. 30 note and left the organization in chaos about which city should host this year's meeting.
The ANMC has 12 members: Beijing, Tokyo, Taipei, Seoul, Manila, Bangkok, Hanoi, Yangon, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta and Delhi.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR CHIEF TENDERS RESIGNATION OVER RIOT BY THAI LABORERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh confirmed a media report Friday that the nation's top labor administrator has tendered her resignation to assume political responsibility for a recent riot by Thai laborers working for the mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung.

Asked whether he would accept Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu's resignation, Hsieh didn't answer directly. He instead said the whole incident regarding the riot is still under investigation.
Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu said she admires Chen's courage to make such a decision.
Noting that the incident has caused a great deal of trouble for the government, Lu said Chen has set a good example for politicians regarding accountability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Sept. 3, or the 30th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1189: Richard the Lion-Hearted receives his father's crown at Westminster and becomes King Richard I of England. A leader of the Third Crusade, he was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1650: The English, led by Oliver Cromwell, defeat the Scots at the Battle of Dunbar in Scotland.
1783: Britain finally recognizes the independence of the United States of America after they sign the Treaty of Paris, officially ending the Revolutionary War.
1899: Sir Frank MacFarlane Burnet, Australian virologist, is born. He was awarded the Order of Merit in recognition of his work on diseases such as influenza, polio and cholera.
1904: Japanese troops defeat Russian forces at Liaoyang in China.
1913: Nanking falls to forces under Yuan Shih-kai.
1914: Cardinal Giacomo Della Chiesa is elected Pope as Benedict XV. He sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace.
1930: The first nonstop flight from Paris to New York is made by Diedonne Caste and Maurice Bellonte.
1939: Britain, France, Australia and New Zealand declare war on Germany after its invasion of Poland on Sept. 1, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: Singapore is returned to British control after being occupied by the Japanese since 1942.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek agrees to create a committee of five, headed by U.S. Ambassador J. Leighton Stuart, to pave the way for a coalition government of ROC.
1951: The ROC government declares that the peace treaty with Japan soon to be concluded in San Francisco will not be binding on the Republic of China.
1955: Armed Forces Day is first observed in memory of the contributions of military servicemen during the eight-year Sino-Japanese War, which ended with the Japanese surrender on Sept. 3, 1945. Servicemen are given leave in accordance with Ministry of National Defense directives.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Fidel Castro's government in Cuba.
1966: Captain John Ridgway and Chay Blyth complete their journey across the Atlantic in a row boat in 91 days, landing on the isle of Aran in Ireland.
1967: Nguyen Van Thieu wins South Vietnam's presidential election, with Nguyen Cao Ky as his vice president.
1968: China Television Company is inaugurated in Taipei.
1969: Ho Chi Minh, president of North Vietnam, dies from a heart attack in Hanoi at the age of 79.
1977: Sadaharu Oh, a famous ethnic Chinese baseball player in Japan, slugs his 756th homer, setting a new world record.
1983: The Republic of China bans Philippine Airlines from flying to Taipei in response to the Philippine government's Aug. 22 order to China Airlines to suspend its CI811 flight to Manila.
1994: Beijing and Moscow proclaim an end to decades of confrontation and agree to cease aiming nuclear missiles at each other.
1998: A Swissair MD-11 jetliner crashes off Nova Scotia, Canada, on its way from New York to Geneva, killing all 229 people aboard.
1999: Taipei kindergarten teacher Lin Chien-chuan, who died in a school bus fire trying to rescue the small children in her care six years before, becomes the first woman to be enshrined in Nankang Martyr's Shrine in suburban Taipei.
2000: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that the ROC government will continue to maintain the "no haste, be patient" policy that limts Taiwan's investment in mainland China.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says his party will "seriously attend to the matter" of former Chairman Lee Teng-hui's stumping for the newly formed Taiwan Solidarity Union.
2004: Russian commandos storm a school in Beslan, North Ossetia, southern Russia where a group of Chechen rebels has been holding more than 1,000 students hostage for two days. More than 300 were killed in the siege, nearly half of them children.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Truth means the realization of our being; and moral law means the law of our being. Truth is the beginning and end (the substance) of existence. It is for this reason that the moral man values truth."

Los Angeles Times: New Orleans Slides Into Chaos; U.S. Scrambles to Send Troops.
The rushed mobilization of federal troops to the storm-desolated Gulf Coast was outpaced Thursday by New Orleans' rapid descent into chaos. Sniper fire threatened hospital evacuations and a mass bus caravan to Texas, corpses were found outside the city's decaying convention center and weakened refugees collapsed amid enraged crowds on city streets.

The Japan Times: New Orleans mayor issues SOS
Storm victims were raped and beaten, fights and fires broke out, rotting corpses lay in the open, and rescue helicopters and law enforcement officers were shot at as hurricane-flooded New Orleans descended into anarchy Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA appeals to both allies and foes for national unity
President Arroyo yesterday appealed to the nation to end destructive political warfare and, for national unity, to save the Philippines from a potential "economic dislocation" after world oil prices soared to their highest level in history.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 3 bishops got up to P4M from Pagcor
THE PRICKLY issue of gambling money and the Church has again been highlighted by allegations that three prominent bishops are receiving "donations" ranging from P500,000 to P4 million from the Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp. (Pagcor).
The Philippine Star: Not yet time to intervene in impeachment, says SC
The Supreme Court refused yesterday to grant a petition asking it to intervene to save an apparently doomed opposition attempt to have President Arroyo removed from office, saying the petition was "premature" and not yet "ripe for adjudication."
The Manila Times: 15 more impeach backers withdraw
FIFTEEN administration congressmen who have signed the impeachment complaint are reportedly withdrawing their signatures, dealing what could be the final "death blow" to the opposition, an unimpeachable source in the House told The Manila Times.

The Washington Post: Guard Troops Descend on New Orleans; Military arrives to speed evacuation of thousands of refugees left behind.
The National Guard arrived here in force Friday and mobilized to speed the evacuation of tens of thousands of desperate people trapped since Hurricane Katrina ravaged the Gulf Coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMBETABLE SHOULDN'T BE SET ON CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS: DPP

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not set a timetable on cross-strait affairs lest the island lose bargaining chips in its dealings with China, a spokesman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, made the remarks after Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said in a television interview a day earlier that he will push for the implementation of direct cross-strait trade and transportation links within two years if his party wins the 2008 presidential election.
Cheng criticized the remarks as demonstrating Ma's "lack of thorough consideration, " which the DPP spokesman said demonstrates that Ma is "incapable of handling cross-strait issues."

Cheng noted that the KMT tried in the past to add a clause for accelerating the implementation of direct cross-strait transportation to the revised Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area but that the party eventually gave up because of the people's opposition.

The DPP spokesman said that setting a timetable for issues involving cross-strait exchanges would be a "self-confining approach" that would undermine Taiwan's bargaining position in negotiations with China.
He added that not setting a timetable will give Taiwan maximum flexibility and maneuvering room.
Cheng also pointed out that the levels of freedom of speech, religion and assembly in China are still lagging far behind those of many other countries.

He said Ma's affirmation that China is moving in the direction of freedom and democracy is "overly optimistic, " suggesting that Ma stress Taiwan's democratic values and work with other countries in the world to prod China to move toward democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN PROVINCIAL GOVERNOR HOPES TO STRENGTHEN TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Sept. 2 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The governor of the Abruzzo Province in Italy expressed Friday his wish to further strengthen relations between Abruzzo and Taiwan in a wide range of fields, including trade, economy and culture, and to boost mutual understanding and friendship between the two sides.
Octtaviano del Turco made the remarks while meeting with visiting Republic of China Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng at his office.

Lin invited del Turco to visit Taiwan after the governor revealed that he has very much been interested in visiting Taiwan since his sister told him about her good impressions of Taiwan and the island's development after returning from her trip there in 1991.

During the meeting, del Turco proposed visiting exchanges between Abruzzese and Taiwanese industrial and commercial groups to boost mutual understanding and cooperation. He described Abruzzo, located in central Italy, as a region with abundant natural resources and many international high-tech operations, including those set up by South Korea-based Samsung Electronics.

Del Turco also expressed his welcome for the ROC's liaison office in Italy to hold a photograph exhibition featuring Taiwan's landscape in L'Aquila, the capital city of the province, Sept. 22-Oct. 31.

A total of 65 photos featuring natural and urban landscapes, tourist spots, cultural and folk festivals, as well as art activities in Taiwan will be on display in the exhibition to be held at the national Abruzzo Museum. Del Turco has promised to attend the opening of the show slated for Sept. 22.
Del Turco had served as a senator for two terms before being elected as governor of Abruzzo in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., JAPAN SHOULD JOINTLY ENSURE SECURITY IN TAIWAN STRAIT: PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said in an interview with a major Japanese daily that he is concerned about China's military buildup and that it is necessary for the United States and Japan to jointly ensure security in the Taiwan Strait.
The Asahi Shimbun on Saturday ran the interview which was conducted in Taipei the previous day.

The premier said that he welcomes U.S. and Japanese officials listing the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue as a common strategic objective in a Security Consultative Committee meeting in Washington D.C. in late February this year.

He pointed out that peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait not only relates to the two countries, but is also linked closely to peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, adding that it is only natural that the two countries are concerned about the stability in the Taiwan Strait.

The premier said he is deeply concerned about China's recent military buildup, pointing out that the buildup has exceeded what is warranted to deter Taiwan from moving toward independence. China is a country moving toward hegemony, he added.

On the cross-strait military balance, Hsieh said that Taiwan currently enjoys an edge. But he added that if the arms procurement package to buy crucial weapons from the Untied States doesn't clear the Legislative Yuan, then the military balance will tip in China's favor by 2012.

The premier also said that Taiwan will further promote direct cross-strait chartered flights, implemented for this past Chinese New Year holiday, and engage in consultations on chartered cross-strait cargo and passenger flights.

After reaching agreement with China on the chartered flights, Taiwan will open to Chinese tourists and will exchange views with China on cooperation in cracking down on cross-strait crime, Hsieh said.

He also said that to maintain peace and the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan will adopt a flexible attitude, adding however that until China becomes a democratic and pluralistic country, he does not trust China's "peaceful rise."

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND TO SEND 2 LAWYERS TO ASSIST LABORERS INVOLVED IN RIOT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Sept. 3 (CNA) (by S.C. Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Thailand has decided to send two senior lawyers to Taiwan to help Thai laborers who could face prosecution for their roles in a recent riot in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, the Thai government announced Saturday.

Lawyers Uthai Artiwet and Sasin Sukjaras, both of whom work for an international human rights protection organization, as well as Nualpan Mahakun, executive director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei, will head to Kaohsiung to help Thai laborers during Taiwan authorities' investigations into the riot. The two experienced lawyers will offer free legal counsel and defend in court any of the laborers who are formally charged.

Taiwan law enforcement authorities have focused on 16 Thai laborers involved in the riot, stressing that if they come forward, they will be given lenient treatment, and that if they wait until they are summoned, they will be dealt with according to normal procedures. So far, none of the Thai laborers have come forward.

Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) rioted Aug. 21 to vent their anger about unreasonable management and poor living conditions, hurling rocks at police as well as damaging dormitories and burning vehicles.
The riot brought to light the poor conditions under which the Thai laborers work, and both countries have started a probe into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO MULL SENDING RESCUE TEAM TO U.S. GULF COAST: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that relevant authorities are weighing whether to dispatch rescue units to Hurricane Katrina-affected areas along the U.S. gulf coast.

"As a member of the global village, Taiwan will not keep aloof from any efforts to rescue victims of disasters in other countries, " Hsieh stressed, noting that Taiwan has already donated US$2 million for rescue and relief efforts in Hurricane Katrina-affected areas in the United States.

Hsieh said that he believes the U.S. government, faced with tough post-disaster challenges, such as maintaining social order and preventing the outbreak of epidemic diseases, will formulate a plan to arrange the offers of assistance and aid from foreign countries.

DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: More Troops and Aid Reach New Orleans; Bush Visits Area; Chaotic Exodus Continues
Military vehicles bearing food and supplies sloshed into New Orleans, while commercial planes arrived to lift hurricane survivors.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bank of Italy reform: 7-year term for governor.
The Italian Cabinet meeting approved a central bank reform package Friday, introducing a seven-year term for Bank of Italy governor when there is a new bank chief. The reform draft, which does not set any age limits for the governor, avoids forcing the beseiged 69-year-old life-long incumbent governor Antonio Fazio to resign.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SPEAKS ON CLA CHIEF'S RESIGNATION OFFER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that the question of whether or not he accepts Council of Labor Affairs Minister Chen Chu's resignation will depend on the results of a probe into the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung MRT system's construction.

Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung has been commissioned to carry out an investigation into the riot that resulted from Thai laborers' anger over poor treatment by management and poor living conditions.
Chen submitted her resignation to take responsibility in the aftermath of the riot.

Hsieh said that with the council, the Kaohsiung City Government, and Thai employment brokers all involved in the case, it is presently difficult to determine who the culprit is, adding that a determination must await the completion of the investigation.
Hsieh made the remarks at a celebration to mark Lawyers' Day in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS TASK FORCE FOR FOREIGN LABORERS FORMED: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Saturday the inauguration of a task force to look into the human rights situation of foreign laborers in Taiwan and a legal team to provide free legal assistance to any laborers charged for their involvement in the Aug. 21 riot at a Kaohsiung MRT construction site.

The vice president, who concurrently serves as the chairwoman of a human rights advisory commission under the Presidential Office, made the announcement in a press conference held at the Presidential Office.

Lu noted that the recent riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. to protest against what they perceived as harsh treatment form the management and poor living conditions "is a crisis that has turned into an opportunity to redress the the matter properly."
The government does not condone poor treatment of foreign laborers and will carry out an overall review to demonstrate that Taiwan is a model human rights-based country, she further said.

Lu said that the legal team will help Thai laborers who face prosecution, providing them with human rights protection and legal counsel. On the choice of translators for the legal team, Lu said the views of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei will be respected by the government.
She said that the task force and the legal team have taken into consideration the notions that "human rights are borderless" and that "sovereignty will be upheld through rule of law."

The task force and legal team will help underscore that Taiwan is a country based on human rights and that it respects international conventions on labor, although foreign as well as Taiwanese nationals will have to abide by Taiwan law while here, Lu said.

On the 10-member task force formed by Thailand to look into the incident, Lu stressed that the issue of foreign laborers falls into the category of cross-border affairs, expressing the hope that the two countries can cooperate to root out irregularities and establish ajust and reasonable foreign labor policy.

Liao Fu-ter, Lu's deputy in the human rights advisory commission who serves as the convener of the task force, said that each individual's human rights should be protected regardless of their nationality or type of employment.

Taiwan should review its foreign laborer policy, use international standards of laborer rights as a reference, as well as review the brokerage, management, medical care, social security and working conditions of foreign laborers, Liao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL-OUT EFFORTS BEING MADE TO GAIN ATTENDANCE FOR CHEN AT APEC SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: All government units are trying their utmost in seeking to have President Chen Shui-bian be able to participate in the 2005 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum set for Nov. 17-19 in Busan, South Korea, Republic of China Vice Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang said Saturday.

Shih made the remarks at a luncheon in Seoul, capital of South Korea, with Taiwanese businesspeople operating in the country. Before coming to Seoul, Shih attended the 12th APEC Small and Medium Enterprises Ministerial Meeting Sept. 1-2 in Daegu.
Taiwan's head of state has been barred from attending all previous APEC leadership summits due to China's objections. Taiwan joined the regional economic organization as a formal member in 1991.

Last month, President Chen called on the South Korean government to grant him a visa for the Busan event to allow him to meet with his counterparts of other APEC member states and talk with them on Taiwan's political and economic achievements and the island's willingness to make a contribution to APEC's sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANEL CONCLUDES MAKESHIFT BRIDGE NOT BUILT TO 'TOADY' TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A panel of experts commissioned by the Executive Yuan to probe allegations that a makeshift bridge leading to a Hsueshang Tunnel construction site was built simply to "toady" to President Chen Shui-bian has concluded that the allegations were false.

Yang Yung-pin, a professor of civil engineer at National Taiwan University and chairman of the eight-member panel, said the investigation revealed that the iron bridge, built at a cost of NT$1.5 million (US$46,175), is a necessary part of the ongoing tunnel construction project.
He added that the makeshift bridge's completion on the eve of the president's scheduled inspection tour of the construction site Aug. 27 was simply a coincidence.

Tsai Jong-geng, president of the Taiwan Society of Professional Structure Engineer and a member of the panel, said that it is possible that construction workers completed the bridge a few days early in order to accommodate the president's visit, but he stressed that the bridge was not built simply for the purpose of pleasing the president and that it is a vital part of the ongoing construction project.
The panel said they gave the makeshift bridge a rating of 0.7 on a scale of 0 to 1 in terms of necessity, with 0 representing "completely unnecessary" and 1 representing "absolutely necessary."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T PUSHING TO SET UP HIGH-LEVEL DIALOGUE MECHANISM WITH U.S., JAPAN

TEXT.P: The government is pushing for the establishment of a regular high-level communication and dialogue mechanism with the United States and Japan, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff revealed Saturday.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the Presidential Office, who made the remarks in an exclusive interview with CNA, added that the establishment of this mechanism "has not yet ripened."
In the interview, Yu also touched on the government's promotion of second-phase constitutional reforms, as well as the positive development of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Yu pointed out that China's rise and military expansion in recent years, as well as its enactment of an Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan on March 14 and its recent joint military exercise with Russia have raised concerns among countries around the world. These developments have not only affected U.S. global strategic deployment, they have also impacted the interests of the United States and Japan in the Asia-Pacific region, he said.

He noted that U.S. and Japanese officials listed the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue as a common strategic objective in a Security Consultative Committee meeting in Washington, D.C. in late February this year.
He said that a new international situation and China's military threat have helped deepen Taiwan-Japan and Taiwan-U.S. relations and move them toward positive development.

The government is promoting a regular high-level communication mechanism with the United States and Japan, Yu said, adding that there is a regular security consultative committee meeting between Washington and Tokyo which serves as a communication platform, and that the United States is bound by the Taiwan Relations Act to provide Taiwan with sufficient weapons to defend itself.
Taiwan and Japan have had close exchanges, but a common communication platform is lacking between Taiwan, the United States and Japan, he continued.

Yu is scheduled to travel to Japan Monday to attend the Taiwan-Japan Forum set for Sept. 6-7. Although it is an unofficial dialogue mechanism between the two countries, it will help boost bilateral relations to a "para-alliance level" in the sense of the two countries' common values of democracy, freedom and peace, and is therefore significant in this regard, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 SEMINARS TO BE STAGED FOR 2ND PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: In order to drive home to people the necessity of President Chen Shui-bian's second phase constitutional reform, the government will stage at least 10,000 seminars around the island to spread the president's idea, Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office said Saturday.
In an interview with the CNA, Yu said President Chen himself would preside over some of the seminars to be staged from September at each of the country's 8,000-odds villages and boroughs.
The seminars will consist of speeches, debates and opinion-exchanges with the purpose of building public consensus on issues of national concerns.

During the reform, Yu said, the opinion of the grassroots, rather than the leaders, will be respected, the Constitution will be thorough revamped and all unrealistic provisions in it will be picked out and reviewed.
The reform will also bring the country's Constitution in line with that of the advanced countries in terms of the protection of human rights, liberty and others.
The revised constitution will be put to a referendum in conjunction with either the 2007 lawmaker elections or the 2008 presidential election, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CHARTER FLIGHT FROM HONG KONG ARRIVES IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The first charter flight operated by Hong Kong-based Express airline between Hong Kong and Taichung, central Taiwan, arrived at the Chingchuankang Airport Saturday evening.
On board were Hsieh Tien-tsi, president of the Express airline, , seven senior executives of the Express and 28 Hong Kong journalists and travel agents.
They were greeted at the airport by Huang Chung-shen, magistrate of the Taichung county, and local business leaders.
Hsieh said he was glad to be allowed to operate charter flights between Hong Kong and Taichung, and hopefully the service will be developed into scheduled flights.

Huang said the arrival of the flight bears witness to the fulfillment of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise to upgrade the Chingchuankang Airport to an international airport and it will sure promote the prosperity of central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHALLENGES OPPOSITION TO VOTE CABINET OUT OF OFFICE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh challenged the opposition in the legislature Saturday to support his administration's request for NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) over eight years to prevent flood, or vote his Cabinet out of office.

Tired by the opposition's foot-dragging on the bill for flood-control program, the premier said the opposition should pass a nonconfidence vote against his administration if they really believe the bill is inappropriate.

In the case, the premier said, the president will have no choice but to dissolve the legislature and call for a general election, and let the public to decide whether the legislature has made the right decision.

Giving the Constitution doesn't give the premier the power to dissolve the legislature when his major policy was rejected by the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said, a nonconfidence vote is the only way to solve the impasse between the executive and legislative branches in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Sept. 4, or the 1st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Alexander III, King of Scotland from 1249 to 1286, is born. He consolidated royal power, leaving Scotland united and independent.
1781: Los Angeles is founded by Spanish settlers and named "El Pueblo de Nuestra Senora La Reina de Los Angeles" (the Town of Our Lady the Queen of the Angels).
1791: King Louis XVI is forced to approve France's first constitution, which makes him a mere civil servant, following the French Revolution.
1839: British ships fire the first shots as the illegal opium trade in China propels the two countries toward war. The seeds of the Opium War of 1839-42 were sown in a worsening trade relationship between Great Britain and China's Ching court.
1839: In a letter to Britain's Queen Victoria complaining about the opium trade, Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu writes: "How can you bear to go further, selling products injurious to others in order to fulfill your insatiable desire?"
1906: American biologist Max Delbruck is born in Germany. He shared a 1969 Nobel Prize for investigating the mechanism of viral infection in living cells.
1909: The education and foreign affairs departments of the Ching court hold examinations in Beijing for the first batch of students who will receive higher education in the United States.
1944: British and Canadian troops liberate the Belgian cities of Brussels and Antwerp.
1948: Queen Wilhelmina of The Netherlands abdicates in favor of her daughter Juliana.
1959: Laos accuses North Vietnam of aggression and requests a United Nations emergency force.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of "Free China," a bi-monthly Taiwan magazine, is arrested by the Taiwan Garrison Command for alleged sedition.
1964: British Commonwealth troops move against Indonesian guerrillas in Malaya.
1965: Albert Schweitzer, French philosopher, physician and musician, dies in Africa at the age of 90. The physician founded and spent much of his life at a missionary hospital in Gabon. He was a noted organist, wrote many philosophical and theological works, and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1952.
1970: Natalia Makarova, the brightest star of Leningrad's famous Kirov Ballet, currently on a European tour, defects in London.
1976: The U.S. spacecraft Viking II lands on Mars and begins sending back photographs of the Martian landscape.
1978: The Pingkuang Little League team from Pingtung in southern Taiwan returns home after winning the World Baseball Championship in the United States.
1986: Thousands of Japanese, including at least 130 Diet members, meet in Tokyo to hold the "National Committee for the Commemoration of President Chiang's Benevolence to Japan" to mark the centennial of late Chinese nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek. Kung Teh-cheng, president of the ROC Examination Yuan, heads a delegation to attend the party, during which a message from Madame Chiang is read.
1987: A Soviet court sentences Mathias Rust, the West German teenager who flew his light plane from Poland straight through the Russian air defense system to land in Moscow's Red Square on May 28, handing down a four-year term in a labor camp.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo and ROC President Lee Teng-hui sign a joint communique in Taipei calling for closer bilateral relations.
1990: Chang Li-yi and Yeh Chang-ti, ROC U2 spy plane pilots, return to Taipei from the United States after being captured and exiled for 27 years.
1995: The Fourth Conference on Women, the biggest United Nations gathering in history, opens in Beijing.
1999: The ROC National Assembly votes to recess after ramming through the third and last reading of a controversial constitutional amendment extending the terms of its members.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh says that incompatibility between President Chen Shui-bian's actual strength and what appears to be his perception of his power has resulted in political instability.
2001: Chinese Taipei gets revenge against Japan in the final of the Fourth Asian Youth Baseball Championship tournament in Taipei with a 2-0 win to secure their first title in the event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Truth is not only the realization of our own being. It is that by which things outside of us have an existence. The realization of our being is moral sense. The realization of things outside of us is intellect."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS WITH SOMALI REBELS MAKING PROGRESS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is making every possible effort to rescue the crew of three Taiwan tuna boats that were seized by Somali rebels in August, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Sunday.

According to the latest information obtained by the Foreign Ministry, Lu said, negotiations with the Somalian rebels -- who have demanded US$500,000 for the release of each ship and its crew -- have made some progress over the last two days and the ministry will heed all possible variables and respond to them quickly.
Maintaining the safety of the 48 crewmen is the top priority of the rescue efforts, Lu said.
He noted that Taiwan has asked for international assistance in contacting the Somalian gunmen and began talking to them Friday.

The MOFA has made emergency contact with the Kuala Lumpur-based Piracy Reporting Center under the International Maritime Bureau for help in rescuing the crews. The ships had three Taiwanese captains and 45 international crew members, including 14 Indonesians, 13 Chinese, 12 Filipinos and six Vietnamese.

The Foreign Ministry has also contacted other international human rights organizations and the governments of the United States, Britain, various European countries, Saudi Arabia and South Africa to ask for help, Lu added.

He said the ministry hopes the rebels, who seized the trawlers at the port of Kismayo Aug. 16, will release the boats and their crews unconditionally. But if the pirates continue to demand US$500,000 for the release of each ship and its crew as news reports have said, the MOFA hopes the rebels will be asked through international mediation bodies to lower the ransoms, Lu added.
The Somalian gunmen had threatened to start killing one hostage a day if the ransom was not paid within 48 hours, but so far, the crew members have not been badly harmed, according to Lu.

Meanwhile, Lu and Lee Chen-hsiung, director-general of the MOFA Department of African Affairs, traveled to Tungkang, Pingtung and Hsiaoliuchiu in southern Taiwan, to meet the families of the three captains Sunday to convey the concern expressed by President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen over the incident.

Chen directed a day earlier that relevant government agencies should try their utmost to facilitate the rescue of the boats and their crews after meeting with Chuang Chi-yi, owner of Chungyi No. 218, one of the tuna boats.
