DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BACKPEDALS ON CHALLENGE TO OPPOSITION TO TOPPLE CABINET

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday he had been "a bit emotional" when he challenged the opposition parties to topple his Cabinet Saturday because the legislature would not meet to discuss his proposal to use NT$80 billion over the next eight years to fight floods.

Hsieh said some officials told him they do not know what to do with a "domineering" Legislative Yuan whose president has a different view from the chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT).

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, criticized the government for trying to buy votes with the special anti-flood budget, while KMT Chairman Ma ying-jeou claimed the budget had not been well planned. "These are two contradictory views, " according to Hsieh.

Hsieh said he would accept a decision by the legislature with regard to the flood-control budget, just as he accepted a cut in the premier's special spending allowance to NT$240,000 per month, less than the NT$340,000 for the mayors of Taipei and Kaoshiung.
He said the legislature can cast a no-confidence vote on him on the grounds that his special budget request is not good for the country, the result of which he will accept.

Given that the total budget has not been increased despite an increase in the defense budget, Hsieh said it is reasonable for his Cabinet to propose a NT$10-billion-per-year budget for flood control projects.

In the past, flood control projects have failed because they were not financed by special budgets, he said, claiming that the Keelung River flood control project was successful precisely because it was funded by a special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PRESIDENT POSTPONES MEETING WITH BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Chinese President Hu Jintao has agreed to postpone a scheduled meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush in Washington, D.C. Sept. 7, according to a statement released by the White House Saturday.
The statement said Bush spoke with Hu on the phone and thanked him for the sympathies of the Chinese people on the hardships suffered by Americans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina,
Both presidents agreed that in the present circumstances, it is best not to have a meeting in Washington next week, the statement said, adding that they agreed to reschedule the visit.
The two presidents agreed to meet in New York on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly later this month, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CONTACT FROM TWO TAIWANESE STUDENTS IN HURRICANE-AFFECTED AREA
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Texas, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By H.Y. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: An official of the Taiwan Economic and Cultural Office in Houston said Saturday that two Taiwanese students studying at universities in the Hurricane Katrina-affected area have still not made contact with their families.

The official said the office has written to the governor's office of the state of Louisiana, which is in charge of matters related to the relief of victims of the disaster, to request help in the search for the two students.

He also called for other Taiwanese students in the hurricane-affected area to make contact with their families as soon as possible, adding that students who have been unable to make international calls to their families in Taiwan can contact him through his mobile phone: 713-504-6060 or his office: 713-871-0851.

According to the official, there are 17 Taiwanese students studying at the University of New Orleans and 44 Taiwanese students at Tulane University. The official said that five Taiwanese students who graduated from Tulane University in August have not yet left the campus.

Pointing out that his office has helped 26 Taiwanese students in New Orleans to settle temporarily at a hotel in Houston, the official said that the office will help set them up in various apartments in the city or to return to Taiwan next week.
Two students from Fu Jen Catholic University, who recently went to New Orleans for a visit, arrived safe in Houston Saturday and are expected to return to Taiwan soon, the official added.
He further said his office will help arrange for Taiwanese students from the hurricane-affected area to continue their studies in other U.S. universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI LAUNCHES RELIEF EFFORT FOR HURRICANE-AFFECTED VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. operations of Taiwan's largest private charity organization, the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, launched an America-wide aid campaign Saturday aimed at speeding physical and psychological help to the victims of Hurricane Katrina in three southern U.S. states.

From Saturday, Tzu Chi volunteers from across America began to solicit donations on the streets to help with the relief for victims in the states of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, where Hurricane Katrina wreaked havoc on cities, particularly New Orleans, with strong winds and flooding that have left at least 1,000 people dead and incalculable damage.

According to Ke Cho-yan, a Los Angeles Tzu Chi representative, the foundation has activated a US$4 million emergency aid fund to finance the establishment of makeshift medical service stations in the three affected states. The fund is also being used to finance the distribution of US$100 token coupons with which the recipients can buy daily necessities.

Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Texas operation has established a relief center, dispatching volunteers to Houston and Dallas to provide free medical treatment or psychological counseling to thousands of flood victims who were bussed from New Orleans to the Texan cities for temporary settlement.

Tzu Chi officials also welcome people from around the world to mail donations, via personal checks, to the Tzu Chi L.A. operation to beef up the Katrina relief effort. The operation's address is: 1100, S. Valley Center Ave, San Dimas, CA 91773.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LONDON "TAIWAN FESTIVAL" TO BE HELD
DOC.DATELINE: London, Sept. 3 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in London said Saturday that his office will hold a two-day "Taiwan festival" Sept. 10-11 at Brent Cross, the biggest shopping mall in the north of London, to introduce the country's art and culture.

Edgar Lin, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom, said in an interview with the Central News Agency that the festival, which he believes is the first to be held in London, is aimed at showing the differences between Taiwan and China in the fields of art and cultural performance, as well as clarifying the concept of "China is China, Taiwan is Taiwan."

Pointing out that in the past, Taiwan's art and cultural performances have always been given in London as part of the activities in the "Chinese festival" organized by the Chinese Embassy and the municipality of London, Lin said the arrangements, which "treat the island as part of China," goes against the truth.
He further said the arrangements have also failed to help Taiwan introduce the unique features of its culture to the people of London.

According to the Taiwan Representative Office in London, performances including puppet shows, paper-cutting and calligraphy demonstrations will be given during the festival by a puppet group headed by Chen Hsi-huang, son of renowned Taiwanese puppet master Lee Tian-lu, and local Taiwan expatriates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO REJECT PRESIDENT'S 2ND PHASE OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) , the second-largest opposition party in the legislature, indicated Sunday that it will not be party to the second phase of President Chen Shui-bian's constitutional reforms, but will concentrate on issues affecting the people's livelihoods after the new legislative session opens Sept. 13.

Reacting to news reports that Chen plans to hold 10,000 discussion sessions across Taiwan from mid-September to elicit grassroots support for his constitutional reform plan, Huang Yi-chiao, the PFP legislative caucus convener, alleged that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is "indifferent to the people's suffering" and knows only the gimmicks of manipulating the constitutional reform topics.
Huang said the PFP will not be party to what he described as Chen's "game," but will concentrate on helping the people resolve the problems that most affect their livelihoods.

He pointed out that Taiwan is experiencing an economic slowdown, which makes the living conditions harsher for the people. In addition, he claimed, there are burning issues like deteriorating social order, corruption of government officials and increasing transfers of benefits due to collusion between business and the government.

"Can't President Chen see all these problems? " Huang asked, adding that he is surprised that Chen is constantly mindful of the second phase of constitutional reforms before those more serious problems are resolved.

In an interview with the CNA Saturday, Yu Shyi-kun, chief of general staff to the president, said the DPP will push the second-phase constitutional reforms from mid-September by holding a total of 10,000 discussion sessions around the nation.
In June, the president declared that he will form a constitutional reform committee and allow the public to be fully engaged in the constitutional reform discussion.

The second phase of constitutional reforms, according to Chen's plan, will involve such issues as whether the nation should have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power; whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government; reform of the legislature; whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government; lowering of the minimum voting age; modification of compulsory military service requirements; human rights and labor rights protection; and the inclusion of a special chapter on the well-being of aboriginal citizens in the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF TO RETURN TO TAIWAN MONDAY

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who left Taiwan before the Kuomintang (KMT) chairman election on July 16, will return to Taiwan Monday, PFP spokesman Huang Yi-chiao said Sunday.

Upon Soong's return the media will be watching how he will interact with the KMT's new chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, and how he will handle his party's co-sponsorship with the Communist Party of China of a so-called "elite forum" in mid-September in Shanghai.
Another topic that the media will be paying attention to is how Soong will tackle his party's nominations for the year-end city and county elections, as well as PFP-KMT coordination in this regard.
Huang said he does not see any urgency for Soong to meet with Ma, as inter-party coordination has been going on in his absence.

He denied as a groundless rumor that "an all-out war between the PFP and the KMT will erupt" after Soong comes back to Taiwan, noting that the two parties have been working together well to "guard the interests of the people" at the Legislative Yuan.

Chang Shien-yao, director of the PFP Policy Research Center, said Soong will call on former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, discuss with Ma the year-end elections and the government's special budget proposal for arms purchases, and exchange views with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on the arms purchase.
Other sources said Soong's priority will be stumping for PFP candidates in the city and county elections.

Soong was re-elected as PFP leader uncontested while he was abroad, which some observers claimed was an indication he was not keen on being elected for another term, particularly after a number of PFP lawmakers had questioned his policy directions.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW-INTEREST LOANS TO HELP ENTERPRISES RECOVER FROM TYPHOON LOSSES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises that suffered losses from Typhoon Talim may speed up their recovery by applying for low-interest loans from a development fund, a spokesman for the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Sunday.

The spokesman said those companies that suffered damage from Typhoon Talim last week are qualified to apply for loans at a favorable interest rate of 3.345 percent, provided they can produce documents from local government authorities certifying their losses.
If a company cannot put up sufficient guarantees for a loan, its application may be referred to another fund that provides credit guarantees for such enterprises, he said.

Information related to the low-interest loans has been posted on the Web site of the MOEA at: http: //www.moea.gov.tw. Inquiries may also be made by calling the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration at 080-005-6476.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERMENT OF LATE PRESIDENTS WILL TAKE PLACE AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The interment of the embalmed bodies of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo is expected to take place in March or April next year as scheduled, even though construction of their burial plots has lagged due to bad weather, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Sunday.

Although construction of the Chiangs' tombs, located at the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichih, Taipei County, has been interrupted by torrential rain and thick fog, the project will be completed in accordance with the terms of the contract, said Gen. Tai Po-te, commander of the MND Allied Logistics Command.

Tai confirmed a statement from the MND Bureau of Armaments and Acquisition -- the builder of the tombs -- that construction began in early March this year and will be ready as scheduled without any shortcuts in quality and design.

Meanwhile, according to Tai, the affairs regarding the relocation of the two Chiangs -- who have been embalmed in interim mausoleums in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan -- to the Wutzushan military cemetery for permanent interment will be in the charge of the Ministry of the Interior in line with the State Funeral Law.
As to the management of the tombs, Tai said, this will be transferred from the MND to the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the Executive Yuan.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing China to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting proper burial in China.
Chiang Ching-kuo, who was respected for ending martial law in Taiwan shortly before his death, died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PUSH FOR PRIORITY BILLS DURING NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will use the year-end "three-in-one" local elections to push for a package of priority draft bills during the new legislative session that will start in mid-September, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus said Sunday.

William C.T. Lai said that in the run-up to the elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors, and township/village chiefs, the DPP will try to expound on the contents of various key draft bills, the government's stance and the disputed points between the ruling and opposition parties, to solicit public support.

Lai said the move will not only boost the possibility of priority draft bills clearing the legislature but will also enhance the DPP's chances of winning the elections, which will be a litmus test for the political climate in the lead-up to the 2008 presidential election.

The second session of the sixth Legislative Yuan is due to formally open Sept. 13, and with fewer than 100 days remaining until the Dec. 3 elections, the ruling and the opposition parties are expected to unveil a series of bills related to the general public to solicit voter support for their candidates.

The Executive Yuan has come up with a total of 18 prioritized draft bills for the legislature to screen during its new session, including a draft statute governing an arms procurement package, an eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control budget plan, a proposal on confirmation of the Control Yuan members, a draft revision to the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan and a draft amendment to the National Health Insurance Law, according to Lai.

Based upon a consensus reached between the DPP legislative caucus and the Executive Yuan, the number of priority bills has been reduced, Lai said. He called on the opposition-controlled legislature to support all the draft bills, which he said are of great importance and urgency.

Meanwhile, Legislator Chen Ching-chun, who also serves as secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, voiced the hope that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will lead his party with new vision into cooperating with the ruling party to push for the early passage of various key draft bills during the new legislative session.

The arms procurement bill and its budget to buy eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States as well as the confirmation of the Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian have been stalled for two consecutive sessions due to opposition from the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) . Whether the two long-stalled draft bills will be put on the legislative agenda is still a focus of media attention.
Over the past five years, the KMT and the PFP have used their slim majority in the legislature to boycott various policy initiatives launched by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRAISES ROTARY CLUBS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded Rotary International (RI) Sunday for its strenuous efforts to cultivate young leaders and encourage young people to take part in social services.

In a written message to the opening ceremony for the International Rotary Youth Leadership Awards (RYLA) in Taiwan, Chen said that RI volunteers have made great contributions to progress and peace across the globe through their selfless services.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen also extended a written message to the ceremony, saying that the holding of the event in Taiwan will help the international community get a better understanding of Taiwanese culture and Taiwan's progress in various fields.
The activity will not only boost civic international changes but will also cultivate a new generation of young leaders and broaden young people's international vision, he said.
The international RYLA, sponsored by Rotary International District 3520, will run through Sept. 9, with around 250 people from more than 20 countries participating.

During the seven-day camp, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will deliver a speech on "building a world-class capital -- the Taipei experience." Mark Daniel Maloney, trustee of the Rotary Foundation, will also deliver a speech and Michel Lu, director-general of the Department of Information and Cultural Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, will share his experience in diplomatic work with the participants.

Other activities will include visits to the National Palace Museum, the Hsiao His Yuan Puppet Theater, and Acer -- one of the top IT companies in the world -- as well as the Taroko National Park and the Kuang-long Museum.

The participants have come from the United States, Canada, Germany, Sweden, Poland, Estonia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, India, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Mongolia, Hong Kong, Bolivia, Nigeria, South Africa and Taiwan.

Brain Lai, adviser to the International RYLA in Taiwan, said that the primary goal of sponsoring the event is "Taiwan walks out and the world flies in, " hoping that the youth from around the world will learn more about Taiwan.

They will also discover the beauty of Taiwan from the perspectives of art, culture, technology and diplomacy, while the domestic participants can immerse themselves in the international environment, enhance global understanding and broaden their horizons.
The RYLA originated in Australia in 1959. It is a training program for people aged 20-30 aimed at emphasizing leadership, citizenship and personal growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON YOUTH MANPOWER DEVELOPMENT TO BE HELD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced Sunday that the Executive Yuan will convene a national conference to work out long-term government policy as well as medium- and short-term goals for youth manpower development.

Government officials, industrialists and academics will be invited to take part in the conference to discuss issues relating to education and employment as well as various national development and investment projects, Hsieh said.

Hsieh made the remarks after hearing a report on conclusions pertaining to young people's employment, educational resources and government's youth policy on the third day of a national youth conference that began Friday.
The participants in the conference conducted in-depth and extensive discussions of various issues, Hsieh said, claiming that the forum has enabled people to participate in policy-making.
The government has the responsibility to provide young people with development opportunities, according to Hsieh.

As to the allocation of education budget, Hsieh said that a mechanism for eliminating those universities that do not operate in a sound way should be set up, while incompetent teachers should be fired.

Touching on young people's participation in politics, Hsieh noted that the government is planning to launch a second phase of constitutional reforms to lower the minimum age for civic rights, including election, recall, referendum and initiative.
Although there are still some disputes about the minimum age for civic rights, Hsieh pointed out, the age is expected to be lowered from the current 20 years to 18 based upon a preliminary consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD OFFERS CONDOLENCES TO FAMILY OF CHINESE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu offered his condolences Sunday to the family of Zhu Xiangdong, a deputy director of Beijing's National Bureau of Statistics who died of heart failure while taking a hot spring bath on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei two days ago.

Wu visited Taipei City Hospital, Yangming Branch, where Zhu's body was cremated. Wu directed the MAC and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to assist Zhu's family in affairs regarding the cremation, a brief funeral and their travel back to Beijing.
Zhu's wife and son flew into Taipei Saturday in the company of several Beijing officials in charge of Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan affairs.

Zhu, who was visiting Taiwan in his capacity as an adviser to the National Statistical Society of China, went with four other colleagues to visit an observatory run by the Central Weather Bureau in Zhuzihu, Yangmingshan in Taipei City's northern suburb Thursday.
After visiting the observatory, Zhu and his group visited a famous hot spring, checking into separate hot spring baths at the observatory's guesthouse.

According to Zhu's companions, they entered his bathroom after an hour and found him passed out in the hot spring tub. All the windows were closed, which is against safety regulations, according to prosecutors.

Authorities from Taipei City Hospital, Yangming Branch said Friday that Zhu showed no signs of life when he was rushed to the hospital and Prosecutor Wang Jen-kuei from the Shihlin District Prosecutors' Office said after an autopsy that Zhu's death was an accident with no signs of foul play.
The MAC, the SEF and the Bureau of Immigration have been assisting the family over the past two days to allow them to enter Taiwan.
Zhu, 50, was the highest-ranking Chinese official to die in Taiwan since the two sides began private exchanges more than a decade ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGES LEGISLATURE TO PASS FLOOD-CONTROL BILL BY OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Sunday he is hopeful that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan will pass an eight-year NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control bill before the end of October to allow for an early start of various flood prevention programs around the country.
Cho said the government originally expected the legislature to hold an extraordinary session during its summer recess, but the legislature refused.

According to the legislature's work schedule, the first two months of the new legislative session will be devoted to general interpellations after lawmakers begin to meet in mid-September. In that case, the legislature will not begin to screen the flood-fighting bill until December.

In view of the repeated flood-triggered devastation in recent months, Cho said it is hoped that the opposition-controlled legislature can put the nation's well-being above partisan strife and pass the flood-control bill as early as possible.

"I'm hopeful that the legislature can devote at least one day per week to screening major bills once its new session kicks off later this month. Hopefully, the flood-control bill can clear the legislative floor before the end of October. Should that be the case, the government will have two months to prepare and ensure that various flood-fighting projects can get underway in January 2006, " Cho said.

As to Premier Frank Hsieh's challenge to the opposition to topple the Cabinet if it wants to continue to stonewall the flood-control bill, Cho said Hsieh's remarks were mainly aimed at highlighting the legislature's absurdity.

Tired by the opposition's foot-dragging on the flood-controlled bill, Hsieh said Saturday that the opposition should pass a no-confidence vote against his administration if they really believe the bill is inappropriate. Should the legislature passes the no-confidence vote, Hsieh said, he would ask the president -- in line with constitutional provisions -- to dissolve the legislature and pave the way for a new legislative election to let the public to decide whether the legislature is qualified to reject the flood-control bill.

Cho said Hsieh's remarks mainly reflected his admiration for what he claimed is the U.S. Congress' "high efficiency" in response to the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina. The U.S. Congress advanced its opening day of the new session to pass a US$10.5 billion budget for emergency flood relief programs in the wake of the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP LABOR AFFAIRS OFFICIAL BENT ON RESIGNING: CLA STAFF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official is determined to quit her job after tendering her resignation last week to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project, aides at the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Sunday.
The aides said that Chen Chu was furious about rumors suggesting that her resignation was in preparation for her planned candidacy for Kaohsiung mayor in the year-end elections.
Premier Frank Hsieh disclosed last Saturday that he had not decided whether to accept Chen's resignation and that the question would depend on the results of a probe into the Kaohsiung County riot.

Hsieh has instructed Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung to carry out an investigation into the riot, which arose because of the Thai workers' protest against inhumane treatment and has severely damaged Taiwan's international image.

Chen's aides also denied speculation that she submitted her resignation because she was unhappy that after receiving her investigation report on the riot, the premier wanted another Cabinet minister to probe the causes of the riot.
The aides said that Chen's report mentions a few points of suspicion for prosecutors to clarify and that she is willing to cooperate with them in their investigation of the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: COOPERATION WITH PFP IN LEGISLATURE IS KMT PRIORITY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will make it a priority to cooperate with its "pan-blue alliance" ally the People First Party (PFP) in passing or blocking a government law bill in the next Legislative Yuan session that opens Sept. 13, KMT officials said Sunday.

They said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and his aides have been watching Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's statements on such issues as weapons procurement, flood control and nomination of Control Yuan members.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT Policy Committee, said depending on party-to-party talks with the PFP, the KMT might not necessarily support the Cabinet's arms purchase budget bill but might agree to a special budget proposal for using NT$80 billion over the next eight years to fight floods.

However, KMT think tanks recommend that the flood-control budget be proposed in accordance with the law governing government debt, which stipulates that the share of special budgets must not exceed 15 percent of the total budget.
Therefore, Tseng said, the government should break the NT$80 billion total into eight annual budgets of NT$10 billion so that the proposal will accord with the spirit of annual budgets.

In regard to the special budget for purchasing three major weapons, Ma has asked the party caucus to consider the issue from the standpoints of stabilizing cross-Taiwan Strait relations and building a mechanism to promote mutual trust.

Tseng said this kind of logic might make it unnecessary to buy any major weapons. Still, this is not yet final, as a KMT ad hoc committee is still evaluating the views of all parties concerned, he added.

He added that even though the government has moved the special budget for buying Patriot III anti-missile batteries to the annual budget, the KMT might not support the remaining portion of the special budget for buying submarines and anti-submarine aircraft.

Wang has indicated that the arms purchase bill should at least be discussed at the Legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee. With the KMT's strong intervention, the bill might not pass the Procedure Committee if the PFP acts in concert, Tseng added.

On the controversy about President Chen Shui-bian's nominations of the Control Yuan members, Tseng said the KMT expects the president to renominate the members and change some members in the review committee, including Nita Ing, chairwoman of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSR).
Tseng said that only when Chen presents a new list of Control Yuan nominees will the KMT and PFP consider deliberating the list.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, also a KMT Central Standing Committee member, agreed that Chen should renominate the Control Yuan members and that the flood control budget should be put on the regular budget instead of a special budget.
Lai noted that the KMT has not finalized its position on the arms purchase issue.

The party will adopt a strategy of "close monitoring but no filibustering" during the new legislative session, mainly in cooperation with the PFP, to maintain the "pan-blue alliance" majority in the legislature, party officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS NO RECOGNITION OF CHINA'S ACADEMIC ACCREDITATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that Taiwan will not recognize China's academic accreditation during his tenure.

"So long as I remains in office, Taiwan is unlikely to recognize China's academic accreditation. This is not for my sake, but rather for the sake of Taiwan, for Taiwan's schools and young people," Chen said while attending a closing session of the three-day National Youth Conference.
If the government recognizes China's academic accreditation, Chen said he is afraid that local youths would travel to China in throngs for education.
"Then, our schools would have a hard time recruiting enough students. In that case, Taiwan's educational system would be gravely affected," he added.

Touching on the proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait forge direct transport links, Chen said the issue should be addressed from the perspectives of national security and Taiwan's maximum interests.

"Some people have been pressuring the government to open direct cross-strait air and shipping services. This is a solemn issue that we cannot afford to make any misjudgment, " Chen said. Even though direct cross-strait transport links may bring economic benefits, Chen said the government should make an overall review of such links' impact on Taiwan's national security and maximum interests.
"We should consider whether the arrangements would denigrate our national status or undermine Taiwan's separate national identity," he added.

Noting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lack mutual understanding, Chen said Taiwan should encourage research on China and the Communist Party of China. By the same token, he said, China should also try to understand Taiwan and encourage "Taiwan study."
"When we come to better understand each other, we would be less likely to indulge in wishful thinking," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WON'T LET ARMS BILL PASS LEGISLATURE'S PROCEDURE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: With a new session of the Legislative Yuan approaching, the nation's second largest opposition People First Party (PFP) said Sunday it is still opposed to putting the government's arms purchase budget bill on the legislative agenda.

Wang Jin-pyng, president of the legislature, has said that the bill should at least be discussed at the committee level, but PFP spokesman Huang Yi-chiao said the opposition parties should use all opportunities, including the Procedure Committee, to "thoroughly guard" national interest.

Huang's remarks dimmed the prospect of the government bill passing through the legislative floor to purchase Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft as the largest opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has vowed to make it a priority to cooperate with its "pan-blue alliance" ally PFP in the new session starting Sept. 13.

Huang said the reason for PFP taking such a tough stand is that the nation's opposition forces are suffering from an "asymmetrical" disadvantage in the face of the ruling camp's huge political resources. He said the move is aimed at nipping in the bud any ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) attempts to divide the opposition.

Huang said the DPP has used various special budgets, starting with the so-called "defensive referendum" in late 2003, to stage rallies and spread rumors trying to coerce the opposition parties to let the government have it ways, and yet little progress has been made in administrative efficiency.
He said the PFP will stand firm on its position to monitor the government, and it will ask its KMT ally not to loosen up.

Chang Shien-yao, director of PFP Policy Center, said his party has never opposed buying weapons or fighting floods. But because of the nation's financial difficulties, PFP has demanded that the government put forward a list of priorities for the nation's overall interests.

For instance, Chang said, flood control should precede arms purchase because the latter concerns cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- if there is peace across the strait, then weapons procurement would not be so urgent.
That's why PFP has since August been saying that flood-control bills should be a priority for the legislature, not the special budget bill for buying weaponry, he added.
Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP lawmaker, cited the hurricane disaster in New Orleans, southern U.S., as an example of a domestic issue taking precedence over the war issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S CHIEF OF STAFF TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff will leave for Tokyo Monday to attend a forum on Taiwan-Japan relations scheduled for Sept 6-7, political sources said Sunday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, will be the highest-ranking Republic of China official ever to attend a public event in Japan since Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972, the sources said.

Most of the Taiwan-Japan forum activities are closed-door meeting, with the exception of a seminar scheduled for Sept.7 afternoon on the new Asian situation and feasible response strategies which will open for media coverage, the sources said.
Both Yu, a former ROC premier, and Yasuhiro Nakasone, who served as Japanese prime minister from 1982 through 1987, will attend the Sept. 7 seminar to exchange views on relevant topics.
On behalf of their respective countries, the sources said, Yu and Nakasone will speak at a cocktail reception marking the end of the forum on Sept. 7 evening.

In his speech, Yu will accentuate the need for Taiwan and Japan to forge "Track II" dialogue channels and strengthen their cooperation in promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and peace in the face of the new Asian situation. Yu will also take the opportunity to express Taiwan's gratitude for Japan's granting of 90-day visa-free treatment for prospective Taiwan visitors, the inclusion of Taiwan into the list of strategic goals of the Japan-U.S. defense treaty, and its support for Taiwan's bid to become a World Health Assembly observer.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation will include Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-lung; Lo Fu-chuan, president of the Association of East Asian Relations; Tseng Yung-hsien, vice chairman of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies; and Tung Li-wen, director of the China Affairs Department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Since the DPP took power in 2000, the Presidential Office has set up a special panel to boost exchanges and cooperation with Japan. The Taiwan-Japan forum is the panel's achievement in forging a dialogue mechanism in the absence of official ties.
Yu is scheduled to wrap up his Japan visit and return to Taipei Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S U.S. LAYOVER NOT TO BE AFFECTED BY POSTPONEMENT OF HU'S VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's planned transit stop in the United States will not be affected by the postponement of Chinese President Hu Jintao's U.S. visit, a Presidential Office spokesman said Sunday.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, was responding to media reports that Hu has postponed his official visit to the United States next week due to Hurricane Katrina, but he and President George W. Bush have agreed to meet on the sidelines of a U.N. assembly in New York later this month.

Hu was originally scheduled to arrive in Seattle Monday to start his first official visit to the United States since he assumed office in 2003. According to foreign wire service reports, Hu talked with Bush by phone Saturday and the two leaders agreed to postpone a meeting planned for Wednesday "due to the special condition faced with the U.S. government in handling with the serious disaster caused by Hurricane Katrina."

The White House also said Saturday that Bush had to cancel his meeting with Hu because of the hurricane's aftermath but the two leaders agreed to meet in New York on the sidelines of a U.N. meeting in mid-September to mark the world body's 60th founding anniversary.

Commenting on the reports, Huang said President Chen's planned layover in the United States later this month on his way to Central America will not and should not be affected by the postponement of Hu's U.S. visit.
"President Chen will just make a transit stop in the United States en route to Central America for a diplomatic tour, " Huang said.
As to the postponement of Hu's U.S. travel plan, Huang said the Presidential Office doesn't have any opinion and cannot make any comment.

Huang further said the itinerary of President Chen's Central America visit will be announced in mid-September. Chen will travel to Nicaragua later this month to attend a summit meeting with the nation's Central American diplomatic allies and visit several other countries in Central America and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO 2ND-PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday he will do his utmost in the next two year to hasten the birth of a new constitution that fits Taiwan's political reality.
Chen made the remarks while attending a session of the three-day National Youth Conference that began Friday.

Claiming that the existing ROC Constitution has become obsolete and unfit to Taiwan's political and social situation, Chen said he will push for second-phase constitutional reform in the coming two years to consolidate Taiwan's young democracy.

After listening to a report on democratic development and relations across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said Taiwan's sovereignty issue is not just strengthening localization but should also upgrade its national identity.
"We should drive home to the international community that Taiwan is not part of China. Taiwan is the Republic of China. It is by no means part of the People's Republic of China," Chen stressed.

Touching on the second-phase constitutional reform, Chen said the reform will bring the country's Constitution in line with that of the advanced countries in terms of the protection of human rights, liberty and others.
Moreover, Chen said the second-phase reform will focus on restructure the government system and adjust election schedules as part of the efforts to improve government efficiency.
"At present, we have too many elections. We conduct elections almost every year. We have paid a great deal of social costs for all those elections. This trend should be stopped," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Sept. 5 or the 2nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Navy teams at last halt the massive city-wide fire that has raged in London for a number of days by blowing up a swathe of buildings in the path of the flames. More than 13,000 homes and 90 churches have been destroyed but only nine lives were lost.
1735: Johann Christian Bach, German composer known as the "English Bach," is born. Son of Johann Sebastian Bach, he became Music Master to Queen Charlotte of Britain and composed more than 40 symphonies and several operas.
1798: Turkey declares war on France.
1857: Auguste Comte, French philosopher known as the founder of positivism, dies at the age of 59. He also established sociology as a systematic study.
1864: French, British and Dutch fleets attack Japan in the Shimonoseki Strait after Japan closed its ports and expelled all foreigners.
1905: The Treaty of Portsmouth is signed in New Hampshire, ending the Russo-Japanese War. Through the treaty mediated by US President Theodore Roosevelt, a victorious Japan obtains complete control over Korea and rights and interests in southern Manchuria, leaving the north to Russia.
1915: The first convention for international socialists is convened in Switzerland.
1922: American aviator James Doolittle makes the first American coast-to-coast flight, lasting 21 hours 19 minutes.
1939: The United States proclaims neutrality at the start of World War II.
1945: The first units of the Chinese New Sixth Army Corps arrive in Nanking by air before General Ho Ying-ching receives the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from General Okamura on Sept. 9.
1967: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Barbados.
1972: Palestinian terrorists strike at the Munich Olympics, killing 11 Israeli athletes.
1974: Lt. Gen. Walter M. Galligar, commander of the 5th U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by Lynette "Squeaky" Fromme, a follower of the cult leader Charles Manson, in Sacramento.
1980: The 16.3 km St. Gottard road tunnel, the longest in the world, is formally opened to traffic in Switzerland.
1986: Four gunmen holding a hijacked Pan Am plane in Karachi open fire on 400 passengers on board, killing more than 10 people and injuring over 120 others after Pakistan security forces storm the Boeing 747 jet.
1987: Communist China's first Chinese arts festival opens in Beijing.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces that the long-range Hsiung Feng II missile has been successfully developed and will soon be added to the ROC arsenal.
1991: The Union of Soviet States is no more. Under pressure from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, the Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union reluctantly winds up the Union and hands power to the Soviet republics.
1995: France conducts an underground nuclear test on Mururoa Atoll, causing worldwide condemnation.
1997: Mother Teresa, an Albanian-born Indian nun who won the 1979 Nobel Peace prize, dies at the age of 87. Dedicated to relieving the suffering of India's desperately poor and dying people, she founded a Roman Catholic congregation of sisters, the Missionaries of Charity, in 1950.
1999: Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu, Honduran President Carlos Flores and Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Alemen arrive in Taipei to attend the second Summit of the Republic of China and Central American countries.
2000: P. K. Chiang, former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, warns that economic problems should not be politicized and that he is worried about the "inappropriate" economic policy of the administration.
2000: Pop singer Chang Hui-mei, known to her fans as Ah Mei, is honored by the Taiwan Junior Chamber as one of Taiwan's top 10 outstanding young people.
2001: Taiwan's plastics tycoon Wang Yung-ching gives President Chen Shui-bian the thumps up for his support for phasing out the "no haste, be patient" policy curbing investment in and trade with mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Moral sense and intellect are the powers or faculties of our being. They combine the inner or subjective and outer or objective use of the power of the mind. Therefore with truth everything done is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REVIEWS SWAT TRAINING DRILL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday reviewed a SWAT training drill aimed at testing and honing the quick-reaction special police unit's capabilities.

Nearly 200 members of the SWAT force took part in the drill, which was highlighted by a mock hijacking of a bus. In the drill, the SWAT members stormed the bus, arresting the hijackers and freeing the hostages.

The drill, which featured state of art crime-fighting equipment, was staged at a training base of the Special Police First Headquarters, National Police Administration (NPA) in Taipei's northern suburb of Shihpai.

President Chen was flanked by Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, NPA Director-General Hsieh Yin-tang and Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Hou You-yi during the review.

The Ministry of Defence said the expanded training area should allow the SAF to conduct more training locally.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, KMT CHAIRMEN SET TO MEET WITH EACH OTHER SOON

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong promised Monday upon his return to Taiwan that he will soon call on new Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and exchange views with him on important issues related to Taiwan's interests and the people's well-being.

Speaking at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Soong, who left for the United States before the Aug. 16 KMT chairmanship election for a vacation, also said that the opposition parties must do whatever they can to oversee the ruling government's conduct.
The PFP head was greeted at the airport by Ma and high-ranking PFP officials. It was Ma's first meeting in person with Soong since he was elected as KMT chairman last month.
Besides extending his congratulations on Ma's victory in the chairmanship election, Soong also expressed the hope that the two parties will continue to work together at the Legislative Yuan.
"Only through better cooperation between the two parties can the strength of the 'pan-blue alliance' be consolidated," he said, adding that "this will also meet with the public's expectations."

Pointing out that issues regarding bills which have long been stalled in the legislature, the crisis of marginalization in the international economic system that Taiwan faces, cross-Taiwan Strait stability, the nation's status and the oppositions' stance on how to oversee the government's operations are the focal points of the public's concerns, Soong said that he will thoroughly discuss these issues with the KMT's new leader.

Soong further said that while he was in the United States, he really worried a lot about the current situation in Taiwan, adding that continuing to waste time in dealing with the issue of the nation's development will absolutely have an impact on the competitiveness of the island.
"Therefore, the opposition parties must be united and better oversee the work of the government in order to prevent Taiwan from drowning and perishing," Soong stressed.

Noting that if Taiwan doesn't work hard and push forward, it will gradually be forgotten by the international community, the PFP head also urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to deal practically with cross-strait relations. "Otherwise, the island will continue to regress in the future, " he added.

Meanwhile, Ma said that his presence at the airport was not only aimed at welcoming Soong's return to Taiwan, but also for the purpose of arranging for an official Soong-Ma meeting as soon as possible, as such a meeting "will effectively bridge the gap between the two parties."

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen also said that Ma wanted to show his goodwill by heading to the airport to welcome Soong back, adding that Ma appreciates the quick response of the PFP chairman who promised to pay a courtesy call to the KMT headquarters soon.
Meanwhile, staff members of the PFP also said the same day that the PFP and the KMT have maintained a very solid cooperation relationship, including close cooperation in the legislature.

As Soong had frankly voiced his support for Wang Jing-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, in the KMT chairmanship race, the interactions between Ma and Soong as well as their views about the future cooperation between the two parties in the year-end county magistrates elections have been a focus of the public's attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. URGED TO PLAY ACTIVE ROLE IN MAINTAINING CROSS-STRAIT PEACE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 4 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: About 40 Taiwanese students and expatriates in France launched a campaign Monday at the Taiwan Representative Office in Paris to urge members of local Taiwanese communities to jointly sign a statement requesting that the United Nations play an active role in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait.

The statement said that Taiwan has no intention of challenging the rights of any U.N. members by pushing its bid to join the world body, adding that Beijing's continuous obstruction in dealing with Taiwan's efforts to join the international community can only irritate the 23 million people of Taiwan and Taiwanese living abroad.
"This obstruction will not help improve relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. On the contrary, it will be harmful to peace in the strait," it further said.

The statement also called for U.N. members to look without bias at Taiwan's legitimate right to participate in the United Nations and urged them to support the Taiwan people's right to representation in the organization.
Furthermore, the statement also urged China, in accordance with the U.N. Charter, to give up its threats of military force and to engage in peaceful dialogue and exchanges with the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOVERNOR TO VISIT TAIPEI TO DISCUSS BEIJING'S BEHAVIOR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara is scheduled to visit Taiwan Sept. 6-9, mainly to discuss the repercussions of Beijing's abrupt withdrawal from the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC) and its annual meetings.

Officials from the Tokyo Governor's Office confirmed Monday that during his four-day stay in Taiwan, Ishihara will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to exchange views on the changing situation after Beijing announced Aug. 30 that it had decided to drop out of the ANMC group.

Founded in 2001 by Ishihara, the ANMC is meant to be a forum of mayors of major Asian cities. It groups Bangkok, Beijing, New Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Tokyo and Yangon. The 12 cities have since taken turns hosting the ANMC annual meetings.

Taipei began to bid to host the 2005 ANMC meeting in July 2004, but Beijing entered the race against Taipei for the hosting right only a few days before the Nov. 22-23, 2004 Jakarta meeting, simply because it did not want to see Taipei play any significant role in the meeting.
In a vote to choose between Taipei and Beijing, Beijing beat Taipei by winning seven out of 12 votes, but was one vote shy of the two-thirds needed to win the hosting right.

In the ensuing negotiations, all of the meeting-attendants except Beijing Deputy Mayor Zhang Mao, the Beijing representative, agreed that Beijing should host the 2005 meeting, with Taipei getting the priority right to host the 2006 meeting.
When the chairman of the meeting announced the results of the negotiations, Beijing's representative walked out in protest.
Beijing has since refused to endorse a joint statement issued by the 2004 ANMC meeting regarding the 2005 and 2006 sponsorships.

Ishihara himself has also asked Beijing to sign the joint statement over the past 10 months. Nevertheless, Beijing informed Tokyo abruptly Aug. 30 that it was withdrawing from the ANMC grouping, apparently in a gesture of opposition against Taipei's hosting the ANMC meeting in 2006.

In a news conference held in Tokyo last Friday, Ishihara condemned Beijing's rudeness and unreasonableness by dropping out of the grouping, saying that refusing to endorse the ANMC joint statement runs counter to international rules and norms. "China is a country that does not play by the rules," Ishihara said.

Because of Beijing's abrupt withdrawal, the holding of the 2005 ANMC annual meeting is now facing various uncertainties, including whether the 2005 ANMC meeting will be held or not, prompting Ishihara to go to Taipei to meet President Chen and Taipei Mayor Ma, who attended the 2004 meeting in Jakarta.
During the 2004 ANMC meeting, Ma expressed regret that Beijing's representative did his best to scuttle Taipei's chance to play a role on the international stage.
However, Ma did not rule out the possibility of attending the 2005 meeting in Beijing in spite of his unhappy encounter with the Beijing representative in Jakarta.

Ishihara's forthcoming visit to Taiwan will be his fifth since assuming the Tokyo governorship in April 1999. He was in Taipei in May 2004 to attend President Chen's inauguration for a second four-year term and he was again in Taipei in October the same year at the invitation of the Taiwan Railway Administration.
He visited central Taiwan shortly after the island was struck by a deadly earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.

Ishihara, formerly Japan's minister of transport and a talented writer who received the prestigious Akutagawa Prize for one of his books, has been the most prominent Japanese political figure to visit Taiwan since Japan severed formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF LEAVES FOR TOKYO TO ATTEND FORUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff left for Tokyo Monday to attend a forum on Taiwan-Japan relations scheduled for Sept 6-7.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, is the highest-ranking Republic of China official ever to attend a public event in Japan since Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972.
Yu said prior to his departure that the theme of this year's Taiwan-Japan forum will focus on new situations in Asia and possible responsible strategies to address changes.

During his first tenure as the Presidential Office secretary-general, Yu concurrently headed a Presidential Office special panel in charge of promoting exchanges and cooperation with Japan. He later served as premier and returned to serve as Chen's chief of staff again after ending his premiership earlier this year.
"The Taiwan-Japan forum can serve as a 'track-two' unofficial dialogue channel, which can contribute to the two countries' policy formulation," Yu said.

In his view, Yu said, substantive Taiwan-Japan relations have made significant progress in recent years. The upcoming Taiwan-Japan forum will discuss what the two countries can do to cope with the emerging new situations in Asia, he added.
Yu will also meet with Japanese politicians, including former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara.
Thanks to Ishihara's promotion on Taiwan's behalf, Yu said the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has increased substantially in recent months.
"I'll take the opportunity to thank Ishihara for his assistance in attracting Japanese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan," Yu said.

Most of the Taiwan-Japan forum activities are closed-door meetings, with the exception of a seminar scheduled for Sept. 7 afternoon which will be open for media coverage. Both Yu and Nakasone, who served as Japanese prime minister from 1982 through 1987, will attend the Sept. 7 seminar.
On behalf of their respective countries, Yu and Nakasone will also speak at a cocktail reception marking the end of the forum on the evening of the same day.

In his speech, Yu will accentuate the need for Taiwan and Japan to forge "track-two" dialogue channels and strengthen their cooperation in promoting their common values of freedom, democracy, human rights and peace in the face of new Asian situations.

Yu will also take the opportunity to express Taiwan's gratitude for Japan's granting of 90-day visa-free treatment for prospective Taiwan visitors, the inclusion of Taiwan Strait peace into the list of strategic goals of the Japan-U.S. defense cooperation, and its support for Taiwan's bid to become a World Health Assembly observer.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation include Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung; Lo Fu-chuan, president of the Association of East Asian Relations; Tseng Yung-hsien, vice chairman of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies; and Tung Li-wen, director of the China Affairs Department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Yu is scheduled to wrap up his Japan visit and return to Taipei Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THE MOST VULNERABLE DEMOCRACY TO 'ASYMMETRICAL THREATS': CHEN

TEXT.P: Terrorists have been waging "asymmetrical war" against some Western democracies, and although Taiwan is not a target of international terrorism, it is most vulnerable among all democracies to "asymmetrical threats, " said President Chen Shui-bian Monday.

Chen made his remarks while addressing Taiwan's rapid strike police force that had just concluded a training program. He called on the crack force to constantly upgrade their combat skills as criminals are also upgrading their tools and techniques.
The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the recent bombings of London's public transit system indicate that the line between social order and national security has blurred, Chen said.
"With a sophisticated plan, a few people can cause great casualties to a certain group of the public and paralyze the operation of a city without any prior warning," he said.
These kinds of asymmetrical attacks and threats pose the gravest challenge to social and national security agencies around the world, Chen added.

He said Taiwan is the most vulnerable among all democracies in the face of these asymmetrical threats. To put it simply, he noted, Taiwan is a country that is under constant threat of war and yet does not have a wartime regime.

The president pointed to China as the source of that constant threat on Taiwan as Beijing's Anti-Secession Law authorizes the People's Liberation Army to use "non-peaceful" means to settle disputes with Taiwan, and China's military has been carefully studying "asymmetrical war tactics."

Chen said judging from the various signs, "We cannot exclude the possibility that China has already infiltrated Taiwan through legal and illegal channels, and is ready to sabotage and launch attacks against us."

He stressed that maintaining good social order is the government's top priority as it is also the No. 1 concern of the people, and that's why he had announced that improved social order, tax reform and the overhaul of the health care system are the major issues that the government must tackle in response to public wishes when he formed his new Cabinet on Feb. 1 this year.

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese tourists were killed in a bus crash in Australia Monday, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said.
Two other people in the tour group organized by Taipei's Cola Tours were critically injured, bureau officials said.
The cause of the crash and the list of casualties has not been made available to the media, the officials said.
