DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILL HELP WITH MRT CORRUPTION PROBE IF NECESSARY

TEXT.P: Prosecutors are investigating if government officials and businesses have colluded in the construction of the mass rapid transit (MRT) system for Kaohsiung and Premier Frank Hsieh is willing to work with prosecutors in the probe if necessary, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Monday.

Cho Jung-tai was responding to requests by opposition legislators that Premier Hsieh recuse himself from the investigations into the contract- awarding and the construction of the MRT system because these took place while Hsieh was still Kaohsiung mayor.

The spokesman said that when the MRT system was approved for NT$195.2 billion (US$6 billion) on Oct. 2, 1998, it was decided that a "build, operate and transfer, " or "BOT" method would be used, meaning that the private sector would be responsible for building and operating the facilities for a certain period of time before transferring the management to the government.
At that time, Vincent Siew was premier, Lin Feng-cheng was the Minister of Transportation and Communications, and Wu Den-yih was Kaohsiung mayor, Cho said.

The contract to build the MRT system was formally signed Jan. 2, 2001, and Chang Chun-hsiung was premier then, Yeh Chu-lan was the Minister of Transportation and Communications and Frank Hsieh was Kaohsiung mayor. The amount approved was NT$181.3 billion.

On questions about why the government adopted a BOT model to build the MRT system and allow a minor investor -- Chairman Chen Min-hsien of the small entity, the Southeast Cement Corp. -- to control the use of the huge construction fund when the government was shouldering the lion's share of the investment in the project, Cho said that BOT was approved in the previous Kuomintang administration and that only then-mayor Wu was unable to push for it.

He said that the Kaohsiung City Government attaches importance to the progress and quality of the construction work, and that the private sector in the project was to be in charge of subcontractors and finding foreign laborers.

On Premier Hsieh's appointment of Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung to investigate the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), Cho said that Hsu's investigation will focus on the division of duties between the central and local governments as well as the supervisory operations of the CLA.

Reports have surfaced of possible collusion between government officials and businesses who reaped huge profits from brokering foreign laborers into the MRT construction for the southern Taiwan city. The matter only came to light after a recent riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) to vent their anger about harsh management and poor living conditions.
Both Taiwan and Thailand have started investigations into irregularities in the wake of the Aug. 21 riot.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS MINISTER DETERMINED TO QUIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top labor affairs official reiterated her determination Monday to step down from her post as minister of the Council of Labor Affairs to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on an MRT development project in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Chen Chu, who tendered her resignation to Premier Frank Hsieh last week, again announced her determination to quit Monday, saying to the public that as a minister, she should not only be self-critical, but should also accept the political responsibility after such a terrible thing like the Aug. 21 riot occurred.

Chen, who was unable to speak several times because of sobs, said that she could not sleep whenever she thought of how the Thai laborers were hurt and exploited in Taiwan -- an incident that seriously jeopardized human rights.

Chen said she joined Taiwan's democratization movement at the age of 19 and has lived through may tribulations over the past 30 years, including political oppression, court trials and doing time in dark jail cells, but she has never failed in her resolve to uphold human rights.

Being a "daughter of Taiwan, " Chen said she defends the nation's reputation in the international community in the same way she protects her parents' image. She said she owes the country, particularly the working class, an apology after the riot, which she said has damaged Taiwan's international image.

She once again refuted rumors suggesting that her resignation was in preparation for her planned run for Kaohsiung mayor in the year-end elections, saying that the goal of her resignation is to recover the people's confidence in the administration.
"My resignation is also a simple reflection of democratic politics, where responsibility is the core value as well a starting point," Chen added.

Premier Hsieh said Saturday that the question of whether or not he accepts Chu's resignation will depend on the results of a probe into the Aug. 21 riot that resulted from Thai laborers' anger over poor treatment by management and shabby living conditions.

Hsieh said that with the council, the Kaohsiung City Government, and Thai employment brokers all involved in the case, it is presently difficult to determine who the culprit is, adding that a determination must await the completion of the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 17.27 points to close at 6,098.78.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,131.95 and hit a low of 6,094 during trading. A total of 2.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.13 billion (US$1.79 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 504 to 373, with 164 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 11 points to close at 6,108, with 9,383 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down one point to end at 6,110, with 156 contracts traded, while December futures lost three points to finish at 6,105, with seven contracts traded. March futures moved down three points to close at 6,107, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,119 for September, 6,111 for October, 6,108 for December, 6,110 for March and 6,100 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

September TE futures remained unchanged at 251, with 2,023 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 0.1 points to finish at 251.1, with 14 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 0.6 points to end at 251, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.
September TF futures lost four points to finish at 936, with 766 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 4.6 points to end at 932.8, with 79 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.107 to close at NT$32.422.
A total of US$793 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.560 and hit a low of NT$32.394.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC WANTS TO WAIT AND SEE IF FUEL PRICE HIKES ARE NECESSARY

TEXT.P: Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) needs to observe the world oil market a bit longer before reaching a decision on whether it is necessary to increase fuel prices in the domestic market, a CPC executive said Monday.
When asked how much longer the state-run company needs to wait and see, Lin Cheng-hsiung, vice president of CPC, said there is no limit to the period of time needed to evaluate the world market.

Lin noted that the price of West Texas Intermediate crude oil dropped slightly to US$68 per barrel after the United States and the 26 member states of the Paris-based International Energy Agency agreed last Friday to release some of their strategic petroleum reserves to combat shortages.
However, their effect on world oil prices still remains to be seen, Lin said.

The CPC has not received any instruction from the Cabinet or the Ministry of Economic Affairs on whether or when to increase domestic oil prices, but as a state-owned enterprise, CPC has a duty to comply with government policy and try not to cause big fluctuations of commodity prices, he added.
Although Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPC) raised its wholesale prices for gasoline and diesel fuel by NT$2.4 and NT$2 per liter, respectively, on Aug. 31, the CPC has not followed suit.

CPC's last price hike was made on Aug. 2 when it followed the move of the FPC to increase prices of gasoline and diesel fuel by NT$1.5 per liter, representing a 7.6 percent increase, the highest in the past decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC VICE CHAIRMAN DENIES WRONGDOING IN RIOT OVER LABOR CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien on Monday categorically denied any wrongdoing in introducing Thai workers whose recent riot in protest against maltreatment by Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. has created a political storm in Taiwan.

Chen made the denial both at a news conference and while being questioned by Kaohisung district prosecutors, who released him after two hours but restricted him from going abroad so he will be present when required. Chen voluntarily reported to the prosecutors.

At the news conference held at the KRTC, an angry Chen denied that the KRTC has taken any commission for bringing in the Thai workers and that some "powerful people" have been involved in alleged profiteering from importing and managing Thai workers.

Chen said he is very upset by the media, whose high profile coverage has implicated him. He said he will quit his vice chairmanship and presidential advisor job, as he called on the public not to link the riot to politics.

He said he is just a small player who cannot possibly control the NT$104.7 billion engineering project of the rapid transit system and whose duty is nothing but mediating and helping resolve difficulties.
"Otherwise, what are the other members of the board doing? Are they just eating shit?" Chen said.
He emphasized that former presidential deputy secretary-general Chen Che-nan had not been involved in bringing in and managing Thai workers.
Thai workers had been brought in directly, so that no mediation was needed, and naturally there was no room for so-called "intervening" by the powers that be, Chen Min-hsien said.

As to his own role, he said he has never been a controversial figure, nor is he a man of questionable character, and he has worked as the KRTC's vice chairman without pay just to see that the operations of the BOT project go smoothly.

Chen said more than 200 Thai human resource companies were vying to get the job of sending workers to Kaohisung, and the KRTC decided to cooperate with three of them because they were recommended by the Thai labor minister.
And now the Thai minister is denying all this, "I don't know what to say," Chen said.

As to why Huapan was selected to manage Thai workers' daily life in Kaohisung, Chen said he had no idea. He said he only knows that the three Thai companies had the right to choose whoever they liked to be their partners in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SUGGESTS WAYS TO FOIL CHINA'S LIES ABOUT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested Monday that the government widely publish a U.N. resolution to foil lies by China about Taiwan.

Lu made the remarks after addressing the opening of an Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission meeting and then took questions from its members for a wide range of issues, including the launching of the Democratic Pacific Union, which was a brainchild of the vice president as well as on how to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Since 1993, Taiwan has every year asked the U.N. Steering Committee, through its diplomatic allies, to place Taiwan's U.N. bid on the General Assembly agenda. Taiwan has been unsuccessful every time because of China's obstruction.

Lu said that before assuming the vice presidency, she spent a lot of time promoting the U.N. bid, but she "lamented" that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has never asked about her opinions on the bid since she became vice president in May 2000.

On how to effectively promote Taiwan's bid to join the U.N., Lu suggested that Taiwan educate the world, especially reminding U.N. members that they have been fooled by China on U.N. Resolution No. 2758 in 1971 which gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

She said that Beijing authorities said to the world that the resolution has ascertained that "Taiwan is part of China, " and that the "People's Republic of China can represent Taiwan, " which she believes are "outright lies."

The resolution states in fact that the People's Republic of China is the only legitimate government of China, Lu said, adding that it has not touched on the relation between Taiwan and China, and has not ascertained that the People's Republic of China represents Taiwan.
Lu said that Beijing has fooled the world for many years, adding that the previous administration and the current one still have "blind spots" in their international publicity campaigns.

Lu also said that recently another report also showed how unscrupulous China is. She said that the Republic of China is a founding member of the United Nations, and was the first one to sign its charter when the world body was founded on Oct. 24, 1945. Reports have said that Beijing has added "People's Republic of" in front of the "China," although it was not even born at the time.
She lamented that the U.N. would condone tampering with history.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN AND JAMES SOONG ON THE POLITICAL WAY OUT: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, the former chairman of the Kuomintang, and James Soong, the chairman of the People First Party, will soon become "has-beens, " despite the media hype they caused by their trips to China, President Annette Lu said Monday.

Speaking at the opening of a meeting of the commissioners of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, Lu said the two opposition leaders' China trips "sent out ripples" which seemed to be significant at the time, but history has proved "the two old men are fading from Taiwan's politics."
"Taiwan is Taiwan, China is China, and all those fed on Taiwan's rice will love Taiwan rather China, and Lien and Soong were trying in vain to create an enthusiasm for China in Taiwan," Lu said.

Some people consider China as a friendly state or even their homeland, and pledge their friendship to Beijing after being greeted in Beijing with a red carpet welcome, but those people found their glory has dissipated like smoke and there is no longer any role for them in Taiwan politics, Lu said.
She was referring to Lien's trip to China from April 26 to May 3, and Soong's trip to China from May 5 to May 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST FIRST ASIAN SOLID-STATE CIRCUITS CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: After two years of strenuous efforts, Taiwan has obtained the right to host the 2005 Asian Solid-State Circuits Conference (ASSCC) in early November, announced TCL Group CEO Hu Cheng-ta Monday.

Hu, who will chair the ASSCC, said that the annual conference will be held Nov. 1-3 in the northern city of Hsinchu, with representatives from semiconductor and IC design sectors of 17 countries in Asia, Europe and America participating.

General Manager Tsai Li-hsing of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Dr. Ken Sakamura, professor of Information Science at the Japanese University of Tokyo, and Kinam Kim, a senior vice president of South Korean Samsung Electrics Co., will be invited to deliver speeches on R&D achievements made in semiconductor and IC design sectors during the three-day conference, Hu noted.

Hu pointed out that Taiwan participates in the International Solid-State Circuits Conference every year and releases many theses relating to the development of semiconductor and IC design industries, thus enabling the country to obtain the right to host the first ASSCC.

The holding of the event in Taiwan will not only reflect the great development potential of the semiconductor industry in Asia, but it will also demonstrate the pivotal role Taiwan is playing in this field, according to Hu.

Leaders from several world-renowned enterprises, such as IBM, Toshiba, Samsung, and Renesas Technology, will unveil application technology concerning unit processors, wireless local area network (WLAN) and 16M SRAM in the upcoming ASSCC, while a total of 118 theses will be released, Hu said.

Coinciding with the three-day symposium, the organizers will also sponsor a design competition and related training programs for university and college students to upgrade the nation's ID design level, Hu went on.
Hu further said that the 2006 Asian Solid-State Circuits Conference will take place in the Chinese city of Hangzhou, while the event for 2007 will be held in South Korea's capital city of Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 TAIWAN GOLF PROS TO COMPETE IN SINGAPORE OPEN

TEXT.P: Thirteen professional golfers from Taiwan will join 131 players from other countries to compete in the 42nd Singapore Open from Sept. 8 to 11 for a record US$2 million in prize money.
The event at the Sentosa Golf Club will see a stunning turnout of players from the Asian Tour rarely seen before at a national open in Asia.

Among the players will be the top five from the Asian Tour's Order of Merit, led by top-ranked Thaworn Wiratchant from Thailand, his compatriot Thongchai Jaidee, who is in second place, Jyoti Randhawa from India and Australia's Terry Pilkadaris and Scott Barr.
The other players from the top-10 will be India's Jeev Milka Singh, Australian Marcus Both, Simon Yates from Scotland and Taiwanese veteran Wang Der-chang.

Taiwan's impressive line-up also includes Lin Keng-chi, Lin Chie-hsiang, Lin Wen-tang, Kao Bo-song, Sung Mao-chang, Chang Tse-peng, Lu Wei-chih, Lu Wei-lan, Lin Wen-ko, Lu Wen-teh, Yeh Chang-ting and Chen Yuan-chi.

Other noted players are Adam Scott of Australia, who marched to victory in the Johnnie Walker Classic in April, his compatriots Nick O'Hern and Craig Parry, Darren Clarke of Northern Ireland and Lee Westwood of the United Kingdom.
The 144 professionals will be vying for the first prize of US$315,000, with US$216,000 for the second-placed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, KMT MIGHT INITIATE PARLIAMENTARY INQUIRY INTO KRTC LABOR RIOT

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" might form a parliamentary committee to conduct its own investigation into the Thai workers' riot in Kaohsiung late last month, an incident that has created a political storm and has led to the resignation of Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu, opposition People First Party (PFP) sources said Monday.
The Legislative Yuan inquiry committee is likely to be discussed when PFP Chairman James Soong meets with his Kuomintang (KMT) counterpart Ma Ying-jeou Wednesday, according to the sources.

The sources said Soong paid a lot of attention to the incident while he was abroad and that he told PFP lawmakers to gather as much information as possible on the riot that has further tarnished Taiwan's human rights image internationally.
Thai workers hired to build Kaohsiung's rapid transit system rioted Aug. 21 in protest against maltreatment by their management firm, Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd.

Soong returned to Taipei early Monday to be greeted by Ma at the airport. The two are expected to meet Wednesday to discuss cooperation in fielding candidates for the year-end city and county elections and in the legislature.

The KMT, PFP and the New Party form the "pan-blue alliance, " which enjoys a majority in the legislature over the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU NOMINATES CANDIDATE FOR CHIAYI MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: The Central Executive Committee (CEC) of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) nominated TSU Deputy Secretary-General Liu Yi-teh Monday to run for the mayorship of Chiayi City in southern Taiwan in year-end elections for local government heads.

Following CEC approval of the nomination at a meeting held in the northern city of Keelung, TSU Secretary-General Cheng Cheng-lung said party officials and legislators will do their utmost to drum up voter support for Liu.

Cheng claimed that as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang are facing "problems of internal integration" in Chiayi City, the TSU stands a fair chance of winning the mayoral election.

The holding of the CEC meeting in Keelung City and fielding Liu to vie for the Chiayi mayorship was aimed at exerting dual pressure on the DPP in the hope that the ruling party will make concessions to TSU candidates in some constituencies in the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors, and township/village chiefs.
Cheng said that during the meeting, the CEC members also discussed the election situation in Keelung City. The TSU has nominated former Legislator Chen Chien-ming to run for the Keelung mayorship.

According to the results of a recent survey, Chen's support rate rose from the initial 5 percent to 12 percent, which Cheng claimed shows that Keelung citizens have high expectations toward the TSU candidate.
Describing Chen as a young candidate with no political burden, Cheng said he is confident that the TSU candidate will gradually take the lead over the DPP candidate, Legislator Wang Tuoh.
However, he added that if the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the TSU fail to integrate its forces, the "pan-greens" will lose the Keelung mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES REACH US$254.09 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a record high of US$254.09 billion as of the end of August, according to statistics released Monday by the Central Bank of China.

The amount represented an increase of US$524 million over the July figure, due largely to revenue from foreign exchange reserve investments and the appreciation of the Euro against the U.S dollar, the statistics show.

The figure made Taiwan the third-largest holder of foreign exchange reserves in the world, behind Japan's US$821.68 billion as of the end of July and China's US$711 billion posted in June, according to bank officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIWAN-JAPAN FORUM TO OPEN IN TOKYO TUESDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan-Japan Forum will open in Tokyo Tuesday, with the participation of government officials, think tank scholars and business executives from the two countries.

Among the participants will be ROC President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, who arrived in Taipei Monday along with 20-plus other members of the Taiwan delegation to the annual conference.

Yu, secretary-general to the president, is the highest-ranking Republic of China official ever to attend a public event in Japan since Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation include Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung; Lo Fu-chuan, president of the Association of East Asian Relations; Lin Song-huann, director of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Tseng Yung-hsien, vice chairman of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies; and Tung Li-wen, director of the China Affairs Department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
The 2005 Taiwan-Japan Forum is being co-sponsored by the Taipei-based Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies and the World Peace Research Institute of Japan.

The theme of this year's forum will focus on new situations in Asia and possible responsible strategies to address changes. Topics will include regional security, economic integration and cooperation, as well as prospects for Taiwan-Japan relations.
Yu said upon his arrival in Tokyo that the Taiwan-Japan forum can serve as a "track-two" unofficial dialogue channel, which can contribute to the two countries' policy formulation.
He was greeted by Koh Se-kai, the ROC representative to Japan, and senior executives of the World Peace Research Institute at the airport.

In his view, Yu said, substantive Taiwan-Japan relations have made significant progress in recent years. The upcoming Taiwan-Japan forum will discuss what the two countries can do to cope with the emerging new situations in Asia.
Yu will also meet with Japanese politicians, including former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara.
Thanks to Ishihara's promotion on Taiwan's behalf, Yu said the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan has increased substantially in recent months.
"I'll take the opportunity to thank Ishihara for his assistance in attracting Japanese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan," Yu said.

Most of the Taiwan-Japan forum activities are closed-door meetings, with the exception of a seminar scheduled for Sept. 7 afternoon which will be open for media coverage. Both Yu and Nakasone, who served as Japanese prime minister from 1982 through 1987, will attend the Sept. 7 seminar.
On behalf of their respective countries, Yu and Nakasone will also speak at a cocktail reception marking the end of the forum on the evening of the same day.

In his speech, Yu will accentuate the need for Taiwan and Japan to forge "track-two" dialogue channels and strengthen their cooperation in promoting their common values of freedom, democracy, human rights and peace in the face of new Asian situations.

Yu will also take the opportunity to express Taiwan's gratitude for Japan's granting of 90-day visa-free treatment for prospective Taiwan visitors, the inclusion of Taiwan Strait peace into the list of strategic goals of the Japan-U.S. defense cooperation, and its support for Taiwan's bid to become a World Health Assembly observer.
Yu is scheduled to wrap up his Japan visit and return to Taipei Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR GROUPS PROTEST AGAINST FILIPINO LABORERS' TREATMENT

TEXT.P: Several labor groups went to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Monday to protest on behalf of laborers from the Philippines working for the Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG's) sixth naphtha cracker plant who they alleged had been beaten and improperly treated.
The FPG later called a press conference to explain the situation and express its appreciation for the contribution by foreign laborers.

The labor groups, including the Hong Kong-based Asia Pacific Mission for Migrants, said Filipino laborers at the naphtha cracker plant in the Mailiao Industrial Zone in Yunlin, southern Taiwan have their wages deducted illegally, live in squalor and eat by the side of a ditch because of a lack of proper dining areas. As a result, they have staged strikes, for which they have been severely mistreated.
On Aug. 2, four Filipino laborers were beaten by security guards, fired without proper reason and deported by the management along with 12 other foreign laborers.
The matter only came to light after flight attendants discovered the mens' injures. The CLA promised to investigate.
Wu Hsin-tze, an FPG manager at the group's sixth naphtha cracker denied that the laborers were beaten at the plant site.
Wu claimed that during the repatriation process, the Filipino laborers had attempted to escape and security men "might have engaged in a scuffle with them," resulting in their injuries.

FPG officials noted that it has been 10 years since the plant was built and that more than 40,000 foreign laborers have been employed there, working in harsh and very windy conditions. He admitted that the construction could not have been completed on schedule without their assistance.

The officials said that the FPG is carrying out a fourth-stage expansion of the naphtha cracker and that there are currently 3,197 Thai laborers and 1,802 Filipino laborers in the Mailiao Industrial zone.

The expansion work is being undertaken by local contractor CTCI Corp. The FPG only introduces foreign laborers in name, but in fact it is the CTCI that is in charge of the hiring, use and management of the foreign laborers, while FPG only exercises "rigorous supervision," they said.

On the wage deduction, they said this was "mainly done" by a manpower brokerage firm commissioned by CTCI Corp., which deducted the wages without explaining the matter, resulting in "misunderstanding."

On July 14, 156 Filipino laborers assembled in their dormitories, saying that their wages in the first month were deducted by 40 percent (equivalent to between NT$6,400 and NT$8,400), the officials said.

On learning about their discontent, the company immediately called a meeting with the CTCI Corp, Samsung Engineering Co. Ltd (SECL) -- another contractor -- as well as the foreign laborers. The Philippine office in Taichung also sent officials to the meeting.

In an attempt to mollify the workers, the FPG asked the CTCI to provide wage receipts in Chinese and English, and said the wages will go directly into the accounts of the laborers and not via the brokerage firm. The brokerage fee should be negotiated between the foreign laborers and the brokerage firm and paid in the Philippines. The money taken was returned July 19.
However, 16 of the laborers refused to work July 15 and deterred others from working. The FPG therefore dismissed and deported them.
The FPG said that if the foreign laborers can produce evidence to show that they were beaten, the FPG will blame the contractor.

Yunlin Magistrate Lee Chin-yung recently visited the Mailiao Industrial Zone to learn about the working conditions of foreign laborers after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) in protest against harsh management and poor living conditions.
Lee was said to be satisfied after the FPG officials briefed him on the humane management and the establishment of smooth communication channels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ROSE TO RECORD HIGH IN AUGUST: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) rose 3.56 percent in August year-on-year, is a record high since December 1998, according to statistics released Monday by the Director General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.
DGBAS official Wu Chao-ming blamed the sharp rise in food prices in the wake of typhoons Haitang and Matsa for the higher-than-expected rise in the index.

Wu said the two typhoons took a heavy toll on agriculture, with Haitang causing damage of NT$3.6 billion (US$111 million) , which is more than the NT$3.1 billion damage suffered by agriculture in the whole of 2004.
As if that weren't enough, Wu said Matsa ravaged the island hot on the heels of Haitang before farmers could clear their land of crops destroyed by Haitang.
As a result, Wu said, vegetable prices are on average 49.61 percent higher than that of the previous August and hit a new record, while fruit prices are 28.07 percent higher.
The vegetable and fruit accounted for 3.01 percent out of the 3.56 percent rise in CPI, Wu went on.
The much-hyped rise in the price of international crude oil drove up the domestic petroleum price by 11.71 percent in August and accounted for a 0.3 percent rise in CPI, Wu said.
Consumers will feel the pain of the hike in oil prices more sharply if the 10 percent hike is maintained for more than one year, the official said.
In that case, he estimated, the CPI will be pushed up by another 0.39 percent to more than 2 percent for the whole year.
Citing statistics compiled by the DGBAS, Wu said the CPI stood at 105.31 in August, which represents a growth of 0.76 percent over the previous month.

The rise brings the average CPI rise in the first eight months of this year to 2.13 percent. However, the core prices, which do not take into account the prices of fresh vegetables, fish and energy, rose only a moderate 0.69 percent in the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TENDERS RESIGNATION OVER RIOT BY THAIS: AIDE

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai has tendered his resignation to Premier Frank Hsieh over a recent riot by Thai laborers working for the southern port city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system, his aides said Monday.

The acting mayor's aides made the remarks after Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said at a news conference earlier in the day that she rejected a plea from Hsieh to stay on the job because she felt responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot.

Responding to press inquiries as to whether Chen Chi-mai will follow the lead of the CLA head and resign over the incident, his aides said the mayor has on many occasions reaffirmed his commitment to accepting any responsibility that he should assume.

According to his aides, Chen Chi-mai first offered to resign verbally to the premier Aug. 27 and then tendered his written resignation Aug. 29. The legislator-turned-acting mayor is scheduled to issue a formal statement on his stance Tuesday, his aides said.
Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai confirmed in the evening that Premier Hsieh has received Chen Chi-mai's resignation letter.
Cho said the Cabinet will handle the top labor administrator's and the acting Kaohsiung mayor's resignation offers on the same standards.

The Aug. 21 riot began when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory after a day off and were barred from bringing in alcohol and cigarettes. The workers burned cars and battled police with stones and slingshots. The laborers, who are building Kaohsiung's MRT system, complained about rigorous management rules and poor living conditions.
On Monday, Chen Chu took political responsibility for the situation.

"The fact that the foreign workers were deprived and were being hurt dealt a severe blow to my human rights values, and it gave me pain and unease, " she said. "I don't just blame myself but want to take responsibility for it."
Thais make up the largest group of foreign workers in Taiwan. There are about 94,000 on the island, employed mostly in the construction industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU ACCUSES KRTC VICE CHAIRMAN OF LYING

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) claimed Monday that Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien was lying when he publicly denied knowing Yaoming Enterprise Co. and Huapan Administration Consultant Co., the companies that acted for KRTC in hiring the Thai laborers that rioted late last month.

TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming (Kaohsiung City) said the name of Yaoming Enterprise was on the witness column of the contract signed by KRTC and the Thai authorities, which means Chen was lying publicly, Lo said.

In addition, he continued, in an application form, employer KRTC delegated the hiring job to Yaoming Enterprise Co., whose chief executive officer is Wang Neng-hui, whose father, Wang Yao-li, is the CEO of Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which has been accused by Thai workers of exploiting them.
TSU Legislator Tseng Tsahn-deng (Kaohsiung City) said the riot has hurt Taiwan's international reputation and yet Chen has not made any apology.

Tseng said the prosecution should investigate who is at fault and that the Kaohsiung city government should take over the build-operate-transfer (BOT) project instead of continuing to authorize the scandal-ridden consultant companies to manage the labor force.

TSU legislative caucus convener Ho Min-hsien praised Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu for resigning to take political responsibility but expressed hoped that she will show her courage and disclose who are the "powerful people" behind the saga.
Kaohsiung County's Labor Affairs Bureau has finished its probe and decided to punish Yaoming Enterprise Co. for violating the employment and service law.
Bureau official Chen Mei-hsi said because Yaoming was not operating at the place of its registration, it will also be fined between NT$300,000 and NT$1.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD: 2ND-PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM WILL BE DISASTROUS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's much-hyped second phase of constitutional reforms will lead the country to disaster, opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong claimed Monday.
Soong, who has just returned from a vacation in the United States that day, said the president has reneged on an agreement with him in a February meeting by pressing for the reforms.

The PFP chief did not elaborate, but during that February meeting, the president basically reiterated promises he made in his 2000 inaugural address that he will not push for Taiwan independence during his term.

Soong also quoted what he termed U.S. sources as telling him that there is no chance whatsoever in the next two years for any improvement in government ties between Taiwan and China, thereby giving the PFP a good chance to play an active role in promoting friendly exchanges between Taiwan and China.

Citing the president's announcement the previous day that he will not give accreditation to Chinese schools during his term, Soong said this exposes the president's lack of confidence in himself and will not help Taiwan's competitiveness at all.
"Taiwan's competitiveness will not be boosted by putting China in a bad light, and the president's decision, based as it is on political considerations, is unacceptable," Soong said.

He also reconfirmed his party's opposition to the government's request for NT$80 billion for flood-control programs and NT$340 billion for arms purchases, claiming that the budgets are "too sketchy" to be examined, while the administration's "poor job performance" casts doubt on its ability to use the budget properly.
He promised to strengthen opinion exchanges within the heavily fractured PFP, but added that different opinions among members are common for any democratic party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA UNVEILS LIST OF LOCAL CASUALTIES IN AUSTRALIA BUS CRASH

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese tourists -- a man and a woman -- were killed in a bus crash in Australia Monday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Five other people in the tour group organized by Taipei's Cola Tours were critically injured, MOFA officials said, adding that the remaining 15 group members also sustained minor injuries in the accident.
The deceased were identified as Ko Poh-wei and Liu Hsiu-lan. One of the five critically injured was a man identified as Ko Pei-wen. The injured are receiving treatment in five Australian hospitals.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Taiwan's representative office in Sydney has been in contact with Australian police and hospitals and added that the office will offer all necessary assistance to the victims.

According to foreign wire service reports, two people were killed and 22 injured in Australia Monday when a bus full of Taiwanese tourists on their way to visit a temple ran off a road and rolled 10 meters down an embankment.
The 24-seat bus was taking the group to the Nan Tien Temple near the coastal city of Wollongong south of Sydney when the accident happened, the reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KEEPS PUSHING FOR PRESIDENT'S ATTENDANCE AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The government is still doing its best to get permission for President Chen Shui-bian to attend the 2005 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in mid-November in South Korea, a presidential aide said Monday.

Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, made the remark in response to media reports that a cartoon figure of Chen was replaced by that of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh at an exhibition of cartoon figures for leaders who will attend the upcoming APEC summit. The exhibition started Monday in Busan City, the venue of this year's annual event.

The move does not represent the official stance of the host country because any APEC resolution must be adopted based upon a consensus reached among all member states, Huang explained, adding that whether Chen will be able to attend the informal APEC leadership meeting cannot be judged only from a cartoon exhibition.
Huang stressed that all relevant government agencies will continue efforts to push for Chen to attend the annual APEC summit in person.
Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, has represented Chen at the annual APEC leadership meeting over the past three years.

APEC is one of the few international organizations to admit both Taipei and Beijing. Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has never been allowed to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

APEC, which is dedicated to promoting the free flow of information, trade and investment, groups 21 economies, including Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Sept. 6, or the 3rd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1522: The Vittorio, a Spanish ship commanded by Sebastian del Cano, reaches Seville after sailing around the world, and is the only survivor of a fleet of five ships that set sail three years earlier seeking a westward passage to the Indies.
1566: Suleiman I, known as "Suleiman the Magnificent," dies in Constantinople at the age of 72. He was the Sultan of Turkey (1520-1566) under whose government the Ottoman Empire reached the height of its power.
1757: Marquis de Lafayette, French statesman and soldier who fought with the American colonists for independence, is born. He was also a major figure in the French Revolution.
1866: Serica, Taiping and Ariel, the three British tea clippers which left Foochow at the end of May, reach London within two hours of each other after a 25,750 km race all the way from southern China.
1876: John James Rickard Macleod, Scottish physiologist, is born. He shared a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1899: John Hay, United States Secretary of State, starts the idea of the Open-Door Policy by sending notes to the competing powers, including Britain, Germany and France, asking them to maintain complete equality for all the nations that wished to trade with China.
1901: William McKinley, the 25th president of the United States, is shot by an anarchist in Buffalo, New York and is fatally wounded. His presidency was marked by the Spanish-American War, the annexation of Cuba and the Philippines, and the passage of the Gold Standard Act.
1913: Hideyo Noguchi, Japanese-born American bacteriologist, discovers the cause of rabies by sorting out its virus.
1940: Chungking is proclaimed provisional capital of China.
1942: Chang Chi-luan, editor in chief of the Takungpao, a daily newspaper in China, dies of lung disease in Chungking at the age of 54.
1960: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC national decathlon champion, wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic silver medal.
1965: India invades West Pakistan. Some 2,500 Indians died in the 17-day war.
1966: South African Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd, who was responsible for much of the country's white racist apartheid system, is assassinated in Parliament by a parliamentary messenger.
1968: The Kingdom of Swaziland in Southern Africa gains its independence from Britain.
1975: A massive earthquake rocks the town of Lice in Turkey, killing more than 2,350 and injuring some 3,000 others.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan sends congratulations to King Sobhuza II on the national day of the Kingdom of Swaziland.
1976: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun leaves for Seoul to take part in the Sino-Korean ministerial conference on economic cooperation.
1979: The Cabinet announces an extension of the ROC's territorial waters to 12 nautical miles and establishment of a 200-mile economic zone.
1988: Thomas Gregory, 11, from London, becomes the youngest person to swim the English Channel, completing the trip from Cap Griz-Nez to Dover in 12 hours.
1989: Mainland Chinese Air Force pilot Chiang Wen-hao defects to the ROC by landing his fighter jet on Kinmen's Shangyi airport.
1991: The Soviet Union recognizes the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as independent.
1992: Direct air service between the ROC and Vietnam resumes for the second time in 13 months.
1998: Akira Kurosawa, noted Japanese filmmaker, dies at the age of 88. His internationally acclaimed works, including "Rashomon," "Ran," and "The Seven Samurai," often concerned traditional Japanese institutions.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui meets with Salvadoran President Francisco Flores to exchange views on how to strengthen bilateral relations between the Republic of China and El Salvador.
2000: While taking part in a rescue drill, a helicopter crashes into a stream in southern Taiwan, injuring five men.
2001: Taiwan's Central News Agency and Spain's Agencia EFE sign an information service cooperation agreement, pledging to strengthen news and photo service exchanges as well as cooperation in training and mutual support of correspondents.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Absolute truth is indestructible. Being indestructible, it is eternal. Being eternal, it is self-existent. Being self-existent, it is infinite. Being infinite, it is vast and deep. Being vast and deep, it is transcendental and intelligent."

Los Angeles Times: Official Death Toll Starts to Mount. Thousands of Bodies Are Expected in a Recovery Process That May Last Months.
The nationa's senior health official bluntly predicted that Hurricane Katrina's death toll would rise into the thousands as Louisiana medical authorities tallied the first sobering evidence--59 dead in makeshift morgues and another 100 corpses lined on docks east of the flood-swept city.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Putin Denies Rift With Europe
President Vladimir Putin told a group of leading Western experts at the Kremlin on Monday that Russia did not have any major rifts with the European Union over the velvet revolutions in Ukraine and Georgia, but said that the West should listen to Moscow regarding what he said were Russia's legitimate interests in the former Soviet Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Medan crash kills 149.
An Indonesian domestic airliner slammed into a busy neighbourhood in Medan shortly after take-off yesterday, killing 102 people on board and 47 on the ground.
Among those killed in the crash were North Sumatra Governor Tengku Rizal Nurdin and a legislator, Abdul Halim Harahap.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 15 passengers survived in Medan crash.
A Boeing 737-300 disintegrated on impact and burst into flames yesterday morning, setting on fire parked vehicles and dozens of homes barely 500 metres from Medan's Polonia Airport runway.
The crash killed 102 passengers on board and 47 on the ground, but 15 passengers survived in this tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE CONTINUES TO REJECT ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan continued to stonewall a long-stalled arms procurement package Tuesday, with the legislative procedure committee refusing to put it on the legislative agenda.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said it is regrettable that the opposition pan-blue alliance-controlled procedure committee still blocked the bill even after the Cabinet had made a goodwill response to some opposition lawmakers' suggestion that part of the procurement package be financed by the regular defense budget to allow for closer legislative scrutiny.

The package comprises three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries. For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has declined to screen the package for various reasons.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, said recently he thinks that the legislature should begin to deal with the arms procurement bill when the new legislative session formally opens Sept. 13. However, most KMT and PFP lawmakers seemed not to see eye to eye with Wang on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECOGNIZING CHINESE DEGREES 'DIFFICULT' PRIOR TO ASSESSMENT: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday that it will be difficult for the government to recognize academic degrees issued by China's colleges and universities before an assessment is carried out and complimentary measures are formulated.
The head of the nation's top China policy planner made the remarks before attending an annual meeting of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

His remarks came in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's statement Sunday that the government will not recognize mainland Chinese college and university academic degrees during his remaining term in office.

Wu said the government has to take current realities into consideration when formulating its policy, noting that more than 160 colleges and universities in Taiwan already face serious problems in recruiting enough students.
A rash decision to recognize mainland Chinese academic accreditation would make the situation even more difficult for Taiwan's colleges and universities, he said.

In addition, he pointed out, there exists the rampant problem of fake academic degrees in China, adding that "it will be difficult for a further opening" prior to educational authorities discussing seriously procedures concerning accreditation.

On suggestions that Taiwan colleges and universities open their doors to Chinese students, Wu said that several Taiwan colleges have already accepted Chinese students under exchange programs and that related government agencies are discussing how to establish a mechanism on cross-strait recognition of academic credits.

Regarding the EMBA programs set up in China by several Taiwan colleges, Wu said that progress has been good, noting that the schools can now recruit students other than Taiwan businesspeople operating in China and the Taiwan executives working for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 3,000 EXPECTED TO ATTEND 'TAIWAN REPUBLIC' FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Over 3,000 pro-independence activists are expected to attend the "Taiwan Republic national flag-raising" ceremony slated for Thursday in front of the Presidential Office, the convener of the 908 Taiwan Republic Movement said Tuesday.

Wang Hsien-chi made the prediction at a news conference for the upcoming activity, which will be held to mark what he called "Taiwan Independence Day, " which falls on Sept. 8 -- the date that Japan gave up its territorial claims to Taiwan after signing a peace treaty with the Allied nations in San Francisco in 1951.
Wang said that his group hopes that a new "Taiwan Republic" constitution can be promulgated and that the movement to rectify the name of Taiwan can achieve its goal by 2008.
He urged those who support the campaign to join the Sept. 8 flag-raising ceremony, which he described as "the first of its kind in 400 years."

Wang also mentioned that five young people will read a statement of the Taiwan Republic Movement in five different languages, including Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka, English and one of the languages of Taiwan's aboriginal tribes, at the flag-raising event to mark the official beginning of the independence movement.

Wang said he hopes the next president of Taiwan will announce the promulgation of the new "Taiwan Constitution" at the time when he or she officially assumes office in 2008, and that by that time, Taiwan can submit an application for a seat in the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan," he said.
The opposition Taiwan Solitary Union and the Taiwan Association of University Professors have said they will send representatives to take part in the flag-raising ceremony, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUBMARINE SUCCESSFULLY TORPEDOES TARGET FRIGATE IN ANNUAL DRILL

TEXT.P: As an ROC submarine successfully torpedoed a target vessel in the sea southwest of Taiwan Tuesday, ROC Navy Commander-in-Chief Chen Pang-chih stood up and applauded the roughly 800 officers and sailors participating in this year's "Whale Hunting Torpedo Firing Exercise."
Chen said that owing to quite a number of variables at the scene, it was not easy to hit the target from a submarine as even sophisticated weapons are difficult to maneuver.
The fifth "Whale Hunting" torpedo ever fired by the ROC Navy hit the central part of the target ship, which was not carrying any fuel or explosives, rupturing the hull and sinking it.
The whole process was broadcast live by the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, a research body run by the Ministry of National Defense.
The ROC Navy Fleet Headquarters said the exercise was aimed at testing the submariners' abilities, the commanders' tactical skills with torpedoes and the efficacy of the weapons.
Two submarines took part in the demonstration, but only one of them fired at the target ship.

During a recent joint air force and navy nighttime exercise, dubbed "Han Kuang No. 21, " submarines also succeeded in firing torpedoes that passed a fleet of ships before hitting their targets 5,000 meters away.

Chen said Tuesday's exercise was not a military public relations activity to convince lawmakers of the importance of buying more submarines for the country. A special budget bill for a major arms purchase from the United States is still languishing in the legislature.

However, Chen used the opportunity to stress that submarines are a very effective deterrent, adding that Taiwan also needs anti-submarine aircraft to ensure the safety of its shipping routes as the enemy has improved silent running technology on its submarines.

Naval headquarters said China's submarines far outnumber those of Taiwan, posing a threat to sea traffic around the island. If the navy can acquire eight more submarines, as proposed by the government in its U.S. procurement package, the navy will be able to increase the risks and uncertainty for the Chinese navy.
Moreover, when the ROC Navy is capable of deterring China's naval actions, the business sector will be reassured of the country's investment environment, the navy added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 41.36 points to close at 6,140.14.
The bourse opened at 6,141.28 and fluctuated between 6,145.3 and 6,123.84 during trading. A total of 2.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$60.37 billion (US$1.85 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
The two other major stocks categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down at 0.7 percent and cement stocks losing 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 548 to 336, with 153 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HSIEH STILL PONDERING RESIGNATIONS OF TWO OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will wait until all the facts are in regarding a recent riot by Thai laborers before he decides what to do with the resignations tendered by two top officials who are trying to shoulder responsibility for the incident.

The resignations of Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai have put the premier in a cleft stick as he wants to properly assign political responsibility, but doesn't want to dismiss important officials whose direct connection with the riot is questionable.
Thais working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system rioted Aug. 21 over poor housing and living conditions and a failure to give them their human rights.

During a visit to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Hsieh called on the public not to encourage a culture of "the more you do, the more mistakes you make" that will scare away competent and responsible people from serving in government.
He also asked the people not to demand somebody's head immediately after a scandal erupts, a move that he said will blur the focus of the issue.

Hsieh praised Chen Chu for being a "brave and responsible" Cabinet member who has made a great contribution to the government. If such a good minister leaves the government because of unreasonable pressure, it will be "a loss for society," he added.
He said that he had told both Chens to calm down since speculation on the incident has caused people to lose sight of the critical points at issue.

For example, he said the media is demanding to know how the decision was made to build the Kaohsiung MRT as a BOT (build, operate and transfer) project? Moreover, why has the government invested NT$150 billion, only to hand over the project to the private sector without ever thinking of controlling the process by itself?

He said the central issues here are: who made that critical decision and when? "These critical issues have not been discussed, " he claimed, noting that all the answers actually can be found in official documents.

As to the political responsibility for the fiasco, he said both Chens have some "responsibility of supervision, " but to what extent should they be held accountable has yet to be determined. He said he will wait for the report that will determine the administrative responsibility of all officials related to the incident before deciding whether to accept their requests to quit.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: Siniscalco's stance on Bank of Italy controversy is personal, but realistic.
Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Monday that Minister of Finance and Economics Domenico Siniscalco's stance on Bank of Italy controversy is personal, but is in many ways realistic. Siniscalco urged the Italian central bank's governor Antonio Fazio to step down for the sake of the bank's and country's credibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR APOLOGIZES OVER THAI LABORER RIOT

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai on Tuesday apologized to the public over the controversy triggered by a recent riot by Thai laborers working for the southern port city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system.

Chen was several times choked with emotion when he read a statement at a news conference held at the city government, stressing that the ordeal he had been through since the Aug. 21 riot was greater than he had originally expected. He left after reading the statement without responding to any questions.

Chen said that after the riot, he had offered to resign verbally to Premier Frank Hsieh Aug. 28 and tendered his resignation to the Executive Yuan Aug. 30 to shoulder his political responsibility as city head.

In order not to affect the progress of the construction work, the city government asked the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) -- the employers of the Thai laborers -- to improve the living conditions, end its contract with Huapan Co., -- the company in charge of the management of the Thai laborers, reshuffle the KRTC, resettle the Thai laborers, and form a task force to investigate the incident.
The city government tried to solve the problem without dancing to the tune of wild speculation, Chen said.

On some reports alleging that his father, Chen Che-nan, a former Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, was involved in the lucrative introduction of Thai laborers for the KRTC, this was hurtful and unbearable, he said.
He stressed that his integrity can be examined over the past decade in politics, and that he and his family would not profit from their duties.

He also said that he was "disheartened" to read reports that a battle line between the two Chens -- meaning himself and Chen Chu, the chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs -- had been drawn to jockey for position to run as the party's candidate in the 2006 Kaohsiung mayor election, saying that he only had his mind on city administration at work, and not on the election.
Both Chens have offered to resign over the riot in which Thai laborers vented their anger against what they perceived as harsh management and poor living conditions.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that both Chens are outstanding members of the party, and that the Executive Yuan is expected to handle their resignation offers properly.
William Lai, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, also expressed the hope that reports will not relate their resignation to factional fighting within the DPP or the mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.164 to close at NT$32.586.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 38 points to end at 6,148, with 344 contracts traded, while December futures gained 53 points to finish at 6,156, with nine contracts traded.
