DOC.HEADLINE: THAI WORKERS IN TAIWAN WIRE US$400 MILLION BACK HOME IN 2004
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Sept. 6 (CNA) (By Wu Hsie-chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Thais working in Taiwan wired around 16.2 billion baht (US$400 million) back to their country in 2004, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Thai Farmer Research Center.

The tallies show the number of Thais applying for work in Taiwan decreased over the past few years. In 2000, there were over 100,000 Thais working in Taiwan; the amount dropped to 94,000 in 2001, 79,000 in 2002, 75,000 in 2003, and further to 69,000 last year. The amount of money the Thais wired home also fell from 25 billion baht in 2000. Despite that, Taiwan was still the largest market for Thai labor exports.

The center also estimated that from January to July, the number of Thais working on the island stood at 28,000. The laborers remitted near five billion baht to Thailand during that period, it said, noting that over 100,000 households are dependant on the money for survival.

Regarding a recent call by Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra for the Thai laborers to return home after the riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung rapid transit line projects Aug. 21 in protest against poor living condition, center researchers warned that if all the laborers in Taiwan return home and stayed, their need to find work would be a big burden for Thailand. Thailand's unemployment would worsen, while over 1,000 employment brokerage companies would also be affected, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG EARTHQUAKE HITS EAST OF HUALIEN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.1 on the Richter scale struck about 60 kilometers east of Hualien Tuesday morning, sending shock waves across Taiwan, the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
The tremor was felt in Taipei, rocking buildings and causing goods in stores to fall from shelves. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.
The tremor hit at 9:16 a.m. Its source was 11.7 kilometers below the sea floor, with the epicenter located at 23.97 degrees north latitude and 122.23 degrees east longitude.

The quake was felt as a magnitude 3 in northeastern Taiwan, with the force weakening to magnitude 2 in northern and central Taiwan, and to magnitude 1 in southern Taiwan, according to seismologists at the CWB.
Taiwan is an island frequently hit by earthquakes. On Sept. 21, 1999, a 7.6-magnitude earthquake destroyed 40,000 homes and killed 2,378 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAS NO JAPAN LAYOVER PLAN: TOP AIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian has no plan to make a transit stop in Japan during his upcoming Central America diplomatic tour, his chief of staff said Tuesday in Tokyo.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks at a news conference held after his meeting with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara.

Fielding questions from Japanese reporters on whether he would take advantage of his current trip to arrange for President Chen to make a layover in Japan on his way to Central America later this month, Yu said, the speculation is groundless.
"Chen would probably make a transit stop in the United States en route to Central America and he has no Japan layover plans," Yu said.

Yu arrived in Tokyo Monday to attend a Taiwan-Japan forum on relations between the two countries as well as Asia-Pacific regional security and economic integration. Yu is the highest-ranking Taiwan official ever to attend a public event in Japan since Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.
President Chen is scheduled to travel to Nicaragua later this month to attend a summit meeting with the top leaders of Taiwan's allies in Central America and visit several Caribbean countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT COMMENTS ON OPPOSITION BLOCKING ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed deep regret Tuesday over continued efforts by opposition parties to block an arms procurement draft bill, saying that opposition legislators have boycotted the bill more than 26 times.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with American Heritage Foundation Chairman Edwin Jr. Feulner at the Presidential Office.
The president told his guest that he has publicly spoken for the proposed arms procurement more than 80 times since he was sworn in for his second four-year term on May 20, 2004.

It is regrettable that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) have continually filibustered the draft statute governing an arms procurement package submitted by the Executive Yuan last year to the legislature for deliberation, Chen said.

In a goodwill gesture to opposition parties, Chen pointed out that the government has made pragmatic adjustments to the required outlay for several items in the package by listing Patriot anti-missile batteries in the regular budget instead of the originally proposed special budget.

Referring to recent remarks by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, that the legislature should begin to deal with the arms procurement bill when the new legislative session formally opens Sept. 13, Chen said he would be happy to see such a positive development of the issue.

In the face of China's rise, especially its military expansion, Taiwan must beef up its self-defense capabilities, Chen stressed. He also thanked U.S. President George W. Bush for having approved the sale of a package of advanced weaponry to Taiwan to help upgrade the island's defense capabilities.

The arms procurement package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. The budget plan for the procurement has been blocked for two consecutive legislative sessions due to opposition from the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature.
Over the past five years, the KMT and the PFP have used their slim majority in the legislature to boycott various policy initiatives launched by the government.

During the meeting, Chen also expressed again his sympathies to families of those who were killed by Hurricane Katrina in the southern U.S. states, saying that he immediately extended his concern to Mississippi State Governor Haley Barbour after he learned about the devastating natural disaster.
On behalf of the Taiwan people, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated US$2 million to the United States last Friday for the relief of victims of the hurricane.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY TO HAVE ASIA'S LARGEST MUSEUM PARK
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, Sept. 6 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Tainan County is set to become home to Asia's largest museum park after a six-year-old plan to build a metropolitan park in Jenteh township was brought back to life with the injection of new funds from the Ministry of the Interior and the Chi Mei Group.
The NT$600 million project is being jointly developed by the Tainan County Government and the state-owned Taiwan Sugar Corp.
Chi Mei Group has pledged to spend NT$1 billion to build a museum in the park. A donation ceremony will be held Sept. 9 for Chi Mei to present the gift to the county government.

According to the plan, the Tainan Museum Park, covering an area of 40 hectares, will present indigenous cultures, industries, landscapes and customs, while stressing the theme of coexistence with the local ecology.
After completion, the park will also be an ideal place for artists to exhibit their works outdoors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN OFFICIALS IN KENYA TO NEGOTIATE RELEASE OF TAIWNESE SHIPS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday that officials sent by his ministry have traveled to Kenya to communicate with Somalian rebels who have held three Taiwan fishing vessels since mid-August for a ransom of US$1.5 million.
"It is hoped that after two or three days, we'll have news that the public will like to hear," Chen said.

The three fishing boats -- the Kaohsiung-based "Chungyi No. 218," the Hsiaoliuchiu-based "Hsinlienfa No. 36" and the "Chengchingfeng" -- have not been in contact since they entered a Somalian fishing port Aug. 16 for refueling and maintenance.
The three hijacked boats have 13 Chinese crewmen, 14 Indonesians, 12 Filipinos and four Vietnamese.
The shipowners later came to learn that the three ships had been hijacked by Somalian insurgents and appealed to the foreign ministry Aug. 24 for assistance.

Chen said that the government is very concerned about the safety of the three ships and its crew members, adding that President Chen Shui-bian had inquired about the situation several times, and that the ministry also sent officials to Kenya. The ministry also contacted the families of the crew members to keep them abreast of the rescue operation.

He said that as the matter involves personal safety, the ministry cannot reveal how it is negotiating with the insurgents, adding that the ministry understands the emotional response of the families of the crew being held hostage.

The ministry is exhausting every channel in its attempt to rescue the sailors, and is soliciting assistance from relevant governments, international organizations and the nation's missions to Europe and Africa, as well as sending officials to Kenya for better communications.
So far, the ministry has learned that "the ship and the personnel are safe," he added.

Foreign affairs ministry spokesman Michel Lu said that rebels from one of the five warlords of Somalia took the Taiwanese ships. Four ships have been taken by Somalian rebels so far, showing that the rebels are not only targeting Taiwan ships.
Noting that the central government, five warlords and Muslim elders are the major forces in Somalia, he said that negotiations are very complicated and require great patience.

He said the aim of negotiations is to ensure the personnel safety and their release without having to pay ransom, and even if ransom is paid, it should be kept to a minimum as long as the hostages are safe and sound.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR POLITICAL LEADERS MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the nation's political leaders Tuesday to sit down as soon as possible and talk about major issues facing the country.

Meeting commissioners of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) at the Presidential Office, Chen said uniting Taiwan and normalizing cross-Taiwan Strait relations are two major issues that call for an early solution.
He admitted that it's getting more and more difficult to promote cross-strait policy, noting that the crux of the problem is not China's pressure, but Taiwan's own disunity.

"If there is only one voice in Taiwan, the other side [China] will have to deal with the government; if our voices are discordant -- if there are only politicians vying to concede to the other side because of election calculations or personal agendas, allowing China to drive a wedge in Taiwan society by striking at the government and weakening Taiwan -- this absolutely will not serve the interests of the 23 million people in Taiwan," Chen said.

He said cross-strait exchanges are not a zero-sum game or an all- or-nothing choice. "We must not restrain ourselves by supposing that China does not exist, such that we need not have anything to do with it," he said.

On the other hand, he continued, "We cannot harbor any illusions about China, thinking that by bowing low we will win some favor from it. Nor can we echo China's tunes, forcing the government to make one concession after another to it."
Chen criticized "a certain party's chairman" for promising to realize the goal of "opening up three links with China" if and when his party wins back power in 2008.

Shifting the whole responsibility to not opening up the three links with China on the government, trying to make this an election issue, is a "severe distortion of the facts" and "an act of placing partisan interests above national interests, " Chen accused, adding that this is a "very dangerous" move.

The president claimed that the biggest stumbling block to the three links between Taiwan and China is not Taiwan, but China, because China insists that Taiwan accept its "one China" principle before any talks can be held.

He claimed that if Taiwan accepts China's "one China" principle or "one country, two systems" formula in order to negotiate terms of opening up the three links, Taiwan would be losing ground and totally surrendering to China, and downgrading itself to the level of a regional government of China.
He said he believes that such harsh conditions for opening up the three links with China will not be accepted by whichever political party is in power in Taiwan.

In order to forge a consensus on and avoid over-politicizing cross-strait policy issues, he said in his inaugural speech last year that he had called for a political party leaders meeting to form a "Cross-strait Peace and Development Commission" and to draft "Guidelines for Cross-strait Peace and Development."
He said more than a year has elapsed since that time, and now he would like to urge party leaders again to sit down and discuss a way of promoting cross-strait peace and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL DEFENDS REJECTION OF ACCREDITATION OF CHINSE SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: An education official defended President Chen Shui-bian's rejection of accreditation to Chinese schools Tuesday, saying it meets the expectation of most local universities.

Vice Education Minister Fan Sun-lu said most of Taiwan's universities and colleges didn't want her ministry to give accreditation to Chinese schools out of concerns it would make it even harder to find enough students.
She also dismissed as a "political gambit" China's move this year to reduce tuition and fees imposed on Taiwan students to the same level as that for Chinese students.

Fan cast doubts on China's measures, saying they are designed to attract Taiwan students, but probably will not be enforced honestly and Taiwan students might not be treated the same as their Chinese counterparts in terms of studying.

She said Taiwan's high education is excellent and recognized around the world and her ministry has urged local universities to cooperate with foreign schools to broaden students' horizons through education, adding that local students should be confident in the quality of local education.
She made the comments after President Chen said on Sunday that he will not give accreditation to Chinese schools as long as he is in office to ensure local universities can get enough students.

Chen's announcement prompted criticism to the effect that the president should withdraw accreditation to foreign universities by the same token although that would only spoil local universities and downgrade their teaching levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Nominates Roberts as Chief Justice; President Seeks Quick Approval With Another Seat Left to Fill.
President Bush nominated John G. Roberts Jr. yesterday as the 17th chief justice of the United States, promoting his nominee for associate justice to lead the Supreme Court and the rest of the federal judiciary even before Roberts was confirmed for the first assignment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF VISITS TOKYO GOVERNOR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian paid a courtesy visit to Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Tuesday.

Expressing his joy at visiting an old friend, Yu Shyi-kun extended his gratitude to Ishihara for promoting tourism to Taiwan. Thanks to Ishihara recommendation, Yu said, the number of Japanese people who traveled to Taiwan for sightseeing from January to August grew nearly 40 percent over the level of the same period last year.

During the 40-minute meeting, they exchanged opinions on a wide range of issues, including Taiwan's constitutional reform and national security. Yu made the visit in the company of national policy adviser to the president Yeh Kuo-hsing, ROC Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai and several officials of the representative office.

At a news conference after the meeting, Yu said he told Ishihara he feels regret over Beijing's decision to withdraw from the "Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMA) " -- an organization set up under the initiation of the Tokyo metropolitan governor in 2001 -- in protest against Taipei's participation.
Both Taiwan and Japan are willing to contribute to regional peace and stability, Yu said, noting that Taiwan would like to be more involved in international activities.

Yu arrived in Japan Monday for the 2005 Taiwan-Japan Forum that opened in Tokyo Tuesday. As secretary-general to the president, Yu is the highest-ranking ROC official ever to attend a public event in Japan since Tokyo switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972.
The Taiwan-Japan Forum is being co-sponsored by the Taipei-based Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies and the World Peace Research Institute of Japan.

The theme of this year's forum will focus on new situations in Asia and possible responsible strategies to address changes. Topics will include regional security, economic integration and cooperation, as well as prospects for Taiwan-Japan relations.

Most of the forum activities are closed-door meetings, with the exception of a seminar scheduled for Sept. 7 that will be open to the media. Yu and former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will attend the seminar.
Yu is scheduled to return to Taipei Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO LEGITIMACY' TO SHUT TAIWAN OUT OF WHO: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: There is no legitimacy for the World Health Organization (WHO) to shut Taiwan out of the world health body, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Michel Lu, director-general of MOFA's Department of Culture and Information, made the remarks when he addressed 250 people from more than 20 countries participating in the international Rotary Youth Leadership Awards (RYLA) on the fourth day of a seven-day camp.
The RYLA originated in Australia in 1959. It is a training program for youths aged 20-30 aimed at emphasizing leadership, citizenship and personal growth.

In a speech titled "The Republic of China (Taiwan) : A Story of Success, " Lu touched on the issues of the globalization of Taiwan, international participation, international competition and Taiwan's non-governmental organizations.

For the sake of the health of the 23 million people of Taiwan, and out of a desire to contribute on health issues, Taiwan has been trying to join the WHO, Lu said, adding that the charter of the WHO states that it wants all people to receive the highest possible level of health.

Lu said that the right to health is a basic human right and Taiwan wants to become an observer of the WHO so as to contribute to world health cooperation. It is dangerous to exclude Taiwan from a global outbreak alert and response network (GOARN) under the WHO, he added.

He said China has opposed Taiwan's participation in the WHO due to political confrontation and the WHO has agreed to shut Taiwan out of the organization, which he claimed is not true to the law, unprofessional and lacks moral legitimacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Bush Makes Return Visit; Two Levees Secured
President Bush returned to the Gulf Coast, and Army engineers resealed two levees that had been breached and cautiously began pumping water out of New Orleans.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Floodwaters Recede In New Orleans
The floodwaters in New Orleans were being pumped back into Lake Pontchartrain as rescue crews from as far away as California trolled the evacuated city for stragglers and authorities braced for what the receding deluge would reveal.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER UNFAMILIAR WITH CHINESE AFFAIRS: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who has served a two-year stint as vice minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) from 1991 to 1993, is "probably unfamiliar" with Chinese affairs, MAC Minister Joseph Wu alleged Tuesday.

Citing Ma's statement made Sept. 3 that direct transport links with China can be launched within two years if the KMT is elected to power in the 2008 presidential election, Wu said Ma "obviously" does not understand that China is quite rigid in terms of the conditions it imposes for such links.

Taiwan's efforts to build up trust with China by pushing for bilateral negotiations on opening passenger charter flights and cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait is more pragmatic, Wu claimed.
According to Wu, his department has worked out a comprehensive plan for the negotiations and is pushing for it step by step.

However, he admitted that passenger charter flights for the forthcoming Mid-autumn Festival, which falls on Sept. 19, might not be possible because of China's lukewarm response to Taiwan's request for negotiations.

He denied that a group of private tourism operators who headed for Xiamen Tuesday for a tourism exhibition will talk with the Chinese authorities about China's decision to allow more Chinese people to visit Taiwan, saying such talks need government authorization.

The MAC chief, who made the comments at a seminar about exchanges among Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao, ended his statement with a warning that Taiwan people are increasingly feeling China's hostility toward them.

This trend remains intact despite the trips to China made by the leaders of opposition Kuomintang and People First Party in April and May, respectively, because the Chinese pressure on the country is so persistent, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CAUCUS TO SUE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES FOR NEGLIGENCE

TEXT.P: The caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) at the Kaohsiung city council claimed Tuesday that it is in possession of evidence about a scandal that prompted the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on greater Kaohsiung's rapid transit system and will sue the relevant government agencies for negligence.

Chuang Chi-wang, convener of the KMT caucus, said the caucus will file a lawsuit with the District Attorney's Office against the Council of Labor Affairs and the Labor Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government for "serious negligence of duty."
He added that another suit will be filed against the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KTRC) for falsifying documents and illegal transfer of benefits.
Chuang claimed that the lawsuits are not politically motivated but are intended to safeguard the interests of all the residents of Kaohsiung.

Meanwhile, Wu Yi-cheng, a Kaohsiung city councilor of the opposition People First Party, introduced a motion calling on the speaker of the City Council to convene a special session Sept. 12 to discuss the scandal and the political storm faced by the KTRC and relevant government agencies. By late Tuesday, more than 20 city councilors had endorsed the motion.

According to the city council's rules, a motion requesting a special session must be submitted at least 10 days before the target date of the meeting, except for important issues that need urgent attention.

Wu said the riot by Thai workers is an important issue because it has caused serious damage to Taiwan's global image. In addition, he said, it is necessary for the city council to establish the cause of the riot and find out who are responsible for the inhumane treatment of the Thai laborers, so that similar incidents will not happen again.

The riot occurred at the living quarters of some 1,700 Thai workers in Kaohsiung County when about 100 of them set fire to a dormitory building and a management office in protest of their poor living conditions and harsh restrictions placed on them. The fire caused NT$10 million-worth of property damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE HOUSEHOLD SAVINGS DROP TO NEW LOW: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's average household savings dropped to a new low of NT$198,600 (US$6,304.76) in 2004, according to the results of a survey released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Tuesday.
It was the lowest figure since 1993, when the average household savings recorded in a similar survey stood at NT$223,752.
DGBAS officials attributed the decrease mainly to an increase in household consumption.

According to the DGBAS report on domestic annual household income and consumption over the past decade, the average household income amounted to NT$1.12 million last year, up 1 percent from the 2003 level.
Over the past decade, the report said, the annual growth rate of the domestic household income averaged 1.7 percent.
The household income and expenditure survey collects detailed information about the expenditure, income and household characteristics of a sample of households around the country.

The general goals for conducting the survey are to identify the net levels and patterns of expenditure of local private households on a comprehensive range of goods and services purchased for private use, and to determine how these levels and patterns vary according to income levels and other characteristics of households, such as size and composition, location and principal sources of cash income.
Of the 2004 average household income, salary accounted for the lion's share of 55.3 percent, down 3 percentage points from the 1994 ratio.
According to the DGBAS survey, the average disposable household income was about NT$891,000 up 1.1 percent from the 2003 level, and the growth rate for the past decade averaged 1.5 percent.

The DGBAS report further said the average household expenditure amounted to NT$693,000 in 2004, up 3.9 percent from the year-earlier level. The annual growth rate averaged 2.4 percent for the past decade.

Of the household expenditure, dwelling-related spending, including rent, utilities, furniture and household management, accounted for 26.8 percent, while spending on food and non-alcoholic beverages made up 23.7 percent.

With household consumption rising, the average household savings have declined steadily over the past decade. Nevertheless, the figure remained positive, indicating that local households have continued to accumulate wealth during the period.

The survey also found that the composition of local households has changed, with young members moving out to form nuclear families. As a result, the number of local households increased from 5.57 million in 1994 to 7.08 million in 2004, while the average number of members of each household dropped from 4.02 to 3.5. Against this backdrop, per capita savings still registered a marginal 0.2 percent increase over the past decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOVERNOR ARRIVES IN TAIPEI TO DISCUSS ANMC 21

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara arrived in Taiwan Tuesday for a four-day visit to discuss the repercussions of Beijing's abrupt withdrawal from the Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC 21) and its annual meetings.

During his stay in Taiwan, Ishihara will meet with President Chen Shui-bian and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to exchange views on Beijing's withdrawal from the ANMC 21, a forum for the mayors of major Asian cities that hope to "take the lead in the 21st Century."

Founded in Tokyo in October 2001 by Ishihara, the ANMC 21 now has 12 member cities -- Bangkok, Beijing, New Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Tokyo and Yangon, with the aim of boosting prosperity and development of Asia in the 21st century. The 12 cities have since taken turns hosting the ANMC 21 annual meetings.

Taipei began to bid to host the 2005 ANMC 21 meeting in July 2004, but Beijing entered the race against Taipei for the hosting right only a few days before the Nov. 22-23, 2004 Jakarta meeting, simply because the Beijing authorities did not want to see Taipei play any significant role in the forum.
In a vote to choose between Taipei and Beijing, Beijing beat Taipei 7-4, but was one vote shy of the two-thirds needed to win the right to host the annual meeting.

In the ensuing negotiations, all of the meeting attendees except Beijing's representative agreed that the 2005 meeting would be hosted by Beijing, with Taipei getting the priority right to host the 2006 meeting.

When the chairman of the meeting announced the results of the negotiations, Beijing's representative walked out in protest. Beijing has since refused to endorse the "Jakarta Declaration" issued by the 2004 ANMC 21 meeting regarding the sponsorship for the 2005 and 2006 meetings.

Ishihara himself has also asked Beijing to sign the joint statement over the past 10 months. Nevertheless, Beijing informed Tokyo Aug. 30 that it decided to withdraw from the ANMC 21. Because of Beijing's withdrawal, the holding of the 2005 ANMC 21 annual meeting is now facing various uncertainties, including whether the 2005 ANMC meeting will be held or not.

Ishihara's current visit to Taiwan is his fifth since assuming the Tokyo governorship in April 1999. He was in Taipei in May 2004 to attend President Chen's inauguration for a second four-year term and he was again in Taipei in October the same year at the invitation of the Taiwan Railway Administration. He visited central Taiwan shortly after the island was struck by a deadly earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURERS ENCOURAGED TO INCREASE INVESTMENT IN CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) urged Taiwanese businessmen Tuesday to invest in Central America, saying that the region is expected to offer plenty of trade opportunities after the formation of a planned Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA).

Following the adoption of a U.S.-Central America Free Trade Agreement by the U.S. Congress in July 2004, the United States has been working on integrating the economies of the Americas into a single free trade area, according to a report on the American economic and trade integration issued by the CEPD's Overall Planning Department.

As the 34 American countries, including the United States and Canada, will be integrated into the world's largest economic and trade community in the near future, Taiwanese manufacturers should take advantage of every opportunity to make inroads into the unique market, a CEPD official said.

After the establishment of the FTAA, its gross domestic product (GDP) will reach US$14.8 trillion, accounting for 40 percent of the global total GDP, while its foreign trade volume will hit US$3.9 trillion, making up 21.4 percent of the total volume of global trade, and its population will be 880 million, or 13.8 percent of the global total population, the official noted.

The official said that thanks to the global economic recovery, Central American and Caribbean economies are growing steadily, adding that based upon a research report released by the International Monetary Fund, Central American nations' GDP will increase at least 1.5 percent after the formation of the FTAA.

Central American and Caribbean economic growth rates for 2005 are forecast to reach 3.3 percent and 4.2 percent, respectively, the official pointed out, adding that their annual average growth rates for the next 10 years are estimated at 3.2 percent and 3.8 percent, respectively, higher than the United States' 3 percent and the European Union's 2 percent.
The government has been working on forging free trade agreements (FTAs) with Central American countries in an effort to boost bilateral economic and trade relations, the official pointed out.

Bilateral talks for signing a Taiwan-Guatemala FTA were completed in late August and the two nations are expected to ink a formal FTA in the near future, while Taiwan-Nicaragua FTA negotiations will also be completed soon. In addition, Honduras and El Salvador have expressed the intention to sign FTAs with Taiwan.

Panama was the first country to ink an FTA with Taiwan to boost bilateral trade exchanges. Since the agreement came into force in Janaury 2004, two-way trade has posted a phenomenal growth of 111.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA: LAW TO BE AMENDED FOR BETTER TREATMENT OF FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) under the Cabinet pledged Tuesday that it will propose an amendment of the Employment Services Act within two months to improve the treatment of foreign laborers in Taiwan.

Senior CLA officials made the promise during a meeting with representatives from labor movements and human rights groups who expressed concern about the poor treatment of foreign workers exposed by the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working on Kaohsiung's rapid transit railway system.

The officials said that the planned amendment would permit the government to hire foreign laborers without using brokers, allow foreign workers to switch to a different employer from the one they apply to work for when they enter Taiwan, and remove the limitation on the number of years a foreign laborer is allowed to stay in Taiwan.
Currently foreign laborers are allowed to work in Taiwan for a maximum of six years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO DEFEND HANDLING OF THAI RIOT ON TV

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will defend on TV his administration's handling of the riot of Thai workers in Kaohsiung after two members of his Cabinet tendered their resignations to take responsibility for the incident.

The premier told journalists after emerging from a meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in Hsinchu City that he will air the administration's side of the story in an interview with TVBS Wednesday.

Hsieh said the offers of resignation by Mainland Affairs Council Minister Chen Chu and the acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chih-mai should be seen in a favorable light, but unfortunately the opposition has presented them in a bad light, turning what was supposed to demonstrate a Cabinet member's integrity into inter-party strife.
The premier had said the previous day that he will hold off a decision on the resignations until the responsibility for the riot has been ascertained by an investigation.
The Thai workers introduced to work on the construction of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit System rioted Aug. 21 to protest ill-treatment by their management company and bad living conditions.
Hsieh's administration came under fire for the riot, which the opposition said is only the tip of the iceberg betraying a major labor scandal involving political heavyweights.

Hsieh told journalists after the DPP meeting that the rapid transit system construction plan was laid down under the previous Kuomintang government and that his administration was only executing it. If there were any irregularities involved in the plan, the KMT policy makers at the time should be called to account for them.

Mentioning the name of former KMT Kaohsiung mayor Wu Deng-yi, who criticized the project on a TV show recently, Hsieh said Wu should shoulder the lion's share of the responsibility for irregularities, if any, involved in the plan.

He criticized the KMT for trying to divert public attention from the workers' riot to the transit system program, as if they are innocent, in defiance of the fact that the program was set up by the party itself.
The premier said he was sure the public will "see through these groundless allegations" once they have "learned the truth" from his TV interview.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Sept. 7, or the fourth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1533: Elizabeth I, Queen of England and Ireland who succeeded the Catholic Mary I and reestablished Protestantism in England, is born. Her reign was marked by the execution of Mary Queen of Scots in 1587, the defeat of the Spanish Armada in 1588, and domestic prosperity and literary achievement.
1571: The combined Christian navies rout the Turkish Ottoman fleet at Lepanto off the coast of Greece, weakening Ottoman dominance of the Mediterranean.
1689: China's Ching court signs with Russia the Nertchinsk Treaty, the first peace treaty signed between China and European countries. Nertchinsk is a city in Siberia.
1812: Napoleon Bonaparte's forces defeat the Russian army under General Kutuzov at the Battle of Borodino, 112 km west of Moscow.
1813: In an editorial in the Troy Post of New York, "Uncle Sam" is first used as a symbolic reference to the United States.
1822: Brazil proclaims independence from Portugal with Pedro I appointed as its first emperor in December.
1901: The Treaty of Peking is signed between the Ching court and 11 foreign countries, ending the Boxer Uprising. Under the humiliating treaty, China was disarmed and forced to pay large indemnities.
1910: Polish chemist Marie Curie announces she has isolated pure radium.
1940: Hundreds of German bombers begin the year-long "blitz" bombing campaign, raiding London in waves that continue well into the night and kill more than 300 people.
1962: The ROC government orders the withdrawal of ROC embassy personnel from Vientiane after breaking off diplomatic relations with Laos.
1967: Japanese Prime Minister Eisaku Sato arrives in Taipei and is greeted at Sungshan Airport by Vice President Yen Chia-kan in a ceremony with full military honors.
1969: Scottish motor racing driver Jackie Stewart wins the Italian Grand Prix to secure his first world championship.
1976: Salvador's new ambassador arrives in Taipei to present his credentials.
1979: The government of the Republic of China donates US$100,000 to the Dominican Republic for hurricane relief.
1986: Chilean President Augusto Pinochet's motorcade is ambushed by armed left-wing opponents with bazookas and automatic weapons. Pinochet is lightly injured but 15 of his bodyguards are either killed or wounded.
1986: South African Foreign Minister Roelof Botha arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit. Botha emphasizes that the Republic of China should be further advanced.
1993: Six former Soviet republics -- Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Russia -- sign an agreement to keep the Russian rouble as their common currency.
1993: The remains of Ferdinand E. Marcos, former president of the Philippines, is shipped back to his country from Hawaii to be buried in his hometown.
1994: US Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord formally notifies the ROC representative in Washington, Ding Mou-shih, of the results of the Clinton administration's policy discussion about Taiwan. The U.S. agrees to the ROC representative office changing its name to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, and to ROC officials visiting all U.S. government offices except the White House and the Department of State on official business.
1995: The ROC and Singapore initial an agreement to cooperate on a project to launch a communications satellite.
1997: Mobutu Sese Seko, former president of the Republic of Zaire and one of Africa's longest-serving strongmen, dies in exile in Morocco. He was ousted from his country in May, 1996 by a rebellion led by Laurent Kabila.
1999: The second Summit of the Republic of China and its seven allies in Central America and the Caribbean opens in Taipei. A joint communique was signed in the evening to further strengthen the already close ties among them.
2000: EVA Airways makes its maiden flight from Taipei to Tokyo after 10 years of efforts to get a share of the lucrative air route.
2001: The 2001 Ilan International Collegiate Invitational Regetta begins at the Tungshan River, with 220 teams from 10 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In vastness and depth, absolute truth is like the earth. In transcendental intelligence it is like heaven. Infinite and eternal, it is infinity itself."
