DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TYPHOON FORMING, MAY AFFECT TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: A tropical low pressure system near the Philippines is expected to become a typhoon within the next 24 hours, and its outer rim could start to affect Taiwan from Saturday at the earliest, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Wednesday.

The tropical storm system, located some 1,800 kilometers away from Taiwan as of 10 a.m., will be named Typhoon Khanun if it continues to strengthen in force to become the 15th typhoon in the Pacific this year, CWB meteorologists said.

They forecast normal hot summer weather for Thursday and Friday, adding that rainy weather is expected from Saturday, particularly for northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan, as the storm system moves closer to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO DEAL PRUDENTLY WITH ISSUE OF OIL, ELECTRICITY PRICE HIKES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that the government will deal with the issue of oil and electricity price hikes prudently and avoid sharp increases.
The premier made the remarks in an Executive Yuan floor meeting in which the situation of soaring international oil prices and rising domestic consumer prices was reviewed.

The consumer price index (CPI) rose 3.56 percent in August on a year-to-year basis, which is a record high since December 1998, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.

Typhoon Haitang in mid-July and Matsa in early August took a heavy toll on agriculture, with Haitang alone causing damage totalling NT$3.6 billion (US$111 million), which is more than the NT$3.1 billion in damage suffered by the agricultural sector for the whole of 2004.
The premier said the higher-than-expected rise in the consumer price index was due mainly to the soaring price of fruits and vegetables in the wake of the two typhoons.

Generally speaking, if the CPI increase falls within three percent, it is considered a modest increase and is tolerable, the premier said, adding that if it continues to fall or remains stagnant, it means that the economy is listless.
He said that the soaring vegetable and fruit prices triggered by the typhoons accounts for 0.71 percentage points of the increase in the consumer price index.
The government has adopted necessary measures to stabilize consumer prices, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE ALSO A WORLD ISSUE: ROC ENVOY TO E.U.
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 6 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top official in Brussels said Tuesday that Taiwan must make Europe realize that developments in the Taiwan Strait situation are not just a regional issue, but also an issue that could have an impact on the whole world.
Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the European Union and Belgium, made the remarks in the wake of an annual E.U.-China summit, which was held in Beijing Monday.

As several countries in the Asia-Pacific region, including Australia, Japan, New Zealand and the United States, have expressed their opposition to the E.U.'s idea of lifting its arms sales ban on China put in place in 1989, the envoy said that such opposition has also made the E.U. understand that the ban does not only concern human rights and bilateral relations between China and the E.U., but also concerns more and more countries that have viewed a lifting of the ban as an issue that is related to their own interests.

He further said that the enactment of an anti-secession law by Beijing in March of this year has grabbed more attention from the E.U. to the cross-strait situation, adding that the E.U. has also been forced to begin cautiously dealing with matters relating to the rise of China.

"Taiwan must make the E.U. realize that the future developments in the cross-strait situation will not only affect China and the West Pacific region, but will also have an impact on Europe, " he said, adding: "This is a regional issue and also a world issue. "

In a joint statement released after the conclusion of Monday's summit, the E.U. reiterated that the Taiwan issue should be resolved peacefully through constructive dialogue between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: All phone numbers may go truly mobile.
All phone users may be able to take their numbers with them when they switch operators under proposed changes to the system.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Stricter controls on pre- paid phone cards to kick in from November.
Stricter controls for pre-paid phone cards will kick in from November as part of increasing moves to tighten the security landscape against possible terror attacks, Deputy Prime Minister Wong Kan Seng made this announcement yesterday.
In the region, we have seen elements of the Jemaah Islamiyah using pre-paid cards extensively to avoid detection and sometimes to rig improvised explosive devices, said Mr. Wong.
He said the Homefront Security Division in Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has been working closely with the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) and commercial service providers to work out a practical regulatory regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ABOUT THAI APPEAL TO U.N. OVER RIOT NOT FACTUAL: MOFA

TEXT.P: A media report saying that Thailand will appeal to the United Nations over a riot by Thai laborers working for a mass rapid transit (MRT) system in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung is not factual, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Wednesday.

The report quoted unidentified Kaohsiung prosecution sources as saying that the Thai government's plan to file a petition with the United Nations against Taiwan over the alleged maltreatment of Thai laborers might impair Taiwan's international image.
Lu said the ministry has directed the nation's representative office in Bangkok to verify the media report.

"According to information offered by our representative office, the report was not erroneous, " Lu said, adding that the MOFA will keep Thai authorities informed of the latest probes into the Aug. 21 incident through proper channels.

The Aug. 21 riot began when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory after a day off and were barred from bringing in alcohol and cigarettes. The workers burned cars and battled police with stones and slingshots. The laborers, who are building Kaohsiung's MRT system, complained about rigorous management rules and poor living conditions.
Both Council of Labor Affairs Minister Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai have tendered resignations to assume political responsibility for the rare labor incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS DEAL PROBLEM SHOULD FIRST BE SETTLED BY CABINET: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the Cabinet should first settle the problems posed in the aftermath of the 2004 referendum if it wants to push for the passage of a long-stalled arms procurement bill in the Legislative Yuan.

Ma made the remarks while addressing a regular KMT Central Committee meeting on matters regarding the bill put forward by the Executive Yuan for legislative approval, according to the party's spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen.

Pointing out that one of the most important items that the Cabinet wants to buy from the United States is anti-missile equipment, the KMT head said that in the referendum held in 2004 on whether the country should strengthen its anti-missile defense capability, only 45.17 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots, making the referendum invalid.

Ma also said that President Chen Shui-bian had even stressed at the time that the referendum was more important than the presidential election, adding that in the wake of the issue relating to the procurement of anti-missile equipment being vetoed by the people, the administrative branch must come up with a solution to the problem posed by the referendum result. "Otherwise, the Legislative Yuan will be unable to examine the bill without breaking the law," Ma claimed.
The arms procurement bill has long been stalled in the legislature due to opposition from lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

According to the Ministry of National Defense, the items on the procurement list include eight diesel-powered submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ADVOCATES PHASING OUT DEATH PENALTY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Wednesday that capital punishment will be phased out in Taiwan once and for all.

Chen said that since 2000, when he vowed upon his presidential inauguration to make Taiwan a "nation of human rights," the country's criminal code has been revised to change the "sole death punishment" to "relative death punishment" to allow more room for debate and consideration before a death sentence is actually handed down in a case.

During an audience at the Presidential Office with visiting Siobhan Ni Chulachain, vice chairwoman of the International League for Human Rights, and her delegation, Chen said he hopes that Taiwan's criminal code will be revised further so that the death penalty for certain crimes is replaced with life imprisonment to pave the way for the eventual complete abolishment of capital punishment in Taiwan.
Chen reiterated the hope that the death penalty will be used as sparingly as possible ahead of the complete abolishment of capital punishment in Taiwan.

The president expressed his admiration for the International League for Human Rights, saying that because of the league's efforts, at least one country a year has repealed the death penalty in recent years.

Chen recalled that he began to push for the abolishment of capital punishment when he was an aide to his wife, Wu Shu-jen, when she was a legislator. However, Taiwan society in general was not supportive of the abolishment of the death penalty, he said, noting that up to 80 percent of respondents in a public opinion poll at that time said they were against it.

In the same poll, Chen added, opposition dropped to 40 percent when respondents were asked what they felt about the death penalty being abolished if it were accompanied by tougher conditions for prisoner release.

Meanwhile, Chen told his guests that before he became president, 32 people were executed in Taiwan in 1998 and 24 were executed in 1999. The figure dropped to 17 in 2000, the first year of his presidency, falling further to 10 in 2001, three in 2004, and only one so far this year, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Americans Ignored Risk In Flocking to Coast; The Lure of Coastal Life Outweighs The Risks.
The hurricane that flattened parts of this coastal city and drowned New Orleans, that tossed casino boats into apartment buildings and killed perhaps thousands of Americans, was a disaster long ago foretold.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCENTIVES HELP ATTRACT 'TAISHANG' BACK TO TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Government incentives have successfully helped attract Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "Taishang" -- and their funds -- back to Taiwan, Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Wednesday.

Citing a series of government incentives, including the "006688 land lease preferential treatment in industrial zones, " Hsieh said, that these privilege programs have attracted 46 "Taishang" to return to Taiwan in recent months with their capital, totaling NT$24.1 billion (US$753 million), for various investment projects.
These investment projects are poised to create a total of 4,912 jobs, generating production worth some NT$29.5 billion initially, Hsieh continued.

Hsieh's remarks, made at a regular Executive Yuan meeting, were a follow-up explanation to a statement made by President Chen Shui-bian, who said the day before during an audience at the Presidential Office with a group of commissioners of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission that "Taishang" have nowadays begun to return home with their funds like "salmon returning to their stream of birth."
Claiming that this is just the beginning of a new trend, Hsieh called on the country to be confident in the government's resolve and efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE MEETINGS IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is scheduled to hold its first-ever "mobile" Central Standing Committee (CSC) meeting in southern Taiwan Sept. 11, in an attempt by the twice-defeated party to win back the hearts and minds of the grassroots.

Joining the chairman, vice chairmen, CSC members and Central Committee cadres will be Kaohsiung and Pingtung Central Advisory Committee and Central Committee members, as well as party delegates and county and city chapter leaders.

The first such meeting will take place at the Chungshan Hall in Kangshan township, Kaohsiung County. Party nominees for the year-end county and city elections will be presented to the participants. Lin Yi-shih, KMT nominee for county magistrate, will deliver a report at the meeting.

Later that day, the "Central Standing Committee in Action" will move to the Cultural Center of Chaochou Junior High School in Chaochou township in Pingtung County and will listen to a report by Wang Chin-shih, the party's nominee for county magistrate.
Organizers estimated that each meeting will draw around 500 participants, who will make their suggestions to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE RIGHT TO APPROVE PREMIER SHOULD BE REINSTATED

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the legislature should be given the power to exercise the "right of consent" on the president's nomination of the premier, a power that was taken away when the Constitution was amended during former President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.

In an exclusive interview with CNA, Wang claimed he was making the call because "many people expect it" and claimed that only when the legislature is given such power can it effectively check and balance the Executive Yuan.

His remarks were prompted by Premier Frank Hsieh challenging the opposition parties, which refused to pass his NT$80 billion special budget bill for flood control, to topple his Cabinet with a motion of no-confidence.
Wang said some conditions have to be met and procedures followed to topple the Cabinet.

He explained that the Constitution stipulates that the premier is appointed by the president and that when the appointment has been made, the Constitution does not have clear provisions regarding when to replace or dismiss a premier.
Under the current Constitution, the president can do nothing if he wants to fire his premier but the premier refuses to step down, Wang said.

Because this is a complex issue, he claimed, "many people" expect something to be done to restore the Legislative Yuan's power to approve or reject the president's appointment of the premier, so that the legislature can better check and balance the Cabinet, which is led by the premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SPEED MEDICAL AID MATERIALS TO SOUTHERN U.S.

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is preparing to speed batches of medical aid materials to the United States to help with relief of victims of Hurricane Katrina in three southern U.S. states, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Cho Jung-tai quoted DOH Minister Sheng-mou Hou as saying during a regular Executive Yuan meeting that the DOH is making preparations for a speedy delivery of medical materials that will be enough for 10,000 patients for three months.
Hou reported at the meeting that the U.S. authorities have acknowledged the DOH action and have decided to accept the Taiwan relief materials, according to Cho.

Meanwhile, Cho said, the DOH has also offered to dispatch doctors and nurses to the U.S. to help with medical relief work in the flood-ravaged areas, particularly New Orleans. However, he said, the U.S. authorities said that only medical professionals who are U.S. certified will be accepted.
Currently, the DOH is recruiting personnel and the team will depart as soon as enough members are recruited, Cho said.

Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen donated US$2 million on behalf of the Republic of China government to the United States Sept. 2 to help with the relief efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, which wreaked havoc on three southern U.S. states in late August.
President Chen Shui-bian has also conveyed his condolences to U.S. President George Bush, while the Foreign Ministry has expressed its sympathies to the governors of the four affected U.S. states.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OWES EXPLANATION FOR PURCHASE OF ANTI-MISSILE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The government should deal with a failed proposal in the country's first nationwide referendum before discussing the budget for the procurement of Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday.
In an interview with CNA, Wang said this was the consensus he reached with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou in a meeting the previous day.

Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, was referring to one of the two questions asked in the country's first nationwide referendum March 20, 2004 in tandem with the presidential election -- whether the nation should strength its anti-missile capability.

A total of 45.17 percent of more than 16 million eligible voters cast their ballots in the referendum. Just over 91 percent of those who participated answered "yes" to the question, but the referendum was considered invalid because less than half of the eligible voters participated in the referendum.

Wang said the Executive Yuan pulled out all stops to promote the referendum on anti-missile system, but it was rejected by the public and the government owes the public an explanation on why a failed proposal was resubmitted to the legislature.
He failed to point out that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) also pulled out all the stops to urge the public not to vote in the referendum.

The anti-missile system was included in the Executive Yuan's proposal to buy three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries -- from the United States.

The Cabinet made a goodwill response to some opposition lawmakers' suggestion that part of the procurement package be financed by the regular defense budget to allow for closer legislative scrutiny, but the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan continued to stonewall the long-stalled arms procurement package Tuesday, with the legislative procedure committee refusing to put it on the legislative agenda.

Wang said the redrafted arms procurement will "eventually be put to review " in a consensus with Ma, although the matter will still respect the views of PFP Chairman James Soong and the legislative caucuses of the KMT and the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 14 points to close at 6,164, with 21,421 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October increased 12 points to finish at 6,160, with 413 contracts traded, while December futures gained seven points to end at 6,163, with nine contract transactions. March futures moved up 10 points to close at 6,155, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,150 for September, 6,148 for October, 6,156 for December, 6,145 for March and 6,126 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

September TE futures moved up one point to close at 254.2, with 3,123 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 1.1 points to finish at 254.2, with 43 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures decreased 0.2 points to finish at 941.2, with 1,789 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 938, with 239 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES END FLAT ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: As investors hesitated to push early gains made on the back of an overnight rally on the U.S. stock market and a further drop in international crude oil prices, share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended flat Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up one point to close at 6,141.14.
The bourse opened at 6,168.51 and fluctuated between 6,168.51 and 6,130.56 during trading. A total of 2.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.1 billion (US$2.02 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most by 1.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks by 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues by 0.4 percent, textile shares by 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks by 0.1 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares moved up by 0.1 percent, while prices for banking and financial issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 490 to 367, with 178 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.057 to close at NT$32.643.
A total of US$1.16 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.586 and fluctuated between NT$32.538 and NT$32.706.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CALLS ON PRESIDENT TO RENOMINATE CONTROL YUAN MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that when he met with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Tuesday, both of them agreed that President Chen Shui-bian should renominate members of the Control Yuan.

The president's nominations must win legislative approval to become effective and as the legislature refused to screen Chen's initial nominations, the Control Yuan has since Feb. 1 been without members.
Wang said he does not know whether or not Chen will present a new list of nominees to the legislature.
He said that as the legislative chief, he must respect the views of People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, his caucus, and the KMT caucus in the legislature.
Wang said if Ma and Soong also agree that the president should renominate, "then I will express the view directly to the president, and I will handle this from a third party standpoint."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government not to force Bank of Italy governor to quit.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and Northern League leader Umberto Bossi reached a consensus in a dinner meeting Tuesday night that the government would not take initiatives to force Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio to quit. The government's role in the Bank of Italy controversy has been exhausted last Friday when it approved a central bank's reform program, they affirmed. The Northern League is one of the parties that form the governing coalition and a staunch supporter of Fazio.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLLECTED KITCHEN SCRAPS WILL NOT BE FED TO PIGS FROM JAN. 1: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will phase out the practice of its sanitation teams collecting kitchen refuse as feed for hog farms beginning Jan. 1 next year, EPA head Chang Kuo-lung said Wednesday.
Chang said the decision was made at the request of the Council of Agriculture as a measure to prevent possible swine diseases from spreading.

Statistics compiled by the EPA show that Taiwan's 25 counties and cities generate about 45,000 metric tons of kitchen refuse, of which 70 percent is fed to pigs and the remaining 30 percent becomes compost to be used as fertilizer.

The EPA head said that although currently the kitchen refuse is pasteurized with high temperatures before being fed to pigs, there is no guarantee that the method can prevent all hog-related diseases. He added that Taiwan's NT$40 billion hog-raising industry cannot afford the outbreak of a swine plague.

Chang acknowledged that the 21 compost processing plants in Taiwan, with a combined handling capacity of 450 metric tons a day, cannot cope with the 1, 400 tons of kitchen refuse collected each day. It is, therefore, unlikely that the EPA will impose a total ban on swill feeding.

He assured that the practice of swill feeding will be phased out eventually, with all the kitchen refuse collected to be recycled as compost. This, however, does not affect contracted collection by private sanitation companies, he added.

Swill feeding of swine is popular in many countries as a way to lower production costs, but the practice is known to be a risk that can cause a disease outbreak with a major economic impact, such as foot and mouth disease. Other risks associated with swill feeding include African swine fever, classical swine fever and swine vesicular disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF AGAINST BUDGETS FOR ARMS PURCHASE, FLOOD-PREVENTION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: People First Party Chairman (PFP) James Soong said Wednesday his party opposes acting on the government's bill to purchase arms from the United States, citing a 2004 referendum that failed because not enough voters turned out to cast ballots.

Speaking to journalists before his meeting with Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, Soong said the proposed arms deal would fleece the people because of what he called its unreasonably high price. "No country in the world would waste taxpayers' money in this way, " he said.
Noting that the KMT intends to refer the bill to the defense committee for review, Soong said: "We have to make it clear that we don't agree with this move."
The PFP chief said the results of the 2004 referendum should be respected and the legislature is not in a position to overrule the people's decision.

In last year's referendum, the voters were asked whether the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons and whether the government should engage in negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides."

Only 45.16 percent of voters cast their ballots on the first question, rendering the referendum invalid, as 50 percent had been previously determined as the threshold for the vote to be valid, although over 90 percent of those who did vote answered "yes" to both questions.

Quoted unnamed U.S. sources as having told him that the "NT$600 billion" price tag for the arms purchase was "not fixed by us [the Americans], " Soong said the price demanded by the Democratic Progressive Party administration is inflated and would not bear public scrutiny.

The price of the purchase was initially set at NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) in 2004 when the bill was first submitted to the legislature but has since been cut to NT$480 billion and then NT$340 billion after the defense ministry put some of the purchase items into its regular budget.

Claiming that his party succeeded in killing the bill in the last legislative session, Soong said his party, which controls 34 seats in the 225-member legislature, will stick to its stance in this session.

Soong also reiterated his party's opposition to the bill for a NT$80 billion budget for a flood-control program, saying that it's sketchy and does not have any concrete programs. He said that he couldn't see how these projects could solve the flooding problems that routinely occur whenever the island is hit by a typhoon.

In a response to President Chen Shui-bian's criticism that the opposition's stonewalling of the flood-control program would hinder the government's efforts to redress the water shortage problem in Taoyuan, Soong said the president is trying to shift the blame for this problem onto the opposition.

Soong said he would like to have a public debate with the president over the cause of that problem, which is believed to be the silting up of the Shihmen Reservoir that supplies drinking water to Taoyuan County, and who should bear responsibility for the continuing situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD CONTROL BUDGET PLAN SHOULD BE DEALT WITH: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the legislature should begin to deliberate an eight-year, NT$80 billion flood control budget plan as soon as posible during the session scheduled to open Sept. 13.

At an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Wang, a heavyweight of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said that the legislative caucuses of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) will come up with a joint version of a draft flood control statute and form a task force to help opposition legislators screen the budget plan submitted by the Executive Yuan.
Noting that the flood control issue is of great importance and urgency, Wang said the draft statute governing flood control and its relevant budget should be reviewed as soon as possible.

The Executive Yuan "should be in charge" of working out a concrete, flood control project under the principle of regional balance in order to effectively resolve the country's longstanding flooding problems, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO KMT-PFP AGREEMENT ON ARMS PURCHASE BILL IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The chairmen of the nation's two largest opposition parties failed to adopt a joint legislative strategy on how to handle the government's special budget bill for buying advanced weapons from the United States Wednesday.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong did not reach a consensus on whether to put the bill on the legislative agenda, saying their legislative causes will keep on discussing a joint strategy.

PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng said the bill should not be put through the legislature's Procedure Committee because the government's referendum on arms purchases failed, and "people's direct opinion should not be vetoed by their indirect opinion [as expressed in the legislature]."
The KMT and PFP agreed that the country must maintain its defence capability, "but the government cannot veto the referendum results with mere slogans," Chin said.

His KMT counterpart, Chan Chun-po, said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should actively seek to resolve the issue of tying the arms purchase referendum to the presidential election of 2004.
Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, has suggested that the arms procurement bill be put on the legislative agenda so lawmakers can debate all aspects of the issue.

Ma and Soong also failed to hammer out a joint strategy on the government's request for a NT$80 billion special budget for flood control, agreeing that their legislative caucuses will jointly draft a detailed flood-fighting plan to replace the government's "sloppy" proposal.

The two leaders briefly touched on coordinating efforts to win more city and county magistrate seats in the year-end elections, agreeing on such principles as respecting the majority view and keeping good faith toward each other.

How to cooperate in this regard will be discussed by the two parties' legislative caucuses, Chan said. The two parties realize that unity will benefit both parties whereas disunity will harm them, Chin said.

Emerging from his meeting with Ma, Soong said both of them hope to form a "strong monitoring team" in the legislature to keep the government from falling further apart, as they realize that if the opposition parties cannot check and balance the government, they will have difficulty facing the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW '319 TRUTH COMMISSION' SHOULD BE SET UP: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that a new "319 truth commission" to look into the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of 2004 presidential election should set up during the current legislative session.

Wang, a former vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency in which he said the idea was the consensus reached between him and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou the previous day.

Wang noted that President Chen has said publicly that he is not opposed to the formation a "319 truth commission, " and that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus also said in the previous legislative session that it is not against the idea.
The issue of the formation of a "319 truth commission" is bound to be broached by lawmakers across the party spectrum, Wang said, adding that it will be difficult for the DPP to obstruct or block it.

He also said that a revision of the previous "319 truth commission" statute is necessary, although the revision will be a very technical issue, and the revision and the formation of a new commission can be conducted simultaneously.
The new truth commission will exercise its authority under the revised statute, Wang said, adding that it will not supersede the interpretation of the Council of Grand Justices.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party authored the original "319 truth commission" statute which was railroaded through the legislature to create an all-powerful special commission to investigate an assassination attempt against President Chen and Vice President Lu on the eve of the bitterly contested March 20 presidential election last year.
The statute was promulgated only after the "pan-blue alliance"-dominated Legislative Yuan overrode the Cabinet's veto in a showdown.

The DPP legislative caucus then asked the Council of Grand Justices to impose a temporary injunction on the statute until the council decided whether the statute was constitutional. The council later ruled that some articles of the statute were unconstitutional, which rendered the commission formed under the statute toothless. The commission later disbanded.

Chen narrowly won re-election a day after the March 19 shooting on the campaign trail. He was only lightly injured. His challenger, KMT Chairman Lien Chan, has insinuated that Chen staged the shooting to win sympathy votes. Although Lien has offered no evidence to support his allegations, he filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and even the validity of the entire election. Both were thrown out of court.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER LEAVES FOR SOUTH KOREA TO ATTEND APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan left for South Korea Wednesday to attend the 12th finance ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum Wednesday.

The meeting, which will run through Sept. 9, will focus on two subjects -- free and stable capital flow and economic challenges of aging population. The two-day conference will also review various financial service development projects, financial supervisory personnel training programs, financial management and financing for small and medium enterprises.
Representatives from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the Asia Development Bank will deliver reports on the global and regional economic trends.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation include Central Bank of China Deputy Governor Liang Fa-chin, Vice Finance Minister Chen Shu and staff members from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other relevant government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CROSS-STRAIT TASK FORCE SHOULD BE CREATED: WANG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that a planned legislative task force on cross-Taiwan Strait affairs should be set up during the current legislative session.
Following the formation of the special task force, the legislature will energize bilateral relations between Taiwan and China, Wang said during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

The legislature adopted a set of rules governing the formation and operation of a legislative task force on cross-strait affairs in 2000, under which the ad hoc group was to be formed by 21 legislators, with the legislative speaker and deputy speaker serving as convener and deputy convener, Wang noted.

During the first session of the sixth Legislative Yuan, Wang proposed that the planned task force be set up as soon as possible to help promote cross-strait exchanges, but the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was against the proposal on the grounds that the task force would impinge on the president's power.

Wang also said that he is willing to visit China in his capacity as chief of the highest representative body of the people under the principle of parity if his visit meets the nation's requirements and is approved by the Taiwan people and the legislature.

Asked when would be opportune for him to visit China, Wang said that it would depend on the government's future cross-strait policy. He added that President Chen Shui-bian also hopes to meet with leaders from domestic political parties to reach a concerted stance on the cross-strait issue and to jointly deal with cross-strait affairs.

Meanwhile, Chen Ching-chun, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, reiterated that the DPP caucus will continue to oppose Wang's proposal to set up a legislative task force on cross-strait affairs, saying that dealing with cross-strait affairs falls under the auspice of the president's power.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOULD HAVE PROVIDED TAIWANESE FINANCING 'LONG AGO'

TEXT.P: China should have provided loans to Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland long ago in light of the large number of investments of Taiwan businessmen there, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday.
The official made the remarks after China decided to provide 30 billion yuan (US$3.71 billion) initially over a five-year period for development loans for Taiwan businessmen.
The official, who did not wish to be identified, noted that Taiwan's investment in China has become significant, and China should have thought about the financing problem long ago.

But he said that since China will only provide the 30 billion yuan over five years, it will only benefit a few Taiwanese businessmen. If China is concerned about the interests of a vast majority of Taiwanese businessmen, it is better to have governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait negotiate an investment protection agreement.

He cited unofficial statistics to show that Taiwan businessmen's investments in China have exceeded US$100 billion with an investment of this scale China should have provided them with financing long ago, which he said is also necessary for China to enter into a free economic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES PRESIDENT TO TALK WITH OPPOSITION OVER ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: As the ruling-opposition deadlock over a government proposal to buy key weaponry from the United States looks likely to linger on after a meeting of the leaders of the nation's two largest opposition parties, a minor party called on President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to personally talk with them in a bid to resolve the impasse.

Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Secretary-General Cheng Chen-lung said the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) should not stop the government from acquiring needed weapons simply because the government's 2004 referendum on arms purchases failed to meet its threshold for "validity."

"Taiwan is facing a serious problem of a rapidly worsening military imbalance [with China]," Cheng said, adding that the KMT and the PFP must be reasonable when it comes to national security, as they themselves have a chance to become ruling parties and face the same problem in the future.

He suggested that President Chen meet with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, PFP Chairman James Soong, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and other key figures. He urged both sides to compromise and pass the arms purchase bill quickly.

The meeting could also deal with the president's nomination of Control Yuan members as well as the Cabinet's NT$80 billion special budget request for flood control, two other urgent matters that are stranded in the legislature because of the "pan-blue alliance" opposition, Cheng said.
The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party forms a majority in the legislature over the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and TSU.

The PFP is adamant about keeping the arms bill from ever being put on the legislative agenda on the grounds that people's direct opinion, as expressed in the referendum, cannot be vetoed by their indirect opinion expressed through the legislature.
The KMT suggested that President Chen actively seek to resolve the issue of "tying the arms purchases referendum to the presidential election of 2004."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA PLANS TO NET IN POULTRY, HOG FARMS TO PREVENT AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is planning to help poultry and hog raisers in Taiwan build bird nets around their farms to prevent a possible outbreak of avian influenza brought in by migratory birds.
Sung Hua-tsung, director of the COA's bureau of animal and plant health inspection and quarantine, told the media Wednesday that the plan would require NT$1 billion.

The nets would prevent wild and migratory birds from eating the feed for chickens, ducks, geese and pigs in the farms and spreading the avian flu virus. Those farms close to wetlands will be given first priority in setting up the nets, Sung said.

The COA will also enlist the help of bird-watching societies to monitor migratory birds. Their members will be asked to notify authorities in charge of animal disease prevention whenever they spot a dead migratory bird, he added.
Migratory birds, which used to be welcome in Taiwan, have become a source of fear. Studies show that they may not get sick from the virus, but can transmit the disease to chicken farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN GROUPS TO MARCH TO BOOST SUPPORT FOR ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: A pro-independence group, League of Hand in Hand to Protect Taiwan, said it will stage a march in conjunction with the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Taipei on Sept. 25 to boost public support for the government's arms purchase from the United States.

Accompanied by former President Lee Teng-hui, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, the league's executive director Wu Shu-min told a news conference that the demonstrators will gather at 2 p.m. at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall that day and march through the city's streets beginning at 3 p.m., and will end up at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.
Wu said the march will also muster support from the league for creating a new constitution and re-designating the country's official name as "Taiwan," and not the Republic of China.

Yao Chia-wen said at the news conference that more than 100 members of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations who will gather in Taipei for an annual meeting on Sept. 24 are expected to join the Sept. 25 march to arose public interest in national security, and inspire them to support the government's arms acquirement program.

The parade is expected to turn on the heat on the opposition of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which have repeatedly stonewalled the budget plan for the arms purchase in the Legislative Yuan.

Disagreeing with the government's plan to finance the purchase with a special budget, the two opposition parties have insisted on having the funds for the purchase included in the government's regular budget.

The government has left no stone unturned in its efforts to have the budget clear the legislature, not only because of China's increasing military threat, but also because of the impatience of the U.S with Taiwan's foot-dragging on the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY AMMUNITION DEPOT EXPLODES IN MATSU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Sept. 7 (CNA) (By Yu Hao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An ammunition depot belonging to the Matsu Defense Command on the frontline island of Matsu exploded Wednesday night, according to firefighters on Matsu.
The explosion took place at the Chengkung Ammunition Depot at 9:00 p.m., with loud explosions echoing around the entire island for 15 minutes after the initial blast.
Defense Command called in firefighters to help put out the ensuing fire and throw a cordon around the depot.

The depot is located in a military complex and there is no reports of casualties thus far, but local residents were worried that the fire, which was still burning, could spread to a nearby pumping station.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT HAD BEEN DECIDED BEFORE REFERENDUM: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The procurement plan for three items of advanced arms, which is pending approval by the Legislative Yuan, had been decided before the first nationwide referendum held alongside the March 20, 2004 presidential election, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.

Cho made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the government should deal with a failed proposal in the country's first referendum before discussing the budget for the procurement of eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

The purchase of the eight diesel-electric submarines was decided in 1994, while the procurement of a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and the six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries was determined in 1997 and 1998, respectively, Cho explained, adding that the U.S. government approved the sale of Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries in 1999, and submarines and anti-submarine aircraft in 2001.

Cho said that one of the two questions asked in the referendum was -- "The people of Taiwan insist that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

According to Cho, what the referendum wanted to emphasize in the question was the government should "acquire more anti-missile weapons." But the arms procurement package had been decided before the referendum and none of the three items were "additionally" increased, he stressed.

As for the question whether there is still room for the government to adjust downward the budget required for the arms procurement package, Cho said that the legislature has the right to slash the budget while deliberating the procurement plan.

The budget plan for the procurement has been blocked for two consecutive legislative sessions due to opposition from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: YU SHYI-KUN ASKS JAPAN TO UPDATE ENGAGEMENT MECHANISM WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff urged Japan Wednesday to update its engagement mechanism with Taiwan forged in 1972 after it switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, made the appeal at a cocktail reception marking the end of the 2005 Taiwan-Japan Forum.

Yu said the 1972 mechanism, under which the two countries have to deal with each other through quasi-official intermediary bodies, has become obsolete and cannot meet the needs of the current international situation.
"The current mechanism poses difficulties to bilateral relations. It is our hope that Japan can consider the issue in a pragmatic and forward-looking manner," Yu said.

The cocktail reception was hosted by former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in his capacity as head of the World Peace Research Institute of Japan which co-sponsored the Taiwan-Japan Forum with the Taipei-based Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies.
Yu invited Nakasone to visit Taiwan. Nakasone said he would consider the invitation.
Over the past year, Yu said, Taiwan-Japan relations have seen many breakthroughs, including Japan offering 90-day, visa-free treatment for Taiwan visitors.

Noting that the Asia-Pacific situation faces three variables that could challenge security in the region and democratic values, Yu said they are China's non-peaceful rise, North Korea's nuclear weapons development project and the development prospects of Asia's emerging democracies amid China's continued military build-up and its increasingly extreme nationalism.

While Taiwan is striving to forge a new balance of power mechanism to buttress its young democracy and peace across the Taiwan Strait, Yu said it hoped that Japan can strengthen strategic cooperation with Taiwan to safeguard peace and stability in East Asia.

In addition, Yu said the conditions for Taiwan and Japan to sign a free trade agreement has ripened. "We hope Japan can pragmatically consider this issue to further boost bilateral economic cooperation," he added.

Yu arrived in Tokyo Monday to attend the Taiwan-Japan forum, making him the highest-ranking ROC official to attend a public event in Japan since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1972. Yu will wrap up his Japan visit and return to Taipei Sept. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP PANNED FOR BLOCKING ARMS PURCHASE AND FLOOD-CONTROL BUDGETS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lambasted the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party for refusing to support the government's NT$340 billion budget for an arms purchase package from the United States and a NT$80 billion budget for flood control.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang told a fundraising dinner party in Yunlin County, central Taiwan, for a DPP candidate in the election for magistrate there that the two budgets are vital to the country's security and the safety of the people's property, but the opposition parties turned them down for partisan interests regardless of the interests of the nation and the people.
He urged the public to punish the opposition in the year-end elections for magistrates around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Sept. 8, or the 5th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1157: Richard I, King of England, also known as "the Lion-hearted," is born. He began a crusade in 1190 which ended in the signing of a three-year peace treaty with Muslim leader Saladin.
1760: French forces at Montreal surrender the city to British General Jeffrey Amherst, completing the British conquest of Canada.
1900: A hurricane strikes Galveston, Texas, killing more than 5,000 people.
1916: Woodrow T. Wilson, the 28th President of the United States, promises women the vote. His administration was also marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1927: China's Mao Tse-tung starts leading peasants and workers in Hunan, Kiangsi and Hupeh provinces, and launches an armed struggle against the Nationalist government.
1943: US commander General Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the unconditional surrender of Italy to the Allies.
1944: Nazi Germany starts using its new V-2 rockets to strike London, adding to the havoc caused by the swarm of V-1s launched at the city since June.
1945: Hideki Tojo, Japan's prime minister during most of World War II, attempts suicide rather than face a war crimes tribunal.
1949: Richard Strauss, German composer, dies at the age of 85. He was known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote" (1897) and his operas, including "Salome" (1905).
1951: Japan and representatives of 49 other nations sign the Treaty of Peace in San Francisco. On Sept. 3, the Republic of China government had declared that it would not be bound by the treaty.
1954: Representatives of the United States, Britain, France, Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Pakistan and Thailand sign the Southeast Asia Defense Treaty in Manila.
1956: Lin Hsien-tang, an ROC public opinion leader, dies in Tokyo at the age of 76. He and other prominent members of the Taiwan elite organized the February 28 Incident Management Committee on March 2, 1947.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down seven mainland MiG-17s and damages two others off the coast of mainland China.
1962: The ROC opens an embassy in Kingston, capital of Jamaica.
1974: Naka Funada, former speaker of the Lower House of the Japanese Diet, heading a delegation of 30 scholars, arrives in Taipei to participate in the Sino-Japanese Conference on the China Mainland and the Sino-Japanese Cultural Interchange Symposium.
1974: US President Gerald R. Ford pardons Richard Nixon for his part in the Watergate affair.
1975: A five-member delegation led by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Tokyo to attend the executive board meeting of the Asian People's Anti-Communist League.
1976: Guatemala and the Republic of China sign a treaty of trade and cooperation.
1978: Chinese girls from Taiwan dominate the 13th annual International Children's Art Competition held in Pittsburgh in the United States, winning three of the top five prizes.
1980: Tamkang University and Ludwig Maximillians University of Munich, West Germany, establish sister ties.
1981: Six recently retired ranking Japanese officers, led by General Goro Takeda, former chairman of the Japan Self-Defense Force Council of the Chiefs of Staff, arrive in Taipei to exchange views on the strategic situation in the Asian-Pacific region.
1994: A USAir Boeing 737 crashes near Pittsburgh International Airport, killing all 132 people on board.
1999: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang decides to expel National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng from the party for his part in the passage of a congressional reform package opposed by the KMT.
2000: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, chairwoman of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Council, re-registers her party membership and becomes a life-member of the party she has served for most of her life.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung predicts that the Democratic Progressive Party will emerge as thelargest party in the Legislative Yuan after the year-end elections.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The absolute truth manifests itself without being evident; it produces effects without action; it accomplishes its ends in an unconscious fashion."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT LEADERSHIP HAS SOME SHORTCOMINGS: OIG REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 7 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A report released by the Office of Inspector General (OIG) of the U.S. State Department has said that Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), has used his expertise to advance U.S. interests, adding, however, that his leadership had some shortcomings.
The report, which was released by the OIG July 20, is aimed at providing systematic and independent evaluations of the AIT operations.

According to the report, an OIG inspection of the AIT found that the institute has effectively apprised Washington of key developments in Taiwan and has conveyed American positions to local authorities.

"The AIT's director has used his considerable expertise to advance U.S. interests and ensure Washington is fully aware of the nuances in the positions of the new Taiwanese government, " the report also said.
Nevertheless, the OTG also determined in the report that the AIT director's leadership had some shortcomings and that the AIT's facilities are substandard, prompting operational concerns.

"The AIT leadership has worked hard to improve operations by promoting legislation to permit the assignment of active-duty Foreign Service and military personnel to Taiwan and by establishing an eligible family member program, " according to the OTG report.

"Consular operations are exceptional and provide quick, efficient service. Administrative services are good, particularly financial management, although there are shortcomings in the human resources office," the report further said.

The OTG also said it considers the AIT's headquarters in Washington, D.C. to be "well-run and efficient, " stressing, however, that the institute's biggest need is "for more guidance on how to interpret U.S. policy toward Taiwan."

"Guidance is often too reactive to an individual case, resulting in hasty precedents, " the office further said in the report, adding that "the State Department could assist the AIT and other agencies by updating and reissuing to all relevant agencies a helpful guide to U.S. policy that was last issued in 2002."

Public hospitals are postponing non-urgent operations because their wards are clogged with dengue patients.
Health Minister Khaw Boon Wan fears the situation may get worse. The delays for such operations now run to days and weeks, but could go up to months if the number of people inflected remains at over 500 a week, he said
The Lianhe Zaobao: Khaw Boon Wan: Fight dengue fever just like fight SARS.
Last week, 547 new dengue cases were reported, and hospitals are feeling the strain.
Every day, some 80 patients are coming down with dengue and of those, more than 60 will require hospital care, so that's why the non-urgent operations are being postponed in public hospitals.
