DOC.HEADLINE: BUILDING KAOHSIUNG MRT UNDER BOT MODEL WAS KMT DECISION: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday night that the decision to build Kaohisung's mass rapid transit system under the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model was made when the Kuomintang (KMT) was in power both in the city and in the central government.

During an exclusive interview with TVBS, the premier showed several copies of official documents which clearly recorded the decision-making process leading up to the decision to transfer the city government's responsibility for building the MRT system to private contractors, a decision that eventually led to the recent riot by Thai workers brought in to build the system.

The decision to transfer the right to build the orange line to private investors was made on the eve of the 1998 mayoral election in an apparent attempt to prevent the incumbent KMT mayor's challenger -- Hsieh himself -- who ended up winning the election, from enjoying the right to assign construction contracts, Hsieh said.

In response to a question about why he did not try to change the decision after he became Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh said that he did not see the official documents until it was time to negotiate the terms of the BOT contract, adding that as the KMT was still in power in the central government, it was nearly impossible to change the KMT policy.

Regarding the appointments of the Kaohsiung Mass Transit Corp. (KRTC) board members, Hsieh said that when China Steel Corp. was awarded the building contract, its chairman, Wang Chung-yu, was appointed to act as KRTC chairman and Chen Min-hsien was appointed as vice chairman. He noted that Chen, whose role became controversial after Thai workers rioted Aug. 21, was already the vice chairman before the Democratic Progressive Party came to power.

Hsieh claimed he never intervened in the personnel arrangements of the KRTC after becoming Kaohsiung mayor. It was the board's decision to name Chen Min-hsien as vice chairman even though Chen had invested only NT$700 million in the NT$150 billion project, he added.

Hsieh also tried to clear suspicions that former Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan might have been involved in the KRTC scandal. Noting that as Chen had competed against him for the DPP candidacy to run for mayor, Hsieh asked: "How could he (Chen) have tried to come to me to ask for some favor?"

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH TRYING TO DIVERT ATTENTION BY BLAMING FORMER MAYOR WU: KMT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh was trying to "shift responsibility and divert people's attention" by saying that his predecessor in Kaohsiung City, former mayor Wu Den-yih, made the decision to build the city's mass rapid transit system under the BOT model, Kuomintang (KMT) spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Thursday.

Cheng claimed that all contracts for the construction project were awarded and executed during Hsieh's time in office in Kaohsiung, and it is Hsieh who must explain matters to the people regarding the current controversies surrounding the MRT's construction.
She said that Wu had only decided on the "direction" of building the MRT system under the "build, operate and transfer" formula -- a decision which she said the Cabinet at the time did not agree on.
If Hsieh was also against the BOT project, he could have changed it, instead of carrying through with it, the KMT spokesman claimed.

Cheng also questioned why the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government insisted on removing China Steel Corp. Chairman Wang Chung-yu soon after the party came to power in 2000 and then hurried to award all the construction contracts for the project. She added that there should be a complete investigation into the awarding of the contracts.
She also demanded that the premier give straight answers to all the questions surrounding the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Requests $51.8 Billion More for Relief; GOP Leaders Launch Inquiry on Katrina Preparation and Response.
President Bush sent Congress a request for $51.8 billion in additional hurricane relief yesterday, raising Katrina's cost to the federal government to $62.3 billion so far, easily a record for domestic disaster relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KAOHSIUNG CITY DIRECTORS RESIGN OVER MRT WORKER RIOT

TEXT.P: The directors of Kaohsiung City Government's Bureau of Labor Affairs and Department of Mass Rapid System have resigned to take responsibility for "failure to supervise" a private company's management of Thai workers who rioted Aug. 21 in protest against poor treatment.

Fang Lai-chin and Lee Cheng-pin followed Acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai, who had earlier tendered his resignation to Premier Frank Hsieh. Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu has also quit over the incident that has created a political storm in Taiwan and reverberated to Thailand.

Fang and Lee decided to quit in spite of a city government investigative report that determined that neither of their departments was at fault. They said they hope their resignations will calm things down so that the MRT project can move forward.

Since Aug. 21, Thai workers hired to build the Kaohsiung MRT have moved to better dormitories that are not as crowded; Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which the workers have accused of violating their human rights, has lost its contract with the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) ; and the KRTC has taken various steps to make improvements regarding all the alleged violations of rules against the workers.

Meanwhile, prosecutors have launched investigations into alleged criminal acts against Thai workers or regarding the operations of the KRTC. Still, the worker protest has led to a political storm that has triggered heated debate and virulent accusations from all sides.
Fang and Lee said they hope their resignations will speed up the construction of the MRT, whose completion they said will benefit the citizens of Kaoshiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.74 points to close at 6,149.88.
The bourse opened at 6,157.47 and fluctuated between 6,170 and 6,140.34 during trading. A total of 2.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.21 billion (US$2 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up 0.4 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, construction issues, banking and financial shares and cement stocks, all at 0.4 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 491 to 402, with 152 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS FOR JAPAN STOPOVER DURING PRESIDENT'S C. AMERICA VISIT: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen on Thursday denied reports that President Chen Shui-bian will make a transit stop in Japan during his upcoming Central America diplomatic trip.

President Chen is scheduled to travel to Nicaragua later this month to attend a summit meeting with the top leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and visit several Caribbean countries.
The minister said that "there is no plan to make a stopover trip in Japan."

He also said that the ministry has not heard anything about the summit meeting being postponed, although he added that with the United Nations General Assembly scheduled to open Sept. 13, and national leaders set to converge in New York for the U.N. General Assembly, it has been difficult to finalize the itineraries of the Central American leaders who will attend the summit meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Deputy prime minister urges Bank of Italy governor to step down.
Deputy Prime Minister Gianfranco Fini urged Bank of Italy governor Antonio Fazio Wednesday to assume to his "institutional responsibility" for the central bank and to step down. Fini, who doubles as minister of foreign affairs, said that both the central bank and Italy are at risk of losing their credibility to the international community every day when Fazio stays on his curresnt post.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WARNS MEDIA OF CONSEQUENCES OF ABUSING FREEDOM OF SPEECH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accused some media Thursday of helping spread "a culture of smearing" by basing their reports on anonymous letters, warning that abusing freedom of speech endangers democracy.

Airing his views on his online newspaper regarding the media's recent reports that said the president was being fawned on by subordinates, Chen said a key difference between an advanced democracy and a backward one lies in the abuse or respect of freedom of expression.

He stressed that in an advanced democracy that enjoys 100 percent freedom of the press, those making public statements or contributing to news reports must also shoulder 100 percent of the responsibility for their statements or reports.
He suspected that recent reports about "the bridge of sycophants" and "sycophant troops" are examples of abusing freedom of the press because both, he said, were based on anonymous letters.

One such letter, which triggered a whirlwind of reports and commentaries about a make-shift bridge that he used to inspect the Hsuehshan Tunnel on the Taipei-Ilan Expressway, has cast aspersions on the contributions made by thousands of engineers and workers, Chen said.
Another anonymous accusation has also hurt the feelings of hundreds of men and women in uniform who worked hard in preparation for a presidential visit for an Armed Forces Day function, he added.
He said all members of society should reflect on the appropriateness of the media using unsigned letters to exaggerate so-called " news events."

The president said all citizens of the country can write or call any government agency to express their opinions about government services, but one critical condition for government agencies to respond to the letters or calls is to first determine the source.

The government will not respond to any accusation or criticism coming from an unidentified source; officials can even go ahead and toss away the correspondence in order to stop the spread of "the ill wind of rumors," the president said.
He quoted an ancient Chinese saying -- "Water holds and water topples" -- to warn that once abused, freedom could turn from "the best value" of democracy into its "worst enemy."

As Buddhists say, a change of mind could land you in heaven or hurl you to hell. "Are we marching toward a civilized society or a barbarian one? This, too, depends on a single change of mind, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS OPPOSES REVIEWING ARMS BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus in the Legislative Yuan refused Thursday to review the arms procurement bill put forward by the Cabinet, saying that they will not exclude the possibility of requesting that the executive branch present a new budget plan to the legislature.

As the referendum held in 2004 on whether the country should strengthen its anti-missile defense capability failed to obtain the need participation from voters to be considered valid, the caucus said that an inclusion of the procurement of six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries in the Executive Yuan's annual budget is certainly against the law and that reviewing it would be unlawful.

They also said that their opposition to the examination of the arms procurement bill remains unchanged, although KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Wang Jing-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, have reached a consensus on the legislature's examination of the procurement of eight diesel-powered submarines and 12 P-3 anti-submarine aircraft.
The caucus's stance on the arms deal was clearly reflected by KMT legislators Tseng Yung-chuan, Su Chi, Ting Shou Chung and Pan Wei-kang at a news conference they jointly held earlier in the day.

Questioning the Executive Yuan's legitimacy of including the purchase of the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries in its annual budget, Tseng said that as the issue was rejected by the people in the 2004 referendum, the Cabinet cannot again present the same budget plan for the procurement of the missiles within three years. "How can the Legislative Yuan go against the law to examine the bill, which was presented by the executive branch illegally and against the will of the public," he added.

Ting, also a member of the KMT's arms procurement group, said that the government " is obviously turning a blind eye to the law" in terms of presenting its annual budget for the purchase of the Patriot anti-missile batteries, adding that without taking issues related to cross-strait relations, national defence, public opinion and political situations into consideration, the procurement of arms from the United States is "useless" and "self-consolation."

Pointing out that neither the executive nor the legislative branch can take the law into their own hands, Su, also a member of the group, said he firmly insists that the Patriot anti-missiles cannot be included in the Cabinet's annual budget since " the government has no right to do this."

KMT Chairman Ma also said Wednesday while addressing the party's regular Central Committee meeting that the Cabinet should first settle the problems posed in the aftermath of the 2004 referendum if it wants to push for the passage of the long-stalled arms procurement bill in the legislature.
In the referendum, only 45.17 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots, making the referendum invalid. However, of those who did vote, over 90 percent supported buying more defensive weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY TO BE DELAYED ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: The inauguration of Taiwan's first high-speed railway will be postponed to Oct. 31, 2006, marking a one-year delay from the original schedule, Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing said Thursday.
Ing made the announcement after a meeting of the THSRC board of directors.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.103 to close at NT$32.746.
A total of US$745.5 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.673 and hit a high of NT$32.752.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 10 points to close at 6,154, with 11,634 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October moved down five points to end at 6,155, with 242 contracts traded, while December futures lost 10 points to finish at 6,153, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,164 for September, 6,160 for October, 6,163 for December, 6,155 for March and 6,140 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

September TE futures moved up 0.05 points to close at 254.25, with 2,574 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 0.05 points to finish at 254.25, with 71 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 0.2 points to end at 253.85, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost 6.2 points to finish at 935, with 1,928 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 6.4 points to end at 931.6, with 308 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 3.8 points to close at 935, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO BRIEF FOREIGN ENVOYS ON STRATEGIES AGAINST BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: A briefing by government agencies on how Taiwan is coping with the threat of avian flu will be held Sept. 12 and foreign representatives in the country have been invited to attend, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Liao Tung-chou, vice director-general of the ministry's department of international organizations, told a regular new conference that the briefing at the ministry will also stress the urgent need for Taiwan to participate in the World Health Organization.
Department of Health Minister Ho Sheng-mao will explain Taiwan's strategies regarding public health and the use of vaccines and medicines against the flu virus.

Ho will also detail measures Taiwan has taken to prevent a possible outbreak of bird flu, including stopping the disease at Taiwan's borders, strengthening quarantines, taking precautionary steps in Taiwan's communities and heightening the preparedness of all hospitals.

Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung will also brief the foreign diplomats on how bird flu has affected parts of the world and what efforts Taiwan has made in preventing the disease from hitting the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTS AS SYRIA FAILS TO ISSUE VISAS FOR ROC OFFICIAL GROUP

TEXT.P: The government has protested against Syria for its attempt to exclude the Republic of China on Taiwan from taking part in the 2005 annual meeting of the Afro-Asian Rural Development Organization (AARDO) to be held later this year, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) filed a complaint with the AARDO secretary-general's office recently to protest against Syria's decision not to issue visas to the Taiwan delegation to the AARDO annual meeting scheduled to be held in Damascus Nov. 13, said Liao Tung-chou, a deputy director-general of the MOFA's department of international organizations.
The decision, made for fear of riling Beijing, has infringed on Taiwan's rights as a full member of the AARDO, Liao said.

Taiwan joined the AARDO as a full member in 1968. AARDO, formed in 1962, is an autonomous, inter-governmental organization comprising 28 members from Africa and Asia. The New Delhi-based AARDO is devoted to developing understanding among members for better comprehension of each other's problems and to explore, collectively, opportunities to coordinate efforts for promoting welfare and eradicating drought, famine, illiteracy, diseases and poverty among people in rural areas.
Liao added that the foreign ministry has asked its offices overseas to notify governments of other AARDO member countries about Syria's discrimination against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH REJECTS WOMAN'S REQUEST TO GET SPERM FROM DEAD HUSBAND'S BODY

TEXT.P: The Department of Health has refused to make an exception to the law and give special permission to a woman who begged to be allowed to harvest sperm from her husband who died Wednesday.

ROC Army Captain Sun Chi-hsiang died in hospital after being injured when the armored vehicle he was driving suddenly accelerated by itself and crashed. Being an only son and a newlywed, his parents and wife urged doctors to take his sperm so that his wife can have a baby through in vitro fertilization.
The doctors told her that according to the law governing artificial insemination, a man's sperm must be destroyed after his death. Unless a special permit is issued, they can do nothing to help her.
The health department said that making an exception in this case would set a precedent, which it is not willing to do.
Su Shu-chen, a eugenics official at the health department, said at the request of the Sun family, doctors did ask for special permission, but the spirit of the law is to help infertile couples.
"Since Sun Chi-hsiang has died, there are no provisions in the law that allow us to grant such a request," she added.
Besides, Su pointed out, even if doctors could get around the law and legally retrieve sperm for Ms. Sun, the next step, in vitro fertilization, would be illegal.
Gynecologist Lee Sheng-mao said there is a 50 percent to 60 percent chance of success with the procedure if the sperm is taken within 24 hours after a man dies.
After 24 hours, the success rate will drop by 10 percent. After 48 hours, as the sperm dies gradually, it is no longer practical to try to make a baby, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AGREES TO HOST ANMC MEETING AFTER BEIJING'S WITHDRAWAL

TEXT.P: Taipei has agreed to host the next Asian Network of Major Cities 21 (ANMC) meeting in early 2006 after China abruptly withdrew from the regional city organization, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.
Ma said that he "gladly accepted" the offer to host the meeting Thursday during a meeting with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, who came to Taiwan Tuesday for a four-day visit.
The 2005 ANMC meeting, originally set to be convened in Beijing this winter, was thrown into disarray after China announced Aug. 30 that it had decided to drop out of the organization altogether.

Ma said that Ishihara has asked Taipei, which was awarded the right to host the ANMC meeting for 2006 between October and November, to move ahead its schedule so that the next meeting will not be too far apart from the previous meeting.
Ishihara also agreed that the ANMC Secretariat will call a provisional meeting in Tokyo to confirm this, according to Ma.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that the convening of the ANMC meeting will help promote diplomatic work. In view of the close relations between Taiwan and Japan, the government will assist Taipei in hosting the event, whether in its funding or preparations.

The ANMC was founded in 2001 by Ishihara, and is meant to be a forum of mayors of major Asian cities. It groups Bangkok, New Delhi, Hanoi, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Manila, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Tokyo and Yangon, with the twelfth city having been Beijing. The ANMC annual meeting is to be hosted by each city in rotation.

Taipei began to bid to host the 2005 ANMC meeting in July 2004, but Beijing entered the race against Taipei for that right only a few days before the Nov. 22-23, 2004 Jakarta meeting simply because it did not want to see Taipei play any significant role in the meeting.
In a vote to choose between Taipei and Beijing, Beijing beat Taipei by winning seven out of 12 votes, but was one vote shy of the two-thirds needed to win the hosting right.
In the ensuing negotiations, all of the meeting attendants except the Beijing representative agreed that Beijing should host the 2005 meeting, with Taipei hosting the 2006 meeting.
On a side note, Ishihara visited the Taipei Artist Village Wednesday, and Ma asked him Thursday to send artists to Taiwan to be artists-in-residence and exchange their wisdom with local artists.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SIGNS ANTI-LANDMINE STATEMENT TO UPHOLD HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen on Thursday signed an anti-landmine statement to show the government is opposed to the use of landmines and is determined to uphold human rights.
Chen signed the statement after meeting with Kristen Connors, Miss Wheelchair America, and Taiwan's first "Miss Wheelchair" Chen Mei-yu.

Recalling that he had seen those injured by landmines on the outlying island of Kinmen, Chen said that the global anti-landmine campaign aims to rid the planet of mines, which destroy life and cripple many each year.
As Taiwan has always advocated resolving problems through peaceful means, it will definitely support the clearing of landmines so that innocent people will not be victimized, Chen said.

Eden Social Welfare Foundation is sponsoring the event and the foundation's vice executive director, Lin Chin-chuan, also said that confined by the fact that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, it cannot sign the 1997 Mine Ban Treaty, which bans the use, production, transfer and stockpiling of antipersonnel landmines.

So that Taiwan can participate in the spirit of the treaty, the foundation has become a representative of Taiwan in the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL) , a network of more than 1,200 non-governmental organizations in 60 countries, Lin added.
The foundation has in recent years collected wheelchairs to donate to countries where landmines are deployed, he said.

He expressed the hope that the government will pass an anti-mine bill as soon as possible to demonstrate to the world that Taiwan is a country of love and is willing to contribute to the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODUCTS FREQUENT WINNERS OF MAJOR WORLD DESIGN AWARDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's locally designed and developed innovative products have been frequent winners at major world design competitions, officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

Since the establishment of the Taiwan Design Center -- a non-profit governmental organization -- in 2003, the center has helped Taiwan innovative products and their designers enter major design competitions and more than 100 products have taken prestigious awards over the past two years, the officials said.

Taiwan products garnered 33 German International Forum Design (iF) awards this year, more than double last year's 14, while 20 Taiwan products won the Reddot Award (Design Zentrum-Germany) this year, compared to only two last year, the officials quoted the Taiwan Design Center tallies as indicating.

A total of 2,322 products from 31 countries entered the iF competition this year, in which Taiwan won more than South Korea for the first time. Among the participating Taiwan companies, ASUS Computer garnered a Gold iF Award, the first of its kind ever won by a Taiwan company.
Five Taiwan products won the Industrial Design Excellence Award (IDEA) from the United States this year, outperforming South Korea's four and on a par with that of Japan.

Meanwhile, Taiwan products also won scores of G-Marks (Good Design Awards) from Japan this year, increasing the number of major world design awards that Taiwan companies have won this year to 100, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX-MONTH SHORTAGE PREDICTED FOR BANANAS
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, Central Taiwan, Sept. 8 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to face a shortage of bananas for the next six months after two typhoons caused serious damage to the banana crop in the past two months, market experts predicted Thursday.

The fruit and vegetables cooperative in Nantou County, a major source of Taiwan's bananas, estimated that it will take at least six months for Taiwan's banana growers to recover from the devastation wrought by Typhoon Haitang and Typhoon Talim, which stuck Taiwan July 18 and Aug. 31, respectively.

Statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture show that Typhoon Haitang caused losses worth NT$1.5 billion to Taiwan's agricultural sector, while damage from Typhoon Talim totaled NT$4.2 billion. Bananas were one of the fruit items that suffered the greatest damage.

In Nantou County, where the marketplaces for the banana trade are usually teeming with wholesale buyers, supplies have dropped by 60 percent, and less than 20 percent of the stock qualify for "Grade A" labels, the experts said.

Although the price once surged to the record NT$5,000 per 100 kg for Class A bananas shortly after the typhoons and has dropped to NT$4,100 at present, farmers do not have enough bananas to meet demand.

Some of the banana supplies did not even reach the marketplace because they were grabbed by buyers who would offer a better than normal price. With the price on the domestic market remaining so high, executives of Nantou County's fruit and vegetables cooperative said they believe there will be very few bananas left for the export market this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO AMEND THE CONSTITUTION AGAIN: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) claimed Thursday that there is no need to amend the Republic of China Constitution again.

Asked by the press about his opinion on the second phase of President Chen Shui-bian's constitutional reform plan, Ma Ying-jeou, who is also mayor of the capital city of Taipei, said that if the Constitution is going to be amended again, the first thing to be done should be reinstating the legislature's power to approve the president's nomination of the premier -- a constitutional right that was taken away when the Constitution was amended during former President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.
Ma pointed out that during the past 15 years, the Constitution has been amended seven times.

There is no other nation in the world that has amended its constitution as frequently as the ROC, he said, adding that the government actually only needs to do a good job carrying out what is in the Constitution.
The president declared in June that he will form a constitutional reform committee and allow the public to be fully engaged in the constitutional reform discussion.

He declared that the second phase of his constitutional reforms will involve such issues as whether the nation should have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power, whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government, whether to reform the legislature, whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government, whether to lower the minimum voting age, whether to modify compulsory military service requirements, protection of human rights and labor rights, and the inclusion of a special chapter on the well-being of aboriginal citizens in the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS NABBED ON YUNLIN COAST

TEXT.P: A total of 13 Chinese men were caught at the estuary of the Choshui creek in the south-central county of Yunlin in the small hours of Thursday as they were trying to sneak into Taiwan, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported later that day.

The illegal immigrants were apprehended after they came ashore from a fishing boat and tried to run into woods on the southern bank of the estuary, authorities from the CGA's Fifth Patrol Operation said.
The coast guard set up roadblocks on roads leading to the estuary, believing that an unknown number of other Chinese stowaways escaped and made their way to Yunlin during the round-up in the dark.

According to the coast guard officers, a suspicious fishing boat was spotted by radar at around 2 a.m. Thursday and "knowing instinctively" that Chinese were attempting to enter the country illegally, the CGA Fifth Patrol Operation mobilized some 250 men, including local police, to hunt for them.

The apprehended men were believed to have paid NT$20,000-NT$25,000 (US$625-US$781) each for the trip aboard an unidentified fishing boat to Taiwan from Pingtan, in China's Fujian Province, the officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES ANOTHER BREAKTHROUGH IN ANIMAL CLONING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh presided over a christening ceremony Thursday for a goat born to Taiwan's first transgenic cloned goat that carries a foreign gene -- human blood Factor 8 -- in its genome.
The kid, which Hsieh christened Paopei, carries the same foreign gene deliberately inserted into the mother goat, named Paoyu.

"Both Paoyu and Paopei are our pride and joy. They mark new milestones in our animal cloning history and I have named the baby goat Paopei in hopes of his longevity and fertility, " Hsieh said at the christening ceremony held at the Taiwan Livestock Research Institute (TLRI) under the Council of Agriculture (COA) in the southern county of Tainan.
Factor 8 is a protein that circulates in the blood, stabilized by another protein. Factor 8 can be used to treat A-type hemophilia patients.
COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung said one gram of Factor 8 can fetch up to US$2.9 million in the world market. The annual world demand is about 300 grams, which is worth US$800 million to US$900 million.
"These figures indicate the value of the foreign gene carried in Paoyu and Paopei," Lee said.

According to Lee, the TLRI cooperated with National Taiwan University, National Chung Hsing University and National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in cloning Paoyu, using both transgenic and somatic cell cloning technologies.

Paoyu was cloned in March 2004, making her Taiwan's first transgenic cloned goat. She has since grown into a healthy dairy goat. She was impregnated through natural methods last November and gave birth in late April. The kid Paopei has now grown to 23.5 kg.
"We are jubilant at the birth of Paopei because it proves that a transgenic cloned goat can reproduce naturally, " said Chen Li-jen, a TLRI biological research division chief.
Premier Hsieh praised the research team for their team spirit and hard work.
"The cloning of Paoyu and the birth of Paopei indicate that Taiwan is second to none in the field of animal cloning, " Hsieh added.
COA Chairman Lee said the Taiwan researchers have done all the research themselves, but some of the team members traveled to Britain for training.
"It took seven to eight years to come to this point at a cost of less than NT$100 million. Thanks to the correctness of our research direction, we have made tremendous headway," Lee said proudly.

"Paoyu" is a sister of "Paochi" and "Paohsiang" -- Taiwan's first cloned goats created in July 2002. They were all cloned from ear-derived somatic cells of an adult alpine goat. But only Paoyu was inserted a foreign gene -- Factor 8.

"Paochi" and "Paohsiang" are a pair of twins cloned from somatic cells of an adult female alpine goat. They are the world's first dairy goats cloned from ear-derived somatic cells of an adult alpine goat. The twins have grown well and given birth to many kids naturally.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH 1ST LADY: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office said Thursday that first lady Wu Shu-jen has nothing to do with the Free Universe Education Foundation, Taipei (FUSE) , which is accused of having received donations from the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan (MBBT).

Officials from the Presidential Office Department of Public Affairs stated that the first lady has no relation to the FUSE and appealed to the public not to spread "untrue rumors" aimed at misleading public opinion.
Some 3,000 MBBT staff reportedly staged a strike around the country Thursday to protest against the MBBT head office's decision to sell out its shares and eventually dissolve the bank.

In Taipei, nearly 300 MBBT staff gathered at the bank's head office Thursday where they staged a day-long sit-in. Some strikers told the media that MBBT Chairman Chung Su-sheng took NT$4.19 million from the bank to give to "the first lady's charity organization FUSE" to increase his own public relations.
MBBT Labor Union leader Lin Wan-fu said later in the day that the sit-in will go on on a daily basis if the management fails to give the workers satisfactory answers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INAUGURATION OF TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL TO BE POSTPONED FOR ONE YEAR

TEXT.P: The inauguration of Taiwan's first high-speed railway will be postponed for one year until Oct. 31, 2006, Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Chairwoman Nita Ing announced Wednesday.
Ing apologized to investors and the public over the decision, but claimed she is confident of achieving the new goal of launching the high-speed railway by October next year.
She said that in view of an overall consideration of the progress of the construction, system tests and operation preparations, the board of directors was forced to postpone the launch by one year.
Ing was unwilling to identify where the faults lie but said that the Japanese Shinkansen system is "more complex" than expected.
However, THSRC officials said construction of core mechanical and electrical systems have lagged behind schedule by more than 30 percent, affecting system tests and operation preparations.

The head of Japan-based Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC), which is providing train carriages and is the main contractor of the mechanical and electrical system, said that both parties have their own "interpretations" of the reasons for the delay upon which he refused to elaborate "out of respect" for the contract, although he admitted that the two sides had "found it hard to reach consensus."

Ing said that THSRC's attitude toward TSC with regard to the contract has been to see it as a cooperation partner and help it solve problems, although it will not deviate from the contract, undermine the interests of the THSRC or the overall goal of the government in promoting the high-speed rail system.
Ing did not say whether the THSRC will ask TSC for compensation, noting that the main task now is to complete the project.
She said that according to the contract and related regulations, the THSRC can "reasonably adjust" the launch date without breaching the contract.

She also said the THSRC has sent its rescheduled plan to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, as well as the banking consortium in charge of the finances for the project, and will also offer an explanation to shareholders.
TSC officials said that the THSRC had not asked for compensation, but said both sides need to confirm the costs of "quite a number of items."
THSRC President George Liu said that because of the postponement, the total cost of the project will be increased from NT$460.7 billion (US$) to NT$480 billion.
Interest and other finances will account for around NT$13.8 billion of the increase, while business operations will account for NT$5.5 billion, Liu said.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said the THSRC has reported to Premier Frank Hsieh about the postponement and that the premier has asked that the company calculate the schedule accurately and reasonably.
"Hopefully, we won't have to go so far as to resort to buying back the railway," Cho Jung-tai said.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said the guiding principle will be safety and that the ministry will supervise this aspect rigorously.

He denied reports that Chunghwa Telecom will invest in the THSRC. On whether the government will increase investment in the project, Lin said that the THSRC has not made such a request and that the matter will also have to respect the decision by the Legislative Yuan. If the legislature approves, it will be a good thing to the THSRC, he added.

The 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network and it is claimed will reduce travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes. The system will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.
The multimillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT THANKS TAIWAN FOR ASSISTANCE FOR HURRICANE KATRINA

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto American embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, expressed its appreciation Thursday to Taiwan's donation of US$2 million and medical supplies for relief for the victims of Hurricane Katrina.

In a press release, acting AIT Director David J. Keegan expressed heartfelt appreciation to the Taiwan government and people for their generous offer of assistance after Hurricane Katrina battered the southern United States.
"Your offer of US$2 million and medical supplies has been identified as fulfilling a critical need, " Keegan said, expressing appreciation for this show of solidarity with the United States.
"The fact that the people of Taiwan have responded so quickly and so thoroughly reaffirms the enduring friendship between our two peoples," he said.

"I have been told that many private citizens have expressed a desire to donate personal funds to help Americans. The U.S. Department of State encourages citizens to donate Katrina relief through the Red Cross," he continued.

As U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has said, the U.S. has seen its people respond generously to help others around the globe during their times of distress, and now, Americans are seeing a similar urgent, warm and compassionate reaction from the international community in response to the devastation, he said.
"We're very grateful that people are reaching out to the United States." Every offer of assistance is important, and appreciated, Keegan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO DEMINING KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed an anti-lan dmine statement Thursday to accentuate his administration's commitment to demining the nation's two former frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and promoting world peace and human rights.
Chen signed the statement while meeting with Kristen Connors, Miss Wheelchair America, and Taiwan's first "Miss Wheelchair, " Chen Mei-yu, at the Presidential Office.

Even though clearing landmines on Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to China than to Taiwan, takes time and a huge sum of money, Chen said the government will do its utmost to fulfill the demining goal as soon as possible.
He expressed his admiration for the two women's courage and perseverance in overcoming their physical disabilities and dedicating themselves to the global campaign against landmines.

Chen Mei-yu is a volunteer of the Taipei-based Eden Social Welfare Foundation, which has become a representative of Taiwan in the International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL), a network of more than 1,200 non-governmental organizations in 60 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SETS UP OFFICE TO COORDINATE PREVENTION OF NEW FLU STRAINS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) set up an office Thursday to coordinate efforts between government agencies in the prevention and control of new flu strains amid heightened global awareness of the potential threat of avian flu to humans.

DOH Minister Ho Sheng-mao warned that avian flu is likely to hit Taiwan between January and March next year and that based on the lessons Taiwan learned when it was hit by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003, there is a need for a special office to coordinate the nation's efforts in the prevention of a possible avian flu pandemic.

The DOH's Center for Disease Control predicted that if an outbreak of human avian flu occurs, an estimated 5.3 million people in Taiwan will be affected by the virus, causing 64,000 people to be hospitalized, with an additional 3 million requiring treatment at clinics and hospitals.
The death toll could rise to 13,000 people, according to the center.

The duties of the new office will include stepping up publicity to educate the public about the threat of avian flu. Whenever an individual shows any flu symptoms, he or she should refrain from going to public places. In addition, people should develop the habit of wearing a face mask, an official at the new office said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS RAISE FLAG TO MARK 'INDEPENDENCE DAY'

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 pro-independence activists gathered at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office Thursday to raise a flag to mark what they called the country's "day of independence" from Japan and China.

The activists chose Sept. 8 because it is the anniversary of the signing of the 1951 San Francisco Peace Treaty, in which Japan gave up its territorial claim over Taiwan. Japan ruled the island from 1895 to 1945. The Kuomintang, or the Chinese Nationalist Party, that was founded in China, then took over Taiwan when it retreated from China to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war with the Chinese communists.

The Beijing government still claims sovereignty over Taiwan. Earlier this year, China passed a so-called anti-secession law codifying the use of force against Taiwan if it moved toward formal independence.

The pro-independence supporters, mobilized by a private association promoting the establishment of a Taiwan republic, sang songs and prayed as their blue, white and green flag slowly rose above a stage erected on the Ketagalan Boulevard leading to the Presidential Office building.
The flag has a red sun in the middle with the Chinese characters for "Taiwan Nation."

Wang Hsieh-chi, a convener of the association, said the group will unveil the "national flag and anthem" of the "Taiwan Nation" in 2007 in the hopes of raising the flag inside the Presidential Office on Sept. 8, 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION POLICE HEIGHTEN SECURITY ALERT AFTER JAA RECEIVES THREAT

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Bureau said Thursday it had enhanced security inspections, particularly passenger luggage, at Taiwan's two major international airports after Japan Asia Airways (JAA) Tokyo headquarters received a terrorist threat.
According to the bureau, JAA's Tokyo office received an intimidating letter threatening to place bombs or explosives on its planes around the world.

After receiving the information, the bureau said, security inspections were intensified at Taiwan's two main gateways -- Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport -- to prevent any terrorist attacks. Five JAA flights take off from CKS Airport each day.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE

TEXT.P: THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Alarm Growing on Storm's Cost for Agriculture

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Sept. 9, or the sixth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1087: William I, King of England, known as "William the Conqueror," dies at the age of 60. He led the Norman invasion of England after being promised the English throne by his cousin Edward the Confessor.
1513: King James IV, King of Scotland, dies at the Battle of Flodden Field, defeated by English troops.
1776: The United States is born when the Second Continental Congress in Philadelphia changes the name United Colonies to the United States.
1850: California enters the Union as the 31st US state.
1894: Dr. Sun Yat-sen heads his first attempt at revolution in China.
1926: American Broadcasting Company, Inc. is established in New York.
1942: In one of their rare raids on the continental United States, a Japanese plane drops incendiaries on Oregon.
1945: US troops land in southern Korea while Soviets take the north from the Japanese, and the 38th parallel is made the dividing line.
1945: General Ho Ying-chin receives the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from General Okamura in Nanking.
1948: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea) is created with Kim Il Sung as its premier.
1954: US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles arrives in Taipei to confer on Sino-American issues with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: American singer Elvis Aron Presley's first appearance on TV draws much controversy. Known as "the King," the late singer's numerous hit records, such as "Heartbreak Hotel," "Hound Dog," and "Don't Be Cruel" and charismatic manner greatly influenced American popular culture.
1962: An ROC Air Force U-2 spy plane is shot down over eastern China, killing its pilot, Chen Hwai-sheng.
1968: The ROC extends its period of compulsory education from six to nine years.
1969: A total of 11 nations, including Albania, submit their proposal for admission of the People's Republic of China into the United Nations.
1976: Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, dies at the age of 82 after a series of strokes.
1977: General Cheng Wei-yuan, as first president, announces the inauguration of the Republic of China Parachutists' Association in Taipei.
1982: Grace Patricia Kelly, American actress who married Prince Rainier III of Monaco in 1956, dies in a traffic accident at the age of 53. Her motion pictures included "High Noon" and "Country Girl," for which she won an Academy Award.
1991: The Central Asian Soviet republic of Tajikistan declares independence from Moscow.
1991: While Israelis sought shelter from attacks by Iraqi Scud missiles during the Gulf War, Deri Schriebman, an 18-year-old computer wizard, hacks into Pentagon computers to find out how top-secret Patriot missiles protecting Israel worked.
1993: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization agree to recognize each other, taking an important step toward ending the conflict between Jews and Arabs.
1995: Chang Ai-ling, a noted Chinese woman writer, dies in the United States at the age of 74.
1996: Typhoon Sally hits coastal areas of Guangdong Province in southern China, killing more than 130 people and injuring thousands of others.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang issues a public apology for the anxiety and outrage caused by the controversial constitutional amendment giving National Assembly members two extra years in office.
2000: Noting that the government has run up a debt of nearly NT$10 trillion (US$322.58 billion), legislator Lee Ching-an says that the limitation on government deficits of 15 percent of any year's budget should not be eased.
2001: Sweden's Daniel Chopra cards a one-under-par 71 for a four-under-par 284 total to win the US$300,000 Taiwan Mercuries Masters at the Taiwan Golf & Country Club at Tamshui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The principle in the course and operation of nature may be summed up in one word: it exists for its own sake without any double or ulterior motive. Hence the way in which it produces things is unfathomable."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER IN VIETNAM FOR BILATERAL WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh has led a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) delegation to Vietnam for bilateral consultations on Vietnam's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), MOEA officials said Friday.

Taiwan and Vietnam have tentatively agreed on tariff reduction on more than 200 industrial and agricultural products from each side, with the reduction rates averaging about 20 percent, the MOEA officials said.
They added that Ho is expected to meet with her Vietnamese counterpart to finalize a bilateral agreement on the tariff reduction package and other terms for Vietnam's WTO accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN CANADA PROTEST CHINESE PRESIDENT'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Sept. 8 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Several Taiwanese organizations in Canada have decided to protest against the current visit of Chinese President Hu Jintao to Ottawa by peacefully voicing their support for Taiwan and opposition to China's threats against the island.
Hu, at the head of a Chinese delegation, arrived in the Canadian capital Thursday for a three-day visit.

W.H. Lin, president of the Taiwanese Association in Ottawa, said that Taiwan is a sovereign state and a free, democratic and peace-loving country. "This is a fact, and we won't allow any country to threaten Taiwan by force," he added.

W.F. Lu, president of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace, Ottawa Branch, said that cross-Taiwan Strait problems should be resolved by peaceful and democratic means. He added that Hu has used "stick and carrot united front" tactics to deal with matters with Taiwan since becoming China's head of state in March of last year.

According to Lu, promoting Taiwan agricultural exports to China is "a soft united front tactic," while enacting an anti-secession law threatening the island is "a hardline united front tactic." He also said that China ought to listen to the Taiwan people's voices and better its understanding of the fundamental spirit of democracy and peace.
S.E. Lin, director of the Taiwanese Social Service Center in Canada, requested that China dismantle its missiles targeting Taiwan as "we want peace."

W.L. Chen, president of the Taiwanese Professional Professors Association in Canada, urged Beijing to handle cross-strait relations by learning from the methods used by the United States and Canada in handling their relations with each other peacefully.

H.Y. Chan, president of the Taiwanese Student Association in Ottawa, called for Beijing to better its understand of Taiwan's sovereignty, stressing that China should use peaceful means rather than military threats to tackle the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON KHANUN INCREASES IN STRENGTH, CONTINUES ON PATH TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Khanun has increased in strength over the past few hours to become a "medium" typhoon, posing an increasing threat to Taiwan as it continues to move toward the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Friday.

The typhoon, with a radius of 200 kilometers, was centered 1,060 kilometers away from Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi at 11 a.m. Friday, moving in a northwest direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 21 kph, CWB meteorologists said.
The weather bureau is expected to issue a sea warning for Khanun, the 15th typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, later in the day.

The eye of typhoon is forecast to be located about 690 kilometers east of Oluanpi by 2 a.m. Saturday, the meteorologists forecast, warning ships operating in waters north and east of the Philippines to be on alert against rough seas.
The weather bureau also discouraged the Taiwan public from vacationing by the sea over the weekend.

The eastern, northern and central parts of Taiwan are expected to start experiencing heavy rain by Saturday when these areas come under the influence of the typhoon, while southern Taiwan, Penghu Island, and the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu are forecast to continue to experience the usual hot summer weather Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SOLDIERS KILLED IN EXPLOSION AT WEAPONRY FACTORY IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Two soldiers were killed in an explosion at a weaponry factory in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung Friday morning, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said.

Initial investigations revealed that a machine used in the production of ammunition blew up at the military-run factory in Kaohsiung County's Tashu township, killing two soldiers and injuring one other, an MND spokesman said.

The deceased were identified as Chiu Kuo-chen, a sergeant first class, and Hsu Ming-cheng, a staff sergeant. The injured soldier, identified as Su Ching-kuo, also a staff sergeant, was rushed to a nearby hospital for emergency treatment, the spokesman said.

"We feel deep regret over the accident, " the spokesman said, adding that the ministry will assist the families of the deceased soldiers in handling the aftermath and spare no efforts in treating the injured.
Moreover, the spokesman said, the MND has formed a special task force to investigate the cause of the fatal accident.

The blast came just two days after a string of explosions rocked an ammunition depot on the Taiwan-held frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan. No one was injured, and the military is still investigating the explosions.
On Wednesday, Army Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang was killed when an armored vehicle suddenly accelerated during an operation at a military base in central Taiwan. Investigators are still probing the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON OIG REPORT ABOUT AIT LEADERSHIP: ROC ENVOY TO E.U.
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 8 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's envoy in Brussels said Thursday that he has no comment on a report relating to the leadership of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

The report, which was released July 20 by the Office of Inspector General (OIG) of the U.S. State Department, said that although AIT Taipei Office Director Douglas Paal has used his considerable expertise to advance U.S. interests, his leadership has some shortcomings.

In response to a question raised by the Central News Agency regarding the report, Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the European Union and Belgium, said that he does not want to express any opinion about Paal's style or way of doing things as the AIT director despite the fact that he has known him for years. Chen has served in the past as foreign affairs minister and as the ROC representative to the United States.

Noting that he was already acquainted with Paal when he became the island's vice representative in Washington in the 1980s, Chen only said: "I've known him for a very long time, and he is an erudite person, with plenty of energy and a straightforward character."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO SPONSOR CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMICS FORUM IN SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition People First Party (PFP) is scheduled to host a cross-strait economics forum in Shanghai in mid-September to help facilitate business and trade exchanges between Taiwan and China, a PFP spokesman said Friday.

PFP Chairman James Soong will lead a delegation from the opposition party to Shanghai for the forum, which will include four major topics: namely Taiwan's economically strategic development and Taiwan businesspeople's roles in China; direct cross-strait air links; agricultural exchanges; and the normalization of cross-strait business and trade relations, said Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's Policy Research Center.

It has been decided that PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of Beijing's State Council, will jointly preside over the opening as well as the closing of the forum.

PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, a cardiologist-turned-politician, will deliver a keynote speech at the closing ceremony, while noted scholars from across the Taiwan Strait, including Yeh Wan-an, Hu Angang and Li Yining, will also deliver their research reports during the forum.

This will be the first high-ranking PFP delegation to visit China since Soong's "bridge-building" journey to Beijing in May this year during which he met with Hu Jintao, general secretary of the Communist Party of China and president of China.

Soong has attached great expectations to the forthcoming forum, considering it a concrete step in realizing the sixth point of the Hu-Soong consensus reached during their historic meeting May 12 that a "dialogue platform" of a private nature should be formed to help accelerate exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, according to Chang.

Chang said that the PFP may arrange for Soong and the party delegation to return to Taiwan after the forum via the "mini three links" route, which would entail first flying from Shanghai to the southern Chinese port city of Xiamen, then taking a ferry from there to Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen before boarding a plane back to Taiwan proper.
The PFP will consult with Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, early next week about matters regarding the forthcoming forum, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS ISSUE TO CAST SHADOW OVER E.U.-CHINA RELATIONS: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 8 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in Brussels speculated Thursday that slow progress made by China on its human rights performance will cast a shadow over European Union-China relations.

Chen Chien-jen, the island's representative to the E.U. in Belgium, made the remarks following the European Parliament's passage that same day of a joint resolution urging Beijing to cease its persecution of Christians.
According to Chen, freedom of religion is part of the human rights and was one of the topics discussed by the E.U. and China during their summit meeting held in Beijing earlier this week.

Noting that members of the European Parliament are concerned about the human rights situation in China, the representative said that the E.U. has refused to lift its arms sales ban on China out of consideration of the current human rights situation.
Chen also said the improvement of China's human rights situation will have a positive impact on the Chinese people and the development of the world.

In the resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Chinese government to put an end to religious repression and to ensure that it respects international standards of human rights as well as religious rights, democracy, freedom of expression, freedom of association, freedom of the media, and political freedom.
It also urges the E.U. Commission and the Council of Ministers to make clear to Beijing that a genuine partnership can only develop when shared values are fully respected and put into practice.

Expressing disappointment at the lack of substantial results from human rights dialogues between the E.U. and China, the resolution also invites the commission and council to voice their concerns about the issues during their forthcoming session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 30.82 points to close at 6,119.06.
The bourse opened at 6,161.8 and fluctuated between 6,167.9 and 6,108.4 during trading. A total of 2.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.24 billion (US$1.74 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks both at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 634 to 278, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER URGES GOVERNMENT TO BUY OUT HIGH SPEED RAILWAY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chou Hsi-wei suggested Friday that the administration buy out the high-speed rail project and its builder before the entire project goes down the drain.

Chou claimed that Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) and the high-speed rail project that it has been building over the past five years may go bankrupt as a result of a snowballing deficit assessed to top NT$1 trillion (US$31.25 billion) , consequently leaving Taiwan's first high-speed railway in jeopardy.

He suggested that the administration, which will foot the bills for 87 percent of the costs of the entire project according to agreements, gain complete control of the multimillion-dollar rail system that is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

Meanwhile, Chou, who has announced his bid to run for the magistrate seat in Taiwan's largest county of Taipei, also suggested that the Legislative Yuan set up a high-speed rail ad hoc group to look into any irregularities in THSRC operations and its financing.

Chou said that the Legislative Yuan ad hoc group should be established as soon as possible to find out whether there has been interest-peddling and collusion, whether the Japan-based Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) has sustained any influence or pressure from former President Lee Teng-hui or President Chen Shui-bian, and whether professional judgment and decisions have been compromised because of politics.

THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing announced Thursday that the launch of the railway will be postponed for one year until Oct. 31, 2006, citing various reasons, including an overall consideration of the progress of the construction, system tests and operation preparations. Ing was unwilling to identify where the faults lie but said that the Japanese Shinkansen system is "more complex" than expected.
Ing apologized to investors and the public over the decision, but claimed she is confident of achieving the new goal of launching the high-speed railway by October next year.

However, THSRC officials said construction of core mechanical and electrical systems have lagged behind schedule by more than 30 percent, affecting system tests and operation preparations, while the the head of TSC, which is providing train carriages and is the main contractor of the mechanical and electrical system, admitted that the two sides had "found it hard to reach consensus."

Chou lashed out at THSRC for "abusing" the spirit of a BOT project, questioning what kind of BOT the high-speed rail is as the government is paying more than NT$400 billion while the private investors are footing only NT$19.2 billion. In addition, he said, the government will have to pay an extra NT$50 billion because of the one-year postponement, which will increase the total cost of the railway to NT$480 billion.

The 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network that it is claimed will reduce travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes. The system will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIT CULTURAL AFFAIRS OFFICER ASSUMES POST

TEXT.P: Nicholas Papp has taken up his duties as the cultural affairs officer at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, an AIT press release said Friday.
According to the press statement, Papp will concurrently serve as the director of the American Cultural Center.
Papp formally assumed his AIT duties Aug. 26, the press statement said.

A native of Trumbull, Connecticut, Papp joined the U.S. Foreign Service in 1999. While overseas with the Department of State, he has served as the deputy press attache in Bangkok (2002-2004) , and as a consular officer in Abu Dhabi (1999-2001) . Papp is the recipient of two Department of State Meritorious Honor awards.

Prior to joining the Foreign Service, Papp spent 15 years in the U.S. financial services industry. He holds a B.A. from Cornell University in government and economics, and an MBA from Thunderbird, the Garvin School of International Management.
The AIT press statement said Papp speaks Chinese, Thai and French, the statement added.
