DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE FEEL THEY ARE POOR: MAGAZINE SURVEY

TEXT.P: Eighty-five percent of the respondents to a survey conducted by Winner Magazine feel they are "poor, " according to the survey results released Friday.

Faced with poverty, 64 percent of those polled around the country cited practicing thrift as the way to deal with the problem, while 47 percent chose to better manage their money and 46 percent cited moonlighting.

The Taipei-based monthly journal announced the results of the online survey Friday at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan. The poll, carried out Aug. 1-20, received a total of 1,391 valid samples and had a margin of error of 2.6 percentage points on a 95 percent confidence level.

The survey also found that 79 percent of the respondents said their wages did not cover their spending, while 70 percent said prices of basic necessities were increasing, 47 percent expressed worry over Taiwan's economic future and 44 percent said they believe their quality of life has dropped.

To deal with increasing prices of commodities, 70 percent of those surveyed said they have reduced spending on entertainment, 47 percent said they try to make more money and 45 percent said they dine at home as often as possible.
Legislator Wu Yu-sheng of the opposition Kuomintang claimed that Taiwan is stricken by a "poverty panic" disease and he urged the government to map out strategies to manage the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF DEAD ARMY CAPTAIN MAY SEEK STATE COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: The family of an army captain killed in an accident Wednesday is entitled to seek state compensation after Department of Health (DOH) officials squandered his fiancee's opportunity to harvest his sperm, leaving her unable to have his offspring, a lawmaker said Friday.

Wu Fu-quei of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party told a press conference at the Legislative Yuan that the 1994 Assisted Reproductive Technology Control Measures cited by DOH officials to dissuade the fiancee from making use of the in vitro fertilization method has not been passed by the legislature.
In addition, the legislative process of the Artificial Reproduction Bill is still incomplete, Wu said.
He criticized the DOH officials as being "cruel" and "negligent," and vowed to help the woman to seek state compensation.

Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang, a 29-year-old company leader, was killed while guiding a tank onto a truck. The vehicle accelerated suddenly and lost control, crushing him to death. His 26-year-old fiancee, Li Hsin-yu, begged the Minister of National Defense and other authorities to have his sperm preserved in the hope that she could bear his child through artificial insemination.

Also speaking at the press conference, attorney Huang Kun-chian pointed out that there is no law in Taiwan that forbids the harvesting of sperm after death and he claimed that the DOH officials who relied on executive orders to dissuade Li from her planned move violated the spirit of the Constitution through obstruction of her freedom.
Su Shu-cheng, head of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the DOH, defended the DOH, saying that DOH officials did not cite any relevant law but only used what she described as "moral persuasion."

She claimed that although there is no law banning the harvesting of sperm, a medical practitioner involved in this behavior could still be penalized for violating professional ethics under the Doctor's Law.

Her claims, however, were contradicted by Maj. Gen. Liu Chih-chien, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense, who said the ministry had asked the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion to clarify the situation and was told that according to the current "Assisted Reproductive Technology Control Measures, " the plan to obtain the dead captain's sperm should not be allowed to proceed.

A statement issued by legislators on behalf of Li deplored that the only hope of prolonging the Sun family lineage was shattered and it called on the nation to pay more attention to the issue so that other families in similar situations will not have to suffer similar heartache.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE MUM ON SOUTH KOREAN APEC AMBASSADOR'S COMMENTS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office declined to make any comments Friday on a foreign wire service report that South Korea has rejected a request from Taiwan's president to be allowed to take part in the 2005 informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in November.
"We cannot comment since we were not aware of the report, " Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said.

President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions expressed his strong desire to attend the upcoming APEC summit meeting in person, saying it would be an historic moment if both he and North Korean leader Kim Jong-il could attend the 2005 APEC summit in South Korea's second-largest city of Busan Nov. 18-19.

A foreign wire service report quoted South Korea's APEC Ambassador Kim Jong-hoon as saying Friday that he fully understands President Chen's stance, but he added that since 1993, a Taiwanese presidential envoy has been taking part in APEC summits to represent the island.
"It's difficult for him to take part [in the forum] unless an agreement between all APEC member states is forthcoming, " Kim was quoted as saying.
Because of Beijing's obstruction, the Republic of China's head of state was unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

Asked who will be Chen's representative if he is still barred from attending this year's APEC summit, Huang said the government must name a high-ranking official to attend to show Taiwan's respect for the APEC summit.

Meanwhile, a Presidential Office official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said President Chen would not lose any opportunity to upgrade Taiwan's international profile and expand its diplomatic frontiers.

Thanks to his unflagging efforts, the official said, Chen managed to attend the late Pope John Paul II's funeral in the Vatican earlier this year. "In the same spirit, he is seeking another opportunity to enhance Taiwan's international presence," the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ANTI-SMOKING ALLIANCE WANTS CIGARETTE PRICES DOUBLED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's medical groups formed an alliance against smoking Friday and is asking the government to double the price of a pack of cigarettes.

The alliance's founding members include the Taiwan Medical Association, the Formosan Medical Association, the Taiwan Association of Family Medicine, the Taiwan Society for Adolescent Medicine and Health, the Taiwan Family Medicine Education Research Institute and the Taiwan Pediatric Association.

Lee Meng-chin, president of the Taiwan Pediatric Association, told the media that according to calculations in a study by the World Health Organization, for every NT$10 added to the price of a pack of cigarettes, the number of smokers could drop 5 percent.
He said the alliance wants the legislature to pass a law allowing the price of cigarettes to be doubled.
Currently a Taiwan-produced brand costs about NT$40 a pack, while an imported foreign brand costs NT$50 to NT$70 a pack.
Lee cited statistics from health authorities as showing that of the NT$370 billion expenditure on health care in Taiwan each year, about NT$20 billion is spent on treating smoking-related diseases.

He said there is no doubt that cigarette smoking has become a major killer of Taiwan's people, and that the government should pass a law to impose a total ban on smoking in public places, schools and working environments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MAKES INSPECTION TOUR OF MATSU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a half-day inspection tour of the Taiwan-held frontline island of Matsu Friday to boost morale of troops garrisoned there ahead of this year's Mid-Autumn Festival, which on Sept. 18.

Chen arrived at Matsu's Nankan Airport at 8 a.m. He then traveled to Matsu's outlying islets -- Tungyin, Liangtao, Kaoteng, Tunglu and Hsilu -- via a military helicopter to greet all military personnel and thank them for their devoted service to the country.

Chen returned to Nankan around noon. He lunched with staff members of the Matsu Defense Command and representatives of various military units stationed in Matsu, which lies closer to China's southeastern province of Fujian than to Taiwan.
Addressing the lunch meeting, Chen expressed his admiration for the high morale shown by all troops posted on the frontline island and their contributions to national defense.

Before returning to Taiwan in the afternoon, Chen also inspected the Chengkung ammunition depot where a string of explosions took place two days ago. No casualties were reported in the blast. Chen was briefed on the situation, the cause of the blast and the military's follow-up handling of the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF RETURNS TO TAIWAN FROM JAPAN

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, chief of staff of President Chen Shui-bian, returned home Friday from Tokyo where he had been taking part in the 2005 Taiwan-Japan Forum Sept. 6-7.

At a news conference at the Chiang Kai-shek Airport, Yu described himself as a key window for private and official dialogues between Taiwan and Japan. During his five-day stay in Japan, he met with several old friends including former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, Yu said.
He said topics of discussion at the forum were mostly centered on what measures Taiwan and Japan have to take in the face of China's rise.

Yu stated that he proposed that Taiwan and Japan update the so-called "1972 mechanism, " which was established after Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. Under the mechanism, the two countries have to deal with each other through quasi-official intermediary bodies.

The reason Japan and the United States have listed peace in the Taiwan Strait as one of their strategic goals in defense cooperation, Yu said, is because they worry about China's non-peaceful rise. Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law in April has obviously impacted the desire for peace in the Strait, he added.

Given all this, Taiwan and Japan should review their relationship under the "1972 mechanism, " Yu said, adding that he believes Japan should also be prepared to deal with an "irrational anti-Japanese trend" that is expanding in China.

Besides that, Yu said he hoped that the two countries could sign a free trade agreement. He explained that a Taiwan-Japan FTA would not only serve as an affirmation to Taiwan's economic strength, but also encourage more countries to sign similar agreements with Taiwan, a situation that would help regional peace and the implementation of the Japan-U.S. security pact.
Yu was the highest-ranking Republic of China official to attend a public event in Japan since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN WILL FACE THE MUSIC FOR SAILING DIRECTLY TO CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: A flotilla of Taiwan fishermen who sailed directly to China Friday on a pilgrimage to honor Matsu, the goddess of fisherman, will have to face the consequences of its unauthorized action, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.
MAC spokesman You Ying-lung said 21 fishing boats and 129 fishermen sailed to Meizhou, Fujian in southern China from their home port in Ilan Wednesday night and arrived Friday.
You said his office has cautioned the fishermen before that sailing directly to China is not allowed unless the voyage is approved by the government in advance.

However, the leader of the flotilla, the abbot of a temple called Nantiengung in Ilan, said they didn't intend to sail to China but might take refuge there from Typhoon Khanum, which is expected to start affecting Taiwan Saturday.
Each boat in the flotilla carried a statuette of Matsu, and Meizhou is believed to be her home.

MAC official Yang Chia-chun said the Coast Guard Administration's patrol boats followed the flotilla but returned after losing sight of the boats when they left Taiwan's territorial waters and mingled with a number of Chinese fishing boats.
Information from China confirmed that the flotilla arrived in Meizhou Friday afternoon.

Noting that another group of Matsu's followers, also from Ilan, flew to Meizhou via the frontline island of Matsu the same day with the MAC' s permission, Yang said he didn't understand why the fishermen didn't bother to apply for permission for their pilgrimage, which has been approved in previous years, and why they should risk their lives by starting the voyage under the threat of a typhoon.

The MAC official said when his office contacted the flotilla this morning, they gave the MAC their location as being somewhere in Japanese territorial waters when they were actually asking the Chinese for permission to enter their waters.
Calling the move an open challenge to the authorities, the MAC official said the fishermen will be investigated for breaking the law after they return.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED FOR TYPHOON KHANUN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued a sea warning for Typhoon Khanun Friday evening.

Bureau meteorologists warned ships sailing or operating in waters north, northeast and southeast of Taiwan to be on alert against rough seas, suggesting that no activities should take place on the beaches along the coasts of the eastern part of Taiwan.
It is expected that a land warning will be issued at between 5:00 a.m. and 8: 00 a.m. Saturday if Khanun keeps moving toward Taiwan at the current speed of 21 kph, they said.
The northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan are expected to start experiencing showers by Saturday. These areas will see increasing wind and rain by Saturday evening, meteorologists forecast.
According to the bureau, Khanun, the 15th typhoon reported in the Pacific, was centered 830 kilometers east of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi, moving in a northwest direction toward Taiwan.
Khanun is the Thai word for Jackfruit, a large tropical tree fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH REVERSES DECISION, WILL ALLOW SPERM HARVEST FROM DECEASED MAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health reversed its position Friday evening and agreed to a woman's plea to harvest sperm from her dead fiance so that she could use in vitro fertilization in an attempt to get pregnant.

The health department made the decision following an emergency meeting between its officials and experts on legal and medical affairs. The meeting reached the conclusion that since the legislative process of the Artificial Reproduction Bill is still incomplete, the sperm harvesting would not break any law.
However, the Bureau of Health Promotion under the health department indicated that another meeting with experts will take place next week to discuss whether to allow the artificial insemination.

Shortly after the health department gave the green light, an ROC Army doctor successfully obtained the sperm from the deceased man -- Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang, 29, who was killed Wednesday when the armored vehicle he was trying to guide onto a truck accelerated suddenly and crushed him. Sun's 26-year-old fiancee, Li Hsin-yu, who begged authorities to have his sperm preserved Thursday but to no avail, was elated after learning that she now has a chance to bear his child.
However, it is uncertain whether the plan could succeed because experts say the window of opportunity -- the first 48 hours after the man's death -- to harvest the sperm has closed.
The chance of success would now depend on the vitality of the sperm, according to experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 58.5% WANT GOVERNMENT TO HAVE LEAD ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: POLL

TEXT.P: Just over 58 percent of respondents to a recent opinion poll said they agree to the view that government's leadership is needed in talks with China to better protect national interests, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung told a news conference that the Cabinet-level council commissioned National Chengchi University's election research center to conduct a telephone poll from Aug. 26-28 to explore local adult residents' views on relations across the Taiwan Strait. A total of 1,096 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.96 percent.
More than 60 percent of those surveyed said they think that China's military expansion has threatened the national security of Taiwan and other neighboring countries, You said.

Meanwhile, 63.6 percent said they support President Chen Shui-bian's proposal that top leaders of major domestic political parties hold a summit meeting to forge a consensus on the development of cross-strait relations.

According to the survey results, 81.4 percent said they feel that domestic political parties should abide by the law and government regulations in their engagements with China and should put national interests above everything else.
The poll also found that 56.3 percent of the respondents support more stringent management of cross-strait social exchanges.

About 76 percent were against China's practice of pressuring Taiwan to accept individuals or groups designated by it as Taiwan's representatives in cross-strait talks, and 51.5 percent said they don't think that China has sincerity in starting negotiations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Political Issues Snarled Plans for Troop Aid
One of the most pointed questions about the response to Hurricane Katrina has been why more troops were not available more quickly.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Congress Approves Katrina Package Of $51.8 Billion
A $51.8 billion Katrina relief package won quick approval from Congress even as lawmakers moved toward making billions of dollars more available for welfare and flood- insurance payments to families displaced by the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINCENT SIEW VISITS ANCESTRAL TEMPLE IN XIAMEN

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, a former ROC premier, paid homage at the Siew clan's ancestors' temple in Xiamen, Fujien province Friday and unveiled a tablet he brought from Taiwan to be placed in the temple.

Accompanied by his wife, Chu Shui-hsien, and his daughter, Siew Ju-feng, Siew went to the temple in Wushipu, a small town in Xiamen and were greeted by 500 members of the Siew clan from as far as Hubei, and Hunan provinces in central China, and Hong Kong.

The clan members lined the street and welcomed Siew and his family with the sound of gongs and drum bands. A clan representative said they were proud of Siew, who served as Taiwan's premier from 1997 to 2000, because he held the position equal to that of current Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao.

In the temple, Siew led his wife and daughter to kneel in front of the spiritual tablet of the Siew clan's ancestors, kowtowed three times and gave offerings before unveiling the tablet he donated to the temple.

He said it has been a lifelong desire to greet his ancient ancestors at the family temple in Xiamen, and now his dream has come true and he felt that his ancestors in Taiwan would feel comfortable because he finally made the trip.

The temple, founded in 1515 and rebuilt in 1998, is the clan temple of most Siew families in southern China, Taiwan and overseas. Xiamen authorities designed it as a cultural heritage in August because it houses the spiritual tablet of the ancestors to many Siew families in Taiwan.
Siew, who was born in Chiayi in 1939, has been a promoter of the establishment of a common market between Taiwan and China since after he left the premiership.
He came to Xiamen early this week to attend an economic forum and will now tour central China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH TOLL OF WEAPONRY FACTORY BLAST RISES TO 3

TEXT.P: The death toll from an explosion at a weaponry factory in Kaohsiung County Friday morning rose to three, the Ministry of National Defense said.

Two soldiers -- Chiu Kuo-chen, a sergeant first class, and Hsu Ming-cheng, a staff sergeant -- were killed immediately after a machine used in the production of ammunition blew up at the military-run factory in Kaohsiung County's Tashu township.

A third soldier, identified as Su Ching-kuo, also a staff sergeant, sustained critical injuries in the blast. Even though a medical team performed difficult surgery in efforts to save his life, Su died in the afternoon, a military spokesman said.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye traveled to Kaohsiung in the evening to visit the families of the three deceased soldiers. Lee promised to offer the best possible pecuniary aid to the soldiers' bereaved families and assist them in handling the aftermath.
Lee said the defense ministry has formed a special task force to investigate the cause of the fatal accident.

The blast came just two days after a string of explosions rocked an ammunition depot on the Taiwan-held frontline island of Matsu, which lies closer to China's Fujian province than to Taiwan. No one was injured, and the military is still investigating the explosions.

Also on Wednesday, Army Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang was killed when an armored vehicle suddenly accelerated during an operation at a military base in central Taiwan. Investigators are still probing the case.
MND spokesman Rear Adm. Liu Chih-chien said Lee has ordered a thorough review of military operations and sorted out all the causes of those accidents in order to draft improvement measures.
Before the causes are determined, Liu said, relevant operations will be suspended for safety concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER SIGNS THREE AGREEMENTS IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, who is heading a 30-strong delegation on a visit to Vietnam, signed three agreements Thursday in Hanoi, officials of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.

The signing was completed at the fourth Taiwan-Vietnam trade and economic consultative meeting, with the agreements signed including a Taiwan-Vietnam trade accord, an agreement on Vietnam's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) and a memorandum on an assessment of standardization, weights and measures, as well as compatibility.
Under the trade accord, Taiwan exports to Vietnam will be entitled to tariffs at a preferential rate, representing a 50 percent-tariff cut, the BOFT officials noted.

Vietnam will offer Taiwan the most privileged treatment in trade even before it becomes a formal WTO member. Taiwan will in return provide the country the same trade treatment as other WTO state members enjoy.

In total, Vietnam has promised a significant tariff reduction to over 200 items of Taiwan's agricultural and non-agricultural products, while answering Taiwan's demand for the opening of computer, banking, marketing, telecommunication, insurance and transportation markets, the officials said.

Ho's visit to Vietnam, aimed at studying the investment environment and Taiwan businesses' operations, will also take her to Quang Nam, Danang and Ho Chi Minh City. She is scheduled to return to Taiwan Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE EASIER IF CHINA DEMOCRATIZES: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh Friday he believes that dialogue across the Taiwan Strait would be easier if China were to democratize.
Hsieh made the remarks while meeting with representatives of an association of elected officials of Chinese origin from Los Angeles.

Responding to his guests' call for a calmer cross-strait relationship, Hsieh said if the gap between the political systems on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are narrowed, their differences could be lessened.

"Hopefully, China could move toward democratic reform following its successful economic development. We believe that cross-strait dialogue would become easier once China evolves into a democracy, " Hsieh said.
Earlier in the day, President Chen Shui-bian also met with the delegation.

During the meeting, Chen reaffirmed his administration's commitment to beef up Taiwan's defense capabilities. He expressed his hope that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can pass a long-stalled plan to purchase three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States as soon as possible.
The package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAND WARNINGS FOR TYPHOON KHANUN TO BE ISSUED EARLY SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Land warnings for Typhoon Khanun are expected to be issued between 2: 30 a.m. and 5: 30 a.m. Saturday, Wu Teh-jung, the chief forecaster of the Central Weather Bureau, said Friday.
The storm, located about 770 km from the southernmost tip of Taiwan at 8 p.m. Friday, is moving on a westnorth path at a speed of 23 kph.
Wu said the storm might sweep by Taiwan or through its northern part, according to its current path. Either way, the island will begin to feel its effects early Saturday.

Bracing for the storm, EVA Air has rescheduled its Saturday flights to Seoul, Brisbane, Amsterdam, Los Angeles and Vancouver. The carrier urged its passengers to check with the airport for departure times.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, September 10:
09:00, A seminar organized by the Mainland Affairs Council on China's rise and challenges will be held at the Far Eastern Hotel in Taipei.
10:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will preside over the opening of the National Taichi Boxing Championship at Chiancheng, Kaohsiung City.
11:30, Vice President Annette Lu will inspect the construction of the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit system at Fengshang, Kaohsiung City.
11:30, President Chen Shui-bian will open a beer festival in Shanghua, Tainan County.
14:20, Premier Frank Hsieh will preside over a seminar for Cabinet members in Kaohsiung.
15:40, President Chen Shui-bian will visit a company dealing with roosters in Pingtung City, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Sept. 10, or the 7th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1771: Mungo Park, the Scottish explorer known for his expeditions on the Niger River in Africa, is born.
1855: The Russian Black Sea naval base of Sevastopol finally falls to the British and French armies after an 11-month siege.
1907: Some 10,000 laborers hold an anti-Chinese demonstration in Vancouver, Canada.
1920: The Indian National Congress votes to adopt Mahatma Gandhi's campaign of non-cooperation with the British colonial government.
1926: "Rashomon," a motion picture directed by Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa, wins the first prize at the 12th Venice Film Festival.
1929: American golfer Arnold Palmer is born. He won four US Masters, two British Opens, and the US and Spanish opens.
1942: Britain's Royal Air Force uses 476 planes to drop 100,000 bombs on Dusseldorf in Germany in a single raid.
1952: West Germany offers Israel US$540 million in compensation for Nazi atrocities.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Cyprus.
1965: Yale University publishes a map showing that the Vikings reached America in the 11th century.
1965: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces that the Chinese legation in Haiti has been elevated to the status of an embassy.
1969: The ROC and Swaziland establish diplomatic relations.
1973: The eighth Sino-Korean ministerial conference on economic cooperation opens in Taipei with Tae Wan Sun, Korean vice premier and director of the Economic Planning Board, and Y.S. Sun, minister of economic affairs, presiding.
1974: A seven-member team leaves Taipei for Brazil to participate in the first world youth judo championships at Rio de Janeiro.
1976: A Yugoslav DC-9 collides with a British Airways Trident jet over northern Yugoslavia, killing all 176 people on board the two planes.
1979: Siamese twins Chang Chung-jen and Chang Chung-yi are surgically separated in a day-long televised operation at the National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei.
1981: Minister of National Defense Kao Kuei-yuan decorates Sheikh Othman Al-Homaid, assistant minister of the Defense and Aviation Ministry of Saudi Arabia.
1984: Mainland China is admitted into the International Criminal Police Organization. The ROC representatives walk out of an Interpol annual meeting in protest.
1986: The 11th ROC-Japan trade conference is held in Taipei. The ROC agrees to assist Japanese enterprises to invest in Taiwan, Japan promises to transfer more high technology to Taiwan, and several other agreements are reached during the two-day meeting.
1988: Beijing announces the establishment of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, with Ding Guangen as director.
1988: West German tennis star Steffi Graf, 19, becomes the third woman in history to win a Grand Slam -- the Australian, French, Wimbledon, and US Open singles titles in the same year.
1996: The United Nations General Assembly approves the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.
1999: The Baseball Federation of Asia at its board of directors meeting in Seoul unanimously supports Taiwan as host of the 2001 World Cup Baseball Championship Tournament.
2000: Fijian golfer Vijay Singh wins the 2000 Johnnie Walker Taiwan Open Golf Championship after taking a one stroke lead in a sudden-death playoff with South African Craig Kamps.
2001: Wang Chien-shien, a candidate jointly endorsed by the opposition camp for the seat of Taipei County magistrate in the year-end elections, calls on Taipei Mayor Ma ying-jeou to sek his support.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Nature is vast, deep, high, intelligent, infinite, and eternal."

Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko fired his 7-month-old government Thursday, dismissing dynamic Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko-the heroine of the Orange Revolution that swept him to power-and accepting the resignation of one of the movement's top financial backers, Peter Porpshenko.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush Pledges Aid for 'Long Haul'.
President Bush promised the hundreds of thousands displaced by Hurricane Katrina that the government would be with them "for the long haul, " and Congress voted to provide $51.8 billion in emergency funds to finance the relief and reconstruction programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Opposition withdraws SC plan
The opposition bloc in the House of Representatives with drew yesterday its original plan to challenge before the Supreme Court the decision of the chamber killing the impeachment process, moving to its second option of initiating a "shame campaign" against President Arroyo. San Juan Rep. Ronaldo Zamo ra, head of the opposition's legal team, said this was "agreed upon by the group Thursday evening, with all the congressmen and pri vate lawyers present."
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo choice stirs military
In a seemingly surprise, last-minute move, President Macapagal-Arroyo designated Armed Forces Deputy Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Edilberto Adan, replacing the retiring Lt. Gen. Alberto Braganza. Adan's assumption of the command yesterday promptly stirred a new controversy in the military as the Board of Generals (BOG) had earlier recommended Maj. Gen. Samuel Bagasin to the post.
The Philippine Star: Opposition won't elevate impeachment case to SC
Opposition lawmakers in the House of Representatives have backpedaled on their vow to bring the dismissed impeachment complaint against President Arroyo to the Supreme Court.
The Manila Times: RP's growth rating dips
THE Philippines slipped one notch lower in the ranking of the 2005 Human Development Report Index, the United Nations Development Program said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: War on dengue moves to high gear.
Fighting dengue will become a national effort involving all Singaporeans as the Government moves into high gear with the formation of an inter-ministerial committee.
The committee's plans will be set out later, but one sure step was identified yesterday: A hotline will be set up to stop people being passed from pillar to post when they tip off the Government on mosquito-breeding areas.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Six ministers will terminate mosquito and stop the dengue spread together.
An inter-ministerial committee headed by Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, Yaacob Ibrahim, has been formed to tackle the dengue situation in Singapore.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loon, who made the announcement yesterday in the National Healthy Lifestyle Campaign, describes the situation as worrying.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON KHANUN DRIFTING NORTH, BUT HEAVY RAINS EXPECTED

TEXT.P: Typhoon Khanun has drifted north of its earlier projected path and will likely skirt the northern tip of the island, having less of an impact that anticipated, according to the Central Weather Bureau Saturday.
However, the northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan, including Ilan, Keelung and Taipei, should guard against strong winds and heavy rains, they said.

In the bureau report, released at 1: 15 p.m., Typhoon Khanun's center was about 390 kilometers east of Hualien, eastern Taiwan. With a radius of 200 kilometers, it is moving northwest at 23 kilometers per hour. Its center winds have a maximum speed of 40 meters per second.
Weather forecast center director Wu Jung-teh indicated that it is expected that Khanun, the 15th typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, will leave the island by Sunday afternoon.

Ships sailing or operating in waters north, northeast and southeast of Taiwan are on high alert. Meanwhile, affected by the approaching storm, the northern, northeastern and eastern parts of the island should expect showers Saturday, and the rain and wind are expected to increase in the evening.
Mountainous areas in northern and central Taiwan are expected to experience heavy rains by Sunday, which may cause landslides, falling rocks and mudflows.

Meteorologists forecast that the mountainous areas of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli are expected to receive accumulated rainfall of between 400 millimeters to 600 millimeters, while those in central Taiwan could see between 100 mm to 200 mm and those in southern Taiwan around 100 mm.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NATIONAL LEADERS TO SHARE EXPERIENCES IN DEMOCRACY WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui and four former national leaders from countries that have no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China will take part in the inaugural meeting of the World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA) in Taipei next week.

Michael Ying-mao Kau, executive director of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) , made the announcement during a Central News Agency interview Saturday. The TFD was founded in June 2003 with support from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Legislative Yuan.

Kau, also the vice minister of foreign affairs, said that more than 100 ranking officials from governments and civic organizations from more than 20 countries in Asia will take part in the WFDA meeting Sept. 15-17 at the Taipei International Convention Center.

The three-day meeting will feature a number of speakers, who include Canadian parliamentarian David Kilgour on human rights in Asia; Michael H.H. Hsiao, national policy advisor to President Chen Shui-bian on the experience of Taiwan's democratization; and Professor Arthur Waldron of the University of Pennsylvania on the outlook of democratic development in Asia.
The meeting will also invite President Chen, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen to give speeches, Kau said.
Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh will host dinners in honor of the participants.
In view of the fact that the rise of China has become a hot topic in the world community, the meeting will also have a debate on how China's rise will affect the development of democracies in Asia.
The forum will also exchange views on such issues as religion, women, direct democracy and political responsibility, Kau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: FEMA Director Replaced as Head Of Relief Effort.
The Bush administration removed Michael D. Brown, the embattled director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, from the Gulf Coast disaster zone yesterday as the White House tried to regain footing amid criticism of its response to Hurricane Katrina, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEGETABLE PRICES HIT NEW HIGH AT TAIPEI'S WHOLESALE MARKET

TEXT.P: As Typhoon Khanun approaches Taiwan, the average price of vegetables skyrocketed to a record high of NT$47.3 (US$1.45) per kilogram on the wholesale market in Taipei Saturday.

Statistics from the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co. showed that the price surged NT$5.34 over the level of Friday, and broke the historical record of NT$43.2 per kilogram, seen right after Typhoon Talim rampaged through Taiwan Sept. 1.

The market received a total of 1,005 tons of vegetables Saturday, up 168 tons over the previous day. Despite the increasing supply, prices of most kinds of vegetables still went up, with that of scallion from Ilan, northern Taiwan posing a significant growth to NT$420 per kilogram.

Officials of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture blamed the hike on the public's anticipation of typhoon devastation. To meet the demand, the council has been working to release frozen stocks, while offering half-price tariffs to imported supplies.
Several hundreds tons of imported vegetables are expected to flow into the market by Monday, the officials said.
Typhoon Khanun is expected to leave Taiwan by Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES MATOU POMELOS ON HIS VISIT TO HOMETOWN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised the quality of pomelos grown in Matou township of Tainan in southern Taiwan Saturday during a visit to his hometown, saying that he intends to present the seasonal fruit to foreign diplomatic missions stationed in Taiwan as a gift in celebration of the Chinese traditional Mid-Autumn Festival, which will fall on Sept. 18 this year.

Chen made the announcement after growers complained that the president cared less about the sales of fruits grown in his hometown than those from other places, referring to pomelos from Touliou in Yulin County, central Taiwan, which Chen recently commended. The president was born in Tainan.

On his visit to Tainan, Chen met with local residents after visiting a temple, where he paid his respects after winning the presidential election in 2000. He then turned to Shanhua township for a beer festival.
At the event, Chen sampled Taiwan beef and beer, praising the two locally produced items, saying that they go with each other perfectly.

Encouraging the traditional manufacturing industry on the island to try to transform itself into a modern leisure-oriented industry, Chen suggested that local manufacturers try to dedicate themselves to the development of goods with added value, and try out new ideas.
Taking Taiwan beer as an example, he said local beer will sell well teamed up with slightly boiled Taiwan beef, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N COULD BENEFIT FROM ADVICE FROM ASIAN DEMOCRACY FORUM: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA) would be a useful tool for the United Nations and would provide valuable counseling, an official said Saturday.

Michael Ying-mao Kau, executive director of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) and vice foreign affairs minister, made the announcement during a Central News Agency interview Saturday. The TFD was founded in June 2003 with support from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Legislative Yuan.
The inaugural WFDA meeting is set for Sept. 15-17 at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Kau noted that in addition to inviting former President Lee Teng-hui and four former national leaders from countries that have no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China to attend the inaugural meeting of the WFDA next week to share their experience in promoting democracy, experts and democracy activists from Europe, America and Africa will also attend the biennial meeting.
Initiated by the TFD, Kau said several leading democratic institutes in Asia forged a consensus to promote the WFDA.

He noted that the organizational team was inaugurated in October 2004, and its members included the TFD, the Alliance for Reform and Democracy in Asia, the Alternative Asean Network on Burma, Forum Asia Democracy, and Initiatives for International Dialogue. The chairmen of the non-governmental organizations will come to Taipei to attend the meeting, he said.

Kau said that the inaugural meeting will discuss and adopt guidelines to promote the solidarity of Asian democracies, support democracy activists who are opposed to authoritarian regimes, and solicit support from the international community on democratization in Asia.

The plan is to submit the guidelines to the United Nations' Secretariat and member states for reference, and obtain the status of providing counselling to the U.N. so that the views of the WFDA can be passed to related meetings in the U.N. and Asia's democratic voice can be strengthened in the United Nations, he said.
Another focus of the meeting will be to discuss the formation of an index on which to gauge the quality of democratic countries in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Cabinet proposes a draft bill on telephone tapping.
The Cabinet meeting approved a draft bill on the telephone tapping Friday which stipulates that it can only be practiced in cases of serious crimes, such as terrorism, mafia and murder. The maximum penalty for journalists who publish transcription of illegal telephone tapping will be 5,000 euros.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO PRESENT BILL GOVERNING BUILD-OPERATE-TRANSFER PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) is working on a bill to provide the government with the legal framework to monitor the build-operate-transfer programs in the country, a PFP lawmaker said Saturday.

Hwang Yih-jiau, the convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said the bill, drafted by experts and scholars under commission of the party, will also give the Legislative Yuan a role in supervising these programs, including the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System and the Taiwan high-speed rail, although construction on the two projects is already underway by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation (KRTC) and the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), respectively.

The bill is almost finished except for a few parts which still have to be fleshed out and has received a positive response from the party's political ally in the legislature, the Kuomintang, Hwang went on.
Hwang said the PFP bill will oblige owners of private companies that win the right to build public BOT projects to follow the law regarding procedures, and give regular reports to the legislature.
According to the bill, Hwang said, major public BOT projects should be examined by foreign experts before the government accepts them.

Citing the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System and Taiwan high-speed rail as examples, Hwang claimed that currently the government has no way of controlling the private companies authorized to build these projects, although the government has provided the largest share of funds for their construction.
In order to bring these two projects under the control of the government and legislature, Hwang said the bill, if enacted, should be applied retroactively.

Both the KRTC and the THSRC have been embroiled in controversies recently after Thai workers at the KRTC rioted to protest bad treatment from the management, and the THSRC admitting that it could not meet the government's deadline to open the rail line in October of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LEGISLATOR LI AO TO MAKE 12-DAY VISIT TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Li Ao is scheduled to leave for Beijing Sept. 19 for a 12-day "cultural" visit to China, according to a news report from Beijing Saturday.
The Beijing Morning Post cited an executive of Peking University as saying that Li will visit the most prestigious university in China and deliver a speech there.
The official said that Li, a noted writer, will be greeted in his capacity as a scholar.
According to the report, the itinerary of Li's visit to China has been fixed and he will also go to Shanghai and Hong Kong. He is scheduled to wrap up the trip Sept. 30.
During his planned stay in Beijing Sept. 19-25, Li will also visit Tsinghua University, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GETTING THE RIGHT CARICATURE NO LAUGHING MATTER AT APEC EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: It's only natural for South Korea to display a caricature of President Chen Shui-bian alongside his counterparts from 20 other member states in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum who will attend the 2005 informal leadership meeting in Busan later this year, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Ministry spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks Saturday after the Busan City Government changed the caricature of the ROC's leader from Lee Yuan-tseh, the president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, to that of President Chen, at an exhibition thanks to the tenacious efforts of Taipei's representative office in South Korea.
Taipei's mission in South Korea said after the change that the caricature of Chen will help the South Korean public learn more about who the leader of the ROC really is.
The mission noted that in an APEC summit caricature exhibition that opened Sept. 5, the caricature of the ROC leader was shown as Lee.

The mission then negotiated with South Korean Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade and it in turn notified the Busan City Government and the Busan Cartoon Club, the sponsors of the exhibition, to replace the caricature to one of President Chen Friday.

The mission gave three reasons to convince South Korea to make the change: the exhibition is a cultural event and is not related to any political activity; the exhibition shows the caricatures of the 21 APEC members' heads of state and Chen is the president of the Republic of China on Taiwan; and as President Chen has yet to make a decision on whether to attend the meeting, it should respect the member economy of "Chinese Taipei."
Moreover, it is only natural to display the caricature of President Chen to avoid confusion. Chen is depicted in the caricature as in high spirits and all smiles.

The Busan Cartoon Club revealed that before the exhibition, the foreign affairs authorities has told them that the exhibition should show those who will attend the 2005 APEC summit in South Korea's second-largest city of Busan Nov. 18-19. For this reason, if the picture shown is someone who isn't going to come, then it would be inappropriate. Therefore, the club was forced to replace the original caricature of President Chen to that of Lee.
The show is expected to close Saturday night.

Because of Beijing's objections, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES PRIORITY TO FLOOD-CONTROL BILL

TEXT.P: The bill for a comprehensive national flood-control program should be the top priority for the next legislative session that opens Sept. 13, Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday.

Emerging from a conference with his Cabinet in Kaohsiung, the premier said he is amenable to debating the bill with the opposition who has threatened to kill the legislation on the grounds that it's nothing but pork barrel politics.

Other bills high on the premier's priority list include draft statutes to introduce a minimum tax system, to modify the debt-laden national insurance program, to reorganize the Executive Yuan and to impose income tax on military personnel and teachers.

He denied that he had given up his efforts to reconcile with the opposition-controlled legislature when he challenged the opposition Sept. 3 to oust his Cabinet with a non-confidence vote if they turned down his administration's request for a budget for the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control program, arguing that it was simply a way to break the political impasse between the executive and legislative branches.

The premier said, a non-confidence vote, which would lead eventually to asnap general election, is a mechanism provided for in the Constitution to settle disputes between the executive and legislative branches by the voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Death Toll in New Orleans May Be Lower Than First Feared
The first organized effort to scour the city for its dead has turned up far fewer bodies than expected, officials said Friday. That raised hopes that the death toll from Hurricane Katrina might be much lower than the 10,000 that the mayor and others had predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD URGES RATIONAL DISCUSSION ON ARTIFICIAL REPRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Department of Health Minister Ho Sheng-mao said Saturday that the public should rationally discuss whether to ease the current restrictions on artificial reproduction.

Ho made the remarks during a seminar on the performance of Premier Frank Hsieh's Cabinet in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, amid public concern about an accidental death of an army captain and his fiancee's request that his sperm be preserved in the hope that she could bear his child through artificial insemination.
Premier Hsieh cited the example of preserving evidence before any litigation process to say that the sperm should be preserved first before discussing its use within legal boundaries.
Otherwise, the precious timing may be lost forever, he said, adding that members of his Cabinet should take the initiative in solving problems.
Ho also said that he is glad to learn that the sperm is being preserved, and now is the time for everyone to discuss the matter rationally.

The incident could be considered from several points of view, Ho pointed out, including if the current conditions for artificial reproduction -- which targets barren and living husbands and wives -- can be eased, whether it can be set as a common practice for harvesting sperm after death, and whether ethics and folk customs can accept the practice, as well as taking stock of similar examples from other countries.

Capt. Sun Chi-hsiang, a 29-year-old company leader, was killed while guiding a tank onto a truck. The vehicle accelerated suddenly and lost control, crushing him to death. His 26-year-old fiancee, Lee Hsin-yu, begged the Minister of National Defense and other authorities to have his sperm preserved.
Lee came to an obs-gyn clinic in Taichung, central Taiwan, where Sun's sperm is being kept.

Lee, who came for a checkup, listened to the advice of a doctor who reminded her that the success rate for reproduction using a dead man's sperm for artificial insemination is lower and the risks for abortion or deformity are high.
Lee, who earlier was relieved after learning that her request to harvest the sperm was approved, was determined despite the reminder, saying that she has to try to give Sun a baby.
Meanwhile, Taiwanese Society for Reproductive Medicine on Saturday urged thorough consideration to protect the reproduction rights of single women.

Liu Chih-hung, president of the society, said that in developed countries, the reproduction right of single women is protected and considered a basic human right. But in Taiwan, the public has never given this much thought.

He pointed out the first article of a draft Artificial Reproduction Bill stipulates that it will only protect the reproduction right of infertile couples, which he said narrowly defines and neglects the reproduction rights of single women, and is not in tune with the social situation, citing the examples of Nita Ing, chairwoman of Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp., and actress Jodie Foster, saying that society does not discriminated against them because they are single and have children.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HEADS FOR LABOR AFFAIRS AND KAOHSIUNG CITY MAY NAMED SOON

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh suggested Saturday that he might have to name new chiefs for the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the Kaohsiung city before Sept. 13 when the Legislative Yuan begins its new session.

Hsieh told journalists after a meeting with his Cabinet members in Kaohsiung that he talked with Chen Chih-mai the acting mayor of the Kaohsiung city who offered to quit over a riot staged by Thai workers in Kaohsiung, but couldn't persuade Chen to change his mind.
The premier said he may also have to name a new head for the CLA after its minister Chen Chu resigned to take responsibility for the same riot of Thai workers.

Hsieh said both Chens were cleared of any responsibility for the incident according to an investigation conducted by his administration, but none of them would withdraw their resignations, Hsieh said, adding he would take a decision on their resignations before the Legislative Yuan gather for the next session.
Chen Chu and Chen Chih-mai didn't showup for Saturday's Cabinet meeting.

The riot which triggered their resignation took place on Aug. 21 when a group of Thai workers employed to build the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit systems smashed and set fire to their dormitory to vent their anger with the inhuman treatment from the management.
The riot tarnished the image of the country although no casualties were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Sept. 11, or the eighth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1297: Scottish patriot William Wallace leads a Scottish resistance force that defeats a much larger English force under the Earl of Surrey at the Battle of Stirling Bridge.
1777: English forces under General William Howe defeat George Washington's troops at the Battle of Brandywine Creek during the American War of Independence.
1830: The Republic of Ecuador is established.
1913: Shyong Shi-ling forms his so-called "first-rate Cabinet" after the Republic of China's first Congress was formed on April 8, 1913, under Yuan Shih-kai's dictatorial rule.
1917: Ferdinand Marcos, former president of the Philippines, is born. His conspicuously corrupt rule came to an end when he was deposed by the "People Power" revolution led by Cory Aquino.
1944: With the Nazis in retreat throughout Europe, the first Allied forces enter Germany when the U.S. First Army under General Omar Bradley crosses the German border at Eupen.
1944: Leaders of the United States and Britain decide at their second Quebec meeting during World War II to shift the focus from the European to the Pacific theater.
1963: Typhoon Gloria hits northern Taiwan, claiming more than 200 lives.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Mauritania.
1967: Indian and mainland Chinese troops clash in a border area in the Himalayas.
1971: Nikita Khrushchev, former Soviet premier, dies in obscurity at the age of 77.
1973: Chile's democratically elected Marxist government is overthrown in a U.S.-backed military coup, and President Salvador Allende is killed.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Paraguayan Vice Minister Raul Saguier Cabellero with the Order of the Brilliant Star with the Grand Cordon.
1979: A China Airlines Boeing 747 cargo plane crashes into the sea off Chuwei fishing port in Taiwan, killing all six people on board.
1980: The Dominican Republic decorates Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, along with five government officials for their contributions toward building friendship and coorperation between the Dominican and Chinese people.
1981: A three-day Sino-Japanese Strategic Study Seminar on political, military and economic problems in the Asia-Pacific region opens.
1985: Two trains collide head-on in Portugal, killing some 150 people.
1984: The NT$17.7 billion construction of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit system begins. It was originally slated for completion in June 1989.
1991: The National Science Council under the ROC Executive Yuan announces the establishment of a national space project directorial group, with council chairman Hsia Han-min as convenor.
1997: Scotland votes a resounding "yes" in a referendum to set up a separate Scottish parliament for the first time in nearly 300 years.
1998: Independent counsel Kenneth Starr tells the U.S. Congress that there are 11 grounds for the impeachment of President Bill Clinton.
1999: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang sends an ultimatum to former Taiwan Governor James Soong, a member of the ruling party, demanding that he withdraw his presidential bid or face punishment.
2000: ROC Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien urges the new administration to intensify its disaster prevention, disaster relief, and disaster recovery activities.
2000: The ROC and Australia sign a science and technology cooperation memorandum as well as a memorandum of understanding on the promotion of two-way investment in biological technology.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang condemns the terrorist attaks in New York and Washington, and expresses its "immeasurable regret and grief" over the casualties and losses.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The heaven appearing before us is only this bright, shining spot; but when taken in its immeasurable extent, the sun, moon, stars, and constellations are suspended in it, and all things are embraced under it."

Manila Bulletin: Officials allay EVAT fears
Officials of the Department of Finance (DoF) and the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) said yesterday that the impending implementation of the expanded value-added tax (EVAT) law will not have much impact on the prices of petroleum-based products and basic commodities.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Bishops set special meet -- Inquirer sources
