A 29-year-old Filipino maid was arrested in Singapore Saturday for the grisly murder of a woman, believed to be her compatriot, whose head and limbs were found in Singapore's shopping district, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANG LEE'S LATEST WINS GOLDEN LION AT VENICE FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Sept. 10 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwan-born director Ang Lee has done it again, with his latest work -- "Brokeback Mountain" -- winning the Golden Lion for best movie at the Venice Film Festival Saturday.

"Brokeback Mountain, " a Canadian-produced film starring Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal as two gay cowboys in the conservative American West of the 1960s, bested 19 other films to win the top award at the 62nd Venice Film Festival.

Receiving the award from Japanese animation film director Hayao Miyazaki, who won this year's Golden Lion Lifetime Achievement Award, Lee said: "I want to thank Annie Proulx for writing this moving great American love story that brought all of us together to make this movie."
"Thank you all for your support," he added in Chinese.

Lee, whose other masterpieces include "Sense and Sensibility" (1995) and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" (2000) , described "Brokeback Mountain" as a "unique and universal" story. "I'm so glad it's prevailed here and was received so warmly here."
Meanwhile, another Taiwan director, Lin Chien-ping, took the Leone Citroen Award for best short film, for his "Xiaozhan" (Small Station).

The 30-minute short film tells the story of a mother who takes her alienated and autistic adult son on a trip to a small town simply to watch trains at a railway station. The story, set in modern day Taiwan, tells how people who were labeled as "abnormal" by society struggled with despair and discrimination.
Lin's short film beat out nearly 800 other short films that entered in this year's Venice Film Festival, which witnessed the participation of a total of 1,907 films of various kinds.

The 62nd Venice Film Festival was described as being "very Asian," with its opening film being "Seven Swords," a feature by Hong Kong director Tsui Hark, and its closing film being "Perhaps Love" by Hong Kong director Peter Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FESTIVAL CHARMS BRITISH AUDIENCE
DOC.DATELINE: London, Sept.10 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A two-day "Taiwan Festival" program kicked off at Brent Cross Shopping Center in northern London Saturday, attracting large numbers of British shoppers to participate.

The festival has been organized by the Taipei Representative Office in the United Kingdom, which represents Taiwan's interests in Britain in the absence of diplomatic ties, as part of its efforts to promote bilateral cultural and civilian exchanges.

"The program is aimed at highlighting the differences between Taiwanese and Chinese performing arts and cultures, as well as helping British citizens understand that 'China is China, Taiwan is Taiwan,'" said Edgar Lin, the Republic of China's de facto ambassador to the U.K.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Lin said British citizens are welcome to take part in all the activities presented in the festival. He also took the opportunity to introduce the beauty of Taiwan's arts and culture.
Lin also introduced to the British audience Taiwan's master puppeteer Chen Hsi-huang, who has traveled to London to introduce Taiwan's unique style of puppetry.

Chen led his Tataocheng Puppet Troupe in putting on three dazzling puppet shows at Brent Cross Shopping Center Saturday, winning loud applause from the British audience. At the end of each show, Chen also demonstrated to some of the children in the audience how to manipulate the unique Taiwan puppets.
On Saturday, the Taipei Representative Office also arranged for Taiwan expatriates in Britain to present paper-cutting and calligraphic arts as part of the festival activities.

Special Taiwanese delicacies, including pineapple tarts, as well as handicrafts were handed out to shoppers. Two Taiwan carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways -- and BenQ computer company offered plane tickets and digital cameras as gifts for winners of a Taiwan-focused quiz show.

In the past, Lin said, Taiwanese culture and performing arts were usually presented in London as part of the activities in the "Chinese festival" organized by the Chinese Embassy and the municipality of London.
Lin said such arrangements apparently treated Taiwan as part of China and didn't really allow Taiwan to introduce the unique features of its culture to Londoners.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PROPOSALS ON TAIWAN'S U.N. BID TO BE SCREENED BY GENERAL COMMITTEE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 10 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin, Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two proposals submitted by Republic of China allies supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations have been listed to be screened by the U.N. General Committee to decide whether or not they will be put on the U.N. General Assembly's agenda.

Unlike previous years, Taiwan's diplomatic allies have presented two proposals to the U.N. Secretariat this year -- "the U.N. play an active role in ensuring peace in the Taiwan Strait" and that "the U.N. recognize the Taiwan people's right to representation" -- in the hope that both proposals will be put on the U.N. agenda.

It is expected that the "peace" proposal, submitted by 15 ROC allies, will be screened and voted on during the morning of Sept. 13, when the 2005 U.N. General Assembly kicks off, while the "representation" proposal, submitted by 12 ROC allies, will be screened and voted on during the afternoon of the same day.

As more than 100 proposals are scheduled to be screened, the ROC allies have suggested that the U.N. General Committee allow two representatives who support the proposals regarding Taiwan and two who are opposed to the proposals to debate the proposals in order to accelerate the screening process. As of press time, it was uncertain whether the General Committee would accept the suggestion.

Meanwhile, Andrew Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, stressed Saturday that one of the goals of Taiwan's "strenuous bid to enter the U.N. is to let the world understand the pressing issue of the Taiwan Strait crisis."

Hsia said that the founding of the United Nations in 1945 was a commitment to peace after years of war, referring to World War II, adding that today's U.N. has a responsibility to work to prevent the outbreak of military conflict in every region around the world.

He added that with China's passage in March of an anti-secession law which sets the conditions for the use of force against Taiwan, there is even more reason for Taiwan to draw the U.N.'s attention to the heightening threats to peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.
"Only the U.N. can act as a forum for maintaining security and peace," Hsia stressed.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year through its diplomatic allies to have its U.N. membership bid placed on the General Assembly's agenda. However, it has been unsuccessful due to Beijing's obstruction.

Last year, 21 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies voiced their support for the island's U.N. bid at a General Committee meeting, although the committee eventually decided not to put their proposal on the U.N. General Assembly's agenda.
According to Hsia, Beijing mobilized 94 countries to voice opposition to Taiwan's bid, dragging out the screening and voting process and eventually defeating the proposal.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, the ROC has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VICE ECONOMIC MINISTER TO TAKE UP DUTIES MONDAY

TEXT.P: New Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hou Ho-hsiung will formally take up his duties Monday, government sources said Sunday.

Hou, 61, will fill the post left vacant by the transfer of Yiin Chii-ming to serve as an Executive Yuan adviser over water supply problems in the northern county of Taoyuan in the wake of Typhoon Matsa in August.

In the past, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) assigned two of its vice ministers to, respectively, oversee its two water resources-related units -- the Water Resources Agency (WRA) and Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC).

This arrangement will be changed after Hou assumes his post, MOEA sources said. Hou will be charged with overseeing both WRA and TWC operations with a view to speeding up inter-department coordination and upgrading operational efficiency, the sources said.

Hou, a former deputy mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung who has a doctoral degree in civil engineering and coastal engineering from the University of Florida, will also oversee operations of the MOEA's Bureau of Mines, Energy Commission and Commission of National Corporations.

According to the MOEA sources, Hou will have to deal with a number of thorny issues, including adjustments of gasoline and electricity rates, water supply issues of the Shihmen Reservoir and an all-important eight-year NT$80 billion flood-control bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILL NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION BE SAME OLD STORY?By S.C. ChangCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: With the new session of the sixth Legislative Yuan set to open Tuesday, attention has focused on whether lawmakers will repeat their "politics over policy" fighting of the previous session and thereby increase the public's sense of frustration as a host of important bills are awaiting deliberation.

For now, the ruling camp, which does not enjoy a majority in the legislature, does not seem optimistic that a "new phase" of Taiwan politics characterized by rational debate and professional law making will emerge. The ruling party caucus leaders, however, are acknowledging the need for communication and compromise with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) in order to make some breakthroughs in the legislative agenda.

Only 46 bills were passed during the last legislative session, a record low since the fourth Legislative Yuan, leaving unresolved such critical bills as the special budgets for an arms procurement package and flood control, the establishment of the National Communications Commission (NCC) , direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, and the restructuring of the Executive Yuan -- the administrative branch of the government.

The political battle between the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, FPF and New Party and the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) has also stalled screening of President Chen Shui-bian's Control Yuan member nominations list, leaving the Control Yuan without members since February this year.

Analysts say one of the main reasons for the legislature's refusal even to screen the nominees' qualifications is PFP Chairman James Soong's demand that President Chen apologize for alleging that Soong had met with China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yun-lin in the United States early this year.

Many analysts have said that it is the Soong party's "scorched earth" strategy -- of refusing even to put the key arms purchase bill through the legislature's Procedure Committee -- that is straining the nerves of the ruling and opposition lawmakers and testing their ability to carry out their constitutional duties for the electorate.

Some analysts have predicted that Soong's party will not only block major government bills from being put on the legislative agenda, but will also make use of the two BOT scandals involving Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) to launch a new offensive against the government.

A Cabinet member and Kaohsiung's acting mayor have resigned to take responsibility for the KRTC incident triggered by a recent riot by Thai workers in protest of maltreatment; and the THSRC's announcement of postponing by a whole year the date of inaugurating high-speed rail service has prompted cries demanding that someone take responsibility for an estimated NT$66.7 billion loss incurred from the delay.

DPP legislative caucus convener Chao Yung-ching accused Soong of adopting an hard-line strategy to "hijack" both KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and national security. However, Soong's argument -- the Chen Shui-bian government's referendum on arms purchases was defeated last year, and the people's "direct opinion" on this issue cannot be vetoed by the legislature's "indirect opinion" -- has put the DPP in a straight jacket.

The KMT must cooperate with the PFP for another reason, according to PFP legislative caucus deputy convener Sun Ta-chien: If the KMT agrees to put the arms purchase bill through the Procedure Committee, the PFP will counter with a move that will be fatal to the KMT. Sun was referring to a DPP-proposed bill on political parties' "ill-gotten" assets, which has also been blocked from appearing on the legislative agenda because of KMT-PFP cooperation.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung, a convener of the legislature's National Defense Committee, said his party agrees that the arms bill must be carefully examined and that all unnecessary spending must be "taken out" to save money for taxpayers. However, he complained that even though all the committee members have agreed in private to "work together" to examine the arms bill item by item, this agreement "disappears when the members face the media's cameras because of partisan positions."

The legislature's handling of the arms bill is a key indicator of the nation's determination to upgrade its defense capabilities in the face of China's "non-peaceful" rise. The United States is watching closely, and all the lawmakers are aware of this.

The KMT is also aware of this, but it is inclined to let the legislature debate the bill. At the same time, it is now handicapped by its consideration of the year-end city and county elections in which the "pan-blue alliance" must work together, not to mention the PFP's threat to work with the DPP on the party assets bill.

Therefore, inside the "pan-blue alliance, " the interactions between Ma and Soong, and between Ma and Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan who was roundly defeated in the race for KMT leadership, will be closely watched as these interactions are a good indicator of how closely knit the alliance will remain.

For example, some in the DPP are depending on a possible difference between Wang and Ma on whether to put the arms bill on the legislative agenda for an "opportunity" to force the KMT into agreeing to do so. Wang has openly advocated that the bill should be deliberated on the legislative floor.

However, William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, has said he does not think it is practical for the DPP to "try to drive a wedge" between Ma and Wang or between Ma and Soong. Ko Chien-ming, executive director of the DPP Policy Committee who has rich experience in dealing with the "pan-blue alliance, " said it would be more feasible for the DPP to urge Wang to act as the speaker of the nation's legislature, rather than as a KMT or "pan-blue" member.

Ko said there seems no better alternatives for the DPP than seeking to communicate and compromise with the "pan-blue alliance." However, the compromise should not go as far as to "share power" with the opposition, according to Lee Wen-chung, who envisions an opposition demanding to form a "coalition government" with the DPP if some Cabinet posts are ceded to the KMT or PFP. In such a scenario, there would be infinite troubles, he added.

Still, given the nation's economic challenges and diplomatic isolation, if Premier Frank Hsieh's "reconciliation and symbiosis" slogan is to remain more than mere empty words, and if the DPP wants to break through the legislative impasse and push through the major bills in order to achieve its policy goals, there appears no better strategy for the ruling camp to follow than to listen to its Policy Committee head's advice for frank communication with the opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS INTERNATIONAL SCHOOLS CYBERFAIR FOR 3RD STRAIGHT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan won the 2005 International Schools Cyberfair championship by garnering a total of nine platinum, 13 gold, 15 silver and 24 special awards, a Ministry of Education official said Sunday.
It marked the third year in a row that Taiwan has won the event, said Liu Chin-ho, a deputy director of the education ministry's Computer Center.
The International Schools Cyberfair engages students in powerful educational story-telling activities, which benefit students and their communities.

According to Liu, the winners of Taiwan's 61 awards come from schools in every region of the country, reflecting that the government's efforts to reduce the so-called digital divide have borne fruit and that the development of information technology education in the country has been regionally balanced.

Among the award winners was the outlying island of Kinmen's Cho Huan Elementary School with a student population of only 160. Despite the school's distance from "big cities, " the students and teachers won a gold for Taiwan with their Web site design featuring Kinmen's forest industry dubbed "The Green Miracle."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR INTRAPARTY UNITY TO WIN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday to consolidate intraparty unity and integration to ensure a victory in the year-end "three-in-one" elections.

Chen made the appeal during a meeting with DPP politicians and grassroots civic representatives in the southern city of Chiayi on a range of issues, including the Dec. 3 elections for mayors/magistrates, city/county councilors and township chiefs, as well as the ongoing financial reforms.

Commenting on the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU's) decision to nominate its own candidate to run for the Chiayi mayorship, Chen said the DPP need not care too much about the TSU move and should instead step up integration of various intraparty forces to ensure re-election of incumbent Chiayi Mayor Chen Li-chen, a DPP standard-bearer.

The TSU, which controls 12 seats in the Legislative Yuan, has traditionally been a DPP ally as both parties advocate Taiwan's separate identity. But relations between the two parties have soured recently over the "three-in-one" elections issues. the TSU has insisted on fielding its own candidates in several constituencies, including Keelung and Chiayi.
Chen said he is convinced that the DPP would be able to retain its control of Chiayi City so long as it can consolidate its ranks.

Touching on the ongoing second phase of financial reform, Chen said the ultimate goal of the sweeping reform is to streamline local financial institutions and enhance their operational efficiency and global competitiveness.

According to the government's financial reform plan, the number of the state-owned banks must be halved from 12 to six by the end of this year and the number of financial holding companies must be halved from the current 14 to seven by the end of next year. Hopefully, Chen said, the merger and restructuring of local financial institutions will achieve economies of scale and enhance their competitive edges.
Through all these reforms, Chen said he is convinced that it will become easier for local banks to compete in the global financial service markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL WORRIED FEWER TAIWAN STUDENTS STUDYING ABROAD

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan students seeking advanced studies abroad has been decreasing over the past 10 years, according to the Ministry of Education, whose official fears that if the trend continues, Taiwan will run short of manpower for international competition.

Data provided by the Institute for International Education of the United States show that during the 2001-2002 academic year, 28,930 Taiwan students were studying in the U.S., ranked fifth among all foreign students. China ranked the second, with 63,211, next only to India's 66,836.

India continued to top the rankings with more than 79,000 students in the U.S. in 2003-2004, followed by China with 61,000, while Taiwan's ranking slipped to sixth, with 26,178, a decrease of seven percent from the previous academic year.

The Ministry of Education said the U.S., United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and Japan are the top five foreign countries accepting Taiwan students, whose number has been declining in tandem with the decrease in the U.S.

Professor Michael Porter of Harvard University has warned that if China's training of advanced manpower approaches or even surpasses that of Taiwan, which has been relying on its quality human resources to maintain its competitive edge, then Taiwan will have a big trouble for further development.

Chang Chin-sheng, director of the ministry's Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations, said the quality of foreign-trained professionals had contributed a great deal to Taiwan's economic development. Taiwan's high-tech industry has developed well because many U.S.-trained Taiwan students have returned home to lay a solid foundation by devoting their expertise in research and production, he said.

For the time being, Chang added, Taiwan still enjoys a competitive edge over China in high-tech manpower and investment environment, but for how long? "It will depend on our long-range manpower training program," he said.

Several reasons explain why there have been fewer Taiwan students seeking advanced studies overseas, Chang said, including Taiwan universities setting up their own graduate schools, Taiwan's poor economic performance over the past few years, higher tuition charged by U.S. universities, and growing difficulties for foreign students to get U.S. visas.

What worried Chang most was what he calls "the declining enthusiasm of Taiwan's young people to seek new knowledge in advanced countries, " a phenomenon that he claims will blunt Taiwan's international competitiveness, leading to Taiwan's marginalization even without China's boycott in all sectors of economy and different spheres of life.

He said if the trend continues, fewer and fewer faculty members in Taiwan's higher education institutes will have foreign degrees. He called on the people to look squarely into the future and encourage youngsters to further studies abroad so that Taiwan will be able to compete internationally in the age of globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS CALL FOR IMPROVED EMPLOYMENT CONDITIONS FOR YOUTH

TEXT.P: Are young people confronted with prevailing poverty? Academics and young employees said Sunday this is quite true, and the government needs to do something to stop 20- and 30-somethings from being exploited in the job market.

At a seminar co-sponsored by the Alliance of Fairness and Justice, Lin Chia-ho, executive director of Taiwan Labor and Social Policy Research Society, said "flexible working conditions" and unstable job market have caused stress for young employees.

Lin said some studies have shown that by 2050, the world will become a 20-80 society in which only 20 percent of the population will be able to boost productivity, and young people will account for these 20 percent.

A woman delegate working in the advertisement industry said she has to work more than 10 hours a day for a monthly pay of NT$23,000 to NT$25,000. Supposedly she can take some days off, but dares not for fear of losing her job, and long-time stress has created some health troubles for her.

Example like that prompted Lin to suggest that if the job market trend cannot be changed, government leaders must design some mechanism for young workers to survive, such as the social safety net of some advanced countries where people enjoy a better quality of life in spite of the same unstable job market.
He also called on the government to take care of the middle- and advanced-aged groups who are also being affected by the unstable job market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC MUM ON SOONG'S PLAN TO TRAVEL VIA 'MINI 3 LINKS' ROUTE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) would not comment on opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's plan to travel via the "mini three links" route across the Taiwan Strait until after Soong unveils details of his plan, an official said Sunday.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the remarks after PFP Legislator Chang Hsieh-yao said earlier in the day that Soong would not break any existing law or regulations if he returns to Taiwan via the "mini three links" route after attending a cross-strait elite forum in Shanghai in mid-September.

The "mini three links" route refers to direct shipping services between the two Taiwan-held frontline islands of Kinmen/Matsu and two port cities of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian province. Direct cross-strait air and shipping links have been suspended for decades, but since January 2001, Taiwan has allowed direct trade, postal and shipping links between Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/ Mawei, commonly known as the "mini three links."

While the government still imposes certain conditions for those who want to travel via the "mini three links" route, You said, the government is willing to deal with certain applications on a case-by-case basis under certain circumstances.
"The MAC will decide how to respond to Soong's plan after the PFP unveils details of Soong's itinerary and travel purposes," You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKS FORWARD TO BETTER TIES WITH JAPAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China looks forward to increasingly reinforced ties with Japan after Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi won a mandate to push ahead with his reform program in Sunday's lower house elections, an official said.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after Koizumi said late Sunday night that it appeared his Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) had won a lower house majority. The leader of the main opposition Democratic Party conceded defeat later.
Lu said Japan is one of Taiwan's most important trade partners and democratic allies.

"We are concerned about the results of the Japanese parliamentary elections. For Taiwan, it is hoped that the Koizumi government will continue working for peace and stability in the West Pacific region, particularly further boosting friendly ties with Taiwan on the current basis, " Lu said.

Public broadcaster NHK and several commercial networks said exit polls indicated the Liberal Democrats stood to win as many as 309 of the powerful lower house's 480 seats, 60 more than it held before Koizumi dissolved it. TBS, another network, said the LDP would win 307 seats.
The main opposition party, the Democrats, was expected to win 104 seats, a devastating plunge from its previous standing of 175 seats, NHK said.
An official vote count won't be released until Monday morning.

Lu said the foreign ministry will ask the ROC's representative office in Tokyo to convey felicitations from President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen to Japanese authorities after the final electoral outcome is announced.

Meanwhile, Koh Se-kai, the ROC representative to Japan, said he believes that Taiwan-Japan relations will continue to grow steadily after the LDP won a landslide victory in the lower house election Sunday. The victory has granted Koizumi overwhelming public approval for his plan to privatize Japan's postal service.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Sept. 12, or the ninth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1683: The two-month siege of Vienna ends when the Turkish Ottoman army surrounding the city is routed by a European relief force, marking an end to Turkish domination in eastern Europe.
1910: Mrs. Alice Stebbin Wells is appointed by the Los Angeles Police Department as the first policewoman in the world. She was a social worker in her previous career.
1913: Jesse Owens, American track and field athlete who won four gold medals at the Berlin Olympics in 1936, is born.
1949: The new West German parliament meets for the first time in Bonn and elects Konrad Adenauer as chancellor.
1951: British mountaineers find footprints of the "abominable snowman" on Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1953: U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy marries Washington Times-Herald photo-journalist Jacqueline L. Bouvier in Newport, Rhode Island.
1953: Nikita Khrushchev is elected first secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1959: The Soviet Union launches Luna 2, the first spacecraft to reach the moon.
1968: Albania announces that it is withdrawing from the Warsaw Pact.
1971: Lin Piao, deputy chairman of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and army leader who was appointed Mao Tse-tung's successor as a reward for his contributions toward purging Liu Shao-chi, dies in a plane crash in Outer Mongolia after failing in an attempt to kill Mao on Sept. 8.
1974: The Executive Yuan ratifies extension of the Sino-Salvadoran agricultural technical cooperation agreement for two years.
1976: Dr. Alfred Eggers Jr., vice chairman of the U.S. National Science Foundation, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1977: The Forum on Europe-Asia opens at the Presidential Hotel in Taipei with 30 Chinese and 11 European scholars participating.
1977: Gen. Jose Dolores Gerardo Herrera, El Salvador's first resident ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume his duties.
1982: Hua Kuo-feng is removed from his posts as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and its military commission and replaced by Hu Yao-pang and Teng Hsiao-ping, respectively, at the 12th CCP Congress.
1984: The ROC Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan is established with Wang You-tsao as its chairman.
1985: The United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei inaugurates the world's first Chinese-language ATM.
1985: The ROC Control Yuan approves the 5th nomination of 16 Grand Justices by President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1987: Communist rebels battle government troops in fierce fighting near Manila, the Philippines.
1990: West and East Germany and the World War II Allies sign a treaty to restore sovereignty to a united Germany.
1993: A French cargo plane arrives in Taipei to open air services between the two countries.
1997: Jiang Zemin, mainland Chinese president and head of the CCP, redefines Chinese socialism at the opening of the Communist Congress.
1999: U.S. President Bill Clinton urges Taiwan and mainland China to end their confrontation, saying that otherwise, the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will suffer.
2000: The Investigators Reform Association threatens to make public National Security Council information collection activities on opposition parties if the NSC fails to stop such activities.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian sternly condemns the deadly terrorist attacks on major U.S. targets, saying the move was a grave challenge to democracy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The earth, appearing before us, is only a handful of soil; but taken in all its breadth and depth, it sustains the mighty Himalayas without feeling their weight; rivers and seas dash against it without causing it to leak."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY WRANGLING UNDERMINING NATIONAL DEFENSE DEVELOPMENT: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that irrational inter-party wrangling poses the greatest challenge to the development of the nation's defenses, referring mainly to the long-stalled arms procurement bill in the legislature.

Addressing a joint ceremony held at National Defense University to mark the beginning of the new academic year for several military institutes, Chen blamed the opposition parties for their irrational boycott of and procrastination in endorsing plans aimed at upgrading and modernizing the military's capabilities.
The opposition's obstruction has seriously undermined the upgrading of the armed forces' combat preparedness and Taiwan's deterrence and defense strategies, Chen claimed.

Chen stressed that the procurement of the three weaponry items that the United States has offered to sell to Taiwan -- namely eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- was decided upon prior to his being elected president in 2000.
The president asked: "How can Taiwan require its allies come to its rescue in a crisis when the country itself remains reluctant to make efforts to beef up its own defensive capabilities?"
Chen urged the legislature to act with a sense of responsibility and review and pass the arms procurement bill as soon as possible.

He said that if the opposition parties harbor different opinions about the costs or the items of the procurement plan, these differences can be tackled through debate in the Legislative Yuan, adding that the administration will also actively seek, via negotiations, to increase the annual budget for military spending on a yearly basis and gradually return the annual national defense budget to a level equivalent to 3 percent of the country's gross national product (GNP).
