DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF SOUTHEAST ASIAN PROSTITUTES IN TAIWAN ON THE RISE: NPA

TEXT.P: The number of prostitutes from Southeast Asian countries is on the rise in Taiwan, while the number from China is on the decline as a result of the government's tighter controls, National Police Administration (NPA) officials reported Monday.

NPA officials quoted tallies compiled by the top police office as indicating that 140 foreign nationals were apprehended in the first six months of this year for engaging in the illegal sex trade in Taiwan, up 83 from the year earlier level. Of the 140 foreigners nabbed, Vietnamese, Cambodians and Indonesians topped the list, with their numbers totaling 56, 25 and 24, respectively.
According to NPA statistics, 41 foreign women were arrested for prostitution in Taiwan in 2002, and 45 were nabbed in 2003. The figure shot up to 152 in 2004.

Between Jan. 1, 2002 and June 30, 2005, 156 Vietnamese women were arrested for prostitution in Taiwan, while 81 Thai women, 51 Indonesian women and 41 women from Cambodia were nabbed during the same period, according to the NPA tallies.

By comparison, NPA officials said, the number of women from mainland China, Hong Kong or Macau arrested in Taiwan for prostitution in the first six months of this year totaled 667, representing a decline of 500, or 43 percent, from last year's figure for the same period.

NPA officials attributed the significant decline mainly to a series of "deterrent" measures taken by the government, including compulsory interviews upon arrival at Taiwan airports for this group of mainland citizens.

Meanwhile, only 36 mainland Chinese women who sneaked into Taiwan with the help of "snakehead" human trafficking rings were nabbed in the first six months of this year, down 206, or 85 percent, from the level for the same period a year earlier, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOMECOMING PASSENGERS WARNED AGAINST BRINGING IN FRUIT, MEAT

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) Monday warned overseas Taiwan citizens returning home for the upcoming Mid-Autumn Festival holiday against attempting to bring in food and fruit products from abroad, to help keep epidemic diseases at bay.

Officials from the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Inspection and Quarantine (BAPIQ) instructed homecoming passengers not to bring with them products such as moon cakes containing meat or fresh fruit originating from China or Southeast Asian countries where foot and mouth disease, avian flu, rabies and swine streptococcus are declared epidemic diseases.

Allowing imports of unsafe food and fruit products from these areas unchecked could leave Taiwan's agricultural and livestock industries compromised and people's health impaired, BAPIQ officials stressed.

The officials noted that the COA has arranged for sniffer dogs to be on duty at airports and seaports to beef up searches of inbound passengers and their luggage. The dogs are capable of sniffing out dozens of goods, including mangoes, apples, pears, oranges, garlic, beef, pork, duck and chicken.
Any food and fruit products discovered will be destroyed or ordered to be shipped back to point of origin, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FACTION WANTS PRESIDENT TO DISSOLVE LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Monday to support constitutional amendments so that the president can dissolve the Legislative Yuan.

The lawmakers of the Justice Alliance, a major DPP faction, was responding to recent remarks by Ma in which he said that if the government is serious about pushing for a second phase of constitutional reforms, it should return the legislature's power to exercise the "right of consent" on the president's nomination of the premier, a power that was taken away when the Constitution was amended during former President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.

Gao Jyh-peng, secretary-general of the Justice Alliance, called a press conference Monday to say that if the legislature's right of consent on the premier is reinstated, the legislature will be all-powerful and turn the nation's government into a parliamentary system rather than the existing system that tilts more toward presidential one.

He noted that both President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank hsieh want to dissolve the legislature, hoping to learn from the example of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who dissolved the Japanese parliament and called a new election to seek a new mandate for reforms.

Hsieh recently challenged the opposition parties, which enjoy a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature and have refused to pass an NT$80 billion special budget bill for flood control, to topple his Cabinet with a motion of no-confidence. Such a legislative move would then allow President Chen to dissolve the opposition-controlled legislature and pave the way for new legislative elections.

Legislator Chuang Suo-hang said Ma should support the second phase of reforms so as to resolve the current stalemated legislature, referring to several major bills that are bogged down due to the continued boycotting of the opposition parties.

Legislator Huang Wei-cher said the opposition's refusal to confirm the Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen has resulted in a constitutional crisis and that if the legislative right to consent of the premier is reinstated, then the nation could come to a complete stop.

Legislator Jao Yung-ching said a constitutional amendment to allow the president to take the initiative to dissolve the legislature will help solve the political stalemate and stop the legislature from abusing its power.

Under the existing Constitution, after the Legislative Yuan initiates a no-confidence motion to topple the Executive Yuan, the premier must resign within 10 days or ask the president to dissolve the legislature.
On the other hand, a KMT caucus whip in the legislature said Taiwan has neither a presidential system nor a parliamentary one and that it is meaningless to talk about toppling the Cabinet.

KMT Legislator Cho Po-yuan claimed that under the current governing system, the president has "rights but no responsibilities" while the premier has "no power and only responsibilities" and that the premier is only the "executive director" of the president's policy.

If the ruling party wants a new mandate from the public by electing a new legislature, Cho said President Chen himself should resign along with his entire Cabinet to pave the way for simultaneous elections of the president and the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 45.92 points to close at 6,164.98.
The bourse opened at 6,155.38 and fluctuated between 6,166.11 and 6,130.99 during trading. A total of 2.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.48 billion (US$2.03 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 1.5 percent and textile stocks gaining 0.1 percent.

The other six major categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent, construction issues and foodstuff issues both at 0.2 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 459 to 437, with 145 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLLEGE STUDENTS RECRUITED TO GIVE AFTER-SCHOOL TUITION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has been working with the National Youth Commission (NYC) to carry out a "hand-in-hand" project to help both college/university students in financial straits and remote middle schools with fewer educational resources than their urban counterparts.

The plan is scheduled to be put into practice on a trial basis from Sept. 19-Dec. 31. Through the NYC's Web site for students looking for part-time work, the MOE plans to recruit 500 college or university students from low-income families to give tutorial lessons in middle schools around the island. Low income is defined as income lower than NT$1.14 million (US$34,900) per year, MOE officials said Monday.

For the time being, over 1,100 college students have applied for the job, while more than 198 middle schools have submitted demands for after-school tutors to help students with weak academic performance.
Each tutor will be paid NT$300 an hour by the MOE, with an additional travel subsidy of between NT$1,000 to NT$3,000, according to ministry officials.

With the tutorial project, the MOE hopes that it can not only help underprivileged students out of financial straits but also help reduce the wide margin between urban and rural middle school students in the academic performance, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO SEEK TO HOST 2009 INTERNATIONAL OLYMPIC COMMITTEE CONGRESS

TEXT.P: Taipei has won the support of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports in its attempt to seek the right to host the 2009 Congress of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), Taipei City officials said Monday.

If Taipei is successful, its hosting of the largest gathering of international sports organizations would no doubt help boost the international profile of the capital city and the development of relevant businesses, according to city bureau of education officials.
Taipei must file its application to the IOC before Oct. 3, since the host city for the 2009 event must be decided in 2006, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN BLUE' MEMBERS ADVOCATE GLOBAL CHINESE UNION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 11 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two key members of Taiwan's opposition "pan blue alliance" are in Washington to promote a Global Union of Chinese Commonwealth (GUCC), an idea that seeks consolidation of all Chinese people around the world and makes peace across the Taiwan Strait its top guiding principle.

Yok Mu-ming, chairman of the tiny New Party -- the smallest of the three political parties that make up the opposition "pan blue alliance" -- and Joanna Lei, a New Party consultant and a legislator of the Kuomintang -- the largest party in the alliance -- arrived in Washington Sunday to tout the GUCC concept in th U.S. capital.

Yok noted that he mentioned the GUCC idea during a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao when he visited Beijing in July and said he will raise the topic during a discussion with scholars from the Brookings Institution Monday. He did not elaborate on how or even whether Hu responded to his GUCC advocacy.

Meanwhile, Lei, who also hosts a television talk show focusing on major political and economic issues in Taiwan, said that seeking cross-strait peace is the top guiding principle of the GUCC and that unification is only one of the options.

On the question of whether the GUCC might appear naive or unrealistic at a time when China still refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan should the nation edge toward formal independence, particularly after Beijing passed its Anti-Secession Law in March targeting Taiwan, Lei said that pursuing cross-strait peace is the common wish of all Taiwan people and that the New Party-initiated GUCC is an idea with peace and reconciliation as its prerequisite.
Under this concept, Lei said, the New Party expects Beijing to show sincere goodwill toward Taiwan to help expedite the arrival of peace across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET PROBE INTO RIOT BY THAI LABORERS TO BE FINALIZED

TEXT.P: Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung will present the results of an investigation into a recent riot by Thai laborers to Premier Frank Hsieh Tuesday, Cabinet sources said Monday.

As the Legislative Yuan will open a new session Tuesday, political observers originally predicted that the Cabinet would unveil its report Monday on the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for a mass rapid transit system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
But Hsu's office said the report would not be referred to Hsieh Monday because of some procedural issues.

Investigations by Hsu's team show that the riot was mainly related to labor management flaws involving Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Co. (KRTC) and Huapan Administrative Consultant Co., the Cabinet sources said.
As to the political responsibility for the fiasco, the sources said both central and local governments have some "responsibility of supervision."
According to the report, the sources said, the existing foreign laborer management system and supervisory operations require a comprehensive review and improvements.
Both Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai have tendered their resignations to shoulder political responsibility for the riot.
Hsieh has said on many occasions that even though both officials have some "accountability of supervision, " the extent of their responsibilities do not merit their resignations.
If they both insist on quitting, Hsieh said over the weekend, they should remain in his administrative team and take on other jobs to continue serving the country.

The Aug. 21 riot began when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory after a day off and were barred from bringing in alcohol and cigarettes, a move that was the final straw in a long list of grievances. The workers burned cars and battled police with stones and slingshots. The laborers, who are building Kaohsiung's MRT system, complained about rigorous management rules and poor living conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 51 points to close at 6,165, with 18,912 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 50 points to end at 6,161, with 983 contracts traded, while December futures gained 40 points to finish at 6,158, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,114 for September, 6,111 for October, 6,102 for December, 6,105 for March and 6,090 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

September TE futures moved up 4.1 points to close at 257.5, with 4,112 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 3.85 points to finish at 257.25, with 305 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 4.6 points to end at 257.5, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 927.6, with 2,461 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 0.6 points to end at 924, with 447 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 6.6 points to close at 918, with two contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 8.4 points to finish at 920, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.066 to close at NT$32.684.
A total of US$781 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.650 and fluctuated between NT$32.628 and NT$32.701.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: We'll win.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi told his allies Sunday at a Forza Italia regional chapter gathering that a poll made during the period between the beginning of this summer and September shows both the ruling coalition and the opposition union are tied at 48.3 percent of popularity. The ruling coalition should be proud of what it has doneand will win the next year's general elections, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS SIMULTANEOUS REVIEW OF NCC BILL, CABINET ORGANIC LAW

TEXT.P: Taipei, Sept. 12 (The) Premier Frank Hsieh expressed hopes Monday that the Legislative Yuan will review simultaneously a proposed amendment to the Executive Yuan Organic Law and a proposed National Communications Commission (NCC) Organic Law.

In a meeting with Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in which Wang expressed reservations about linking the two bills, Hsieh noted that if the NCC Organic Law is passed but the proposed amendment to the Executive Yuan Organic Law is not, then there will be a "conflict of legal basis" because the amendment package is a prerequisite for the creation of an NCC.
But Wang claimed that the proposed NCC Organic Law can be passed first and that it will be "no problem" to review quickly the proposed amendment to the Executive Yuan Organic Law.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has listed the proposed NCC organic law as priority bills in the new legislative session, saying that it will vote on the issue Sept. 25 after a four-month waiting period for inter-party consultation expires without consensus having been reached.

At issue is the opposition's stance that the members of the NCC should be named in proportion to the ratio of legislative seats held by each political party, an idea to which Hsieh is opposed. The "pan-blue alliance" controls a thin majority in the 225-seat legislature.

The premier also expressed hope that Wang will coordinate on such priority bills on an arms procurement package and a flood-control project, as well as the confirmation of Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian.

Wang said that he will "do what he can" concerning the arms procurement package, adding that although the Executive Yuan has shown goodwill in listing one of the three big-ticket items in the package -- six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries -- on the regular annual budget, the two other items -- eight diesel-electric anti-missile submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- listed under "special budget" will need "further coordination."
The opposition parties will also take national defense, finance and cross-strait relations into their overall considerations, Wang said.

On the stalled confirmation of Control Yuan members nominated by Chen, Wang expressed the hope that the president will respect the legislature's wish to name a new list and communicate with the lawmakers on the issue.
On the flood-control project, Wang conveyed the "pan-blue alliance" stance that it will rigorously screen the project so as to use the taxpayers' money wisely.

The premier also asked the Legislative Yuan to review the budget of the central government quickly so as not to affect economic development and delay a calculation of the nation's economic growth rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO SET MIDWIFERY GUIDELINES FOR WATER-BIRTHS FOLLOWING DEATH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health said Monday it will set guidelines for midwives helping women give birth in water.
The DOH made the decision in the wake of a reported death of a baby after its mother tried to give birth in water at a midwife clinic in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
The clinic's owner, Tsai Sha-ning, denied the report.

In 1999, Tsai assisted a Miss Lai, who had lived in France, in giving birth to a child in water, an alternative method of childbirth in the developed world. Ever since, Tsai has helped nearly 100 women to do so, five of whose babies have died in the process.

Hsu Chen-chieh, president of the Taiwan Society of Perinatology, said infant mortality is about 0.2 percent in normal childbirth and that the 5 percent rate for water-born infants apparently is too high.
He said it is not the procedure that is to blame, but rather the clinic's ability to handle such incidents as contamination, lack of oxygen and suffocation.
Wang Chung-lang, a gynecologist-turned-DOH official, said that throughout Taiwan, there are only 25 registered midwife clinics that help a little over 500 childbirths, mostly in remote areas.

Wang said the number of water births in Taiwan is too small to determine the mortality. However, to avoid medical disputes, the DOH will adopt three principles: To regularly check the qualifications of midwives and update their knowledge and skills; to ensure that pregnant women are informed of the risks involved in giving birth in water in Taiwan; and to set up guidelines on the standard operating procedure that can be used as evidence to determine if a midwife is professionally responsible for any mishap.

Hsu said in some countries where midwifery is common, clinics are integrated into the national health care system in such a way that whenever an emergency occurs, patients can be referred to a hospital immediately.
He noted that with the hospital as a back up, infant mortality can be greatly reduced in water-births.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM DENIES REPORT HE WAS TREATED UNFAIRLY IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen denied a news report Monday that he received improper treatment during a transit at the New York airport in May on his way to visit two Republic of China allies in the Caribbean.

The report claimed that instead of being treated as dignitaries under international diplomatic protocol, Chen and his wife were told like ordinary passengers to pass through a process of security checks, including a body search, by New York security officials.

Chen said the report was not true. He explained that at the time, the U.S. officials assigned to greet him at the airport arrived late. "There was no offense" taken by him, and besides, he went on, the relevant U.S. authorities had already made a sincere apology for the minor incident. He also denied having been frisked.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPECT DPP MUD-SLINGING IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Expect the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to come out slinging mud during campaigning for the year-end local elections, Chan Chun-poh, secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday.

Chan told party lawmakers in a meeting that the DPP is expected to go all out to win the elections for county and city chiefs, county and city councilors, and township chiefs, and is almost certain to try to tarnish the opposition's image by presenting their performance in the Legislative Yuan in the worst light possible.
The opposition KMT and People First Party, which control a slim majority between them in the legislature, often reject the DPP administration's bills, to the frustration of the ruling party.

Furthermore, Chan said, among the KMT candidates for county and city chiefs, six are legislators and six are ex-lawmakers. Their DPP rivals are sure to make their voting records in the Legislative Yuan issues in the campaign.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a member of the KMT, also cautioned party lawmakers to think carefully about how to react to the government's various key bills in the forthcoming session. These include flood-control, arms purchase, a national communications committee bill, the revision of the Organic Law for the Executive Yuan, and the president's nominees to fill the paralyzed Control Yuan.
Wang said one misstep with these bills could provide the DPP ammunition against the KMT in the year-end elections and compromise the party's chance for victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN RELATIONS EXPECTED TO GROW AFTER KOIZUMI'S LANDSLIDE WIN

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Monday that the Japanese administration of Junichiro Koizumi is friendly to Taiwan and bilateral relations are expected to grow steadily, after the prime minister won an overwhelming victory in Sunday's lower house elections.
Koizumi's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) won an absolute majority of 296 seats in the lower house for the first time in 15 years. The LDP has ruled Japan for most of the past 50 years.
Chen said, "Koizumi has personal charisma, and he is brave enough to say what he wants to say. It is obvious that Japanese voters like this kind of leader. "

The ministry feels that Koizumi's administration will continue good relations with Taiwan, even though some of the Dietmen who were part of a parliamentary group who have long supported Taiwan were defeated because of their opposition to postal reform, Koizumi's key reform plan.

Chen cited as an example of Japan's intent its inclusion of the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue as a common strategic objective with the United States for the first time in the security consultative committee meeting in late February.

Japan also supports Taiwan's bid to become an observer in the World Health Organization and has waived visa requirements for Taiwan tourists, indicating that Taiwan-Japan relations are growing steadily, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Visits as New Orleans Sees Some Gains
President Bush arrived for his third visit as the stricken city continued its determined struggle to recover from Hurricane Katrina.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: EBay Agrees to Buy Skype For $2.6 Billion in Cash, Stock
EBay agreed to acquire Internet-telephony firm Skype for $2.6 billion in cash and stock, posing a new threat to phone companies and expanding the reach of the online-auction company.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LAWMAKER TO SPEAK AT THREE NOTED CHINESE UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Li Ao is scheduled to leave for Beijing Sept. 19 for a 12-day "cultural journey."
Li is expected to speak at three noted universities -- Peking University, Tsinghua University and Fudan University and attend seminars.

Li, also a prolific writer, attended a teleconference between Taipei, Beijing and Hong Kong Monday. He was accompanied by Liu Changle, chairman and CEO of Phoenix TV, who has helped arrange Li's trip to China.

Li, 70, said that he has lived in Taiwan for 56 consecutive years without ever making an overseas trip. Although he is going to visit China, it is not an "overseas visit, " because "the mainland is part of China, and Taiwan is also part of China."
Li, who is from Jilin province in northeastern China, said "Taiwan is also my hometown, " and it is not a homecoming or a revisitation, and he feels no homesickness.

Noting that Peking University rolled out the red carpet for former U.S. President Bill Clinton and former opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan when they visited the university, Li said the school "can spare the trouble" this time, because he is not going in his capacity as a guest, vowing, however, to give a more brilliant speech than the other two.
According to an earlier report, the itinerary of Li's visit to China has been fixed and he will also go to Shanghai and Hong Kong. He is scheduled to wrap up the trip Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE'S OK OF PREMIER WOULD NECESSITATE POWER BALANCE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday if the legislature were to be given back its right of consent on the premier's appointment, the president would also have to be given the right to dissolve the legislature.
Chen made his comments while meeting a group of French members of the National Assembly at the Presidential Office.

The comment was a response to Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's suggestion that the Legislative Yuan's power to veto the presidential appointment of the premier should be reinstated if a new round of constitutional amendments is to be pursued.
Ma reportedly made his remarks when meeting with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng. However, Ma also said there is absolutely no need at present to push for revising the nation's basic law.

Chen said under the ROC Constitution, the president does not have the automatic right to disband the legislature; nor does the legislature have the right to veto the president's appointment of the premier.
Ma's proposal is aimed at making the president appoint someone who would be supported by the majority in the legislature, according to the president.

Ma and many like him haven't thought through how the French style of "dual heads of government " might be applied to Taiwan, but were that to come to pass, the president should have the power to dissolve the legislature when he sees fit, Chen said.

If the Constitution is to be amended for the legislature to enjoy the power to veto a presidential appointment, it should be done in a comprehensive and well-rounded package, not just for the interest of a certain party, Chen said.
Taiwan has tried to frame France's "dual heads of government" system into Taiwan's Constitution, Chen said, but the attempt was not successful, and there have been constitutional problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES FRANCE TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he earnestly hopes that France can help with Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations or at least refrain from publicly opposing it.

Chen made the appeal while meeting with a delegation from the French National Assembly, which is currently on a visit in Taipei. His call came on the eve of the opening of the annual U.N. General Assembly plenary session in New York.

Of the 190-plus countries in today's world, Taiwan is the only one with no representation in the U.N. This unfair situation dates back to 1971 when the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China (PRC) at Taiwan's expense.
Hopefully, Chen said, France can pay attention to and show concern for the 23 million Taiwan people's lack of representation in the United Nations.

"We look forward to your country's assistance to our U.N. bid, " Chen told his guests. If France cannot extend a helping hand in this regard, Chen said, it should at least refrain from explicitly speaking against Taiwan's cause.
France maintains formal diplomatic ties with China and voiced opposition to Taiwan's U.N. bid during previous U.N. General Committee debates.
Chen recalled that the political ideals of freedom and equality as advocated in the French Revolution have had a far-reaching impact on many countries around the world, including Taiwan.
Noting that China's Anti-Secession Law codifies the use of non-peaceful means to resolve its disputes with Taiwan, Chen said such a move is in stark violation of the spirit of the French Revolution.
Against this backdrop, Chen said he wonders why French President Jacques Chirac pushed the European Union to lift its ban on arms sales to China.

The E.U. imposed the arms ban after the 1989 Tiananmen Massacre in which Chinese troops brutally crushed pro-democracy demonstrators. Over the past 16 years, Chen said, China has not made any progress in human rights protection.

"The reasons for the E.U. arms ban have not disappeared. If the E.U. were to lift the ban lightly, it seems to me that the E.U. would be encouraging an undemocratic and belligerent China to use E.U.-provided weapons to attack democratic and peace-loving Taiwan, " Chen said.

Over the past decade, Chen said Taiwan-French trade, cultural and technological exchanges have become ever closer. Two-way trade reached 3.9 billion euros last year. Chen said he hopes bilateral trade and cooperation in various fields can continue to grow in the years ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP KEEPS PUBLIC GUESSING ON CHIEF'S RETURN FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Instead of returning from a seminar in China later this month to Taiwan via Kinmen as initially announced, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will decide the day before his departure from China how to get back to Taiwan, a PFP official said Monday.

Chang Hsien-yao, the director of the PFP's policy center, said he met with an official of the Mainland Affairs Council Monday to talk about Soong's plan to return from Shanghai later this month through the frontline island of Kinmen, which has direct shipping links with Xiamen in southern China, but was told that the transport service is available only to Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland and residents of Kinmen.
Other people are not eligible for this service unless in an emergency or with the approval of the MAC, Chang quoted the MAC official as saying.
Soong, who will preside over the opening of a political forum between Taiwan and mainland China in Shanghai Sept. 16, said he planned to return from Shanghai through Kinmen.
However, Chang said, Soong will have to reconsider since the MAC refuses to greenlight the trip, and will decide how to return on Sept. 17 when he is expected in Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS TO TEST WHO FOR IHR APPLICABILITY

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen asked Taiwan's allies Monday to "test" if the World Health Organization's International Health Regulations (IHR) are applicable to Taiwan when it comes to joint efforts in fighting avian flu.

Chen said the bird flu crisis provides the world community a good opportunity to "test" if China will accept the IHR, which was adopted by the WHO in May so that all countries, regions and organizations can work together for the improvement of health conditions for all mankind.
The flu's H5N1 virus has hit such Asian countries as Vietnam, Thailand, Kampuchea and Indonesia, causing a 70 percent death rate among those infected.
Chen was joined by Department of Health (DOH) and Council of Agriculture (COA) officials in a briefing of foreign envoys on Taiwan's preparation for a possible avian flu outbreak.

Chen said that in a report to Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) , WHO's West Pacific Office has stated that international cooperation would be "the most critical factor" in every step of pushing a contingency plan against an avian flu epidemic.

Yet this office has rejected Taiwan's requests for other countries' contingency plans, the minister accused, expressing regret and disgruntlement over the WHO office claiming that it could not have any contact with Taiwan.
He asked foreign officials based in Taiwan to urge their home governments to help Taiwan participate in the global mechanism of preventing avian flu epidemics and enter into cooperation with the WHO.
DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao said Taiwan has adopted a three-point strategy and a four-line defense, and has been staging exercises accordingly, in preparation for a possible attack of avian flu.
The three-point strategy involves measures to stop infections, stockpiling anti-flu medicines, and developing and producing new vaccines.
The four-line defense includes stopping the epidemic offshore, quarantine at the borders, preventive measures in communities, and strengthening the health care system, according to Hou.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN STUDENTS WARMLY GREETED BY KAOHSIUNG COUNTY UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County-based Shu Te University hosted a ceremony Monday to welcome 21 new students who are from foreign countries including the United States, Cambodia, Vietnam and Malaysia.

Seventeen of the students are going to study at graduate schools at the university dedicated to globalization, while four will be in the information management and visual communications departments, school executives said, noting they are all on scholarships.
This was the first year that the university enrolled foreign students.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM ADMITS HITCH IN TALKS FOR RELEASE OF TAIWAN FISHERMEN IN SOMALIA

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen said Monday his ministry is doing its utmost to free three Taiwan fishing boats and their crew hijacked in Somalia, but he has no idea how long it will take.

The 48 crew of the three boats, held by Somalian pirates in the southern Somalian port of Kismayo since Aug. 16, are safe for now, but the talks on their release have been more complicated than expected, the minister said.

"We hope they will be released soon, but it seems the whole thing is not so simple; the situation in Somalia is quite complicated. We would advise local fishermen to steer clear of that country because even a United Nations' vessel could be hijacked there," Chen said.

Although only the skippers of the three boats are Taiwanese, the others crew are fishery workers from Vietnam, the Philippines, and Indonesia, but the minister said his ministry is no less aggressive in its efforts to win their release.
The pirates originally demanded a ransom of US$500,000 for each of the vessels and their crew, but slashed it to US$50,000 in government-brokered negotiations Sept. 6.
Because of the chaos in Somalia, the Taiwan families of the skippers are not certain how and to whom should the ransom be paid and whether the crew will be released then.

Taiwan fishermen began catching fish in waters near Kismayo in 1988 after entering into an agreement with the Somalia warlord who then controlled Kismayo. This is the first time Taiwan vessels have been hijacked by pirates who are rife along the Somalian coastline.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPROVES RESIGNATIONS OF CLA CHIEF, ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh approved the resignations of two senior officials Monday over the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for a mass rapid transit (MRT) system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Hsieh had tried hard but failed to persuade the two officials -- Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai -- to remain in the administrative team.

"The premier made last-ditch efforts to persuade both Chens to remain in their posts or at least to transfer to serve at other government positions. However, both insisted on stepping down to shoulder the responsibility for the incident," Cho said.
As both Chens will leave Hsieh's administrative team, Cho said, the premier will recruit suitable replacements as soon as possible.

To ensure smooth Cabinet operations, Cho said, no other personnel reshuffle will be made for the time being. Cho's remarks were seen as a denial of media speculation that Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan may succeed Chen Chi-mai as acting Kaohsiung mayor.

Quoting a yet-to-be-released investigative report by Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung, Cho said even though both the CLA and the Kaohsiung City Government should shoulder some "accountability of supervision" regarding the Aug. 21 riot, the extent of their responsibilities do not merit the resignations of their top officials.

However, Chen Chu, a human rights activist who was jailed for many years during Taiwan's martial-law era for her pro-democracy stance, said the riot has tarnished her personal image and that she would leave politics for a certain period of time for reflection.
Meanwhile, Chen Chi-mai said the incident and ensuing speculation about his father's role in Thai laborers employment have disheartened him.

The Aug. 21 riot began when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory after a day off and were barred from bringing in alcohol and cigarettes, a move that was the final straw in a long list of grievances. The workers burned cars and battled police with stones and slingshots. The laborers, who are building Kaohsiung's MRT system, complained about rigorous management rules and poor living conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO ADDRESS OPENING OF NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION SEPT. 13

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will open its new session Tuesday, with Premier Frank Hsieh delivering an administrative report and fielding questions from lawmakers of different political stripes.
In his report, Hsieh will outline the government's policy goals and working agenda for the coming year.

According to a written report referred to the legislature by the Cabinet Monday, the government will focus on six tasks in the coming year -- resuming dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, upgrading the added-value of domestic industries, improving the government's financial status, establishing a learning-oriented society, reforming the social welfare service system and promoting government restructuring and administrative reform.

In preparation for the opening of the new legislative session, the legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang held meetings Monday to discuss their work strategies and their priority list of bills to be passed.
The legislative caucuses of two other major parties -- the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- will also hold their own working meetings Tuesday to discuss tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REITERATES PRINCIPLES FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his basic principles of peace, democracy and parity Monday for dialogue and engagements across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the reaffirmation while meeting with a Danish parliamentary delegation which is currently on a visit in Taiwan.

Chen told Danish lawmakers that his administration would not miss any opportunity to forge rapprochement with China. Nevertheless, he said, his administration would also not rush to negotiate with China out of fears of China's military threat.
"We would be patient in waiting for a good timing for cross-strait dialogue. We would never compromise on our national dignity and sovereignty simply for the sake of talks," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, September 13:
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech to the 2005 summit of the logistics express industry at the Howard Hotel in Taipei.

09:00, The Legislative Yuan will begin its second session of this year. 09:30, Yu Shyi-kun, the secretary-general of the Presidential Office will pay a call on the Taiwan Solidarity Union at the TSU headquarters in Taipei. 10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will award medals to retired Olympic medalists Yang Chuan-kuang, Chi Chen and baseball coach Tseng Chi-en.
10:00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a news briefing at its Taipei headquarters.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing at its Taipei headquarters.
10:40, The People First Party will hold a news briefing about a forum it co-organized with the Communist Party of China in Shanghai, which is slated to open on Sept. 16.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will see a national delegation to the World Wheelchair Games.
13:30, The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly meeting at the party's Taipei headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Sept. 13, or the 10th day of the eigth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1598: Philip II, the world's most powerful ruler in his time, dies at the age of 71. He was King of Spain (from 1556), of Naples and Sicily (from 1554) and of Portugal (from 1580) as Philip I. In 1588, he launched the Spanish Armada in an unsuccessful attempt to invade England.
1759: British troops led by James Wolfe defeat the French force under the Marquis de Montcalm in Quebec. The young British general dies a hero, and the French commander is fatally wounded in the Battle of the Plains of Abraham.
1788: New York becomes the capital of the United States.
1857: Milton Snaveley Hershey, American chocolate manufacturer, is born. He built the world's largest chocolate factory to make his Hershey Bars and established the Hershey Foundation, through which his wealth was used for education purposes.
1912: Funeral rites for Emperor Mutsuhito, who adopted as his title "Meiji," meaning "enlightened rule," are held. The years in which he reigned from 1867 to 1912, are known as the "Meiji period," during which Japan developed into a modern industrial and military power.
1931: Cantonese rebel forces invade Hunan Province, driving toward Hengyang.
1942: German troops begin an all-out attack on Stalingrad against stiff Soviet resistance.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the national government by the ruling Kuomintang following the demise of Lin Sen, who died on Aug. 1. Chiang was sworn in Oct. 10.
1955: The Soviet Union agrees to establish diplomatic ties with West Germany.
1970: The Osaka Expo, the largest trade exhibition ever held, formally closes after attracting some 63 million visitors.
1973: Sun Fo (Sun Ko), president of the Examination Yuan, dies in Veterans General Hospital at the age of 83.
1973: Vice Foreign Minister Tchen Hiong-fei is appointed ROC ambassador to Uruguay.
1974: Yu Kuo-pin, ROC ambassador to Honduras, is stabbed to death by his driver.
1983: The Chinese Taipei baseball team wins the championship at the 12th Asian Baseball Tournament held in Seoul, South Korea.
1985: The World Health Organization announces in Geneva that AIDS has become a worldwide epidemic.
1986: The board of trustees of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) appoints David Dean, chairman of the board of trustees of AIT, as the new director of the Taipei office. Dean would arrive in Taipei in January 1987.
1988: Chen Ding-nan, Ilan County Government chief, orders all cinemas in the county to stop showing films of the National Anthem of the Republic of China.
1989: A British banking computer error gives customers two billion pounds (US$3.7 billion) in just half an hour.
1989: Yu Teng-fa, former chief of Kaohsiung County Government, is found dead in his bedroom.
1991: A yacht sinks off Paisa Village of Penghu County (The Pescadores), killing 18 people aboard. Twenty-two others are rescued.
1992: Latvian Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis visits Taipei to seek mutually beneficial cooperation. An ROC-Latvian investment guarantee agreement would be signed on September 17.
1993: U.S. President Bill Clinton loosens the national trade embargo against Vietnam, allowing American companies to join international development projects in Vietnam.
1999: Aviation rights negotiations between Taipei and Manila are held in Taipei to determine whether direct air links will continue or be terminated at the end of September.
2000: The Taiwan Provincial government announces that it has signed a sister state accord with the U.S. state of Delaware to enhance bilateral relations.
2000: Premier Tang Fei says at a Cabinet meeting that the Investigation Bureau must follow existing guidelines and cease all intelligence gathering activities unrelated to national security and criminal investigations.
2001: The ban on all flights in the United States strands Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung in Hawaii.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The mountain appearing before us is only a mass of rock; but taken in all the vastness of its size, grass and vegetation grow upon it, birds and beasts dwell on it, and treasures of precious stones are found in it."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR AND CLA HEAD NAMED

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian and former vice premier, will serve as acting Kaohsiung mayor, while Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, will serve as Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) chairman, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Tuesday.
Premier Frank Hsieh made the decision after careful consideration, Cho Jung-tai said.

The premier finally accepted the resignations of two senior officials Monday over the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on construction of the mass rapid transit system in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

The premier had tried in vain to persuade the two officials -- Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai -- to remain on the administration's team, Cho said.
After Lee assumes his new post, Cho will concurrently serve as Executive Yuan secretary-general.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ADOPT 'PARALLEL RELATIONSHIP POLICY' IN RELATIONS WITH FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 12 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy in France said Monday that Taiwan will follow a "policy of parallel relationship" in developing its relations with France.
Yang Tzu-pao, who assumed his new post as Taiwan's representative to France on Sept. 5, made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency.

Claiming that Taiwan welcomes France to promote its relations with China, the envoy said that the French government should also know that developing its relations with Taiwan will not be harmful to its relations with China.
"We do not oppose France developing various relations with China. Basically, we welcome France to help China to become a responsible power in the world, " he said.
The envoy also said that Taiwan-France relations should not only be based on national interests but should also include moral considerations.

"We would like to make publicly known that we will adopt a 'policy of parallel relationship.' We also hope that France will understand that the development of its relationship with Taiwan will not affect the progress of its relations with China," Yang said.

Pointing out that Beijing may refuse to accept the concept of "parallel relationship" and may continue to try to obstruct Taiwan's attempts to develop its relations with France, Yang urged the French authorities to deal with any "childish requests" by Beijing regarding Taiwan with a "mature attitude."

The representative further said that his main task now is to upgrade Taiwan's image in France, stressing that he will work to help the French people obtain a better understanding of Taiwan's current situation as well as its cultural, economic and technological achievements.

Pointing out that substantive relations between Taiwan and France have developed well, the envoy noted that visits by Taiwan and French officials to each other's countries have been more frequent than between Taiwan officials and officals from any other country in Europe.

He also noted that Taiwan-France relations have entered a delicate stage as the "China fever" in France has subsided and Paris is currently reviewing how to balance its interactions with China, adding that under these circumstances, there is definitely room for Taiwan to develop its relations with France.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPOINTMENT UNRELATED TO 2006 ELECTION: NEW ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, said Tuesday that it is her responsibility to take up the post of acting Kaohsiung mayor and that her appointment has nothing to do with considerations about the 2006 mayoral election in the southern port city.

Yeh made the remarks after she was named by the Executive Yuan to the position following the resignation of Chen Chi-mai, who stepped down to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the construction of the mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung.

Yeh vowed to continue the construction project as planned so that residents will be even prouder of their city, saying that the MRT system must be completed as soon as possible and that preparations for the 2009 World Games in the port city will be carried out relentlessly.
Yeh, 56, is a legislator-turned-politician who has served in the posts of transportation and communications minister, Council for Hakka Affairs chairman, and vice premier.

Saying that she is no stranger to major urban construction projects, Yeh vowed to work with the Kaohsiung city administrative team to serve the people. The team will not undergo any major personnel changes out of considerations of stability, she added.
Construction should not stop for even a single day, and reforms must not stall because of personnel changes, Yeh quoted Premier Frank Hsieh as saying to her Monday night.

Yeh said that her appointment has nothing to do with the 2006 mayoral election. Her comments were in response to media speculation that she was chosen for the position because she is highly respected in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and that her appointment could somehow silence the many aspirants within the party who have been coveting the post.

She also claimed that the election is not on her mind, saying that the decision on who will be the DPP candidate will be based on the prospective candidates' credentials, abilities as well as suitability in leading the city forward to become a great city.

Noting that there is a democratic system within the DPP in choosing the party's candidate for the Kaohsiung mayoral election, Yeh said that any aspirants will have to win the candidacy through the mechanism.
She also said that she has communicated with Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Tsai Chien-hsin and will call on the city council Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL DELEGATION VISITS U.S. SENATOR IN D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 12 (CNA) (By Winnie Chi & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese trade delegation made up of representatives of agricultural businesses called on U.S. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley at his office Monday.

The delegation, headed by Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Taiwan Grains and Seeds Development Foundation, comprises representatives of the Taiwan Feed Industry Association, the Taiwan Vegetable Oil Manufacturers Association, the Taiwan Flour Mills Industry Association and the Taiwan Regional Association of Tanneries.

Grassley expressed his thanks to Taiwan for its generous purchase of American agricultural products and its sparing no efforts to push for trade exchanges with his country. At the same time, the senator asked when Taiwan will reopen its market to U.S. beef and beef products.

The Taiwan group is scheduled to sign a letter of intent on agricultural procurement for 2006 and 2007 Wednesday on Capitol Hill. According to the pact, Taiwan will buy 14.5 million tons of soybeans, corn and wheat, as well as more than 5 million pieces of rawhides in the United States in both 2006 and 2007. The total value of the product is estimated at around US$3.1 billion.

According to Taiwan's Representative Office in the United States, Taiwan is currently the seventh largest market for U.S. agricultural exports. In the 2004-2005 agricultural procurement agreement, Taiwan promised to purchase from U.S. traders 15.1 million tons of soybeans, corn and wheat, as well as 4 million pieces of rawhides. To date, Taiwan has imported 10.5 million tons of grains and beans under the agreement.

The agricultural delegation is scheduled to visit U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Mike Johanns Tuesday. On Friday, members of the group will be divided into three teams for separate visits to U.S. states that produce soybeans, maize, wheat and rawhides.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN SPOKESMAN TO ORGANIZE SPOKESMAN TEAM

TEXT.P: The spokesman of the Executive Yuan, who has been named to serve concurrently as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, will organize a team to speak on behalf of the Executive Yuan.

Cho Jung-tai took over the post left open by former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, who has been appointed to serve as chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, replacing Chen Chu, who resigned to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 Thai laborer riot in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Cho said Tuesday Premier Frank Hsieh wants him to serve in the two posts simultaneously, as well as to organize a spokesman team of members who will speak for the Executive Yuan on a rotational basis.

Cho said that the team will be comprised of between three and five people. In addition to himself, there will also be Pasuya Yao, head of the Government Information Office and Cheng Li-chun, chief of the National Youth Commission. Other young, dynamic and talented Cabinet members will also be invited to serve, he said, without divulging any names.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KAOSHIUNG MAYOR BLAMES PREMIER FOR KRTC FIASCO

TEXT.P: Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih blamed his successor Frank Hsieh, who is now premier, Tuesday for failing to supervise the construction of Kaohsiung's rapid transit system, claiming that Hsieh should take full responsibility for the project.
During a TV interview Sept. 7, Hsieh showed official documents indicating that the decision to use the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model to build the system was made while Wu was mayor.
The BOT project was at the center of a controversy after Thai workers brought into the country to build the system rioted Aug. 21 in protest over maltreatment by private contractors.

Wu, now an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator, rebutted Hsieh's accusation that the decision to transfer the right to build the orange line to private investors was made on the eve of the 1998 mayoral election in an apparent attempt to prevent the incumbent KMT mayor's challenger -- Hsieh himself -- who ended up winning the election, from enjoying the right to assign construction contracts.

During the interview, Hsieh claimed that after he became mayor, he did not see the official documents until it was time to negotiate the terms of the BOT contract, and that as the KMT was still in power in the central government, it was nearly impossible to change the KMT policy.

Wu said while he was on the election campaign, his deputy, Huang Chun-ying, sent the city's decision on the MRT to the Executive Yuan, which did not agree with the city government's proposal to build the system under the BOT model.
But when Hsieh took over as mayor, he went ahead and implemented the BOT project, Wu pointed out, adding that it should be Hsieh, not himself, who should take the blame.
Wu said if he were responsible, he would have long been thrown behind bars.

He noted that acting mayor Chen Chi-mai, who was in that position for only six months, has resigned over the KRTC scandal, whereas Hsieh, who has been mayor for over six years and has seen so many problems with the project, has not even made a single apology.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN QUESTIONS CHINA'S RESTRICTIONS ON FOREIGN BANKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Sept. 12 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has questioned whether the restrictions imposed by China on foreign banks violate its accession commitment to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and has demanded an explanation from Beijing for the restrictions, a source close to the Taiwan Permanent Mission to the WTO said Monday.
The WTO is set to begin this month its fourth transitional review over China's trade policy since the nation became a member of the world trade body in 2002.

The source said that although Taiwan has not yet authorized its banks to set up branches in China, the questions it has raised under the WTO's Transitional Review Mechanism are aimed at examining whether China has honored its accession agreement and are not related to Taiwan's current policy toward China.
Several Taiwan banks have set up offices rather than branches in China, according to the source.

The mission said that China promised when it became a WTO member that its licence-approval procedure would not become market-access restrictions, adding that it also recognizes China's efforts to improve its business environment as well as to honor its accession commitment to the WTO.

Nevertheless, the mission does not agree with Beijing's requirement that a foreign bank branch must start with a minimum capital of 100 million renminbi to 500 million renminbi and that a foreign bank that wants to set up a branch in China must have assets of at least US$20 billion.

Demanding that China explain whether its restrictions are in line with the rules of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) and its accession commitments to the WTO, the mission also questioned whether China has a plan to reduce the minimum capital request.
It also demanded that Beijing explain its rules relating to the US$20 billion minimum assets requirement.

Taiwan also questioned China's rules that demand that foreign insurance companies who want to open branches in China must first set up offices in China for at least two years, claiming that as experience has shown that it only takes a few months for a foreign insurance company to complete its procedure for obtaining a licence from the Chinese authorities, Beijing should shorten the time of licence-approval to less than one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT PROJECT STONEWALLED FOR 28TH TIME

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan blocked a long-stalled arms procurement package for the 28th time Tuesday, refusing to allow it to be put on the legislative agenda.

The package comprises three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries. For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has refused to screen the package because it claims the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special budget.

The package was rejected the second time in the newly opened session of the legislature after the Ministry of National Defense put one item in the package -- the anti-missile batteries -- under the regular budget in response to a suggestion by some opposition legislators and remarks by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng that the arms procurement package should move into the review process.
William C.T. Lai, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, condemned the opposition parties for "maliciously blocking" the package yet again.

The package concerns national security, and the opposition parties have no reason to oppose it, Lai claimed, adding that the public should turn away from the opposition parties for putting national security in jeopardy.
KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan claimed, however, that caution is needed in regard to arms procurement, adding that there is "no rush" to review the package as public consensus has yet to be forged.
The KMT caucus will hold a meeting Thursday to listen to the views of the party's legislators, he said.

Not only the arms procurement package, but other proposals such as the confirmation of the Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian, the establishment of a bill governing the establishment of a supervisory committee for the labor pension fund, amendments to the Referendum Law, the handling of ill-gotten assets by civic groups, and the amendment to the National Property Law were also blocked.

But the proposals for the central government budget for next year, a special budget to expand public construction, as well as legislation relating to Chinese people coming to Taiwan as tourists were put on the agenda.

A draft bill concerning artificial insemination was also put on the agenda in the wake of a controversy over the fiancee of an army captain who requested to harvest his sperm after he was killed in an accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHIEF INVITED TO JOIN PRESIDENT ON CENTRAL AMERICA TRIP

TEXT.P: The chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian, invited opposition Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang Tuesday to join Chen on a Sept. 20-Oct. 1 visit to Central America.

According to Yu Shyi-kun, Chen will visit five Taiwan allies -- Guatemala, Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, St. Vincent and Saint Christopher & Nevis -- and take part in the fifth Taiwan-Central American leadership meeting scheduled to open in Nicaragua Sept. 23. He will make a transit stop in Miami on his way to Central America and another in San Francisco on his way home.

Yu said Chen invited the leaders of all major domestic political parties to join him on the trip in an effort to help expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers since China has never stopped trying to squeeze Taiwan out of the international community.

Even though, the chairmen of both the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have already refused to travel with the president, Yu said he will still visit the two parties' headquarters to deliver the invitations.
TSU Chairman Su accepted Chen's invitation, saying he is more than willing to join Chen on the Central American tour to boost the nation's diplomatic work.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.1 points to close at 6,169.08.
The bourse opened at 6,170.37 and fluctuated between 6,186.12 and 6,156.12 during trading. A total of 2.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.61 billion (US$2 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.5 percent and cement stocks gaining 0.4 percent.

The other six major categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.4 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.02 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.01 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 543 to 335, with 177 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down one point to close at 6,164, with 18,755 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up two points to end at 6,163, with 1,068 contracts traded, while December futures gained 16 points to finish at 6,170, with five contracts traded. March futures moved up nine points to close at 6,165, with one contract traded.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures gained 2.8 points to finish at 930.4, with 2,496 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up four points to end at 928, with 594 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 0.6 points to close at 924.8, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REJECTS REPORTS ON ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh rejected Tuesday reports about having a political axe to grind in his appointment of the new acting Kaohsiung mayor.

Hsieh, a possible contender for the presidential election in 2008, was responding to reports about an opposition legislator who questioned if Hsieh's appointment of Yeh Chu-lan, a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, to the post of acting Kaohsiung mayor, had anything to do with putting her in a more high-profile position to pave the way for putting her on the next presidential election ticket.

Hsieh denied the legislator's allegation, saying that "the public will know that it is not going to happen with the passing of the time," while Yeh said the possibility of a Hsieh-Yeh ticket would be "nil."
"Those who made the speculation obviously don't know much about the ruling Democratic Progressive Party," Yeh claimed.
Yeh said that as a member of the administrative team, it is her duty to accept the appointment.

Yeh said she hopes to continue what she described as Hsieh's "good performance" as Kaohsiung mayor before he assumed the premiership, as well as that of former acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, who stepped down to take responsibility for the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for the rapid transit system in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHALLENGES `PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' TO RE-ELECT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) challenged Tuesday the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party (PFP) and New Party, which forms a majority in the Legislative Yuan, to topple Premier Frank Hsieh's Cabinet so the president can dissolve the legislature.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang asked them to look at Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's example and initiate "a bold project" to dissolve the legislature and give the people a chance to re-elect it.
Su made the proposal in response to the "pan-blue alliance's" boycott of such major bills as the long-stalled arms procurement bill and legislation over an NT$80 billion flood control project.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, TSU caucus convener Ho Min-hao blamed the "pan-blue alliance" for causing political chaos in Taiwan and challenged it to propose a no-confidence vote against the premier.
Hsieh himself has also challenged the major opposition parties to topple his Cabinet so President Chen Shui-bian can disband the legislature and call an election.

Ho's caucus had planned to initiate a no-confidence motion, but called off the action because not all 12 members of the caucus supported it. The TSU and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which form the "pan-green camp, " failed to win a majority of the 225 seats during the last legislative election in late 2004.

The Constitution stipulates that a motion of no-confidence on the premier can be initiated if signed by more than one-third of the legislators. The premier should resign if more than half of the lawmakers vote for the motion, and request that the president dissolve the legislature.
"Pan-blue" lawmakers said they would not "fall into the `pan-green' trap" since executive power would still be in the president's hands even after a legislative shake-up.
If Taiwan wants to learn from Japan, the people should also have a chance to re-elect the president when they vote for a new legislature, they claimed.
