DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES ATHLETES FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated three senior athletes -- Yang Chuan-kuang, Chi Cheng and Tseng Chi-en -- with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon Tuesday in recognition of their contributions to Taiwan's athletic development.

Yang, better known as the "Iron Man of Asia, " burst onto the international sports scene at the 1954 Asian Games, winning the gold for Taiwan in the decathlon, while Chi competed at three Olympics for Taiwan in 1960, 1964 and 1968, and won a bronze medal in the 80-meter hurdles in Mexico City. Yang, a member of the Malan Ami tribe in Taitung County, also won a silver medal in the decathlon of the 1960 Rome Olympic Games.
Tseng, considered a "national treasure" of baseball, served as coach of different-level national baseball teams that took part in various world baseball tournaments.
Speaking at an award ceremony at the Presidential Office, Yang voiced the hope that the government will attach greater importance to sports development.

Chi promised to continue to help step up Taiwan's athletic development by sticking to what Chen called the spirit of the "Taiwan son." During a meeting with a group of all Olympic medal winners at the Presidential Office May 3, 2001, Chen said that the perseverance shown by athletes exemplified the spirit of the "Taiwan son, " according to Chi.

Tseng thanked the president for attaching great importance to the development of baseball in Taiwan. He also called on the government to channel greater efforts into training programs in order to cultivate more outstanding players.

Also present at the ceremony were Chen Chuan-shou, chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, and You Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUGGESTS TAIWAN RAISE DEFENSE BUDGET TO 3.5% OF GDP: PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has suggested that Taiwan raise its defense budget to 3.5 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) to prevent the cross-Taiwan Strait military balance from tilting further in favor of China, a Japanese economic daily reported Tuesday.

The Nihon Keizai Shimbun quoted unidentified sources familiar with Taiwan-U.S. military exchanges as saying that U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld had conveyed the message to senior Taiwan military officers during a meeting in the United States earlier this summer.

Quoting data collected by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, the newspaper said in a Washington-datelined dispatch that Taiwan's 2004 military spending accounted for about 2.6 percent of its GDP, far lower than China's ratio of 4.3 percent. The U.S. defense spending ratio is about 3.5 percent of its GDP.

The report said the United States has on many occasions pushed Taiwan to accelerate its military modernization, but added that it is unusual for the United States to suggest a concrete figure by which it thinks Taiwan should increase its defense spending. This, the paper claimed, mainly reflects rising U.S. concern about the growing imbalance in military strength on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

To meet Taiwan's defense needs, the United States agreed in 2001 to sell a robust package of weapons to Taiwan, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. The deal, however, has so far not been struck because of a boycott by Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" that holds a slim majority in the legislature.

In July, the United States unveiled an annual report on China's military power that expressed apprehension about the rapid increase in the number of ballistic missiles deployed by China against Taiwan. The number of Chinese missiles targeting at Taiwan has been increased at a rate of about 100 annually in recent years. American military experts said that if Taiwan fails to beef up its defense capabilities, the cross-strait military imbalance will widen substantially.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CLA HEAD VOWS TO UPHOLD LABORERS' RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The newly appointed chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) vowed Tuesday to protect and uphold the rights of laborers.

Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, made the remarks after he was appointed by Premier Frank Hsieh to head the nation's top labor administrative agency following the resignation of Chen Chu.

Lee, 52, a medical professor-turned-politician, has previously served as a legislator and as vice representative to the United States, as well as vice secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Lee said that taking over the post from Chen Chu, a heavyweight within the DPP, gave him a feeling of great responsibility after taking over the baton from Chen.

He also claimed that the DPP, moving from an opposition force to a major social movement force to its present ruling stance, "has always sided with the laborers" and that "laborers have been the blessing of Taiwan and myself."

Lee said he "will not let the DPP or the laborers down, " adding that he has long "mingled with laborers and social movement activists" and that he will continue to work toward upholding the "dignity, rights, working conditions and retirement system" of laborers.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai made an announcement earlier in the day that the premier believes Lee to be dynamic and with rich experience in coordinating among government agencies, which makes him very qualified to fill the post vacated by Chen Chu, who resigned over the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. in the southern Taiwan port city.

Reports also said that the premier was impressed by Lee's performance in communication and coordination over the recent strikes by the workers' unions of the state-controlled Chunghwa Telecom and Taiwan Business Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P:
In the second line of the second paragraph of CEP 16, "...St. Vincent and Saint Christopher & Nevis" should read "...Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Saint Kitts and Nevis." A corrected version follows. Thanks.
TSU CHIEF INVITED TO JOIN PRESIDENT ON CENTRAL AMERICA TRIP

Taipei, Sept. 13 (CNA) The chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian, invited opposition Taiwan Solitary Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang Tuesday to join Chen on a Sept. 20-Oct. 1 visit to Central America.

According to Yu Shyi-kun, Chen will visit five Taiwan allies -- Guatemala, Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Saint Kitts and Nevis -- and take part in the fifth Taiwan-Central American leadership meeting scheduled to open in Nicaragua Sept. 23. He will make a transit stop in Miami on his way to Central America and another in San Francisco on his way home.

Yu said Chen invited the leaders of all major domestic political parties to join him on the trip in an effort to help expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers since China has never stopped trying to squeeze Taiwan out of the international community.

Even though, the chairmen of both the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have already refused to travel with the president, Yu said he will still visit the two parties' headquarters to deliver the invitations.
TSU Chairman Su accepted Chen's invitation, saying he is more than willing to join Chen on the Central American tour to boost the nation's diplomatic work.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIBUSTER JUSTIFIED METHOD FOR OPPOSITION IN LEGISLATURE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday that he saw nothing wrong with the method used by by the legislative caucuses of the two major opposition parties to block proceedings on the first day of the Legislative Yuan's new session.
Ma Ying-jeou, who is also Taipei mayor, explained that filibustering is allowed in the parliaments of democratic countries for an opposition party to get concessions from the ruling party.
Filibuster is a term for any attempt to block or delay legislative action through debate at length, or by offering numerous procedural motions or any other delaying or obstructive actions.

Asked by reporters about doubts from the public that the opposition parties have not done an adequate job in overseeing the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Ma said he has asked the KMT legislative caucus to become more sensitive to public opinion and to react more quickly to issues that are of great concern to the public.

The legislature spent its first day in chaos, as opposition party caucus members from both the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) took over the rostrum to voice their demands that Premier Frank Hsieh should not be allowed to present his report on the work of his Cabinet but should be granted leave while waiting for an investigation on a series of alleged scandals involving either him or members of his Cabinet.

The KMT and PFP caucuses want to set up a commission to investigate suspected corruption in the construction projects of the Kaohsiung rapid transit system and Taiwan's high-speed railway, the second phase of the government's financial reform plan, an insider trading scandal involving a top official charged with the duty of preventing insider trading in the stock market, and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom that deliberately violated a resolution passed by the previous legislature calling on the government to halt the move.
There was a sea of placards with slogans held by members of different party caucuses in the meeting hall.

Some KMT legislators unfurled white banners carrying such slogans as "Find those who sucked the blood of Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway, " and "Corrupt Premier Hsieh should be on leave and waiting for investigation."
The opposition legislators claimed they wanted to use the strong protest actions to show the severity of the series of alleged corruption cases that surfaced while the legislature was in recess.

Amid the chaos, the caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union tried to get support for a proposal to topple the Cabinet, so that President Chen Shui-bian can disband the legislature in an attempt to break the current deadlock and pave the way for the election of a new Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY CARRIAGES ARRIVE FROM JAPAN

TEXT.P: The 23rd set of locomotives and carriages for Taiwan's high-speed railway arrived from Japan Tuesday at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.

The carriages will be transported to an assembly plant of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) Wednesday in Kaohsiung County, a THSRC spokesman said, adding that a series of test runs for the new carriages will be conducted on a test track after assembly is completed.

The arrival of the carriages appeared to quash a rumor that the Japanese supplier will suspend its delivery of the carriages because of the THSRC's financial problems, according to the spokesman. THSRC has ordered a total of 30 sets of carriages from Japan.

THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing announced last Wednesday that the inauguration of Taiwan's first high-speed railway will be postponed for one year until Oct. 31, 2006. The 345-km railway linking Taipei in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung in the south was originally scheduled to be inaugurated next month.
Ing apologized to investors and the public over the decision, but claimed she is confident of achieving the new goal of launching the high-speed railway by October next year.
She said that in view of an overall consideration of the progress of the construction, system tests and operation preparations, the board of directors was forced to postpone the launch by one year.
Ing was unwilling to identify where the faults lie but said that the Japanese Shinkansen system is "more complex" than expected.
However, THSRC officials said construction of core mechanical and electrical systems have lagged behind schedule by more than 30 percent, affecting system tests and operation preparations.

The trip between Taiwan's biggest and second-biggest cities will supposedly take about 90 minutes. The multibillion-dollar railway system is also Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER VISITS PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Sept. 12 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Interior Minister Chang Wen-ying donated 400 wheelchairs, as well as other medical equipment and supplements to total value of around US$150,000 to Panama on behalf of the government at a ceremony in Panama City Sunday.

Delivering the donations was Chang's major mission on her visit to Panama City, where she also attended a Latin American conference on human rights for the mentally and physically challenged on behalf of first lady Wu Shu-jen.

During the opening ceremony for the meeting, Panamanian first lady Vivian Fernandez de Torrijos extended her country's gratitude for the donation from Taiwan and expressed the hope for Taiwan's help in equipping Panamanian disabled people with vocational skills.
Chang also visited the Panamanian Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Social Development Monday for talks on cooperation between the two countries.
Chang, leaving Taiwan for Panama Friday, is scheduled to wrap the visit Sept. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q2 HOUSING PRICES CONFIDENCE LEVEL AT TWO-YEAR LOW: CEPD

TEXT.P: The composite confidence in Taiwan's housing prices dropped to 100.53 points in the second quarter of this year, the lowest since the third quarter of 2003, when SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) was ravaging the country, according to a Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) report released Tuesday.
On the other hand, house mortgages as a share of family income has risen for the seventh quarter in a row, an indication that housing prices may be approaching a peak, said the report.

The report noted that nationally in the second quarter, house buyers were paying 629 percent of their annual income to buy a house, and mortgage payments accounted for 29 percent of their monthly income, an increase of 2.9 percent over the same period of last year and the seventh consecutive quarterly increase.

The "Report on the Changes in Taiwan's Housing Demands" pointed out that the average space for negotiating the price of a house during the second quarter of 2005 has gone up to 10.5 percent, up 0.8 percent from the previous quarter and a two-year high.
Another indicator that a buyer's market exists is that the average time used to look for a residence has lengthened to 4.7 months, as buyers have turned more hesitant.

On their views of housing prices in the coming year, 30.4 percent of surveyed house buyers said it will rise, while 29.7 percent said it will fall, still another indication that house buyers are becoming more reserved about the housing market, said the report.
But for the near future, 32.1 percent of those who have bought a house said housing prices will go up, with only 14.7 percent saying that they will go down.
Professor Chang Chin-er of National Chengchi University said the message should catch the attention of sellers.
The report surveyed house buyers, real estate agents and banks across the country from July 1 to July 15, receiving 2,964 valid responses. The margin of error was around 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: "Judges Are Not Politicians, " Roberts Says; As Hearings Begin, Democrats Call for Fuller Answers on Civil Rights Views.
John G. Roberts Jr. opened the first Supreme Court confirmation hearing in 11 years yesterday by portraying himself as a humble, non-political judge who would interpret the law "without fear or favor" if he became the 17th chief justice of the United State.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: THE NEW YORK TIMES: 45 Bodies Are Found in a New Orleans Hospital
The discovery sharply increased the death toll and raised new questions about the breakdown of the evacuation system
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Boeing, Lockheed Rocket Tie-Up Meets Financial, Political Hurdles

A plan to combine the rocket businesses of Boeing Co. and Lockheed Martin Corp., considered almost inevitable barely a few months ago, has run into unexpected financial and political hurdles, according to Pentagon and industry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE OPENS IN CHAOS, KMT STOPS PREMIER FROM GIVING BRIEFING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legislature opened the first day of the new session Tuesday with chaotic shouting and shoving as opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers prevented Premier Frank Hsieh from taking the podium to give his report on the administration's agenda.

The floor of the legislature was filled with lawmakers from various parties holding placards -- from the opposition camp: "Anti-corruption, save Taiwan"; from ruling party supporters: "Dissolve the legislature, hold a new election."

KMT lawmakers said that the premier should not be allowed to continue at his post until investigations have been completed into a riot on Aug. 21 by Thai laborers in Kaohsiung over poor working conditions.

As Hsieh was mayor of the city from 1998 to 2005, the legislators said that he could be involved in the import of the Thai workers and might have been involved in alleged kickbacks surrounding the mass rapid transit system that the workers are constructing.
The KMT lawmakers claimed that it was Hsieh who decided to bring in the Thai workers, and that he should subject himself to a judicial investigation.

Since it became clear that the premier was not going to be able to give his report on schedule, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, called for a break and urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to negotiate with the KMT to find a way to end their protest.
Premier Hsieh, meanwhile, sat out the storm absorbed in a book.

Negotiations went nowhere as the DPP would not agree to the KMT's call for the establishment of an ad hoc group under the Legislative Yuan to look into the riot as well as several other hi-profile incidents, including the postponement of the opening of the nation's first high-speed rail line and the sale of government stakes in Chunghwa Telecom.

Taking the bull by the horns, the DPP not only turned down the KMT's idea, they dared the opposition to try to oust the premier's Cabinet by calling for a non-confidence vote, which would mean that if successful, the president could dissolve the legislature and call for a snap election.
Getting no satisfaction from the ruling party, KMT lawmakers again occupied the podium and quarrelled with their DPP counterparts. Wang was forced to announce another break until 3:15 p.m.

After the break, Wang invited the premier to give his report. But KMT lawmaker Huang Chao-hsun refused to let the premier go to the podium, which forced a third break which last until 6: 05 p.m. when the speaker called an end to the day's fiasco.

Later in the day, the premier said he was frustrated with the opposition's behavior and blamed KMT lawmakers for disappointing their constituents by hindering the legislative process when taxpayers across the nation are hard at work.
Lawmakers of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political ally of the DPP, also blamed the KMT, saying that they had wasted an entire day of the legislature, which had cost taxpayers millions of dollars.
However, Wang said that Tuesday's protest was "mild" in comparison with the DPP's actions during the time when the KMT was in power.
He said the premier had a chance to give his report in the afternoon, but it was wasted because of an eleventh-hour hitch in negotiations between the DPP and the KMT.
Calling partisan bickering a natural part of democracy, Wang urged the public to be patient, adding that he was sure that the political parties will sort out their differences eventually.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS BANK EMPLOYEES END FOUR-DAY STRIKE AGAINST MERGER

TEXT.P: Thousands of employees of the state-owned Taiwan Business Bank agreed to return to work from Wednesday, ending their four-day strike against a merger plan after opposition legislators promised to intervene on their behalf and include the issue on the agenda of the legislature.

Lin Wan-fu, chairman of the Taiwan Business Industrial Union, who led the strike, said the battlefield has now shifted to the Legislative Yuan, and that union members will not resume their strike unless the government continues the auction process to select a satisfactory top bidder.

Some 3,000 of the banks's 5,000 staff began a strike last Thursday to protest the planned merger which they fear would cause many of them to lose their jobs. They staged sit-ins outside the bank's main office buildings in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung.
The government is trying to privatize the bank -- the 10th largest in Taiwan -- as part of its plan to reduce the number of state-owned banks in Taiwan to six by the end of the year through mergers.

The Ministry of Finance was expected to announce a winning bidder last Friday, but the auction turned out to be a failure because the bids it received were unsatisfactory. The best offer reportedly came from E. Sun Financial Holding Co., which took over the state-run Kaohsiung Business Bank last year.

Taiwan's commercial newspapers have quoted Minister of Finance Lin Chuan as saying that the merger plan will continue and that the top bidder has been asked to make a higher offer within three to five days.

Although some 90 opposition legislators had sponsored a motion by late Tuesday calling on the Ministry of Finance to halt the auction, finance officials indicated that the merger plan is unlikely to be stopped at this stage.
They said that if the plan is to be scrapped, it will be due to failure to secure a satisfactory bid in the second round of the auction, rather than influence from the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR PUBLIC TO DENOUNCE LEGISLATIVE CHAOS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) called for the public to speak out against Tuesday's opening legislative session as a waste of taxpayers' money, as nothing was achieved because of opposition protests.

TSU legislative whip Ho Ming-hao made the appeal after the pro-unification opposition "pan-blue alliance" occupied the podium at the legislature for the entire session to prevent Premier Frank Hsieh from delivering an administrative report.

Hsieh was originally scheduled to address the Legislative Yuan's opening session in the morning and then field questions from lawmakers of all political stripes. Due to a boycott by lawmakers from the two "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , Hsieh and his entire Cabinet ended up sitting all day in the legislature watching the "circus."

"Pan-blue alliance" legislators demanded that Hsieh take a leave of absence as they claimed Hsieh was responsible for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system construction scandal. Hsieh was Kaohsiung mayor for six years until February, when he became premier.

Ho said the "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers were protesting at taxpayers' expense. According to him, the national coffers must pay NT$1.35 million in legislators' attendance fees per day when the Legislative Yuan is in session.

"If the salaries of all Cabinet members and their aides as well as legislature's administrative staff were taken into account, the national coffers lost an estimated NT$10 million today, " Ho lamented.
Ho said he worries that the "pan-blue alliance" will continue to boycott the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) initiatives at every turn for the rest of the legislature's term.

"I deplore the 'pan-blue alliance's' irrational move. The alliance has used its majority in the legislature to stonewall a number of critical bills, including the arms procurement package, the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control project and the nomination of the Control Yuan members for more than a year while daring not to topple the Cabinet," Ho said.
Claiming that this situation should be changed, Ho urged ordinary citizens to voice their discontent over the legislative inaction and chaos.

Ho also called on the public to take to the streets Sept. 25 to take part in a rally to be organized by the Hand-in-Hand-to-Protect-Taiwan Alliance to call for the early passage of the long-stalled arms procurement package to beef up Taiwan's defense capabilities in the face of China's mounting threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASAHI WORKERS TO VACATION IN HUALIEN, BOOSTING TAIWAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 staff from the Asahi Breweries Group of Japan will be taking a company vacation in Hualien this year, giving the local tourist industry a boost, Tourism Bureau Director-General Hsu Wen-shen said Tuesday.

Asahi employees will fly to Hualien in eight chartered China Airlines flights starting from November, Hsu noted, saying this will be the third time that the big Japanese business group will have sent its staff to Taiwan for sightseeing.
Hsu said the Japanese excursion is a feather in the cap of tourism in Taiwan.
According to Tourism Bureau statistics, as of the end of July, the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan reached over 630,000, representing a 39 percent growth over the level of the previous year.

To attract more Japanese tourists to Taiwan, the bureau began a prize draw in September for Japanese travelers, awarding winners with various prizes like laptop computers and air tickets worth a total of 50 million yen (US$450,800).

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HSIEH URGES PUBLIC TO TRUST JUDICIAL PROBE OF KAOHSIUNG MRT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the judiciary is investigating the Kaohsiung rapid transit project as well as the Thai workers' riot, and people should trust the nation's judicial system.

A frustrated Hsieh, who was blocked by the opposition from making a report to the legislature on the opening day of its new session, said he urges the people to think hard on the problems facing the nation.
The biggest problem, in the premier's view, is the opposition's lack of trust in the nation's judiciary.

Hsieh was kept from stepping onto the podium by Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) legislators who demanded that he ask for leave and wait for investigators' results in their questioning regarding the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. scandal.

Hsieh said that throughout the day, he was "absorbed in self-reflection" but he still wondered if the opposition's demand -- that he ask for a leave of absence and wait for the results of an investigation -- would help resolve the problem.

He said even if investigative results were published, the opposition would still accuse the government of political interference, as they had done with regard to the judicial probe and court ruling on the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Before Kaohsiung's acting mayor, Chen Chi-mai, and Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu tendered their resignations over the incident, many were demanding their heads, Hsieh said.
"Now they have resigned, but they are being called scapegoats or being accused of evading, " the premier said.
In the "pan-blue alliance's" eyes, only an investigation by the Legislative Yuan is valid, he said, referring to the KMT, PFP and New Party alliance.
As a matter of fact, Hsieh continued, the Legislative Yuan is an arena of political wrestling that will not resolve the real problem.
He said he would call on the people, not the opposition parties, to look squarely into how to end the legislative impasse.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TASK FORCE TO MONITOR UPCOMING BUSH-HU MEETING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has set up a task force to keep an eye on the upcoming meeting between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines of this year's U.N. General Assembly, a government official disclosed Tuesday.

Victor J. Chin, director-general of the foreign ministry's Department of North American Affairs, told a news conference that Hu put off his trip to the United States until mid-September after Hurricane Katrina battered three southern U.S. states in late August.
Hu is scheduled to meet Bush on the sidelines of the 60th U.N. General Assembly, Chin said, adding that the two leaders are expected to touch on the Taiwan issue during their meeting.
According to Chin, the foreign ministry task force will carefully monitor the Bush-Hu meeting and evaluate whether Taiwan's national interests have been affected.

Based on a previous U.S. briefing to Taiwan, the U.S. side will persist in its consistent policy toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chin said. He added that U.S. officials are expected to deliver a briefing on the Bush-Hu meeting to the ROC government after the event.

Touching on Taiwan's efforts to obtain a seat in the United Nations, Chin said that the U.S. government is expected to maintain its attitude towards the island's U.N. entry bid this year -- keeping "goodwill silence."

Taiwan has adopted a new strategy to promote its bid to join the U.N. by presenting two proposals through its diplomatic allies. One urges the U.N. General Assembly to ascertain the U.N. representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan, while the other asks the U.N. to play an active role in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Chin said that the U.S. government has gained a better understanding of Taiwan's stance of presenting the peace maintenance proposal to the United Nations following intensive communications between the two sides.

The ROC, a U.N. founding member, lost the "China" U.N. seat to Beijing's communist government in 1971, and since 1993 has launched annual bids to get back into the organization. The past 12 bids were quashed by China and the prospects for this year's campaign remain "unclear."

China's former Kuomintang (KMT) government lost a civil war to the communists in 1949 and fled to Taiwan, where it claimed to be the legitimate Chinese government. But it disavowed the claim in 1991 and Taiwan's leaders have drifted toward a separate Taiwanese identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF CHINESE CITIZENS LIVING IN TAIWAN INCREASES: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The total number of mainland Chinese citizens living in Taiwan under government approval reached 158,000 as of the end of June, the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Tuesday.

A DGBAS official said that the number of Chinese citizens living on the island was up sharply after the government eased the regulations governing applications by mainland Chinese spouses for permanent residence in Taiwan in 2004 under humanitarian considerations.
The number of Chinese citizens applying for permanent residence in Taiwan increased 59,000 in 2004, according to statistics released by the DGBAS.
As of the end of June, Chinese citizens made nearly 1.2 million visits to Taiwan for social exchanges, cultural and economic activities as well as for sightseeing, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL CALLS FOR NORMALIZATION OF FINANCIAL TIES WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Financial Supervisory Commission urged China Tuesday to conclude an accord with Taiwan on the supervision and management of financial institutions as a step toward the normalization of bilateral financial ties.
Lin Chung-cheng made the statement after Beijing decided last week to provide 30 billion renminbi in credit to Taiwan-funded companies in China.
Lin said his commission has worked out a draft bill governing the establishment of representative offices in Taiwan by Chinese banks, pending the Executive Yuan's approval.
Under this bill, Lin said, Chinese banks will be treated in the same way as foreign banks, except for special cases.
The establishment of a representative office is the first step for foreign banks to set up branch offices and do business in Taiwan.

However, Lin said the draft bill is negotiable, meaning that if China would like to talk with Taiwan on this issue, this can be arranged. For example, the requirement for a bank's minimum investment provided for in the draft bill may be adjusted downward in light of the fact that Taiwan's banks are usually of small size in comparison with their Western counterparts.

As to the combined credit offered by local banks' overseas banking units (OBU's) to overseas Taiwan businessmen, Lin said his commission has no intention of raising the current ceiling of 30 percent of the OBU's net assets, and any suggestion that the ceiling should be raised would need the approval of the Mainland Affairs Council and the Central Bank of China.

Although no Chinese bank has ever expressed interesting in operating in Taiwan thus far, Lin said his commission keeps an open mind toward China, and is more than willing to talk with them on an agreement of financial supervision and management which is the necessary step toward the normalization of bilateral financial relations.

The absence of such an agreement is part of the reason that no banks on either side of the Taiwan Strait operate on the other side in spite of the fact that trade between the two sides tops billions of dollars every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP HEADS WILL NOT JOIN PRESIDENT'S DIPLOMATIC TOUR

TEXT.P: The heads of the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- will not join President Chen Shui-bian on his upcoming Central America diplomatic tour.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun paid a visit to PFP headquarters Tuesday to forward Chen's invitation to PFP Chairman James Soong.

Yu said the president decided to invite opposition leaders to join him on his diplomatic tour mainly because he wants to pool wisdom and resources to expand the nation's diplomatic frontiers and cement ties with the nation's allies in the face of China's relentless diplomatic suppression against Taiwan.
As to whether Soong would accept the invitation, Yu said, Chen would respect Soong's decision.

PFP Deputy Secretary-General Liao Tsang-sung received the invitation and promised to relay it to Soong. PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said later that as an opposition party, the PFP's main role is to oversee the government's operations.
"Because of his busy schedule, Soong will not travel with Chen," Hsieh said, adding that the PFP wishes Chen a smooth Central America journey.
Yu will also send a similar invitation to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou later this week.
Ma, who concurrently serves as Taipei mayor, said Tuesday he has to turn down the president's invitation because he must field questions at the Taipei City Council during that period.

Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei Sept. 20 for an 11-day diplomatic tour that will take him to six Taiwan allies in Central America and the Caribbean -- Nicaragua, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Saint Kitts and Nevis.

During his stay in Nicaragua, Chen will attend the fifth Taiwan-Central American leadership meeting scheduled for Sept. 23. He will make a transit stop in Miami on his way to Central America and another in San Francisco on his way home.
While in Miami, Chen is expected meet with Florida Governor Jeb Bush, a younger brother of President George W. Bush.

A CNA report from Washington, D.C. quoted Richard Bush, a former head of the American Institute in Taiwan, as saying that transit visits to the United States are useful opportunities to bring Taiwan's leaders up to date on developments of U.S.-PRC relations. If there were particular observations or comments that Taiwan's leaders made during the transits, they would certainly be conveyed back to Washington, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 14 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, September 13:
08: 10, People First Party Chairman James Soong will leave the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport for a trip to Shanghai.
09:00, The Cabinet will hold its weekly meeting at the Executive Yuan.
09:00, The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang will hold its weekly meeting at the party's Taipei headquarters.

10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a camp organized by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan to explain his proposal for the second phase of constitutional reforms in Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
10: 00, An aide to President Chen Shui-bian will hold a news briefing at the Presidential Office about the president's forthcoming trip to Central America.
12: 20, The Ministry of the Interior will hold a business review meeting at the ministry's Taipei headquarters.
13:00, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao will hold a news conference about the Kaohsiung Film Festival at the GIO's Taipei office.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a group of activists who advocate clean elections at the Presidential Office.
16:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a group of overseas Chinese living in Yokohama, Japan at the Presidential Office.
19:30, Yeh Chu-lan, a senior adviser to the president, will conduct a class at the Ketagalan Institute in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LEGISLATURE TO PASS MAJOR BILLS SOON

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Tuesday to pass a number of critical budget and legislative bills as early as possible to facilitate Taiwan's development and upgrading of its competitiveness.

In a written report to the legislature, Hsieh outlined a priority list of bills that his Cabinet wants to see their early passage, including the central government's 2006 budget plan and a special budget bill for expanding public investment and infrastructure construction, and a special statute on an eight-year NT$80 billion flood-control project.
Also high on the list are a long-stalled arms procurement package, three bills concerning sweeping government restructuring and the nomination of Control Yuan members.

In his written administrative report, Hsieh reaffirmed his commitment to promote reconciliation and symbiosis among all domestic political parties and ethnic groups as well as to seek dialogue and engagements across the Taiwan Strait to maintain regional peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Sept. 14, or the 11th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1769: Baron von Humboldt, German scientist, is born. He explored Central and South America and published data which forms the foundation of the study of ecology, which he initiated.
1847: American forces under General Winfield Scott capture Mexico City, ending the Mexican War.
1851: The Duke of Wellington, the title bestowed on Arthur Wellesley, British commander and politician, dies at the age of 83. The "Iron Duke" defeated Napoleon at Waterloo in 1815. He later became British prime minister and passed the Catholic Emancipation Act in 1829.
1854: Allied forces from Britain, France and Turkey land in the Crimea to attack the Russians, who had initiated the Crimean War by invading Turkey in July 1953.
1868: Scottish golfer Tom Morris scores the first recorded hole-in-one during the Open Championships at Prestwick.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, 43, becomes the 26th and youngest president of the United States, succeeding William McKinley, who died from wounds suffered from an assassination attempt in Buffalo, New York on Sept. 6.
1927: Isadora Duncan, American dancer, dies in a car accident near Nice, France, at the age of 49. She revolutionized the world of ballet, winning worldwide acclaim for her free, barefoot interpretation of classic pieces.
1937: China submits the question of Japanese aggression to the Council of the League of Nations.
1944: Chairman Chiang Kai-shek urges 100,000 young men to enter the army.
1960: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is created by Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.
1974: Nicaraguan President-elect Anastasio Somoza and his wife are greeted at the Taipei Airport by Vice President Yen Chia-kan and Premier Chiang Ching-kuo at the start of an official visit.
1978: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya.
1979: A 21-member delegation, headed by Economics Minister Chang Kwang-shih, leaves for Jeddah to attend the fourth Sino-Saudi Economic and Technical Cooperation Conference.
1982: Princess Grace of Monaco dies of head injuries suffered in a car crash. She was 52. The American film actress married Prince Rainier in 1956, ending her acting career. She won fame as the cool beauty in films such as "The Country Girl," for which she won an Oscar.
1983: The Philippine Civil Aeronautics Board lifts the ban on China Airlines flights to Manila, and the Civil Aeronautics Administration of the Republic of China lifts the ban on Philippine Airlines flights to Taipei.
1983: The Marshall Islands, which adopted its own constitution in 1979, holds a referendum and votes for independence from the United States. The United States had administered the islands as part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands since 1947.
1984: South African Prime Minister Pieter Willem Botha is sworn in as the first president under the new constitution, which combines the offices and powers of the prime minister and state president under the office of state president.
1986: The Taipei Municipal Zoo moves from Yuanshan to Mucha.
1987: Lee Yung-teh and Hsu Lu of the Independence Evening Post become the first Taiwan reporters to send back news reports from the Chinese mainland.
1991: John K. Fairbank, American scholar who was director of the Southeast Asian Research Center at Harvard University and a noted China expert, dies at the age of 84.
1996: Cambodian King Norodom Sihanouk pardons Khmer Rouge leader Ieng Sary for his role in the "killing fields" era of the 1970s.
1996: The ROC states its four-point position during the Tiaoyutai Islets dispute with Japan -- the ROC's absolute sovereignty, a rational attitude, no cooperation with Beijing, and the protection of Taiwan's fishing rights.
1999: Governor Howard Dean of the U.S. state of Vermont says that he fully backs Taiwan's efforts to join the World Trade Organization, and that 41 states across America support Taiwan's membership in the world trade regulatory body.
2000: National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou says that intelligence gathering has switched its focus from military and political information to national security-related economic and technological affairs.
2001: The main opposition Kuomintang sends a letter to former President Lee Teng-hui asking him not to slam the party any more.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The water appearing before us is but a ladle of liquid; but taken in all its unfathomable depths, the largest crustaceans, fishes and reptiles are produced in them, and all useful products abound in them."

The Moscow Times: Khodorkovsky Appeal May Be Quick Lawyers for Mikhail Khodorkovsky said his appeal, due to begin in court Wednesday, could be over within days as the Kremlin rushes to thwart the jailed oil tycoon's election bid.
The Moscow City Court was due to begin hearing Khodorkovsky's appeal of his conviction on tax evasion and fraud charges in May. He was sentenced to nine years in prison after a trial that was widely seen as payback for the threat he posed to Kremlin power.

A mistake on a single bundle of wires Monday cascaded into a major blackout in and around Los Angeles, inconveniencing millions of people and renewing questions about the vulnerability of the region's power system.

The Straits Times: Seawater fit for drinking now a reality.
Water from the sea that is safe to drink and affordable.
That is now a reality, and in record time too, with yesterday's opening of the first plant in Singapore to turn seawater into drinking water.
Before some 600 guests, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong turned on the tap at the desalination plant in Tuas, one of the world's largest.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Desalinate seawater, cheers.
The Singapore's first desalination plant in Tuas began running after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong turned on the tap last evening.
Speaking at the official opening, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Singapore has turned its water challenge from a vulnerability into a strength.
The new facility will begin pumping in October and contribute 10 percent of Singapore's water needs daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES ANG LEE FOR WINNING PRESTIGIOUS AWARD
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 13 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has sent a congratulatory message to renowned Taiwan-born director Ang Lee for winning the Golden Lion award for best movie at the 62nd Venice Film Festival Sept. 10, Government Information Office (GIO) sources in New York said Tuesday.

Lee grabbed the top honor at the prestigious film festival with his latest work -- "Brokeback Mountain" -- a Canadian-produced film starring Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal which tells the story of a gay cowboy couple in the conservative American West of the 1960s.
"Brokeback Mountain" bested 19 other feature films to win the top award at the film festival.
In his congratulatory message, President Chen praised Lee for being "a source of pride" for all the people of Taiwan.

Lee gained fame with the Taiwan-produced feature film "The Wedding" (1993) -- a lighthearted and moving human-interest story. He became internationally renowned after directing the Academy Award-winning "Sense and Sensibility" (1995) and his later hit "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" (2000).
Premier Frank Hsieh and GIO Minister Pasuya Yao also sent congratulatory messages to Lee, GIO officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD KEEN TO STABILIZE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong promised Wednesday to do whatever he can to stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations, saying that only a stable relationship between Taiwan and China can help the island's economic development.

The PFP head made the promise at Chiang Kai-shek Airport prior to his departure for Shanghai where he will attend a forum jointly organized by his PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) to discuss trade, economic and "three links" issues.
According to Soong, the holding of the forum is aimed at stabilizing relations between the two sides of the strait and helping the Taiwan people enjoy a safer and more prosperous environment.

"Everybody knows that without a stable cross-strait relationship, Taiwan's economic situation will not be able to improve, " he said, adding that "if the political parties cannot work on stabilizing Taipei-Beijing relations, the island's economy will not have a bright future, and the Taiwan people will be the main victims."

Pointing out that Beijing stated in May of this year that it will not use force against Taiwan if the island does not move towards independence and that the Legislative Yuan has not yet resolved the problems related to the arms procurement bill, the PFP chairman said that its better for the political parties to help the people make a good living than to agree to pay a large sum of money to purchase arms from foreign countries.
"Why don't we work together to stabilize cross-strait relations and improve the island's economy as these are the public's main expectations," he added.

He also promised that he will thoroughly exchange views during his visit to Shanghai with high-ranking Chinese officials on issues regarding the establishment of mutual trust and direct charter flight services and sea links between the two sides of the strait.
Soong also criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's "mini three-links" policy, saying that the policy is already "lame."

"If ships coming from Hong Kong and Macau to Taiwan do not pose any security problems to the island, why would ships sailing from Xiamen and Foujou to Taiwan be harmful to the island's security, " he asked.

Talking about the invitations extended by President Chen Shui-bian to opposition leaders to join him on his upcoming visits to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, Soong took U.S. President George W. Bush's recent decision to cut short meetings with foreign heads of state and make dealing with the natural disaster along the U.S. Gulf Coast a top priority, saying that the leader of a country should first deal with issues that the people are most concerned with.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES CABINET MEMBERS TO USE FILIBUSTER TIME PRODUCTIVELY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Wednesday told members of his Cabinet to prepare for the possibility that the opposition parties' filibustering tactics in the Legislative Yuan could become a "normal state of affairs" and to make good use of the delays by doing something useful.

The premier, who was blocked from delivering his administrative report when opposition legislators took turns occupying the podium during the entire first day of the new legislative session Tuesday, made the remarks during an Executive Yuan floor meeting.
Hsieh and his entire Cabinet ended up sitting all day in the legislature watching the "circus" Tuesday.
The premier noted that chaos is a phenomenon seen in the early stages of a democracy, adding that the administration must continue doing its work and not idle away the time unproductively.

He urged his Cabinet members to use the extra time to do useful things such as looking over reports, holding small coordination meetings and handling petitions by legislators, pointing to himself as an example by saying that he got a lot of work done during the previous day's filibuster and even read half a book.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CANNOT OPERATE NORMALLY WITHOUT U.N. MEMBERSHIP: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 13 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in New York City stated in a radio interview Tuesday the difficulties that the nation has experienced in its bid to join the United Nations, saying that the government cannot operate normally without membership of international organizations.

The interview with Andrew Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, was conducted on the eve of the opening of the 60th U.N. General Assembly with the aim of discussing issues related to Taiwan's U.N. bid and the situation in the Taiwan Strait.
Hsia said that for many countries, obtaining U.N. membership seems to be a natural thing, but pointed out that Taiwan has encountered many difficulties in its bid to join the organization.

"The Taiwan government and its people will be unable to operate normally nor to make more contributions to the international community if they cannot join international organizations, " he said, claiming that although Taiwan has tried to give assistance to the victims of various disasters, the donations have been refused by international organizations.

As China's military buildup over the past few years has created an imbalance of military power between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Hsia said this is why Taiwan's allies hope the United Nations can play an active role in maintaining peace in the strait.

"This is also why they have jointly raised a motion in support of Taiwan's U.N. bid and have expressed the hope that the U.N. Standing Committee will place the motion on the agenda of this year's U.N. General Assembly," he said.

Asked whether Taiwan worries that closer economic and trade relations between China and the United States will lead Washington to give less support to the country, Hsia said that Taiwan-U.S. relations have a solid historical background and are based on the common values of freedom and democracy with a legal basis supplied by the Taiwan Relations Act, but he added that Taiwan expects more support from the United States.
He also said that many factors will affect the development of cross-strait relations.
