DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KAOHSIUNG MAYOR: PREMIER SHOULD STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: Former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that Premier Frank Hsieh should step down, claiming that he lied during a Sept. 7 TV interview about who decided to build Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

Wu, now an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator, claimed that it was Hsieh who decided to adopt the BOT model for Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system but then said the decision was Wu's. Former China Steel Corp. Chairman Wang Chung-yu was also named by Hsieh.

Wu showed a copy of an official document, which he said was provided by an anonymous sneak because his own request for data from the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) was denied, to support his claim.

According to the document, dated March 12, 1999, then-Mayor Hsieh -- who defeated Wu in a 1998 mayoral election -- officially informed the Executive Yuan that he had decided to build the city's mass rapid transit routes under the BOT model.

Wu said he asked for leave Dec. 4 to run for re-election and his deputy, Huang Chun-ying, sent a letter to the MOTC asking it to approve the city's suggestion to adopt the BOT model. Huang sent the letter in response to an Executive Yuan instruction, which later said it did not agree with the city government on the issue.
Hsieh then announced in 1999 that the city's MRT will be built under the BOT model put forward by Wu.

Wu claimed that it is "utterly evident" that during his six years as Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh himself made the final decision on the BOT model but tried to shift responsibility to his predecessor by "lying" to society.

Wu demanded to face Hsieh in an open debate and a cross-examination session. Either he himself or Hsieh must quit politics to take responsibility for the Kaohsiung MRT fiasco in order to set a good example for Taiwan's politics, he added.
"This is not the time to talk about judicial procedures. Let's talk about political responsibility first, " Wu challenged.

The choice of the BOT model for Kaohsiung MRT came under fire after Thai workers brought in to build the project rioted Aug. 21 in protest over maltreatment by the Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd., which managed the workers.

Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit Corp. Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, who has been blamed for the fiasco, has resigned, as have Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu and Hsieh's successor, acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINAL GROUP TO PROTEST AGAINST JAPAN AT U.N.

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei is scheduled to lead an aboriginal group to the United States Thursday to lodge a protest at the United Nations against Japanese atrocities against Taiwan's aboriginal people before and during War World II.

Kao Chin, an aborigine and a member of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, is scheduled to lead the 60-member aboriginal group to U.N. headquarters in New York Sept. 23 to tell the world how the Japanese Imperial Army committed inhumane brutalities on Taiwan's indigenous people during its colonial rule of the country.

At a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan on the group's trip, she showed two copies of Japanese books, published in 1913 and 1914, respectively, which record how Japanese soldiers took aboriginal villages militarily with reports written and photos taken by members who were among the invading troops.
These books are solid evidence of the Japanese atrocities, Kao Chin added.

Kao Chin led an aboriginal group to Japan in June to demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government for the Taiwanese aborigines who were killed during World War II in combat as drafted Japanese Imperial Army soldiers.

Kao Chin and the protesters had planned to demonstrate outside the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, where their ancestors who fought for the Japanese are honored among some 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan and 1,068 convicted war criminals.

They demanded the removal of the aboriginal soldiers' memorial tablets from the shrine "so that their spirits can be escorted back to Taiwan." Kao Chin said it was absurd that the aboriginal soldiers, whom she described as victims of Japanese persecution, are honored together with their persecutors at the Yasukuni Shrine.

Her group of protesters, however, were stopped about 200 meters from the shrine and prohibited from getting off their buses by Japanese police for fear that they might clash with a group of Japanese right-wingers who had gathered at the scene ahead of their arrival.

Describing their treatment by the Japanese police as "brutal, " Kao Chin said it demonstrated once again that the Japanese government has an absurd lack of remorse for what Japan did during World War II, prompting her to decide to lead the same Taiwan group to the United Nations to put their protest on the world stage.
"Where there is no Japan of remorse, there will be no Japan of peace-seeking," Kao Chin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY, COUNTY TO DECLARE SUPPORT FOR KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and acting Taipei County Magistrate Lin Hsi-yao will sign a joint declaration Sept. 17 in support of the Kyoto Protocol and affirm their commitment to helping curb global warming by reducing carbon dioxide emissions.
The two administrative heads, accompanied by their respective entourages, will ride bicycles and meet at the border between Taipei City and Taipei County, on the Huachiang bridge.

The joint declaration will be signed as part of the celebrations for International Car-Free Day, which promotes walking, cycling and public transportation in an attempt to raise public awareness of the importance of sustainable transport.
Taipei county government officials disclosed that Ma and Lin will pledge in their joint declaration to link the bicycle routes of Taipei City and Taipei County and turn them into a 270-km network.

International Car-Free Day, initiated in France in 1998, takes place Sept. 22. The festival is celebrated each year in some 1,500 cities all over the world by 100 million people. The event is also a fun day out for people of all ages who leave their cars behind and use pollution-free transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down nine points to close at 6,155, with 15,568 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October decreased seven points to finish at 6,156, with 1,616 contracts traded, while December futures lost 33 points to end at 6,130, with three contract transactions. March futures ended flat at 6,160, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,164 for September, 6,163 for October, 6,163 for December, 6,160 for March and 6,140 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

September TE futures moved down one point to close at 256.40, with 2,281 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 0.70 points to finish at 256.50, with 264 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures moved up 1.6 points to finish at 932.0, with 1,518 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures gained 0.4 points to close at 928.4, with 644 contracts traded. December TF futures dropped 0.8 points to end at 926.4 points, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Affected by a decline in share prices on the U.S. stock market and a wait-and-see attitude adopted by investors, share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 20.38 points to close at 6,148.70.
The bourse opened at 6,159.97 and fluctuated between 6,172.89 and 6,132.99 during trading. A total of 2.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$53.45 billion (US$1.62 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most by 1.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks by 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics issues by 0.5 percent, cement stocks by 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical shares and textile issues by 0.1 percent.
Banking and financial shares moved up by 0.2 percent, while prices for foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 658 to 238, with 152 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.033 to close at NT$32.774.
A total of US$961 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.741 and fluctuated between NT$32.713 and NT$32.811.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEPLORES LACK OF TRUST IN TAIWAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh deplored the lack of trust in Taiwan's political circles Wednesday, in particular the opposition's demand that he be investigated for his role in the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit controversy.
"Investigated by whom? By the judicial institutions? It is the opposition who has claimed the judiciary is dead, " Hsieh said at a Cabinet meeting.

He criticized the opposition parties for "adding to problems instead of solving them" by demanding judicial inquiries as they see fit and if the investigation results are not to their satisfaction, they just claim that the judicial system is dead.

Judging from a few previous examples, such as the court ruling on the March 19, 2004 shooting of the president and vice president, which was not to their liking, they responded by claiming the ruling was the product of political interference, said the premier.

"If a judicial investigation were to find me innocent, they would make the same claim, a response that will not help solve the problem but will simply destroy the credibility of our judicial system, " Hsieh said.

He suggested that everyone "return to the institutions" and, if court rulings are defective, make criticisms from the perspective of evidence or theory, because these are "civilized" standards based on which the institutions can operate and win the trust of the people.

He said some observers are worried that the opposition's filibuster of the premier's report to the legislature Tuesday might have scuttled his "rapprochement and symbiosis" philosophy, but added that it will take time for his philosophy to take root. However, he claimed that he is still "fully confident" of Taiwan's path toward rapprochement and symbiosis.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MONGOLIAN PRIME MINISTER TO ATTEND FORUM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Former Mongolian Prime Minister Rinchinnyamiin Amarjargal will attend the inaugural meeting of the World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA) in Taipei that is scheduled to open Thursday, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday.

Kau, who is also the executive director of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD), which is sponsoring the forum, said the former Mongolian leader, together with former Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia, former El Salvador President Francisco Guillermo Flores and former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will have a discussion that it is hoped will help raise the international profile of Asian democracy.

In addition, more than 100 government and civic group leaders from more than 20 countries, as well as regional organization leaders, Asian democracy activists and parliamentarians will also take part in the Sept. 15-17 forum at the Taipei International Convention Center, he said.
Among them are Singapore Democratic Party Secretary-General Chee Soon Juan and Chinese pro-democracy activist Xiao Qiang.

Kau said the inaugural meeting will discuss and adopt guidelines to promote the solidarity of Asian democracies, support democracy activists who are opposed to authoritarian regimes, and solicit support from the international community on democratization in Asia.

The plan is to submit the guidelines to the United Nations' Secretariat and member states for reference, and obtain the status of providing counselling to the U.N. so that the views of the WFDA can be passed to related meetings in the U.N. and Asia's democratic voice can be strengthened in the United Nations, he said.

The three-day meeting will feature a number of speakers, including Canadian parliamentarian David Kilgour, who will speak on human rights in Asia; Michael H.H. Hsiao, national policy advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, who will address the topic of Taiwan's democratization; and Professor Arthur Waldron of the University of Pennsylvania, who will give his outlook on democratic development in Asia.
The meeting will also invite Chen, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen to speak, Kau said.
Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh will host dinners in honor of the participants.

The sponsor originally wanted to invite former Japanese prime ministers Yasuhiro Nakasone and Yashiro Mori to attend the forum to explore the prospects and strategies of Asian democracy, but because of their ages and personal itineraries, as well as fear of pressure from China, they declined to make the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. COMMITMENT TO PEACE, SECURITY QUESTIONABLE: MOFA HEAD

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen expressed regret Wednesday at Taiwan's 13th consecutive failure in its bid to enter the United Nations and questioned the U.N.'s commitment to world peace and security.

Two proposals submitted by Republic of China allies supporting Taiwan's U.N. seat bid failed to be listed for screening by the U.N. General Committee to decide whether or not they will be put on the U.N. General Assembly's agenda.

The U.N. General Committee rejected the two proposals that the question of U.N. membership for Taiwan and that peace in the Taiwan Strait be put on the agenda for the assembly's 60th session, which opens on Wednesday, after debates between representatives from Gambia and China and between Chad and Pakistan were conducted.

Unlike previous years, Taiwan's diplomatic allies presented two proposals to the U.N. Secretariat this year -- "that the U.N. play an active role in ensuring peace in the Taiwan Strait" and that "the U.N. recognize the Taiwan people's right to representation" -- in the hope that both proposals would be put on the U.N. agenda.
Chen offered his gratitude toward the ROC allies for their support for Taiwan. The "peace" proposal was submitted by 15 ROC allies, while the "representation" proposal was submitted by 12.

He expressed regret over Taiwan's new setback, pointing out that the founding of the United Nations in 1945 was a commitment to peace after years of war, but adding that today's U.N. has a responsibility to work to prevent the outbreak of military conflict in every region around the world.

Despite the setback, Chen said Taiwan will not be defeated spiritually and should stick firmly to international mainstream values and stand on the right side of history. So long as the people of Taiwan remain resolved in achieving their goal, they will make it one day, he said, adding that "nothing is impossible in politics."

The foreign minister also pointed out that the Taiwan opposition leaders' visits to Beijing has been used and quoted by China as reference in open debates on Taiwan's U.N. bid. This should prompt the Taiwan public to conduct soul-searching about the entire situation, he said.
Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau lashed out at the United Nations for its failure to demonstrate international justice and righteousness.
Kau said that as a citizen of Taiwan, he will lodge protests in the sternest terms against the U.N. for reneging on its founding spirit of safeguarding world peace and security.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year through its diplomatic allies to have its U.N. membership bid placed on the General Assembly's agenda. However, it has been unsuccessful due to Beijing's obstruction.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, it has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED OVER TIMING OF FORMER PRESIDENT'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The United States welcomes a visit by former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui but has concerns about the timing of his trip, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday.
Kau made the remarks in the wake of reports that the United States has asked Lee to postpone his trip, originally planned for between late September and early October.

Lee is scheduled to visit Los Angeles and to then proceed to Washington, D.C. and New York. In addition to meeting with Taiwan expatriates, he is also expected to meet with U.S. political figures, according to the reports.

Kau said that U.S. concerns over Lee's timing because it might coincide with transit stops by President Chen Shui-bian in the United States during his upcoming 12-day visit to Central America and the Caribbean, as well as the United Nations National Assembly meeting being held in New York.

Kau said that although Lee's trip was arranged by Lee's office and a U.S. governor friendly to Taiwan, according to reports, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will provide every necessary assistance for the former president.
He said that Lee's trip is still under discussion with the U.S.
Ministry officials said earlier that Lee's travel plans might be postponed because of the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH CUT PROPORTION OF GOV'T INVESTMENT IN KAOHSIUNG MRT: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reduced the proportion of government investment in the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit construction project to 83 percent of the total from 89 percent when he was Kaohsiung mayor, his spokesman said Wednesday.

Cho Jung-tai was responding to former Kaohsiung mayor Wu Den-yih's accusation that Hsieh, not Wu, decided to construct the MRT under the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model, a decision that may have contributed to the Aug. 21 riot by Thai construction workers, which triggered a political storm in Taiwan.
Wu said Hsieh insisted on using the BOT model to build the city's MRT system in spite of the Executive Yuan's concern over the appropriateness of using such a method.

Cho said that according to official records, the Executive Yuan was merely questioning the suitability of the city government's initial proposal to shoulder 89 percent of the entire project, with the private sector sharing 11 percent.

Hsieh lowered the government's share of the investment to about 83 percent while the private sector's share was raised to a little over 16 percent, a decision that won Executive Yuan approval on June 4, 1999, Cho pointed out.

As to whether Hsieh had favored any private contractors, Cho claimed that the awarding of contracts was jointly done by the Kaohsiung City Government and China Steel Corp., whose chairman, Wang Chung-yu, was also chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), a corporation formed to build and run the MRT.
Given this, people should ask Wang if the city government favored any individual contractors during the bidding process, Cho said.

As to why Hsieh hurried to initiate the bidding process just 38 days after he replaced Wu as mayor, Cho said Hsieh was facing time constraints to make good on his campaign promise that construction of the MRT would start within two years of his election.

In response to opposition parties' claim that the city government dominated the process of choosing KRTC's key board members, Cho said the city government had only one seat on the board, which was filled by a representative of Kaohsiung City Bank, whereas the central government had two seats, both of which were filled by representatives from state-run China Steel.
"So how could anyone say that the city government had any decisive power to choose board members?" Cho asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE NO. 2 KILLER OF 15-44 AGE GROUP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Suicide became the No. 2 cause of death among Taipei residents aged between 14 and 44 last year, according to figures released Wednesday by the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Taipei City Government.

For the 15-24 age group, accidents killed 58 people last year, followed by suicides which resulted in 21 deaths. In the 25-44 age group, 244 deaths were attributed to malignant tumors, while 133 died in suicides.

Altogether, 13,733 Taipei residents died in 2004, showing a death rate of 523 in every 100,000 people, up six people compared with 2003. Those who died in 2004 lived an average of 70.6 years, an increase of 5.7 years from a decade ago. Of this group, men lived an average 69.6 years, while the life span of women averaged 72.

Malignant tumors were still the No. 1 killer of Taipei residents, followed by heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes, kidney disease, accidents, pneumonia, suicide, chronic liver disease and cirrhosis of the liver, and diseases related to high blood pressure.
Compared to 2003, pneumonia went from No. 5 to No. 7 among other causes of death last year, while suicides rose one notch from No. 9 to No. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC SIGNS CONTRACT WITH QATAR COMPANY FOR LIQUEFIED NATURAL GAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) signed a 25-year contract with Qatar Tuesday to buy liquefied natural gas (LNG), CPC sources said Wednesday.

CPC Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai, who is currently visiting the Middle East, and Yusif Husayn al-Kamal, Qatar minister of finance and chairman of Ras Laffan Liquefied Natural Gas Company II (RasGas-II) , signed the contract in Doha, Qatar. Republic of China representative to Saudi Arabia Yang Sheng-tsung and ranking officials of RasGas II were on hand to witness the signing.

According to the contract, the CPC will purchase three million tons of LNG per year starting from 2008 to provide the natural gas to Tatan Power Plant of the state-owned Taiwan Power Co. and for growing domestic needs.

CPC currently relies mainly on Indonesia and Malaysia for its supply of LNG. The long-term contract with Qatar will help with "source diversification" and secure a more steady supply of LNG as well as enhance cooperation between the CPC and Middle East countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO QUID PRO QUO FOR PREMIER'S RIGHT TO REPORT TO LEGISLATURE: DPP

TEXT.P: The premier has a constitutional right to deliver an administrative report to the legislature, and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) cannot use it as a quid pro quo for forming five commissions for investigating various incidents of alleged government misconduct, the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus said Wednesday.

Caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai said his caucus will not oppose the formation of five commissions to investigate the suspected corruption in the construction projects of Kaohsiung City's rapid transit system and Taiwan's high-speed railway, the second phase of the government's financial reform plan, an insider trading scandal involving a top official charged with preventing insider trading in the stock market, and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom that deliberately violated a resolution passed by the previous legislature calling on the government to halt the move.

Lai said his caucus may go even further to propose forming more commissions to probe all sorts of corruption scandals over the past years, government construction projects that ended up lying idle, and land pollution.

Still, he said, it is the premier's constitutional duty to make his administrative report to the Legislative Yuan. If the KMT keeps on its "unreasonable" filibuster, it will be shunned by the people, he warned.

Premier Frank Hsieh failed to make his report at the legislature on the opening day of the new legislative session Tuesday as lawmakers from the opposition KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP) , took over the podium, keeping Hsieh away.
KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said this could have been avoided if the DPP had honored an agreement between the two parties signed by DPP Policy Committee Executive Director Ko Chien-ming.

Under the agreement, Hsieh was to deliver his report at 3:00 p.m. Tuesday, but DPP caucus convener Chao Yung-ching insisted that without his signature, the agreement was invalid. The two-party pact broke down as a result, according to Ma.

He called on the DPP to recall what it had done while it was an opposition party, and "place itself in the KMT's shoes" while trying to blame the largest opposition party for causing the legislature to waste a whole day.
The KMT caucus threatened to repeat the "scorched earth" tactics on Friday and deny Premier Hsieh another chance to make his report if he does not apologize for the Kaohsiung MRT scandal.
Chao said since the investigation of the Kaohsiung MRT incident was still underway, and who should be responsible has yet to be determined, how could the KMT demand that Hsieh apologize now?

At the legislature, Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will call a "negotiation session" Thursday in which party caucuses will try to reach a deal on the five investigative commissions. If all things go well, Hsieh will be able to step onto the legislative podium and deliver his report Friday.

Meanwhile, as the Kaohsiung MRT controversy has turned into a "personal duel" between the two former mayors -- KMT Legislator Wu Den-yih and Premier Frank Hsieh, the KMT may adopt a two-pronged strategy of filibustering the legislature and street demonstrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS CAN TAKE NATURALIZATION TESTS NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Naturalization tests for foreigners will start next year and the test questions and their answers will be published in late October at the earliest, according to a draft proposal passed in a meeting of the Ministry of the Interior Wednesday.

The ministry said that in tune with the revised Nationality Law, ministry officials passed the draft proposal, ensuring that aliens applying for naturalization will possess a basic language ability and a grasp of the rights and obligations of ROC nationals.
For this purpose, starting in 2006, aliens can provide certificates showing that they have taken related courses or that they have taken part in oral or written tests -- to be held four times a year.

Vice Interior Minister Lin Chung-sheng said that foreigners can provide certificates showing that they have studied in public or private schools for more than one year, or have taken part in government-sponsored or commissioned courses. For most applicants, they must attend 200 hours of classes; for special applicants (spouses or step-children) , or those over 65, only 100 hours is needed.

For those who don't want to go to classes, they can take part in the naturalization tests. The applicants must pay NT$500 (US$22.22) administrative fees, and can either take written tests or oral tests, choosing either Mandarin, Hakka, Taiwanese or aboriginal languages for the tests.

Whether oral or written, the 20 questions will be taken from a 200 question bank, ministry officials said, adding that the 200 questions and their answers will be published in late October or early November. For the average applicant, 70 points will be considered a passing score, with 60 points for special applicants and 50 points for those over 65.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$100 BILLION AVAILABLE IN LOANS FOR FARMING SECTOR FROM OCT. 1

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission under the Cabinet held a meeting with representatives from government agencies and domestic banks Wednesday to discuss a plan to make NT$100 billion available for loans to Taiwan's farmers, fishermen, and farming and fishery enterprises.
A spokesman for the commission said these loans will be made to the farming and fishery sectors from Oct. 1 this year to Sept. 30, 2006.
The day's discussions centered around how to make use of money in existing funds and other available resources to ensure that the plan will be successful.
Financial institutions are encouraged to join in the plan to help the farming and fishery sectors, which suffered heavy losses when typhoons Haitang and Talim hit Taiwan in July and August.
Officials from the commission and the Council of Agriculture will meet with representatives of these financial organizations Every three months to review the loan operations, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM THANKS ALLIES FOR SUPPORTING TAIWAN IN INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen thanked six ROC allies Wednesday for their support for Taiwan's bid to enter the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU).

The minister said speakers from El Salvador, Guatemala, Nauru, the Marshall Islands, Tuvalu and Saint Christopher and Nevis spoke out for Taiwan during the Summit of Speakers of Parliament organized by the IPU in New York Sept. 7-9.

The minister quoted Ciro Cruz Zepeda, speaker of El Salvador parliament, as saying in the summit that the El Salvador parliament supports any UN efforts to better human rights protection and to ensure peace around the world, including the peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Jorge Mendez, the speaker of the Guatemala parliament, was reported as telling the summit that his country has sympathy for the 23 million Taiwan people who are shut out of most international organizations, not least the United Nations, despite the equality of man enshrined in the UN charter.

Valdon Dowiyogo, speaker of the Nauru parliament, was quoted as saying at the same occasion that his country believes the world is dodging its international responsibility by refusing to address Taiwan people's plight caused by their country's exclusion from most international organizations.

Litokwa Tomeing, speaker of the Marshall Islands, said during the summit that the IPU should consider Taiwan's application, because that country's 23 million people's voices should be heard in all international organizations.

Otinielu Tutelemalae Tausi, speaker of the Tuvaru parliament, said at the summit that Taiwan's remarkable democratic achievements and its contribution to international development make it a pivotal partner in the world in wiping out poverty, adding, "We strongly support the idea of discussing its representation in the United Nations and the Inter-parliamentary Union."

Marcella Liburd, speaker of the parliament of Saint Christopher and Nevis, said during the summit: "We prodded the United Nations to take action to ensure the peace across the Taiwan Strait and to accept Taiwan, the democracy, and its 23 million people as a member state."

Founded in 1889, the IPU is the international organization of parliaments of sovereign states. Its 2005 Summit of Speakers of Parliament has brought together 150 speakers of parliaments from countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIDS TO HOST INTERNATIONAL OLYMPIC COMMITTEE SESSION IN 2009

TEXT.P: Taipei and the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee will bid on behalf of Taiwan to host the 121st International Olympic Committee (IOC) Session and the 13th Olympic Congress in 2009, a sport official said Wednesday.
Chu Shou-chien, vice minister of the national council on physical fitness and sports, said his council is seeking the support of other countries, including China.

Noting that his council as well as the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee have good contacts with Chinese sport officials, and have worked together with them for many sport exchanges, Chu said it is possible for Taiwan to win Chinese endorsement although only the support of a majority of IOC members can ensure Taiwan's success.
Chu said, however, the support from the United States, Japan and European states are more important than from China.
As the country's supreme sports policymaker, Chu said, his council is not in a position to bid to host these events, which has to be done by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee.

The IOC session is the most important sport gathering in the world. Would-be host cities have to tender their bids three years in advance. The 2009 IOC session will choose the host city for the 2016 summer Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Sept. 15, or the 12th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster accordinig to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: San Salvador declares its independence.
1857: William Howard Taft, the 27th president of the United States, is born. His term was marked by passage of the Payne-Aldrich Tariff Act in 1909. He later served as chief justice of the US Supreme Court.
1900: Hirobumi Ito, the Japanese politician who helped draft the constitution of 1889 and served as prime minister, becomes the first president of the Friends of the Constitution Association established in Tokyo.
1917: Russian Socialist Revolutionary Party Prime Minister Aleksandr Kerenski proclaims Russia a republic.
1924: The second war between the Chihli faction and the Manchuria army breaks out in China when Chang Tso-lin leads his army in attacking Tsao Kun's faction during China's warlord era.
1932: Japan signs an agreement to formally recognize so-called "Manchukuo." The "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1935: Manuel Luis Quezon is elected first president of the Philippine Commonwealth.
1935: At a huge Nazi rally in Nuremberg, Adolf Hitler, the German Fuehrer, announces new decrees which relegate Jews to "untermensch" (sub-human) status.
1949: Theodor Heuss is elected first president of West Germany, and Konrad Adenauer is elected first chancellor.
1950: U.N. forces commanded by American General Douglas MacArthur land at Inchon in an attempt to drive North Korean troops out of South Korea.
1954: The 1st Plenum of the 1st Chinese Communist Party Central Committee is held in Beijing and passes the "Constitution of the People's Republic of China."
1959: Russian Premier Nikita Khruschev arrives in the United States for a 12-day visit.
1961: Two mainland Chinese pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, defect to South Korea in their AN-2 plane.
1966: H.M.S. Resolution, Britain's first nuclear submarine, is launched by the Queen Mother.
1975: A Japan Asia Airways DC-8 touches down in Taipei, signifying the resumption of service between Taiwan and Japan by the flagship carriers of the two countries. Arriving on the inaugural flight are Nobusuke Kishi, former prime minister, and some 20 parliamentarians and other dignitaries.
1978: A computerized typewriter for the Chinese language is developed in Taiwan.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan leaves for a three-day visit to Saudi Arabia, accompanied by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tsiang Yien-si, Chief of the General Staff Admiral Soong Changchih, and Director General of the Government Information Office James C.Y. Soong.
1983: Israeli Prime Minister Menachim Begin, founder of the right-wing Likud Party, resigns and is succeeded by Yitzhak Shamir.
1983: Chien Shih-liang, president of the Republic of China's Academia Sinica, dies of illness in National Taiwan University Hospital at the age of 76.
1988: The Museum of the Moving Image, the world's largest film museum devoted entirely to the history of film and television, opens on London's South Bank.
1989: Prime Minister Mary Euginia Charles of the Commonwealth of Dominica arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1996: The United States removes the ROC from a wildlife conservation watch list in recognition of its progress in protecting endangered species.
1999: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macci, accompanied by his wife and a group of more than 10 officials, arrives in Taipei for a five-day state visit.
2000: The 2000 Olympic games opens in Sydney, with 11,000 athletes and 5,100 support stuff from 199 countries and regions, including the Republic of China, participating.
2001: Three new container shipping wharves, funded by Taiwan's Evergreen Group, are inaugurated at the southern Italian port of Taranto.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Oh, how great is the divine moral law in man! Vast and unlimited, it gives birth and life to all created things. It towers high up to the very heavens."

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH AGAIN URGES HU TO ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 14 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. national security official said Tuesday that President George W. Bush has again urged Chinese President Hu Jintao to engage in more dialogue with Taiwan, including dialogue with the island's duly-elected government.

Mike Green, special assistant to the U.S. president for national security affairs and senior director for Asian affairs, made the remarks while briefing reporters on the meeting between the two heads of state held earlier in the day in New York City.

This is the second time that the White House has publicly expressed President Bush's call for dialogue between the Chinese president and the Taiwan government. Bush made a similar appeal during a phone conversation with his Chinese counterpart a few months ago.

According to Green, during the meeting in New York, Hu raised Beijing's concerns about cross-strait issues and Taiwan, while President Bush, for his part, reiterated the U.S. stance, including its one China policy, the three communiques, the Taiwan Relations Act, opposition to unilateral moves by either side to try to change the status quo, and non-support for Taiwan independence.

Hu also explained some of China's moves to reduce tensions in the Taiwan Strait, while Bush expressed the hope that dialogue between Taiwan and Beijing could expand to include the government of Taiwan, Green said.

Claiming that he himself does not think anything new regarding the Taiwan issue came out of the meeting, Green, however, added that: "This is an important issue for China, it is an important issue for us, and in almost every bilateral summit between the American and Chinese leaders, in one way or another, publicly and/or privately, both sides have to reaffirm where they are."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CALLS FOR WORLD DEMOCRATIC COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian called on Asia's democracies to join other democratic countries and form a "world democratic community" that will help open up closed societies and democratize non-democratic regimes.

Speaking at the first World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA) , the president pointed to North Korea, Myanmar and the People's Republic of China as the "non-democratic regimes" that are causing "grave hidden concerns" about regional stability.

North Korea's nuclear program is threatening Northeast Asian countries; Myanmar's military junta is causing controversy and trouble within ASEAN and beyond; and the "clouds of war" created by China in the Taiwan Strait are not only threatening the democracy treasured by Taiwan's 23 million people, but also seriously challenging regional security and order, Chen said.
In order to maintain peace and prosperity in Asia, efforts must be made to promote democratization in all Asian countries and establish a pan-Asian civil society, he said.

Asian democracies should also work with other democracies in forming a "world democratic community" that will help non-democratic regimes transform into democracies while consolidating the democratic institutions of those countries that have achieved democratization, the president added.

He welcomed foreign participants to the forum, saying the fact that so many foreign friends are willing to share views on the prospects of democracy in Asia is proof that democracy is a universal value that goes beyond national boundaries.
The gathering shows that democratization is important to peace and prosperity in Asia; it also indicates that Taiwan's free society is charming and attractive, the president said.

He said Taiwan is the first country in Asia that has set up a national foundation -- the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy -- because Taiwan has a special sense of responsibility for and commitment to Asia's democratization.

Chen said that since the end of World War II, many Asian countries have worked hard to develop their economies over the past 60 years, many of which, including Taiwan, have also established democracy and the rule of law.

If history serves as a guide for the future, Chen said, whether the Asian economy will continue to develop and whether stability in this part of the world can be maintained depends on creating a "democratic Asia."

The forum is being sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, with participants coming from the Alliance for Reform and Democracy (ARDA), Alternative Asean Network on Burma (ALTSEAN), Forum Asia Democracy (FAD) , and Initiatives for International Dialogue (IID).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOT SURPRISED BY FILIBUSTER IN LEGISLATURE ON OPENING DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thought there was "nothing surprising" about the new session of the legislature opening with opposition lawmakers filibustering, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
According to Wang, the president said he was not surprised as he had seen many similar scenes when his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was the opposition.

"This is not happening only today, " Wang quoted Chen as saying in reference to Tuesday's scene in the legislature when opposition Kuomintang and People First Party lawmakers occupied the podium to block Premier Frank Hsieh from making his administrative report.

Chen told Wang that in a democracy, opposition parties filibustering in the legislature is something that can happen when a new session opens, adding that it had happened many times when the DPP was not in power.

Chen and Wang spoke Thursday while attending the World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA), where Chen delivered a speech calling on Asia's democratic countries to join hands with other democracies to form a "world democratic community" to help open up closed societies and democratize such undemocratic regimes as North Korea, Myanmar and the People's Republic of China.

Wang, who is also chairman of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy that sponsored of the WFDA meeting, said he hopes that such meetings will continue "until the torch of democracy and human rights lights up all corners of Asia."

Wang also said that Taiwan's democratic experience is a useful reference for other Asian countries as it shows that democratic values can be applied to all Asian societies that are pursuing rapid economic growth.

Taiwan should share its democratic experience because democratic institutions serve as a solid foundation for regional peace and economic prosperity, he said, noting that democratization is closely linked to peace and security for Asian people.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO PROTEST JAPANESE ATROCITIES AGAINST ABORIGINALS AT U.N.

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei departed for the United States Thursday at the head of a 60-member aboriginal group to lodge a protest at the United Nations headquarters in New York over Japanese atrocities against Taiwan's aboriginal people during its colonial rule of Taiwan.
Among the people who saw Kao Chin off at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport was opposition Kuomintang Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Kao Chin said that the Japanese government, instead of showing remorse for its crimes committed in the past, has tried to destroy the evidence of its cruelty by altering history textbooks. She added that she intends to expose the atrocities committed against Taiwan's aboriginal people at the U.N. headquarters so that all peace- and human rights-loving people will join in their condemnation of Japan's actions.

Kao Chin, an aboriginal lawmaker and a member of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) , is scheduled to appear at the U.N. headquarters Sept. 23 to highlight Japan's atrocities committed against Taiwan's indigenous people during its colonial rule of the island between 1895-1945.

She criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for not forcefully bringing forward the issue of Japan's past atrocities, saying that she believes that most of the Taiwan people will support her cause.

Influential political figures have begun to show support for her campaign, Kao Chin pointed out, citing the examples of KMT Chairman Ma, NPSU Chairman Chang Po-ya, and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, which she said is a good start.
Ma noted that Kao Chin's campaign aims at "returning the identity and dignity to the aboriginal people, " and that it also makes one reflect on the social status of the aboriginal people in Taiwan.
Knowing that the delegation is cash-strapped, Ma presented a red envelope containing US$3,000 in cash to Kao Chin in the hopes that it will induce others to make contributions.
Independent lawmaker and writer Li Ao has already donated NT$1 million (US$30,760) to the cause.
Kao's delegation is scheduled to return to Taiwan Sept. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINIC CLOSED FOR 6 MONTHS AFTER WATER-BORN BABY DIES

TEXT.P: Health authorities in Taipei County ordered a midwifery clinic in Hsinchuang City Thursday to suspend operations for six months for improper care of a water-born baby leading to its death.
The owner of Yung Hsin Midwifery Clinic, Tsai Sha-ning, will be charged with "professional negligence leading to death, " officials of the county's Bureau of Health said.
Official investigations found that the health condition of the baby boy, born at 4: 45 a.m. on Sept. 8, was initially normal, but that the baby began to turn pale 15 minutes after birth.

Clinic staff continued "monitoring" the baby until 6: 50 a.m., by which time the baby's skin had turned cold and secretions were flowing from its nose and mouth. The clinic staff then began first aid treatment before sending the baby to Taipei Hospital in Hsinchuang at 7:16 a.m. According to the hospital's records, the baby was dead on arrival.
Officials said that in the two hours of "monitoring" the baby, clinic staff did not contact a doctor or properly record the baby's vital signs, even after abnormal signs became apparent.
The clinic will be closed from Sept. 19, 2005 to March 18, 2006 for failing to inform medical authorities of the new-born baby's condition in a timely manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL JOIN U.N. WHEN TIME IS RIPE: ROC ENVOY TO U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in Washington said Wednesday that although the island has again failed in its bid to become a member of the United Nations, the efforts have grabbed the attention of the whole world, adding that "time will finally be on our side."

David Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, made the comments after the U.N. General Committee decided in a meeting held earlier in the day not to put the island's U.N. seat bid on this year's U.N. General Assembly agenda.

During the meeting, two proposals presented by Taiwan's diplomatic allies to the U.N. Secretary calling for the U.N. " to play an active role in ensuring peace in the Taiwan Strait" and "to recognize the Taiwan people's right to representation" were rejected for further discussions at the 60th U.N. General Assembly, which opens the same day, as the committee members did not reach a consensus on the matter.
This marked Taiwan's 13 consecutive failure since 1993 in its bid to enter the United Nations.

Nevertheless, Lee said he is still confident that Taiwan will join the world organization one day, adding that "a long effort and wait are needed for Taiwan to become a U.N. member. I believe that we will join the U.N. when time is ripe."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILL EXPLAIN KAOHSIUNG MRT IF ALLOWED TO AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: If the opposition wants to hear the full story about the government's involvement in the Kaohisung mass rapid transit system, Premier Frank Hsieh will reveal all at the legislature -- as long as the opposition does not filibuster, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.
Cho made the offer as the Legislative Yuan was scheduled to hold a plenary meeting Friday, when the premier is supposed to deliver his administrative report to the floor.

But the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party is still demanding that Hsieh apologize first and that five commissions be formed to investigate alleged government corruption before Hsieh gives his report.

Hsieh was blocked from approaching the podium Tuesday on the opening day of the new session as slogan-shouting opposition lawmakers surrounded it while waving placards and banners, with the day ending in a political show of farce.
Cho said if the same thing happens again Friday, the premier will use his time at the legislature to execute his official duties as usual, or read a book.

Cho touched on media and public criticism of a "wasted day at the legislature, " noting that besides the costs to the government, society's loss of confidence in the future of the country is a cost even harder to estimate.

If opposition lawmakers want to know the whole story about the Kaohsiung MRT project, let Premier Hsieh make his administrative report and then ask him questions in the ensuing interpellation sessions, and he will give open and comprehensive answers, Cho added.
If the opposition just demands a "formal apology," what they will get is nothing but a "forced apology at the behest of exploitation by the majority," Cho said.
He said any questions or suspicions about the Kaohisung MRT project can be cleared up through debate at the legislature, a task that the premier sincerely hopes the Legislative Yuan will undertake.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Multi-front plan to fight dengue.
A ministerial committee charged with hammering out dengue containment measures had its first meeting yesterday morning. By lunchtime, it had worked out a strategy to curb the raging outbreak.
Its first move: a blitz this weekend to comb four estates for mosquito breeding sites, and distribute pamphlets to residents in all 84 constituencies on how to prevent dengue.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush to Request More Aid Funding; Analysts Warn of Spending's Impact.
President Bush will call tonight for an unprecedented federal commitment to rebuild New Orleans and other areas obliterated by Hurricane Katrina, putting the United States on pace to spend more in the next year on the storm's aftermath than it has over three years on the Iraq war, according to White House and congressional officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bomb explodes in military barracks, one killed and another one injured.
A bomb exploded in military barracks in the province of Latina, central Italy, Wednesday, killing a soldier and injuring another one. It remained unclear when and why the explosive was brought into the dormitory of barracks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 66.14 points to close at 6,082.56.
The bourse opened at 6,132.45 and fluctuated between 6,139.99 and 6,079.57 during trading. A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.7 billion (US$1.79 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 759 to 154, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.059 to close at NT$32.833.
A total of US$1.09 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.794 and fluctuated between NT$32.761 and NT$32.873.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 75 points to close at 6,080, with 23,987 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 69 points to end at 6,087, with 4,201 contracts traded, while December futures lost 61 points to finish at 6,090, with 25 contracts traded. March futures moved down 51 points to close at 6,098, with two contracts traded, while June futures moved up 26 points to close at 6,157, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,155 for September, 6,156 for October, 6,151 for December, 6,149 for March and 6,131 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures moved down four points to close at 252.4, with 3,582 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 4.4 points to finish at 252.1, with 715 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 2.4 points to end at 254, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost seven points to finish at 925, with 1,619 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 5.6 points to end at 922.8, with 713 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 4.4 points to close at 925.2, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOONG'S CROSS-STRAIT COMMENTS NOTHING NEW: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's pronouncement on cross-strait affairs - parroting the format used by President Chen Shui-bian in his 2000 inaugural address - is old wine in a new bottle, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

The nation's top China policy planner was referring to Soong's new "four noes plus one" pronouncement in Shanghai where he is attending a forum jointly organized by the PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) to discuss trade, economic and "three links" issues.

Soong's new "four noes plus one" refers to no cessation of "bridge-building" activities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, no loss of focus in promoting a "renaissance of the Chinese people, " no closing of the door of cross-strait reconciliation, no wavering on the determination to ensure cross-strait peace, and given these, there will be "no hesitation and retreat."

Asked to comment, Wu said this is a familiar refrain from the pro-unificationist Soong and he wouldn't say if the statement would make any difference in the current development of cross-strait relations.
Speaking at a forum in Shanghai on Thursday, Soong again promoted direct cross-strait transportation, saying that it could start with Taipei and Shanghai on a trial basis.
In this way, Shanghai, Taipei and Hong Kong could form a new "golden economic triangle," and that it will later expand to Shenzhen and other cities in the mainland.

Soong said that cross-strait economic exchanges are important, and no one can afford to ignore direct cross-strait links, noting that one of the conclusions he reached with CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao during their meeting in Beijing in early May was to promote these links.

He said that Shanghai and Taipei are geographically close, and they also have dense populations and close exchanges. There are more than 500,000 Taiwanese businessmen in the greater Shanghai area and they long for the opening of direct transportation as soon as possible, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELIGIOUS EXCHANGES NOT ABOVE THE LAW: MAC

TEXT.P: Those from Taiwan wishing to make religious pilgrimages to China must be aware of the regulations governing cross-strait exchanges and realize that they are not exempt, Taiwan's top mainland China policy planner said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said that religious followers should apply for approval from the government prior to leaving for China via the "mini three links" route for religious activities since currently, ordinary people from Taiwan are not allowed to sail directly across the Strait to the mainland for any purpose.
Wu made the remarks in the eastern city of Ilan, where he was visiting a detention center exclusively for illegal immigrants from China.

Twenty-one Ilan-based fishing boats, each escorting an icon of Matsu -- the Chinese goddess of the sea -- departed from Ilan for the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu Sept. 7 for a worshipers' procession on the sea. The boats instead sailed directly to Meizhou Island of China's Fujian province on the excuse that a typhoon was approaching and to repair "mechanical failures" of their boats.

The fact of the matter was that these fishing boats had planned all along to sail directly to Meizhou and were taking the Matsu icons on a "homecoming" visit, according to Wu. Meizhou is the legendary home of Matsu -- a young girl who sacrificed herself to save the lives of her father and older brothers, who were fishermen, and was later deified -- and thus has been a mecca for Matsu followers for nearly 1,000 years.
The fishing boats are scheduled to return to Ilan on Thursday.

According to Wu, agencies have been collecting evidence regarding the fishing boats and their trip across the Taiwan Strait. It will be decided later whether the fishermen and boat owners will be penalized.

At present, only residents on Taiwan-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu or businesspeople with interests in China can use the direct shipping service between Kinmen/Matsu and China's Xiamen/Mawei, commonly known as the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: Editor's note:In the headline of CEP 20, "Doong" should read "Soong."A corrected version follows. SOONG'S CROSS-STRAIT COMMENTS NOTHING NEW: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's pronouncement on cross-strait affairs - parroting the format used by President Chen Shui-bian in his 2000 inaugural address - is old wine in a new bottle, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

Asked to comment, Wu said this is a familiar refrain from the pro-unificationist Soong and he wouldn't say if the statement would make any difference in the current development of cross-strait relations.

In this way, Shanghai, Taipei and Hong Kong could form a new "golden economic triangle," and that it will later expand to Shenzhen and other cities in the mainland.

Soong said that cross-strait economic exchanges are important, and no one can afford to ignore direct cross-strait links, noting that one of the conclusions he reached with CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao during their meeting in Beijing in early May was to promote these links.
