DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG CANNOT USE 'MINI THREE LINKS' TO RETURN TO TAIWAN: REVIEW PANEL

TEXT.P: A request by opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and his delegation to return to Taiwan proper from China via an outlying island has been denied, a review panel said Thursday.

The review team, comprised of officials from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC). the Ministry of the Interior, and the National Police Administration, as well as national security officers, turned down in a meeting Thursday the request of Soong and his delegation to return to Taiwan proper via the "mini three links" channel, meaning through the outlying islands of Kinmen or Matsu.
Yang Jia-jun, director of the MAC's department of legal affairs, said that Soong's request does not conform to the existing regulations regarding travel from China via the "mini three link" channel.

According to information supplied by Soong and his delegation, none of the members are residents of Kinmen and Matsu, and none of them have special needs, Yang said, adding that the team therefore rejected the request.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu earlier explained that current regulations stipulate that only those who have domiciles registered in Kinmen or Matsu can shuttle between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via the "mini three links."

Only in extraordinary circumstances can any others use the links, such as those with a serious illness or accident victims, during natural disasters or other emergencies or other major accidents, Wu said.
Wu made the remarks while visiting a detention center Thursday for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in Ilan, northern Taiwan, to learn about their situation.

Soong is currently in Shanghai attending a forum jointly organized by the PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) to discuss trade, economic and "three links" issues. He and his delegation are scheduled to return to Taiwan Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATAYAL PEOPLE TOP ALL ABORIGINAL CIVIL SERVANTS IN NUMBER

TEXT.P: Of the roughly 360,000 civil servants in Taiwan, 6,778 are aborigines, with Atayals topping the list of all aborigines serving in public offices, the Ministry of Civil Service reported Thursday.

A total of 1,877 Atayals, originating from the Central Mountain Range -- the geological backbone of Taiwan -- have served as civil servants as of the end of June this year, making them the largest aboriginal group of government employees (excluding teachers and cleaners).

Atayals were followed by the Paiwan people, originating from mountains in southern Taiwan, with 1,535 serving as civil servants, and the Amis, originating from the eastern coastal area of Hualien, with 1,400, officials from the Ministry of Civil Service said.

The 6,778 aboriginal civil servants constituted a mere 1.48 percent of the entire population of Taiwan's indigenous people, numbering roughly 460,000, the officials quoted their latest statistics as indicating.
Of the 6,778 aboriginal government employees, 5,390 or 80 percent were male. Of these aboriginal men, 3,802 worked as policemen.
Of the 6,778 aboriginal government employees, two have doctor's degrees, 48 have master's degrees and 607 are university graduates.

The average age of the aboriginal civil servants was 39 years, compared with the average age of 42 for all the civil servants in Taiwan. The aboriginal civil servants served an average 14 years, compared with 16 years for all the civil servants in the country.
The number of aboriginal government employees accounted for 1.89 percent of all the government employees in Taiwan, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST INTERNATIONAL 'PHYSICS YOUNG AMBASSADORS' STUDY CAMP

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won the right to host a study camp of "physics young ambassadors" from 14 countries as one of the events of World Year of Physics 2005.
The study camp will take place at Tamkang University in Taipei County from Dec. 31-Jan. 4, 2006.

Nine Taiwan students who excelled in the World Year of Physics talent search will join more than 100 other young ambassadors from Argentina, Austria, Cameroon, Croatia, Cyprus, India, Indonesia, Poland, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Korea, Switzerland and the United States.

In addition to exchanging information and ideas, they will compete in various friendly contests in three groups -- primary school, junior high school, and senior high school. Each winner will be awarded a certificate of honor signed by a Nobel laureate in physics.

World Year of Physics 2005 was initiated by the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics to celebrate the pioneering contributions of Albert Einstein, whose three important papers in 1905 have greatly influenced the world. The worldwide endeavor is also intended to call the world's attention to the importance of physics and the role it has played in people's daily lives.
Taiwan's research institutes in physics have participated in the celebrations by holding a series of activities in various cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS OWE NATION AN APOLOGY: DPP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged two opposition heavyweights Thursday to apologize to the public because their China trips earlier this year have been used by Beijing as an excuse to block the United Nations from addressing Taiwan's U.N. bid.

"Former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong owe the public an apology because Beijing officials have used their China trips as justification to dissuade the U.N. General Committee from putting Taiwan's U.N. bid on this year's General Assembly agenda, " said William Lai, a DPP legislative whip.

The U.N. General Committee debated Tuesday whether to include two proposals presented by Taiwan's diplomatic allies regarding Taiwan's representation in the United Nations and U.N. attention to the Taiwan Strait tension. In the debate, China's representative cited Lien's and Soong's separate visits to China between late April and early May to claim that the cross-strait situation is not strained and that the U.N. need not address the two proposals at its ongoing General Assembly plenary session.
Lai said the visits have confused the world about the real cross-strait situation, particularly China's mounting military threat to Taiwan.
Far from helping boost cross-strait peace, Lai claimed that Lien's and Soong's China trips have become a new excuse for China to obstruct Taiwan's U.N. bid.
"They should make a public apology for such a regrettable development," Lai said.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year through its diplomatic allies to have its U.N. membership bid placed on the General Assembly's agenda. However, it has been unsuccessful due to Beijing's obstruction.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, it has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY TO DISCUSS TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: The government would welcome the Taiwan issue to be put on the international stage for discussion because it is a question that deserves attention, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Thursday.
Cho Jung-tai made the remarks after a meeting between Chinese President Hu Jintao and U.S. President George W. Bush on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly in New York Tuesday.

On Hu's expressed hope during the meeting that the U.S. will join China in safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Cho said that Hu's remarks indicate that he is thinking of his own interests, but Taiwan hopes that the U.S. will stand on the side of "justice, peace, democracy and freedom."

Cho also noted that Bush again urged Hu to engage in dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian. Only through dialogue with the duly elected president of Taiwan can regional peace and stability be helped, Cho added.
Meanwhile, an official of the opposition Kuomintang deplored that Taiwan has been further marginalized by the meeting between Hu and Bush.

Chang Jung-kung, vice executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee and director of the party's Department of Chinese Affairs, claimed that the government is incapable and has no intention of breaking the cross-strait stalemate, and that Taiwan's situation will become more deplorable in view of the political transaction between China and the U.S., since the two powers share many interests.

Chang also claimed that Beijing has recently developed a mechanism with the U.S. to prevent Taiwan from moving toward independence and triggering a cross-strait crisis, citing as examples U.S. President George W. Bush's use of an unusually stern warning to Taiwan regarding its referendum plan during talks with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao at the White House in December 2003, as well as China's enactment of its Anti-Session Law early this year.

Chang said that although Bush was "unprepared" and did not answer specifically in response to Hu's hope that the U.S. will join China in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait, the U.S. "could not possibly" turn down a request from China to discuss the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN U.N. BID STRATEGY DRAWS INTERNATIONAL ATTENTION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's new strategy adopted in this year's bid to enter the United Nations has drawn more international attention and discussions than before.

Although Taiwan failed for the 13th straight year in its bid to have its U.N. membership discussed as a result of Beijing's obstruction, this year's new approach of presenting two proposals at the U.N. General Committee during an agenda screening process proved to be a more stimulating strategy in calling for world attention to Taiwan's resolve to pursue peace and to security concerns in the Taiwan Strait, he claimed.
It was the first time since 1993 that Taiwan had brought a second proposal to the U.N. -- calling for the U.N. to play a pro-active role in maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait.
The first proposal was very similar to those put forward in the past -- urging the U.N. General Assembly to ensure the representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan in the world body.
Chen made the remarks during a cocktail party held in Taipei to mark the 184th anniversary of Central American Independence.

The president offered his sincerest gratitude to the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America for their long-term support for Taiwan and he also called for all the allies in that part of the world to continue supporting Taiwan in a common ideal of a "world democratic community."

Chen also told those at the party that he will attend in person the fifth leadership summit of Taiwan, Central American countries and the Dominican Republic scheduled to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25.

Chen said that during that 12-day trip, his fifth to Central America, he will also visit four other allies -- Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Saint Christopher and Nevis, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: FINANCIAL REFORMS WILL CONTINUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the second phase of the government's financial reform plan will continue, despite temporary setbacks.

He said the government will not flinch in its efforts to halve the number of state-owned banks to six through mergers by the end of this year, although he admitted that the state-run Taiwan Business Bank has experienced some difficulties in finding a bidder.
The president was referring to the failure of the Ministry of Finance to select a satisfactory top bidder for Taiwan Business Bank in an auction process set for the weekend.

The bank is the fourth state-owned bank on the list to be auctioned off. Three others have been merged with private banks in an attempt to raise their competitiveness. A four-day strike by thousands of bank employees against the merger is believed to be the main factor behind the failure.
Chen said the government's experience in the first phase of the reform plan -- liberalization of the financial market -- is proof that financial reform is the correct path for Taiwan.
He added that the sooner the goal is achieved, the smaller the price the country will have to pay.
Noting that even China is reforming its state-run banks, Chen said Taiwan should waste no time in carrying out the second phase of financial reforms.

More than 90 opposition legislators have sponsored a motion calling on the Ministry of Finance to halt the auction, but ministry officials have indicated that the plan is unlikely to be stopped at this stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TRAVEL BUDGET APPROPRIATED IN LINE WITH LAW: CABINET

TEXT.P: Budgets for all government officials' overseas trips have been planned in exact accordance with the regulations, including transport and daily living expenses, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.

Cho was responding to a claim by opposition lawmakers that government agencies have set aside too much money in the 2006 budget plan to finance what they described as officials' "lavish overseas trips."

"The accusation is unfair and incorrect. All the appropriations for overseas visits by public functionaries for official purposes have been budgeted strictly in accordance with relevant regulations," Cho said.
According to Cho, the regulations set clear provisions regarding government employees' overseas travel expenses.
"We have unified payment standards regarding transport, accommodation and living expenses," Cho added.

On the opposition allegation that the Ministry of Finance is most extravagant in overseas travel spending, Cho said the planned trips by Finance Ministry officials to the United States and Europe next year as listed in the government's 2006 budget bill are aimed at attracting foreign financial institutions to invest in Taiwan.
"The budget listed in the bill includes money needed for renting large conference rooms and equipment for presentations, as well as transport and living costs," Cho explained.
As to the Government Information Office's travel budget, Cho said the appropriations will finance official visits to France and Italy to attend the world famous Cannes and Venice film festivals.

Cho also explained why the Ministry of Justice has not stated the destination where local prosecutors will visit next year to take part in an international prosecutors conference. The annual meeting is held in a different country each year and the destination for the 2006 meeting has yet to be announced, he pointed out.

Touching on a Ministry of Economic Affairs plan to send officials to visit China next year to look into its intellectual property rights (IPR) protection system, Cho said four ministry officials are scheduled to travel to China in two groups to attend IPR seminars to be co-organized by Taiwan and Chinese industrial associations.

"Given the ever-closing trade and economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, it is necessary for the Economics Ministry to gain a better understanding of China's IPR protection system and its administrative measures in the event of IPR infringements or commercial piracy," Cho added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA INVITING U.S. TO SAFEGUARD STABILITY `RIDICULOUSLY FUNNY': DPP

TEXT.P: It is "ridiculously funny" that Chinese President Hu Jintao asked the United States to join China in safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, ruling Democratic Progressive (DPP) Party Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said Thursday.

Hu was quoted as having said to U.S. President George W. Bush during ameeting in New York Tuesday that "proper handling" of the issue of Taiwan is crucial to the future of Sino-U.S. relations, adding that "I hope that the United States will join the Chinese side in safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and opposing so-called Taiwan independence."
Hu's invitation to Bush to jointly safeguard cross-strait peace and stability is tantamount to a bandit inviting a police officer to jointly maintain public order, Lee ridiculed.
Calling China a "predator" rather than a "victim, " Lee pointed out that China is the major threat to peace and stability, not only across the Taiwan Strait, but also in East Asia.

Hu's remarks to Bush were meant to make China seem like a "victim" -- an attempt aimed at misleading international opinion and making Taiwan a culprit responsible for cross-strait uncertainties, Lee added.

He quoted U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld as having said recently that although no countries in the world pose any threat to China, the country has constantly bolstered its military build-up. Thus, Lee said, the source of threats to the security of the Asian-Pacific region is China and its intention of building itself into a new military hegemony in the region.

Lee said it is an easy task for both sides to defuse the cross-strait tension so long as China dismantles its 700-strong missiles targeting Taiwan, stops military expansion that is threatening neighboring countries, and reduces its annual defense budget, which he said is the largest of its kind anywhere in the world.

He called for China to resume dialogue with Taiwan and sign a peace accord under an international framework of reconciliation. If were to happen, he added, it would be unnecessary for Hu to invite the U.S. to jointly safeguard cross-strait peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO HAVE REGULAR MEETINGS WITH SMALL BUSINESS REPRESENTATIVES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh and senior economics and finance officials will join representatives of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized businesses for regular meetings from Sept. 19, National Association of Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises Chairman Day Sheng-tong said Thursday.

Day, who is also an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, said the meetings "over afternoon tea" with the premier once every three months will provide an opportunity for business and industry leaders to let government officials understand their needs through face-to-face discussion.
He pointed out that Taiwan has 1.17 million small- and medium-sized enterprises, accounting for 98 percent of Taiwan's businesses. Together they provide 7.5 million jobs.

The meetings will be sponsored jointly by the National Association of Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises and the Taiwan Federation of Industry (TFI) in an attempt to set up a mechanism for communication with the government and create a favorable environment for the development of such businesses, according to a spokesman for the TFI.

In addition to the premier, government officials expected to attend the meetings will include Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh, Finance Minister Lin Chuan, Council of Labor Affairs head Lee Ying-yuan and Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan. By Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK RAISES KEY RATES TO FEND OFF INFLATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) raised its key interest rates by 0.125 percentage points Thursday with a view to fending off inflation.
From Friday, the discount rate will be raised to 2.125 percent from the current 2 percent, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan announced after a bank board meeting.
At the same time, the accommodations with collateral rate will rise to 2.50 percent from 2.375 percent, while the accommodations without collateral rate will rise to 4.375 percent from 4.25 percent.

Noting that the central bank's main mission is to maintain stability in consumer prices and to drive the economy towards growth, Perng said the CBC must adjust its key lending rates in a gradual manner.

It will be the third CBC key rates hike so far this year and the fifth round of hikes since September 2004, bringing the cumulative increase in CBC key lending rates since September 2004 to 0.75 percentage points.
The mild increase in interest rates this time is expected to lead to only limited rises in corporate funding costs, Perng said.
"These rate hikes should not affect domestic economic growth as there are sufficient bank funds to meet demand from enterprises, " he said.
Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, echoed Perng's view, saying that the moderate hikes can help minimize the impact on the domestic economic growth.

According to Hu, the domestic inflation rate is not very serious. The consumer price index, the key gauge of inflation, registered an annual growth rate of 3.56 percent in August, Hu said, adding that this mainly resulted from rises in vegetable and fruit prices due to typhoon damage.
Stressing that the average increase in prices of core commodities was only about 0.7 percent, Hu said inflationary pressure has been kept at bay.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REJECTS 'APOLOGY' AS CONDITION FOR ADDRESSING LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday it is "irrational" for opposition lawmakers to ask him to apologize for alleged Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction scandals as a condition for him to deliver an administrative report.
Hsieh made the remarks while attending an evening party in the central county of Taichung to celebrate the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's upcoming founding anniversary.

"Addressing the legislature on the government's policy goals and work plans is the premier's official duty and his obligation to the public set forth in the Constitution. This sacred mission cannot be traded off and no political strings should be attached to it, " Hsieh said.

Hsieh was originally scheduled to address the Legislative Yuan's opening session Tuesday and then field questions from lawmakers of all political stripes. However, lawmakers from the main opposition Kuomintang occupied the podium at the legislature for the entire session to prevent Premier Frank Hsieh from delivering an administrative report. They demanded that Hsieh take a leave of absence as they claimed Hsieh was responsible for the Kaohsiung MRT construction scandals. Hsieh was Kaohsiung mayor for six years until February, when he became premier.
Because of KMT lawmakers' boycott, Hsieh and his entire Cabinet ended up sitting all day in the legislature watching the "circus."
It remains unclear whether the KMT lawmakers will continue to block Hsieh from delivering his administrative report during the legislative plenary session Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Sept. 16, or the 13th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: A group of Puritan separatists sets sail from Southampton, England, in the Mayflower, bound for what would become Plymouth, Mass., and religious freedom.
1733: The Ching court begins to implement the "Tithing System" in Taiwan. The system, devised by Prime Minister Wang An-shih (1021-1086) of the Sung dynasty, was aimed at maintaining internal security and strengthening national defense.
1869: The Suez Canal, a narrow, artificial waterway in Egypt that joins the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, is opened. The construction of the canal began on April 25, 1859.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's former prime minister, is born. He masterminded Singapore's transformation from a colonial outpost into a booming industrial metropolis.
1927: The Kuomintang Central Special Committee is established after Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, resigned on Aug. 13 in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking, Hankow and Shanghai factions of the Kuomintang.
1936: The Guangxi problem is amicably settled after rebels set up an independent regime in Guilin on Aug. 19. Li Tsung-jen assumes office as commander of Guangxi Pacification Headquarters.
1940: President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the Selective Service Bill which made all U.S. male citizens between the age of 21 and 35 eligible to be called for military service.
1945: The last remnants of the Japanese army in Hong Kong surrender to the British under Admiral Harcourt.
1951: The United Daily News, formed by a merger of three dailies in Taipei, is inaugurated.
1953: The 8th session of the U.N. General Assembly rejects a Soviet proposal to seat the Communitst Chinese in the United Nations.
1957: Chi Pai-shih, noted Chinese painter, dies in Beijing at the age of 97.
1959: Charles de Gaulle, French President of the new Fifth Republic and former head of the committee of National Liberation in Algiers, offers Algeria a referendum on independence.
1963: Malaysia becomes independent with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first prime minister, and a mob of more than 100,000 people burn down the British Embassy in celebration.
1967: The Central Personnel Administration is established under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1970: Pope Paul VI, who created much controversy with a 1968 encyclical that continued church teachings prohibiting birth control, disbands the armed forces of the Vatican. The Pope was also noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1974: The ROC and Nicaragua agree to step up cooperation in trade, industry and agriculture. The agreement is reached at a meeting of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, president-elect of Nicaragua, and the ROC's Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang.
1975: A coal mining accident at Shuanghsi Village in Taipei County claims 25 lives.
1975: Papua New Guinea gains independence from Australia.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a two-year extension of the fishery technology cooperation agreement with Panama.
1986: The ROC Ministries of Finance and Economic Affairs decide to revise tariffs on roughly 1,800 items.
1987: Seventy countries sign an agreement in Montreal to curb the use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), which threaten the ozone layer. The use of CFCs, a compound used in aerosols and as a refrigerant, was to be frozen at then-current levels and reduced by half within 12 years.
1987: KMT Chairman Chiang Ching-kuo proposes at the party's Central Standing Committee meeting that a task force of five be formed to study the possibility of allowing Taiwan residents to visit relatives on mainland China.
1991: Liberals score a resounding victory in the first direct elections to Hong Kong's legislature. They say their triumph sends a clear message to Beijing that the people want more democracy.
1999: The ROC naval destroyer Anyang is formally decommissioned after completing 32 years of service and more than 500 battle and training missions.
2000: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that the nation has been "on the decline" over the past several months because the ruling Democratic Progesssive Party has been unable to master essential administrative approaches.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung invites senior financial and economics officials to a meeting to discuss the possible impact on the Taiwan economy of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
2004: Former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Donald W. Keyser was charged in Alexandria, Virginia with passing U.S. government documents to a Taiwan official posted to Washington and hiding a visit to Taiwan in 2003.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How wonderful and great the divine moral law in man is! All the institutions of human society and civilization -- laws, customs, and usages -- have their origin there."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE PASSES RESOLUTION WELCOMING PRESIDENT CHEN'S STOPOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C. Sept. 15 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution Thursday welcoming President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan to the United States for a transit stop ahead of his visit to the island's diplomatic allies in Central America.

The resolution, which was jointly introduced Sept. 8 by four co-chairmen of the Taiwan Caucus in the House of Representatives, including Reps. Steve Chabot, Sherrod Brown, Dana Rohrabacher and Robert Wexler, was first adopted by the House's Committee on International Relations earlier in the day.

Besides offering its "warmest welcome" to President Chen Shui-bian upon his visit to the United States, the House of Representatives also recognizes in the resolution that the president's upcoming visit is "a significant stop toward broadening and deepening the friendship and cooperation between the United States and Taiwan."

The House also recognizes in the resolution the president's commitment and efforts to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait as well as thanks the Taiwan government and its people for their contribution to relief efforts in the devastated areas stricken by Hurricane Katrina.
Furthermore, it also asks President Chen to convey the U.S. Congress and the American people's support to the people of Taiwan.
The House also congratulates the president on receiving the Human Rights Award from the Congressional Human Rights Caucus.
It is expected that Chen will receive the award during his transit stop in Miami next week.

According to Taiwan's Representative Office in the United States, the passage of the resolution not only reiterates the U.S. Congress' support and friendship for Taiwan, it also demonstrates its respect for President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen is scheduled to make a transit stop in Miami en route to Central America next week and a stopover in San Francisco on his way back to Taiwan. The main purpose of the president's upcoming trip is to attend the fifth ROC-Central American Summit slated to be held in Nicaragua at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: STALLED ARMS BILL A MATTER OF CONCERN TO U.S.: STATE DEP'T ADVISER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, D.C. Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior adviser to the U.S. State Department's Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs recently reiterated Washington's serious concern over the long-stalled arms procurement bill in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan and the minimal increase in the island's defense budget over the past few years.
James Keyth made the reiteration after attending a hearing held by the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission under the U.S. Congress Wednesday.
Talking about issues related to Taiwan's arms procurement bill, the adviser said that the island should take actions to deal with the bill as soon as possible.

Keyth noted that the United States is growing increasingly concerned about Taiwan's insufficient investment in the purchase of advanced military equipment, including weapons and command-and-monitoring systems, which he said will affect the island's defensive and deterrence capabilities.

According to Keyth, Taiwan's spending on national defense has only increased slightly over the past few years, while spending on the economy and social welfare has registered double-digit growth during the same period.

Meanwhile, on former President Lee Teng-hui's reported upcoming visit to the United States, Keyth defined it as a private visit, pointing out that anything Lee might say while in the United States will represent his own opinion and not the policy of the government of Taiwan.

Asked whether U.S. lawmakers can present the Congressional Human Rights Award to President Chen Shui-bian in a public ceremony during his scheduled upcoming transit stop in Miami, Keyth said that there are norms and rules to regulate Taiwan leader's transit stops in the United States and that these rules remain unchanged.

Chen is set to make a stopover in Miami next week ahead of his visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America. While in the city, Chen will receive the human rights award from the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus.

Commenting on the lack of dialogue between the governments of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Keyth said that U.S. President George W. Bush had expressed the hope during his recent meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in New York that Beijing would engage in dialogue with the Taiwan government.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIWAN-JAPAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Despite the absence of formal diplomastic relations, Japan and Taiwan have maintained ever-increasing political and economic ties through close science and technology exchanges, Japan's top liaison officer in Taiwan said Friday.

Tadashi Ikeda, representative of the Interchange Association Taipei Office, said that it is important for the two countries to reinforce each other with knowledge to boost their creativity and international competitiveness.

Ikeda borrowed the 3R (reduce, reuse, recycle) concept that Japan advocated during the G8 Summit in Scotland in July in addressing the opening of the 2005 Taiwan-Japan Science and Technology Forum, whose theme is environmental protection technology and green products. The opening was held at the Grand Hyatt in Taipei.
Ikeda expressed the hope that the 3R concept will be discussed at the forum and consequently help boost exchanges between Japan and Taiwan in both the science and technology and business sectors.

He said that Taiwan and Japan share many similarities, including that both lack natural resources and both are prominent economic powers as a result of their high-caliber workforces, excellent economic planning and government support, and the research and hard work of their academic institutions and official agencies.
Taiwan, in particular, is indispensable for Japan in terms of strengthening bilateral exchanges because of its strong and immense technological prowess and market demand, Ikeda added.

Vincent Siew, former Republic of China premier and current chairman of the Taiwan-Japan Science and Technology Interchange Committee, which is sponsoring the forum, said that the gathering will contribute to a further understanding of related policies and strategies.

Siew said he hopes that through such science and technology forums, waste resulting from duplicate research will be reduced, and the two countries will sharpen their international competitiveness and achieve high economic growth rates, producing a "win win" result.

The 2005 Taiwan-Japan Science and Technology Forum, the third of its kind since 2003, has brought together some 400 leaders from the research, corporate and public-policy fields from the two countries to exchange views on environmental protection efforts and related policies and products.

Prominent figures scheduled to make keynote speeches at the forum include Kenichi Mizuno, a veteran Liberal Democratic Party legislator recently re-elected for a fourth straight term, who will speak on Japan's environmental protection policies; and Akio Morishima, chairman of the Institute for Global Environmental Strategies in Japan, who will speak on how to build up the environmental protection industry and businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S RISE HAS NEGATIVE IMPACT ON ASIAN DEMOCRATIZATION: KAU

TEXT.P: The rise of China as a big power has been more negative than positive in terms of its impact on the democratization of Asia, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Friday.

Kau was addressing the topic of the impact of a rising China on democratization in Asia in a meeting of the World Forum for Democratization in Asia (WFDA) on the second day of the three-day forum at the Taipei International Convention Center. The forum is being sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD).

Kau noted that the international community has centered its attention on the economic expansion and military modernization of China, but it has ignored the impact of a rising China on such universal values as democracy and human rights.
It is hoped that the forum will provide a more balanced discussion and examination of the topic, Kau said.

Parris Chang, vice secretary-general of the National Security Council, noted that China began to move toward economic opening in the 1980s but that it has maintained a tight control politically, which he said is "not correct and deplorable."
He pointed out that a rising China will have a negative impact on the democratization of Asia as its political and economic strength will affect neighboring countries.

In addition, China has supported many undemocratic regimes such as Myammar and Cambodia, Chang said, adding that the international community should not only look at China's economic and military strength, but should also think seriously about a strategy to promote democratization in those non-democratic countries.

Speaking on the same occasion, David S. Hong, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that although China has achieved stunning economic growth, it has many hidden problems, adding that "a short-term brilliant performance will not solve long-term problems, " including a widening gap between rich and poor and between urban and rural communities, as well as a worsening environment.
Even if social and political structures are undergoing changes, they have not helped expedite democratic progress, Hong said.

Herman Kraft, a researcher at the Institute of Strategic and Development Studies of the Philippines, said that Taiwan will bear the brunt of a rising China and that the island should realize that disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strati could spill over to other countries in East Asia.

Kraft noted that many newly democratic countries in Asia have a fragile democratic basis and that the military buildup between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could easily affect the democratic progress of these countries.
Srikanth Kondapalli, a research fellow at the Institute for Defence Studies & Analyses in India, said that rapid economic growth in China has produced a powerful magnetic effect in the region.

China's military modernization also threatens Japan and Taiwan, and it has indirectly impacted the regional balance of power and multilateral foreign policy, leading the countries in the region to rely too heavily on China and to have their democratic development influenced by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC PLAY LEADING ROLE IN TAIWAN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Friday that "the people of Taiwan, rather than the president" play the leading role in a new book published by the Presidential Office that recounts major domestic and diplomatic events over the past two years.
The book, titled "Maritime, Progressing Taiwan" is the second book with photos and caption literature recording Chen's work published in the last two years. The first was published in August 2003.

According to Chen in a ceremony held at his office to mark the launch of the book, the people recorded in the book are "ordinary" people. They are, however, representative of Taiwan, a country of hard-working people with strong, die-hard vitality.

Chen said that he has traveled to 319 cities and rural townships around the country over the past five years, including remote areas such as the Tungsha (Pratas) islands, the island of Pengchiayu and the frontline island of Matsu, to listen to the voices from the grassroots.

Currently, Chen said, his greatest wish in similar efforts is to visit Taiping island, the largest coral reef in the Nansha (Spratly) island archipelago in the South China Sea, located about 1,600 km from Taiwan and the southernmost tip of Republic of China territory.

Prominent photos contained in the book feature: Chen attending Pope John Paul II's memorial service in the Vatican; Chen playing soccer in the Republic of China diplomatic ally of Belize; Chen visiting the Tungsha islands to inspect a coral conservation effort; Chen collecting empty bottles and cans as an environmental protection volunteer; and members of the first family taking part in the March 26, 2005 rally opposing Beijing's passage of its Anti-Secession Law codifying China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks Taiwan is seeking formal independence.
Meanwhile, the Presidential Office also launched Friday another book recounting Chen's overseas trips, the sixth of its kind published since 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. TIES IN GOOD SHAPE: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States are in good shape because the two countries share strategic interests, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Friday.

Kau was responding to a press inquiry about his view on Chinese President Hu Jintao's latest proposal that the United States join China in safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait. Hu came up with the proposal during a meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush on the sidelines of the U.N. General Assembly in New York Tuesday.
"Hu's proposal was obviously an international 'united front' trick, " Kau said, adding that he does not think the United States will be duped into cooperating with China at Taiwan's expense.

In his view, Kau said, China came up with the proposal partly because the United States and Japan for the first time publicly announced in February that "maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait" is one of their common strategic objectives.

"As a big power, China is certainly a target that the United States would woo to be a cooperative partner. Nevertheless, I don't think that the United States would likely sacrifice Taiwan's interests simply to cooperate with China," Kau said.

He acknowledged that Taiwan and the United States have had rifts at times, but once the controversies were over, their common strategic interests remained consistent. At the moment, Kau said, Taiwan-U.S. relations are steady and smooth.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DENIES REPORTS ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) denied Friday reports that negotiations on charter cargo and passenger flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have come to fruition.
The reports are untrue, the MAC said in a press release.

According to the reports, Michael Lo, former head of the Taipei Airline Association (TAA) , traveled to Hong Kong several times to negotiate with Chinese representatives on the charter cargo and passenger flights, and that the government will soon announce their launch.
Cross-strait charter cargo flights will be launched first and three months later, the charter passenger flights will start, the reports claimed.

The MAC reaffirmed that it has commissioned the TAA to help the communications between the two sides on the matter and has taken into consideration China's stance, as well as the positive exchanges between the two sides.

Since the announcement by Premier Frank Hsieh Aug. 3 that discussions on both charter cargo and passenger flights can be conducted simultaneously, Taiwan has been communicating with China, the press release said.
The MAC stressed that if there are any substantive results from bilateral talks, it will inform the public immediately and it urged the media not to print mere speculation as real news.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT REJECTS KMT-PFP APPEAL TO NULLIFY 2004 ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court of Taiwan rejected Friday an appeal by the two main opposition parties -- the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- seeking to have the 2004 presidential election declared null and void on the grounds of suspected fraud and deceit.
President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party won the election March 20 last year by a slight margin.

The KMT and the PFP, known as the "pan-blue alliance," claimed that the election was affected by many dubious factors, including unclear motives behind the shooting that wounded Chen and Lu on the eve of the election and possible interference by a referendum held alongside the election.

The case was one of two lawsuits filed by former KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong in an attempt to reverse the election results. The other suit seeking a court ruling to declare Chen's election invalid was rejected by the Supreme Court June 17. Both cases are now closed, as the rulings are final.
The Supreme Court is expected to give a detailed explanation of why it rejected the appeal at a press conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: MPA APPRECIATES TAIWAN'S HELP IN ROOTING OUT PIRACY

TEXT.P: The Los Angeles-based Motion Picture Association (MPA) offered its appreciation Friday to the Taiwan authorities for their help in cracking down on movie piracy in Taiwan.

At a press conference held jointly with Taiwan's private Foundation for the Protection of Film and Video Works (FVWP) in Taipei, Frank Rittman, vice president of the MPA Asia-Pacific operations based in Singapore, said the MPA appreciates Taiwan's assistance and support for anti-piracy enforcement initiatives aimed at reducing movie piracy in Taiwan.
However, he pointed out that it is worthy of close attention that an increasing number of people and companies in Taiwan have burned pirated movies onto optical discs with CD-R or DVD-R burners.

Burner labs can contain dozens of burners capable of producing millions of pirated CD-Rs or DVD-Rs per year, Rittman said, adding that in 2004, 1,755 optical disc burners were seized in FVWP/MPA operations in Taiwan, representing 56 percent of total MPA seizures in the Asia-Pacific region.
Rittman did not elaborate on development of FVWP/MPA operations in China, considered a haven for piracy of all intellectual property goods.

At the press conference, FVWP and MPA officials released updated results of anti-piracy enforcement operations coordinated with the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of Economic Affairs targeting video rental shops in Taiwan that illegally manufacture and rent pirated movies.

The operations, which began Jan. 4, comprised 818 shop inspections and 34 raids and have netted seizures of 243,475 pirated CD-Rs and DVD-Rs, 127 optical disc burners and have resulted in the arrest of 48 people, according to MPA officials.
The program builds upon recent undertakings by Taiwan's Government Information Office and the Intellectual Property Office to ensure that shops in Taiwan are not engaged in piracy.

Since last December, the Intellectual Property Office has urged rental shop owners to respect copyrights and refrain from selling or renting pirated copies, said Hank Kuo, executive director of the FVWP.
He reiterated that anti-piracy operations will go on relentlessly.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER VISITS VOCATIONAL TRAINING CENTER IN L.A.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Sept. 15 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Interior Minister Chang Wen-ying visited the Lincoln Training Center in Los Angeles for the mentally and physically challenged Thursday in an effort to learn from the facility about ways to equip disabled people with vocational skills.

Chang was on a transit stop on her way home after concluding a visit to Panama Sept. 9-13 where she attended a Latin American conference on human rights for the mentally and physically challenged on behalf of first lady Wu Shu-jen.

Taiwan has spared no efforts to take care of the mentally and physically challenged in recent years, she said. There is an official fund in Taiwan used to finance vocational training for such people, and that the funds mainly come from local government agencies or private companies which fail to hire so many mentally and physically challenged people as the law demands, Chang indicated.

The non-profit Lincoln Training Center, located in El Monte City in suburban Los Angeles, was founded by a group of family members of challenged people some 10 years ago. Thanks to efficient management, it trained over 400 mentally and physically challenged people each year.
Chang is scheduled to return to Taipei Sept. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 35 points to close at 6,045, with 25,257 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 47 points to end at 6,040, with 7,229 contracts traded, while December futures lost 50 points to finish at 6,040, with 18 contracts traded. March futures moved down 59 points to close at 6,030, with three contracts traded, while June futures moved down 62 points to close at 6,012, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,080 for September, 6,087 for October, 6,090 for December, 6,089 for March and 6,074 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures moved down 2.35 points to close at 250.05, with 4,042 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 2.4 points to finish at 249.7, with 1,129 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 6.7 points to end at 248.55, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.
September TF futures lost two points to finish at 923, with 2,117 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down four points to end at 918.8, with 1,300 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN YOUTH FORUM KICKS OFF IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The third Taiwan-Japanese Kansai Youth Forum, organized by the Republic of China's liaison office in Osaka, kicked off Friday in the port city of Kobe.
The forum serves as a platform for exchanges between Taiwanese and Japanese young people, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Osaka.

Ten Taiwanese studying in colleges or universities in Kansai on western Japan, as well as nine Japanese college students from the region, attended the two-day forum to discuss issues on youth exchanges between Taiwan and Japan. They also planned to issue reports on their research in the political, economic, social, educational and cultural development of the two countries.

Wu Chia-hsiung, head of the Osaka TECO, said in his opening address at the event that he expects expanded exchanges between Japanese and Taiwanese youths, describing such exchanges as one of the best ways to boost friendly relations between the two counties in the absence of diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT BLAME EACH OTHER FOR KAOHSIUNG MRT SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) continued to trade accusations Friday over the scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway construction project exposed by the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers.

The Legislative Yuan spent another unproductive day, with its scheduled proceedings blocked as members of the legislative caucuses of both parties took turn at the rostrum to blame each other for the scandal, which has dented Taiwan's global image as a democracy that respects human rights.

KMT legislators demanded an apology from Premier Frank Hsieh for allegedly lying when he produced a document during a call-in TV program and claimed that it was former Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih -- now a KMT legislator -- who decided to adopt the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model for the Kaohsiung rapid transit system project. The claim was later rebutted by Wu, who produced a document of his own that was purported to show that it was Hsieh himself who recommended that government investment be handled by the private sector. Hsieh was Wu's successor as Kaohsiung mayor before he assumed the post of premier.

The KMT legislators also said they wanted to set up five commissions with authorized access to all documents related to the construction projects of both the Kaohsiung rapid transit system and Taiwan's high-speed railway, the second phase of the government's financial reform plan, an insider trading scandal involving a top official charged with preventing insider trading in the stock market, and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom that deliberately violated a resolution passed by the previous legislature calling on the government to halt the move.

Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, insisted at a news conference that it was Wu who set the tone in a document one day before the mayoral election allowing government investment to be utilized by the private sector, and that as Kaohsiung mayor, Hsieh was merely carrying out the plan under a KMT-controlled Cabinet.

On a separate occasion, Wu claimed that the BOT model for the Kaohsiung rapid transit system was "merely a general direction" set by the government at the time, but was carried out during Hsieh's term as Kaohsiung mayor.
Wu further claimed that it would be "slander" to say that he was the decision maker for the BOT project.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO BRIEF 'TAISHANG' ON CHINA POLICY UPDATES: SEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will brief Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as taishang, on progress in the government's China policy initiatives during a Mid-Autumn Festival gathering, an official said Friday.

Hsieh may also announce new mainland policy initiatives on the occasion, You Ying-lung, secretary-general of the quasi-official Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) , said. According to You, the SEF will join forces with the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports and the National Federation of Industries in organizing a package of activities Sept. 20-21 for taishang who have returned to Taiwan for the festival.
Mid-Autumn Festival, one of the principal holidays of the lunar year, falls on Sept. 18 this year.

Among the activities will be a dinner to be organized by the SEF Sept. 21, You said, adding that Hsieh and MAC Chairman Joseph Wu will attend to brief the taishang on the latest progress in the three major China policy initiatives announced by Hsieh during a similar gathering earlier this year in celebration of Dragon Boat Festival.

The three policy initiatives referred to the opening of direct charter cargo and passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait, the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, and Taiwan's farm produce exports to China, You said.
As to whether the premier is likely to take the opportunity to announce any new China policy initiatives, You said he would not rule out that possibility.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. It is under the MAC's supervision.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG AQUACULTURAL OPERATORS TO FOLLOW STRICT TEST PROCEDURE
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Pingtung county government has told aquaculturists raising groupers to follow the same strict test procedures for exports when selling them locally after groupers raised in several ponds were found to contain what might be a carcinogen.

Huang Cheng-lung, head of the bureau of agriculture, made the announcement after the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced the previous day the results of tests on locally produced groupers. Out of 36 samples collected from 13 aquaculture ponds in the counties of Tainan and Pingtung, 14 were found to contain malachite green, a synthetic dye used to color silk, wool and leather. It is also an effective medication for the control of various external parasites of freshwater and marine fish. In animal tests, it has been shown to be harmful to the liver.
Although it has not been confirmed as carcinogenic, the United States, the European Union, Canada, Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan have banned its use either in raising or in the delivery process.
The COA suspended sales of groupers from the aquaculturists who failed the tests and imposed fines of between NT$6,000 (US$185) and NT$30,000.
Groupers in nine aquaculture ponds in Pingtung contained malachite green, although one of the operators denied using it.
Huang said that operators found to have used the chemical will be stopped from selling them and be put on a tracking system until they can improve and pass the test.

Hong Kong first blew the whistle when it reported that it had found a carcinogen in a sample exported from Taiwan in late August, but the Taiwan authorities denied at the time that there was a problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION AGAIN TURNS LEGISLATURE INTO FARCE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh was again kept from delivering his administrative report at the Legislative Yuan Friday because of obstruction by opposition lawmakers.
The legislative caucus of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the largest opposition party, said it would allow the premier to make his report only if two conditions were met.

The first was that the premier must first apologize for the controversial mass rapid transit (MRT) system in Kaohsiung, construction on which was launched when he was still the mayor of the southern port city. The issue of the Kaohsiung MRT system was thrust into the spotlight after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the construction of the system.

The second was for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to consent to the formation of five committees to look into five controversial issues: the one-year delay in the opening of the high-speed rail, allegations of corruption in the Kaohsiung MRT construction project, allegations of insider trading on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the second phase of the government's financial reform plan, and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom.

The DPP responded by saying that there would be no horse trading and emphasized that the premier must be allowed to speak first and discussions on forming committees could come later. Whether the premier will apologize for anything would be another matter, the DPP caucus said.

Opposition lawmakers unfurled banners in front of the speaker's podium after the session reopened in the afternoon Friday demanding that the premier apologize for the Kaohsiung MRT controversy. Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng pleaded with the legislators in vain to return to their seats to prepare for the convening of the session. Wang had to call for a recess.
Opposition lawmakers from the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), continued to occupy the podium and hoisted placards, blocking the proceedings.

DPP legislators remained in their seats, holding placards that read: "convene, " and banged on their desks demanding that proceeding begin. Lawmakers from the Taiwan Solidarity Union held posters proclaiming: "real boycott and fake investigation" and wandered around the hall, as the legislature took on the air of a misbehaved group of kindergartners.
Speaker Wang had to announce that the legislative session would resume next Tuesday, adding that he will try to mediate among political parties next Monday to get the legislature moving.

Some opposition lawmakers were apparently ready to forgo having the premier apologize, to which the DPP said, in a tit for tat move, that the premier should be allowed to speak and then the ruling party would form three committees to look into past corruption cases - presumably by the KMT - involving polluting the nation and misused land. The idea was rejected by the opposition.

The scene was similar to Tuesday's opening day of the new session where the only thing accomplished was yelling, grandstanding and legislators throwing things at each other. The premier was also blocked from speaking that day.

The premier urged Cabinet members to use the time that the opposition is obstructing the legislature productively, such as reading official documents or holding small coordination meetings. Premier Hsieh said that the day "was not too bad" for him.
Hsieh said that he used the time to meet with 16 Cabinet members and decided on a number of things. He also said that these sorts of antics could drag on and that he'd just have to get used to it.

However, the premier had earlier said sternly that the KMT and the PFP, which hold a slim majority in the legislature, shouldn't stop legislative proceedings, saying that doing so will paralyze the administration and is against the principles of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES BUSH'S CALL FOR DIALOGUE BETWEEN HU, ROC GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council welcomes U.S. President George W. Bush's call for dialogue between Chinese President Hu Jintao and the Republic of China on Taiwan's duly elected government during his meeting with Hu in New York on Sept. 13, a council spokesman said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said the council was happy to hear Bush mention the Taiwan issue in his meeting with Hu.

You said, "The U.S. government has pointed out the right direction, " meaning that Chinese authorities should not refuse to engage in dialogue with the ROC's ruling party and its duly elected government, while talking only with its opposition parties; they should not avoid contacting the ROC government.
Eventually, the governments on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will have to deal with relevant issues, You said, adding it is the only way for the two sides to really resolve problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-CANADIANS TO PROTEST CHINESE LEADER'S VISIT TO VANCOUVER

TEXT.P: Overseas Taiwanese community leaders in Vancouver said Thursday they will protest against China during Chinese President Hu Jintao's forthcoming visit to the city Saturday.
The leaders from 24 Taiwanese groups in Vancouver said at a news conference that the theme of their protest will be "Anti-aggression, anti-nuclear, anti-hegemony, and the protection of Taiwan."
Hu is expected to arrived in Vancouver on Friday, and will attend a state banquet given in his honor by Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin at the Westin Bayshore Hotel.
The leaders said they will mobilize hundreds of their members to protest outside the venue of the state banquet, which will cap the state visit by Hu.
They also urged Canada not to be silent on China's poor human rights and democracy records simply because of Canada's attempts to tap the Chinese market.

Tsai Fei-chu, the chairwoman of the Taiwanese Associations in Vancouver, said at the news conference that China, instead of using its growing national strength to improve its people's living standard, has actively sought the annexation of Taiwan and thereby poses a threat to world peace and security.
Tsai claimed an independent Taiwan would prod China to move on the path towards democracy rather than pose a threat to China.

Hsu Chian-li, chairman of the Taiwanese-Canadian Cultural Society, said at the news conference that they organized the protest not only because of their love for Taiwan but also for the benefit of Canada, adding that Canada's interests could hardly remain intact if China attacked Taiwan.

Hsu said China has taken pains to prevent Taiwan from joining the World Health Organization (WHO), and has blocked other countries from extending assistance to Taiwan when severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) erupted in Taiwan in 2003.

As a result, Hsu claimed, Taiwan became a loophole in the WHO's fight against epidemics. This could compromise Canada's efforts to ward off epidemics in light of the heavy air traffic between Canada and Taiwan.

Trade with China hasn't brought any benefit to Canada thus far, Hsu claimed, citing statistics showing that China had a trade surplus of 17.5 billion Canada dollars (US$14.78 billion) with Canada in 2004, which is more than 10 times that of a decade ago.
"Canada's strength will be sapped if the trend continues, " Hsu warned.

Yang Cheng-chao, head of the Friends of Taiwan group, raised questions about China's potential market saying that the country is dogged by uneven distribution of wealth, ethnic restlessness, pollution, and human rights infringements.
"Canada should not pursue China's market at the expense of its core values," Yang said.

DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Bush Pledges Federal Role in Rebuilding Gulf Coast
President Bush said the government would provide help on taxes, housing, education and job training for the hurricane victims.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Bush Promise a Massive Rebuilding
President Bush promised a massive federal effort aimed at rebuilding lives, levees and communities on the Gulf Coast and said such large disasters call for greater federal authority, including a bigger role for the armed forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE ASKS PUBLIC TO RESPECT RULING ON 2004 ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office asked Friday that the public respect the Supreme Court ruling on the legality of the disputed 2004 presidential election.

"Hopefully all social quarters can respect the Supreme Court ruling against an appeal by the opposition 'pan-blue alliance' about the legality of the 2004 presidential election, " said Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department.

Chen made the remarks after the Supreme Court announced earlier in the day that a panel of judges had overruled the opposition "pan-blue alliance" appeal to declare the March 20, 2004 election null and void because of alleged irregularities in the voting procedures.

Friday's ruling closed all lawsuits resulting from the 2004 presidential election. In the election, President Chen Shui-bian defeated his opponent, former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, by arazor-thin margin.

On the eve of the election, Chen Shui-bian was shot and lightly wounded by an unknown assailant while campaigning in the southern city of Tainan. The opposition claimed the shooting was staged, a theory an official investigation has rejected.
The opposition's original petition accused the Central Election Commission of ballot tampering and other irregularities, and demanded the election be held again.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party also claimed that a referendum held on the same day as the presidential election had unfairly influenced the outcome of the vote. But there was no connection between the referendum and the outcome of the presidential election, the Supreme Court ruled Friday.
On June 17, the Supreme Court also ruled against another opposition appeal, which had contested President Chen's re-election on the basis of the election-eve shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS RESULTS OF 2004 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Supreme Court upheld the results of the 2004 presidential election in a ruling Friday and rejected an appeal by the two main opposition parties that sought to have the election declared null and void.

The Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) argued in the appeal that the election should have been canceled after President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu -- Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates for president and vice president at the time -- were injured in a shooting on March 19 last year on the eve of the election.

The two opposition parties, known as the "pan-blue alliance," also claimed that a referendum held along with the election violated the Referendum Law and affected the results of the election, resulting in Chen and Lu wining by a small margin.

The case was one of two lawsuits filed by former KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong in an attempt to reverse the election results. The other suit seeking a court ruling to declare Chen's election invalid was rejected by the Supreme Court June 17.

In its ruling Friday, the Supreme Court said the Central Election Commission did not violate any law in deciding that the election should proceed as scheduled despite the March 19 shooting because the law provides that the commission can cancel a presidential election by public announcement only in the event of the death of a presidential candidate before the vote.
The court also explained that a presidential election cannot be rescheduled unless it is made impossible by a natural disaster or an "irresistible force."

The court also ruled that it was difficult to affirm that there was a connection between the election and the referendum, or that the referendum had affected the election results. Therefore, whether the Referendum Law was violated or not, the referendum could not be used as a reason to claim that the election was invalid.

The referendum asked voters' opinion on two questions about China's missile deployment opposite Taiwan and measures to manage relations with Beijing. Because voter participation failed to reach the 50 percent required by law, the referendum was declared null and void.

At a news conference Friday night, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said the Supreme Court ruling will not be the final judgment, because the final judgment will be by the people, and history and justice will eventually prevail in Taiwan.
She said the people of Taiwan are not surprised at the ruling, and "that makes the whole thing particularly sad."

The spokeswoman added that the people waited a whole year only to find out that Taiwan's judiciary system could not play a supervisory role and provide the checks and balance necessary for a democratic society.
Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, deplored the court ruling, saying also that he was "not surprised at all."
He pledged that the PFP caucus at the legislature will push for the establishment of a new commission to unearth the truth behind the March 19 shooting.

Also commenting on the court ruling, Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, urged the KMT and the PFP to respect the decision and work for a reconciliation between the ruling and the opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO REFORM AT DPP BIRTHDAY EVENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must never waver on its pledge to reform to retain its grip on power and not let down the public.
Chen made the remarks while attending an evening party in the central city of Taichung to mark the DPP's 19th founding anniversary.

"Reform is the road we must take. We must insist on continued reform of our political, economic and social systems to keep our vitality and competitiveness. Otherwise, we'll be ousted from office," Chen told DPP members and supporters.

While cutting a birthday cake, Chen also made three wishes -- that Taiwan becomes a "normal, complete, progressive, beautiful and great country"; that the DPP wins control of more than half of the 21 mayoral and magistrate posts up for grabs in the year-end elections; and that the DPP remains in power after the 2008 presidential election.

The DPP's founding anniversary falls on Sept. 28. As President Chen will be on a Central America diplomatic tour from Sept. 20 to Oct. 1, the DPP advanced its celebrations to Friday. DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang will accompany Chen on the journey that will include transit stops in two U.S. cities and official visits to five of the ROC's allies in Central America and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROBBERS RANSACK TAIWAN'S REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN JOHANNESBURG
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Liu Cheng-ching)

TEXT.P: A group of armed robbers ransacked Taiwan's representative office in Johannesburg Friday and escaped with cash and valuables they found in a safe.

Officials at the office said the robbers followed one of their employees as he entered an elevator. They held him hostage and forced him to open the safe in the office -- one of two Taipei liaison offices in South Africa, the other one being in Pretoria.
No one was injured during the holdup, and the losses were still being counted, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION COMMISSION PLEASED THAT COURT EXONERATED ITS ACTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission said Friday that it was pleased that the Supreme Court has cleared it of any wrongdoing in conducting the 2004 presidential election.

In a statement issued after the Supreme Court threw out an appeal by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate, James Soong, against a Taiwan High Court decision to dismiss their request to invalidate the 2004 presidential election, the commission said the ruling vindicates the commission's declaration that the country's 180,000-odd election workers had honestly carried out their jobs and followed the law.

The court ruled that Lien and Soong, who lost to President Chen Shui-bian by a margin of 0.228 percent of the votes, and had claimed that there were thousands of invalid ballots included in the final tally and numerous ballots cast by nonexistent voters, had make groundless claims.

Of course, the commission said, the election was not perfect, and some election workers had unwittingly made mistakes, and the commission has already taken action to address these problems. However, none of these mistakes affected the outcome of the presidential election, the commission added.

The commission said it is pleased that presidential election was able to bear the court's scrutiny, and hopes the controversies surrounding the election will be put to rest forever with the Supreme Court's decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN FORMALLY INFORMS TAIWAN OF PERMANENT VISA WAIVER

TEXT.P: Japan formally informed the Republic of China's representative office in Tokyo Friday of its decision to drop visa requirements for Taiwan tourists from Sept. 26.

Masaji Takahashi, president of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), conveyed the message to Koh Se-kai, the ROC representative to Japan. The JIA is a quasi-official institution authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Koh said the Japanese decision is a belated reciprocal measure. Taiwan has long offered visa-free treatment for Japanese tourists. "The mutual exemption of visa requirements symbolizes close substantive ties between Taiwan and Japan," Koh said.

Earlier this year, the Japanese Diet passed a special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the Aichi Expo. With the temporary visa waiver period soon to expire, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill Aug. 5 to allow for permanent visa-free status for Taiwan passport holders from Sept. 26.

In the future, Koh said the ROC representative office will focus on lobbying Japan to improve the bilateral engagement mechanism. Stressing that the mechanism -- formulated in 1972 following Japan's switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing -- has become obsolete, Koh said Japan should make an overall review and forge a more effective mechanism to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

Under the 1972 mechanism, both Taipei and Tokyo set up intermediary bodies -- the Taipei-based Association of East Asian Relations and the Tokyo-based Interchange Association -- to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of direct official contacts.

Now that Japan has explicitly singled out Taiwan Strait peace as a common strategic objective in the U.S.-Japan defense cooperation treaty, Koh said Japan should not continue resisting improvements to communication channels with Taiwan simply for fear of offending China.

Meanwhile, Koh said he will also strive to lobby Japan to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan. "It won't be an easy task, but anyway, we'll make every possible effort to create a favorable environment to that end," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S HELP TO TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN NOT AN OPENING FOR PROPAGANDA: MAC

TEXT.P: China should not interpret its helping safeguard Taiwanese investments in China as an opening to engage in political propaganda, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a statement Friday.

The council released the statement after the first cross-strait civilian forum co-hosted by the opposition People First Party and the Communist Party of China ended in Shanghai with proposals aimed at safeguarding the rights and interests of Taiwanese investors on the mainland.

The rights and interests of Taiwanese investments in China, as well as problems of cross-strait commercial arbitration and intellectual property rights protection were to be further discussed by both sides before talks were suspended in 1995, the statement said.

No progress has been made on this front as Beijing does not want to talk with officials of the ROC government on Taiwan, and the MAC is asking that China be practical and work together with Taiwan to protect Taiwanese business interests and rights, especially the safety of Taiwanese working in China.
The MAC also hopes cross-strait negotiations will resume as soon as possible to build a protection mechanism for Taiwan interests in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN HAS NEVER ASKED SOONG TO CONVEY MESSAGE TO HU: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has never asked opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong to pass any messages to Chinese President Hu Jintao, a Presidential Office spokesman said Friday.

James Huang, a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, made the remarks after James R. Keith, a U.S. State Department senior adviser, said that Soong met P.R.C. President Hu Jintao and other P.R.C. leaders in Beijing on May 12 and passed the message that Chen Shui-bian was willing to engage in dialogue with Beijing using a flexible formulation about what constitutes "one China."
Huang said he didn't know where the U.S. State Department got its information and that the State Department has not contacted the Presi ential Office regarding the matter.
One thing is certain, however, and that is that Chen has never asked Soong to pass any messages to the Chinese leadership, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT GIVES THE GO-AHEAD FOR TAIPEI FREE PORT

TEXT.P: Taipei Harbor's application to be a free port was approved by the government Wednesday, and the port is expected to post an initial output of NT$650 million every year, according to the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The council said in a statement Friday that the port is expected to handle 8,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEU) in cargo, in addition to 470,000 tons of bulk cargo, and create 400 job opportunities in the first year.
The harbor, with a preliminary area of 79 hectares, is supposed to be a regional hub for the logistics industry and one company has already been approved to operate in the port from October.
The area of the free trade port will be extended in 2008 when a container shipping center, measured 110 hectares, is completed.
