DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Sept. 17, or the 14th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1665: The Great Plague breaks out in London.
1701: James II, King of England, Scotland and Ireland, dies at the age of 68. The last Stuart king to rule both England and Scotland, he was overthrown by his son-in-law, William of Orange.
1787: George Washington, leader of the Philadelphia Convention, is presented with a new Constitution for the United States of America.
1796: Washington, who had been president since 1789, gives his farewell address to the American people as president of the United States.
1901: Sir Francis Chichester, British sailor and aviator, is born. He was knighted for sailing around the world solo in the "Gypsy Moth IV" and flew his plane the "Gypsy Moth" solo east to west across the Tasman Sea.
1924: The Second Chihli-Fengtien War breaks out in China, which later resulted in the defeat of Wu Pei-fu and the resignation of Tsao Kun.
1939: Russia invades Poland, taking 217,000 Poles prisoner.
1957: A bloodless coup launched by General Sarit Thanarat overthrows the government of Field Marshal Pibul Songgram in Thailand.
1963: Malaysia severs diplomatic relations with Indonesia.
1973: Simon S. Nxumalo, Swaziland minister of industry, mining and tourism, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo makes an oral administrative report at the 54th session of the Legislative Yuan, with Nieh Wen-ya presiding.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo says the Republic of China has the ability to make nuclear weapons but will never do so.
1976: The Republic of China and the United States sign a fishery agreement in Washington, with Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Vice Minister Liu Shih-cheng attending the ceremony.
1976: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea open their 11th ministerial conference on economic cooperation in Seoul.
1978: An agreement for Middle East peace is signed at Camp David in the United States between Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Egyptian President Anwar Sadat.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV and Queen Halaevalu Mata'aho of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1990: A team of 200 athletes and coaches flies to the Chinese mainland for the ROC's first appearance in 20 years at the Asian Games.
1991: The United Nations General Assembly admits North and South Korea, Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania as U.N. members.
1992: An ROC-Latvia investment guarantee agreement is signed in Taipei following a visit by Latvian Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis.
1995: An exhibition of 71 landscape paintings from the collection of the Louvre in Paris opens at the National Palace Museum in Taipei. The exhibition runs through Jan. 15.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton sends 3,500 troops to Kuwait and warns Iraq of new attacks if it threatens neighboring countries.
1997: For the fifth straight year, ROC supporters in Africa, Latin America and the Pacific fail to sway the U.N. General Assembly to consider readmitting the ROC to the United Nations.
1999: Chinese Taipei defeats mainland China 4-0 in Seoul to finish in third place at the 20th Asian Cup Baseball Championships.
2000: A monument made of debris from the devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 is inaugurated in Nantou City in memory of those who were killed in the temblor.
2000: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan urges the government to "rein itself in from the edge of the precipice" and continue construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant.
2001: A world conference on religious cooperation in memory of the lethal Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake opens in downtown Taipei with 135 religious leaders and representatives from 29 countries and areas taking part.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Unless there be the highest moral power, the highest moral law cannot be realized."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN TO VISIT OVER ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of U.S. congressmen has tentatively decided to visit Taiwan next month to exchange views with government officials and legislators on the country's long-stalled arms procurement package from the United States.
U.S. Congressman Rob Simmons (R.- Conn.) is arranging the delegation, which will mainly comprise members of the Committee on Armed Forces of the U.S. House of Representatives.
The delegation will come for Double Ten National Day celebration activities on Oct. 10 and will meet with legislators to discuss national security.

The congressman originally hoped that Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou would help solve differences within the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party, and work toward early passage of the arms procurement package.

Ma recently turned down an invitation from the Taiwan Caucus -- a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. House of Representatives -- to visit Washington, D.C. in September to explain the opposition camp's opposition.
However, Ma said that he and the KMT caucus will ensure that Taiwan's defensive capability is strengthened and that relations between the U.S. and Taiwan are further cemented.
Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan blocked the package for the 28th time earlier this week, refusing to allow it to be put on the legislative agenda.

The package comprises three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries. For more than a year, the "pan-blue alliance" has refused to screen the package because it claims the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS AWARD MARKS INTERNATIONAL AFFIRMATION TO ROC: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A plan of the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus to confer on President Chen Shui-bian a human rights award is an affirmation to the Taiwan people's efforts to seek human rights, democracy and freedom, the Presidential Office said Saturday.

The award represents not only an affirmation of Chen's contribution, but also of the Taiwan people's sacrifice and struggle in a decades-long fight for human rights and democracy, according to Chen Wen-chung, head of the office's department of public affairs.

Chen made the statement after the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) voiced a protest over the event, pointing out that it would be ironic to issue a human rights award to a country recently shocked by revelations of gross human rights abuse of its foreign workers.

Besides the Presidential Office, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) also issued a statement praising the award as an reaffirmation of Taiwan's efforts in the promotion of human rights.
DPP caucus whip Chen Jin-jun said the DPP regrets the KMT's criticism, while staying silent over China's abysmal human rights record.

Pan Wei-kang, a KMT legislative caucus whip, hosted a news conference at the Legislative Yuan Saturday to accuse the government of harming human rights because it failed to properly address the scandal involving the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway construction project exposed by an Aug. 21 riot by maltreated Thai laborers. She noted that the scandal has blemished Taiwan's global image as a democracy that respect human rights, and pointed out that the Thai government has filed an accusation against Taiwan at the United Nations.

Pan said the president should clean up the mess after Premier Frank Hsieh, who served as Kaohsiung mayor for six years before taking the helm of the Cabinet in February, refused to apologize for the scandal, while the government has been reluctant to release the results of an investigation into the scandal involving corruption among government officials.

KMT Legislator Su Chi said the KMT caucus plans to write to the U.S. Congress to provide details about the riot and about opposition claims that the government has suppressed the freedom of the press.
It is expected that President Chen will receive the Human Rights Award during his transit stop in Miami en route to Central America next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SHOULD TAKE HEED OF TAIWAN BEING UNFAIRLY CONTAINED: FM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen expressed hope Saturday that the international community will take heed of Taiwan being unfairly contained by China.
Chen made the remarks at the inaugural World Forum for Democratization in Asia, which entered its third and last day at the Taipei International Convention Center.
Describing Taiwan's democratic experience as a success story worthy of reference for other countries, he lamented that Taiwan is a democracy shut out of the international community.

During the Cold War, he claimed, democratic countries "contained communist countries, " but now it is totalitarian China that tries to contain Taiwan, Chen said, adding that the international community should not turn a blind eye to the situation.

He also said that democratization in Japan, Taiwan, Thailand and Mongolia have made great strides and that these democratic countries should build a democratic front and integrate the region to create a pan-Asia organization that shares the common values of democracy and can become a force of powerful influence.

He cited as an example the fact that Myanmar, because of its human rights record, is often criticized by the international community and was forced to abandon the rotating chairmanship in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

The authoritarian regime in China has become a hurdle to regional integration and is a threat to neighboring countries, he said. It is also a major force in supporting other non-democratic countries such as North Korea, Myanmar and Uzbekistan, he said.
Democratic countries in Asia must unite to prod China to move toward democratization or the future of democracy in Asia will face daunting challenges, he went on.

Chen also said that since the international community thinks the Taiwan Strait is a possible flashpoint, it should play a role of coordinator between the two sides of the strait so that the two governments on either side can sort out their differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD WILLING TO MEET WITH U.S. CONGRESSMEN OVER ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou is willing to communicate with U.S. congressmen on the country's long-stalled arms procurement package from the United States, a KMT spokeswoman said Saturday.

Cheng Li-wen made the remarks amid reports that U.S. Congressman Rob Simmons (R.- Conn.) is arranging for a visit to Taiwan by delegation mainly comprising members of the Committee on Armed Forces of the U.S. House of Representatives.
The delegation will come for the Oct. 10 Double Ten National Day celebration and will meet with government officials and legislators to exchange views on the arms package, according to the reports.
Cheng said that Ma is very willing to communicate with them if a meeting can be arranged.

She made the claim that "most of the U.S. congressmen" have their information supplied by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which she said might have given them false information. She cited especially the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) , a U.S.-based pro-Taiwan independence organization, which she claimed often "twists the truth and supplies incorrect information, " leading the U.S. congressmen to form misunderstanding of the KMT.
If chance arises, she went on, the KMT is very willing to put its side of the story -- that the KMT believes the problem lies with the DPP and not the KMT.

Ma recently noted that the arms procurement package was approved by the Cabinet in 1998, when Lien Chan, former KMT chairman, was premier, and that the U.S. did not approve the arms procurement package until 2001, by which time the DPP's Chen Shui-bian was president.

But the DPP waited until 2004 to submit a special budget for the three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries -- triggering questions as to why the tag price ballooned at one point from the original amount of between NT$200 billion (US$6.15 billion) and NT$300 billion to NT$610.8 billion.

Ma said the arms procurement package involves price and cross-strait relations issues, and that the government should think seriously about how to avoid plunging the two sides of the Taiwan Strait into an arms race.

For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has refused to screen the package because it claims the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special budget. The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan blocked the package for the 28th time earlier this week, refusing to allow it to be put on the legislative agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TO CLEAN TAIWAN KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: Over 70,000 volunteers from 320 organizations around Taiwan, equipped with brooms, tongs and garbage bags, joined the largest "clean up the island" campaign of the country in five years Saturday that kicked off at 1,598 spots around the country simultaneously.

At the campaign headquarters -- the Sanchiaotu wharf on the Keelung River in Taipei, Taipei Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan, Taipei City Commissioner of Environmental Protection Chen Yeong-ren, as well as Lai Tung-min, chairman of the non-profit Good Neighbor Foundation, headed a group of volunteer workers picking up waste along the river and sorting it for recycling.

A team made of around 30 college students in northern Taiwan caught the most attention as all its members roller-skated along the bicycle track along the river at the Pailing Riverbank Park, showing dazzling skating skills during their public service.

The campaign took place from the Paisha Bay in Taipei County in the north to the Kenting National Park in the south, Tungying on the outlying island of Matsu in the west and Lungtung on the northeastern cape of Taiwan in the east, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE FORUM TO KICK OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan Business Alliance Forum, organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to attract foreign investors, is scheduled to take place Sept. 22 in Taipei with the expected participation of representatives of over 400 domestic and foreign businesses.

The one-day forum will discuss nanotechnology and relevant industrial applications in conjunction with the planned Taiwan Nanotech 2005 exhibition and conference Sept. 21-25, MOEA officials said Saturday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh is scheduled to host a press conference a day before the opening of the forum to introduce the annual event, which was established last year. National Science Council Minister Wu Mao-kun, Industrial Technology Research Institute President Johnsee Lee, as well as several foreign business operators, are expected to attend the conference to share their experiences of investing in Taiwan and international cooperation.

Dr. Kazunobu Tanaka of Japan, the founding chairman of the Asia Nanotech Forum, and Matthew Nordan of the United States, vice president of Lux Research Inc., will give keynote speeches before panel discussions begin, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEN FOREIGN LEADERS SPEAKS FOR TAIWAN IN U.N.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 16 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Leaders from 10 countries spoke out for Taiwan in the United Nations Summit of World Leaders that ended in New York Friday, according to Taiwan officials posted here.
Officials from the Taiwan representative office in New York said that of the 10, nine are from Taiwan's allies and the other comes from Fiji, which does not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
The three-day summit brought together the leaders of 170 states, each of whom was given only five minutes to speak, making the pro-Taiwan words all the more valuable, said the officials.

The leaders of the nine allies who spoke out for Taiwan were Kiribati President Anote Tong, Tuvalu Prime Minister Maatia Toafa, Honduras Foreign Minister Mario Fortin, Palau, Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique de Menenes, Saint Christopher and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas, Nauru President Ludwig Scotty, Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and Solomon Islands Prime Minister Sir Allan Kemakeza.
They either admired Taiwan's economic development and democracy, or urged the U.N. to fulfill its goal of universal representation by admitting Taiwan as a member.

The officials said Taiwan appreciates that the leaders spoke in favor of Taiwan, even though it would not help the country's bid to enter the U.N. this year as it had already been quashed after the U.N. General Committee decided Tuesday against putting it on the agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM THANKS FOREIGN LEADERS FOR SPEAKING FOR TAIWAN IN U.N.

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen thanked the leaders of nine allies and Fiji Saturday for speaking out for Taiwan at the United Nations.

The leaders of the nine allies either praised Taiwan's economic achievements and democracy or prodded the U.N. to admit Taiwan as a member at the United Nations Summit of World Leaders that concluded in New York Friday.

Although their speech did not help Taiwan's bid to enter the U.N. this year, which had already been quashed after the U.N. General Committee decided Sept. 13 not to put it on the agenda of the U.N., they have helped voice Taiwan's desire to reach out to the international community, Chen said.

The Minister said he especially took heart at the speech of Fiji President Josefa Iloila, who said the world should develop ties with China and Taiwan in parallel. Iloila's remarks bode well for ties between the two countries, although there are no diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Fiji, Chen said.

The leaders of the nine allies who spoke out for Taiwan were Kiribati President Anote Tong, Tuvalu Prime Minister Maatia Toafa, Honduras Foreign Minister Mario Fortin, Palau President Tommy Remengesau, Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique de Menenes, Saint Christopher and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas, Nauru President Ludwig Scotty, Marshall Islands President Kessai Note and Solomon Islands Prime Minister Sir Allan Kemakeza.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REFUSES TO ACCEPT CONDITIONS FOR GIVING REPORT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that an opposition lawmakers' demand that he apologize before they will allow him to deliver his administrative report to the legislature is like forcing someone to write a remorse note before a conviction is made.

The premier, who was again kept from giving a report due to the obstruction of the opposition legislators the previous day, was referring to one of the conditions set by the legislators for him to give the report -- that he must first apologize for the controversial mass rapid transit system in Kaohsiung, construction on which was launched when he was still the mayor of the southern port city.
The issue of the Kaohsiung MRT system was thrust into the spotlight after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the system.

The premier, while on a stumping trip for Lin Chia-lung, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate for Taichung City in the year-end elections, also said that he would not apologize under pressure, adding that an apology should come from within.
Meanwhile, the DPP legislative caucus reaffirmed that there will be no horse trading on the premier's report.

William C.T. Lai, caucus whip in the legislature, said the premier's duty to report is stipulated in the Constitution and it will oppose the request by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus that the DPP should first consent to the formation of committees to look into five controversial issues: the one-year delay in the opening of the high-speed railway; allegations of corruption in the Kaohsiung MRT construction project; allegations of insider trading on the Taiwan Stock Exchange; the second phase of the government's financial reform plan; and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom.

As Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will convene a meeting between the KMT and the DPP legislative caucuses next Monday for coordination over the stalemate, Lai said that the DPP's stance will be that the premier should first give the report before it will agree to the formation of the five committees and that the KMT should also agree to the DPP's demand for three committees to investigate the former ruling party's past corruption, environmental pollution, and idle public facilities.
The People First Party (PFP), an ally of the KMT, backed its demands of an apology and formation of committees.

But as it is the KMT who initiated the obstruction of the legislative proceeding, the PFP will respect the KMT's decision on what to allow the premier to report upon, Sun Ta-chien, PFP caucus whip in the legislature said.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said the legislative committees have no substantial function, will not help in finding out the truth and will merely be a tool for grandstanding.
For this reason, Ho Min-hao, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, said the party will oppose the formation of a committee for any single event.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN CRITICIZES KUOMINTANG FOR SHAMING COUNTRY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has no concerns about the country's image when it threatened to stop US congressmen giving a humman right award to President Chen Shui-bian, Cho jung-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said Saturday.

Cho said the award to the president is a honor to be shared by the whole nation, the KMT is subordinating the national interest to its partisan interest by threatening to dissuade the US Congress from giving the president the honor.

Noting that the KMT lawmakers have criticized the president because of the Thai workers in Kaohsiung has resorted to riot to protest their inhuman treatment in Taiwan, the spokesman said the riot is an isolate incident which should not be used as a reason to completely deny the president's efforts to improve human rights.

In its attempt to throw a spanner in the works, the spokesman said, the KMT has exposed its narrow-mindedness and its reluctance to see the president who ended the KMT's five-decade rule being honored in anyway.
Cho said some of the president's critics at home are political biased, they would stop at nothing to debase their country but turn a blind eye to China's attempts to isolate the country.
He called on the opposition to give precedence to the national interest rather then their party's interest.

Cho made the remarks after several KMT lawmakers criticizing the US Congressional Human Rights Caucus's decision to give President Chen Shui-bian a human rights award earlier Saturday, saying they will persuade the caucus to drop its plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Sept. 18, or the 15th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 96: Domitian, the Roman emperor who completed the conquest of Britain, is murdered by assassins hired by his wife, Domitilla. After A.D. 89, his government became dictatorial, leading to a reign of terror.
1502: Christopher Columbus, an Italian explorer in the service of Spain, lands in Costa Rica on his fourth and last voyage to the New World.
1759: French forces at Quebec surrender to the British.
1810: Chile proclaims independence after a junta revolts against Joseph Bonaparte of Spain and takes power.
1851: The first edition of the New York Times, founded by Henry Jarvis Raymond, is published.
1864: John Hanning Speke, 37, British explorer, shoots himself in a tragic accident and dies soon afterward. He had discovered the source of the River Nile six years earlier at the huge African lake he named after Queen Victoria.
1924: China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues his Northern Expedition manifesto against warlords of the Chihli faction at Shaoguan in Kwantung Province, following the establishment of the military academy June 24 at Whampoa, on an island south of Canton.
1931: Japanese troops occupy China's Shenyang (Mukden) in a surprise attack. Important cities in the provinces of Liaoning and Kirin quickly fall in the Japanese advance, an act of aggression that marked the beginning of the Sino-Japanese War.
1947: The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), a United States government agency, is established to gather political, economic and military information about more than 150 nations and to evaluate it for other U.S. government agencies.
1948: Communists in Indonesia set up a Soviet-style government in Java but are forced by government troops to withdraw.
1958: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down 10 Communist Chinese MiG-17s, while the navy sinks three Communist Chinese torpedo boats.
1961: U.N. Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold dies at the age of 56 when a DC-6 plane carrying him and 130 other passengers crashes in the jungle in Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) while on a mission to the Congo.
1967: Explosives planted by the Vietcong destroy the ROC Embassy in Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City).
1967: Sir John Douglas Cockcroft, British physicist, dies at the age of 70. Along with Ernest T.S. Walton, he succeeded in splitting the atom in 1931. They shared a 1951 Nobel Prize for their contribution to nuclear physics.
1967: The United States announces it will build an anti-missile network to counter any attack by Communist China.
1973: West Germany, East Germany and the Bahamas are admitted into the United Nations.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan appoints 15 Grand Justices to the fourth Council of Justice.
1981: Under President Francois Maurice Mitterand, France abolishes the use of the guillotine.
1982: Chou Ling-fei, the grandson of Lu Hsun, a modern Chinese writer most admired by the Communist Chinese, defects to the ROC from Tokyo, Japan, in order to marry Chang Chun-hua, a resident of Taipei.
1988: The military under Gen. Saw Maung seizes power in Burma, overthrowing civilian President Maung Maung.
1988: ROC taekwondo champion Chen Yu-an wins the ROC's first Olympic gold medal in an Olympic exhibition taekwondo tournament in Seoul.
1997: The people of Wales narrowly support in a referendum British government plans to give them home rule.
1999: The Paraguayan Embassy in the ROC is officially opened in Taipei.
2000: Vice President Annette Lu condemns Japan's "comfort women" system during World War II and suggests that the sex slave issue be "internationalized" in order to extract an apology and compensation from the Japanese government.
2001: Construction on Kaohsiung's software science-based industrial park, dubbed "Taiwan's silicon valley," officially begins.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, while honoring the greatness and power of his moral nature, yet does not neglect inquiry and pursuit of knowledge."

DOC.HEADLINE: CORE PACIFIC MALL TOP ENTERTAINMENT DESTINATION IN TAIPEI: ONLINE POLL

TEXT.P: Core Pacific City's Living Mall was named Taipei's most popular entertainment destination in an online survey released Sunday, with the Miramar Entertainment Park coming in a close second.

A total of 18,142 online users voted in the survey, held by the Taipei City Government under the sponsorship of Mio Technology Corp. Core Pacific City's Living Mall led the Miramar Entertainment Park by a slight margin -- only 64 votes.
Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall ranked third, followed by Taipei 101 Mall -- the new landmark of the city and the tallest building in the world.
Yangmingshan National Park and the National Palace Museum won fifth and sixth places, respectively.

The other favorite places in the top 10 are: the Shihlin Night Market, the Taipei Zoo, Maokung -- a popular place in the suburb of Mucha for tea lovers -- and the former residence of Chiang Kai-shek in Shihlin.
Failing to make the top 10 by about only 20 votes were the Peitou Hot Springs Museum and the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOSTING SEMINAR TO ENHANCE NATION'S FLOWER EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will sponsor a seminar on Asian horticultural trade opportunities Monday as part of its efforts to boost the nation's flower exports, a TAITRA official said Sunday.
The Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) , which represents Dutch interests in Taipei in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, has assisted in organizing the seminar, the official said.

According to TAITRA tallies, Taiwan exported US$14.88 million worth of flowers in 2004 while imports reaching US$57.95 million. The gap indicated that there is still ample room for local florists to promote their overseas sales, the official said.

Noting that the Netherlands has been one of the world's major flower exporters, the official said TAITRA has invited major Dutch horticultural companies and agricultural officials to attend the seminar to offer counseling.

Topics to be addressed will include the opportunity for Taiwan to become an Asia-Pacific floral trade center, the current state and future prospects for Taiwan's orchid exports and the feasibility of Taiwan using the Netherlands as a springboard to enter the European horticultural market, the official said.

Dutch horticultural companies sending representatives to the seminar will include Anthura B.V., Bunnik Plants and Geest Orchideeen. Several officials from the Dutch Ministry of Agriculture will also travel to Taiwan to attend the meeting.
In addition to attending the conference, the Dutch visitors will visit major Taiwan horticultural centers to explore possible trade or joint-venture deals.

According to official tallies, Taiwan has 12,579 hectares of flower-growing areas, with an annual production of US$380 million. Orchids alone account for about US$73.94 million. Major flower farms are concentrated in Changhua, Nantou and Chiayi counties.

The Washington Post: Lack of Cohesion Bedevils Recovery; Red Tape, Lapses in Planning Stall Relief.
Three weeks after Hurricane Katrina struck, red tape and poor planning have left thousands of evacuees without basic services, according to local and state officials, public policy experts and survivors themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPATS SUPPORT ROC LAWMAKER'S PROTESTS AGAINST JAPANESE WAR CRIMES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Sept. 17 (CNA) (By C. Chiang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China lawmaker who is currently in San Francisco to launch a campaign in protest against Japanese atrocities against Taiwan's aborigines during its occupation of the island said Saturday that she has received a lot of support and generous donations from local Taiwan expatriates.

According to Legislator Kao Kin Su-mei, at the head of a 60-member aboriginal group, she and the group will lodge a series of protests against Japanese war crimes at Japan's consulates in San Francisco, Philadelphia and Houston and at the United Nations' headquarters in New York City Sept. 23.

Besides expressing her gratitude for the support given by overseas Taiwanese living in the city, the legislator said that the history of World War II only recalls the past sadness of the people in those countries and areas that were under colonial rule of Japan during the war, including China, Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines, Indonesia and Okinawa.

"I will continue to lodge protests against Japan's criminal conduct during World War II if the nation refuses to make a thorough self-examination and an apology for what it did to the people of these countries, " Kao Chin said, adding: "I think Japan is not qualified to be a member of the United Nations Security Council as long as it refuses to apologize for the war it provoked in the Pacific region."

The legislator has visited Japan seven times during the past three years to demand that the Japanese authorities remove the memorial tablets of the aboriginal soldiers who fought for Japan from the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, where they are honored among those Japanese soldiers who died for the country, but the request was ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Casini calls for dialogue on electoral reforms between ruling and opposition camps.
Chamber of Deputies Speaker Pier Ferdinando Casini urged the ruling coalition and the opposition union Saturday to hold a dialogue on electoral reforms. He said that he did not believe that it is anything wrong to deal with electoral laws eight months prior to the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN A STRONG SUPPORTER OF INTERNATIONAL VOLUNTEERISM: IAVE
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Sept. 17 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Board of Directors of the International Association for Volunteer Effort (IAVE) has affirmed the contributions made by Taiwan to the organization and praised the island as a strong supporter of the association, a local IAVE representative in Taiwan said Saturday.
Tim Wu, national representative of the IAVE in Taiwan and an international member of the IAVE's board of directors, made the remarks while attending a conference currently being held in Ottawa.

Wu, who also president and executive director of IAVE-Taiwan, said that during the meeting the members of the board recognized the significant role played by the island in an "IAVE.org project, " which offers an exchange platform for volunteers worldwide, and in the establishment of an IAVE Resource Center in Taiwan.
IAVE, which has individual and organizational members in some 80 countries around the world, is an international non-governmental organization that promotes and strengthens volunteerism worldwide.

Pointing out that President Chen Shui-bian has attached great importance to volunteerism in Taiwan since he took office in 2000, Wu, who founded IAVE-Taiwan in 2002, said that a group of people on the island have since worked on the possible association of international non-governmental organizations with Taiwan's dynamic civilian society.

"The outcome of such efforts was the signing of a cooperation agreement among the IAVE, IAVE-Taiwan and the National Youth Commission under the Executive Yuan in April of this year on the setting up of an IAVE international resource center. Taiwan also agreed in 2003 to help the organization build an Internet Web site network, " he further said.

The IAVE board of directors also briefed Robert Leigh, a senior U.N. official responsible for volunteerism affairs, who also attended the meeting, on the close relationship between the IAVE and Taiwan. "This tells us that although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, its active participation in international activities can make the U.N. understand the contributions that the island has made to the world, " Wu said.

Nevertheless, Wu warned that Taiwan should realize that participating in international affairs means discussing world and regional issues as well as issues related to common values of democracy, freedom and civil society, rather than talking always about the island's own matters.
During the gathering, Wu suggested that the IAVE set up a global education center in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE PROTEST AGAINST HU'S VISIT IN CANADA

TEXT.P: More than 100 local Taiwan expatriates gathered Saturday in front of the renowned Westin Bayshore Hotel in Vancouver to protest against Chinese President Hu Jintao's visit to the city.
The visiting Chinese head of state was in the hotel to participate in a state banquet hosted by Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin in his honor.
Waving banners saying " Shame on China, "One China, One Taiwan, " the Taiwanese marchers joined hands with Falun Gong followers and supporters of the Tibetan independence movement.

Besides protesting Hu's visit, 24 Taiwanese organizations in Vancouver also sent an open letter to the newspaper the "Vancouver Sun" to voice their dissatisfaction with China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan and the passage of the Anti-Secession Law against the island.
In the letter, they also called for Hu to improve the living standard and human rights in China as well as to abrogate the Anti-Secession Law and stop threatening to use force against Taiwan.
The letter was carried by the newspaper the same day. (By F.Y.Ho and P.C. Tang

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUNTEER RANGERS CONVERGE IN HSITOU TO PROMOTE ECO-FRIENDLY TOURS

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 volunteer rangers converged in the Hsitou Forest Recreation Area in the central Taiwan county of Nantou Sunday to promote eco-friendly tours.

The event was organized by National Taiwan University (NTU) , which manages the 2,799.3-hectare Hsitou Forest Recreation Area, one of Taiwan's most popular mountain retreats for people to beat the summer heat.

NTU President Lee Su-chen said the Hsitou forest park was battered by three devastating mudslides caused by Typhoon Herb in 1996, the magnitude 7.6-earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 and Typhoon Toraji in 2001.
After more than six years of rehabilitation with eco-friendly technologies, Lee said, the Hsitou recreation area has emerged as a model region equipped with a superior mudslide prevention system.
"I'm hopeful that today's event can inspire more local people to volunteer their services to help protect our forests and natural environment," Lee said.

The event included an ecology-centered quiz show, a concert and guided hiking along six major courses in the forest park. In support of the event, some British and U.S. tobacco companies donated 20,000 seedlings for forestation in the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ELECTION RESULTS COULD BE LITMUS TEST FOR 2008 PRESIDENTIAL RACEBy Han Nai-kuoCNA Staff Reporter

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major political parties are preparing for heated campaigning for the elections of mayors and county magistrates in December, as their leaders believe the results will set the stage for the all-important 2008 presidential election.

One of the three wishes President Chen Shui-bian made in a speech last week was that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) take more than half of Taiwan's 21 cities and countries being contested in the Dec. 3 elections; another wish being that the DPP continue to be the ruling party after the 2008 presidential election.

The DPP has fielded a candidate in every city and county, except in Taitung County. It has given up in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, where the DPP has never won an election. The party is focusing its efforts on winning in cities and counties currently not under DPP control, especially Taichung City and Taichung County.

Opinion polls show that DPP candidates are ahead of their opponents from other parties in Tainan City and the counties of Taipei, Kaohsiung, Chiayi, Yunlin, Pingtung, Nantou and Changhua. However, in northern and central Taiwan, the DPP is facing a hard battle, especially in Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County, Taichung City and Taichung County.

Although the DPP has designated Lin Chia-lung, former head of the Government Information Office, and former legislator Chiu Tai-san -- both of whom are noted national figures -- to run in Taichung City and Taichung County, respectively, they still have a long way to go in their attempt to unseat incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taichung County Magistrate Huang Jhong-sheng, both of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The DPP is using its advantage as the ruling party to back its candidates in the campaigning. For example, Premier Frank Hsieh has endorsed a plan to construct a rapid transit network for Taichung City which was pledged by the DPP candidate.

DPP party officials told the media they have developed a strategy to weaken support for the KMT in those cities and counties that have long remained under KMT control. These officials said the DPP will resort to a "secret weapon" at the latter stage of the campaigning.

For the KMT, the main battlefields are in the counties of Changhua, Nantou and Yunlin. If the party can win in Chiayi City, where the KMT has been out of power for 26 years, or in the counties of Ilan and Taipei, where the KMT has been the underdog for 16 years, party officials would see the KMT victory in the elections as sealed.

At the same time, good coordination between the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , known as the "pan-blue alliance, " is necessary for the two parties to avoid their candidates competing with each other. Such cooperation, however, is still not assured, as indicated by the rivalry between Liu Wen-hsiung, the PFP's candidate for Keelung mayor, and the KMT's man, incumbent Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li.

In addition to Keelung City, The PFP has vowed to name its own candidates in seven other cities and counties: the cities of Taichung and Chiayi and the counties of Hualien, Changhua, Lienchiang (Matsu), Ilan and Hsinchu. It remains to be seen how the KMT will collaborate with the PFP.

Taipei County, with a population of 3.5 million, will no doubt be the most hotly contested area in the elections. At present, the KMT candidate, Legislator Chou Hsi-wei, and his DPP opponent Legislator Lo Wen-chia are running neck and neck, according to the latest opinion polls. Both parties have acknowledged that they cannot afford to lose in Taipei County, as the election result is crucial to their chance of winning in the 2008 presidential election.

KMT party officials are confident that with the battle fought between the DPP and the "pan-blue alliance, " the KMT candidate will have a considerable advantage, as indicated by the 2004 presidential election when the pan-blue ticket of Lien Chan and James Soong exceeded the DPP ticket of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu by 130,000 votes in Taipei County.

Another major advantage for the KMT is the whirlwind created by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou because of his recent election to the post of party chairman. His personal charisma and the hope he has kindled in the minds of people yearning for national political reform will probably be the biggest asset in the KMT's bid to regain power.

DOC.HEADLINE: KNIFE-WIELDING BIKER GANG SLASH PEOPLE INDISCRIMINATELY

TEXT.P: A motorcycle gang with more than 20 members raced through the streets of Tuchen in Taipei County in the wee hours Sunday morning and attacked innocent passersby with machetes and baseball bats, wounding 12 people who had to be hospitalized.
Three of the victims suffered serious head injuries and are listed in serious condition. They are still in the intensive care unit of a hospital in Panchiao, fighting for their lives.

A group of 12 youngsters who rode their motorbikes home after leavng a barbecue party in celebration of the Mid-Autumn Moon Festival were chased by the gang along the streets and slashed with machetes.
Police are trying to identify the attackers using clues from the tapes of the community's closed-circuit monitors. By late Sunday night, the gang still remained at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SUGGESTS LEGISLATURE VOTE ON WHETHER TO ACCEPT HIS REPORT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh suggested Sunday that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan decide whether to allow him to deliver an administrative report at its plenary session by a vote.

Hsieh made the suggestion after lawmakers from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) twice blocked him from addressing the legislature on his Cabinet's work agenda and its 2006 budget plan last week by occupying the podium of the legislative chamber.

"As the 'pan-blue alliance' controls a slim majority in the legislature, it can do whatever it wants. But I don't think that all opposition lawmakers would like to see the unproductive legislative session continue. Probably, the legislature can hold a vote to resolve this deadlock," Hsieh said.

Touching on President Chen Shui-bian's remarks a day earlier that the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should not come up with a non-confidence vote against the Cabinet as a countermeasure to the "pan-blue alliance's" boycott on Hsieh's administrative report, Hsieh said he fully agrees with Chen's view.
"The DPP legislative caucus indeed should support the government's policy and has no legitimate reason to take a no-confidence vote," Hsieh said.

Under current constitutional provisions, the premier can ask the president to dissolve the legislature only when the legislature passes a no-confidence vote against the Cabinet -- a move that hinders any easy solution to gridlock between the government's executive and legislative branches.

KMT legislative whip Tseng Yung-chuan dismissed Hsieh's suggestion as "nonsense, " claiming that the KMT's boycott was only a temporary measure to press for a government response to a spate of recent controversial cases.

Noting that Constitution requires the premier to deliver an administrative report at the beginning of a new legislative session, Tseng said it's Hsieh's official duty and cannot be a topic to be subject to a legislative vote.

The "pan-blue alliance" originally proposed two prerequisites for Hsieh to deliver the administrative report -- an apology from Hsieh for alleged Kaohsiung mass rapid transit ( MRT) system construction scandals and the DPP legislative caucus' consent to the establishment of five legislative committees to look into five alleged corruption cases.

Tseng said Sunday the KMT caucus would no longer demand Hsieh's apology as a condition. "We would stop boycotting Hsieh's report so long as the DPP agrees to the formation of the five committees to obtain access to official files regarding the five controversial cases," Tseng said.
However, the DPP caucus insisted that addressing the legislature on the government's policy goals and work plans is the premier's official duty set forth in the Constitution.

"This sacred mission cannot be traded off and no political strings should be attached to it, " DPP legislative whip Chen Ching-chun said, adding that the DPP caucus would not oppose the formation of the five KMT-proposed committees if Premier Hsieh is allowed to deliver an administrative report at Tuesday's plenary session.

The five KMT-proposed committees are supposed to look into suspected corruption in the construction projects of the Kaohsiung rapid transit system and Taiwan's first high-speed railway, the second phase of the government's financial reform plan, an insider trading scandal involving a senior official charged with the duty of preventing insider trading in the stock market, and the privatization of state-run Chunghwa Telecom.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO SPEAK FOR TAIWAN'S PLEA AT ONGOING U.N. SESSION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 18 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan should voice its support for Taiwan's plea for an active U.N. role in maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait, a Taiwan official stationed in Tokyo said Sunday.

Chu Wen-ching, the information division chief at Taiwan's representative office in Japan, made the call in a letter to the editors of the Japan Times that was carried in the English-language daily's Sunday issue.

In the letter, Chu said 13 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies sent a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan Aug. 11 demanding that the United Nations pay more heed and play an active role in ensuring cross-strait peace.
Because of China's opposition, the proposal was not included in the agenda of the ongoing plenary session of the U.N. General Assembly that opened Sept. 13.

Since Japan has voiced support for Taiwan in many fields, including Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's governing body -- as an observer and listing the Taiwan Strait peace as one of the strategic objectives of the U.S.-Japanese defense cooperation, Chu said he is hopeful that Japan can uphold this consistent stance and speak out for Taiwan's cause at the current U.N. General Assembly general debate session.

Chu said Japan's explicit support is important for Taiwan and for regional peace and stability because China has stepped up its military threat against Taiwan. The number of missiles deployed by China against Taiwan has been increasing rapidly and China already passed an anti-secession law that codifies the use of force against Taiwan if it thinks Taiwan is moving toward formal independence, Chu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD CALLS FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged the government Sunday to forge direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait as early as possible to maintain Taiwan's global competitiveness.
Soong made the remarks upon his return from a trip to Shanghai to attend a cross-strait economic forum, co-organized by the PFP and the Communist Party of China.

Soong said he was originally scheduled to return to Taiwan via the direct "mini three links" route, namely the direct shipping services between Taiwan-held Kinmen/Matsu and China's Xiamen/Mawei in Fujian province.

Due to a government ban, Soong said he dropped his original plan and instead returned to Taiwan via Macau. Under current regulations, only Taiwan businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " and residents in Kinmen and Matsu can use the direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services.
Soong said the government should ease restrictions on the "mini three links" and more importantly, forge full-fledged direct cross-strait shipping and air links as early as possible.

Claiming that the decades-long indirect cross-strait travel requirement has enhanced taishang's operational costs and undermined Taiwan's global competitiveness, Soong said the Democratic Progressive Party administration should not continue dragging its foot on this critical issue.

Meanwhile, PFP Legislators Chang Hsien-yao and Huang Yi-chiao, who accompanied Soong on his China visit, said they will push for a law revision to allow for more people to travel via the "mini three links" route and push for the opening of full-fledged direct cross-strait transport links by the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES REPORT ABOUT STATUS CHANGE OF NEW AIT BUILDING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) debunked a media report Sunday that the ministry has changed the status of a new building to be built by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) so that the building will be exempted from Taiwan regulations.
"The report is not true, " MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said, adding that the MOFA is not authorized to administer construction affairs or classify a building's status.

Lu said the AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, has not yet come up with any blueprint for its planned building nor has it presented an application for the construction project.

Since the plot of land to accommodate the new AIT building belongs to Taiwan, Lu said, the construction project definitely should follow Taiwan's regulations, including environmental protection and public safety requirements.
According to Lu, the AIT construction project will not get under way until after the U.S. Congress appropriates funds in 2007.
AIT, which was founded under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act -- the U.S. law governing relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, has offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
AIT signed a land lease with the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, which is AIT's parallel organization in Taiwan, last December for its new building construction project.

Under the agreement, AIT will lease a 6.5-hectare plot of land in Taipei's Neihu district to accommodate its new office building. The lease will remain valid for 99 years and the rent will be paid in a lump sum of about NT$339 million at the start of the lease.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESPECT FOR TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY BASIS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Peace talks across the Taiwan Strait should be based on respect for Taiwan's sovereign status, the Republic of China's representative to Germany said Sunday.
Shieh Jhy-wey made the remarks in a seminar with German scholars broadcast on Radio Berlin-Brandenburg's Inforadio.

Shieh, who obtained a PhD in German literature at the Ruhr University in Bochum in Germany in 1987, told his audience that all Taiwan people, regardless of their political stripes or preferences and ethnic origins, treasure their hard-won democratic system and lifestyle.

Noting that Taiwan opposes China's despotic political system, Shieh said Taiwan would be willing to sit down to talk with China whenever China forsakes its military threat and respects Taiwan's sovereignty.
With Taiwan's successful democratization, Shieh said the people of Taiwan yearn to be treated fairly and equally in the international community.

Because of China's suppression, Shieh said Taiwan faces diplomatic isolation. As Germany does not recognize Taiwan, Shieh said he has had to make strenuous efforts to overcome many difficulties forging contacts with German officials and parliamentarians since assuming his current post in May.
During those engagements, Shieh said he found that more efforts must be made to let Germans understand Taiwan's stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is MOnday, Sept. 19, or the 16TH day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1356: English soldiers led by Edward, Prince of Wales, known as "the Black Prince," defeat the French at the Battle of Poitiers, ending the first phase of the Hundred Years War.
1513: Vasco Nunez de Balboa, Spanish conquistador, reaches the west coast of the Americas and becomes the first European to cast his gaze over the Pacific Ocean.
1881: James Abram Garfield, the 20th president of the United States, dies at the age of 50. He was shot July 2 by Charles Guiteau, a frustrated office-seeker, after having been in office for just four months.
1888: The world's first beauty contest takes place in Spa in Belgium, and the 5,000-franc first prize is won by 18-year-old Bertha Soucaret from Guadeloupe.
1893: New Zealand becomes the first country to grant the right to vote to all its women citizens.
1928: U.S. artist Walt Disney releases the first animated film with sound, "Steamboat Willie," featuring Mickey Mouse.
1952: Charles Chaplin, British-born actor, director and producer who gained fame for his role as a tramp in baggy trousers and bowler hat, is dubbed "subversive" by right-wingers in the United States.
1957: The first U.S. underground nuclear test is carried out in Nevada.
1965: Republic of China Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo leaves for a visit to the United States at the invitation of U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.
1968: Malaysia severs diplomatic relations with Manila in protest over the annexation of Sabah by the Philippines.
1968: Chester Carlson, U.S. inventor of the Xerox photocopying system, dies.
1973: Che Yin-shou is named ROC ambassador to Swaziland.
1977: King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV and Queen Halaevalu Mata'aho of the Kingdom of Tonga arrive for a weeklong state visit at the invitation of President and Madame Yen Chia-kan.
1978: The Food and Drug Inspection Bureau is inaugurated under the ROC's National Health Administration.
1979: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Tuvalu.
1983: The Caribbean islands of St. Kitts and Nevis become an independent state called Saint Christopher and Nevis.
1985: A massive earthquake devastates large parts of Mexico City and the surrounding region, killing more than 7,000 people.
1990: The Red Cross societies of the ROC and the mainland reach agreement on procedures for the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants to Taiwan.
1994: Military leaders in Haiti agree to restore democracy after thousands of American troops sweep ashore.
1994: On behalf of their respective governments, the ROC representative in Washington, Ding Mou-shih, and the chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, Natale Bellocchi, sign a Trade and Investment Framework Agreement.
1997: Communist Chinese Party chief Jiang Zemin is re-elected with his hand-picked allies at a party congress.
1997: The ROC's Tobacco Hazard Control and Prevention Law goes into effect.
1999: Taiwan's wildlife conservation activists launch a drive to save Mikaido pheasants, an endangered species which has made Taiwan its home for more than 100 years.
2000: President Chen Shui-bien declares Sept. 21 the National Day of Disaster Prevention in the hope that it will help the Taiwan public foster a higher degree of awareness of disaster prevention.
2000: The U.S. Senate passes the legislation normalizing trade relations with mainland China by an overwhelming 83-15 vote, thereby putting an end to 20 years of annual congressional reviews of Beijing's trade status.
2001: Over 100 Tibetan refugees who overstays their visas receives their formal residency documents and are granted the status of Republic of China overseas Chinese residents.
2003: The first Democratic Pacific Assembly initiated by Vice President Annette Lu opens in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "While widening the extent of his knowledge, the moral man yet seeks to attain utmost accuracy in the minutest details. While seeking to understand the highest things, he yet lives a plain, ordinary life in accordance with the moral order."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EXECUTIVE YUAN SECRETARY-GENERAL ASSUMES POST

TEXT.P: New Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said Monday that he hopes Premier Frank Hsieh can deliver his administrative report at the Legislative Yuan without any hitches Tuesday.

Cho made the remarks after he took over the post from Lee Ying-yuan, who has been named the new Council of Labor Affairs chairman, in a ceremony witnessed by Vice Premier Wu Rong-i. Cho will also continue serving concurrently as the Cabinet spokesman.

Noting that Hsieh was blocked by opposition lawmakers from giving the administrative report last week, Cho said he hopes that Hsieh will be able to deliver the report this time and that the legislature will begin interpellation sessions and the review of the central government budget as well as several special budgets and priority bills.

On his new post, Cho said that he hopes he can serve as "a lubricant" among the heads of the government agencies so that their exchanges will be smooth and they can form a cohesive and competitive administrative team.
Noting that public approval ratings vary for the various government agencies, he also expressed the hope that the agencies' overall image can be upgraded in the shortest possible period of time.
Cho also lauded his predecessor, saying that Lee is the only person ever to serve two terms as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, adding that he has learned a lot from Lee.

Cho later called on various legislative caucuses to express his hope that legislative proceedings will run smoothly and that there will be rational communication between the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CLA HEAD VOWS TO THOROUGHLY REVIEW FOREIGN LABORERS POLICY

TEXT.P: The new chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs promised Monday that he will do his utmost to protect both foreign and local laborers' rights and interests.
Lee Ying-yuan, former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, made the promise in an interview with the Central News Agency after taking up his new post earlier in the day.

According to Lee, the top priorities of his new job are carrying out a thorough review of Taiwan's foreign laborers policy and pushing the Legislative Yuan to pass a bill to set up an organization aimed at monitoring and dealing with a fund for retired workers as these matters are related to the rights and interests of more than one million laborers on the island.

Lee, who has also served as a legislator, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and ROC vice representative to the United States, takes over for former CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu who stepped down over the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit System (KRTS).

Talking about the riot story, the new CLA head also promised that he will visit those Thai laborers now working for the KRTS as soon as possible as "one should stand up from the place where one falls down," he added.

"The riot is an individual case and a case related to human rights as well," Lee further said, stressing that he and his council will conduct a thorough review of the island's foreign laborers policy, including the quality, quantity and brokerage system concerning the hiring of foreign workers.

Promising that he will try to amend the nation's employment and service law to improve employers' treatment of foreign workers, Lee said that if an employer does not properly manage and take care of his or her labor force's living arrangements and conditions, he or she will face criminal prosecution.

Lee also said that he will adjust part of the council's agencies' work in order to improve the management and inspection of the council over the employment process and living conditions of foreign laborers.

Claiming that one of his top priorities is to protect local workers' interests and rights, Lee said that the retired workers fund will soon amount to NT$10 billion and that he will discuss the issue with the opposition political parties in a bid to push for the legislature to pass the bill relating to the establishment of an organization overseeing the operation of the pension fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SIGNS COOPERATIVE PACT WITH MERCY CORPS ON AID TO IRAQ

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Mercy Corps Monday on the second phase of an information technology aid program in Iraq.
Yang Maysing, director of MOFA's Research and Planning Board, signed the agreement with Xu Dan, Mercy Corps' Asia-Pacific chief executive officer, on behalf of the two sides.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Taiwan wants to show the world through this program its determination to give back what it has received from the international community in the course of its development.
"The aid program is also aimed at conveying our sincere friendship to the Iraqi people," Chen said.

During a recent United Nations summit meeting, Chen said, many world leaders called for aid to these people based on humanitarianism. Even though Taiwan has been barring from the United Nations for more than three decades, Chen said, Taiwan has never hesitated to offer humanitarian aid to needy countries.

In cooperation with Mercy Corps, Taiwan has assisted in setting up computer classrooms in Khanaqin, which lies northeast of Baghdad. and building a public Internet networking service center in the region as the first phase of the aid program.

MOFA officials said that in the second phase, Taiwan will assist in completing computer networking services at 14 junior and senior high schools in Khanaqin and its education ministry where Taiwan-financed computer classrooms have been established.

Moreover, the officials said, Taiwan will help with a manpower training program for teachers and students at the Taiwan-financed public Internet networking service center so that they can run the center on their own in the future.

Two Iraqi youths traveled to Taipei last December to attend a presentation on Taiwan's aid program and post-war relief work in Iraq. They also conveyed Khanaqin citizens' gratitude for Taiwan's assistance.

Since the public networking center was completed in January this year, the officials said, Iraqi students have regularly exchanged e-mails with their Taiwan counterparts at 10 junior and senior high schools recommended by the Ministry of Education.

Mercy Corps is a noted U.S.-based non-governmental and not-for-profit organization dedicated to humanitarian aid and development activities. Taiwan has been cooperating with it in carrying out post-war aid programs in Iraq since 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: FEMA's Woes Were Merely the Beginning. The federal government's efforts to help victims of Hurricane Katrina have been hobbled by inadequate planning and coordination,trouble computer systems and confusion over who will pay the costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENT LAWMAKER LI AO DEPARTS FOR CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Li Ao departed for China via Hong Kong for a 12-day visit Monday.

Li, also a prolific writer, historian and TV commentator, is being accompanied by his 12-year-old son as well as 300 books on his first return to Beijing since leaving the city 57 years ago at the age of 13.
He said the trip will mainly be to speak at three noted universities -- Peking University, Tsinghua University and Fudan University -- and attend seminars.
He wouldn't divulge the contents of his speeches, saying only that if he revealed them, Beijing authorities wouldn't let him speak.
"I love Taiwan and will definitely speak for the island," Li Ao said.

Peking University will be the highlight of Li's trip, and as his father Li Ting-yi is a graduate of the prestigious university, the school has decided to roll out the red carpet for the "outstanding son" of its distinguished alumnus.
Li is also expected to visit his daughter, born out of wedlock, in Beijing.

Asked to comment on cross-strait relations in an interview with a local newspaper, Li said that he would advise Beijing that "the issue will require time, rather than the saber-rattling of deploying missiles against Taiwan."
"After all, Taiwan has been separated from the mainland for 110 years since it was seceded to Japan in 1895," he added.

On why he has not thought about revisiting the mainland for more than half a century, Li said that at first, it was the Kuomintang which wouldn't allow him to go, and then it was the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and then it "became a habit of not returning."

Recently, he said, it has been his health that has prevented him from making the visit, noting that his right leg hasn't felt right and that he has brought a walking stick, given to him by former lawmaker Sisy Chen, along for the trip.

Lee said that he had originally planned to return to Beijing after the age of 80, but Liu Changle, chairman and CEO of Phoenix TV, who has helped arrange the trip to China, persuaded him to make an earlier visit lest he become too fragile by the age of 80.

Reports have said that Li, who is often called "master" because of his extensive knowledge gained from reading and who has gained notoriety for litigation and his biting criticism of political figures, has polarized his prospective audiences on the mainland. His fans in China have begun to whip up "Li fever" through heated discussion about him on Web sites even before his arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROP PRODUCTION PROFILE KEY TO UPGRADING AGRICULTURE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pointed out Monday that keeping a good crop production profile is critical for upgrading Taiwan's agriculture, a step that will help differentiate Taiwan's farm products from those of China and Southeast Asian countries.

Speaking at a training program for executives of farmers' and fishermen's associations, the president urged crop and fish farmers to help the government implement the crop production profile system as quality and safety are increasingly replacing price as key requirements on the market.

Chen said Japan and the European Union have already been implementing the crop production profile system, with Japan planning to ban the import of all farm products starting in 2010 whose production processes are not properly profiled.
As Japan is the largest export market for Taiwan's farm products, the president said Taiwan must prepare well to meet that requirement.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) initiated a sample program in 2004 to list 74 agricultural products in the crop production profile system to ensure farm-to-table safety.
Chen said building a system is often an arduous and difficult process, but this is a path that Taiwan must walk as the system has a great bearing on Taiwan's agricultural future.

He called on the government, producers' associations and farmers to work together in implementing the crop production profile system as a critical step to boost the nation's agricultural competitiveness.
He said he is confident, like this year's "champion rice" grower Lin Lung-hsing, in the future development of Taiwan's agriculture.

Lin is an aboriginal rice farmer in Chihshang town, Taitung County, what Chen calls "a minority among the minorities." But Chen said Lin worked very hard and ingeniously to improve his crop, eventually winning this year's championship, enabling him to get NT$11,000 ( US$332) per kilogram. Regular rice goes for about NT$30 per kilo.

But on the downside, the president called on farmers not to repeat what a minority of fish farmers have been suspected of doing -- using banned chemicals to raise gropers -- that could damage a whole industry.
He asked the COA to get to the bottom of the reported violations and ferret out the suspects so they will not damage the reputation of Taiwan's fish farming industry.
"We can never allow a few people's illegal acts to cause major damage to the law-abiding majority," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY MAINTENANCE BUDGET REDUCTION A CONCERN: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party lawmaker on Monday questioned the government's policy of spending less money on the maintenance of military equipment as "this policy will place military personnel in an unsafe environment."

According to Lin Yu-fang, although President Chen Shui-bian has promised publicly that the government will increase the nation's defense budget, the fact is that the government has gradually reduced military spending since the Democratic Progressive Party became the ruling party in 2000.

The legislator said at a press conference held earlier in the day that Chen promised to increase the national defense budget to 3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) within the coming three years; however, the budget introduced by the government for fiscal 2005 only reaches 2.42 percent of GDP, or a record low for defense spending ever introduced by the Cabinet.

Saying that the current national defense budget pays more heed to the purchase of sophisticated arms rather than the maintenance of old weapons and equipment, Lin said that this exposes the Ministry of National Defense's shortcomings of "attaching great importance to arms procurement and neglecting logistic services in the rear."

He further said that the spending on the purchase of spare parts of military equipment has sharply been cut due to the proposed purchase of Patriot III anti-missile batteries which has been included in the annual budget plan of the ministry.

Spending on spare parts in 2006 will be reduced by nearly NT$1.3 billion, or a decrease of 12 percent from the level of the previous year, the legislator said, adding that the budget introduced by the ministry for the procurement of various armed vehicles and spare parts of 18 kinds of military equipment in 2006 will also be cut NT$360 million, or a decrease of 20 percent from the level of 2005, which will certainly deteriorate the maintenance capability of the military.

Furthermore, as the ministry has decided to spend less in resolving the problems related to the storage of ammunition and the handling of useless ammunition, who dares to store ammunition in depots? Lin asked.

Noting that the government has repeatedly accused the "pan-blue alliance" of neglecting the nation's security, the legislator, however, said that actually, it is the government itself who turns a blind eye to the maintenance of military equipment and cuts gradually the budget for national defense.

The lawmaker also condemned the government for forcing military personnel into an unsafe situation and requested Lee Jye, minister of national defense, clearly explain why his ministry cannot get a sufficient budget from the government for spending on the purchase of arms and on the maintenance of old equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Germany election comes out with inconclusive result.
Both Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and his conservative challenger Angela Merkel failed to win a clear mandate to govern in Sunday's election. The narrow vote margin makes them difficult to forma a ruling coalition.
