DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Gazprom Unveils Shtokman Shortlist
Gazprom on Friday narrowed down the list of potential partners for developing the Shtokman gas field to five companies: Statoil and Hydro of Norway; France's Total; and Chevron and Conoco Phillips of the United States..

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: North Korea Says It Will Abandon Nuclear Efforts
North Korea agreed to end its nuclear weapons program in return for security, economic and energy benefits, potentially easing tensions with the United States.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: North Korea Pledges to End Nuclear Programs
North Korea pledged to drop its nuclear-weapons development and rejoin international arms treaties in a unanimous agreement Monday with other countries at arms talks, in the first-ever joint statement in more than two years of negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE ENCOURAGES STUDENTS TO CONDUCT OVERSEAS FIELD TRIPS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has been encouraging local high school students to embark on overseas field trips in recent years with a view to enriching their knowledge and fostering global perspectives.

As part of the drive, the ministry organized a delegation of high school principals, teachers and administrators to conduct a fact-finding visit to Japan earlier this month to gain a better understanding of the possibility of having high school field trips in the country.

Japan, with its preservation of traditional culture, is regarded as one of the best places for high school trips, besides South Korea, Saudi Arabia and Germany, according to members of the delegation that visited Japan Sept. 10-15.

The 75-member team was headed by Liu Yung-shun, chairman of the Taiwan International Association for Education Tours and the principal of Tamshui Vocational High School. The delegation was made up of principals, teachers and executive officials of around 70 high schools and vocational high schools around Taiwan.
The group, divided into five teams, made separate visits to Hokkaido, Fukushima, Chiba, Yamanash, and Shinshu prefectures. Liu said Monday that they were warmly greeted wherever they went.

Japan's long-term effort to preserve the ancient culture adopted by their ancestors is a good thing for Taiwanese students to learn, Liu said, noting that in the long run, more will be done to encourage youths to go on study tours to Japan.

Meanwhile, some members said their schools have long forged sisterhood relationships with high schools in many other countries, including South Korea, Germany and Saudi Arabia. Exchanges of visits by students and teachers with those schools have been on the rise in the past few years, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE DEFENSE MINISTER TO ATTEND CONFERENCE IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Sept. 18 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh said Sunday in Los Angeles that he will communicate with U.S. officials on contentious parts of Taiwan's arms procurement package when he attends the fourth U.S.-Taiwan national defense industry conference that will open in San Diego, California Monday.

Huo was referring to the long-stalled package comprising three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.

Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has blocked the passage of the package for over a year because opposition lawmakers say the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special one.

Huo, at the head of a delegation attending the conference, said that as the U. S.-Taiwan Business Council, sponsor of the meeting, is a non-governmental organization, the disscussions will also be non-official.

The two-day meeting will focus on the study of the current situation of U.S.-Taiwan military cooperation and the outlook of Taiwan's future defense needs, Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, said Sunday.

More than 100 people are expected to take part in the conference, including scholars and academics from think tanks of the United States and Taiwan, military specialists in charge of military cooperation as well as weapons researchers and military officials.
But Hammond-Chambers revealed that Richard Lawless, US Deputy Undersecretary of Defense, will not be able to attend the conference because he was preoccupied with the six-party talks on North Korea.

When Lawless spoke in the previous conference in Phoenix, Arizona, in 2004, he urged Taiwan's legislators across the party spectrum to support the arms procurement to show the country's determination to defend itself.
Edward Ross, a director of the Defense Security Cooperation Agency under the Department of Defense, will attend on his behalf. Ross will also read a speech prepared by Lawless.
Hammond-Chambers explained that he also invited Ho Szu-yin, director of overseas department of the opposition Kuomintang, to the conference to learn about the party's national security policy.
He also pointed out that the conference has in fact no direct relations with Taiwan's arms procurement package.

The issues to be discussed in the conference will be to explore the national defense needs of Taiwan through the perspective of professionals, adding that selling or supplying sophisticated weapons is only an option by U.S. industry, and Taiwan will have the final say.
Though Hammond-Chambers will visit Taiwan in mid-October, he said that his purpose will be different from a group of U.S. congressmen.
U.S. Congressman Rob Simmons (R.-Conn.) is arranging the delegation, which will mainly be comprised of members of the Committee on Armed Forces of the U.S. House of Representatives.
The delegation will come for Double Ten National Day celebration activities on Oct. 10 and will meet with legislators to discuss the long-stalled arms procurement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 15 points to close at 6,030, with 9,602 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 17 points to end at 6,023, with 4,605 contracts traded, while December futures lost eight points to finish at 6,032, with three contracts traded. June futures moved up three points to close at 6,042, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,045 for September, 6,040 for October, 6,040 for December, 6,039 for March and 6,039 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

September TE futures remained unchanged at 250.05, with 2,118 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 249.5, with 1,584 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 1.2 points to end at 250.45, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures lost 11 points to finish at 912, with 2,403 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 10.6 points to end at 908.2, with 2,161 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down five points to close at 919, with one contract transaction, while March TF futures lost 7.4 points to finish at 913.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.35 points to close at 6,035.59.
The bourse opened at 6,044.16 and fluctuated between 6,050.4 and 6,023.08 during trading. A total of 2.05 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$46.21 billion (US$1.4 billion).

Five of eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent and construction issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 509 to 373, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.165 to close at NT$33.096.
A total of US$828 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.992 and hit a high of NT$33.099.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CLA CHIEF PROMISES CHANGES IN FOREIGN LABOR POLICY

TEXT.P: The new head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) vowed Monday to review the government's foreign labor policy and asserted that a recent Thai workers' riot will not hinder relations between the two countries.

Lee Ying-yuan, the new CLA chairman who took over the post from his predecessor, Chen Chu, earlier the same day after he stepped down as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, made the remarks during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency following the changeover ceremony.

Stressing that bilateral ties will not be impacted by the protest staged Aug. 21 by Thai laborers working on the construction of the Kaohsiung mass rapid train system in southern Taiwan, Lee pledged to make adequate foreign labor policy adjustments to deal with possible consequences of the incident -- the first of its kind in Taiwan.

A policy overhaul will be the top priority on the CLA agenda under his leadership, Lee said, adding that the council will invite scholars, labor groups and government officials to debate possible changes next month at the earliest.
In terms of foreign labor management, the CLA will revise the Employment Service Act to include foreign workers in its scope and a draft plan will be put forward in two weeks, he said.

Turning to the question of whether foreign laborers should enjoy the minimum wage protection as Taiwan workers do -- NT$15,840 (US$480) per month since 1997, he called it a controversial issue that must be comprehensively discussed by all parties concerned.

According to Lee, the Thai government fully understands that Taiwan is the top choice of many Thai laborers willing to work overseas and that the Thai worker riot over poor living and working conditions was only an isolated case which was the result of poor management.

To help other countries better realize that Taiwan is a country where rights and interests of migrant workers are duly protected, Lee said that the CLA in the future will invite foreign diplomats or labor affairs officials stationed in Taiwan to visit their countrymen working here.

Lee also said that he will consider visiting some countries that have allowed their laborers to work in Taiwan to boost mutual communications and exchanges, citing his rich experience in foreign affairs.
Currently, there are more than 278,000 migrant workers in Taiwan, with some 94,000, or 34 percent of the total, coming from Thailand. Taiwan is the world's largest importer of Thai workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF SMALL, MEDIUM ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh met Monday with the heads of the financial and economic ministries along with about 40 representatives of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises and the Taiwan Federation of Industry to develop better communication channels.
The afternoon tea event, to be held every three months, was formed based on the model of breakfast meetings between the National Association of Industry and Commerce and Cabinet officials.

Besides Hsieh, the officials joining the tea meeting included Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, secretary-general to the premier Cho Jung-tai, Deputy Central Bank of China Governor Hsu Yi-hsiung, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Hu Sheng-cheng, Vice Minister of the CEPD Thomas Yeh, Vice Minister of the Council of Labor Affairs Lai Chi-lin and Deputy Director-General of the Finance Supervisory Commission Lu Tung-min.

Addressing the meeting, the premier joked that the number of officials in charge of financial and economic affairs attending the event was larger than that for legislative meetings. He thanked them for the opportunity to be able to "reach the podium without having first to build five commissions, " referring to the opposition Kuomintang's boycott of his administrative report to the legislature last week.

Hsieh stated that he respects the work done by small- and medium-sized enterprises and the contributions they have made to Taiwan's economic development. Since taking the helm of the Cabinet Feb. 1, he has never stopped thinking of ways to support and encourage the development of these businesses.
"Only those who are in the business know where the problems are, "he said, noting that the government is very willing to hear from the enterprises themselves about what challenges they are facing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEAM WILL BE FORMED TO EXAMINE TAIWAN RAILWAY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Ho Nuan-hsuan said Monday that the ministry will set up a team to examine Taiwan's railway system to identify any possible problems to ensure smooth operations for next Chinese New Year holiday.
Ho said the team, to be composed of experts and scholars, is expected to submit a report by November.
Ho's announcement came in the wake of tens of thousands of passengers being stranded for hours due to faulty signals in Chitu, Keelung, Friday.
Asked if the faulty signals were the result of vandalism, he said that the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) is looking into the incident and will announce its findings.
He also said that the TRA has heightened its alert after several incidents were found where sections of rail in southern Taiwan were damaged on the 21st of the month. Sept. 21st is this Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR MAY ATTEND ASIA PACIFIC CITIES SUMMIT IN CHONGQING

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu received preliminary approval of the Ministry of the Interior to attend the 2005 Asia Pacific Cities Summit in Chungqing, western China, in October, but the final decision will be made at an inter-ministerial meeting called by the ministry at the end of this month, Taichung City officials said Monday.

There are 122 cities outside China that have expressed interest in taking part in the summit scheduled for Oct. 11-15, and 75 cities have confirmed that they will send representatives, including six from Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan, according to the summit's Chinese organizers.
Meanwhile, the Taichung City Council resolved Monday that Hu should get its approval before departing for the summit although he is under no legal obligation to do so.
Hu, who served as the country's foreign minister between 1977 and 1999, said he has not decided to attend the summit, although his aide is applying for the MOI's permission.

Hu who is seeking re-election in the December election, said as a candidate, he prefers to stay in Taichung to manage his campaign rather than visit China, but as head of the city, he should help enhance the city's profile on the international stage by attending the summit in Chungqing.
Although he didn't say explicitly whether he would go to Chungqing for the summit, he said he would give the city's interests priority while making his decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ACCUSES PRESIDENT OF BRIBERY IN MIAOLI ELECTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Monday accused President Chen Shui-bian of using bribery in an attempt to help the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) running for the post of Miaoli county magistrate in the Dec. 3 election.

Chen visited Miaoli County Sunday and met with County Magistrate Fu Hsueh-peng. News reports quoted a DPP legislator present at the meeting as saying that Chen promised to offer Fu an important position in the central government at the end of his second term as Miaoli magistrate if he is willing to help Miaoli Mayor Chiu Ping-kun win the year-end election to become his successor.

Fu, who was kicked out of the KMT prior the 1997 election, defeated the KMT's incumbent county magistrate in that election as an independent. He was re-elected in 2001. According to law, he can serve a maximum of two terms.

Reacting to the news reports, the KMT caucus in the legislature described the president's quid pro quo for Fu's cooperation in the election as "real proof of bribery" and urged the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office to take action.

The KMT caucus pointed out that Article 17 of the "Examples of Bribery in Elections" published by the Prosecutor-General's Office Aug. 11 describes one of the bribery acts as "offering or finding someone a job opportunity or better position" in an attempt to affect the election results.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said it would be unfair for the president to use national resources as a tool or reward to help candidates of his own party get elected.

However, the DPP legislative caucus attempted to defend Chen, claiming that he was acknowledging Fu's good performance as Miaoli county magistrate and offered to place him in an appropriate post should an opportunity present itself. According to the DPP caucus, this should not be "confused" with election bribery.

The Presidential Office public relations department later issued a statement saying that the president was hoping to put talent to good use in the government and that his offer had "nothing to do with bribery."

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTLYING ISLANDS IDEAL FOR CROSS-STRAIT FREE TRADE ZONE: PFP

TEXT.P: The establishment of a cross-Taiwan Strait free trade zone is a complex issue, but the government can take the initiative by using Taiwan's outlying islands to set the stage, according to a key official of the opposition People First Party (PFP).

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy center, made the remark Sunday during a stopover at Xiamen airport on his return to Taiwan after having taken part in a cross-strait economic forum co-sponsored by the PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Shanghai -- the first of its kind between a Taiwan political party and the CPC. PFP Chairman James Soong also participated.

Citing a conclusion reached during the forum, Chang said that the two parties share a common aspiration that a cross-strait "golden triangle" -- a free trade zone linking Taipei, Shanghai and Hong Kong -- should be set up for the benefit of all.

According to Chang, it would be easier to crystallize the cross-strait free trade zone idea by starting with the islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, in part due to the complexity of the matter and in part to help boost economic development in those areas.

At present, there are no direct airlinks between Taipei and Shanghai and the PFP is trying hard to help promote direct point-to-point flights in the initial stage with the aim of pushing cross-strait direct three links legislation through the Legislative Yuan by the end of 2006, Chang said.

Present-day economic relations across the strait are so close that they go "far beyond the imagination" of the people in Taiwan, he claimed, urging the government to place more emphasis on economics than politics. It also was the major reason behind the PFP's decision to hold the Shanghai forum with the Chinese, despite the long-standing political gridlock between Taiwan and China, he said.

The PFP is Taiwan's third-largest political party, and Soong paid what he described as a "bridge-making" trip to China in early May in the hope of helping bring Taiwan and China closer -- rivals since 1949 when the island split from China following a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO SEND TALENT SCOUTS OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is preparing to send a group of talent scouts to various countries including Japan, Canada and the United States in late September to enroll people in the high-tech and academic fields.

The planned delegation will be led by Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching and will be made up of officials in charge of economic and technological affairs, as well as representatives of 38 industrial and academic institutes around the country.

Lin explained Monday that the group will travel to San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Vancouver and Tokyo from Sept. 21 to Oct. 3, organizing seminars on each stop to advertise Taiwan's desire to enroll overseas technological talent.
He said this will be the first time Taiwan has expanded the enrollment to Canada.
Besides these plans, the delegation has also been commissioned to recruit retired Japanese senior technicians to work in Taiwan, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER ASSURES IWGA 2009 KAOHSIUNG WORLD GAMES ARE ON

TEXT.P: Senior Presidential Advisor Ye Chu-lan, who is scheduled to become acting mayor of Kaohsiung City next week, assured the International World Games Association (IWGA) Monday that the city will make the 2009 World Games a big success.

She told Peter Orzo, deputy executive director of the coordination group between the IWGA and the host city, that hosting the 2009 Games is a key administrative goal of the city government, that she is determined to see the games take place and that she will do her part well.

Orzo, deputy executive director of the Organizing Committee of the World Games 2005 in Duisburg, Germany, was visiting Kaohsiung at the invitation of Chen Yi-heng, executive director of the Kaohsiung Games Organizing Committee.
Orzo suggested that Yeh herself take over Chen's job when she becomes acting mayor next Monday, since in that position she will be more able to manage all aspects of the 2009 Games.

He also reminded her of the summer heat that could hit the city when the 2009 Games are held from July 16-26. Two other problems that she might have to consider are traffic in the city and training volunteers for the games.

Yeh accepted all his suggestions and promised that she will see to it that construction of all related facilities are completed on schedule and that the questions of traffic and volunteers are solved so that the games will be successful.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASKED PFP CHAIRMAN TO RELAY MESSAGE TO CHINESE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asked James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) to relay a message to Chinese President Hu Jintao in May, but the message was not about trying to resume the dialogue between Taiwan and China through a "flexible" explanation of what constitutes "one China," the Presidential Office said Monday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Presidential Office public relations department, made the statement to discount a previous claim announced Sept. 16 by James Huang, a Presidential Office deputy secretary-general, that the president had not asked Soong to pass any message to Hu.

The PR director would not disclose what was in the message, saying only that it was not, as U.S. State Department senior adviser James R. Keith said in a testimony at a congressional hearing, that Chen was willing to engage in dialogue with Beijing using a flexible formulation about what constitutes "one China."
"The Presidential Office never mentioned to the U.S. side about the president asking Soong to pass a message to China," he said.
Meanwhile, PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, speaking on behalf of Soong, said the U.S. State Department official told the truth but that the picture he presented was "not clear enough."

Chang explained that Soong agreed to meet with the president in February because the latter did try to modify his definition of "one China." Furthermore, he added, their conclusion at the meeting affirmed that the conduct of cross-Taiwan Strait relations should be based on the Constitution of the Republic of China, which provides that there is only one China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PUBLISHES PAMPHLET IN SIMPLIFIED CHINESE CHARACTERS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) released Monday an illustrated pamphlet in simplified Chinese characters detailing the olive branches Taiwan has offered to China.
It marked the first time the government has ever issued a publication in simplified characters, which are officially used in China.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said during an informal meeting with local journalists that the simplified characters version will be distributed to Chinese visitors to Taiwan as well as to Taiwan's representative offices in Hong Kong and Macau and local organizations with close exchanges with China, such as the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.

The illustrated brochure recounts the 30 olive branches that President Chen Shui-bian has extended to China since he assumed office in May 2000, including his now famous "five noes" basic stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Wu said.

Noting that goodwill, cooperation and permanent peace constitute the gist of the government's cross-strait policy, Wu said it is hoped that the new publication can help people in China to better understand Taiwan's basic position.
Wu said the publication also has an English edition, titled "Taipei's Olive Branches, " which will be provided to foreign visitors to Taiwan as well as to Taiwan's overseas offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS CANADIAN PM'S REMARKS AGAINST USE OF FORCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the Republic of China government and people are grateful for Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin's recent remarks that Canada is staunchly opposed to China's threats to use force against Taiwan.

"We admire Martin's concern and support for Taiwan when he told Chinese President Hu Jintao during Hu's recent visit to Canada that despite its 'one China' policy, Canada firmly opposes China using force against Taiwan, " Chen said while meeting with a Canadian parliamentary delegation.

Chen also hailed a proposed Taiwan Affairs Act being screened in the Canadian parliament. The bill, initiated by Jim Abbot, a member of parliament of the opposition Conservative Party, passed its first reading in April.
The proposed bill aims to "provide for an improved framework for economic, trade, cultural and other initiatives between the people of Canada and the people of Taiwan."

"We welcome any legislation that would contribute to the expansion of substantive Taiwan-Canadian relations, " Chen said, adding that he would be very happy and grateful if the bill finally clears the Canadian parliamentary floor.

Chen also took the occasion to express his gratitude for the Canadian parliament's passage of resolutions in 2003 and 2005 supporting Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's decision-making body -- as an observer. Because of Beijing's opposition, Taiwan has so far been barred from the world health regulatory body.
Stressing that disease knows no borders, Chen said Taiwan should not be excluded from the global epidemic-fighting network.

Over the past two years, Chen noted, about 20 of Taiwan's central government department heads and Cabinet members have visited Canada, indicating that high-level exchanges between the two countries are cordial.
Chen further pointed out that a Canadian court verdict once ruled that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state and immune to foreign criminal charges.

He also cited a number of official figures to prove close Taiwan-Canada ties -- Taiwan is Canada's seventh-largest source of tourists, with some 150,000 Taiwan people visiting Canada annually. Taiwan is Canada's 11th largest-trading partner and its fourth-largest in Asia, while 15,000 Taiwan students are now pursuing academic degrees in Canada.
Chen said he hopes bilateral commercial exchanges and cooperation in various fields can continue to grow.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO STOP OBSTRUCTION OF PREMIER'S REPORT IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said late Monday that they will end their attempts to stop Premier Frank Hsieh giving his administrative report in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, and seek a condemnation of the premier by the Rules Committee of the premier.

After fruitless negotiations earlier that day with their counterparts from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on a compromise to stop their obstruction tactics at the legislature, Tseng Yung-chuan, the director of the KMT's Central Policy Coordination Committee, claimed that the party's demands to set up five committees at the Legislative Yuan to probe five "scandals" involving the administration have already won the support "of the whole people."

Instead of continuing their obstruction of the premier's report, Tseng said his caucus will motion to condemn the premier at the Rules Committee Tuesday, and will grill the premier during the question time after his report about his responsibility for the irregularities arising from the construction of Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System.

He also took the chance to dig at his DPP counterparts in the legislature, saying that they asked for a meeting with the KMT caucus to work out a compromise to end the KMT's obstruction, but failed to show up, "bearing out the fact that they had no intention of ending the impasse at all."

Lawmaker Sun Ta-chien, the deputy whip of the opposition People First Party caucus at the legislature, said his caucus supports the KMT's decision, as the KMT has already made a point of stressing the premier's role in the Kaohsiung scandal.
The KMT's decision came after KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said earlier that day that the party caucus should "stop its obstruction tactics after achieving its goal."

The KMT caucus has succeeded in preventing the premier from delivering his report ever since the legislature began its session Sept. 13, demanding that the premier first apologize for his "groundless accusation" of the KMT concerning the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System and demanding the formation of investigation committees to look into five "scandals" involving the premier's administration.
The premier refused to bow to their pressure, claiming that it is his constitutional and non-negotiable right to present an oral report to the legislature.
Owing to the political impasse, the legislature ground to a halt, causing a public outcry, but nether the opposition nor the premier would budge until the KMT's about-face.

The premier said after the KMT's announcement that he would like to field the opposition's questions about the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit System, as it will be a good chance to set the facts straight.

The premier, who served as the mayor of Kaohsiung City from 1998 to 2005, claimed that many criticisms of the system stemmed from misunderstandings and baseless allegations, adding he is sure his answers will help the public understand the truth.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE IN TIMETABLE FOR CHINA-BOUND HIGH-TECH INVESTMENT: MAC

TEXT.P: The government's promise to allow local investors to set up a maximum of three wafer fabs in China by the end of this year remains unchanged, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

"The government's decision to permit local companies to establish up to three wafer plants in China by the end of this year has remained unchanged, " Wu said during an informal meeting with local journalists.
Wu said the MAC is working on regulations governing China-bound investment in wafer production and will unveil them when the time is ripe.
According to Wu, the MAC has so far not received any applications from relevant companies seeking to relocate their wafer plants to China or set up new ones there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE CENTER IN BANGKOK TO BE INAUGURATED IN OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Sept. 19 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Trade Center, to be founded by the Taipei-based Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , will be inaugurated in Bangkok Oct. 3, a Taiwan economic official posted here said Monday.

Kao Li-ming, the chief economic official at the Taiwan representative office in Bangkok, said the inauguration would be the culmination of a year of efforts by TAITRA, which has been exploring the possibility of opening a trade office in Bangkok since last year.
Kao said the trade center has got the greenlight from the Thai Foreign Ministry and Trade Ministry and will help Taiwan businessmen to break into the Thailand market.
He predicted that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Thailand, which stood at US$11 billion last year, will increase significantly with the opening of the trade center in Bangkok.

TAITRA is spearheading Taiwan's efforts to tap the markets of Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN) after ASEAN announced a program to phase out tariffs among its members and establish a free trade zone along with China, Japan and South Korea, Kao went on.
In light of the fact that ASEAN boasts a quarter of the world's population, Kao said TAITRA is working to open trade centers in Indonesia and Malaysia, two other ASEAN states.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Sept. 20, or the 17th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
480 B.C.: Greece defeats Persia in the naval battle of Salamis in the Aegean Sea.
1519: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan sets sail from Seville, Spain, with a fleet of five small ships in an attempt to circumnavigate the globe.
1580: Francis Drake, English naval hero and explorer who was the first Englishman to sail around the world, makes landfall in Plymouth, England, with his ship laden with treasures and spices. He was vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1853: Chulalongkorn, reformist king of Siam (now Thailand), is born.
1857: British forces capture Delhi in India, held by mutineers, after a three-month siege.
1914: The Chinese Revolutionary Party convenes a meeting in Tokyo to discuss revolutionary strategies and adopts the emblem of "a white sun in a blue sky over a field of crimson," an adaptation of Lu Hao-tung's design, as the national flag of the Republic of China.
1931: Britain abandons the gold standard, devaluing the pound by almost a third, in an attempt to halt foreign speculation in sterling and to prevent further gold withdrawals.
1932: Mahatma Gandhi, India's spiritual and political leader who preached nonviolence in his long campaign for freedom and social reform, begins his prison hunger-strike to protest the caste-segregated election system drafted by the British for India.
1934: Sophia Loren, Italian actress who married the man who groomed her stardom, Carlo Ponti, is born. She won an Oscar for "Two Women" and proved herself to be an able comedienne in "The Millionairess."
1945: The All-India Congress Committee under Mahatma Gandhi and Pandit Motilal Nehru rejects British proposals for self-government, calling instead for full independence.
1946: The first Cannes Film Festival opens.
1957: The first made-in-Japan rocket is launched from Akita Prefecture.
1959: America's Disneyland turns down a visit request by Soviet Prime Minister Nikita Khrushchev for security reasons.
1964: Peng Ming-min, political science professor at National Taiwan University, and his students Hsieh Tsong-min and Wei Tyng-jau are arrested for alleged acts of insurrection.
1965: The National Palace Museum is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1975: Cheng Feng-hsi, a disabled man and winner of the "Ten Outstanding Youths" award, dies of liver cancer at the age of 32.
1979: Dictator Jean Bedel Bokassa of the Central African Empire is overthrown in a coup by his cousin, David Dacko.
1984: The Council of Agriculture, a new government agency in charge of the ROC's agricultural development, is formally established.
1984: A suicide bomber with a truckload of explosives attacks the U.S. Embassy in Beirut, killing 40 people.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, who flew an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea on Aug. 24 where he requested political asylum in the ROC, arrives in Taipei.
1989: F. W. De Klerk is sworn in as president of South Africa.
1989: A French UTA DC-10 airliner crashes in the Sahara Desert in Niger on a flight from Brassaville to Paris, killing all 171 on board.
1992: French voters barely approve (51 percent) the Maastricht Treaty on European Union.
1998: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's sacked deputy prime minister, is arrested by police after thousands of demonstrators demand the ouster of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohammed.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui and visiting Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further reinforcing cooperative ties between the two countries.
2000: Cabinet Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin says that President Chen Shui-bian's monthly pay will be slashed from the current NT$822,000 (about US$26,516) to NT$448,800, starting Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian chairs a national security meeting to discuss the general international developments in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
2001: Formosa Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching leaves for South Korea for a four-day visit with his wife at the invitation of former South Korean President Kim Young Sam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Going over what he has already acquired, the moral man keeps adding new knowledge to it. Earnest and simple, he respects and obeys the laws and usages of social life."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT HONORARY CHAIR TO GREET ROC PRESIDENT DURING STOPOVER: STATE DEPT.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Monday clearly defined President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming transit stop in the United States as a "private and unofficial" matter and said that the honorary chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) will welcome Taiwan's head of state upon his arrival.

The president is scheduled to arrive in Miami Sept. 20 for a two-day stopover on his way to Central America. He is also scheduled to make a short transit stop in San Francisco Sept. 29 en route back to Taipei.

"I would note that President Chen's activities while he is in the United States will be private and unofficial, consistent with the purposes of the transit, " State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said at a press briefing.

Pointing out that when Washington receives requests for transit stopovers, it evaluates the requests on the basis of certain criteria, including safety, comfort and convenience of the traveler and respecting the traveler's dignity, Ereli said that "on that basis, we approved this request for transit."
He also said that Chen will be greeted upon arrival in the United States by the honorary chairman of the AIT, which is the private organization that carries out U.S. unofficial relations with Taiwan.

Although Ereli did not mention the name of the honorary AIT chairman, a State Department official said later that William Brown, who had served as the acting chairman of the institute after former AIT head Therese Shaheen left the post last year, will greet the president in his capacity as incumbent honorary AIT chairman.

In response to questions regarding the U.S. State Department's current estimation on Taiwan's human rights since it expressed concern about the island's media censorship in its 2004 Human Rights Report, the deputy spokesman said: "I think our views on that issue are a matter of public record and I'd refer you to the Human Rights Report."
The president is expected to receive a human rights award from the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus during his stay in Miami.

The main purposes of the president's trip to Central America are to attend the fifth Taiwan-Central America Summit slated to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25 and to sign a free trade agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart Sept. 22.
