DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DEPARTS FOR OFFICIAL VISIT TO CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his entourage departed Taipei Tuesday for Central America for a 12-day state visit featuring mainly a leadership summit to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25.

Flanked by Vice Premier Wu Jung-yi and Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, President Chen is scheduled to make a transit stopover in Miami Wednesday en route to Guatemala. In Miami, the president will be presented with a human rights award by the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus in recognition of his long-term efforts to boost human rights, democracy and freedom in Taiwan, officials from the Presidential Office said.

From Miami, Chen and his entourage will head to Guatemala Thursday where he will meet with Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo to jointly sign a bilateral free trade agreement between the two countries.

Prior to arriving in Nicaragua Sept. 25, Chen and his entourage will head to the Dominican Republic Sept. 23 for a two-day state visit. While there, a Taiwan softball team made up of members of Chen's entourage and reporters covering the trip will play the Dominican national softball team in a friendship game.
The fifth leadership summit of heads of state of Central American countries, Taiwan and the Dominican Republic is scheduled to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25.

The summit is expected to call together presidents from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, namely Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, in addition to political leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu.
Chen is scheduled to make a brief transit stop in San Francisco Sept. 29 en route back to Taiwan. He is expected to return to Taipei Oct. 1.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang and opposition Taiwan Solitary Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang are also part of Chen's entourage on the 12-day trip, the president's fifth to Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO ASK CHUNGHWA TELECOM TO INVEST IN HIGH SPEED RAIL: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government is not asking Chunghwa Telecom to invest in Taiwan High Speed Rail for the time being, and what the telecom company does in the future, as it has been privatized, will be decided by its own board, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.
Hsieh made the remarks in reply to a question posed by People First Party (PFP) Legislators Wu Ching-chih and Chen Chao-jung during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

The premier said the government supports the construction of the Taiwan high speed railway but does not have a policy of asking Chunghwa Telecom to invest in the project. Inauguration of high speed railway service was recently postponed by a year until next October.

As Chunghwa is now a private company in which the government is but a shareholder, the question of whether it will invest in the high speed rail will have to decided by its board of directors and supervisors, Hsieh noted.

The premier was finally able to deliver his administrative report Tuesday morning after days of filibustering by opposition lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and PFP. The interpellation session followed the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 69.76 points to close at 6,105.35.
The bourse opened at 6,015.98 and fluctuated between 6,115.54 and 5,994.46 during trading. A total of 3.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$83.54 billion (US$2.53 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues, both at 0.3 percent, and cement stocks and banking and financial shares, both at 0.2 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down by 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues losing 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 717 to 196, with 143 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO FIGHT 'BATTLE OF GLORY' IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang is set to use "battle of glory" as its rallying cry for the campaign for the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections, and the goal of the battle is "to win Taiwan's glory back," KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said Thursday.

The spokeswoman said that the KMT Cultural and Communications Committee has decided the party's campaign theme for the year-end elections and submitted it to the Central Standing Committee for endorsement.

Claiming that currently everything in Taiwan is going bad, from poor economic performance and a chaotic political situation to loss of social order and uncertainty about the future, Cheng said that losing confidence in Taiwan is the "saddest feeling at the bottom of the people's hearts."

Under the Kuomintang's rule, the people felt that their future could be filled with glory, she noted, adding that the Democratic Progressive Party "only emphasizes dignity, " which she said is widely seen as a kind of "sadness."

The spokeswoman also said the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been rather disappointing and well below the expectations of the people since it became the ruling party in 2000, adding that "these expectations have become illusions."

Fighting a "battle of glory" is for the purpose of winning back "the glory of Taiwan" as "this is a concrete and practical way of doing things, " she continued, adding that the KMT's goal is not to just gain more political power or to win posts for its candidates, but instead to ensure the future prosperity and confidence of the Taiwan people.
She also said that the KMT has promised to push for a clean and high-quality campaign in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO OBSERVE OIL PRICES FOR 3 MONTHS BEFORE DECIDING ON HIKE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the government has set a three-month period to observe crude oil prices and that it will only consider adjusting the price upward if the price remains high after that period.

The premier made the remarks while giving an administrative report at the Legislative Yuan. He was obstructed from giving the report twice last week but was able to take the podium after agreement was reached with opposition Kuomintang and People First Party legislators.

The premier noted that with the surging oil price, the privately run Formosa Petroleum Corp. announced a gas price hike of NT$2.4, or almost 10 percent, on Aug. 31. Normally, the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) would follow suit, but it didn't this time, mainly because of concerns about placing a heavier burden on the people.

He said that although the price of oil has now dropped to around US$65 per barrel, analysts have divergent views on the oil price trend, and this is why the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Council for Economic Planning and Development have decided to observe the situation for three months before determining how to act.
The premier said that during the three-month period, the government is considering adjusting downward the commodity tax for some petroleum products so as to reduce the pressure on the CPC.
He reaffirmed that not hiking gasoline prices and electricity fees will be given priority consideration and that there will be other complementary measures.
He also said that the consumer price index last month was higher largely because of the effect of rising agricultural produce prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST GAS STATIONS NOT ADEQUATELY INFORMING CUSTOMERS OF PRICE HIKES

TEXT.P: Most drivers don't hear about gas price hikes until they arrive at gas stations to refuel, and a majority of them aren't clearly informed of the hikes when they arrive there, Consumers Foundation Chairman Lee Feng-hsiang said Tuesday.

The foundation held a news conference in Taipei to publicize the results of its survey of 98 gas stations in Taipei City, Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County Sept. 15-19.

The survey found that 54 percent of the gas stations did not erect public notices of fuel price increases. Of the 46 percent that did, 80 percent displayed the notices in difficult to see spots, Lee said, noting that a similar survey in the United States found that almost all gas stations there have huge signs informing customers of price hikes.
"It's all about the right of consumers to know," Lee said, adding that "in Taiwan, the consumers always seem to be the last ones to know."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE GOVERNMENT TO EASE QUAKE VICTIMS' LOAN INTEREST BURDEN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Min-tsang and several of his colleagues urged the government Tuesday to help ease the loan interest burden of victims of the massive earthquake that struck central Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.
Lin was joined by KMT Legislators Yang Chiung-ying and Lai Shyh-bao as well as several of the earthquake victims from a Taichung community in a press conference at the Legislative Yuan.

According to Yeh Hsiu-chi, one of the victims in the 800-family community, more than 500 families in the community whose houses were damaged in the earthquake have been carrying interest burdens ranging from NT$300,000 to NT$1 million over the past six years, burdens that have caused depression for many of them.
"Is it because no one in our community died (in the quake) that we have not been able to see the 'eyes of care' from the government?" Yeh asked.
Lin pointed out that NT$180 billion of the government's NT$210 billion "921 Earthquake Relief Fund" was donated by the public.
Lai said the KMT caucus in the legislature will ask the ad hoc commission for rebuilding quake-hit areas to make a report to the legislature.

The KMT lawmakers called on the government not to raise interest rates for loans used specifically for rebuilding houses damaged in the quake, and to put off the deadline for paying back the loans when need be.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY REMAINS UNCHANGED: PANAMANIAN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Sept. 20 (CNA) (By M.S. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Lewis Navarro has told his Chinese counterpart that his country's cross-Taiwan Strait policy will remain unchanged, according to a news release issued by the Panama's Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday.

"Panama has no intention of changing its diplomatic relationship with Taiwan, nor altering its policy of maintaining a commercial relationship with China, " Lewis said while meeting with Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaozing in New York City Monday, the ministry said.

During the meeting, Li said that all U.N. members should normalize their relations with China, it said, adding that the two ministers also exchanged views on the development of commercial relations between the two countries during the past 10 years.
The Panamanian government has made it clear that Taiwan and China should resolve their own problems, the ministry further said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR KUNG FU NOVELIST JIN YONG IN TAIPEI FOR SHORT VISIT

TEXT.P: Popular kung fu novelist Jin Yong, whose knight-errant novels have been devoured by Chinese people across the world, is in Taipei to attend a party marking the 30th anniversary of the Yuan-Liou Publishing Co., which publishes most of the Hong Kong-based novelist's works in Taiwan.

The Shanghai-born Jin Yong -- Hong Kong's most eminent man of letters whose real name is Dr. Louis Cha -- is visiting Taipei at the invitation of Yuan-Liou's founder, Wang Jung-wen, for a series of celebratory activities, including the establishment of a Yuan-Liou Reading Studio in Taipei and the launch of "Jin Yong credit cards."
Jin, who has written 15 best-selling martial arts novels, met with a group of writers from Shanghai, including renowned novelist Wang Anyi, Tuesday morning.
He is scheduled to meet with his Taiwan readers over a dinner party Tuesday evening.

Most of Jin's martial arts novels have been adapted for films and televised drama series in the Chinese-speaking world. He is scheduled to preside over a ceremony Wednesday marking the launch of the "Yuan-Liou Jin Yong credit cards" designed to promote reading in Taiwan. The credit cards will be issued jointly by Yuan-Liou and the Taipei-based International Commercial Bank of China.
Jin arrived in Taipei Monday for a whirlwind visit. He met with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Academia Sinica Vice President Ovid Tzeng the first day of his arrival.

The soft-spoken, quintessentially Chinese man, now nearly 80 years old, is renowned not only as the author of the 15 kung fu novels but as a veteran reporter, publisher and political commentator. He was the founder of the Ming Pao newspaper and its sister publications.

Jin is considered one of the best and most prolific Chinese novelists of the modern era. But his 15 novels, written between 1955 and 1972, are more than just kung fu stories. Their pages burst with fantastic knight-errant tales of heroic swordsmen and beautiful heroines, intermingling romance, tragedy and comedy with Chinese and religious values.

Universities around the Chinese-speaking world have formed Jin Yong fan clubs, sponsored seminars or opened classes on Jin's classic novels, in which, Chinese readers can immerse themselves in their cultural heritage from the language, calligraphy, art, music, traditional costumes, cuisine and martial arts that they find in the novels. Traditional Chinese culture, fantasy and history form the colorful backdrops for his works.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO EVIDENCE OF GOVERNMENT-BUSINESS COLLUSION IN MRT PROJECT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh apologized Tuesday for government negligence in supervising the construction of Kaohisung's mass rapid transit system but he claimed that no evidence shows there has been any suspicion of collusion between the government and the private contractors in the MRT project.

Hsieh made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in reply to opposition lawmakers' questions concerning the Kaohsiung MRT scandal which has led to Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung mayor Chen Chi-mai stepping down. An investigation by judicial authorities is underway of Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien.

The scandal erupted Aug. 21 when Thai workers brought in the country to build the MRT system rioted in protest of poor living conditions and maltreatment by Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. that had been charged with managing them.

Hsieh said the riot was caused by "the businesses infringing on the rights of workers, " not by "the state infringing on foreign workers or the government authority infringing on the human rights [of foreign workers]."

Therefore, he added, the government has been investigating the incident and demanding responsibility according to law, but there has not been any evidence of the government trying to cover things up or colluding with the private sector.

He said Huapan's management problem is an isolated case, but he was Kaohsiung's mayor, and is now the premier, and so he cannot dodge his responsibility for failing to supervise Kaohsiung's labor and mass transit bureaus as well as the Cabinet's CLA, and "for that, I would like to apologize."

As to whether there has been any involvement by "the powers that be" or any breach of trust on the part of the government, he claimed that these questions are being investigated by responsible government authorities.

On the appropriateness of building the MRT system under the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model, Hsieh said adopting the BOT model has long been a government policy because the government budget is restrained as the economy is not doing well, and the government tries to give the private sector major projects to boost the economy.

Over the past 60 years, ever since the Kuomintang moved to Taiwan to become its ruling party until 2000, there have been many, many corruption cases, none of which involved a BOT project, Hsieh said, urging the people not to besmirch Kaohsiung MRT's BOT project simply because of the riot by Thai workers.

In fact, he boasted that by adopting the BOT model for Kaohsiung's MRT system, the government has saved more than NT$40 billion. And since the BOT project has been carried out, responsibilities would be confused if the government had to award building contracts and assign a vice chairman to the KRTC board.

In reply to KMT lawmaker Wu Ching-chih's demand to know whether KRTC has been "in collusion with" Hwang Chang General Contractor Co. Ltd., that won numerous government projects all around Taiwan, Hsieh said this is a typical example of "Tseng Sen kills a man," an ancient Chinese story of "many rumors make a truth."

Wu said KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, now under judicial probe, flew to Japan soon after the Thai workers protested -- "Was he trying to shirk responsibility by going overseas to make arrangements for future testimony?"
Hsieh said he does not know the details of Wu's story, and if Chen was ganging up with somebody to make a false confession at home, it would not be difficult to find out.
Wu claimed that no one would believe there has not been any government cover-up or government-business collusion in the scandal.

To this accusation, Hsieh said, "This is what is terrible about our society: We're saying Tseng Sen has killed a man, and then say it again and again. Even Mao Zedong boasted that telling a lie a hundred times will make it a fact."
"I cannot go against my conscience and say that something wrong is right and that something right is wrong," he asserted.

He emphasized that the decision to adopt the BOT model for Kaohsiung's MRT had been made before he took over the job from his predecessor, Wu Den-yih, and he was responsible for executing the BOT project and awarding the contracts, a process participated in by China Steel Corp. (CSC).
"Was CSC profiting [from the contract awarding process]? Was there any problem with CSC?" Hsieh asked.

Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said he will ask "integrity" officials to gain an understanding of the contract-awarding process but will not go into any individual case with regard to the KRTC controversy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLICITS JAPANESE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS FOR EDUCATION TOURS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is encouraging high school students to visit Japan for education tours, and is promoting reciprocal trips to Taiwan by Japanese high school students, Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu said Tuesday.

A group of Japanese high school principals are scheduled to visit Taiwan before the end of this year to sample the courses that may be open to Japanese high school students when they visit Taiwan for education tours in the future, Fan said.

According to Fan, the Ministry of Education began to promote international education tours in 2000 after it founded the Taiwan International Association for Education Tours, targeting students of high schools and high-school-level vocational schools for exchanges.

The program was suspended in 2003 after an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan, Fan said, adding that high school students from Taiwan and Japan have traveled to each other's country back and forth since the program was resumed last year.

Fan said that in addition to Japanese students, high school students from Germany, Saudi Arabia and other European and Western Asian countries have also made education tours of Taiwan over the past several years. A Russian group from a high school in Moscow is expected to arrive in Taiwan in November this year, she added.

Meanwhile, according to Kuo Chiu-yi, 2,657 students from 113 high schools from around the world made education tours to Taiwan last year. Of the total, 1,609 students were from 49 high schools in Japan.
A total of 1,300 Taiwan high school students visited Japan on education tour programs last year, Kuo said, adding that this figure is expected to be increased three fold this year.

The most prevalent motto in Japanese schools -- Greeting people by saying hello, valuing and respecting people-to-people relations and observing the law -- is perhaps the most valuable lesson that Taiwan students learned during their education tours in Japan, Kuo noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MORE IMPORTS OF THAI WORKERS FOR KAOHSIUNG MRT PROJECTS: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The heads of the Kaohsiung City department of Rapid Transit System (DRTS) and the city's Bureau of Labor Affairs (BLA) agreed Tuesday that no more Thai laborers will be imported for construction projects of the city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system after their employment contracts expire.

DRTS Director Lee Cheng-pin and BLA Director Fang made the promise in an interpellation session of the City Council after six councilors out of the 44-seat body asked that overseas workers on the Kaohsiung MRT system be replaced by local laborers.

The six councilors from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party made the appeal after the outbreak of a riot by Thai workers Aug. 21 on the MRT projects to protest against maltreatment by their managers. Subsequent allegations have been made of corruption by local officials.

Councilor Huang Shu-mai indicated that since the beginning of the rapid transit line construction in 2001, the unemployment rate in Kaohsiung has never shown a noticeable drop. She claimed this is because native workers are not hired in significant numbers on construction projects.
Her colleague, Eteng Yinai, an aboriginal Taiwanese, said that he knows many aboriginal people who are willing to work for similar wages paid overseas workers.
Hiring aboriginal people around the island to help build public transportation systems would also help the nations unemployment, Yinai suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL TOURIST SPENDING DEFICIT DOWN

TEXT.P: Helped by a larger number of inbound foreign visitors, Taiwan posted a smaller deficit in terms of international tourist spending in the first half of 2005, with the figure down by US$189 million from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the government Tuesday.

Taiwan earned US$2.4 billion in tourist dollars and spent US$4.27 billion in overseas travel in the first six months of this year, up by 29.7 percent and 9.2 percent year on year, respectively, for a deficit of US$1.87 billion, tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show.

Foreign visitor arrivals totaled 1.64 million in the six-month period, for an annual increase of 18.1 percent. Some 646,000 of those visits were for tourist purposes, a noticeable growth of 46.1 percent compared with the previous year's level. Meanwhile, outbound departures rose by 8.2 percent to 4.01 million during the same period.
Hotel occupancy rates averaged 71.1 percent during the first half of this year, representing an increase of 61 percent over the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: DONATE UNWANTED OLD COMPUTERS TO LESS PRIVILEGED CHILDREN: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is urging companies and individuals not to throw away any unwanted old computers, but instead donate them to less privileged children and low-income people in Taiwan's remote areas through the EPA's "PC rebirth program."

An official with the EPA's Recycling Fund Management Board said Tuesday that the EPA is prepared to spend NT$11 million to renovate 1,600 unwanted computers that have 586mhz chips or better and will install new software in the old units, and then give them to low-income people living in remote areas, including aborigines and schoolchildren.
He said that an unwanted old computer may be seen by some people as a piece of junk that just takes up space, but to a schoolchild of a poor family, it may mean a dream fulfilled.
The official said the EPA is still about 5,000 computers short of its target after its current campaign began early this year.

The campaign will end Oct. 31, and those who want to support the plan may find a collection point nearest them by checking the online information at: http: //www.istec.iii.org.tw/. They may also call toll-free at 0800-000-156.
Figures released by the EPA show that since 2000, the EPA has given away 2,700 computers to low-income people in 170 remote areas through its PC rebirth program.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM THANKS LEADERS OF FIVE ALLIES FOR SPEAKING FOR TAIWAN AT U.N.

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen thanked the leaders of five of the Republic of China's allies Tuesday for their vocal support in the United Nations General Assembly for the ROC's U.N. bid.

The presidents of the countries included Panamanian President Martin Espino Torrijos, Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte, Nauru President Ludwig Scotty, Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique de Menenes and El Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca Gonzalez.

They spoke for the ROC and urged the U.N. to pay attention to cross-Taiwan Strait peace in the first-round of the annual general debate of the U.N. General Assembly, which began Sept. 17 in New York and will run through Sept. 23.
The second-round of the debate is slated for Sept. 26-28.
At present, Taiwan maintains diplomatic ties with 26 countries.

Claiming that the allies all support Taiwan's U.N. bid, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it is expected that more countries will speak for Taiwan in the following General Assembly debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POPULATION AGING FAST: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is estimated to become an "aged society" by 2018, as its population is aging at a rate more than double the pace in developed countries, a government official said Tuesday.

Kao Hsien-kuei, vice director of the Performance Evaluation and Overall Planning Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that Taiwan will develop from an "aging society" to an "aged society" by that time when the ratio of its people aged 65 years or above surpasses 14 percent.

It will take another 13 years for Taiwan to become an "aged society, " double the pace of aging in Western and industrialized countries, Kao said, noting that Taiwan became an "aging society" in 1993, when the portion of its population aged over 65 years reached 7 percent.
It took France 115 years to go through the transition, while the United States took 72 year and Britain 47 years in the transitional period, Kao reported.

Citing CEPD estimates, Kao said that Taiwan will be an "elderly society" in 2026, when its elderly will make up 20 percent of its total population, according to the definition set by the United Nations.

Although an aging population will unavoidably deal a blow to a country's economy, Kao said that it also provides orientation for businesses to focus on insurance and financial services and health care products for elderly people.
An upcoming vice ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum slated for September will also discuss challenges facing an aging society for the first time, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR UNDER STRONG DEPRECIATION PRESSURE

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar has come under strong depreciation pressure due to Taiwan's weak economic performance and anticipated U.S. interest rate hikes, banking sources said Tuesday.

Judging from Taiwan's economic fundamentals, there is no room for the local currency to pick up in value, in particular at a time when the U.S. Federal Reserve is preparing to hike interest rates in the days ahead, sources said, pointing out that the new Taiwan dollar is more likely to depreciate gradually.

Although the new Taiwan dollar has depreciated less compared to other currencies, such as the South Korean won, it has widely been speculated in the domestic foreign currency exchanges that the local unit will further dip to 33.2 against the U.S. dollar in the near term following continued falls in recent days.
The new Taiwan dollar ended at a nearly 10-month low of 33.096 Monday in the Taipei Foreign Exchange against the greenback, losing ground by NT$0.165 from last Friday's finish.

Thomas M. F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that the depreciation of the local currency should help boost Taiwan's exports in the fourth quarter -- traditionally a peak season for export businesses.

Taiwan registered a combined trade surplus of US$1.17 billion for the first eight months of this year, an astounding plunge of 79.1 percent from the year-earlier level -- another major driving force that Yeh said has sent the new Taiwan dollar plummeting. In comparison, South Korea posted a trade deficit of US$15.98 billion for the same eight-month period.

It was reported in a CEPD meeting Monday that the South Korean government has set a goal of achieving an average per-capita income of US$20,000 for its nationals in 2008, causing widespread concern that Taiwan has been outpaced by South Korea.
Hung Jue-pin, head of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that in the meeting that in contrast to the general assumption, Taiwan actually performs better than South Korea.

Citing data provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the economic forecasting agency Global Insight, Hung said that Taiwan posted smaller reductions in export growth than South Korea in the first and second quarters amid a dwindling global economy since the beginning of this year.
The ADB also forecast that Taiwan's economy will expand by 3.7 percent for 2005, ahead of South Korea's 3.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 76 points to close at 6,106, with 26,876 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 97 points to end at 6,120, with 21,577 contracts traded, while December futures gained 83 points to finish at 6,115, with 36 contracts traded. March futures moved up 76 points to close at 6,100, with three contracts traded, while June futures moved up 60 points to close at 6,100, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,030 for September, 6,023 for October, 6,032 for December, 6,024 for March and 6,040 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
September TE futures moved up 5.15 points to close at 255.2, with 3,761 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 5.95 points to finish at 255.45, with 3,661 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures gained 6.4 points to finish at 918.4, with 3,720 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up five points to end at 913.2, with 3,589 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 1.2 points to close at 910.2, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.048 to close at NT$33.048.
A total of US$748 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$33.096 and fluctuated between NT$33.017 and NT$33.119.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO FORMER KAOHSIUNG MAYORS TRADE BARBS OVER CITY'S MRT PROJECT

TEXT.P: Two former mayors of Kaohsiung traded barbs at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday over their roles in deciding to adopt the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model for the city's mass rapid transit system.

Both Wu Den-yih, now a Kuomintang legislator, and Premier Frank Hsieh showed official documents to support their arguments, with Wu accusing Hsieh of lying and Hsieh firing back by claiming Wu does not know how to read documents.

Wu, holding an official letter dated March 12, 1999, pointed out that in the letter to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Hsieh said that after careful evaluations, the city government would suggest that the BOT model be adopted to build Kaohsiung's MRT system.
According to Wu, the document clearly shows that it was Hsieh who decided to build the MRT under the BOT model, and yet Hsieh told the media that he -- Wu -- made that decision, which was a lie.
Wu demanded that Hsieh step down as premier for "ill-intended shifting of responsibility and besmirching" his name. Wu added that if it were him that had lied, he would quit politics immediately.

For his part, Hsieh displayed an official document, dated Nov. 11, 1998, when Wu was mayor, sent by the Kaohsiung City Government to the Executive Yuan in which the city government proposed that the red line be built by the city government and the orange line be built by the private sector.
But on the eve of the election for mayor, on Dec. 4, 1998, the city government reversed the proposal by suggesting that both the red and orange lines be built by private contractors, Hsieh said.
So it is clear that the decision to adopt he BOT model for building the system was made during Wu's term of office, while he himself was merely "executing" the BOT project, said Hsieh.

In reply to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator William C.T. Lai's question, Hsieh said in addition to the Dec. 4, 1998 letter from the Kaohsiung City Government to the Executive Yuan which suggested private-sector participation in building the MRT, Wu has said that decision was made on Nov. 11, 1998. "This further confirms that the decision was made while Wu was mayor," Hsieh said.
Hsieh suspected that Wu "did not understand many things" or, if he did, he was just trying to humiliate him by asking him tough questions at the legislature, rather than to explore the facts.

Hsieh said that the issue here was about "truth, " and about "right and wrong, " and the truth here was that he had saved taxpayers a huge sum of money and yet has been smeared and falsely accused. Regarding this controversy, he said he feels comfortable with his conscience and he has no problem facing the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN GREEN CAMP" TO RALLY FOR MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, is slated to hold a large parade Sunday in Taipei to solicit public support for the government's military procurement plan.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office and acting chairman of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, said that several heavyweight committee members will take part in the march, which is being organized by the Hand-in-Hand Taiwan Alliance.
Yu, however, said that he has no idea of whether government officials such as Premier Frank Hsieh will attend.

According to DPP officials, the party is planning to mobilize more than 10,000 supporters from across Taiwan for the parade, designed to invite greater public backing for a major military procurement bill that failed again to clear the legislative floor earlier the same day.

The major military purchase bill, now valued at NT$340 billion after the Ministry of National Defense slashed its original spending by half, will allow the government to buy diesel-electric submarines, anti-submarine planes and anti-missile equipment from the United States in the face of the increasing military threat from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN NATIONAL DEFENSE INDUSTRY CONFERENCE OPENS
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Sept. 19 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The fourth U.S.-Taiwan national defense industry conference opened in San Diego Monday, with more than 100 representatives from the United States and Taiwan attending.

Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which sponsored the meeting, said that the two-day meeting is not directly related to Taiwan's arms procurement package from the United States.

He was referring to the long-stalled package comprising three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.

Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has blocked the passage of the package for over a year because opposition lawmakers say the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special one.

Hammond-Chambers said the annual meeting gathers think tank scholars, weapons researchers and specialists in military cooperation from the U.S. and Taiwan, as well as manufacturers from the U.S. defense industry, to allow them to understand each other's supply and demand.
He noted that the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council is a non-government economic organization that will only play a liaison role based on the needs of the two countries, without interfering.

Hammond-Chambers and Vans D. Coffman, vice president of the council, called on Huo Shou-yeh, Republic of China vice minister of national defense and head of the Taiwan delegation, right after the opening of the meeting to exchange views on issues involving defense procurement.

Hammond-Chambers said that his duty was to convey to Huo the intentions of the U.S. defense industry soliciting business opportunities in the hope that the U.S. and Taiwan can maintain good supply and demand relations.

Coffman said that although he concurrently serves as chairman of Lockheed Martin Co., he conveyed the hope of the U.S. defense industry for increased business opportunities to Huo in his capacity as vice president of the council.
Meanwhile, Edward Ross, principal director of the Security Cooperation Operations under the Defense Security Cooperation Agency, criticised the progress of Taiwan's national defense budget.

Ross took part in the meeting on behalf of Richard Lawless, U.S. Deputy Undersecretary of Defense, who was unable to attend the conference because he was preoccupied with the six-party talks on North Korea.

Ross lauded Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and his staff for meeting with legislators and communicating with them more than 170 times to attempt to facilitate the passage of a special budget to buy the arms.
He claimed that since U.S. President George W. Bush approved the sale of the arms to Taiwan in April 2001, "nothing" has happened in nearly five years.

The wrangling between the ruling and opposition parties has put the issue out of focus, he said, adding that it seems that political figures in Taiwan are enjoying the inter-party bickering and ignoring the real needs of Taiwan.

He noted that the Taiwan government's investment in national defense is not as much as in other items, pointing out that expenditure in economic and social welfare items are in double-digit growth while the increase for national defense is limited.

He said that if possible, he will appeal to the Taiwan people directly, because the matter involves the future wealth and security of the people. He added that he wants them to know that national security should involve political responsibility and that the Taiwan people should demand that the officials they elect take responsibility.

He said that over the past year or two, he and Lawless have been confronted by U.S. congressmen, officials and entrepreneurs with the same question of why the U.S. should supply Taiwan with its defense needs if Taiwan has no intention of investing in its national defense.

He said the gross domestic product (GDP) of Singapore is US$120 billion, and its national defense budget accounts for 5 percent of its GDP. In contrast, Taiwan's GDP is US$578 billion, but its defense budget only accounts for 2.4 percent of its GDP.
He lauded President Chen Shui-bian's recent request that the defense ratio be raised to 3 percent of the GDP, although he predicted that this will not be accomplished by Chen alone.

Ross said he is not advocating a cross-strait arms race, but reminded Taiwan that it should increase investment in its national defense so that it will be able to avoid the cross-strait status quo being changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BENQ HEAD: KEEP GROUP GROWING BY TAKING OVER OTHER FIRMS

TEXT.P: In order to keep growing, the Taiwan-based BenQ Corporation will not rule out the possibility of taking over other well-known brands in the world, the chairman of the computer giant said Tuesday.

With 10 days to go before his group will formally take over the mobile phone division of the Munich-based Siemens, K.Y. Lee said the deal, concluded in June, will inflate BenQ's cell phone business three-fold and will make it the world's forth-largest handset maker.

Lee said the Siemens mobile phone division has more than 100 outlets around the world and thousands of skilled technicians, quality controllers, and well-developed partnerships with component suppliers, providing BenQ with a valuable chance to move onto the world stage and cooperate with well-known companies around the world.
The takeover of Siemens' handset division will beef up BenQ's ability to come up with new products and will provide it with an efficient economic scale, Lee said.

Encouraged by the success in acquiring the Siemens' cell phone division, Lee said his group will keep looking for chances to acquire other brand-name products to enlarge the group's presence around the world.
He also predicted that the peak season for thin film transistor liquid cristal display panels (TFT-LCD) will arrive in the fourth quarter for the Christmas rush, despite rising oil prices.

Lee said the impact of surging international oil price on industries varies with different lines. For example, the world's auto manufacturers might feel the pinch sharply, but the electronic industry is not expected to be affected seriously, particularly not the manufacturers of computers and cellphones, which are the main products of BenQ.
However, Lee said, profits from these product are marginal because of a fierce price war prompted by a global glut of computers and mobile phones.
He said AU Optronics, a BenQ subsidiary that manufactures large TFT-LCDs began earning profits in the second quarter of this year and that the upward trend continues in the 3rd quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Storm Threat Halts Returns To New Orleans; Mayor Orders Wednesday Evacuation.
With Tropical Storm Rita bearing down on the Gulf of Mexico and growing political pressure from federal leaders, Mayor C. Ray Nagin said Monday that New Orleans residents could not return home after all and that any people already in the city should evacuate. (by Wennie Chi) EDNITEM

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy's Catholic church head opposes new rights for unmarried couples.
Cardinal Camillo Ruini, president of the Italian Bishops' Conference expressed his opposition Monday against granting new rights to unmarried couples. Speaking at a meeting of the bishops' conference, Cardinal Ruini said that supporting legitimate families ought to be the first and real concern of legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: OPPOSITION STAGING 'CULTURAL REVOLUTION-STYLE TRIAL'

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh denounced the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus in the legislature Tuesday for putting a motion of condemning him on the legislative agenda, claiming that the KMT caucus is staging a "Taiwan version of the Chinese Cultural Revolution."

The KMT and its pan-blue ally, the People First Party (PFP) , demanded that he apologize for allegedly lying about the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) project scandal and stopped him twice from delivering an administrative report at the legislature on Sept. 13 and on Sept. 16.

As Hsieh walked onto the legislative floor Tuesday, he was asked to comment on the KMT caucus proposal to pass a legislative resolution condemning him for not apologizing for his role in the MRT saga.
He said he would admit to any mistake he might have made but that he could not apologize under pressure from a pan-blue majority vote.
He claimed that the pan-blue alliance was promoting "the culture of forcing people to write repentant letters" -- a tactic used by the Red Guard during the Chinese Cultural Revolution of 1966-76.
Taiwan should not learn this from China, as the Cultural Revolution caused a 30-year social and economic retrogression, he added.
He claimed that the MRT controversy is a matter of "truth" and a matter of "right and wrong" that cannot be voted on but rather should be made clear with solid evidence.

When he finally made his administrative report and took questions from opposition legislators concerning the Kaohsiung MRT project, he did apologize for government negligence in supervising the construction of the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DISPUTES HUMAN RIGHTS AWARD FOR PRESIDENT FROM U.S. CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will send an open letter to the U.S. Congress to protest the presentation of a human rights award to President Chen Shui-bian by the congressional human rights caucus during his transit in the United States on his way to Central America for a state visit.
Former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi, who initiated the letter, told the media Tuesday that some 30 KMT legislators have signed it.

He said the president does not deserve to receive the human rights award on behalf of the Taiwan people because the government under his leadership has been involved in a series of scandals and disputes, including the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit railway project to protest their inhumane treatment.
The riot has dented Taiwan's image as a democracy that respects human rights and resulted in the resignations of Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chen Chu and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai.

Pan Wei-gang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, said the caucus will send another open letter to the U.S. government, accompanied with a record of what it described as "Chen's human rights violations."

Commenting on the KMT move, Chao Yung-ching, convener of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that an award for the president from the U.S. congressional human rights caucus should be an honor shared by all the people of Taiwan.
He said it is "very strange" that the KMT's legislative caucus wants to send a letter of protest to the U.S. Congress.

Chen, accompanied by an entourage, is in transit in the United States on a 12-day state visit to attend a summit in Nicaragua. He is expected to receive the human rights award from the U.S. congressional human rights caucus in Miami Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARES FOR DOMESTIC FLIGHTS TO BE RAISED

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) announced Tuesday that fares on domestic flight routes will be hiked by an average of 3.2 percent from Oct. 19.
Prices on western Taiwan flight routes will be raised by 3.3 percent, while those for the eastern and outlying island routes will be increased by an average 2.9 percent.

In terms of individual flight routes, the Taipei-Taitung route price will be increased by 5.3 percent, or a rise of NT$104, while the Taipei-Kinmen price increase will be between NT$72 and NT$94, and the Taipei-Kaohsiung route will be upped between NT$74 and NT$90.

CAA Director General Billy K.C. Chang said that domestic air ticket fares approved by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in January this year were calculated on an oil price of NT$13.63 per liter, but the price charged by the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. was NT$19.47 per liter in September, and the average oil price between January and September was NT$16.67, far higher than the originally calculated price base.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM IN MALAWI GETS FINANCIAL SHOT IN ARM
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung County, southern Taiwan, Sept. 20 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese medical assistance team working in Malawi received a financial shot in the arm Tuesday when two non-government organizations donated funds to support two of its projects -- treating AIDS patients and training midwives.

The Rotary Club of Pingtung donated NT$400,000 (US$12,000) , designated for the training of midwives, while the Taiwan Urbani Foundation bought a batch of AIDs test kits at a cost of US$13,755 -- enough for HIV tests for 1,920 people.

The medical team, managed by the Pingtung Christian Hospital, has been in Malawi for three years training midwives for Malawi, as the African nation has only two obstetricians. The shortage of midwives has resulted in a mortality rate of 113 deaths per 1,000 infants, ranking 17th-highest in the world.
The team is also running a "rainbow clinic" specifically to treat AIDS patients. Malawi is one the nations hardest-hit by AIDS.
Other assistance programs being carried out by the team include building a blood bank, providing mobile medical services and training health workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL CHIEF SLAMMED BY PREDECESSOR FOR 'NOT DOING HIS DUTY'

TEXT.P: The chief of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , Chang Kuo-lung, was slammed by one of his predecessors Tuesday for giving a greenlight to the opening of an interchange linking the village of Pinglin in Taipei County with the Peiyi Freeway.

Hau Lung-bin, who served as EPA chief between 2001 and 2004, said Chang had failed to do his duty by not stopping the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) from opening the interchange, which is set to bring more tourists to Pinglin, a quiet village at the center of the catchment area of the Feitsui reservoir. Tourists will promote the commercial development of Pinglin, leading to the pollution of the reservoir, which provides water to metropolitan Taipei, Hau claimed.
As a result, Hau warned, the reservoir will be silted up by persistent mudslides in a few years and its water will be polluted and no longer suitable for drinking.

Noting that at least seven EPA chiefs before Chang had resisted politicians' pressure to open the Pinglin interchange, Hau said their efforts were undone by Chang when he opened the interchange to the public.
The Peiyi Freeway has not yet been completed, but a section linking Taipei and a place near Pinglin has already been finished and opened.

Because of its location in a catchment area, Pinglin's commercial development is virtually prohibited -- to the great displeasure of its residents, who hope the interchange linking the village and the Peiyi Freeway will bring in tourists.

Their desire won the sympathy of Chen Din-nan, a former justice minister who quit his post earlier this year to run in the year-end election for the magistrateship of Yilan County which is where the Peiyi Freeway ends.

In order to win votes in Yilan County, Chen wrote to Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and EPA chief Chang Kuo-lung, asking them to open the interchange to facilitate the development of Yilan and Pinglin.

The MOTC decided Sept. 16 to allow a maximum of 4,000 vehicles to use the interchange through Pinglin per day, but the move only prompted traffic jams because too many vehicles wanted to use the interchange.
Hau criticized the decision as a politically motivated move aimed at helping Chen to win the election regardless of its impact on the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Sept. 21, or the 18th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1327: Edward II, King of England, is murdered in prison at the age of 43. He was defeated at Bannockburn by the Scots in 1314. Captured in 1326 and deposed in 1327 during the rebellion of Roger de Mortimer, he was imprisoned in Berkeley Castle.
1860: An Anglo-French force defeats Chinese troops at the Battle of Baliqiao while on the road to Beijing during the Second Opium War.
1898: A reform movement in China which met with strong opposition from the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi comes to an inglorious end after only 103 days. There followed a coup d'etat in which the Kuang-hsu emperor was imprisoned by the Empress Dowager and those who had played leading roles in the movement were executed or exiled.
1903: "Kit Carson," the first recorded Western film, opens in the United States. It is only 21 minutes long.
1939: Romanian Prime Minister Armand Calinescu is murdered by the fascist Iron Guard.
1944: American General Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines, attacking the Japanese near Manila.
1949: A Taiwan Garrison Command is established with Republic of China Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander.
1952: The construction of the Tienlun hydropower plant near the Tachiahsi River in central Taiwan is completed. Gen. Chen Cheng, president of the Executive Yuan, presides over the inauguration of the plant.
1957: Haakon VII, the first King of Norway following the restoration of Norway's independence, dies at the age of 85. He headed the exiled Norwegian government in London during the Nazi occupation of his country from 1940 to 1945.
1964: The island of Malta in the Mediterranean Sea becomes independent after 164 years of British rule.
1965: Singapore, the Maldives, and Gambia are admitted to the United Nations.
1967: The Sino-German Social and Economic Research Institute is established in Taipei.
1974: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the president-elect of Nicaragua, leaves Taipei for home after a week-long visit. He signed a joint communique with Vice President C.K. Yen.
1974: Tran Van Don, vice premier of the Republic of Vietnam, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Saudi Arabian Commerce Minister Soliman Abdul Aziz Solaim.
1981: Belize in Central America is granted independence from Britain.
1983: Riots follow a massive demonstration of half a million people in front of the presidential office in Manila, killing 10 people and injuring 92 others. The incident occurred after Benigno Aquino, President Ferdinand Marcos' leading political rival, was assassinated upon his return to the Philippines from self-exile abroad.
1989: Hurricane Hugo hits the east coast of the United States and leaves widespread destruction in South Carolina and Georgia.
1990: Xu Xiangqian, a former defense minister of Communist China and a veteran of the communist revolution, dies at the age of 88.
1991: The latest round of negotiations to hammer out an international treaty on climate change and greenhouse gases ends in deadlock in Nairobi, Kenya, with the U.S. refusing to set targets for reducing the amount of carbon dioxide emissions.
1992: The Vatican establishes diplomatic relations with Mexico, ending a 130-year rift.
1995: Economic Minister Chiang Ping-kung leads a delegation to the 19th Joint Conference of the ROC-USA and USA-ROC Economic Councils in Anchorage, Alaska.
1999: A strong earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter open-ended scale rocks Taiwan at 1:47 a.m., killing more than 2,400 people and injuring 11,000 others.
2000: Guatemala's Legislative Assembly passes a resolution to support the ROC's bid for membership in the United Nations and other international organizations.
2000: Former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, P.K. Chiang, urges the new administration to put aside political considerations and go ahead with the construction of the nation's controversial fourth nuclear power plant.
2001: A two-day seminar of Taiwan's Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) begins in Taipei to work out ways to cooperate with international NGOs.
2001: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , on behalf of the American people, donates US$25,000 to the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China to assist in the Taiwan reconstruction efforts after Typhoon Nari.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In a position of authority, the moral man is not proud; in a subordinate position, he is not insubordinate."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RECEIVES RED-CARPET WELCOME IN ALASKA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was accorded a red-carpet welcome upon his arrival at the Anchorage international airport for a transit stopover en route to Central America for an official tour.

Chen kept a low profile during his Anchorage stopover which was originally supposed to last for two hours but was extended to 12 hours because of the closure of Miami's international airport due to Hurricane Rita. Chen is scheduled to make a one-day transit stop in Miami Wednesday.
Alaska Governor Frank Murkowski, a long-term, staunch supporter of Taiwan, hosted a luncheon in honor of Chen and his entourage.
After the luncheon, Chen and his entourage toured a glacier area in Portage and visited a local tourist center, where the president viewed with fascination live ice worms on display.
This visit marked President Chen's second to Anchorage since November 2003.
President Chen and his entourage departed Taipei Tuesday for Central America and the Caribbean for a 12-day state visit featuring mainly a leadership summit to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25.

Flanked by Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, President Chen is scheduled to make a transit stopover in Miami Wednesday en route to Guatemala. In Miami, the president will be presented with a human rights award by the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus in recognition of his long-term efforts to boost human rights, democracy and freedom in Taiwan.

From Miami, Chen and his entourage will head to Guatemala Thursday where he will meet with Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo to jointly sign a bilateral free trade agreement between the two countries.

Prior to arriving in Nicaragua Sept. 25, Chen and his entourage will head to the Dominican Republic Sept. 23 for a two-day state visit. While there, a Taiwan softball team made up of members of Chen's entourage and reporters covering the trip will play the Dominican national softball team in a friendship game.
The fifth leadership summit of heads of state of Central American countries, Taiwan and the Dominican Republic is scheduled to be held in Nicaragua Sept. 25.

The summit is expected to call together presidents from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, namely Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, in addition to political leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu.
Chen is scheduled to make a brief transit stop in San Francisco Sept. 29 en route back to Taiwan. He is expected to return to Taipei Oct. 1.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang and opposition Taiwan Solitary Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang are also part of Chen's entourage on the 12-day trip, the president's fifth to Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES SEA WARNING FOR TYPHOON DAMREY

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for typhoon Damrey Wednesday, anticipating rough seas in the Bashih Channel and torrential rain for southern and southeastern Taiwan for the next several days.

The tropical storm, with a radius of 200 kilometers, was centered 410 kilometers south-southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi at 11 a.m. Wednesday, moving in a west-northwest direction toward Taiwan at a speed of 12 kph, CWB meteorologists reported.

Damrey, the 18th typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, is forecast to continue moving toward the South China Sea over the following two days and to directly affect the Bashih Channel area, the meteorologists warned, adding that ships operating in the channel, the southern part of the Taiwan Strait, and in waters north of the Philippines should be on guard against rough seas.

The eastern part of Taiwan as well as the Hengchun Peninsula at the southernmost tip of Taiwan are expected to begin experiencing heavy rain by nightfall Wednesday when these areas come under the influence of the typhoon, while the northern and northeastern parts of the island are forecast to see rain starting Thursday.

Meanwhile, Saola, the 17th typhoon reported in the Pacific, formed earlier Wednesday near Guam, the weather bureau said, adding that it is still too early to determine whether it will pose any threat to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND: TAIWAN TO SEEK RECIPROCITY IN ARMS DEALS WITH U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Sept. 20 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has asked the United States to make reciprocal technology transfers or purchases in its arms dealings with Taiwan, a visiting Republic of China official said Tuesday.

Vice Minister of National Defense Hou Shou-yeh said he has taken advantage of the just-concluded Taiwan-U.S. defense industry conference in San Diego to convey to the U.S. authorities Taiwan's desire for reciprocity in its arms deals with the United States.

Noting that other government departments have consistently asked foreign suppliers to make reciprocal purchases of Taiwan products or technology transfers whenever they sign major procurement contracts, Hou said the MND will follow this practice in its future arms dealings with the United States to upgrade Taiwan's defense technology and production capacity.
Meanwhile, Hou said he had smooth communications with U.S. defense officials during the two-day Taiwan-U.S. defense industry meeting.

"I didn't feel any pressure from the U.S. side," Hou said, adding that in additional to face-to-face talks during the meeting, MND officials maintained smooth regular contacts with U.S. defense authorities.
Following the defense industry conference, Hou was scheduled to travel to a U.S. military base Wednesday to get first-hand information about Taiwan military officers receiving training there.
Hou and other MND staff members attending the conference are scheduled to wrap up their trip Thursday.

More than 100 people took part in the conference, including Taiwan and U.S. think tank scholars and military specialists, as well as weapons researchers and military officials. The two-day meeting was sponsored by the U. S.-Taiwan Business Council, a non-governmental organization that groups U.S. companies with interests in Taiwan.
The two-day meeting focused on the study of the current situation of U.S.-Taiwan military cooperation and the outlook for Taiwan's future defense needs.

La Repubblica: Berlusconi proposes a single party for the ruling coalition after next year's general elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAISHANG' ARCHITECTS OF TAIWAN'S GLOBALIZATION: VP

TEXT.P: A new world trade map has been shaped and Taiwan is not lagging behind in integrating itself into this map, Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday, adding that Taiwan businessmen operating overseas -- known locally as "taishang" -- will undoubtedly play a role in facilitating Taiwan's globalization.

Lu made the remarks while greeting representatives of taishang at a meeting in Taipei Wednesday. She was speaking on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, who left Taiwan a day earlier on a 12-day official trip to Central America and the Caribbean.

Addressing the opening of the 11th annual meeting of the World Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce, Lu offered thanks and admiration to those taishang -- who traveled from every corner of the globe to Taipei for the meeting -- for their hard work overseas.

Globalization has increasingly impacted Taiwan and this impact has in turn become a challenge to the administration, Lu said, adding that Chen is expected to announce a "prospering allies" project during his trip overseas, aimed at accelerating Taiwan's globalization.
The "prospering allies" project is aimed at boosting Taiwan's exchanges and cooperation with diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean in particular, Lu noted.

As the U.S. Congress has passed a Central American Free Trade Agreement, paving the way for the formation of an immense American free trade zone, the American continent is expected to become the largest trade bloc in the world, where business opportunities will be unlimited, according to Lu.

Noting that Central America and the Caribbean -- the most steadfast area in terms of Taiwan's diplomatic engagement -- with a population of 890 million -- is poised to become part of the world's largest free trade bloc, Lu said the Taiwan government has mapped out plans to offer its development experiences in the agriculture, fishery and high-technology fields to allies in the region and will soon put those plans into practice.
Lu said that El Salvador will be the first country to see these plans carried out, followed by Guatemala and Panama.

Meanwhile, the vice president said that it has been six years since Taiwan was struck by the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999. Despite the devastation, Taiwan, a small island country, managed to "pull together and stand tall" in a very short period of time even in the face of China's persistent threats. This reflects the so-called "Taiwan miracle," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DENIES 'BUYING' HUMAN RIGHTS AWARD FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied that the government had "bought" a human rights award for President Chen Shui-bian, who was due to receive it during a transit stop in Miami Wednesday.

Ministry spokesman Michel Lu was responding to an allegation by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi, who claimed that the government paid U.S. public relations firm BGR (Barbour Griffith & Rogers) US$1.5 million a year or more in order for Chen to be awarded by the Congressional human rights caucus.

Two other PR companies hired by the government to promote Chen's image in the U.S., according to Su, are Cassidy & Associates, which was paid US$540,000 in April, and Laster Wolff, where the son-in-law of U.S. Congressman Tom Lantos works.
Su claimed that the government was "paying handsomely to buy a foreign citation" for the president.

However, Lu said the president was awarded on behalf of Taiwan's 23 million people because the U.S. recognizes their efforts in improving human rights and entrenching democracy, a move that has nothing to do with the PR firms who are hired to lobby for Taiwan.

He noted that the PR firms are part of the communications channels between Taiwan and the U.S. whose major tasks include smoothing the communications between Taiwan and the U.S. Congress and government, and enabling the U.S. to better understand Taiwan's interest in promoting democracy, human rights and peace at home and internationally.

Foreign Ministry officials said the ministry did indeed sign a three-year contract with BGR in March, under which the ministry will pay US$4.5 million to the company from 2005 to 2008. The ministry also signed a contract with Laster Wolff.
The officials said the ministry has yet to assess the effectiveness of hiring PR companies to lobby for the country.

The KMT legislative caucus demanded that the ministry publish not just its "buy America" projects, but all other projects in Central America and the Caribbean, where Taiwan's diplomatic allies are concentrated but where scandals have erupted involving Taiwanese government donations.
KMT Caucus Deputy Secretary-General Pan Wei-kang claimed that Chen's visits to these countries have turned into "bribery scandals" rather than expanding Taiwan's international space.

KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun said that during the past five years, Chen has spent more than US$500 million during his nine visits to foreign allies in food aid, cash donations and funds for building museums.
"Why doesn't he think of our own compatriots who are suffering from various natural disasters, particularly those poor children who cannot afford tuition and or even school lunches?" she asked.

Su Chi quoted Foreign Ministry documents as saying Chen has hired at least 12 PR firms in the U.S., much more than Lee Teng-hui, who was president from 1988 to 2000, and yet Taiwan's relations with the U.S. are not in good shape, its bid to join the United Nations is going nowhere, and worse, its donations to Central American countries have turned into one political scandal after another, proving that the government's diplomatic record is "worse than poor."
The DPP legislative caucus accused the KMT caucus of "humiliating, besmirching and striking at the president" who has been working hard to expand Taiwan's foreign relations.

DPP Caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai charged that the KMT lawmakers are acting like "Taiwan's Quisling, " trying to invite China to hit Taiwan, actions that show "it does not deserve to be Taiwan's opposition party."

The Washington Post: Rita Is Gaining Force in the Gulf; Unknown Path Of Storm Puts Katrina Victims On Move Again.
