DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR ACCEPTS RESIGNATION OF TAIPEI'S TOP CIVIL AFFAIRS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou accepted the resignation of city government Civil Affairs Department chief Ho Hung-jung Wednesday, saying that he respects Ho's decision, even though Ho violated no city government regulations.

Ho, 39, who joined the city government last August, tendered his resignation after the media gave wide publicity to an accusation by Wang Shih-chien, a city councilor of the Democratic Progressive Party, that Ho neglected his duty early this month when Typhoon Khanun hit Taiwan because he was vacationing with his secretary in Bali.

Ma pointed out that Ho asked for leave before he went abroad Sept. 7, and that the Central Weather Bureau's typhoon warning was not issued until 5 p.m. Sept. 9. Therefore, he said, Ho did not violate any city government regulations.

The Taipei mayor, who is also chairman of Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), added that he understood that Ho resigned because he wanted to be free from any burden when he takes legal action against Wang for allegedly spreading a rumor that he was having an affair with his secretary and claiming that they checked into the same hotel room.

Later Wednesday, Ho, accompanied by his wife, Lin Wen-shu, filed a complaint at the District Public Prosecutor's Office of Taipei against Wang, seeking damages for "malicious defamation" of his reputation.

However, Wang also went to the Prosecutor's Office and countered with a lawsuit, claiming that Ho made a "false accusation." He claimed that he did not make any personal attacks against Ho, but only questioned whether it was justified for Ho to spend a vacation with his secretary during a typhoon when he should have been at a disaster prevention and relief center.
Wang added that he never mentioned the name of Ho's secretary, and that Ho's private life and morals are none of his concern.

Ho's wife defended her husband, saying that she trusted him 100 percent. She explained that she had planned to go with her husband on the trip but did not make it because, as an employee of the Taiwan Business Bank, she had to support her colleagues in a series of sit-ins.
She explained that Ho and his secretary checked into the same villa, not the same room.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 30,000 TAIWAN STUDENTS WENT ABROAD IN 2004

TEXT.P: More than 30,000 Taiwan students went abroad to study in 2004, nearly 80 percent of whom opted to go to English-speaking countries, according to tallies made public Wednesday by the government.

A total of 32,525 Taiwan students applied for visas for academic purposes with foreign representative offices in Taiwan last year, up by 23.6 percent over the 2003 figure but down by 3.7 percent from the peak number posted in 2002, statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.

The United States attracted the largest number of students -- 14,054 -- while Britain and Australia came second and third, luring 9,207 and 2,246 students from Taiwan, respectively. The three countries wooed some 78 percent of Taiwan's overall students that went abroad last year.

On the other hand, a total of 9,616 foreign students came to Taiwan to study in 2004, an increase of 23 percent over the year-earlier level, the same tallies show. A vast majority of 7,647 of them chose to learn Chinese at language centers, while the remaining 1,969 studied business management, social sciences, economics and engineering at universities.
DGBAS officials said it is worth noting that 181 foreign students specialized in engineering, double the 2003 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC POSTED LOSS FOR AUGUST: MOEA

TEXT.P: Troubled by high crude oil prices in the world market, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) posted a loss of NT$2.512 billion (US$76 million) in August, becoming the only one of the seven state-run companies to operate in the red for that month, according to a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) report.

However, the CPC still managed pre-tax earnings of NT$13.685 billion for the first eight months of this year, accounting for 91.5 percent of the full-year profit target required by the government, according to officials of the MOEA's Commission of National Corporations.

The seven state-run units -- the CPC, Taiwan Power Company, Taiwan Sugar Company, Taiwan Provincial Water Company, China Shipbuilding Corp., Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. and Tang Eng Iron Works Corp., Ltd. -- posted combined pre-tax earnings of NT$550 million for August and earned an aggregate profit of NT$15.774 billion for the January-August period, more than double the target set by the government for the whole of the year, the officials said.
MOEA officials predicted that the CPC oil procurement cost will hit US$59 per barrel for September if global oil prices remain at their present high levels.
Premier Frank Hsieh said that the government will allow a three-month observation period before deciding whether to permit the CPC to further hike oil prices in the home market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG PRACTITIONERS PRESENT PROTEST LETTER TO H.K. GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By Lu Chien-hui and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Nearly 30 Falun Gong practitioners from Taiwan and Hong Kong asked Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang Wednesday to deliver an open protest letter to Chinese President Hu Jintao on their behalf.

They marched from the Hong Kong High Court to the headquarters of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region to present the letter after a court tried a case concerning the forceful deportation of 80 Taiwanese Falun Gong followers by the Hong Kong authorities in late February 2003.

According to a spokesman for the Hong Kong Association of Falun Dafa, the letter asked the Hong Kong court to persist in judicial independence and to urge the Beijing authorities to respect the "universal values" of freedom and human rights.

The Taiwanese Falun Gong practitioners separately visited Hong Kong Feb. 20 and Feb. 21, 2003 to attend a Falun Gong exchange conference but were denied entry at the airport and forcibly turned away by Hong Kong police even though they had valid Hong Kong visas.
A number of female practitioners were injured due to forcible deportation by the Hong Kong police and filed a lawsuit to the Hong Kong court against the violation of their human rights.
They also accused the Hong Kong government of using violent means during the deportation process and demanded punitive compensation.
Originating in mainland China, Falun Gong now has millions of adherents around the world. Beijing branded the group as a cult organization and banned it in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR `RESURRECTION OF WARMTH, TRUST'

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday he looks forward to a "resurrection of love and trust" that prevailed in Taiwan in the wake of the 921 earthquake six years ago.
Speaking at a Cabinet weekly meeting, Hsieh noted that Wednesday marked the sixth anniversary of the devastating 921 earthquake that rattled Taiwan in 1999.

"Its aftermath was truly a painful period for us. Nevertheless, it was also a moment when the people of Taiwan were most affectionate and unified. Many volunteers dedicated themselves to post-disaster relief and reconstruction work out of humanitarian concerns. There were a lot of heart-warming stories during that period, " Hsieh recalled.

At that time, Hsieh was mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, whose residents alone donated between NT$500 million and NT$600 million to help earthquake victims and the Kaohsiung city government built temporary shelters for surviving victims in Tungship and Chushan townships in central Taiwan, which took the brunt of the devastation, Hsieh said, adding that many southern Taiwan artists and writers also traveled regularly to many of the hardest-hit regions to offer counseling services or stage cultural activities to help surviving victims heal their psychological wounds.

Lamenting that Taiwan society has become far more polarized following the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections, Hsieh said he earnestly hopes that the warmth, love and trust seen in the post-921 earthquake period can be resurrected in local society.
"I yearn to see love, compassion, benevolence and trust prevail in our society without the need of a disaster," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LI AO ASKS CHINESE COMMUNISTS TO LIGHTEN UP
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan writer and independent legislator Li Ao used his first speech in China Wednesday to advise the 69 million members of the Communist Party of China (CPC) to relax and stop "wearing a poker-face."

Li also said that he hoped that the CPC will live to see its 1,000th anniversary, and told an audience of about 500 people at Peking University that all Chinese can "be carried on the back of the party, which will allow it to serve us -- what's wrong with that?"

Liberalism has been restricted in China not because Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai wanted this, but because "part of the Communist Party restricted the fundamental liberal spirit of their chairman and prime minister," he said.

He quoted a passage from Mao's "Little Red Book" to prove that Mao himself advocated the spirit of liberal debate: "Let the people speak up. If they have good arguments, we listen to them; if they don't, we refute them."

But he advised the faculty and students, whom he praised as "the creme de la creme of Chinese society, " not to play the revolution game with the CPC because unarmed civilians will never win over tanks and guns.

"The trick in winning freedom of speech is to speak in such a way that the other person listens to you; that is, express yourself in a sober, rational and jovial manner," Li said, adding, "never bang the table or throw chairs."

He said he knew many people were waiting to see whether he -- being often characterized as mischievous and having a no-holds-barred style -- would dare criticize the CPC on its home turf. Li said that for now, he would only like to praise the early Republican-era warlords whom the CPC and the Nationalist Party (Kuomintang -- KMT) had overthrown.

Li said the warlords had been broad-minded enough to make KMT member Tsai Yuan-pei president of Peking University, and allowed him to preach liberalism and the values of the universal spirit there, "So how are we qualified to criticize the warlords?"

Another liberal-minded scholar, Hu Shih, once said in Beijing, "If you fight for your individual freedom, you are fighting for your country's freedom, " a sentence that former U.S. President Bill Clinton also quoted while in Beijing, said Li, whose father is a Peking University alumnus.
Li continued to quote Hu Shih: "A group of slaves will never make a liberal and progressive country; such a country can be made up only of independent-minded and free-thinking people."

He said liberalism is made up of two things: self-reflection by individuals, and resorting to the constitution by the government. Thus, only highly cultured people can be called liberals and their society a liberal one, he said.
The key to liberalism is an open mind, without which no one can be called a liberal, he stressed.

To show his gratitude to Hu Shih, who he said had given him NT$1,000 when he was down and out, Li Ao said he has donated 350,000 yuan (NT$1.43 million) to have a bronze statute of Hu cast for display in Beijing.
A student who has seen Li's TV programs said Li showed his usual sharpness but still gave the impression that he was "a bit reserved" about criticizing China's ruling party.

Some Chinese journalists covering the event said Li spoke on so many things that they did not know how to write a story on the speech, and that they would ask their bosses before writing their reports.
As to party and government officials listening to Li's advice to smile and relax, they simply remained poker-faced.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES PEOPLE DOING BUSINESS OVERSEAS TO RETURN HOME

TEXT.P: Taiwan business people working overseas should return home "like salmon" and take advantage of the free trade zones the government has set up in Kaohsiung and Taichung, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.
Hsieh was attending a Mid-autumn Moon Festival gathering of Taiwan business people working in China, an annual event sponsored by the Straits Exchange Foundation.

He said the government was continuing to work on its policies of direct charter cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait, fruit exports to China and opening up Taiwan's tourism market to Chinese visitors.

As for the much-hoped-for direct "three links" between Taiwan and China -- direct air, shipping and communications -- he said formal discussions between the two governments must be held before direct exchanges across the Strait can take place.
He blamed China for introducing its Anti-Secession Law that he said had disrupted the government's schedule of opening the "three links" and other exchanges with China.
Hsieh said the government is building more free trade ports that offer tax privileges and boost export competitiveness to attract Taiwan's business people back to their home country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO INDEPENDENCE FACTIONS DISAGREE OVER TAIWAN SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: The leader of World United Formosans for Independence (WUFI) said Wednesday that he disagrees with the view expressed by the Taiwan Defence Alliance (TDA) in an advertisement in the Washington Post that Taiwan, like Puerto Rico and Guam, is an autonomous territory of the United States.

Asked to comment on the advertisement placed in the American daily Tuesday, WUFI Chairman Huang Chao-tang, who is also a presidential adviser, stressed that Taiwan belongs to the 23 million people who live on the island.

The TDA's advertisement said the United States should not mislead the world with the "one China" policy as in the 1972 Shanghai Communique, but should base its policy on the San Francisco Peace Treaty signed on Sept. 8, 1951 between Japan and 48 of the 51 countries represented. Japan declared in the treaty it would give up its sovereignty over Taiwan, Penghu and all its other offshore islands.

However, the TDA maintained that Taiwan is not part of China, and that the status of Taiwan is still undecided, as the Republic of China on Taiwan and the People's Republic of China on the mainland were not invited to the San Francisco Peace Conference, and neither were parties to the San Francisco Treaty.
Huang said that even if Taiwan's status is still undecided, eventually Taiwan's sovereignty must go to its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH PLANNED FOR SUNDAY TO PROMOTE GOV'T WEAPONS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: A pro-ruling party group is organizing a march on Sept. 25 in Taipei for the people to come out in support of the government's proposal to buy a package of weaponry from the United States.

The military procurement bill again failed to pass the legislative Rules Committee Tuesday -- the 29th time the opposition has killed the legislation from moving forward since the Ministry of National Defense put forth the bill to the Legislative Yuan more than a year ago.

Ng Chiau-tong, executive director of the Hand-in-Hand To Protect Taiwan Alliance, which is organizing the "925 march, " said that the event is designed to awaken the public consciousness and back the government's military procurement plan at a time when Taiwan's national security has come under increased military threats from China.

Ng also voiced his suspicion that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), lack the determination to defend Taiwan and are part of an orchestrated plot with the Chinese Communists because of their repeated boycott of the military procurement bill.
Lee Yi-yang, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that the KMT and the PFP are plotting to ruin Taiwan by preventing the bill from passing the legislative floor.

Various DPP heavyweight lawmakers, including William C. T. Lai, Trong Chai, and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Ho Ming-hao, appealed to their supporters across Taiwan to display the people's strength by taking part in the march because the country urgently needs to beef up its national defense and the Taiwan people must make this clear to the "pan-blue" forces.
The bill would allow the government to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States over 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ARRIVES IN MIAMI FOR TRANSIT STOP EN ROUTE TO GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Miami, Florida, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Miami Wednesday for a one-day layover en route to Central America and the Caribbean for an official visit.

Chen, heading a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, flew to Miami after a 12-hour stopover in Anchorage, Alaska, which was originally supposed to last two hours but was extended because of the closure of Miami International Airport due to Hurricane Rita.

Chen was greeted by David Lee, the ROC representative to the United States, and William Brown, who, as acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , is the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, upon his arrival at Miami airport at 6: 20 a.m.
Chen reiterated his resolve to keep a low profile during his current U.S. layover, saying he doesn't want to cause any trouble for U.S. authorities while they are busy preventing hurricane damage.

During his stay, Chen will attend a luncheon to be given in his honor by congressional members from southern Florida constituencies. In the afternoon, he will meet with former Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage and former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall Schriver at his hotel.
Moreover, Chen will hold an hour-long teleconference with 10-plus U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus members. The Taiwan Caucus is a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. Congress.
In the evening, Chen will have dinner with Taiwan expatriates residing in Florida.

The dinner was originally scheduled for Tuesday when Rep. Tom Lantos (D-CA) , co-chairman of the U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus, was to have presented a human rights award to Chen in recognition of his long-term efforts to boost human rights, democracy and freedom in Taiwan.
After the dinner was rescheduled for Wednesday, it remains uncertain whether the award presentation will take place as scheduled.
Lantos once said in private that if the presentation is not held Wednesday, he doesn't rule out the possibility of him traveling to Taiwan later to present the award to Chen in person.

Chen, accompanied by his entourage, is scheduled to leave Miami to start his Central America and Caribbean diplomatic tour that will take him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, as well as St. Kitts and Nevis.
During his 12-hour transit stop in Anchorage, Alaska, Gov. Frank Murkowski hosted a luncheon in honor of Chen and his entourage. Chen later toured the Portage glacier region in Alaska.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, FRANCE RENEW AGREEMENT ON CULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) and the French Academy renewed an agreement Wednesday to continue the Taiwan-France Cultural Award, which is aimed at boosting Taiwan's academic and cultural exchanges with France and other European countries.

The new agreement was signed in Taipei by CCA Chairman Chen Chi-nan and French Academy Permanent Secretary Michel Albert on behalf of the two sides. The French Academy is the highest academic institute in France.
The new agreement will expand beyond France to include exchanges with European countries.

Under the new accord, the Taiwan-France Cultural Award will consist of two prizes totaling 50,000 euros, which will be granted to those making outstanding contributions to academic and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and European countries.

The award has been presented since 1996. Previously only individual French scholars or research bodies were awarded. In the future, outstanding European researchers and institutes will also be qualified to compete for the award.

Also present at the signing ceremony were Larry Yu-yuan Wang, director of the foreign ministry's Department of European Affairs, officials from the French Institute in Taiwan, as well as three members of the screening committee for the Taiwan-France Award.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INCOME GAP AT FOUR-YEAR LOW: CEPD

TEXT.P: The income gap between the richest and poorest families in Taiwan has remained stable this year at a four-year low thanks to the government's social welfare programs, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Wednesday.

Incomes of the country's richest families average 6.03 times that of the poorest families last year and the lowest, the lowest rate since 2001, CEPD officials said, noting that the gap widened to a peak of 6.39 fold in 2001.

From the 1960s to the 1980s, Taiwan's income gap stood between four times and five times, with the levels increasingly growing to 5.18 times in the 1990s and to 5.55 times in 2000 before surging to 6.39 times in 2001, the officials elaborated. The gap began to drop over the past three years, with it falling to 6.03 times in 2004.

The officials hailed the falls over the past three years as concrete evidence of the government's efforts to promote social welfare programs that have benefited many low-income families, such as low-interest loans for buying houses and various types of government subsidies for the underprivileged and jobless workers.

Gauged by the Gini index, Taiwan scored 0.338 in the degree of inequality in the distribution of family income, slightly poorer compared to the 0.308 average of the member states of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development but better than South Korea's 0.35, Singapore's 0.48 and Hong Kong's 0.53, according to a CEPD report.
The Gini index is one of the most used indicators of social and economic conditions for measuring inequality in the distribution of family income in a country. A 0.4 rating is the warning threshold.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIES SPEAK FOR TAIWAN AT U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies protested Wednesday against the U.N. General Committee inadequately handling discussions of two proposals concerning the ROC's bid to join the United Nations, according to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

During a general debate session of the 60th U.N. General Assembly, representatives from the Solomon Islands and Gambia lodged their protests accusing the General Committee chairman of limiting the time and number of representatives who were allowed to voice their views when the committee proceeded to discuss whether the two proposals would be included in the agenda earlier this month.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen thanked representatives from the two diplomatic allies, saying if the U.N. cannot allow its member states to sufficiently express their views, U.N. efforts to promote its democratic concept will be in vain.

Meanwhile, the minister also expressed gratitude to Nicaraguan Foreign Affairs Minister Norman Caldera, Kiribati President Anote Tong, and Guatemala Foreign Affairs Minister Jorge Brize for their support for Taiwan's bid to gain a seat in the United Nations.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year through its diplomatic allies to have its U.N. membership bid placed on the General Assembly's agenda. However, it has been unsuccessful due to Beijing's obstruction.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, it has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT DEBATE BEGINS ON PRESIDENT'S CIVIL SUIT AGAINST TALK SHOW HOST

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court began debating Wednesday on the civil suit filed by President Chen Shui-bian against a talk show host on the grounds that he made an unfounded allegation that Chen presented a US$1 million check to former Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso.

The president, who is on a state visit to Central American countries, filed the lawsuit on Oct. 20 last year. A week later, Jaw Shaw-kong, chairman of UFO Radio, filed a countersuit seeking to restore his reputation while claiming that he obtained the information from a Web site.
Speaking to new media Wednesday, Jaw said that if the president is willing to withdraw the case, he would also be willing to retract his suit.
Jaw insisted that it was a fact that the government of Taiwan had given money to Panama, and that using taxpayers' money to conduct diplomacy is an issue that should be subject to public scrutiny.

He said it could be the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or another government agency that delivered the check, and that the president needed not put himself under the public spotlight by filing the lawsuit.
Jaw added that both sides would waste a lot of time on the suit and the countersuit.
The Presidential Office's deputy public relations director said Jaw will have to wait until the president returns from his overseas trip for a response.
The court will hear the case again on Nov. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED WRITER TO HEAD GROUP TO INSPECT ICDF OPERATIONS IN HONDURAS

TEXT.P: The International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) has invited Wu Tan-ju, a noted writer and radio and TV talk show host, to head a three-member private group to inspect its operations in Honduras, an official said Wednesday.
The group is scheduled to leave for Honduras in late October, ICDF Deputy Secretary-General Shaw Li-chung said.

It will mark the first time that private citizens have been invited to look into the ICDF operations abroad, Shaw said, adding that the move is mainly aimed at helping local people better understand the organization's overseas work and enhancing transparency.

The ICDF is a government-funded organization under the supervision of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to handle aid programs and technological cooperative projects with the nation's diplomatic allies and other less-developed countries.

ROC citizens aged 20 or over are welcome to register for selection, Shaw said, adding that a panel of judges will screen all hopefuls and then select from among them three most qualified candidates to join Wu's mission. Private social and academic groups are welcome to recommend candidates, he said, adding that hopefuls can visit the ICDF's Web site at www.icdf.org.tw to get more information. Registration will close on Oct. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HELP NOT PART OF ROC MILITARY COMBAT PLANS:MND

TEXT.P: Any possible help from the United States has never been a part of the Republic of China military's combat plans, a senior Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Wednesday.

Gen. Hu Chen-pu, director of the MND's political warfare department, made the remarks after Edward Ross, principal director of the Security Cooperation Operations under the U.S. Defense Security Cooperation Agency, said the previous day that if Taiwan is not willing to defend itself, the United States cannot assist in defending Taiwan.
Hu said the ROC military's combat plans have consistently been based on the concept of the island "fighting on its own" and help from the U.S. has never been included.
Ross made the remarks while addressing a session of the fourth U.S.-Taiwan defense industry conference held in San Diego Sept. 19-20. He criticized the slow increase in Taiwan defense budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Sept. 22, or the 19th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: Nathan Hale, 21, an American revolutionary soldier, is hanged in New York by the British as a spy. According to tradition, his last worlds were: "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country."
1791: Michael Faraday, British physicist and chemist, is born. He invented the dynamo, formed many of the principles of electricity, discovered electromagnetic induction, and proposed the field theory later developed by Maxwell and Einstein.
1792: France is declared a republic.
1860: China's emperor flees Beijing as Anglo-French forces advance.
1862: President Abraham Lincoln issues his Preliminary Emancipation Proclamation freeing slaves from Jan. 1, 1863 in rebellious southern states.
1862: Otto von Bismarck becomes premier of Prussia.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party renounces all communist programs, pledging full support for the Three Principles of the People and the abolishment of the "Chinese Soviet Republic" and its "Red Army."
1940: France allows Japan to station aircraft in Tonkin, giving the Japanese strategic entry into Indochina.
1956: Nicaraguan President Anastasio Somoza is assassinated, and his son, Luis, replaces him as president.
1961: U.S. President John F. Kennedy signs an act establishing the Peace Corps, an independent overseas volunteer program of the U.S. government.
1973: A three-nation armed forces soccer tournament opens in Taipei, with South Vietnam, the Philippines and the Republic of China competing.
1974: Finance Minister K.T. Li leaves for Washington to attend the annual conference of the World Bank.
1974: A 35-member delegation headed by C.F. Koo, president of the Sino-Korean Economic Promotion Council, leaves for Seoul to take part in the seventh Sino-Korean economic cooperation conference.
1974: K.H. Yu, governor of the Central Bank of China, leaves for Washington to attend the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund.
1975: An assassination attempt is made on U.S. President Gerald Ford in San Francisco by Sara Jane Moore.
1975: General Alfredo Stroessner, president of the Republic of Paraguay, is greeted at Taipei Airport with full military honors by Republic of China President Yen Chia-kan.
1976: Ma Chao-kuei and Chen Mien-hsieu, newly appointed as chairman of the Bank of Communications and chairman of the Bank of Taiwan, respectively, assume their offices.
1978: Taiwan's population exceeds the 17 million mark. The Ministry of the Interior reports that the population stood at 17,009,328 as of the end of August.
1980: The Iran-Iraq War breaks out when Iraq invades Iran in an attempt to take control of the Shatt al-Arab waterway.
1989: An organization for democracy in China is established at the University of Paris, with Chinese democratic activist Yen Chia-chi as its chairman.
1992: ROC Vice Foreign Minister John Chang and Oleg Lobov, chairman of Russia's Export Council, sign two diplomatic memoranda and a document of state protocol pledging the promotion of trade, tourism and investment, as well as cultural, scientific and technological exchanges.
1994: The chairman of the U.N. General Assembly Committee drops from the agenda the proposal for ROC membership in the United Nations after a 90-minute debate in which seven nations support the ROC and 20 oppose the proposal.
1996: Bob Dent, an Australian cancer victim, becomes the first man in the world to legally commit suicide, by lethal injection under a voluntary euthanasia law.
1999: An earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale rattles central Taiwan following the previous day's devastating quake which wreaked havoc around the island.
2000: Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chin, two mainland Chinese citizens who hijacked a civilian plane to South Korea in 1983, are convicted of murder by Taiwan's highest court and sentenced to be executed.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is moral order in the country, what the moral man speaks will be of benefit to the nation; and when there is no moral social order in the country, his silence will ensure forbearance for himself."
