DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Jakarta warns of bird flu epidemic.
Indonesia warned yesterday that a bird flu outbreak here could turn into an epidemic as international health experts scrambled to help Jakarta control the outbreak.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 37 countries support WHO to against the bird flu together.
Thirty seven Asian-Pacific countries have approved a strategy to counter emerging diseases such as bird flu at a regional meeting of the World Health Organization (WHO) .
But Dr Shigeru Omi, WHO's regional director for the Western Pacific, warned at the meeting in Noumea, capital of New Caledonia, that the plans could not be carried out without the help of wealthier nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Hurricane Rita Rattles Coast.
Hurricane Rita slashed past the Florida Keys and swelled in strength Tuesday as it treaded into the Gulf of Mexuco with 115-mph winds.
Whether forecasters warned that the storm could approach the ferocious Category 4 intensity of Hurricane Katrina, prompting massive preparations by jittery officials and residents from flood-numbed New Orleans to the Texas coastline.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Senate cites National Security Adviser in contempt
Senators had a hard time squeezing details about the RP Venable LLP contract from National Security Adviser (NSA) Norberto Gonzales at yesterday's Senate Blue Ribbon Committee hearing, prompting the committee to cite the Cabinet member in contempt and detain him indefinitely at the Senate building.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Gonzales says nothing, gets cited for contempt
National Security Adviser Norberto Gonzales, the central figure in a controversial contract between President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's administration and a US lobby firm, finally showed up before a Senate panel, left more questions than answers, got cited in contempt and ordered detained.
The Philippine Star: Security adviser refuses to reveal Venable donors
Questions over the government's contract with Venable LLP have become murkier after National Security Adviser Norberto Gonzales was detained for contempt yesterday by senators for stonewalling about Malacanang's dealings with the American lobby firm.
The Manila Times: Senate panel orders Gonzales detained
Failing to get what it said were forthright answers from National Security Adviser Norberto Gonzales, the Senate blue-ribbon committee on Wednesday cited him for contempt and ordered him detained.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Putin to Host Call-In Show in Days President Vladimir Putin will host a televised call-in show in a few days, and he is expected to use the event to readdress speculation that he might stay for a third term and to tout a multibillion-dollar boost to social spending. [By Chang Hung kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Koizumi's new mandate even gets LDP rebels' nod
Liberal Democratic party President Junichiro Koizumi was re-elected prime minister Wednesday by more than two thirds of the 480-seat House of Representatives on the opening day of the Special Diet session, with supporting votes coming even from some of his LDP foes. (by Mike Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION BULLETIN NOTES TERMS OF NEXT MAGISTRATES MAY BE LENGTHENED
DOC.DATELINE: Chung Hsing New Village, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Terms of office of county magistrates, mayors and local council members elected this Dec. 3 could be extended to Dec. 25, 2010, according to the bulletin published by the provincial election committee Thursday.

Whether the terms are extended depends on passage of a proposed amendment to the local government election law, according to the bulletin in which the date for the elections for county magistrates, city mayors, and county and city council members, as well as town and hsiang (smaller towns) heads was formally announced.

Huang Teh-wang, deputy secretary-general of the committee, said that in order to reduce the costs of holding the local elections, the Executive Yuan has drafted an amendment to the local government election law and expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan can pass it before Nov. 3.

If the amendment is passed, the tenures for the next magistrates and mayors will be extended to Dec. 25, 2010, from the current Dec. 20, 2009, while the tenures for council members will also be extended to Dec. 25, 2010, from March 1, 2010.

In addition to electing the county and city level officials, residents of Taiwan province will also cast their votes for town and hsiang heads on Dec. 3. The elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung, the nation's two largest metropolitan cities, will be held next year.
Another highlight in the bulletin is the details about constituencies, the number of elected council members in each constituency, and the spending limit for campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKED TO INVEST MORE IN NATIONAL DEFENSE
DOC.DATELINE: Miami, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Two former ranking U.S. State Department officials on Wednesday said that they hope that Taiwan can do more in its national defense investment and that its legislature can pass the arms procurement bill as soon as possible.

Richard Armitage, former deputy secretary of state, and Randall Schriver, former deputy assistant secretary of state, made the remarks ahead of paying a courtesy call to President Chen Shui-bian, who is currently in Miami for a one-day transit stopover en route to Central America.
President Chen, at the head of a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, arrived in the city earlier in the day from Anchorage, Alaska where he had made a 12-hour stopover.

In response to media questions regarding what issues he will discuss with Chen during the meeting, Armitage said that he hopes to have a better understanding of the president's current thoughts on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Touching on how to resolve the problems related to the long-stalled arms procurement bill in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, the former deputy secretary of state said that he will first discuss the matter with Taiwan's head of state. "I hope they will pass (the bill)," he added.

Meanwhile, Schriver also told the reporters that the United States safeguards the security in the Taiwan Strait in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act. If Taiwan prefers not to invest a little bit more in its national defense, "it will become harder for us," he said.

Besides the two former officials, Terresa Shaheen, former chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , a quasi-official organization in charge of U.S. relations with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two nations, also met with the president.
The two former officials also joined AIT Honorary Chairman William Brown to participate in a luncheon hosted in the president's honor by congressional members from southern Florida constituencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN WILLING TO HOLD 'RATIONAL DIALOGUE' WITH PRC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Miami, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday in Miami that he is willing to hold "rational dialogue" with his People's Republic of China counterpart Hu Jintao without any preconditions.
Such dialogue, which could be held any time and anywhere, would be aimed at creating a "window of opportunity" for "democratic Taiwan and democratic China to co-exist," the president said.

He made the offer during a banquet given by Taiwanese expatriates in the southern Florida city in honor of him as he received a human rights award from the human rights caucus of the U.S. Congress via teleconference. The president and his entourage were on a one-day transit stopover en route to Central America for an official visit.

Chen pointed out that "democratic Taiwan" and "human rights Taiwan" have been realized despite the climate of Chinese military intimidation, diplomatic suppression and the threats of China's united front tactics.

Countries around the world can be divided into two groups today, he said: one is a "community of democracies" that embraces freedom and progress and pursues peace, stability and prosperity; and the other is one of "anti-democracies" that deprive the people of their rights to freedom and democracy while threatening regional and global security and order with militarism and terrorism.
He said he fully understands the world community is expecting Taiwan and China to reopen dialogue in order to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait.

"But I have to seriously remind the world community that the problem between Taiwan and China is by no means a problem of A working with B to jointly manage or maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait," he said.

The crux of the issue is that China is avoiding dialogue with Taiwan's popularly elected government and, worse, is targeting missiles at Taiwan and using its so-called "Anti-Secession Law" in an attempt to tackle the issue through non-peaceful means, Chen stressed.

He reiterated his thanks to the Bush government for repeatedly urging Beijing to talk with Taiwan's popularly elected government and president, a message that he claimed shows the United States' respect of "democratic Taiwan" and "human rights Taiwan."
The U.S. position also shows that cross-strait relations must be handled under the principle of respecting the 23 million people in Taiwan and gaining their consent, Chen added.

"In my mind, I have a beautiful vision about cross-strait relations, " he told the banquet participants, that is, a "democratic Taiwan" and "human rights Taiwan" will live in peace with a "democratic China" and "human rights China" and the two will work together for their mutual benefit and joint prosperity.

Based on that vision and on his analysis of the world situation, Chen said he would like to show his sincerity and good will again to "the leader across the strait" and invite him to shake hands and hold rational dialogue so that they together can open up a "window of opportunity for cross-strait peace and democracy."

Whether that window will ever be opened depends on people on both sides of the strait demonstrating their creativity and patience, and on the international community continuing to show its support and concern, the president said.

In this regard, he said the congressional human rights caucus could play a pivotal role in linking "democratic Taiwan" with "democratic China" and linking "human rights Taiwan" with "human rights China."
On behalf of the U.S. congressional caucus, David Ta-wei Lee, Taiwan's top envoy to the United States, presented the human rights award to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 95.28 points to close at 5,972.06.
The bourse opened at 6,017.25 and fluctuated between 6,039.85 and 5,966.16 during trading. A total of 2.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.15 billion (US$2.21 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up 0.3 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.9 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 737 to 184, with 137 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROPOSES 'ZERO-TARIFF' ON SPORT GOODS, BICYCLE IMPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Sept. 21 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan raised a proposal Wednesday under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) suggesting that members of the organization agree to cancel customs tariffs on imports of sports goods as well as bicycles and spare parts, according to a source close to the island's permanent mission to the WTO.

The source said that harmonizing or cancelling customs tariffs in a sector-by-sector approach is one of the important steps in the Non-Agricultural Market Access (NAMA) talks of the Doha New Round of Trade Negotiations, adding that in order to achieve the goal of further liberalizing world trade and benefiting Taiwan's exports, the island has decided to push for "zero-tariff" for sports goods and bicycle products.

During a NAMA meeting held the same day, Lin Yi-fu, Taiwan's permanent representative to the world trade body, clearly explained why Taiwan has raised the proposal, saying that the "Doha Declaration" notes that the WTO members should cut or cancel customs tariffs for those export products that are beneficial to developing countries as they share 72 percent and 87 percent of the world's export markets for sports goods and bicycle products, respectively.

Pointing out that trade liberalization in sports goods and bicycles will fulfill various useful functions to help benefit both developing countries and developed countries, the representative also said that bicycles are beneficial to the natural environment and that sports goods have social and cultural value.

Statistics show that exports of bicycles and spare parts amounted to US$4.154 billion globally in 2003, and Taiwan ranked second in this category for the year, with exports of such products totalling US$970 million.
However, several of the world's major markets continue to have tariffs of as high as 40 percent on such products, which causes huge losses for exporters of these products.

The statistics also show that exports of sports goods amounted to US$11.743 billion globally during the same period, with Taiwan exports of such products totalling US$1.36 billion, ranking the island third in the world in this category. However, some countries continue to impose tariffs of up to 35 percent on such products.

In the proposal, Taiwan also said that a cancellation of import customs tariffs and an intensive strengthening of market access liberalization will certainly promote and expand trade in developing countries and developed countries.
Lin also said that Taiwan welcomes other WTO members to give an active and positive response to the proposal in order to achieve the goal of further liberalizing world trade.

According to the Taiwan mission, Japan and Singapore have voiced their support for the proposal, while Thailand has expressed support for the part of the proposal concerning the cancellation of import customs tariffs on bicycles and spare parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESSMEN WELCOME ROC PRESIDENT MAKING TRANSIT IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Fifteen members of the United States Congress' Taiwan Caucus warmly welcomed ROC President Chen Shui-bian who was making a transit stop in Miami en route to Central America Wednesday.

Through a teleconference, the congressmen and women congratulated Chen for winning the Congress' human rights caucus' award, and some of them suggested that the U.S. government change its policy and welcome Chen to Washington, D.C.

Under a long-standing policy, leading officials of the ROC that symbolize Taiwan's sovereignty, such as the president, vice president, premier and foreign affairs minister, cannot visit the U.S. capital.

Scott Garrett, who invited Chen to visit his New Jersey constituency, said probably the political climate will change in the near future so that President Chen will be able to visit D.C. If that happens, it will be a major move forward, he added.
Ileana Ros-Lehtinen said that during the teleconference, she told Chen that he has many supporters in the U.S. Congress. David Wu said he also hopes to greet Chen in the capital city.

In response to some Taiwan legislators' opposition to giving the human rights award to Chen, Congressman Steve Chabot, one of the caucus' four co-chairpersons, said just like the U.S., Taiwan is a democracy where people can express their views.
In the U.S., he noted, some people criticize President George W. Bush whereas others praise him, adding it's a pity that in the People's Republic of China, people do not enjoy freedom of expression.

Chabot said he was delighted to see President Chen win the human rights award because the president has been fighting not just for Taiwan's human rights, but also for those in other parts of the world.

He noted that the award should be presented in Washington, and it's quite unfortunate that cannot happen. He said he believes the U.S. policy of banning senior ROC officials from visiting D.C. will change sooner or later.
Those present at the teleconference quoted Chen as expressing Taiwan's concerns about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans and the Gulf Coast.

Chen was also quoted as telling the caucus members that Taiwan's democratic development is irreversible while Taiwan's from the ground up development of democracy can serve as a model for China if it wants to develop democracy.

Dana Rohrabacher, another co-chairman of the caucus, said the U.S. is adopting a "cowardly" foreign policy by fearing to offend Chinese dictators and not daring to show greater concern for those who are morally superior to these dictators, such as President Chen of the ROC.

Rohrabacher recommended that Chen, as a leader of a great democracy and a model for Asian countries, do more to assist the democratic development of Myanmar by supporting its people in their fight against the country's dictatorial regime that is supported by Beijing.
He welcomed Chen to visit his home in California, where he said he will organize a big welcome party in honor of Chen and people won't have to talk to the guest of honor via teleconference.

Sherrod Brown, also a caucus co-chairman, said it is absurd that Chen cannot visit Washington as a leader of a democracy given that he was allowed to before he became president. Brown had met Chen in his congressional office before he won the historic election in 2000.

Also greeting Chen at the teleconference were Robert Wexler, a caucus co-chairman, and Madeleine Bordallo, Mario Diaz-Balart, Phil Gingrey, Joe Wilson, Darrel Issa, Charles Rangle, Debbie Wasserman-Schultz and Roscoe Bartlett.

In addition to the Taiwan caucus members, quite a number of heavyweight congressmen and women and senators called the president at his Miami hotel to extend their greetings and best wishes, including Senate Majority Leader Bill First and House Majority Leader Tom Delay and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi.

Tim Johnson and George Allen, co-chairmen of the Senate's Taiwan Caucus; Senator Diane Feinstein; Roy Blunt, Senate Majority Whip; and Henry Hyde, chairman of the House Foreign Relations Committee, also made calls to the president.

Since its formation in 1983, 210 congressmen and women have joined the Congress human rights caucus whose purpose is to monitor human rights violations across the world and to encourage improvement of human rights conditions in all countries.

The House of Representatives passed Joint Resolution No. 237 Sept. 15 welcoming President Chen to transit in the U.S., and congratulating him for winning the human rights award and praising his efforts and determination to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S VISA WAIVER TO TAIWAN TOURISTS SIGNIFICANT: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday that it is historically significant for Japan to drop its visa requirement for Taiwan tourists.
Japan has agreed to offer permanent visa-free privileges to travelers from Taiwan starting Sept. 26.

Gary Lin, director-general of ministry's department of East Asia and Pacific affairs, noted that Taiwan and Japan have no diplomatic relations, but the Japanese Diet passed a new bill Aug. 5 to allow for permanent, visa-free status for Taiwan passport holders. In contrast, although China has diplomatic relations with Japan, Chinese still are not afforded the same preferential treatment.
Lin said that only Republic of China nationals who have registered their domiciles in Taiwan can enjoy the visa-free treatment.

He also said that Taiwanese tourists can only stay in Japan for 90 days at a time, and should not overstay. The visa-free treatment will be restricted to tourists, and they cannot work, or perform or engage in money-earning activities. The new regulation will also not be applicable to those wishing to study in Japan.
He urged the public to abide by Japanese law while touring in the country, saying that people must not betray the trust offered them.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL INVITES TWO FORMER MAYORS TO REPORT ON MRT

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Council decided Thursday to invite Wu Den-yih and Frank Hsieh, two former mayors, to make detailed reports on how the decision was reached to adopt the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model to build the city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system.
Wu, who lost his re-election bid in late 1998, is now a Kuomintang (KMT) legislator and Hsieh, who succeeded Wu as mayor, has since moved to Taipei to be premier in the Chen Shui-bian government.
Since the Kaohsiung MRT scandal erupted in August, both men have been alleging that the other should be held accountable for making the decision to build the system under the BOT model.

At a special meeting Thursday, council members Lin Shou-shan, Wang Ling-chiao and others recommended that the council invite the two former mayors to submit written reports on how each of them was involved in the decision-making process.
Lin stressed that if they accept the invitations, the council should respect their rights and refrain from asking questions either orally or in writing.

Only when council members act carefully with regard to the two mayors' reports and refrain from launching personal attacks on the two guests of honor will city residents be able to see the truth about the BOT decision-making process, Lin added.
After hearing opinions from other members, council speaker Tsai Chien-hsing agreed that he will send official invitations to Wu and Hsieh.

The MRT scandal erupted after Thai laborers working on the project rioted in protest of their poor living conditions and unreasonable treatment by Huapan Administration Consultant Co., which was charged with bringing them into the country and managing them.

Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) , which was formed to build and run the system, has canceled its contract with Huapan and KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien, a minority shareholder in the NT$180 billion project, is now under judicial investigation on suspicion of corruption.

Kaohsiung's acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai, who replaced Hsieh after he became premier, and Council for Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu have since resigned to take their share of political responsibility for the riot. Premier Hsieh has also apologized for the government's failure to supervise the construction of the system and the management of the workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES MAKING PROMISE TO BUILD AIRPORT FOR GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no plans and has not made any promise to help Guatemala build a new international airport or set up an international aviation company, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu blasted such groundless claims and denied any plan or pledge in this regard by Taiwan toward the Central American diplomatic ally despite the fact that President Chen Shui-bian will sign a free trade agreement and an air-sea transport accord with Guatemalan President Oscar Berger when he arrives in the country later the same day for an official visit from a stopover in Miami.

Lu's remarks came after opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Sun Ta-chien claimed that Guatemala has asked Taiwan to construct an international airport and open an airline company for it in exchange for its continued diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.

Urging the government not to further engage in "dollar diplomacy" for the sake of the national interests and the younger generations in Taiwan, Sun said that since Chen came to power five years ago, several scandals concerning such diplomacy, totalling at least US$5 billion, with the country's diplomatic allies in Central and South America have surfaced.

The government must stop using such means to try to appease those countries that are seeking to gain monetary benefits by taking advantage of the long-standing political gridlock between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said.

The PFP lawmaker, however, refused to identify the sources who provided him with the information, saying only that the information comes from reliable high ranking officials in the Guatemalan government.

Meanwhile, President Chen is slated to arrive in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua Sept. 25, where he will take part in a regional summit the next day with the heads of state of several Republic of China diplomatic allies.

Chen will also visit the Dominican Republic, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and St. Kitts and Neis during his current 12-day tour in Latin America, where many of the ROC's 26 diplomatic allies are located.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT WILL ATTEND SUMMIT AS SCHEDULED: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Panama remain solid and stable, and Panama has repeatedly assured Taiwan that its development of ties with China is only limited to economic exchanges, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu made the remarks in response to a media report that Panamanian President Martin Espino Torrijos will not attend a regional summit between the ROC and various of its diplomatic allies in Central America slated for Sept. 26 in Managua, Nicaragua, citing reported possible changes to diplomatic relations between the two countries as the reason.

Lu said that the report was incorrect and that after having contacted the Republic of China Embassy in Panama City, he was told that Torrijos will take part in the summit meeting as scheduled, and that the Panamanian president will hold bilateral talks with President Chen Shui-bian on the sidelines of the summit.

Ranking Panamanian government officials, including the president, the vice president and the foreign minister, have also repeatedly given their assurances that Taiwan-Panama diplomatic links will remain unchanged and that Panama-China ties are confined to trade and commercial activities, Lu stressed.

Meanwhile, Chen is slated to arrive in Managua from Guatemala Sept. 25. Chen will arrive in Guatemala later Thursday after a stopover in Miami -- the first leg of a 12-day Centra American and Caribbean tour where he will sign a free trade agreement and an air-sea transport pact. He also will visit the Dominican Republic, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES WARNING OF HEAVY RAIN FROM TYPHOON DAMREY

TEXT.P: Typhoon Damrey will not make landfall on Taiwan, but people living in northeastern, eastern and southeastern parts of the island should guard against torrential rain, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Thursday.
The CWB issued a sea warning Wednesday as the typhoon entered the Bashi Channel.

At 5 p.m. Thursday, the center of the tropical storm, with a 200-km radius, was located at 19.9 degrees north latitude and 120.2 degrees east longitude -- about 240 kilometers south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi. It was moving west at 10 kph toward the waters around Pratas Island, according to the CWB's forecast.

CWB meteorologists said that torrential rain is likely to continue until late Friday. They warned people living in mountainous areas of northern, central and southern Taiwan to guard against landslides, falling rocks and mudflows, and that those living in low-lying areas should watch for flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Minister of Finance and Economics Domenico Siniscalco quits.
Minister of Finance and Economics Domenico Siniscalco offered his resignation Wednesday night after a meeting with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Siniscalco, who was scheduled to leave for Washington D.C. at the head the Italian delegation to an International Monetary Fund meeting, decided to quit from his post due to disputes over next year's government budget among ruling coalition parties and having been at odds with Bank of Italy Governor Antonio Fazio. Berlusconi is expected to decide Thursday whether or not to accept the resignation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Texas Coast Braces For Rita; 1.1 Million Ordered To Evacuate Homes.
Hurricane Rita, a massive storm packing 165-mph winds and destructive force equal to the might of Hurricane Katrina, tracked through the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday, prompting evacuation orders for more than 1.1 million Texans and the few remaining holdouts in storm-ravaged New Orleans.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 85 points to close at 5,979, with 40,394 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 81 points to end at 5,990, with 209 contracts traded, while December futures lost 93 points to finish at 5,986, with 66 contracts traded. March futures moved down 80 points to close at 5,985, with 15 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 67 points to close at 5,980, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,064 for October, 6,071 for November, 6,079 for December, 6,065 for March and 6,047 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

October TE futures moved down 4.6 points to close at 248.4, with 5,410 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 4.8 points to finish at 248.5, with 23 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 3.4 points to end at 249.3, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures lost 15.2 points to finish at 890, with 3,222 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 16 points to end at 890.4, with 18 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 11.8 points to close at 890.2, with 14 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 16.4 points to finish at 890, with seven contracts traded. June TF futures lost 10.8 points to close at 898.8, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.047 to close at NT$33.135.
A total of US$1.04 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.021 and hit a high of NT$33.155.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE FORUM HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan Business Alliance Forum, organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to attract foreign investors, took place Thursday in the Taipei International Conference Center with representatives from more than 400 domestic and foreign businesses participating.

Dr. Kazunobu Tanaka of Japan, the founding chairman of the Asia Nanotech Forum, gave the keynote speech on global trends and business opportunities for nanotechnology at the one-day forum, while Matthew Nordan of the United States, vice president of Lux Research, Inc., spoke on the role of venture capital in nanotechnology funding and investment strategies.

Since the United States launched its National Nanotechnology Initiative in 2000, almost every country in the world has attached great importance to nanotechnology development and applications, with a variety of national R&D programs on nanoscience and nanotechnology having been organized over the past several years, Tanaka said.

Global funding to various nanotechnology research and development programs has been constantly increasing, with the total investment in this area reaching US$9.5 billion in 2004, Tanaka said. He added that the proportions of Taiwan's and South Korea's total investment as a ratio to the gross domestic product (GDP) are even higher than those of the European Union and the United States.

Taiwan is planning to invest US$630 million in nanotechnology infrastructure and education, as well as relevant research and development programs during the coming six years, while South Korea will invest US$1.3 billion by 2010, Tanaka pointed out.
According to Tanaka, Taiwan has devoted itself to eco-friendly nanotechnology research and development, thus becoming a pioneer in the field.

There are around 1,200 nanotechnology companies in the world, and half of them are in the United States, Tanaka said. Although only a few of them are operating at a profit, the nanotechnology industry still has a rosy future and is expected to become a mainstream industry in the next 10 years, with potential business opportunities reaching hundreds of billions by 2010.

Under Taiwan's National Science and Technology Program for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, the production value of the island's nanotechnology-related industries is expected to exceed NT$300 billion (US$9.07 billion) by 2008.

Meanwhile, Su Tsung-tsan, director of the Nanotechnology Research Center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, said that Taiwan has successfully built its own nanotechnology brand and now has over 250 companies engaging in nanotechnology-related businesses.

With the government's full support and Taiwan's excellent geographic position, the island's nanotechnology industry has a great potential for development, Su said, adding that foreign manufacturers are welcome to carry out investment projects in cooperation with their Taiwanese counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT TO OFFER FREE FLU SHOTS BEGINNING THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: Free inoculations to certain people will begin this week of the 2.15 million doses of influenza vaccine purchased this year, the Department of Health said Thursday.
Health department officials said that the medicine purchased this year is similar to last year's, and they hope to see a higher inoculation rate than the 60 percent last year.
The free shots are offered to medical personnel, children, rare disease patients as well as those in the poultry or livestock industries.
The inoculation rate for those in this industry was the lowest at 59.9 percent last year, while those in the medical care and quarantine industry had the highest inoculation rate at 88 percent.

Hospitals and clinics will provide shots to the general public for between NT$400 (US$12.3) and NT$500 each. The public demand for the shots are between 800,000 and one million each year, health department officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE CHARITY GROUPS TO EXTEND HUMANITARIAN RELIEF TO CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: Five Taiwan charitable organizations are jointly organizing a humanitarian relief delegation that will travel to Cambodia to help people, particularly children, in a particularly poverty-stricken area of the country.

The "Love of Taiwan" group, comprised of members of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , the Field Relief Agency (FRA) , Compassion International, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, is scheduled to visit Cambodia's northwest border town of Poipet Sept. 25-30, where it will offer free medical services to the people there, many of whom are victims of years of bloodshed, said TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun.

The delegation will include 16 medical professionals, all TRMPC volunteers, who will take with them 600 kg of medication and medical aid materials, as well as crutches, walking aids, white sticks for the blind and 60 wheelchairs, Liu said.

Also going the Cambodia with the group will be 18 standard blackboards, donated by the Taiwan International Lions Club 300-A2, to be installed in 18 classrooms in a new middle school that the FRA has helped build in Poipet, said FRA Secretary-General Yang Wei-ling.

Yang, a flight attendant-turned-philanthropist who founded the FRA seven years ago and has traveled to Cambodia at least twice each year for humanitarian relief work, described Poipet as a "war-torn, poverty-stricken town on the border with Thailand, " where many children are homeless orphans without schooling and many adults are victims of the millions of landmines scattered throughout the area during civil wars over the past several decades.
Believing that education is the best way to help people surmount poverty, Yang has continued to build schools in Cambodia.
Besides schools, Yang has also established a library of Chinese books, all of which have been transported from Taiwan. She has also founded an orphanage and a vocational training center.

Yang offered her gratitude to the Taiwan International Lions Club 300-A2 for its donation of US$80,000 to fund the new Poipet school and added that when the school opens Sept. 25, it will be capable of allowing more than 1,000 poor children to attend school free of charge.
"Education changes a child's fate, " is her belief and will be a motto of the school, Yang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MUST PUT ASIDE PREREQUISITE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu urged China Thursday to put aside its "one China" prerequisite so that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume talks as soon as possible.

The nation's top China policy planner's words came in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's remarks earlier that he is willing to meet with his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, without preconditions and at any time and venue.

Chen said over a banquet in Miami Wednesday en route to Central America for an official visit that he is willing to meet Hu for rational dialogue, hoping to open a window of opportunity for the co-existence of a democratic Taiwan that respects human rights and of a democratic China that also respects human rights.
In an interview with the CNA, Wu said Chen's remarks reflect the long-standing policy of the government.
He lamented that China has often made the "one China" a prerequisite for resumed cross-strait talks, which has hindered dialogue. If it continues, political disputes may never be settled, he added.
In addition to political and leader dialogues, the government is also hoping that both sides can engage in consultations on pragmatic issues of mutual concern, he went on.

In view of the fact that the international community might not understand Taiwan's stance on cross-strait dialogue, President Chen has used different international occasions to display Taiwan's willingness to talk with Beijing and its determination to pursue cross-strait peace and stability, Wu said.
Wu also said that as a member of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Taiwan's leader should have the same right to take part in its informal leadership meetings as other leaders.

Chen has continued to express his willingness to take part in this year's APEC summit meeting Nov. 18-19 in Busan, South Korea, hoping that China will not try to obstruct as it has in the past and that the leaders across the Taiwan Strait can meet in a natural atmosphere and seek reconciliation, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY ECHOES PRESIDENT'S CALL FOR CHINA TALKS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) echoed Thursday a call issued earlier that day by President Chen Shui-bian for unconditional talks with China in the hope of building peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Cheng Wen-tsang, head of the DPP's public relations department, said that Beijing's reluctance to deal with the DPP and the nation's duly elected president, and its unwillingness to recognize the Republic of China's national status, has stalled positive developments in cross-strait relations.

Should China continue avoiding talking with Taiwan and its president, there is no way to build mutual trust and confidence, Cheng said, adding that Chen's offer to talk with China, regardless of venue, timing and without any prerequisites is rational and will also meet the international community's high expectations for better cross-strait ties.
When China also upholds democracy, peace and human rights as its core and principal values, it will "naturally drop its military intimidation of Taiwan," he predicted.

Chen made his latest peace overture to China at a banquet with Taiwan immigrants in Florida en route to Guatemala -- the first leg of a 12-day Central America and Caribbean tour that will also take him to Nicaragua, the Dominican Republic, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and St. Kitts and Nevis.
Chen urged Beijing to join forces with Taiwan to create a window of opportunity based on democracy and human rights that could help both sides co-exist peacefully and prosperously.

Meanwhile, Chang Jong-kong, director of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) mainland affairs department, described Chen's call for peace talks with Chinese President Hu Jintao as empty talk if he is not prepared to forswear Taiwan's "one country on each side of the strait" insistence.
The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , the DPP's ally, criticized Chen's unconditional peace offer to China as a "self-depreciating" move.

China should also display a certain degree of goodwill to Taiwan if the two sides are to open dialogue that must be held in a third country and be of a "country-to-country" nature, a TSU spokesman said, suggesting that the best venue would be Washington and that they should be modeled on the recently concluded six-party North Korea talks, as proposed by former President Lee Teng-hui -- now the spiritual leader of the TSU.
The DPP and the TSU form the "pan green camp" against the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party.
Taiwan and China have been rivals since 1949, when Taiwan split from China following a civil war and bilateral relations have further worsened since Chen first came to power in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CERTIFICATION TO BE EXPANDED FOR LOCAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that a resume system, or "ID" for agricultural products will be expanded in an effort to allay public health fears.
Hsieh made the remarks on the sidelines of the closing ceremony of a training camp for senior executives of the country's farmers' and fishermen's associations.

The premier claimed that a recent scare about carcinogens found in several samples of locally produced groupers were "only isolated cases" and said that certificated fish returned to markets that day after sales were suspended for a few days.

Faced with steep competition in agricultural products from China and the rest of the world, it is necessary to distinguish Taiwan's products from foreign products, Hsieh said, adding that this is why the certification system needs to be expanded.
He said the quality of Taiwan's agricultural products has to be upgraded so as to survive against the competition, adding that Taiwan's farmers "need not fear" displaying the origin of their produce.
The certification system of agricultural products means that written records are provided of production, processing and marketing.

The COA started to promote the system last year, and chose organic rice and certain root and stem vegetables for the system on a trial basis. The system will be expanded to other agricultural products in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS VOWS TO BLOCK PASSAGE OF NCC BILL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will issue an order Sept. 27 to remind all DPP legislators to be prepared for "class A mobilization" to block the passage of the National Communications Commission (NCC) bill in the legislature, a DPP caucus whip said Thursday.

Chen Chin-jun told reporters that the highest degree of mobilization within the DPP caucus will be necessary because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) might put the NCC bill to a vote any time as the four-month negotiation between the DPP and the opposition is coming to an end.
The NCC bill has been one of the major contentions in the legislature between the DPP and the opposition, which holds a slight legislative majority.

When the previous legislature was closing its final session in late January, the DPP legislative caucus managed to block the passage of the bill through various obstructive methods, including filibustering and barring KMT and PFP legislators from using the rostrum.
While both the DPP and the opposition agree that it is necessary to set up an institution like the NCC, they disagree on the make-up of the body.

The pan blue alliance has proposed that the NCC should consist of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, but the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission, so that press freedom will not be affected.

The pan blue alliance has noted there are precedents in other democracies to appoint NCC members in proportion to the parliamentary strength of the political parties. For example, the Federal Communications Commission of the United States is normally staffed according to the proportional representation principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO CREATE SAFE LIVING CONDITIONS FOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that public administrative agencies and preschool education institutions should fulfill their duties of ensuring safe conditions for young children.
Hsieh issued the directive after a 3-year-old boy in central Taiwan suffocated Tuesday after allegedly being left unattended in a kindergarten mini-bus for seven hours.
Noting that he sympathized with the boy's parents, Hsieh said city and county governments should strengthen the supervision of preschool education institutions to protect young children's safety.
The kindergarten in Taichung County's Chingshui township that the boy attended had been operating without a license and had been fined twice before for the same offense.
Hsieh said local governments should not extend the grace period for unlicensed preschool education institutions to improve their facilities and management to meet the requirements for accreditation.

The premier also directed the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior to step up a crackdown on unlicensed daycare centers and kindergartens around the country and to require local governments to tighten oversight of operations and staff training of preschool education institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL: IMPORTANT FOR CHINA TO RESOLVE DIFFERENCES PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Robert B. Zoellick emphasized Wednesday the importance for China to resolve its differences with Taiwan peacefully.
Speaking at a dinner sponsored by the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations, Zoellick noted that China is playing an ever-larger role in Asia.

"The U.S. respects China's interests in the region, and recognizes the useful role of multilateral diplomacy in China. But concerns will grow if China seeks to maneuver toward a predominance of power," he said.

Referring to the differences between China and Taiwan, Zoellick pointed out that the U.S. has made it clear that its "one China" policy remains based on the "three communiques" and the Taiwan Relations Act.
Zoellick said the U.S. seeks constructive relations with all countries that do not threaten peace and security.

"Many countries hope China will pursue a peaceful rise, but none will bet their future on it, " he said, adding that "China's rapid military modernization and increase in capabilities raise questions about the purposes of this buildup and China's lack of transparency."

Urging China to become a "responsible stakeholder in the international system, " Zoellick said that with the huge trade imbalance between China and the United States, "China cannot take its access to the U.S. market for granted. Protectionist pressures are growing." He also mentioned that China's recent policy adjustments of foreign exchange rates are "an initial step" and much more remains to be done.

Referring to China's thirst for energy, Zoellick criticized China for applying "mercantilist strategy leads to partnerships with regimes that hurt China's reputation and lead others to question its intentions." Citing the relations between China and Sudan, Zoellick said China should take more than oil from Sudan -- it should take some responsibility for resolving Sudan's human crisis.

Stressing that "freedom lies at the heart at what America is, " Zoellick said that "we do not urge the cause of freedom to weaken China. Being born ethnically Chinese does not predispose people against democracy -- just look at Taiwan's vibrant politics. Japan and South Korea have successfully blended a Confucian heritage with modern democratic principles," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PULLING WOOL OVER TAIWAN PUBLIC'S EYES: MND

TEXT.P: China has been pulling the wool over the eyes of the Taiwan public, deceiving them into believing that it has turned soft toward Taiwan, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official claimed Thursday.

Hu Chen-pu, chief of the MND's Bureau of General Political Warfare, said the Beijing leadership has been playing a "double-handed" scheme to fool the people of Taiwan by inviting opposition leaders from Taiwan for prominent visits to China and allowing freer trade policy with Taiwan in a bid to lessen Taiwan's vigilance against China and reduce its people's sense of crisis.

Hu said that although the Chinese military has recently moved its three-services combative landing exercises from the East China Sea to the inland areas of Zhejiang and Guangdong provinces, the number and scale of the war game drills have not decreased and the number of people taking part in the drills has actually increased.

China's "double-handed" strategy has increasingly made the people of Taiwan forget China's ever-expanding military build-up and the fact that Beijing has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan to solve cross-strait differences, according to Hu.

Hu claimed that the scheme has led some politicians in Taiwan to believe that Taiwan's procurement of three major weaponry systems from the United States is unnecessary, a situation about which the MND is extremely worried, he added.

Hu said that since 1989, China, with its free-wheeling economy, has continued to expand and modernize its military build-up, posing an increasing threat to Taiwan's national security and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
The Chinese military's establishment of a combat simulation base near Hainan is "solid evidence" that it is aggressively making preparations for taking Taiwan militarily, according to Hu.

The Chinese military established a simulated Taiwan military air base on Dahuo island to the northeast of Hainan, where the Chinese air force conducts drills against what they described as "camouflaged F-16 jetfighters." About eight kilometers away, on Hailin island, army and marine forces conduct landing and combat maneuvers from across a narrow channel to Dahuo island -- drills that are imperative and crucial for China to invade Taiwan militarily, he said.
Hu argued that if China wants to express goodwill toward Taiwan, it should renounce the use of force against Taiwan, instead of conducting military exercises ceaselessly.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO DELIBERATE ARMS PACKAGE S00N

TEXT.P: An official from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) called on the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Thursday to put an arms procurement draft bill on the legislative agenda for deliberation as soon as possible, saying that the ministry will accept the screening result.

Hu Chen-pu, director of the MND's Bureau of General Political Warfare, told a news conference that the draft statute governing an arms procurement package has been rejected by the Rules Committee 29 times since it was submitted to the legislature for deliberation in June last year.

The MND has briefed legislators from the ruling and opposition parties on the arms procurement package more than 170 times since then, and has listed the financing for Patriot anti-missile batteries in the regular budget as demanded by lawmakers instead of the originally proposed special budget, with the total outlay required for the package lowered from NT$610.8 billion to NT$340 billion, Hu said.

In spite of such pragmatic adjustments, Hu pointed out, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature, still filibustered the budget plan, making it impossible for the arms procurement package to enter the review process during the newly opened legislative session.

The package comprises three big-ticket weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries. For more than a year, the "pan-blue alliance" has refused to screen the package because it claims the price is too high and that it should be listed under the regular budget rather than a special budget.

Noting that the military has conducted a series of careful evaluations on a procurement plan for the three items based upon the nation's defense needs, Hu said the MND began to push for the procurement as early as seven years ago in compliance with the military buildup procedures.
It is regrettable that the opposition-controlled legislature has refused to conduct rational, professional and objective discussions of the package, which concerns national security, Hu said.

The armed forces belong to the Republic of China and all of its people, and do not belong to any political party or individual, Hu noted. "In the face of the growing military threaten from China, we cannot afford any internal attrition," he stressed.

Claiming that no political party should put its own interests before national security, Hu voiced the hope that all lawmakers will understand that the arms are vital to upgrading Taiwan's defense capabilities and agree to put the package on the legislative agenda as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUGUST JOBLESS RATE LOWEST IN NEARLY FIVE YEARS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate hit a low of 4.36 percent in August, down by 0.31 percentage points from the same month of last year and marking the lowest single-month record for August in nearly five years, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.
Seasonally adjusted, the August unemployment rate was even lower, at 4.11 percent, the lowest since April 2001, DGBAS officials said.

The number of employed people in Taiwan stood at 9,972,000 in August, up 31,000 from the July figure and up 146,000 from the same month of the previous year, while August's 4.36 precent joblessness rate was equal to an unemployed workforce of about 454,000, up by 5,000 from the July figure, the officials said.
Unemployed workers questioned in August said they had been jobless for an average of 24.4 weeks, 0.3 weeks shorter than the July average.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4TH ANNUAL IADI CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Fourth Annual Conference of the International Association of Deposit Insurers (IADI) is scheduled to be held Sept. 27-29 in Taipei under the auspices of the Central Deposit Insurance Corporation (CDIC).

In conjunction with the IADI annual conference, a series of international symposiums will also be held, CDIC President Chen Chan-sheng said Thursday, adding that this will be the first time Taiwan has hosted an IADI conference.
Taiwan is not a member of the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank because it is not a member of the United Nations, but it is an IADI member, Chen said.

The IADI, recognized by the Bank for International Settlements, is a major international organization. Its mandate is to contribute to the stability of financial systems by promoting international cooperation and to encourage wide international contact among deposit insurers and other interested parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW BOOK RELEASED ON INVESTMENT PITFALLS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: A new book was released in Taipei Thursday to warn Taiwanese businessmen of the hazards they might face if they decide to invest in China.

At a press conference held at the Taipei NGO Assembly Hall, Kao Wei-pang, author of the book and director of the Association of Victimized Taiwanese Investors in China, said his book, titled "Investment in China: The pitfalls You Must Know, " includes a description of his own experience and what he described as true stories told by other Taiwanese investors in China.

Kao said that since the association was founded two years ago, there have been more than 100 cases in which Taiwanese investors have been victims. However, he claimed, none of them have received justice.

The 349-page book listed 12 pitfalls, including Chinese business partners not honoring their commitments and not abiding by the law, stealing the assets of Taiwanese businessmen, and false joint ventures with the aim of committing fraud.
Kao said that if the government in Taipei cannot provide protection to Taiwanese businessmen in China, it should at least tell them the truth about the investment environment in China.

He also claimed that his association is a non-political organization, although he admitted that most of its members are supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party.
However, he went on, the authorities in China treat association members as advocates of Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8.2% KIDS BORN TO S.E. ASIAN MOTHERS SLOW IN LANGUAGE LEARNING: MOE

TEXT.P: An average of 8.2 percent of local elementary schoolchildren born to Southeast Asian mothers are slow in speech and language development, according to the results of a Ministry of Education (MOE) survey released Thursday.
The MOE report said sluggish language development among schoolchildren born to Southeast Asian mothers may be related to their mothers' linguistic barriers.

According to the survey, 10.1 percent of first and second graders with Southeast Asian mothers are slow in language development, but the ratio drops to 6.7 percent among third and fourth graders and further slides to 5.5 percent among fifth and sixth graders.
The figures indicate that education can help mixed-race children in language learning and development, the MOE report said.

The survey also found that 24.13 percent of mixed-race schoolchildren whose mothers can hardly speak Mandarin Chinese or Taiwanese dialect are slow language learners, while only 4.8 percent of mixed-race children with mothers able to speak fluent local language have difficulties in language development.

Meanwhile, the report said, 54 percent of mixed-race children perform well in language and literary study, while the ratio of mixed-race children who perform well in mathematics, social studies, nature and technological studies are relatively low.
More than 60 percent of mixed-race children have adapted well to campus life and group activities and have smooth communications with teachers and classmates, the report said.

Clearing hospitals, nursing homes and coastal neighborhoods, authorities began evacuating more than 1 million people from the western Gulf Coast on Wednesday as the second mammoth storm in a month lumbered toward landfall along the Texas coastline.

Sony to Cut 10,000 Jobs, Reduce Costs by $1.8 Billion

Sony Corp. unveiled a new restructuring plan Thursday under which it will eliminate 10,000 jobs by early 2008 and cut costs by 200 billion ($1.8 billion) to try to bolster its ailing electronics operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO STEP UP VOTE-BUYING PROBES

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin urged local prosecutors Thursday to cooperate closely with government ethics departments at various levels in investigations into suspicious vote-buying charges ahead of the year-end "three-in-one" elections.
Shih gave the directive at a meeting of chief prosecutors from around the country. Wu Ying-chao, the state public prosecutor general, was also present at the meeting.

Noting that the elections for city/county chiefs, city/county councilors and township chiefs will be simultaneously held Dec. 3, Shih said probes into suspicious election bribery cases must get under way and shift into high gear as early as possible to enhance operational efficiency.

Law enforcement units in several constituencies have already uncovered a number of suspicious vote-buying cases, Shih said, adding that grassroots prosecution authorities in other areas should learn from those units.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN HOPES TAIWAN, GUATEMALA CAN JOINTLY OPEN UP MARKETS IN N. AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.c.tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he hopes Taiwan and Guatemala can jointly open up markets for their products in North America in the future.
The president expressed the hope after he signed with Guatemalan President Oscar Jose-Rafael Berger a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries the same day.
This is the second FTA that Taiwan has signed with one of its diplomatic allies in Central America. The first was with Panama in 2003.

As Taiwanese business people, who have long engaged in commercial activities in the Asia-Pacific markets, have extensive knowledge about running businesses in the region, Chen said that the FTA will certainly help Guatemala to promote its business in the region.
He also said the U.S.-Guatemala FTA, which will enter into force next January, will help Taiwanese businesses to sell their products in markets in Latin America.

"The governments and private enterprises of the two countries will also be able to jointly open up their markets in North America through joint ventures and pooling of their capital, " he further said, adding: "This represents that the friendship and constructive partnership of the two countries will move forward toward a new era."
Besides the FTA, the two presidents also signed a volunteer cooperation agreement and an aviation and maritime navigation agreement between the two countries.
Chen, at the head of a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, is currently in the Central American country for an official visit.

He and his entourage received a warm welcome by members of the Guatemalan Cabinet and a grand military salute ceremony held at the national cultural palace after they arrived in the country earlier in the day.

Presenting a white "peace rose" to a bronze statue in the palace, which symbolizes the peace between the Guatemalan government and rebels after they signed a "durable peace agreement" in 1996, Chen said that he hopes that Taipei can sign a peace agreement with Beijing one day.
"But China's missiles targeting Taiwan must first be replaced by 'peace roses,'" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD WELCOMES PRESIDENT CHEN'S OFFER OF DIALOGUE WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou expressed welcome Friday to President Chen Shui-bian's offer to engage in dialogue with the Chinese leadership without any preconditions but pointed out that the key to reconciliation may lie in how Chen positions cross-strait relations.
"Chen's attitude toward how cross-strait relations should be positioned may be a 'precondition' to be tackled before Taiwan can engage in any kind of negotiations with China," Ma said.
He added that the persistent lack of trust between the leaderships across the strait is also a thorny issue in the development of cross-strait relations.

Ma made the comments in response to President Chen's remarks in Miami a day earlier that he is willing to hold "rational dialogue" with his People's Republic of China counterpart Hu Jintao without any preconditions.
Such dialogue, which could be held any time and anywhere, would be aimed at creating a "window of opportunity" for "democratic Taiwan and democratic China to co-exist," the president said.
Chen and his entourage were on a one-day transit stopover in Miami en route to Central America and the Caribbean for an official visit.

Chen said he fully understands the world community is expecting Taiwan and China to reopen dialogue in order to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait. "But I have to seriously remind the world that the crux of the issue is that China has been avoiding dialogue with Taiwan's popularly elected government and, worse, is targeting missiles at Taiwan and using its so-called 'Anti-Secession Law' in an attempt to tackle the issue through non-peaceful means, " Chen stressed.
He reiterated his thanks to the Bush government for repeatedly urging Beijing to talk with Taiwan's popularly elected government and president.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO CONVENE MEETING ON NCC, BUDGET BILLS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will convene an inter-party coordination meeting Monday to discuss the budget proposal for the government for the next fiscal year as well as the National Communications Commission (NCC) draft bill.

Legislator Jao Yung-ching, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the remarks after the DPP legislative caucus called on Wang Friday to ask him to convene the consultation meeting.

Jao said the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus is tilting toward lumping the government budget proposal together with the NCC bill, adding that the KMT will see if the NCC bill can be passed before they decide on the budget proposal.
While both the DPP and the opposition agree that it is necessary to set up an institution like the NCC, they disagree on the make-up of the body.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which holds a slim majority in the 225-seat legislature, has proposed that the NCC be comprised of members in proportion to the number of seats each party holds in the legislature, while the DPP insists that political parties should keep their hands off and let experts and scholars serve on the commission, so that press freedom will not be affected.

Although the DPP claims that such a proportional system is unprecedented, the "pan-blue alliance" has pointed out that there are precedents in other democracies to appoint NCC members in proportion to the parliamentary strength of the political parties. For example, the Federal Communications Commission of the United States is normally staffed according to the proportional representation principle.

As the opposition "pan-blue alliance" might put the NCC bill to a vote as the four-month consultation period between the DPP and the opposition is coming to an end Sunday, the DPP has mobilized to try to block passage of the NCC bill in the legislature.
