DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST HEED U.S. PENTAGON OFFICIAL'S WARNING: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Friday that Taiwan should take heed of a U.S. Pentagon official's stern criticism of the limited growth in the island's national defense budget.

Lee was referring to remarks made by Edward Ross, principal director of the Security Cooperation Operations under the Defense Security Cooperation Agency of the U.S. Department of Defense, at the U.S.-Taiwan Defense Industry Conference 2005 held in San Diego, California Sept. 19-20.
Ross also said that if Taiwan is not willing to defend itself, the United States cannot assist in defending Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan should pay attention to such a stern warning, Lee said that "if friends point out our faults, we must engage in self-reflection, and if they are wrong, then we'll react, " adding that the United States has always been forthcoming.
On whether he will express Taiwan's views to the United States, Lee said the Ministry of National Defense is preparing for a response.

Ross took part in the meeting on behalf of Richard Lawless, U.S. Deputy Undersecretary of Defense, who was unable to attend the conference because he was preoccupied with the six-party talks on North Korea.

Ross lauded Lee and his staff for meeting with legislators and communicating with them more than 170 times to attempt to facilitate passage of the long-stalled arms procurement bill. The procurement package includes three big-ticket items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.
Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that he will not speculate on when the arms procurement package will be put on the legislative agenda for review.

The opposition lawmakers, who have a slight majority in the Legislative Yuan, have blocked the bill's passage for over a year because they say that the price is too high and that the procurement should be funded through the regular defense budget rather than a special budget.
Wang said he believes that every party will take into consideration the nation's overall security as well as the cross-strait military balance in dealing with the procurement issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN UNVEILS NEW PROJECT FOR CO-PROSPERITY WITH ALLIES
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in Guatemala Thursday that Taiwan will come up with a new investment project for co-prosperity with its diplomatic allies in Central America.
Chen, who arrived in Guatemala City earlier in the day from Miami, Florida for a state visit, revealed the plan in an interview with the Guatemalan newspaper "Diario Siglo 21."

The new project, which will call for an outlay of US$250 million per year, will be formally announced when a summit meeting between Chen and his counterparts from the ROC's allies in Central America and the Caribbean opens in Nicaragua Sept. 26, Chen said.

According to Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, who is accompanying Chen on his current 12-day diplomatic tour, the new project will mark a shift in Taiwan's diplomatic strategy from financial aid and technological assistance to economic and trade cooperation.

Ho said the money needed for the new cooperative project will come from three government-run funds, including the International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Executive Yuan Development Fund.

Under the "co-prosperity" project, Ho said, the ROC government will take the initiative to invest in niche industries in various Central American countries in addition to encouraging private Taiwan corporations to make similar investments in the region for exports to North America. The niche industries in Central America include foodstuffs and textiles.

The "co-prosperity" project will pool resources and manpower of various government departments, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and the National Security Council, Ho said, adding that Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will serve as convener of the project.
Wu, who is also a member of Chen's entourage, said the "co-prosperity" project is expected to create a "win-win" scenario for Taiwan and its Central American allies.

"The project will help Taiwan companies establish footholds in Central America to serve as a springboard for tapping into the vast North American market while assisting our Central American allies in developing their economies and creating jobs," Wu explained.
Wu said the government will offer many incentives, including financial subsidies and loans, to encourage Taiwan enterprises to invest in niche industries in Central American countries.

During his interview with the Guatemalan paper, President Chen also said Taiwan will assist Guatemala in expanding its CA-9 highway, with Taiwan offering a loan of US$17 million to finance the expansion of one-third of the 33-km highway from two lanes to four lanes.
Guatemala is the first leg of Chen's ongoing diplomatic tour that will also take him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE SURPLUS DECLINES

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$1.17 billion in the first eight months of this year, marking a noticeable year-on-year decline of 79 percent, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Friday.

Taiwan's two-way trade hit US$240.73 billion in the Jan.-Aug. period, with exports and imports totaling US$120.95 billion and US$119.78 billion, respectively, marking a year-on-year expansion of 6.7 percent and 11.2 percent, respectively, the MOEA officials said.
As a result, the country registered a trade surplus of US$1.17 billion, which was NT$4.45 billion less than the year-earlier level, the officials noted.
They attributed the sharp decline in Taiwan's trade surplus mainly to less vibrant global economic growth, the appreciation of Taiwan's currency and spiralling international oil prices.

China (including Hong Kong) and the United States remained Taiwan's largest sources of trade surplus in the Jan.-Aug. period, with the surplus figures totaling US$30.92 billion and US$4.24 billion, respectively.

Meanwhile, Japan and South Korea were the largest sources of Taiwan's imports, with the country suffering a trade deficit of US$21.65 billion with Japan and a deficit of US$4.88 billion with South Korea in the first eight months.

By area, Taiwan's exports to the six members of the Association of South East Asian Nations grew noticeably, at 12.5 percent year-on-year, while demand from mainland China and Hong Kong also remained strong, with exports increasing a whopping 20.4 percent, according to the officials.

By product, Taiwan's imports of crude oil in the same period skyrocketed 48.2 percent in terms of price, followed by imports of machinery, which grew by 16.2 percent. Electronics products topped the Jan.-Aug. import list in terms of quantity, at 17.2 percent of the total, followed by machinery products at 10.4 percent.

Iron, steel and related products topped the Jan.-Aug. export list, posting a year-on-year growth of 20.4 percent, followed by electronics goods, up 7 percent, while exports of optoelectronic instruments and telecommunications and information technology products declined by 2.4 percent and 20.9 percent, respectively, mainly as a result of Taiwan exporters moving their manufacturing and export operations overseas, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO HAVE MORE CONTACT WITH U.S. OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A former senior U.S. State Department official has suggested that high-ranking officials of the Taiwan government reinforce their communication and coordination with members of the new U.S. governmental team in charge of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
Richard Armitage, former U.S. deputy secretary of state, made the suggestion while meeting with President Chen Shui-bian during the Taiwan head of state's transit stop in Miami Wednesday.
The president, heading a ROC delegation made up of high-ranking officials and business leaders, is currently in Guatemala for an official visit.

A staff member of the president revealed Thursday that during the meeting, the U.S. official admitted that relations between Taipei and Washington were not very smooth for a certain period of time in the past, saying, however, that "this problem was not purely caused by Taiwan."

"The United States should also shoulder some of the responsibility as it had only dealt with matters with the Kuomintang before and was not aware of the Democratic Progressive Party's style and way of doing things," he pointed out.

Noting that the U.S. government did not distinguish the differences between the DPP government officials and the former KMT government officials at the very beginning of Chen's presidency, Armitage said to Chen that the relationship between the two countries went through a short spell of adapting to each other's way of doing things.

As there are now new officials in the Bush administration charged with the task of handling cross-strait affairs, Armitage suggested that high-ranking ROC officials, including national security staff members, establish frequent communications and a coordination mechanism with their U.S. counterparts, rather than relying only on the American Institute in Taiwan, a quasi-official organization in charge of U.S. relations with Taiwan, as the only channel to pass on messages between the two governments.

He further said that at his strong suggestion, the Bush administration agreed in 2001 to sell a package of arms to Taiwan, adding that "this is because the U.S. government worried that a new ruling DPP government might affect cross-strait stability at that time."
"Approving the arms sales was also done in the hopes of maintaining a stable and peaceful cross-strait relationship, " he continued.

On the long-stalled arms procurement bill in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, Armitage said that listing funding for the arms procurement items in the regular military budget instead of a special budget is "a good way of handling matters."
At the same time, he suggested that high-ranking ROC officials help Washington better understand the efforts that the DPP government has made in dealing with the bill.

In response, the president told Armitage that he himself has called for the opposition parties at least a hundred times to support passage of the long-stalled bill in the legislature, according to the president's staff member.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Jiulio Tremonti appointed new minister of finance and economics.
President Carlo Ciampi appointed Jiulio Tremonti as new minister of finance and economics Thursday to fill the vacancy left by Domenico Siniscalco who quit from the post a day earlier. Tremonti is to leave for Washington D.C. Friday to head the Italian delegation to the International Monetary Fund meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Choices open up for secondary school students.
More choices will open up for secondary school students from next year, allowing them to further their education in a variety of ways.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Top normal stream students may be allowed to enter Secondary 5 without N levels test.
From 2007, schools can start selecting capable Secondary 4 Normal Academic stream students to skip the 'N' levels examinations and go straight to Secondary 5 for their 'O' levels.
And the Ministry of Education is studying the possibility of letting secondary school students skip their 'O' levels and be admitted to polytechnics directly.
Mr Gan Kim Yong, who will be Minister of State for Education from October, will chair a Review Committee tasked to study the feasibility of direct admission to the polytechnics for Secondary 4 students.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Thousands Fleeing Rita Jam Roads From Coast; Evacuation Is Ordered as Hurricane Veers Eastward.
As they joined a vast, traffic-snarled exodus from Houston and the upper Texas Gulf Coast, hundreds of thousands of people fleeing Hurricane Rita were stuck in their cars throughout much of Thursday, with many running out of gas and sweltering on roadsides in 100-degree heat as they waited for authorities to bring them gasoline.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY'S CHINA EXPERIENCING HALCYON DAYS: TAIWAN WRITER

TEXT.P: Taiwan writer, TV commentator, political gadfly and independent Legislator Li Ao claimed Friday that today's China is in its halcyon days that have not been seen since the Han (206 B.C.-A.D. 220) and Tang dynasties (A.D. 618-907).

Li, in his second speech in China to Tsinghua University faculty and students, lauded the Communist Party of China (CPC) several times, saying that while China was bullied by Western powers in its modern history, "no-one dares to bully China any more" and "only one party could have achieved that, which is the CPC."
He also claimed that after the Kuomintang fled to Taiwan after being defeated by the CPC in 1949, it took "all the money" to Taiwan and left 3 million "bad elements" behind.
He said that after 1949, China was stripped and in poverty, and yet it has managed to stand up for itself.

He referred to the Constitution of the People's Republic of China during his speech, claiming that it lists all kinds of freedom to which the people are entitled. "If we are serious about them, then the stipulations in the Constitution are bona fide, " he said without elaborating.

Li's first speech at Peking University, in which he advised the CPC to relax restrictions as he glorified freedom of speech, won enthusiastic response from the students but caused embarrassment to some school faculty and party officials.

Reports said that the Beijing authorities were concerned about his speech and wanted to block it. The reports were unsubstantiated, but official Web sites such as Xinhua and other major media did not print the parts of Li's speeches that were deemed sensitive Friday.
Hong Kong-based Phoenix TV, which arranged for Li's 12-day visit to China, aired Li's speech live Tuesday, but taped the second one for later airing.
Li will make a third and last speech at Fudan University in Shanghai before returning to Taiwan at the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE ACTIVISTS WANT SAN FRANCISCO TREATY WRITTEN IN TEXTBOOKS

TEXT.P: Members of the pro-independence 908 Taiwan Nation Movement claimed Friday that the San Francisco Peace Treaty (SFPT) is technically a "birth certificate" for Taiwan that its contents should be written into textbook for Taiwan students.

Japan signed the treaty with 48 United Nations member countries represented in a meeting in San Francisco Sept. 8, 1951. In the treaty, Japan declared that it would give up its sovereignty claims over Taiwan, Penghu and all its other offshore islands.
Wang Hsien-chi, a convener of the 908 Taiwan Nation Movement group, and other group members visited the Ministry of Education Friday, where they met with Vice Education Minister Chou Tsan-teh.
Wang said during the visit that the notion of Taiwan's sovereignty has never had anything to do with China or the People's Republic of China.
He blamed the opposition Kuomintang for promoting a "great China myth" in Taiwan's education domain when the party was in power over the last several decades until 2000.

This "great China myth" education has misled the people of Taiwan regarding Taiwan's sovereignty and its people's national identity, Wang claimed, adding that even today, Taiwan elementary school students have workbooks carrying the motto "Being a dignified and imposing Chinese" on the back cover.
Wang argued that it is now the responsibility of the Education Ministry to "return or resurface the truth of history."
It is hoped that the SFPT and related history be carried in textbooks for junior high, senior high and vocational schools in Taiwan, Wang added.

For his part, Chou said that he will relay Wang and his group's opinion to Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng and relevant departments of the Education Ministry, and said that the matter will be carried in textbooks after historians have researched the issue and find it in accordance with historical truth and data.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO ENHANCE EXCHANGES WITH JAPAN: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 23 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to enhance exchanges with Japan and increase cooperation between Taiwan, Japan and the United States, a Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks in an interview published Friday in the Japanese daily Sankei Shimbun.

Lu expressed appreciation for the Japanese government's support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer and its issuance of visas to former President Lee Teng-hui for private visits.

He also thanked Japan for listing the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue as a joint strategic objective in its security consultation meeting with the United States in February this year, its opposition to China's March 14 enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, as well as its recent announcement of a permanent waiving of visa requirements for Taiwan tourists visiting Japan.

Lu said that the listing of the common strategic objective was significant for two reasons: The Bush and Koizumi administrations attach great importance to the security and safety in the Taiwan Strait; and faced with more than 700 missiles aimed by China at Taiwan, Taiwan needs to consider enhancing cooperation with the U.S. and Japan.

Noting that Japanese Prime Minister Junichi Koizumi won overwhelmingly in recent lower house elections, Lu said this shows that Japanese voters are optimistic about Koizumi's advocacy of reform and his performance, and that Koizumi is expected to solidify his support base.

Lu said that although Taiwan and Japan have no diplomatic relations, private exchanges are close, and he expressed the hope that through the exchanges between non-governmental organizations, bilateral substantive relations will be improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECUPERATING FROM ACUTE GASTROENTERITIS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu stayed at home Friday recuperating from illness after she contracted acute gastroenteritis the previous night, according to a senior official at the Presidential Office.
Cho Chun-ying, deputy director of the Presidential Office's Public Relations Department, said Lu had probably eaten some bad food.
A doctor determined that the vice president's condition was not serious, but suggested that she stay home to speed up her recovery, Cho added.
Lu canceled two visits Friday scheduled for Chiayi County and Mailiao in Yunlin County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKER SALARIES DOWN IN REAL TERMS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan workers' salaries posted negative growth of 0.9 percent in real terms for the first seven months of this year, the largest decline of its kind in the country's history, according to government statistics.

Taiwan employees' monthly salaries averaged NT$35,517 (US$1,077) during the January-July period, for a year-on-year increase of 0.96 percent, but the consumer price index rose by 1.92 percent during the same period, resulting in negative growth of 0.9 percent in worker salaries in real terms -- the second such decline on record, tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.
Taiwan workers in the industrial and service sectors worked an average of 181.7 hours in July, down by 5.6 hours from June and down by 8.4 hours from the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile, survey results made public the same day by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research show that nearly 58 percent of Taiwan companies said they think the domestic business climate will remain "business as usual" in the months ahead, up from 34.5 percent registered in a similar poll a month earlier.

In the same survey, 31 percent of companies said that they think business conditions will improve, down from 46 percent in the previous survey, while only 11 percent said that they think conditions will get worse, down from 19 percent in the month-earlier survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGE LACKLUSTER AMID WEAK CONFIDENCE

TEXT.P: Weak investment confidence took its toll on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, which failed to recover the 6,000-point mark Friday after a plunge of 95 points at the end of the previous trading day.

Although the U.S. stock indexes stabilized Thursday, the weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, still fell by 46.54 points to close at 5,925.54 Friday, mainly affected by large selling by foreign institutional investors and the depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, as well as concern over oil prices. The index at one point fell below the 5,900-point level during the day's trading.

The weighted index dipped by 95.28 points to end at 5972.06 points Thursday, indicating shaking confidence in the domestic bourse. Foreign investors oversold NT$12.42 billion (US$376 million) worth of Taiwan shares that day -- the eighth single-day high on record.

Thomas M.F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), argued that the confidence crisis will be just a short-term phenomenon as a result of skyrocketing oil prices and the widening gap in interest rates between Taiwan and the United States.

Claiming that a country's economic performance is always the prime reason luring foreign capital to flow in rather than other factors such as interest rate gap, Yeh said that Taiwan's economy is expected to expand by 3.65 percent this year and by at least 4 percent next year. The domestic economy increased by 5.7 percent last year.

Meanwhile, market analysts urged investors to be cautious as bearish sentiment seems to continue to prevail in the domestic bourse in the weeks to come until the middle of the next month, the beginning of the traditional peak fourth quarter for both hi-tech and traditional business shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 46.52 points to close at 5,925.54.
The bourse opened at 5,957.79 and fluctuated between 5,973.72 and 5,899.59 during trading. A total of 2.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.61 billion (US$2.07 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 0.2 percent.

The other seven major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent, construction issues at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.2 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 633 to 240, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 48 points to close at 5,931, with 29,486 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 60 points to end at 5,930, with 181 contracts traded, while December futures lost 62 points to finish at 5,924, with 33 contracts traded. March futures moved down 85 points to close at 5,900, with 10 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 56 points to close at 5,930, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,979 for October, 5,990 for November, 5,986 for December, 5,985 for March and 5,986 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

October TE futures moved down three points to close at 245.4, with 4,028 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 3.9 points to finish at 244.6, with 14 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 2.4 points to end at 245.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

October TF futures gained 1.4 points to finish at 891.4, with 2,758 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down 3.2 points to end at 886.4, with 12 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 889.8, with nine contract transactions, while March TF futures lost five points to finish at 886.4, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.038 to close at NT$33.173.
A total of US$1.12 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.135 and hit a high of NT$33.204.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ELABORATES ON PRESIDENT'S INVESTMENT PROJECT IN CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's revelation of a new project for co-prosperity with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America is aimed at assisting Taiwan businessmen to invest in the region and cementing diplomatic relations, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks after the president announced the project Thursday in Guatemala on the first leg of a 12-day, five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean.

The project, which will call for an outlay of US$250 million per year to help the infrastructure of the diplomatic allies, will be formally announced when a summit meeting between the president and his counterparts from the Republic of China's allies in Central America and the Caribbean opens in Nicaragua Sept. 26.

Lu said the project was hammered out among government agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and the National Security Council and that Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will serve as convener of the project.
Lu said the money will come from the International Cooperation and Development Fund under the MOFA (more than NT$5 billion) and the Executive Yuan Development Fund (around NT$2.5 billion).
Lu said that the new project will be different from the past practice of sending technical missions or subsidizing private manufacturers investing in the region.

The government has adopted the different approach mainly because it wants to seize the opportunity of the great business opportunities presented with the passage of the Central American Free Trade Agreement by the U.S. Congress and the expected formation of the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA), he said.

This is why the government wants to join hands with the private sector to increase investment in Central America, which will not only help businesses reach out to the world, expedite their transformation and diversify the risks of their investment overseas, but will also help cement relations with the country's allies.
He said the project will be a long-term investment program that the government hopes will lead businesses to invest in such potential sectors as foodstuffs, textiles, electronics and information.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ORGANIZING CONFERENCE ON MONGOLIA, RUSSIA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) has decided to host Sept. 24-25 its 2005 Conference on Geopolitical Relations between Contemporary Mongolia and Neighboring Asian Countries, dubbed simply "Mongolia and Russia."

A total of 17 domestic and foreign scholars and experts have been invited to attend the two-day conference to discuss interaction and exchanges between Mongolia and three Mongolia-descended republics of the Russian Federation, including the Republic of Tuva, from the perspectives of politics, economics, regional security and culture, according to a MATC news release.

The participants will include Alexander Brokert, chairman of the Tuva-Mongolia friendship association; Zhelezniakov Aleksander, head of the Far East and Central East Center of the Russian Academy of Sciences; and Adiya Tuvshintugs, vice president of Mongolia's Institute of Strategic Studies, while Chang Chun-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan-Russia Association, will address the opening.

It will be the first meeting to gather academic personnel from the two countries in Taiwan to talk about their nations. The discussions are expected to expand Taiwan's knowledge about Mongolia and Russia as it tries to boost pragmatic relations with the two countries, the MATC said.
The MATC held the first conference of its kind in 2003. Topics discussed at the first two events were centered on "Mongolia and Central Asia" and "Mongolia and Northeast Asia," respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS ORDERS HIT RECORD HIGH IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers reached US$22.15 billion in August, the highest single-month figure in history, the Ministry of Economics Affairs reported Friday.
The figure represented an annual growth of 22.6 percent and was due to the increasing demand in Asian markets for information and electronics products, according to the report.

Meanwhile, the report also indicated that the island's industrial production index was 135.78 in August, a growth of 6.3 percent over the level of the previous month, or 5.92 percent over the level of the same month in 2004.
The industrial index in the first eight months of this year stood at 126.49, up 0.6 percent from the previous year, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER-RELIANCE ON FOREIGN TRADE NOT GOOD: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan must not overly depend on foreign trade as a means of expanding its economy and the government should galvanize local demand to that end, an economist urged Friday.

Speaking at a news conference to announce the publication of a monthly investigation of business conditions at home, Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) President Hung Teh-sheng said that now is the right time for the government to gauge how to boost local demand to help the domestic economy at a time when Taiwan's foreign trade surplus has been contracting for some time.

It is not healthy for the Taiwan economy to rely excessively on exports to sustain expansion as it has over the past decades, Hung said, adding that the government needs to encourage greater investment and consumption in the domestic market by the private sector to help minimize the impact of slowing foreign trade.

Taiwan recorded a combined trade surplus of US$1.17 billion for the first eight months of this year, down by 79 percent from the previous year's level. According to Hung, this was due to lagging outbound shipments and rising prices of imported products.

The TIER president attributed the domestic export sector's lackluster performance to relentless relocations overseas by information industry companies and to a side effect of decreasing Taiwan investment in China that has led to less demand for Taiwan exports.

In a related development, 31 percent of Taiwan companies questioned said that they think business conditions at home will improve in the months ahead, down from 46 percent in the previous month's survey, while 11 percent said that they think the business climate will get worse, down from 19 percent from a month ago, according to the same investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GUATEMALA SIGN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian signed a free trade agreement with his Guatemala counterpart Oscar Berger Perdomo Thursday to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
The agreement was sealed shortly after Chen arrived in Guatemala City from Miami, Florida on the first leg of his current five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean.
Chen was accorded a red-carpet welcome complete with full military honors upon his arrival in Guatemala for a state visit.
In an interview with the Guatemalan newspaper Diario Siglo 21 later in the day, Chen said he is hopeful that the Taiwan-Guatemala free trade agreement can take effect Jan. 1, 2006.

Chen said the free trade pact will help narrow the trade imbalance between Taiwan and Guatemala, which is now in Taiwan's favor. Moreover, Guatemala can use Taiwan as a gateway to explore the Asian market while Taiwan can expand its North American market by using Guatemala as a springboard.

In 2004, Chen said, Taiwan exported US$110 million in goods to Guatemala while importing US$4.1 million Guatemalan products. In the first seven months of this year, Taiwan exports to Guatemala dropped 40 percent from the year-earlier level, while Guatemalan exports to Taiwan more than tripled during the same period. Chen said the trade imbalance will further narrow after the implementation of the free trade pact.

Meanwhile, Chen said Taiwan will assist Guatemala in expanding its CA-9 highway which links Guatemala City to El Rancho on the Atlantic coast. Taiwan will assist in expanding one-third of the 33-km highway from two to four lanes, which will call for an outlay of US$17 million.

Chen Cheng-chung, secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund who is accompanying President Chen on his current diplomatic tour, said the ROC will offer a loan for the project. Noting that Guatemala has a good credit rating, Chen Cheng-chung said the Guatemalan government will repay the loan in line with a schedule to be set in a contract to be signed later.
On Thursday, President Chen also signed an aviation and maritime transport service agreement and a volunteer exchange accord with Berger.

Guatemala is the first leg of Chen's ongoing 12-day diplomatic tour that will also take him to the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

During his stay in Nicaragua, Chen will attend a summit meeting with his counterparts from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, namely Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, in addition to the top leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCREENING BEGINS ON ENTRIES IN 2005 GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The executive committee in charge of screening the entry films in the 2005 Golden Horse Awards festival sprang into action Friday after holding its first meeting.

The 11-member committee watched four films in a row: "House of Fury," "Malie," "Seoul Raiders," and "Love and Courage," after electing veteran movie director Chen Yao-chi, who has directed 22 films, as chairman.

Altogether there are 80 films competing in this year's festival for 21 awards. The entries consist of 56 feature films, 17 short films, three documentaries and four animated films. Taiwan has 39 entries, including 18 feature films.

In addition to its chairman, the committee has eight other members who will screen the feature film entries. They are musician Shih Chieh-yung, writer Lao Jia-hua, actress Chen Chiu-yen, movie photographer Chen Huai-en, Shih Hsin University Professor Tseng Hsi-pa, playwright Liming Huang, film critic Wen Tien-hsiang and Hong Kong film director Weng Wei-chuan.

Two other committee members in charge of the screening of non-feature films are Kristy Chu, head of the Department of Communication and Design at Shih Chien University, and Yang Li-chou, a documentary film director.
Two foreign nationals will be invited to join in the evaluation when the competition enters the final stage.

The Golden Horse Awards, an annual festival, is in its 42nd year this year. The committee is scheduled to announce a nomination list on Oct. 18, with the winners in 21 categories to be announced at a ceremony on Nov. 13 at the Keelung Cultural Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORK IS MOSTLY A CHORE FOR NEW EMPLOYEES IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: Most new employees feel uneasy in the workplace in Taiwan, and a majority of them hope to retire early at age 50, according to the results of an opinion poll published Friday.

About 28 percent of new employees polled said that they feel uneasy because of poor relations with their bosses, while 21 percent said that they are worried about being laid off and 19 percent pointed to heavy work pressure, according to the survey carried out by the headhunting human resources Web site -- www.1111.com.tw.

Some 38 percent said they were anxious over what they see as an uncertain future, ahead of 17 percent who hope to start their own business and around 16 percent who admitted to feeling reluctant to go to the office every day.

Sixty-four percent of junior office workers view their current occupation as just a way to make a living, while 16 percent said that working is the leading source of their vigor and more than 14 percent said that they force themselves to work to earn a living.
Some 33 percent of Taiwan's new office workers hope to be able to retire at the age of 50, ahead of 24 percent who hope to do so by the age of 35, and 21 percent who said 40.
The domestic Web site carried out the poll from Sept. 7 to Sept. 21, collecting 1,257 valid samples.

According to an investigation by a South Korean university, South Korean workers and employees are also under constant unease at their workplaces, with women, in particular those aged between 20 and 29 that have worked at least five years, suffering the most, an executive with the local Web site said.
Many office workers in both Taiwan and South Korea have "Monday blues, " with their work frequently being interrupted by fatigue, lack of concentration and anxiety.

According to a South Korean newspaper report, more and more office workers are willing to retire at a younger age now, normally at 40-something. Over 75 percent of the 3.23 million volunteer retirees in South Korea quit their jobs to run their own business, get married and raise children, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Miles of Traffic as Texans Heed Order to Leave
Colossal 100-mile-long traffic jams left many people stranded and out of gas as the huge storm bore down on the Texas coast.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Hurricane Rita Spins Toward Texas-Louisiana Coast
Hurricane Rita roared toward the Texas and Louisiana coasts early Friday, a major Category 4 storm that spurred a traffic-snarled exodus toward higher ground and fears it could cripple the heart of the nation's petrochemical industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Court Rejects Khodorkovsky Appeal
The Moscow City Court late Thursday rejected Mikhail Khodorkovsky's appeal in a marathon 11-hour session, cutting short his campaign for a State Duma seat before it even began.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS APPROVED TRIP BY FORMER PRESIDENT LEE: ORGANIZER

TEXT.P: The United States has approved a visit by former President Lee Teng-hui, Wu Ming-chi, president of the Washington-based pro-Taiwan independence group, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, said Friday.

Wu denied reports that the U.S. was still considering whether to grant approval for the trip, saying that Lee will be recognized in his capacity as a private citizen and the only thing remaining to be settled is the nature of his security detail, given his status as a former head of state.

Wu said his association, which is in charge of Lee's itinerary in Washington, has arranged for Lee to make two speeches, a brief one during a luncheon on Capitol Hill, and one at the National Press Club. The exact dates and times will be announced later by Lee's office, he added.

Local news reports have said that Lee will visit Anchorage, Alaska -- whose governor is a good friend of Taiwan -- New York, Washington and Los Angeles. Lee is expected to be in the States for about two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE COUNCIL TO HOLD EXERCISE IN MID-OCTOBER AGAINST AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture will hold an exercise in mid-October in the central County of Changhua against a possible outbreak of avian flu, with the participation of three other government agencies.

A council spokesman said Friday that the exercise involving the Coast Guard Administration, the Ministry of National Defense and the Environmental Protection Administration is intended to get all related government agencies familiarized with the measures designed to prevent the avian flu virus from spreading in Taiwan.

The council's strategy against avian flu includes such measures as stopping the disease at Taiwan's borders, strengthening quarantines, taking precautionary steps in Taiwan's communities and heightening the preparedness of all hospitals.

The spokesman also said that the council will seek the help of Taiwan's bird-watching societies to monitor the activities of migratory birds from Siberia. These birds may carry the avian flu virus, although they themselves may not be ill. The bird-watchers will be asked to notify authorities in charge of animal disease prevention whenever they spot a dead migratory bird.

In addition, he added, the council will help poultry and hog raisers in Taiwan set up bird nets around their farms to prevent migratory birds from coming into contact with chickens, ducks, geese and pigs in the farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTLINES OPEN FOR TAIWAN EXPATS IN HOUSTON AHEAD OF HURRICANE RITA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's liaison office in Houston, Texas has been ordered to activate an emergency mechanism to safeguard Taiwanese expatriates, students and travelers there with the approach of Hurricane Rita, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.

According the U.S. National Hurricane Center, the Category 4 hurricane, packing maximum sustained winds of about 225 kilometers per hour, is expected to make landfall somewhere between Galveston, Texas and the Louisiana boarder late Friday, U.S. local time. Around 1.3 million residents in Houston and its neighboring cities have been evacuated, the ministry said.

Taiwanese expatriates living in Houston's coastal areas have been evacuated, ministry officials said, noting that those who need help can take advantage of several hotlines, including that of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston at 002-1-832-654-6041, that of the office's Chinese Culture Center at 002-1-713-530-3733, as well as the emergency hotline of the Houston City Government at 002-1-713-837-0311 or that of Harris County Emergency at 002-1-713-881-3100.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE ALLIES SPEAK FOR ROC AT U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen thanked five of the ROC's allies Friday for their support for the country's bid for a seat in the United Nations.

Saint Kitts and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas, Senegal Foreign Minister Cheikh Tidiane Gadio, Vice Foreign Minister of Costa Rica Marco Vinicio Vargas, as well as Stuart Beck, the permanent representative of Palau at the U.N., all spoke for Taiwan during a general debate of the 60th U.N. General Assembly Thursday, following Burkina Faso Foreign Minister Youssouf Ouedraogo praising Taiwan people's efforts to seek democracy and peace at the same event a day earlier, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year through its diplomatic allies to have its U.N. bid placed on the General Assembly's agenda. However, it has been unsuccessful due to Beijing's obstruction.
Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with 26 countries.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the ROC was one of its founding members. However, it has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKED 1ST IN ASIA FOR GROWTH COMPETITIVENESS BY WEF: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked first in Asia, and fifth in the world in terms of growth competitiveness in a survey by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF) , an economics official said Friday.

Citing the 2005-2006 WEF survey, which is expected to be formally released on Sept. 28, Vice Minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said Taiwan is behind only Finland, the United States, Sweden and Denmark among the 117 economies covered by the survey.

Although Taiwan's rank is one place lower than last year, Yeh said the country leads Asian states for the fourth consecutive year, far ahead of the next best nation -- Singapore -- which came in sixth and was followed by Japan at 12th, South Korea at 17th, and Malaysia at 24th.
Hong Kong placed 26th, China 49th and Indonesia 74th.
Compared with last year, all Asian states, except for South Korea and Malaysia, moved down this year.
As details of the survey are not available until Sept. 28, Yeh said his office will study the full report to address the causes which prompted Taiwan's downgrade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO EXPLAIN MESSAGE HE ASKED SOONG TO RELAY TO HU
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will soon explain the details of the message that he asked opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong to convey to Chinese President Hu Jintao earlier this year, one of his aides said in Guatemala Thursday.

Chen, who is currently on a state visit in Guatemala, is scheduled to hold an informal meeting with a group of Taiwan reporters covering his ongoing five-nation diplomatic tour after he arrives in the Dominican Republic Sept. 24 on the second leg of his 12-day shuttle diplomacy, his aide said.
The president will then explain in detail what message he had asked Soong to relay to Hu during Soong's high-profile visit to China in May this year.

Soong met with Hu, who concurrently serves as general secretary of the Communist Party of China, in Beijing May 12. A senior U.S. State Department adviser, James R. Keith, claimed last week that Soong passed the message to Hu during their meeting that Chen was willing to engage in dialogue with Beijing using a flexible formulation about what constitutes "one China."
Beijing has long demanded that the ROC government on Taiwan embrace its cherished "one China" principle as a precondition for resuming dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen's aide said the president has never wavered on his stance toward China, nor did he ask Soong to offer some kind of trade-off on opening dialogue by accepting a flexible interpretation of the "one China" principle.
As to what exactly Chen did ask Soong to pass on to Hu, his aide said, the president will brief Taiwan reporters on the content in person Saturday.

During a transit stop in Miami, Florida, Wednesday, Chen said during a dinner with Taiwan expatriates there that he is willing to hold "rational dialogue" with his People's Republic of China counterpart without any preconditions. Such dialogue, which could be held any time and any place, would be aimed at creating a "window of opportunity" for "democratic Taiwan and democratic China to co-exist," he added.
Chen's aide said the president's call is a response to U.S. President George W. Bush's repeated appeal for Hu to hold a dialogue with Taiwan's popularly elected president and government.

"It is China that has attached the rigorous 'one China' principle as a precondition for resumption of cross-strait dialogue, " the aide said, adding that President Chen's stance has consistently been that cross-strait dialogue should follow the principles of "peace, parity and dignity."

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 24 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, September 24:
09:00, The fifth World Taiwanese Congress will open at Grand Hotel in Taipei.
09:30, A seminar on Mongolian-Russian relations will open at Civil Service Development Center in Taipei.
09: 50, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will speak on the "minimum tax" reform program at a seminar to be organized by Ketagalan Institute at Taipei International Convention Center.
10:15, Vice President Annette Lu will deliver a keynote speech at the World Taiwanese Congress.
11:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect the Nankang Industrial Zone in Nantou County.
15:00, Premier Hsieh will visit a farm produce wholesale market in Hsilou, Yunlin.
18:30, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will host a welcoming party on behalf of President Chen in honor of participants to the world Taiwanese Congress.
21:00, Premier Hsieh will expound on major government policy initiatives in Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY URGES E.U. TO HELP PUSH FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Sept. 23 (CNA) (By Y. S. Lou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Union can play a more active role in helping push the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume dialogue, the Republic of China representative to the E.U. and Belgium said Friday.

Chen Chien-jen told European journalists that despite the geographical distance, Europe has many shared interests with Taiwan. Moreover, he said, Asia's regional stability and security will benefit all people around the world.
Against this backdrop, Chen said he is hopeful that the E.U. can play an active role in pushing China to resume dialogue with Taiwan without any preconditions or political strings.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORTS PRESIDENT CHEN'S CALL FOR DIALOGUE WITH CHINA: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Oliver Lin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government supports Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian in his call made Wednesday for dialogue with China without preconditions, a senior Department of State official said Thursday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, the official, who requested anonymity, said the U.S. position is that the mainland ought to engage in dialogue with the elected representatives of the people of Taiwan, regardless of which party is in power.

As to the strong words made recently by Edward Ross, a principal director of the Pentagon's Defense Security Cooperation Agency, towards Taiwan on the long-stalled purchase of U.S. defensive weaponry, the official said his administration is looking for results, and not so much for further understanding of the complexity of domestic political situations in Taiwan.
"We really believe that the time has come for getting genuine results here, that it's the responsibility for both the ruling party and opposition parties, not one or the other," he said.

As to whether the appearance of increased restrictions on President Chen's U. S. transit this time was any indication of a change of US-Taiwan relations, the officials said that overall bilateral relations should not be judged on the basis of any one event.
Actually, he said, communication is quite good both in Washington and in Taipei: "We have very open channels, as possibly can be, very candid."
Following is the full text of the interview:

Q: On Mr. Keith's public statement to the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission, he mentioned that People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong passed to PRC President Hu Jintao the message that President Chen Shui-bian was willing to engage in dialogue with Beijing using a flexible formulation about what constituted "one China." The PFP, after initial denial, is now saying that you are stating the fact but not clear enough. The Presidential Office said Chen did asked Soong to pass a message, but not the one you mentioned. Could you give us some information on where Mr. Keith's information came from? A: The administration has nothing to add to the testimony that was
made. I think the Taiwan government will speak for itself for
this issue. What's more important is what President Chen has said
publicly about the desirability of cross-strait dialogue without
pre- conditions, which is something that the U.S. government,
this administration, supports. Q: To follow up on that, yesterday in Miami, President Chen said he
was willing to talk to Chinese President Hu Jintao anytime,
anywhere without pre-conditions. Could you talk a little more on

the U.S. position on this? A: The administration's position is completely consistent with the very long-standing policy. The American government position on cross-strait dialogue would like to see the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve these issues and resolve them peacefully. We talk to the Chinese people on both side of the Strait to do this in order to make that happen. Of course that needs dialogue. There has been ways that the two sides have worked out the modality of dialogue in the past. You go back to the 1990's. Clearly, there was such a dialogue going on. We'd very much like to see that happen again. As has been stated in every one of our senior meetings that involved any sort of discussion on Taiwan issues with the mainland, with the PRC, our position is always that the mainland ought to engage in dialogue with the elected representatives of the Taiwan people, regardless of which party is in power, regardless of the specific modalities that the Chinese people on both sides have to work out. Our view is, in order for these issues to be resolved peacefully, the binding concerns that we have is that there has to be dialogue. We certainly support President Chen's call for dialogue. It's clear that the mainland side would also like to be seen as promoting dialogue without pre-conditions. Both sides take the view that there are no conditions attached to their proposal for dialogue. When two sides get down to actually talking about it, one side or the other is able to identify what it perceives as pre-conditions on the other side. Our view is there are not to be any obstacles to the two sides sitting down and talking about the fundamental issues that are at issue in cross-strait relations. Q. So you do support dialogue without pre-conditions? A: We very much support the idea that the two sides are to sit down and have talks. There ought not to be any obstacles to the two sides sitting down and having talks. It's up to the Chinese on both sides of the Strait to work out precisely what that means as an operational term. In any given year you can identify different kinds of obstacles in the dialogue that might occur. Our hope is that on both sides there will be a meeting of the minds that such dialogue could take place. Q. You mentioned China wants to be seen as not attaching any conditions to dialogue?

A: This is often the case. This is telling in the press. If you read newspapers and follow the television reports on each side's position, often you'll see that the mainland and Taipei both want dialogue, and they don't intend that there be pre-conditions. And they have many different ways of describing their positions as if they have no pre-conditions. But the Taiwan side sees certain pre-conditions related, for example, most recently related to the so-called consensus of 1992. Similarly, there have been times in the past when the Taiwan side has proposed talks on various elements of cross-strait dialogue, but that they happen in certain ways in the Macau model or using some other model, and the mainland side has suggested that these are pre-conditions for talks. So all I'm saying is that it is up to the two sides to determine what that phrase means-"without pre- conditions." It 's not up to the Americans to lay that out. It's simply our position that, it's a very logical exposition of our position: number one, we believe that the set of issues embedded in the cross-strait [situation] ought to be resolved, we believe those issues ought to be resolved peacefully. Therefore, it follows, like day follows night, that there ought to be dialogue. Q. It seems that there are more restrictions on President Chen's transiting the U.S. this time. Is that any indication of U.S.-Taiwan relations? A: Well, as a general point, I'd encourage you not to judge the overall relations on the basis of any one event or a set of exchanges of ideas, whether it be the meetings that happened in San Diego earlier this week, or the presence or absence of transits through the United States. None of these are a litmus test for the entire relationship. So, what I'm trying to do is simply to steer you away from that way of looking at the relationship. All that said, this transit was conducted in Miami. It's a fact that it was completely consistent with the guidelines that we've set out for every one of these transits, which involves convenience, comfort and dignity for the individual traveling. So, I would not read too much into any one transit whether it was in 2003 or 2005. Q: How do you take this opportunity to convey your messages to President Chen? A: As you know, we have regular dialogue through our unofficial representatives via the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) Washington office as well as the AIT office in Taipei. Those are our mechanisms for conveying information back and forth about a whole range of issues, political, cultural, economic, scientific, that are important to us in relationship between American people and Taiwan people. Apart from that, I would leave it to the delegation to describe any communications. That's up to them to describe whether they want to or not. I'm not presuming their ability or options to do so. Q. Recently President Hu Jintao called on the United States to "join the Chinese side" in safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, and opposing so-called Taiwan independence. Does the U.S. accept this view? A: As in any scenario with the issue, and I know you've studied the issue very carefully...No, in our exchanges with the PRC on this issue, we have a very careful and deliberate presentation that we make on a regular basis whenever we are asked by the mainland side about this. They need to have their own formulations. They put it into their own words. Neither side seeks to go out and correct every word, every comma in the other side's formulation. Something in illustration of a larger context of the issue, if you go back to 1972, 1979, clearly, the two sides, the United States and the People's Republic of China, had agree to disagree, essentially, through the communiques about this issue. In our presentations, while there may, and often are, differences in the ways that words are put together. I think it's safe to say that we understand each other very well. Our positions are very clear to each other. And even though we don't have to correct every element of the Chinese presentation, and similarly, they seek not to pick at our presentation. Of course, it's very clear we'll include the Taiwan Relations Act. It's an important part of our conception of the Taiwan issue in our relationship both with Taiwan and the PRC. Obviously, there is no reference to the Taiwan Relations Act in any of their presentations. They certainly do refer to the Three Communiques on the mainland side. So, there are differences in our presentations. But I think that simply reflects different emphases that each side would put on or include in descriptions of our policies derived from our own national interests. I wouldn't read too much into the fact either that the Chinese use this particular formulation in this case, or that we didn't respond to it publicly. Our position is our position. It has been there for a long time and it won't be changing. I think the Chinese side understands it very well. Q: Edward Ross, a director in the Pentagon's Defense Security Cooperation Agency, recently had some strong words towards Taiwan on a defense purchase budget. If in the end Taiwan fails to pass the arms purchase budget, how would the United States react? A: I think rather than deal with any one of the many potential outcomes that may be out there, I'd simply make the point that the administration is looking for results, and not so much for further understanding of the complexity of domestic political situations in Taiwan. I think we have a good feel for that, and we understand, these are at times complicated issues that are involved in other parts of the budget and other parts of domestic political context. But we really believe that time has come for getting genuine results here, that it's the responsibility for both the ruling party and opposition parties, not one or the other. Q. What's your impression on the [Nationalist Party - Kuomintang] KMT's new chairman, Ma Ying-jeou? Considering the blue camp accepts the "one China" policy, if the blue camp wins the presidency in 2008, how do you think that would impact cross-strait relations? A: In my sense, the current situation in the Taiwan Strait is conducive to not only dialogue between the mainland and elected representatives of the Taiwan people, but also with progress in some other areas that have been talked about under the Macau model. It seems to me this is a good time for progress to be made in cross-strait, whether by the current ruling party or after the election in the future by the other side. I think what the most important this is to look after the interests of the 23 million Taiwan people. Their interests ought to be paramount regardless of the personality or party that's in charge. Certainly, from an outsider point of view, pursuing dialogue and a peaceful resolution of fundamental issues and progress toward increasing confidence on both sides in a dialogue that could lead to stability would be in the best interests for Chinese people on both sides of the Strait. I do believe that leadership is needed in this area, because of course there are many controversies associated with each and every one of the specific proposals for advancing cross-strait relations. Looking at the trends of two economies integrating, that is Taiwan and the mainland, which is part of the global trend, of course. The American economy is integrating with Asian economies and others around the world. This globalization is a trend that of course, Taiwan is not going to escape, or shouldn't escape. It should seize this opportunity, should take advantage of it from a market perspective, and certainly from the perspective of American businessmen who want to be involved in Taiwan and want to be involved with Taiwan in the mainland. There are great opportunities here. I'd hope that regardless of the personality in power, the party in power, that there will be a willingness to maximize the efforts to take this opportunity. Q: According to the Washington Times, the State Department's Inspector General's Office's inspection report said that AIT Taipei Director Douglas Paal "falsely reported on Taiwanese issues to senior State Department officials, " and "refused to allow dissenting views and was guilty of suppressing reports from U.S. officials who disagreed with his pro-China views." What do you think about this?

A: I find it despicable that anyone would leak this sort of information. I think what is there available publicly could give you a good picture of our operation in AIT, which is staffed by terrific people. And we have the greatest confidence from the leadership on down in that operation. Beyond that I'm not going to comment. I'm not going to give any credence to these charges that were put out by people who obviously had ulterior motives. Q. What is your assessment on current U.S.-Taiwan relations. I would imagined that normally there are goods parts, and also some difficult parts. What are those? And how are communications going between the two sides?

A: I'll take the last point first. I think the communication is quite good both in Washington and in Taipei. We have very open channels, as can possibly be, very candid. We talk about, as you suggest, the whole range of the relationship, including that there might be some differences. It's not only government to government dialogue, of course. There is a great deal of back and forth, not only within the administration, within the government side of the dialogue, but also with our colleagues in the legislative branch and from the legislature in Taiwan. I think there is a very rich and full set of communication on the government side. On our side, of course that is done through the American Institute in Taiwan. And also in the private sector, we have tremendous interest in sustaining the relationship that we have. I think my greatest frustration is that we haven't been able to get traction on these key issues which would help us in advancing the relationship in keeping with the advances that one sees in Taiwan's presence in the mainland. So, looking to the future, what I'd like to see is a development of rich and productive exchanges across the board with the private sector and their Taiwan counterpart that could lead to reconfiguration of economic exchanges and trade between us, and investment that is possible not just in our U.S. relationship with Taiwan, but also looking to other opportunities in the region. Q: Are you referring to the "three links"? A: I think it begins with the "three links," but it's very difficult
for the government to identify precisely those steps. If you look
at the "three links, " I gather, looking from outside as an
analyst, the "three links" are precisely those kind of things
that are necessary for the governments on the both sides of the
Strait to work on, in order to open the doors so that the private
sector can do more. Really it's governments' job to set up those
kinds of communications links necessary so that individuals can
start making the kinds of connections that would be very
productive for both sides, and for Taiwan not only to advance its
own economic interest but also present an opportunity for
enhancing the stability, prosperity, and the predictability of
the relationship across the Strait. These ties increase over time
through these channels that ought to be open.
Q: Again, there is a pre-condition problem for the "three links." A: All I can say to that is, Chinese from both sides of the Strait
found a way around that problem in the past. That means that it
can be done. Q: President Chen has aimed to pass constitutional amendments by the
end of 2007. He has pledged to focus on good governance and avoid
issues such as sovereignty, name and territory. Does the United
States still have concerns over Taiwan's constitutional
amendment? A: I think it is something we have to look at when we have something
concrete before us. That's the reason why we want to hear the
Taiwan side, what their intent is, what their prospects are, that
sort of thing. It's very hard to talk about it in the abstract.
Clearly, it's an issue that the Taiwan people have to decide for
themselves. But just as clearly, we do have an interest in the
overall situation. You know what our obligations are in the
Taiwan Relations Act. So we are more than just an interested
observer. As a result of that, we hope for very good
communications to help us understand what the issues are and once
we have a better understanding of a specific case, then we can
have an American position about it in terms of what the American
overall interest is in cross-strait dialogue and in the region.
Clearly these are issues that Taiwan people have to think about,
digest and formulate before the United States can have a response

to them. Q. Taiwan has accused China of trying to exploit its economic leverage over Taiwan politics, such as exempting tariffs for Taiwan fruit to hurt the [Democratic Progressive Party] DPP's political base. Taiwan calls such measures "united front tactics." What do you think about this? A: In any specific case, the Taiwan side will have to come up with
its own analysis and its own policy recommendations. Taking a
step back from that specific case and just making a general
comment, I think it's difficult to have this both ways. If the
Taiwan side wants the mainland to genuinely formulate policy to
address the needs and aspirations of the Taiwan people, which we
believe it should, then it has to accept that as the mainland
addresses some of these issues, they'll touch upon specific
interests groups or have an effect in the domestic polity in
Taiwan. It's unavoidable. So, while in any one case, one could
posit that the mainland is less interested in substance and more
interested in the process that it looks like than actually
proposing something serious rather than proposing it. I think if
we are going to continue to encourage the mainland to address the
needs of the Taiwan people, we have to assume that some of those
proposals are going to affect some groups more than others, or be
more beneficial from one perspective than another. There has to
be willingness to deal with that kind of effect as part of any
serious proposal for dialogue across the Strait. In other words,
it's a mistake to dismiss any proposal simply because it has a
domestic political effect in Taiwan. If so, you'll have to
dismiss everything because all will be tied up with very
difficult domestic politics on both sides. So while I could
understand the suspicion and concern that the mainland may be
seeking not so much to make progress but just to manipulate, this
is exactly the fundamental point that it's up to the Chinese on
both sides to find their way back to the situation in which
genuine dialogue can happen to address real proposals on both
sides to serve the interests of both populations. I think it's
undeniable that in a general context, agricultural trade is a
good thing across the Strait. Whether this particular proposal
fits into the template that you describe or could become or be
made to be more serious, is up to the Chinese on both sides of
the Strait to determine. But certainly you don't want to rule out
agricultural trade completely, because that wouldn't be
reasonable. There has to be a way to find a productive ground in
between these two extremes, that is, pure propaganda on the one
end and complete unwillingness to engage on the other. Somewhere

in the middle. Q. Former President Lee Teng-hui plans to visit the United States, including Washington, D.C. Would the U.S. agree to let him visit, considering that he has reportedly declared that he would like to say what the Taiwan government dared not say.

A: Certainly his visit here would not be a concern. The administration has very clearly indicated on the record that the former president is a private citizen and more than welcome to visit the United States. It's incumbent for the former president to consider the effect of his public rhetoric while he is in the United States. If, as having been suggested by some comments in the press in Taiwan, there were deliberately provocative statements that were at odds with Taiwan government's policy and the American government's policy, the United States government would have to clarify its own policy, rather than have it be unclear whether there was a change in American policy, or whether there is some lack of clarity about American policy based on the statement that the former president might make in the United States. The United States welcomes all kinds of views, including those views that don't accord with current U.S. policy. It's up to the former president to make up his own mind about the effect of his comments, and whether they would be at bearing with long standing policy both of Taiwan and the United States, which would require some clarification. The political effect of that clarification between what the former president might say in the United States and what our policy is, how our policy would be reiterated, because our policy isn't changing. It's an issue that the former president ought to think about. I'm not going to presume to know what the former president has in mind to say in the United States. I can only make clear that the administration's policy toward Taiwan is absolutely crystal clear. The president [Bush] has spoken to this very clearly. There is no change coming in U.S. policy either on the eve of, during or after a visit by the former president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Sept. 24, or the 21st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
768: Pepin the Short, King of the Franks who was also known as Pepin III, dies at the age of 54. He defended papal interests and established the core territory of the Papal States.
1789: John Jay is appointed by President George Washington as the first chief justice of the U.S. Supreme Court.
1862: Prussian statesman Otto von Bismarck, who was appointed chancellor by King William, rescues his beleaguered king from a losing battle with the Liberal government.
1869: Panic hits Wall Street as the bottom falls out of the gold market -- with the entire stock market following it down, in an event known as "Black Friday."
1877: Japan's modern army crushes a rebellion by 40,000 feudal samurai warriors fighting for their old way of life and their honor.
1905: Wu Yeh, a member of the Revolutionary Alliance, fails in his attempt to assassinate five high-ranking officials of the Ching court at the Beijing railway station. The Revolutionary Alliance, organized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Tokyo, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1924: China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto for the drafting of his "Fundamentals of National Reconstruction."
1933: The China Motion-Picture Studio is established in Nanking.
1934: Babe Ruth, American baseball's first great home run hitter, plays his last game at Yankee Stadium in New York. He hit more than 50 homers in four different seasons, including a record 60 homers in 1927. Before Ruth, no player had hit more than 24 in a season. Ruth had hit a total of 714 home runs by the time he retired in 1935.
1937: Chiang Kai-shek, in an interview with the foreign press, declares that China is fighting for its survival and for the principles of the Nine-Power Treaty, the Anti-War Pact and the Covenant of the League of Nations.
1941: Nine allies meeting in London pledge allegiance to the Atlantic Charter, an eight-point declaration issued by U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.
1941: The siege of Leningrad begins with the Royal Air Force supporting the Red Army.
1947: A trainload of Muslim refugees fleeing to Pakistan is massacred by Sikhs at Amritsar in the Punjab, with at least 1,200 defenseless people shot or hacked to death.
1958: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down 10 Communist Chinese MiG-17s and probably damages six others off the coast of mainland China.
1960: The USS Enterprise, the first American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, is launched from Newport, Virginia.
1973: The Republic of Guinea-Bissau in West Africa proclaims independence from Portugal.
1980: Iraq invades Iran in force and destroys the huge oil refinery at Abadan as months of border incidents flare into full-scale war.
1983: Italy jails chemicals executives responsible for the Seveso dioxin disaster, in which a poisonous gas cloud escaped from a factory in Seveso and contaminated a wide area of land.
1988: The ROC Finance Ministry announces the resumption of a stock exchange levy, beginning from Jan. 1, 1989.
1992: ROC Foreign Minister Fredrick Chien and his Vanuatu counterpart Serge Vohor sign a joint communique pledging reciprocal recognition.
1993: Norodom Sihanouk reclaims the Cambodian throne and signs into law a new constitution proclaiming Cambodia a democratic, constitutional monarchy.
1995: Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organization agree to sign a historic pact at the White House in the United States, ending nearly three decades of Israeli occupation of West Bank cities.
1996: The United States, mainland China, France, Russia and Britain sign a landmark treaty ending all testing and development of nuclear weapons.
1996: The U.S. House of Representatives endorses a July 18 European Parliament resolution supporting ROC efforts to participate in the international community.
1999: Chen Ching-hung, a six-year-old ROC boy is pulled alive by Korean rescue workers from the rubble of a demolished building in Taichung, 88 hours after the cataclysmic 921 earthquake.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, the ROC's top mainland policy planner, meets with visiting Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew for exchanges of views on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Nobel laureate and exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingjian arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit, mainly for an exhibition of his paintings and for talks about publication of his new plays.
2001: The first batch of imported vegetables that the government ordered to cope with the shortages brought about by Typhoon Nari arrives from Vietnam and the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is foolish and yet is fond of using his own judgment, who is in humble circumstances and yet is fond of assuming authority, who, while living in the present age, reverts to the ways of antiquity, such a man is one who will bring calamity upon himself."
