DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, Sept. 23 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shu-bian signed a joint communique with his Dominican Republic counterpart Leonel Fernandez Reyna Friday to reaffirm bilateral friendship and solidarity between the two countries.

President Chen and his entourage arrived in the capital of the Dominican Republic from Guatemala Friday afternoon and were accorded a red carpet welcome complete with 21-gun salute and full military honors.

After the signing of the joint communique, the two heads of state noted that they were happy to see the two countries sign a letter of intent in February on the signing of a Taiwan-Dominican Republic free trade agreement (FTA) and that they agreed that the two countries should begin consultations on the matter immediately so as to strengthen bilateral economic and trade relations.
Fernandez invited Taiwan's public and private enterprises to invest in his country, vowing that his government will provide incentives and all necessary assistance.

President Chen promised to help promote more investment in the Dominican Republic, adding that Taiwan will also help the Caribbean country improve the lives of its garlic growers and urban economy and set up a burn treatment center for children.

For his part, Fernandez expressed his support for Taiwan and his opposition to the use of force in solving cross-strait disputes. He also reaffirmed his support for the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations.
At a dinner banquet, Fernandez reaffirmed his longstanding support for the deepening of democracy in Taiwan and his stance of settling cross-strait disputes by peaceful means.

Noting that Taiwan's economic miracle is the model of Asian and Pacific countries, Fernandez expressed the hope that more Taiwan entrepreneurs will invest in his country and that the two countries can sign the FTA soon.

President Chen said the signing of the FTA will lure more Taiwan businesspeople to invest in the Dominican Republic and promote exchanges between Taiwan and the Caribbean and North America. Taiwan can also serve as a springboard for businesses in the Caribbean to make inroads into the Asian market, he noted, adding that the FTA will create a win-win situation.

Chen also said that a softball team comprised of officials and journalists from Taiwan will have a friendly match with a team comprised of Dominican Republic officials Saturday morning to help close the gap between the peoples of the two countries.
Chen's ongoing 12-day diplomatic tour will also take him to Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

During his stay in Nicaragua, Chen will attend a summit meeting with his counterparts from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, namely Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, in addition to top leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS NEEDED TO EXPAND TAIWAN-RUSSIAN RELATIONS: MTAC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to expand its exchanges and upgrade the level of mutual cooperation with Russia under the concept of regional security, Taiwan's Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) minister said Saturday.

Hsu Chih-hsiung made the remarks at the opening of the MTAC-sponsored 2005 Conference on Geopolitical Relations between Contemporary Mongolia and Neighboring Asian Countries: Mongolia and Russia, held at the Civil Service Development Center in Taipei.

Seventeen domestic and foreign scholars and experts are attending the two-day conference to discuss interactions and exchanges between Mongolia and three Mongolia-descended republics of the Russian Federation -- Tuva, Buryatia and Kalmyk -- from the perspectives of politics, economics, regional security and culture.

Noting that Russia under President Vladimir Putin has made efforts to adjust its international political and economic strategies to adopt to the global trends in the 21st century, Hsu suggested that Taiwan "walk out of the shadow of China" to try to develop multilateral interactions with countries in the Asian region.
The minister expressed the hope that the Taiwan-Russia friendship will take root and deepen further and that mutually beneficial exchanges between the two countries will be established.
Hsu also spoke about his several visits to Russia in recent months, during which he had intensive interactions with high-ranking officials of the three Russian republics.

The participants in the conference include Alexander Brokert, chairman of the Tuva-Mongolia friendship association; Zhelezniakov Aleksander, head of the Far East and Central East Center of the Russian Academy of Sciences; Adiya Tuvshintugs, vice president of Mongolia's Institute of Strategic Studies; and Chang Chun-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan-Russia Association.

Chang said that despite the fact that there is a large geographic distance between the Russian Federation and Taiwan, the latter still needs to concern itself with Central Asian peace and prosperity and to try to boost its relations with Russia in a good way.

Chang, former ROC premier, is set to depart for Russia at the head of a trade and economic delegation Sept. 26 for a visit aimed at enhancing relations between the two countries. Taiwan set up a representative office in Moscow in 1993 in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, with Russia following suit three years later by opening a liaison office in Taipei.
Taiwan and Mongolia exchanged representative offices in 2002. The two countries do not maintain formal diplomatic relations.
Saturday's conference is the third of its kind since 2003. Topics discussed at the first two gatherings centered on "Mongolia and Central Asia" and "Mongolia and Northeast Asia," respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN NAVAL SHIPS RESCUES TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Pingtung-registered Taiwanese fishing boat "Chin Chi Wan" which has been hijacked by its Indonesian crew since Sept. 8 was rescued by two Indonesian naval vessels Saturday in Indonesian waters, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said.

The boat was allegedly hijacked by three Indonesian fishery workers aboard after setting off from the coast of Mauritius Aug. 26 for fishing operations in nearby waters. Also on board were a Taiwanese skipper, identified as Lin Chung-uo, and eight Philippine crew members.

Lu indicated that thanks to the vessel's global positioning system equipment, the government was able to continue monitoring its whereabouts. No sooner was the "Chin Chi Wan" discovered sailing towards Indonesia than the MOFA issued a call for the Indonesian government's assistance to intercept the boat, he said.

No injuries or damage was reported in the rescue operation, and the Taiwanese skipper called members of his family in Taiwan after the incident to report that he was in good health, the MOFA official said.
He also noted that the vessel is expected to arrive Monday in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta where an investigation into the incident will be launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO PROMULGATE REDISTRICTING PLAN BY NOV. 2006

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will promulgate the newly redistricted constituencies for the next legislative election by the end of November 2006, according to a written report by CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung released Saturday.

Chang will be invited to give a report to the Home and Nations Committee at the Legislative Yuan on related operations concerning the redrawing of the constituencies, as well as anti-graft measures in the year-end elections and electoral system reforms.

Chang noted that according to the constitutional amendment passed this June, the electoral system for legislators will be changed from the current multiple seats per constituency to a "single seat, two votes" format.

In line with the constitutional amendment, the CEC, which has been commissioned with the task of redistricting the constituencies, will carry out the task in a "fair, objective and impartial" manner, Chang said, knowing that the issue has been controversial in the experience of many other countries.

Chang said that related operations have included the formation of a team in July 2005 to work out the redistricting principles, which are to be sent to municipal, city and county election commissions.
The commissions will work out their draft redistricting plans and hold public hearings by the end of next March and send the results to the CEC the following month for reference.
The CEC team will hold public hearings by the end of next August and complete a draft redistricting plan by the end of September and then promulgate it by the end of November.

Starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, the legislative electoral system will be changed, and the Legislative Yuan will have only 113 seats and be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

CEC officials have said that the redrawing of the constituencies should be promulgated one year before the term of the incumbent legislators expires, which means it should be announced by Jan. 31, 2007 at the latest.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD AIMING TO CUT JOBLESS RATE TO 4 PERCENT FOR 2005

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will coordinate related government agencies to help boost employment and cut the average jobless rate to 4 percent for 2005.

CEPD officials said the average unemployment rate for the first eight months was 4.19 percent, and they want government agencies to promote various measures, such as training programs and low-interest loans for youths wanting to start their own businesses, to reach the 4-percent goal for this year.

The officials made the remarks as the latest figures released by the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics showed that the jobless rate in August was 4.36 percent, up 0.04 percentage points over the previous month's figure due mainly to new college and university graduates entering the job market.

However, the figure represented a 0.31 percentage point drop from the same month last year, or the lowest for the month in the last five years, showing that the government's efforts to boost employment have borne fruit, the officials said.

Analysis of the August figures shows that job dissatisfaction topped the list in terms of newly unemployed workers, with some 6,000 people quitting their jobs during the month for this reason, while some 2,000 others lost their jobs due to business closures or scaling down.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE FACILITATION MECHANISM PROPOSAL GREETED WARMLY IN WTO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's proposal to set up a regular trade facilitation mechanism under the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been warmly greeted by developing countries in the WTO, a trade official said Saturday.

Huang Chih-peng, director general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the proposal is aimed at encouraging developing and less-developed countries to take part in the talks on trade facilitation which is one of the main issues in the Doha Round talks sponsored by the WTO.

After the persistent efforts by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the forerunner of the WTO -- and the WTO, the tariffs of various countries have been slashed significantly, and tariffs are no longer as much of a barrier to international trade as the large amounts of red tape that exist in moving goods across borders, Huang explained.

Documentation requirements often lack transparency and are duplicated in many places, a problem often compounded by a lack of cooperation between traders and official agencies, and add an extra cost of 5 percent to 15 percent to the price of the goods, Huang continued.

He said Taiwan presented the written proposal at the eighth conference of the WTO Trade Facilitation Committee calling for the establishment of a regular trade facilitation mechanism. He didn't say where or when this conference was held.

With the establishment of such a mechanism, Huang said, negotiations on and cooperation in wiping out red tape in international trade can keep going on after the conference of the committee. By regular mechanism, Huang said, this could mean a commission, working group, task force or annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKER PROTESTS AGAINST JAPAN AT U.N.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 23 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei led a group of aboriginal people to lodge a protest Friday at the United Nations headquarters in New York over Japanese atrocities against Taiwan's aboriginal people during its colonial rule of Taiwan between 1895-1945.

Kao and nearly 30 representatives from six of Taiwan's indigenous tribes -- the Bunun, Paiwan, Taroko, Kavalan, Puyuma and Atayal -- gathered at the Dag Hammarskjold Plaza opposite the U.N. headquarters.

They displayed banners and shouted slogans to highlight their cause, saying that Japan has not taken responsibility for its past mistakes, and using their songs and dances to tell the Japanese government that it is time to reflect, apologize and make compensation for their atrocities.

Though their numbers are not many, Kao Chin said, they are confident that through their determination, they will force change and gain the support of "all peace-loving and human rights-respecting people."
Kao Chin and her group earlier rallied in front of the Japanese general consulate to try to present a protest letter, but no one was there to receive the letter.

Kao Chin's group held a press conference in New York, took part in two charity parties given by Taiwan expatriates, as well as had exchanges with the aboriginal peoples of the United States during their stay in the city. They will leave for Philadelphia Monday.

Over the past three years, Kao Chin has traveled to Japan seven times, and her latest trip was in June this year, during which she demanded an apology and compensation from the Japanese government for the Taiwanese aborigines who were killed during World War II in combat as drafted Japanese Imperial Army soldiers.

Kao Chin wanted the spiritual tablets of their ancestors, who fought for the Japanese, removed from the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. They were placed in the temple along with 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan and 1,068 convicted war criminals.
Kao Chin had said that it was absurd that the aboriginal soldiers, whom she described as victims of Japanese persecution, are honored together with their persecutors at the Yasukuni Shrine.
Kao Chin's demand was obstructed each time and she finally filed suits against the Japanese government.
After her trip in the United States, Kao Chin will travel directly to Osaka to hear the court verdict Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS TOP LIST OF FOREIGN VISITORS TO EXPO AICHI
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan tourists topped the list in terms of number of foreign visitors to Expo Aichi 2005, an official of the exhibition said Saturday.
Expo Association Secretary-General Toshio Nakamura said that Taiwan tourists accounted for 18.8 percent of all foreign visitors. The expo will draw to an end Sunday.
They were followed by South Korean visitors at 15.7 percent, American visitors at 13 percent, Chinese visitors at 11 percent, and Australian visitors at 4.1 percent.
Nakamura said that the goal of 15 million visitors to the exhibition was achieved Aug. 18, and that as of Saturday, the number topped 21.69 million.
Foreign visitors accounted for 5 percent of all visitors to the park, or around one million people, coming from more than 60 countries around the world, he added.

The Japanese parliament passed a special bill granting 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the eco-friendly World Expo in Aichi prefecture in central Japan.
Japan later announced a permanent visa waiver for Taiwan tourists effective from Sept. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ACCOMMODATE CHINESE DEMOCRACY ACTIVISTS IN 3RD COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan authorities are trying to accommodate two Chinese democracy activists in another country and are offering vocational training to prepare them for living abroad, a Chinese affairs official said Saturday.

Yang Chia-chun, director of the Legal Affairs Department under the Mainland Affairs Council, said the government is doing its best to offer Yan Peng and Chen Rongli the convenience of living in Taiwan for the time being, and is exploring through diplomatic channels the possibility of transferring them to another country.
Yang made the remarks after a group of Chinese political dissidents in China and overseas appealed earlier in the day to Taiwan to grant asylum to the two.

Yan, who escaped from the mainland to Kinmen, a Taiwan-controlled island off the coast of Fujian, southern China, in June, 2004, had first been detained in a camp in Ilan as an illegal Chinese immigrant before being removed to an unspecified place.

Calling himself a political dissident, Yan asked for political asylum in Taiwan. He said he had been jailed by Chinese authorities in 2002 for 18 months for organizing a rally in Qingdao, Shandong Province in northern China in 1989 in solidarity with the Tiananmen democracy campaign in Beijing.
Yang said his office is trying to verify Yan's claims and his identification and help him to move to another country as he wishes, adding that this will take both time and patience.
Before he settles in another country, Yang said, the Taiwan government will provide him with confortable accommodation and allowance.
The government is treating in the same way another self-proclaimed Chinse dissident, Chen Rongli, who fled to Taiwan in January, 2004, and sought political asylum.
Yang said the government is keeping a low profile in its handling of the two's asylum bids out of concerns that other countries might deny them entrance should China protest against it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST MEET CHALLENGES BROUGHT BY CHINA'S ECONOMIC RISE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan must adjust its industrial structure, encourage and boost technological research, and develop brand-name products as the island faces a series of major challenges stemming from China's economic rise, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Saturday.

Chen made the remarks at a seminar held at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei. The challenges facing Taiwan in the fields of trade and economy include increasing manufacturing costs, slim profit margins in the high-tech industry, China's rise, the prevalence of regional economic integration, and strict restrictions in the Kyoto Protocol on greenhouse gas emissions, he said.

Pointing to the worldwide impact of China's economic rise, Chen said the "over-heated" economic activities in China have attracted a tremendous amount of "blind" foreign investment inflows. He noted that foreign direct investment (FDI) in China expanded from US$40.7 billion in 2000 to US$60 billion in 2004, with the latter figure representing 50 percent of all FDI in Asia and 10 percent of the global total.

This, coupled with China's great demand for raw materials and energy has resulted in an imbalance in supply and demand. Taking crude oil as an example, he said the daily consumption of crude oil in China is expected to increase to 6.89 million barrels this year from the level of 6.43 million barrels in 2004.
In terms of raw steal, China's annual consumption is expected to rise from 299 million tons in 2004 to 331 million tons for this year, or 25 percent of the global total.

Meanwhile, products made in China are flooding into markets around the world. Citing U.S. statistics, Chen said that 13 percent of imports into the United States in 2004 came from China, up from only 9 percent in 1999. During the same period, Taiwan's share of US market slipped from 3.2 percent to 2.5 percent, while Japan's and South Korea's also slipped.

Faced with these trends, Taiwan must increase its competitiveness by upgrading the conventional industry, encouraging companies to set up research and development centers, and increasing the add-value of products.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUILD UP DEFENSES TO COUNTER CHINA'S RISE: DEFENSE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Facing China's agressive military buildup, Taiwan's should strengthen its defenses to counter China's aggressive military buildup, Vice Minister of National Defense Michael M. Tsai said Saturday.

In a seminar organized by the World Taiwanese Congress, the vice defense minister said China budgets US$30 billion for miltiary buildup every year, in addition to secret military spending of US$60 billion.
In light of the fact that China is under no military threat, its aggressive miltary buildup has belied its claims of peaceful emergence, Tsai said.
In order to counter China's threat, Taiwan has to strengthen its defenses by acquiring the package of arms offered to sell by the U. S., Tsai went on.
His opinion was shared by Kurt Campell, senior vice president of the Washington-based think tank, the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

Campell said at the same seminar that the U.S., preoccupied with the crisis in Iraq, has not paid enough attention to the military threat posed by China in Asia and Taiwan should raise the US general public's awareness of this.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Sept. 25, or the 22nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1690: Benjamin Harris of Boston founds "Public Occurrences Both Foreign and Domestic," the first newspaper in the American Colonies. However, the colonial government ordered it stopped after one issue.
1818: The first blood transfusion using human blood takes place at Guy's Hospital in London.
1851: More than 20,000 Taiping rebels choose the Christian prophet Hung Hsiu-chuan, 39, as king at their mountain stronghold in China.
1897: William Faulkner, American writer, is born. He won the 1949 Nobel Prize for literature. His novels included "The Sound and the Fury" and "The Unvanquished."
1937: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini meets with German Fuehrer Adolf Hitler in Germany.
1944: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, supreme commander of the China Theater of War, asks the United States to replace Gen. Joseph Stilwell, chief of staff of the China Theater of War and commander of all the American armed forces in China, Burma and India. Stilwell is succeeded by Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer on Oct. 29.
1954: Dr. Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa" Doc, wins the presidential election in Haiti.
1957: Protected by a thousand army paratroopers with fixed bayonets, nine black children take their places in the all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas.
1959: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Solomon Bandaranaike is assassinated by a Singhalese Buddhist monk and is succeeded by his wife, Sirimavo Bandaranaike, a radical socialist.
1962: World heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson loses his title in a first-round knockout by Sonny Liston who knocks the champion to the ground with four punches, two minutes into the first round in Chicago.
1966: Two typhoons hit Japan, leaving over 300 people dead or missing.
1967: The first conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens in Taipei with more than 200 leaders from 72 nations and areas attending.
1970: Erich Maria Remarque, German author of "All Quiet on the Western Front," dies in Switzerland at the age of 72.
1972: Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka visits the Chinese mainland.
1977: Giacomo Agostini, Italian ace motorcycle racer, announces he is set to retire. He was a champion a record 15 times between 1966 and 1976, racing both 350cc and 500cc bikes.
1978: A Pacific Southwest Airlines Boeing 727 collides with a private light aircraft over San Diego, killing 150 people.
1984: Egypt resumes diplomatic relations with Jordan after a seven-year break.
1986: The Republic of China, after withdrawing for thirteen years, is readmitted into the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA).
1989: The Sky-bow Weapons System, developed and manufactured by the ROC, is added to the nation's military defense system.
1991: The Mainland Affairs Council announces the establishment of a task force to combat crime across the Taiwan Strait.
1992: Washington and Moscow grant freedom of travel to journalists and business representatives working in each other's countries.
1995: Rodrigo Oreamuno, vice president of Costa Rica, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1995: The DPP nominates Peng Ming-min, a former political science professor and a long-time dissident in exile, as its presidential candidate after a 15-week primary. Peng later names Legislator Frank Hsieh as his running mate.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares a state of emergency to cope with the massive disaster caused by the Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian vows to convert Taiwan into a "green silicon island" during his four-year term by making the island into an international shopping center and an international planning and managing center.
2001: The 2001 Joint Geosciences Assembly opens at the Taipei International Convention Center with geoscientists from Taiwan and overseas taking part in the four-day meeting.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To no one but the supreme head of the empire does it belong to disturb the established religious and social institutions, to introduce new forms of government, to change the form and use of language."

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Rita Wobbles, Gulf Coast Staggers.
Hurricane Rita, ebbing but still dangerous, approached the nearly deserted coasts of Texas and Louisiana today, preceded by driving rain that reflooded sections of New Orleans and swept through low-lying shoreline towns.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASKED PFP CHIEF TO FORWARD MESSAGE TO CHINESE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that before opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong departed for a visit to China in May, he asked him to forward a message to Chinese President Hu Jintao, but added that he is not sure whether Soong did so.
The message, according to the president, can be summed up in eight Chinese characters that can roughly be translated as "sovereignty, democracy, peace and equality."

Chen said that by sovereignty, he meant that the fact that the Republic of China exists must be accepted; by democracy, he meant the free will of the 23 million people in Taiwan must be respected; by peace, he meant that any differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must not be solved with the use of arms or non-peaceful means; and by equality, he meant any cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations must be conducted on a government-to-government basis.

These four principles, Chen noted, are contained in his 10-point consensus with Soong that was reached in February. He said he believes they will be accepted by an absolute majority of people in Taiwan, as they are also the government's basic position with regard to China.
Chen made the remarks in reply to a media question in a meeting with the Taiwan press during a visit to the Dominican Republic.

A U.S. State Department official recently testified to Congress that Chen had asked Soong to carry a message to Hu, who received Soong and Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan earlier this year in Beijing.
Chen said he had also authorized Soong to repeat to Hu the 10-point consensus between them.
The president said he has never changed his position with regard to the "one China" issue, a position well documented in newspapers and government records, and that he stands by it.
He noted that he did not feel comfortable disclosing the contents without Soong's consent and that he was doing it simply in order not to cause any misunderstanding or distortion of the facts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DENIES DOLLAR-DIPLOMACY INITIATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian denied categorically Saturday allegations that his new initiative to seek co-prosperity with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, dubbed the "Jung Pang Project," is an example of dollar diplomacy.
Chen stressed that the project is a new strategy aimed at assisting Taiwan businesses to invest in Central America and the Caribbean and cementing diplomatic relations around the region.

He denied reports that under the project, US$250 million will be spent per year, saying that the project will call for an outlay of US$250 million in total, paid out in stages rather than as a lump sum.

Noting that the new project will be different from the past practice of subsidizing or simply "giving money" as conducted by the former Kuomintang government, Chen said the new initiative will be aimed at helping the diplomatic allies in the region bolster investment and upgrade industrial structure.

The government has adopted the different approach mainly because it wants to seize the opportunity of the great business opportunities presented with the passage of the Central American Free Trade Agreement by the U.S. Congress and the expected formation of the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA), he said.

This is why the government wants to join hands with the private sector to increase investment in Central America and the Caribbean -- a "win win" program that will not only help Taiwan businesses reach out to the world, expedite their transformation and diversify the risks of their investment overseas, but will also help cement relations with the country's allies, he added.

Meanwhile, he stressed the imperative of his conducting "head of state diplomacy, " referring to his effort not long ago to thwart Beijing's attempt to steal Guatemalan diplomatic recognition from Taiwan.

Chen claimed that China has sought to further squeeze out Taiwan's international space by luring away all of its diplomatic allies and that under this scheme, Beijing nearly persuaded Guatemala to sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Fortunately, he said, he called Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo in June, thus solving a diplomatic crisis.

Chen said he called Berger in June after learning that the Guatemalan government was pondering swapping representative offices with China. In their hotline conversation, Chen recalled, he asked Berger two questions in his capacity as a good friend to Guatemala: Whether the office-swapping will indeed benefit Guatemala? And is Beijing sincere in helping the Guatemalan people out of pure goodwill?
"Guatemalan Foreign Minister Jorge Briz told me during my visit to Guatemala City a day earlier that "what happened after June proved that you were right," Chen said.

Guatemala was the first leg of Chen's 12-day, five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean, which has already taken him to the Dominican Republic in the Caribbean. The tour will also take him to Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

During his stay in Nicaragua, Chen will attend a summit meeting slated for September 26 with his counterparts from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica -- in addition to the top leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR SETUP OF CROSS-STRAIT PERMANENT PEACE MECHANISM
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian called on both sides of the Taiwan Strait Saturday to jointly seek an interaction mechanism aimed at stepping up cross-strait permanent peace.
Chen made the appeal while speaking at a dinner hosted by the Taiwanese expatriate community in the Dominican Republic after his arrival in the Caribbean state for a three-day state visit.

Stressing that Taiwan is part of the world but not part of the People's Republic of China, Chen said that as a democratically elected president, he will to his utmost to safeguard national sovereignty, security and dignity while seeking the nation's sustainable development and cross-strait peace.
To achieve the goal, Chen said he has been seeking a mechanism aimed at boosting cross-strait co-existence, co-prosperity and permanent peace based upon the principles of equality and reciprocity.
He voiced the hope that the leaderships on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will join hands to promote the early establishment of such a mechanism through goodwill, reconciliation and cooperation.
Meanwhile, Chen also urged ruling and opposition party leaders to meet with him as soon possible to exchange views on how to step up Taiwan's stability and progress.
"I hope that the ruling and opposition parties will follow the example of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi in putting public welfare before individual or party interests," Chen said.

The coalition government led by Koizumi, chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party, won overwhelmingly in recent elections of the House of Representatives, Chen noted. As the House of Councillors vetoed a major postal reform project put forward by his Cabinet, Koizumi dissolved the lower house, risking his own political life, Chen went on.

The Dominican Republic is the second leg of Chen's Central American and Caribbean diplomatic tour, which will also take him to Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis. Prior to his arrival in Santo Domingo, Chen visited Guatemala, where he signed a free trade agreement with his Guatemala counterpart Oscar Berger Perdomo to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

Chen is scheduled to arrive in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua Monday to attend a summit meeting with his counterparts from five of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica -- in addition to top leaders from Belize, Panama and the Dominican Republic, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.

During the summit meeting, which is held alternately in Taiwan and Central America every two years, Chen and his Latin American counterparts will discuss various multilateral cooperation projects and exchange views on the current international situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED TO JOINTLY PROMOTE DIPLOMACY
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Democratic Progress Party (DPP) urged his Kuomintang counterpart Saturday to jointly work on promoting Taiwan's diplomatic relations with other countries.

Su Tseng-chang, who is accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean, made the appeal while attending a meeting between the president and reporters in the Dominican Republic.

Pointing out the president's efforts to reinforce Taiwan's diplomatic relations with its allies, Su said he hopes KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou will join hands with him to improve the country's relations with other countries.
Chen had invited opposition leaders to join his state visit, but the invitation was ignored by both Ma and James Soong, chairman of the People First Party.

In response to the opposition parties' questions raised regarding the government's aid to its Central American allies and the arms procurement bill that has long been stalled in the Legislative Yuan, the DPP head also called for the opposition leaders to work together in the fields of improving national defense and promoting diplomatic relations.
"Even if the ruling and opposition parties hold different opinions on various issues, they should deal with diplomatic and national defense matters with one voice," he said.

Shu Chin-chiang, chairman of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , who is also accompanying Chen on his visit to Central America, also voiced his concern about the long-stalled arms procurement bill in the legislature.

"Internal affairs can be discussed, while national defense and diplomacy should be handled with one voice, " he said, adding that Taiwan can stand up to China only if it can maintain its sovereignty as well as safeguard its national defense and develop its democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st KMT "MOVING CSC MEETING" HELD IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the KMT's Central Standing Committee (CSC) will continue to hold "moving meetings" in rural areas in order to find out about grassroots opinions.

Ma made the remarks while heading his deputies Wu Poh-hsiung and John Kuan, KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po, and CSC members Hung Hsiu-chu and Lien Sheng-wen at a CSC meeting in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County.

The meeting, the first of its kind, was aimed at showing that the party is paying attention to rural areas in central and southern Taiwan, as well as shortening the distance between Taipei and the countryside, according to the chairman.
Ma said the meetings will help committee members better understand grassroots problems and expectations in the southern part of the island.

He also said that pushing CSC members to go to rural areas is one of his political views expressed during his KMT chairmanship election campaign, and he promised that the CSC members will continue to regularly hold their meetings in central and southern areas rather than holding such meetings only during election campaigns.
Kaohsiung County Council Speaker Hsu Fu-sen and Lin Yi-shih, a KMT legislator and KMT candidate in the Kaohsiung county magistrate elections, also attended the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF DID NOT CONVEY PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE TO CHINESE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said Sunday that PFP Chairman James Soong did not forward a message from President Chen Shui-bian to Chinese President Hu Jintao when they met in Beijing in May.
Before Soong departed for China, Hsieh said he repeatedly made it clear that the party does not represent the government and that Soong himself would not act as a messenger or "secret envoy."

The president, who was visiting the Dominican Republic, told the Taiwan press that he asked Soong to forward an "eight-character" message to Hu that can be translated as "sovereignty, democracy, peace, equality." Chen added that he was not sure whether Soong had passed on the message.

Hsieh said two key principles in a 10-point consensus reached between Chen and Soong, which Chen said he also authorized Soong to pass on to Hu, concerned returning to the Republic of China Constitution and peaceful development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations based on the "constitutional one-China" principle.
Hsieh said he did not know what the president was actually aiming at by disclosing that he had asked Soong to forward the message to Hu.

Chang Hsien-yao, executive director of the PFP's Policy Research Center, said the U.S. Statement Department recently said that Soong had carried Chen's message to Hu, but added that the message definitely was not Chen's "eight-character" message.
Soong himself was not available to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ACCUSED OF NOT PAYING HEED TO `PEOPLE'S MOVEMENT'

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party heavyweight claimed Saturday that the lack of continuous use of what he called "people power" to respond to the opposition parties' actions is "the biggest problem" of the government.
Yao Chia-wen, president of the Examination Yuan, made the comments while addressing the World Taiwanese Congress (WTC) in Taipei.

Saying that a lot of progress is made by "people power, " Yao added that the DPP has not yet considered using it to push the passage of the arms procurement bill in the Legislative Yuan, although the long-stalled bill has been rejected by the opposition 29 times.
He also said that several members of the government have never participated in "people's movement" or civic activities.

Accusing the ruling party of lacking enthusiasm in support of a rally held Sunday in Taipei by members of the WTC to voice their support for the strengthening of the nation's defense capabilities, he also complained about DPP legislators absent from the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Nobel laureate Samuel C.C. Ting visited the National Science and Technology Museum Sunday, where he had a good time watching an exhibition featuring himself and his physics research.

Ting, 68, who won the Nobel Prize in physics in 1976, visited the exhibition titled: "Explore the 90% Unknown -- Samuel C.C. Ting and the Particle" at the museum, aimed at introducing the world of physics to the Taiwan public.
Ting was fascinated by the exhibition, taking pictures and examining the displays.

He showed particular interest in the play-with-physics section, where complicated physics issues are explained in simple or funny ways. On display included an upside down clown, an oil drip experiment and a bronze accelerator that he donated to the museum four years ago. He used the accelerator with other big-name physicists at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) during his years as a young physicist.
In another section, Ting noticed that a research paper by his wife, physicist Susan Marks, was also on display.

Ting was accompanied by Chen Hsun-hsiang, deputy curator of the National Science and Technology Museum; Lee Lou-chuang, director of National Applied Research Laboratories; and Lee Shih-chang, director of the Institute of Physics, Academia Sinica.
Ting last visited Taiwan to attend an annual conference of the members of Academia Sinica in July 2004.
He was also in Taipei in August 2003 to deliver a keynote speech at the 34th International Physics Olympiad that brought together 244 competing physics students from 54 countries.
After visiting the museum, Ting visited Kaohsiung Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: PRESIDENT'S US$250 MILLION FUND EVADES LEGISLATIVE MONITOR

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokeswoman Chen Li-wen accused President Chen Shui-bian Sunday of evading legislative monitoring by using taxpayers' money to set up a special fund in the "co-prosperity" project that he announced in Guatemala Thursday.

The US$250 million project, with money coming from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA) International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Executive Yuan's Development Fund, is aimed at assisting Taiwan businessmen to invest in Central America and the Caribbean and cementing Taiwan's diplomatic ties with countries in the region, according to the MOFA.

In response to media criticism, the president, who was visiting the Dominican Republic, pointed out that the previous KMT government spent "astronomical" amounts of money in its efforts to develop foreign ties before being voted out in 2000.

However, Cheng said the president was merely trying to confound the public about the real focus of the issue, which, according to the KMT, is that he has violated the law by setting up the special fund without going through the budget screening procedure at the Legislative Yuan.

The people realize that it is extremely difficult for Taiwan's diplomats to expand the country's foreign relations and that money must be spent to achieve that purpose, but procedure must be followed, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE MERITS FREE, RATIONAL DEBATE IN LEGISLATURE: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Sunday that the long-stalled arms procurement package deserves free and rational discussion in the legislature.

Wang was referring to a government plan to purchase three big-ticket weaponry systems from the United States, which has failed to make the legislative agenda for more than a year due to the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" obstruction.

Addressing a roundtable meeting on arms procurement and national development sponsored by a private anti-arms procurement group, Wang said that as the proposed arms procurement package is related to national security, government financial status and economic development, it should be put forward for extensive discussions before any decision is made.

"My observation is that the arms procurement package, which includes eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, should be addressed in line with the principles of democracy and rule by law," Wang said.

Noting that democracy and rule by law have been Taiwan's most admirable achievements after several decades of hard work, Wang said the handling of this massive arms procurement project should exemplify those spirits.

While U.S. President George W. Bush approved the robust arms sales package to Taiwan in April 2001, Wang said the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration did not refer the two arms procurement-related bills to the legislature until mid-2004. As the draft bills drew mixed reactions, the DPP administration withdrew the two bills earlier this year and sent two revised ones to the legislature shortly before the opening of the current legislative session early this month.

According to the revised bills, the funds needed for the Patriot anti-missile batteries will come from the government's regular budget while the remaining two items will be financed by a special budget.

Wang said he was scheduled to call a cross-party consultative meeting Monday to work out a schedule for screening the central government's budget bill for 2006. As the budget plan includes funds for the proposed Patriot procurement, Wang said its fate remains uncertain.
In his view, Wang said, the legislature should allow free and rational debate on the arms procurement package.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has used its slim majority in the legislature's Rules Committee to block the two arms procurement-related bills from being placed on the legislative agenda 29 times.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ATTACHES NO IMPORTANCE TO ARMS PROCUREMENT PROJECT: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed Sunday that it is President Chen Shui-bian and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party that attach no importance to the much-talked-about arms procurement project rather than the opposition.

Ma, on the campaign trail in the southernmost county of Pingtung with a KMT group, rebutted Chen's accusations in Central America and the Caribbean over the past several days that Taiwan's opposition parties have been opposing the arms procurement project because they want to curry favor with Beijing.

Discounting Chen's remarks, Ma said that the United States agreed in 2001 to sell the three weaponry items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- to Taiwan, but the DPP government did not submit a bill in this regard until three years later.
This, Ma claimed, indicates that Chen and the DPP did not pay major heed to the matter.

Moreover, Ma said, when the KMT was in office, arms procurement budget accounted for 4 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) , but today the figure has fallen to 2.4 percent since the DPP took power.

Meanwhile, Ma claimed that Chen was trying to blur the focus of attention by stressing a day earlier that the "Prospering with Allies" project calling for US$250 million to be spent in investing in Central America and the Caribbean was "by no means an example of the dollar diplomacy that was practiced by the former KMT government."

The problem with the project, according to Ma, is that it has not been approved or overseen by the legislature. While the Legislative Yuan will have no way to oversee the project, it will be a problem for all parties concerned how the money should be used and who will get the money, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION SEEKING TALENTED PEOPLE IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, September 24 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: A talent-recruiting fair held by a Taiwanese delegation Saturday attracted around 500 young applicants, Cabinet-level National Science Council Deputy Chairman Liao Chun-chen disclosed Sunday.

Liao, leader of the talent-hunting delegation, said that a total of 37 domestic leading manufacturers and research institutions, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and the Biotechnology Development Center, have joined the delegation to recruit high technology and management talent.
The delegation is hoping to recruit around 2,000 experts to work in Taiwan, according to Liao.

In addition to holding interviews with applicants from various famous schools in the Los Angeles area, the delegation members also handed out a variety of pamphlets and encouraged those wishing to join Taiwan high-tech firms and research institutions to sign up through the Ministry of Economic Affairs Web site.
Liao said that a total of 599 high-tech experts were recruited to work in Taiwan in 2003 and that the figure increased to 656 last year.
Saying that the delegation might be able to recruit at least 700 this year to work for Taiwan high-tech companies and help upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness.
The delegation will continue its talent-hunting trip to San Francisco, Seattle, Vancouver and Tokyo. It has already visited San Diego.

Among other members of the talent-recruiting delegation are officials from the Ministry of the Economic Affairs, the National Science Council, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Education, the Council of Labor Affairs, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS NOT TO ENGAGE IN 'DOLLAR DIPLOMACY' WAR WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Sunday that the government has "given up the dollar diplomacy" used by the previous Kuomintang government and will not engage in a "money spending" war with China in order to win diplomatic allies.
While enumerating the government's new diplomatic strategy, Chen repeatedly mentioned the previous KMT government's spending record.

He said China has announced "astronomical" amounts of foreign aid projects that it might not be able to carry through. By contrast, he said, Taiwan does not boast but keeps its word -- which is why Nauru was willing to resume ties with Taiwan after being fooled by China's empty promises.

Chen quoted the U.S. assistant deputy secretary of state in charge of Latin America affairs as saying that over the past two years, China has won over some of Taiwan's allies in that part of the world such as Grenada and the Commonwealth of Dominica by spending hugely.

"Taiwan must never engage in a spending competition with China, " he said, adding that it should instead strengthen trade and economic cooperation with other countries by investing in niche industries and value-added projects.
He explained that if need be, the government can join the business community or make loans to them to invest in less-developed diplomatic allies.
In fact, the government has been doing precisely that, but will do it more thoroughly in order to create a win-win situation for Taiwan's allies and for Taiwan itself, he added.
As to why Taiwan needs diplomatic allies, Chen said that without them, no one will be willing to speak for Taiwan in such forums as the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
He urged Taiwan's opposition parties not to show an aversion to "our international friends and allies."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FM REFUSED TO ACT ON US$300 MILLION KOSOVO PROJECT

TEXT.P: Former Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, now Taichung mayor, said Sunday that while he was foreign minister, he "warded off" a government project to give US$300 million in aid to victims of the Kosovo conflict, a move that he said offended his superiors.

Hu made the remarks in response to President Chen Shui-bian naming him and John Chiang, another opposition Kuomintang former foreign minister, as two former officials who best know about Taiwan's "dollar diplomacy."

Hu said he did not know the exact context of Chen's statement, but he recalled his role in refusing to act on a government project for Kosovo conflict victims in Macedonia. He added that by doing that, he invoked displeasure from then-President Lee Teng-hui, who initiated the project.
Hu, who was foreign minister from 1997 to 1999, said that if Chen aimed to criticize him and Chiang, he had better check his facts.
He said he totally agrees with Chen with regard to the policy of not engaging in a "dollar diplomacy" war with China because "once you've used up your money, you lose the friendship you've bought."
Taiwan must not compete with China in using money to buy diplomatic friendship because in the end, "the other guy will outspend you," Hu added.

It appeared that Hu was also explaining his diplomatic record to Premier Frank Hsieh, who said in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, that the KMT government used "dollar diplomacy" -- the US$300 million Kosova project -- in a bid to set up official ties with Macedonia.

"After just two days, the diplomatic ties broke down, " Hsieh said, adding that Chen's "co-prosperity" project to be financed with a special US$250 million fund, is not "dollar diplomacy" but rather a reform of the government's foreign relations strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO CALL HIMSELF 'TAIWAN PRESIDENT' IF INVITED TO CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in Santo Domingo Saturday that he will address himself as "Taiwan president" if he manages to visit China.

Chen, who is currently on a two-day state visit to the Caribbean nation of the Dominican Republic, made the remarks during an informal meeting with Taiwan journalists to clarify an earlier statement that he is willing to hold "rational dialogue" any time and anywhere with his People's Republic of China counterpart Hu Jintao without any preconditions.

"The statement made during my transit stop in Miami, Florida earlier this week should not be misinterpreted as a compromise on my stance. Any dialogue should take place under the principles of 'sovereignty, democracy, peace and parity.' This is common sense, " Chen explained.

Since no political strings should be attached, Chen said, Beijing should not mention the so-called "1992 consensus" or its "one China" principle as a prerequisite for resuming dialogue across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen said he understands that China is unlikely to agree or accept his "no preconditions" appeal.
"But the United States agrees and supports the 'no preconditions' proposal. I will not give up any possible effort or chance lightly, " Chen said.

Noting that senior U.S. officials, including President George W. Bush, have on many occasions encouraged cross-strait dialogue and pushed Beijing leaders to talk with Taiwan's popularly elected president, Chen said he appreciates U.S. concern about the cross-strait situation.
Chen said he has never been afraid to hold talks with China. Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan should be patient enough to wait for the right time to come.
"It takes two to dance. We cannot harbor wishful thinking nor should we be rash as far as cross-strait issues are concerned, " Chen said.

Stressing that "reconciliation but no retreat, firmness without confrontation" has been his administration's basic stance on cross-strait engagement, Chen said reconciliation is by no means a surrender of Taiwan's fundamental position toward China.

Chen further said he is Taiwan's president. "Whenever I visit foreign countries, regardless of whether they have diplomatic ties with Taiwan or not, I have consistently addressed myself as 'Taiwan president.' If I have the opportunity to visit China, I will do the same," he added.

The Dominican Republic is the second leg of his current five-nation diplomatic tour that already took him to Guatemala and will take him to Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION MEETING TO OPEN MONDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan-U.S. Environmental Protection Technological Conference will be held Sept. 26-27 in Taipei with government officials, academics and experts from the two countries participating, an official from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Sunday.

The U.S. delegation will be headed by Jerry Clifford, deputy assistant administrator for international affairs of the Environmental Protection Agency, while the Taiwan delegation will be led by EPA Administrator Chang Kuo-lung, the official said.

Chang, as well as David Keegan, deputy director of the AIT Taipei Office, and Liang Ying-ping, secretary-general of the Council for Coordination of North American Affairs, are scheduled to deliver speeches at the opening ceremony of the two-day meeting, which will focus on the air pollution control issue.

In addition to sharing their experiences in air pollution control and discussing how to help developing countries improve air pollution caused by vehicles, the participants will exchange views on a two-year bilateral cooperation project concerning the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, long-term pollutant monitoring, soil and maritime pollution control, as well as water quality improvement through ecological engineering methods.

Following the conference, the U.S. delegation will visit several establishments including the Feitsui reservoir, a thermo-power plant in Taichung and an air quality monitoring station at the Yushan National Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CO-PROSPERITY INITIATIVE NOT DOLLAR DIPLOMACY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Sunday that a new initiative unveiled by President Chen Shui-bian to seek co-prosperity with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America is not dollar diplomacy.

Hsieh made the remarks after opposition parties criticized Chen's initiative calling for an outlay of US$250 million, describing it as money diplomacy. Chen, who is on a diplomatic tour of several Central American and Caribbean states, announced the project during a just-concluded visit to Guatemala.

According to Hsieh, the project is a new strategy aimed at encouraging Taiwanese manufacturers to invest in Central American countries to offer locals more jobs, which he said will both help improve bilateral relations and facilitate Taiwan companies' global expansion drive.

Claiming that the new initiative will be different from the former Kuomintang government's financial assistance practices, Hsieh said the KMT government gave money to the Republic of Macedonia in exchange for diplomatic recognition, but shortly afterwards, Macedonia switched diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi does not rule out possibility of primaries.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said at a rally of the ruling coalition Saturday that the primaries do not scare him. He said that he was not afraid of a challenge from his deputy Gianfranco Fini or parliament's lower house speaker Pierferdinando Casini. Meanwhile, he called for unity of the coalition."One thing we have to do is to stop arguing and stand united," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET: 'CO-PROSPERITY' FUND TRANSPARENT, MULTILATERAL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan spokesman said Sunday that a US$250 million "co-prosperity" fund that President Chen Shui-bian announced in Central America is a transparent, multilateral and bilateral mechanism that involves many cooperative projects in 12 countries that are diplomatic allies of the Republic of China.

Cho Jung-tai said what makes it different from previous trade and economic cooperation funds is that the government will act more aggressively to persuade state-run and private enterprises to seek strategic alliances globally,

Cho noted that the government believes the US$250 million fund, which will come from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Executive Yuan's Development Fund, will operate in a transparent milieu and create a win-win situation for the government and businesses in Taiwan, as well as in Central and South America.

In contrast to the previous practice of government subsidies, five new ideas have been adopted in the drafting of the "co-prosperity" fund, he said: the government will assist businesses to make independent investment; businesses are welcome to make joint investment with the government; private businesses can cooperate with state-run enterprises; Taiwan businesses can cooperate with a diplomatic ally's enterprises; and Taiwan businesses can cooperate with third-country businesses in a diplomatic ally.

Cho said under the new government initiative, Taiwan's businesses can make good use of the large pool of labor and new market opportunities offered by CAFTA (U.S.-Central America-Domincan Republic Free Trade Agreement) and FTAA (Free Trade Areas of the Americas) to build bridgeheads in Central America.
He said the government believes that the fund will help Taiwan businesses diversify their investment risks and gain new business opportunities.

Cho said the details of the fund were initially to be announced at a summit meeting by President Chen Shui-bian on Sept. 27 but were "accidentally misquoted" and then reported, drawing criticisms from the media and politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE JUSTICE MINISTER TO SERVE AS DEPUTY KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Justice Tang Chin-chuan has been tapped to serve as new deputy mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, sources said Sunday.
Tang had been a Kaohsiung city councilor and a legislator from the Kaohsiung constituency before assuming his current post.

Political sources said Premier Frank Hsieh handpicked Tang to serve as deputy Kaohsiung mayor to overseas the city's controversies-plagued mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction project with his legal expertise.

Meanwhile, Liao Ching-lung, an engineering supervisor with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will head a Kaohsiung city government task force to examine all engineering problems involved in the MRT construction project. As Liao previously took part in the Taipei MRT system and Taiwan high-speed railway construction projects, he is familiar with rail system technological affairs.

Former Taiwan Water Co. Chairman Lee Wen-liang, who once headed the Kaohsiung City Government's Bureau of Redevelopment, will serve as the city government's adviser to assist in promoting the city's three yet-to-be-completed major construction projects.
All of three new municipal officials will assume office Monday along with new acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO ASSUME POST MONDAY

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, will formally take over as acting mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung Monday.

Yeh will succeed Chen Chi-mai as acting Kaohsiung mayor in a changeover ceremony to be supervised or witnessed by several political heavyweights, including Premier Frank Hsieh. Chen resigned earlier this month to take political responsibility for a riot by Thai laborers working for the city's mass rapid transit system.

Yeh, a former vice premier who also once served as minister of transportation and communications and chairwoman of the Council of Hakka Affairs and a four-term legislator from the Miaoli constituency in northern Taiwan, is a "novice" to the Kaohsiung political arena.

Premier Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan will all travel from Taipei to Kaohsiung to attend the changeover ceremony to land their support behind Yeh.

In addition to continuing many of the city's massive infrastructure construction projects, Yeh is also expected to help consolidate the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's power base in the nation's second largest city ahead of the next mayoral election in late 2006, political observers said.
Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Justice Tang Chin-chuan has been tapped to serve as new Kaohsiung deputy mayor.
Tang had been a Kaohsiung city councilor and a legislator from the Kaohsiung constituency before assuming his current post.

Political sources said Premier Frank Hsieh handpicked Tang to serve as deputy Kaohsiung mayor to overseas the city's controversies-plagued mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction project with his legal expertise.

The sources further said Liao Ching-lung, an engineering supervisor with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, will head a Kaohsiung city government task force to examine all engineering problems involved in the MRT construction project. As Liao previously took part in the Taipei MRT system and Taiwan high-speed railway construction projects, he is familiar with rail system technological affairs.

Former Taiwan Water Co. Chairman Lee Wen-liang, who once headed the Kaohsiung City Government's Bureau of Redevelopment, will serve as the city government's adviser to assist in promoting the city's three yet-to-be-completed major construction projects.
All of three new municipal officials will assume office Monday along with new acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT QUESTIONS RATIONALE BEHIND OPPOSITION TO ARMS PACKAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Sept. 24 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in Santo Domingo Saturday he is hopeful that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) can stop its stonewalling of a long-stalled arms procurement package from being debated in the legislature.

Speaking with a group of Taiwan journalists covering his current five-nation diplomatic tour, Chen said the plan to purchase three big-ticket weaponry systems from the United States was fleshed out during the previous KMT administration.

"It's hard to imagine why the KMT would boycott the bill to such an extent as to the bill cannot even make the legislative agenda for more than a year, " Chen said in an informal meeting with Taiwan journalists.
During his transit stop in Miami, Florida en route to Guatemala before coming to the Dominican Republic, Chen recalled that he talked with an influential U.S. congressional leader by phone.

"The congressional leader told me that he will meet with U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and they will send a joint letter to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to seek Ma's support for the arms procurement package," Chen said.

According to Chen, he had advised the U.S. congressional leader to also write to PFP Chairman James Soong because Soong has played a key role to block the package from being placed onto the legislative agenda for discussion and deliberation.
Chen claimed that Taiwan's opposition leaders have been stonewalling the arms procurement package to curry favors with Beijing.
The arms procurement package comprises three big-ticket items -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
In 1998, Chen said, the then-KMT administration asked the United States to sell Taiwan Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and the U.S. government approved the request in 1999.

"At that time, I have not yet assumed the presidency. After I took the presidency in 2000, my administration began to prepare a budget bill for the procurement project in line with the principle of policy continuity," Chen said.
As to the submarine procurement plan, Chen said, it was determined during a 1994 meeting between then-KMT government and U.S. military authorities.
Now that Taiwan has become a full-fledged democracy, Chen said any major policy initiative can be put forward for open debate and discussion, including the arms procurement project.

Against this backdrop, Chen said, it is unthinkable that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has used its slim majority in the Legislative Yuan to completely obstruct any discussion or debate on the package.

In the face of China's mounting military threat, Chen said he earnestly hopes that the "pan-blue alliance" can allow the package to be placed on the legislative agenda for discussion and deliberation.

"If lawmakers think that the procurement cost is unreasonably high as some claimed, my administration would respect legislators' opinions or recommendations after a rational debate and extensive discussion," he added.

Chen arrived in the Dominican Republic capital of Santo Domingo Friday from Guatemala for a two-day state visit. His current five-nation diplomatic tour will also take him to Nicaragua, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENS OF THOUSANDS TAKE TO THE STREETS TO BACK ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: An estimated 50,000 local people, mostly from pro-independence groups, marched through major Taipei streets Sunday to back an arms procurement package aimed at fending off China but stonewalled by the opposition-controlled legislature.

Holding banners and chanting slogans of "Safeguard Taiwan" and "Strengthen Defenses, " the marchers condemned opposition lawmakers for blocking the government's plan to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.
But dozens of arms procurement opponents staged a small protest outside the Legislative Yuan, claiming that the U.S. arms deal could start an arms race with China and squeeze social welfare spending.
The two groups were separated by hundreds of police and barbed wire barricades. Some members from the two sides traded barbs at times, but no conflicts erupted.
The march was jointly organized by the Hand-in-Hand-to-Protect-Taiwan Alliance and the World Taiwanese Congress.

Ng Chiautong, the event's chief organizer, said the parade will show the world that the people of Taiwan will not be bullied by China and are determined to defend Taiwan's independent sovereign status.
Ng blamed the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party for boycotting the arms procurement package.

"If we don't give our soldiers the most advanced weapons, how are they supposed to fight China and defend Taiwan? " Ng said, adding: "We must be willing to pay for the weapons for our own defense and we must be confident Taiwan will not lose."

In addition to pro-independence groups, some lawmakers and senior executives from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- also took part in the parade to call for more public support for the arms procurement package. Organizers estimated the number of participants to the parade at about 50,000.

For more than a year, opposition lawmakers have used their slim majority in the legislature to scuttle plans to debate the arms package on the excuse that it would spark an arms race with China that could bankrupt Taiwan's economy.

The DPP administration recently made a compromise offer and reduced the special appropriation to NT$340 billion (about US$11 billion), deferring part of it to the regular defense budget. Defense officials say the arms package is aimed at deterring a Chinese invasion, not provoking war.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Sept. 26 or the 23rd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: The Holy Alliance is signed in Paris by Tsar Alexander I of Russia, Francis I of Austria, and Frederick William III, King of Prussia.
1888: Thomas S. Eliot, British critic and writer who won the 1948 Nobel Prize for literature, is born in America. His poems "The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock" and "The Wasteland" established him as a major literary figure.
1900: Japanese Prime Minister Aritomo Yamagata threatens to resign his Cabinet to oppose the establishing of the "Seiyukai Society."
1907: The British colony of New Zealand becomes a dominion.
1937: Bessie Smith, the American blues singer known as the "Empress of the Blues," dies at that age of 43. She is hurt in a car crash in Mississippi and bleeds to death waiting for an ambulance that simply didn't bother to hurry.
1954: A Seikan passenger ship plying a route between Aomori and Hakodate sinks, killing 1,183 people and becoming Japan's worst maritime disaster.
1957: The first council meeting of the Asian Pacific Anti-Communist League opens in Taipei.
1960: U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy and Vice President Richard M. Nixon hold the first nationally televised debate between presidential candidates.
1977: Two hundred and seventy people pay just 59 pounds (US$109) each to fly from London to New York on the first of Freddie Laker's Skytrain flights.
1983: Australia II defeats the U.S. yacht Liberty to win the America's Cup, at last wrenching the famous trophy from the New York Yacht Club, its home for 132 consecutive years.
1984: Britain and mainland China agree that Hong Kong will revert to Chinese rule when Britain's lease on the territory expires in 1997.
1988: Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson, who was a hero two days ago after winning the 100 meters with a new world record, flies home in disgrace from the Seoul Olympics, stripped of his gold medal after testing positive for banned performance-enhancing substances.
1989: Vietnam pulls out its last batch of 26,000 troops from Cambodia.
1989: The Republic of China Executive Yuan permits pro-democracy supporters from mainland China to settle in Taiwan.
1989: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze calls for a total destruction of chemical weapons after U.S. President George Bush offers an 80 percent reduction.
1990: North Korea and Japan agree to open government contacts to improve relations.
1994: President Bill Clinton lifts the U.S. sanctions against Haiti.
1996: Hong Kong activist David Chan (Chen Yu-hsiang) drowns in the East China Sea after Japanese patrol boats thwart his protest ship's bid to land on the Tiaoyutais, a disputed archipelago near Taiwan.
1996: U.S. astronaut Shannon Lucid returns to earth after 188 days in orbit on the Russian space station Mir, a record for a woman.
1997: An earthquake rocks central Italy, killing more than 10 people.
1997: A Garuda Indonesia A-300 Airbus crashes near Medan, Indonesia, killing all 234 people on board.
1999: A 20-year-old man miraculously manages to escape from the rubble of a toppled building in downtown Taipei alive six days after a cataclysmic earthquake hit Taiwan on Sept. 21.
2000: The Republic of China and the Philippines sign an aviation agreement to resume direct airlinks between the two contries.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian receives the year's 10 outstanding youths selected by the Taiwan Junior Chamber at the Presidential Office.
2001: The Republic of China and Britain sign an agreement on expanding cultural and educational exchanges and cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Although a man may occupy the position of the supreme head of the empire, unless he possesses the moral qualities fitting him for the task, he may not take it upon himself to make changes in the established moral and religious institutions."
