DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REITERATES 'FOUR STAGES OF ROC THEORY' IN NICARAGUA
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Sept. 25 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Sunday in Nicaragua the "four stages of the Republic of China theory" he created last month to stress the importance of national identity.
Chen, who arrived in Nicaragua the same day from the Dominican Republic for a two-day visit, made the reiteration while attending a banquet hosted by local Taiwan expatriates in his honor.

During his meeting with a group of USA Formosa Foundation visitors in August in Taipei, the president raised the theory to separate the ROC into four stages -- the ROC was first set up in 1912, it then moved to Taiwan in 1949, it became "the ROC on Taiwan" when former President Lee Teng-hui was in power, and it has become "the ROC is Taiwan" since he himself became president in 2000.

Chen said that the people's affirmation of national identity is one of the most important supports of a country, adding that national identity was really confused and unclear in Taiwan during the long period of "one party" rule.

Although Taiwan cannot be separated from its history nor overthrow the evolution process of history, the public must have an idea about the national identity of their country, he further said, adding: "This is why I raised the "four stages of ROC theory, " which is entirely in line with objective historical facts."

Chen also emphasized the fact that the ROC absolutely does not equal the People's Republic of China as the two are not only separated from each other and do not belong to each other, but are also under the rule of different governments.

Facing China's continuous efforts to block Taiwan from participating in the international community, the president said that his government will adhere to the principle of "Taiwan first, global development, reciprocal interests and crisis management" and use this principle as a guideline to deal with cross-strait relations and make Taiwan into an example of freedom, democracy and human rights in the world.

Touching on the island's failure in its bid to join the United Nations this year due to Beijing's obstruction, the president urged the world organization to "work bravely" on defending international justice and peace. "The U.N. should not succumb to China's pressure," he added.

Two proposals put forward by Taiwan's diplomatic allies at the U.N.'s 60th General Assembly to support the representation of the 23 million people of the island in the organization and to call for the world body to play an active role in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait were voted down by the U.N. General Committee from being placed on the assembly's agenda.

Praising the remarkable courage shown by Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos Geyer and Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi in dealing with reforms in their countries, Chen promised that he will do whatever he can to push reform in Taiwan.
"I hope to see a new and suitable Constitution be introduced in Taiwan before I step down from my post, " he added.

Chen, at the head of a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, was greeted at the airport upon his arrival in the country by his Nicaraguan counterpart and accorded red carpet treatment complete with full military honors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DISASTER MEDICAL TEAM SET UP

TEXT.P: The Taipei Disaster Medical Assistance Team (TDMAT) was formally established Monday to serve as the first medical service system responding to health emergencies or peacetime disasters in cities and counties around Taiwan.
Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou officiated at a ceremony marking the inauguration of the TDMAT in his capacity as head of the disaster medical team.
The ceremony was held at Taipei City Hospital's Zhong Xing Branch, where a helicopter landing apron to be used in the TDMAT operations was also inaugurated.
Addressing the ceremony, Ma said a disaster medical assistance team backed up with helicopters will usher Taipei's medical services into a new era.
The new service will not only shorten medical service administrative procedures, it will also "uplift" the efficiency of disaster medical services in Taipei, Ma said.

He added that although the disaster medical assistance team has been founded by Taipei City Government, it can be used to help people in other cities and counties around the country, particularly people in offshore areas.

Also speaking at the ceremony, Taipei City Hospital Superintendent Chang Hang noted that accidents ranked as the fifth major cause of death in Taiwan and the sixth in Taipei City for the third year in a row in 2004, prompting the city government to establish the TDMAT to deal with emergency situations more efficiently.

Chang said that emergency medical services have become one of the most important areas in the development of modern medical services. The TDMAT will respond to emergency medical needs in the greater Taipei area, which includes Taipei County, as well as offshore and remote areas, such as the islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
The ceremony was followed by a drill to test the TDMAT's response in a simulated disaster emergency in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT HEAD ARRIVES IN MOSCOW FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his wife arrived in Moscow Sunday for a six-day private visit.
Lien's visit immediately grabbed the attention of local media circles even though he had tried to keep it low profile.
The Russian media have actually shown much interest in Lien since he visited China and held a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in May of this year.
A few years ago, Lien received an honorary doctorate from Saint Petersburg State University, which happens to be Russian President Vladimir Putin's alma mater.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR PAINTS ROSY PICTURE FOR HARBOR CITY

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, said Monday that the mass rapid transit (MRT) construction program in Kaohsiung will continue "in high quality" and vowed to turn the harbor city into the "brightest star in Taiwan's landscape."

Yeh made the remarks after she took over the acting Kaohsiung mayor post from Chen Chi-mai in a ceremony presided over by Premier Frank Hsieh. Also witnessing the changeover ceremony were Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and other ranking officials.

Yeh said that she is committed to the wellbeing of the city and that she will listen to the voice of the residents, plan the city's economic development, introduce more high-tech businesses and reinvigorate the economy.
She said that Kaohsiung's MRT construction will continue and that its quality will not be compromised, promising that part of the MRT lines will be inaugurated by Oct. 2006.

She also listed some of the priorities in her administration, including setting up an MRT monitoring team, pulling out all the stops for the preparation for the 2009 World Games, and building a city of law and order.

Yeh's predecessor offered to resign after the Aug. 21 riot by Thai workers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) to protest against what they perceived as harsh and unreasonable management.

Yeh said that she can understand that the Kaohsiung residents' approval rating for city construction plummeted, as seen in recent polls, after the MRT construction scandal. She stressed that her administration will "revive the passion of the residents as well as their confidence."

She said that newly-appointed Deputy Mayor Tang Jinn-chuan is a former Vice Minister of Justice and a legal expert. Another deputy mayor, Cheng Wen-lung, is an engineering expert. Liao Chin-lung, former director general of the Bureau of High Speed Rail, will also be invited to join her administration, she continued.
With their expertise in legal and engineering affairs, Yeh said she is confident that the MRT construction program will proceed smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ASKS TEMPLE MANAGERS TO REFRAIN FROM JOINING MAINLAND ORGANIZATION

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged managers of religious temples around Taiwan Monday to refrain from joining a national cultural organization in China, warning that joining the group would be in violation of Taiwan's laws.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the call at a news conference after the council unveiled a report on Chinese authorities' alternative "united front" strategy of taking advantage of a traditional Chinese religion centered around Matsu -- the goddess of the sea.

You noted that the Chinese Matsu Cultural Exchange Association was established last October on Meizhou Island off Putian in the Chinese province of Fujian, and officially sanctioned. At its first congress, managers of 57 temples around Taiwan were seen on its list of executive members.

When asked about their participation in the Chinese national organization, over 80 percent of these temple managers replied that they did not join the group, while some of them answered that they have totally no idea why they were listed, You said.

Under the existing Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, religious temples in Taiwan are banned from serving as members of any China-based organization like the Matsu Cultural Exchange Association.
Meizhou Island is home to the first Matsu temple of its kind and therefore attracts large numbers of devout Taiwanese believers every year to make visits to pay homage to the sea goddess.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INCREASING MILITARY EXCHANGES WITH CENTRAL AMERICA: MND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military has increased exchanges with its counterparts in Central America since the Ministry of National Defense (MND) was invited to take part in the Central American Military Forum in April this year, Defense Minister Lee Jye said Monday.

Taiwan was invited to take part in the Central American Military Forum as an observer, making it the forum's fifth observer states behind the United States, Germany, France and the Dominican Republic, Lee said.

The ministry's participation in the forum marked one of the nation's major breakthroughs in international military exchanges in recent years, Lee claimed during a session at the Legislative Yuan National Defense Committee.

In the future, he said, the MND will also expand exchanges and interactions with its counterparts in the Asia-Pacific region, as well as seek collaboration in war games and training drills, and help strengthen security efforts in the region.

For instance, the MND will continue to expand bilateral exchanges with Japan, aimed mainly at establishing a format for regular visit exchanges with Japanese security and public safety authorities, Lee said.

Meanwhile, Lee appealed to members of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee for their support for the long-stalled arms procurement bill which has been blocked for three consecutive legislative sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: COPYRIGHT DEALS FOR CHINESE PUBLICATIONS IN TAIWAN TO BE ALLOWED: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese publishers will be permitted to conduct copyright authorization and transfer deals if their publications are approved to be displayed at book fairs in Taiwan, according to a revised draft bill prepared by the Government Information Office.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the remarks after the MAC passed the draft bill Monday.

You said that under the revision, magazines, books, audio publications, movies, pretaped programs and radio and TV programs from China will be able to be displayed in Taiwan after getting approval and that they will be permitted to conduct copyright authorization and transfer deals during the exhibition period.
In addition, the application period for the items from China for exhibition in Taiwan will be shortened from the present two months in advance to one month, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDATORY MILITARY SERVICE TO BE TRIMMED TO 16 MONTHS FROM 2006

TEXT.P: The mandatory military service period for local conscripts will be cut to 16 months from the current 18 months from Jan. 1, 2006, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Monday.
Addressing a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, Lee said the compulsory military service period will be further trimmed to one year by July 2008.
Lee also told lawmakers that the military began to promote a volunteers-conscripts mixed system this year, with an ultimate goal of implementing an all-volunteer service system.
According to Lee, the military plans to recruit 6,561 volunteer soldiers this year. As of August, 4,380 volunteers had been recruited, or 67 percent of the target figure.

"The smooth recruitment indicates that a voluntary military has gradually received social recognition, " Lee said, adding that the military is set to recruit up to 45,561 volunteer soldiers and reserve non-commissioned officers by the end of 2008.

With a view to upgrading military professionalism, Lee said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will continue to streamline its recruiting mechanism, revise the existing law to expand the sources of recruitment, ease age limits for those intending to pursue a military career, recruit female soldiers, lower the retirement age, and mobilize reservists to join disaster prevention and relief work.

Meanwhile, Lee said, the MND will coordinate with the Ministry of the Interior to improve conscription operations to lessen social problems that may arise from the fact that some young male adults have to wait a long time before being drafted into mandatory military service.
In line with the Cabinet's efforts to lower the unemployment rate, Lee said the MND will draft 2,000 additional conscripts by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET HIS PANAMANIAN COUNTERPART PRIVATELY
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Sept. 25 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will meet with his Panamanian counterpart, Martin Torrijos, privately at Chen's hotel room in Managua for a closed-door meeting Monday, foreign ministry officials accompanying Chen on his current visit to this Central American state here said Sunday.

The Chen-Torrijos meeting was arranged because of the Panamanian president's tight schedule which prevents him from attending the summit meeting that has been slated for later Monday among Chen and his counterparts from four of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean -- El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Belize. The summit will also call together vice presidents or foreign ministers from Panama, the Dominican Republic and Costa Rica, as well as the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.

Similar private meetings were also arranged between Chen and Honduran President Ricardo Maduro, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa and El Salvadoran President Antonio Saca, according to foreign ministry officials.
President Chen is scheduled to host a dinner party Monday evening in honor of the political leaders from the nine allies in the region who will be attending the summit.

Nicaragua is the third leg of Chen's 12-day, five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean, which has already taken him to Guatemala and the Dominican Republic. The tour will also take him to St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

The Straits Times: Proposals to make CPF go further.
The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board is studying two ways to help Singaporeans earn better returns on their savings and get a steady of income well into their old age.
One is to have all members take up a pension plan, an investment scheme that can potentially yield more returns than the fixed CPF interest rates.
The other is to get them to but life annuities with their Minimum Sum -- currently $ 90,000 -- instead of simply leaving them with the CPF Board when they are 62 years old. This will guarantee them a monthly income for life.

Most who evacuated prepare to return, while costs are put in the low billions of dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS TO SINGAPORE URGED TO BE ALERT AGAINST DENGUE FEVER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Monday urged Taiwan citizens visiting Singapore to be alert against the mosquito-borne disease of dengue fever, which has caused the worst outbreak on record in the city-state so far this year.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu suggested Taiwan visitors, if must go to Singapore, pay extra heed to the prevention of dengue fever while staying there and avoid visiting potential mosquito breeding areas in particular.
Foreign wire services reported that the death toll of dengue fever has risen to 11 as of Monday with total reported cases so far this year reaching 10,000 in Singapore.
Lu said that the Singaporean health authorities have called for the public to wear long-sleeved shirts while outside and use mosquito nets and insecticides while at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.66 points to close at 5,930.2.
The bourse opened at 5,967.69 and fluctuated between 5,975.98 and 5,894.99 during trading. A total of 2.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$52.09 billion (US$1.57 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 467 to 424, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LI AO TO MAINLAND YOUTHS: IT'S TIME TO SAY GOODBYE TO MARXISM
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By Semy Chen and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Noted Taiwan writer and independent Legislator Li Ao said in Shanghai Monday that the young generation should by now be disillusioned with Marxism as being outdated and that the school of thought should be relegated to history.

In his speech at Fudan University's College of Humanities, Li said that China has produced many talented people in the fields of science, technology and other areas, but for many years they have faced a disadvantage because everything in China must be viewed through the prism of Marxism.

He encouraged mainland youths to embrace liberalism, but added that real liberalism must be accompanied with the ability to discern between truth and falsehood, so that they no one could deceive them.
Li said that a paradise cannot be created with sheer patriotism and efforts, but can be realized when people with the right expertise employ the right methods at an opportune time.
He added that the Communist Party of China will become more open and liberalized if the mainland people force it, coax it and admonish it in that direction.

Li, an author of more than 100 books, said that he would like to use his visit to China to announce that he has abandoned his beliefs as a liberal because liberalism itself is something too elusive and intangible.

He went on to say that from the 17th century to the 20th century, liberalism has asked people to look inward and free their spirits from bondage, while demanding freedoms of speech, thought and publication from the government.

However, he said, when all these freedoms are guaranteed by the Constitution of the People's Republic of China, who needs liberalism? "I would rather choose the Constitution than liberalism," he added.

The speech at Fudan University was Li's third and final one during his weeklong tour of China. Last week he visited Beijing and spoke to students and faculty at Peking University and Tsinghua University.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE, JAPANESE MEDICAL EQUIPMENT INSTITUTES FORGE TIES

TEXT.P: The Biomedical Engineering Center (BMEC) of the Industrial Technology Research Institute signed a memorandum of cooperation with the Japan Association for the Advancement of Medical Equipment (JAAME) Monday to gain knowledge of Japan's management and regulations on medical equipment trading.

BMEC Director-General Michael Su and JAAME President Keiju Hasegawa signed for the alliance with Liao Chi-chou, head of the Department of Health (DOH) Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, also in attendance. The cooperation is expected to help boost exchanges between Taiwan and Japan in terms of medical equipment trading regulations as the DOH has been working to help local manufacturers in the medical equipment industry open overseas markets, Liao said.

He noted that thanks to similar cooperative relations with the United States and the European Union, forged in 1998 and 2001, Taiwan was able to accelerate its implementation of a mechanism to check exports of medical equipment. The BMEC was commissioned to assist local businesses to equip themselves with knowledge of Japanese regulations and procedure about marketing medical equipment in Japan.

Taiwan's production value of medical equipment has seen double-digit growth in the past few years, amounting to NT$50.4 billion (US$1.5 billion) in 2004, up 24 percent from the previous year, Su said.
In 2004, Taiwan's total medical equipment exports reached NT$27.6 billion, with most of the exports shipped to the U.S. and those shipped to Japan worth only NT$2.5 billion, Su added.

Noting that there is around US$19.7 billion worth of domestic demand for medical equipment in Japan, Su said that he hopes via the cooperation with the JAAME, a door could be opened for Taiwanese manufacturers to make inroad into the neighboring market.

According to Hasegawa, the JAAME, which was established around 20 years ago, is one of Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare's designated institution to take charge of work in research, development, manufacturing, export/import, marketing and information collection, and certification of medical machines and equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved up 19 points to close at 5,950, with 25,371 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved up 19 points to end at 5,949, with 246 contracts traded, while December futures gained eight points to finish at 5,940, with 15 contracts traded. March futures moved down seven points to close at 5,930, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,931 for October, 5,930 for November, 5,932 for December, 5,937 for March and 5,928 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
October TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 246.7, with 2,963 contracts traded, while November TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 246.7, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures lost one point to finish at 890.4, with 2,232 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved up 0.2 points to end at 889, with 13 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 4.6 points to close at 888, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.101 to close at NT$33.274.
A total of US$676 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.225 and hit a high of NT$33.285.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE CAN MONITOR USE OF OVERSEAS 'PROSPERITY FUND': MOFA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said Monday the Legislative Yuan has a right to monitor the use of money for a proposed project to assist the Republic of China's allies in Central and Southern America.

Kau's remarks came in the wake of an announcement by President Chen Shui-bian, who is currently on a five-nation official tour of Central American and the Caribbean diplomatic allies, in Guatemala Thursday that the government will set up a special fund of US$250 million for a "co-prosperity" project.

The project, with money coming from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA) International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Executive Yuan's Development Fund, is aimed at assisting Taiwan businessmen to invest in Central America and the Caribbean and cementing Taiwan's diplomatic ties with countries in the region, the president said.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, who is accompanying President Chen, then told the media that related expenditures of the project can go without being screened by the Legislative Yuan, and that the legislature can monitor the use afterwards.

Wu's words drew the ire of opposition legislators who grilled Kau on this point when the latter was invited to report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Committee on the creative approach to promoting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
Kau said that the opposition legislators and the private sector might misunderstand the project and that the problem might be due to poor communication between government agencies.
He stressed that the project has been in the works for more than several months, and it has not been "hastily" unveiled as reported by the media.
As far as he is concerned, "The Legislative Yuan will have the right to monitor the use of the fund."
Opposition legislators said Wu's words were "inappropriate, " believing that the government wants to evade legislative monitoring and threatened to cut the budget altogether.

Legislators Lai Shyh-bao from the Kuomintang and Daniel Hwang from the People First Party said that the government has announced the project in Guatemala even when Taiwan's economy and jobless situation have yet to see improvement.

Though the president denied that the program was "dollar diplomacy, " and termed it "investment diplomacy, " they questioned whether the investment in the region will help Taiwan businessmen to reach out globally.
However, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim didn't see eye to eye with them.

She was positive about the ministry's creative approach in promoting diplomacy, saying that it will help Taiwan businessmen reach out to the world and could promote development in the allies, creating a win-win situation in this way.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CONSCIOUSNESS STARTS EARLY: VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Monday urged education authorities to do more to nurture national consciousness among students.
Lu made the remarks when she attended a ceremony marking the anniversary of the birth of Confucius and Teachers' Day at the Chungshan Building on Yangmingshan. Teacher's Day falls on Wednesday.

The vice president said that China currently deploys around 800 missiles along its coastal provinces. Among these, around 130 medium-range missiles target Japan, and more than 30 long-range missiles target the United States, Europe and Australia.
Faced with such a powerful neighbor, Taiwan's education authorities have to think about strengthening students' national consciousness beginning from when they are young, Lu said.
She said that Taiwan's situation is unique, and that is why education on national consciousness has to start early.

The vice president later held a luncheon to honor outstanding teacher award winners on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, who is currently on a five-nation official visit of Central American and Caribbean allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC UNDECIDED OVER COMBINING PRESIDENTIAL, LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Monday that the commission has not yet started to study the question of whether or not to hold the next presidential election on the same day as the legislative elections.
Chang was replying to Kuomintang Legislator Lin Hung-chih at the Legislative Yuan's home affairs committee.

He said the next legislature will be sworn in on Feb. 1, 2008, while the next president will take the oath of office on May 20, 2008. The current schedules show that the next legislative elections will be held in Dec. 2007 and the next presidential election on March 20, 2008.
If the two elections are to be held simultaneously, Chang said, then the election day for the president and vice president must be moved ahead.
This is a controversial issue on which the CEC will not take any stand, he added.

In a report to the committee, Chang said the re-zoning of legislative constituencies is scheduled to be completed by September 2006 and the new constituencies will be promulgated by the end of November 2006.

The redrawing of constituencies was necessitated by a constitutional amendment that changed the electoral system for the legislature, so that starting from the seventh Legislative Yuan to be elected in 2007, the Yuan will have only 113 members for four-year terms of office, about half of the current 225.

Of that total, 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, six from aboriginal communities, and the other 34 reserved for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives chosen in accordance with the percentage of votes each political party garners.
Chang promised that the re-zoning will be done in an independent, supra-partisan and fair manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 200 FOREIGNERS STUDYING CHINESE AT PROVIDENCE UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: More than 200 foreign students from 36 countries have been studying the Chinese language and culture at Providence University in the town of Shalu in Taichung County since the beginning of September, university officials said Monday.

The number of foreign students marks the largest among universities and colleges located in the central Taiwan area, according to the university, whose Chinese Language Education Center (CLEC) began enrolling students in 1996.
One of the CLEC students, Alexander Oxmar Ramireg Bazan from Paraguay, told CNA Monday that he is grateful for the Paraguayan government to offer him the chance to study at Providence University.

Cyntia Bahiana Esinolamonges, also from Paraguay, recalled her arrival in Taiwan saying she was warmly greeted at the airport by a CLEC teacher and Providence students in the Spanish Language and Culture Department. The kindness of Taiwanese people was her first impression of the country, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINERY DESTROYS 4,000 LITERS OF CONTAMINATED GRAPE JUICE
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou County, Central Taiwan, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Nantou fruit winery of the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. poured 4,000 liters of contaminated grape juice down the drain Monday under the supervision of sanitation workers and officials from the Environmental Protection Administration.

Tests done by technicians at the winery following a standard procedure showed that the juice contained residue of two pesticides -- dithiocarbamates and carbofuran -- that exceeded the legally allowed limits.

According to a spokesman for the winery, the juice was from 6,440 kg of grapes bought from two farms that had probably harvested their crops a few days too early in an attempt to avoid losses from a typhoon. The waste represented only 0.5 percent of the grapes purchased by the winery this year.

The two farms that sold the contaminated grapes will have to absorb their own losses, he said, adding that experts at the winery will continue to follow strict quality control procedures to protect consumers.

The 4,000 liters of grape juice, weighing about six metric tons, was released into the winery's drainage system and diluted with water. It will take about three days for the winery's waste water plant to process the contaminated liquid before it can be released into the county's sewage system, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Relieved Texans Returning Home as Storm Fades
Receding floodwaters in New Orleans brought a welcome respite, and residents who fled Houston began returning home.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL Storm's Damage To Energy Plants Appears Limited
An unprecedented swath of the U.S. energy infrastructure was shut down over the weekend in the aftermath of Hurricane Rita, but damage appeared limited and the long-term economic impact may be muted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS GREAT PROMISE IN SOLAR ENERGY DEVELOPMENT: TYCOON

TEXT.P: With well-developed wafer and semiconductor industries, Taiwan has great promise in solar energy development, the chief executive officer of Taiwan's leading crystalline silicon solar cell manufacturing company said Monday.

Speaking in an interview with CNA, Motech Industries Inc. President Leo Cheng said he urged the government to invest more in solar energy research when his company began investing in the field seven years ago.

"Taiwan is very suitable for solar power development because it has the world's best wafer fabrication plants and a large number of skilled engineers. With this precious asset, I see no other country better equipped than Taiwan to develop solar energy," Cheng said.
In the past two years, Cheng said, more and more local companies have got involved in solar energy development, enhancing the possibility of forming a comprehensive industry supply chain.
"So long as we can develop a complete supply chain, the solar energy industry will become yet another of Taiwan's star industries like the electronics industry," Cheng said.

Motech Industries Inc., founded in 1981 and formerly known as Meter International Corp., is a leading Taiwanese manufacturer specializing in high-end test and measurement instruments. Over the past 20 years, Motech Industries has expanded its product base to become one of the most reputable test and measurement manufacturers in Taiwan, with a growing international presence.
In 1998, Motech received permission to set up its Solar Electricity Division (Motech Solar) in the South Taiwan Science Park.
Motech Solar is Taiwan's first manufacturer specializing in the production of crystalline silicon solar cells.
Its main products include multi- and mono-crystalline silicon solar cells with dimensions of 125mm x 125mm and 156mm x 156mm.
Cheng said Motech Solar plans to further expand its production capacity by the end of 2005.
Motech Solar has also started a pilot production line for wafer slicing to reduce cost and increase the supply of silicon wafers, Cheng said.
Moreover, Cheng went on, Motech Solar plans to begin the construction of a second factory building for future expansion in solar wafer and cell manufacturing.
"One of our goals is to become the lowest-cost solar cell manufacturer in the world," Cheng said.

With the Kyoto Protocol taking effect and crude oil prices skyrocketing, Cheng said there is a resurgence of interest in solar energy. As a result, upstream solar energy materials have been in short supply and he predicted that investment in upstream solar energy materials production will reap certain dividends.

He urged the government to invest more in solar energy research and provide incentives to encourage private investment in the field so that Taiwan can develop a complete solar energy supply chain soon. Cheng further said his company is expected to rank among the world's top five solar energy firms by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG'S NEW ACTING MAYOR BETTING HER CREDIBILITY ON NEW JOB

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, who became Kaohsiung City's acting mayor Monday, said she was betting all her political credibility on regaining public confidence in the city government that has become mired in a mass rapid transit (MRT) construction scandal.

During an exclusive interview with CNA, the former transport and communications minister said she agreed to take the job because she could not bear to see what she described as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) "cohesive power" disintegrating as a result of the MRT fiasco.

She replaced Chen Chi-mai, who resigned to take political responsibility over the human rights controversy that came to light following a riot by Thai workers on Aug. 21 in protest over their poor living conditions and maltreatment by a management company contracted by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).
Ye said she will bring in two deputy mayors and an engineering expert to regain the public's confidence in the city government's ability to build the rapid transit system and to run the city well.

Tang Chin-chih, a law expert, was invited to be deputy mayor along with Cheng Wen-lung, an engineer. The two will be joined by railway expert Liao Ching-lung to review the building contracts, and hopefully they will bring an end to the MRT controversy, Yeh said.

As the MRT scandal is related to the city's decision to build the system under the build, operate, transfer (BOT) model, she described the BOT model as a good way of encouraging private investment in public projects and said it will be adopted for more city projects.
"Public confidence can be regained only if the BOT projects are implemented in due process by people with credibility and as long as no major errors occur," she added.
She reiterated her lack of interest in running for a formal mayoral term after her tenure as acting mayor expires late next year.
What she plans to achieve is to rekindle people's confidence in the DPP's core values, she said without elaborating.
On a practical level, Yeh said she will promote more female executives in the city government and focus on improving social welfare for the less privileged, as well as for women and children.

As the nation's first female mayor of a metropolitan city and a member of the Hakka community, she said she will see to it that a Hakka community in Tsoying gets all the benefits to which it is eligible, including construction of public facilities.

Yeh said she will also carry on city development plans drawn up by former mayors Frank Hsieh and Chen Chi-mai that make use of the area's sea, ports, mountains and rivers to make the city a "shining, comfortable, safe and beautiful place."
She said she also plans to market Kaohsiung's local characteristics as tourist attractions in an effort to improve the local economy.
Yeh was a senior adviser to the president, and before that, she served as the nation's first female deputy premier, transportation minister, and National Assembly speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED PSYCHIATRIST COMMITS SUICIDE

TEXT.P: A noted psychiatrist who gained fame for having treated a number of celebrities was found dead in his clinic in Taipei Monday in what police described as an apparent suicide.
Forensic doctors said Chen Kuo-hua, 35, apparently killed himself by burning charcoal in his clinic. Police were still trying to find out his motive for ending his own life.
Chen, who ran the Beautifulmind Clinic after working in several hospitals in Taipei, wrote in a book that he was twice troubled by depression, which he said was why he chose to become a psychiatrist.
Chen's former colleagues said he apparently carried too heavy a mental burden and did not know to whom to turn for help.

Chou Yuan-hua, a psychiatrist at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, quoted a study in the United States showing that doctors are a high-risk group in terms of the tendency to commit suicide, and that psychiatrists belong to an even higher-risk subgroup within this already high-risk group.
He pointed out that psychiatrists, like anyone else, can suffer from emotional problems and become mentally disturbed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPANY DEVELOPS WORLD'S LARGEST LCD TV PANEL

TEXT.P: Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corporation (CMO), one the world's top three LCD TV panel suppliers, announced at its Tainan headquarters Monday that it has successfully developed the world's first 56-inch LCD TV panel.

With 8.29 million pixels and a resolution of 3840 x 2160 -- four times that of the currently available products -- the panel features the highest resolution ever achieved in the world, according to CMO officials.
The new panel consists of over 24.8 million transistors, with a data transmission speed of over 1.4 gigabytes per second.

In order to achieve the result, the officials said the CMO research and development team had to overcome a number of significant technical challenges, including the development of special new driver methods and scanning procedures.
The LCD panel manufacturer said the new panel also boasts the largest display size among similar products ever developed by Taiwan LCD makers.

Describing the panel as a milestone in global display development, CMO President Ho Jau-yang said the technical challenges were not only in developing a large sized LCD panel, but also in developing the four-fold increase in screen resolution.

The company said the panels can be applied to a number of high-end applications. They will be perfect for ultra high-end multifunction home entertainment systems and for connection to high quality digital still and video cameras.
They can also be applied to high-end specialty uses for high-resolution graphic displays such as in medical video cameras or satellite picture displays, according to the CMO.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN CALLS TWO OPPOSITION-INITIATED BILLS UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: An opposition-initiated cross Taiwan-Strait peace promotion bill and a national communications commission bill are unconstitutional, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai claimed Monday.

One day before the opposition in the Legislative Yuan is set to railroad the two bills through the legislature, Cho said the peace-promotion bill would usurp the president's constitutional rights, while the organic bill of the national communications commission will breach the Basic Organic Law of Central Executive Agencies and contradict the principle of keeping the media free from political influence.

He warned the opposition parties -- mainly the Kuomintang (KMT) (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), which between them control a slim majority in the legislature -- not to trample on the Constitution and law by abusing their majority to steamroller the two controversial bills through.

Cho branded the PFP-initiated peace-promotion bill a political struggle in disguise because it would take away the president's power and give it to a peace-promoting commission, which would trigger another round of constitutional fighting between the president and the legislature.

He was referring to provisions in the bill that provide for the formation of a peace-promotion commission with the power to negotiate with China on the establishment of a military mutual-trust mechanism, a free trade zone and the opening of direct cross-strait transport links. These powers, the Executive Yuan claims, are reserved by the Constitution for the president or the executive branch and cannot be taken away with an ordinary law.
As to the organic bill of national communications commission, Cho said the controversy centers on the lineup of the commission members.

In the bill crafted by the opposition, the commission members should be named by political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature to prevent the ruling party from packing it with its own supporters, but the administration formed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) opposes it for exactly the same reason -- to ensure the proposed commission's independence from political influence.
Cho said the DPP would engage in a last-ditch negotiation with the two opposition parties Tuesday morning in the hope that they will give up the attempts to put the two bills to a vote.

Negotiations between the two sides broke down ealier in the day. The KMT and the PFP vowed to call for a vote the following day on the two controversial bills, which have already been on the shelf for four months because of the impasse and thereby are technically eligible for a settlement by vote.
Both the ruling and opposition parties called on their party lawmakers to turn out Tuesday for a possible showdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATED IN NICARAGUA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian was decorated by his Nicaraguan counterpart Sunday for his contributions to promoting bilateral cooperation.

Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos bestowed upon Chen the Orden de Ruben Dario en el Grado de Gran Cruz con Placa de Plata, the highest honor presented by Nicaragua to foreign dignitaries, in appreciation for Chen's assistance in promoting Nicaragua's economic development and upgrading bilateral relations.

Chen arrived in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua from the Dominican Republic earlier in the day for a three-day state visit, during which he will attend a summit meeting with his counterparts from the nation's allies in Central America and the Caribbean.
After the decoration ceremony, Bolanos hosted a dinner in honor of Chen and his entourage.
Addressing the occasion, Chen praised Bolanos for his efforts to wipe out official corruption, boost national development, reduce foreign debt and promote inter-party reconciliation and dialogue.
"We admire the 'Nicaraguan spirit' in taking up challenges and overcoming difficulties in pursuit of national growth and strength, " Chen said.

Noting that commercial and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Nicaragua have been growing in recent years, Chen said he is convinced that more Taiwan companies will invest in Nicaragua after the two countries sign a free trade agreement in the near future.

The two countries began negotiations for a free trade pact in August 2004 when then-ROC Premier Yu Shyi-kun made an official visit to Nicaragua. Chen said he hopes negotiations can be finalized as early as possible for the mutual benefit of both sides.

The fifth ROC-Central America summit meeting will take place in Managua Monday, with the participation of Chen and his counterparts from El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua, as well as the Belize prime minister and vice presidents or ministers from Panama, the Dominican Republic and Costa Rica and the secretary-general of the System of Central American Integration.
Panama President Martin Torrijos will fly to Managua to meet with Chen Monday. Because of his tight schedule, Torrijos cannot attend the summit meeting.
Nicaragua is the third leg of Chen's five-nation diplomatic tour that has already taken him to Guatemala and the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. QUESTIONS TAIWAN'S WILL TO DEFEND ITSELF: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The United States has raised questions about Taiwan's will to defend itself because of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan's repeated pulling of the plug on a budget bill for the purchase of a major arms package from the U.S., Vice Defense Minister Michael Tsai said Monday.

Speaking at a training camp organized by the National Defense University for senior civic officers and military officials, the vice minister said war in the 21st Century depends not only on weaponry but also on the people's will to defend themselves.

The vie minister said the opposition parties, however, have raised questions in Washington about Taiwan's determination to defend itself by repeatedly refusing to act on the budget for the arms purchase.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Sept. 27, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1601: Louis XIII, king of France and one of the most powerful monarchs in Europe, is born. He relied heavily on his political adviser Cardinal Richelieu to overcome familial insurgence and war with Spain and the Hapsburgs.
1672: The Royal African Company, a new British company chartered today, is given a monopoly on the trade in "black gold," the African slave trade, and begins arranging shipments of slaves from the African coast to markets in the Americas, offering special terms for entire shiploads.
1722: Samuel Adams, American colonial revolutionary, is born. He was involved in planning the Boston Tea Party, an anti-taxation raid on British ships.
1825: A new era of travel begins when George Stephenson's steam engine "Locomotion" pulls a full load of passengers from Shildon to Stockton in England, inaugurating the world's first passenger rail service.
1900: Foreign troops from eight nations enter Tientsin on their way to Beijing to crush a rebellion after secret societies attacked and killed Westerners and Chinese Christians during the Boxer Uprising.
1913: Dr. Sun Yat-sen plans to reorganize the Kuomintang as the Chunghua Kemingtang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) in Tokyo, and five comrades, including Wang Toong, are the first to pledge their allegiance.
1920: Russia, one of the foreign powers which sacked Beijing during the Boxer Uprising, issues its second manifesto to China, giving up the large indemnities it gained the right to collect under "The Boxer Protocol."
1938: Queen Elizabeth, the world's largest passenger liner, is launched at Clydebank in Scotland.
1939: Poland surrenders to invading German troops after enduring three days and nights of constant bombardment. The Soviet Union's forces quickly occupy the eastern part of Poland.
1945: Japanese Emperor Hirohito meets with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, supreme commander of the Allies, at the U.S. Embassy in Japan during the Allied military occupation.
1946: The first annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank is held in Washington, D.C.
1948: Chinan, capital of Shantung Province, falls to the Chinese communists.
1949: China files a complaint with the U.N. General Assembly against the Soviet Union's aid to the Chinese communists and violations of the Sino-Soviet Treaty of 1945 and of the U.N. Charter.
1953: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek recommends an extension of the term of office of the delegates to the first National Assembly, elected in 1947, until a second National Assembly can be elected.
1964: The Warren Commission, after a 10-month investigation, officially rejects conspiracy as a factor in the assassination of U.S. President John F. Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald the previous November.
1965: The Tokyo Maru, the world's largest oil tanker, is launched at Yokohama.
1968: France bars Britain's entry into the European Economic Community.
1970: King Hussein of Jordan and Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, meet in Cairo with 10 Arab chiefs of state and sign an agreement ending civil war in Jordan.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan calls for the Confucius-Mencius Society to make greater efforts at annihilating the Maoist communists and safeguarding the history and culture of the Chinese people.
1977: A Japan Airlines passenger plane crashes in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, killing 33 people on board. Forty-six others were rescued.
1989: Fugitive Hsu Hsin-liang, former chief of the Taoyuan County Government, fails in his attempt to slip back into Taiwan and is nabbed by an anti-smuggling vessel off the coast of southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO SPEAK IN D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The National Press Club (NPC) based in Washington, D.C. confirmed Monday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will give a speech at the club Oct. 20.
An NPC official said Lee will also take questions from the audience after his speech.

In addition, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a Washington-based group promoting international support for Taiwan's cause which is in charge of Lee's itinerary while in Washington, has also arranged for him to give a brief speech at a luncheon on Capitol Hill,

David Ta-wei Lee, ROC's representative to the United States, said Monday that he will act according to the protocol unveiled by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs two years ago on greeting former heads of state.
It has been learned that Lee will probably meet with Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski in Anchorage before flying on to New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles.

Lee visited the United States in 1995 when he spoke at his alma mater, Cornell University, in his capacity as the ROC president, which triggered a vehement protest from Beijing. After his retirement in 2000, he revisited his alma mater in June 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL TEACHERS FACE HIGH LEVELS OF STRESS, DEPRESSION: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Some 71 percent of middle and elementary school teachers have a high stress index, while 52 percent have a high depression index, according to the results of a survey by the private King Car Education Foundation.

According to the survey carried out Sept. 1-25 on 1,600 teachers at 26 middle and elementary schools around Taiwan, the main reasons many teachers are so unhappy are being bound by an uncertain education policy, carrying heavy administrative burdens, and having too little time to prepare for classes.
However, despite the gloominess, 76 percent of the respondents said they would like to have a permanent career in education.
The survey also found that 62 percent of the respondents are worried about being transferred to other positions or schools as student numbers drop due to low birth rates.

The poll showed that 96 percent of respondents don't feel the existing education policy can free students from heavy academic burdens, and 69 percent believe the existing policy fails to adequately equip students with the skills necessary to enter society in the future.

Meanwhile, 81 percent said they believe the education reforms underway islandwide will result in a widening gap between rich and poor, while 76 percent complained that the views of basic-level teachers were not sufficiently taken into account in developing the reform policies.

In terms of education content, 98 percent said students most need instruction in morality and ethics, while 75 percent mentioned the need for life education, and 45 percent pointed to the need for more instruction in environmental protection. Many of the teachers surveyed also suggested the promotion of holistic education and encouraged parents to learn along with their kids.

Many of the teachers said they believe parents have the greatest influence on their students' thoughts and behavior, followed by peers, and the mass media. The influence of teachers was ranked fourth, ahead of the Internet, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ANNOUNCES 'CO-PROSPERITY PROJECT' IN NICARAGUA
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian announced Tuesday in Managua, Nicaragua the "co-prosperity project" to open up a new era of economic, trade and investment cooperation between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.
The president made the announcement while attending the 5th ROC-Central America Summit which is currently being held in the capital of Nicaragua.
According to the project, Taiwan will set up a fund of US$250 million to help develop the economies of its diplomatic allies in the region.

The president said that the current meeting between the ROC and Central American countries' heads of state has "taken on new significance related to democratic, economic and trade development, as well as sustainable peace, and honorable friendship among the allies."

Pointing out that there is no perfect democratic system in the world but only determination in pursuing a perfect democracy, the president said that Taiwan has already put "democratic values" into practice by a "peaceful transfer" of power between political parties in 2000 and that the 23 million people of Taiwan also elected him to continue to lead the country as well as held the first referendum in Chinese society in 2004 to express their opposition to war and desire for peace.

Chen also reiterated his wishes announced at the beginning of this year to open up a new era of political consultation and dialogue for the country, promising that he will continue to push constitutional reform in order to give the people an appropriate, useful and suitable new Constitution as " this is a plan of institutional reform to further the island's democratization."

"A mature, progressive and untarnished "democracy of Taiwan" is a "kinetic energy" that can not only reinforce the international democratic community, but can also serve as a medium to connect democratic systems in Central and South America, he further said.

Noting that without democracy, people will not treasure peace, the president said that many people consider that cross-strait relations are too complicated, but the substantive problem of such relations is democratic differences between the two sides of the strait.

"Taiwan is a free and democratic country, while China is a country without democracy, human rights and freedom; Democratic Taiwan symbolizes a transparency of the decision-making process and a well-monitored policy by the people, " he said, adding that "China, which lacks a public monitored system and a transparent policy, faces the risk of making wrong decisions which might also endanger peaceful development."

Therefore, the president called for the international community to adopt active and appropriate measures to resolve the representation problem of the 23 million people of Taiwan in international organizations and to help rebuild durable peace between the two sides of the strait.

Democratic progress and economic prosperity must go hand in hand with peaceful dialogue and sincere negotiations, he continued, adding that any military buildup and intimidation will be harmful to regional peace and security.

Claiming that the Taiwanese people are peace-loving and supporters of democracy, the president said that they deserve to be treated with dignity by the international community and to have security as "the island is a world citizen and a messenger of peace."

The president also urged the international community to cautiously deal with the matters related to the rise of China, saying that at a time when many countries have been lured by China's huge market, they should pay proper heed to Beijing's recent passage of an anti-secession law which he said poses a grave threat to Taiwan as it legitimizes the use of "non-peaceful" means to resolve problems in the strait.
He also urged the international community to pay attention to the potential uncertainty that might occur during the process of China's rise.

Stressing that nobody would like to see the collapse of China as the international community could not bear the huge burden of such a collapse, Chen said that in order for China to become a "positive force" in the international community during the process of its development, the rise of China must be accompanied by a "peaceful awakening" and "democratic progress."
"If China can follow the international rules to develop its democracy and sincerely accept peace, it will set an example for those remnant forces existing in the dark places, " he added.

Meanwhile, the president also said that if the Central American free trade agreement (FTA) and that between the Dominican Republic and the United States can take effect as scheduled, and if such agreements can combine with the ROC-Panama FTA and the ROC-Guatemala FTA as well as similar agreements that will be signed between Taiwan and other Central American countries, a complete regional economic and trade platform will be built in the future to help bring international investment, including investment from Taiwan, into Central and South America and the Caribbean as well as create a multilateral win-win situation for Taiwan and the countries in the region.

In response to Chen's appeal, Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos Geyer said while addressing the meeting that his government will continue to support Taiwan's bid to join international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE ROC-PANAMA COOPERATION TO FOCUS ON TRADE AND INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said while meeting with his Panamanian counterpart that future cooperation between the two countries will be focused on investment and trade.

Chen is currently on a visit to the Nicaraguan capital of Managua to attend the 5th ROC-Central America Summit with the participation of the heads of state of five countries in the region, including Belize, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama.

According to Huang Chih-fang, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, Chen thanked Panamanian President Martin Torrijo Espino during the meeting for what he has done to enhance relations between the two countries, pointing to Torrijo's earlier decision to send a minister to visit Taiwan on Sept. 9 to discuss with him the future strengthening of bilateral economic and trade relations.

The ROC's head of state also expressed his gratitude for his Panamanian counterpart's decision to take part in the summit. Torrijo, who had not planned to attend the meeting, changed his mind after meeting with Chen.

Pointing out that the free trade agreement signed between Taiwan and Panama has provided both countries with huge investment opportunities, Chen said that the "co-prosperity project" is aimed at increasing the island's investment in Central America.

The project, which was announced by Chen at the summit, will set up a fund of US$250 million to help push economic, trade and investment cooperation between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean.
Saying that future cooperation between Taiwan and Panama will be centered on investment and trade, the ROC president promised that "he will pay much attention to these areas and oversee them."

In response, Torrijo said that the Taiwan-Panama FTA is the first ever agreement of its kind signed between his country and another country, expressing the hope that it can set an example to practically promote economic and trade relations between the two countries and help increase sales of Panamanian agricultural products to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Chen reiterated during his bilateral meeting with Honduran President Ricardo Maduro that the "co-prosperity project" is abrand-new idea of Taiwan's diplomacy, which is aimed at encouraging the island's state-run and private enterprises to invest in countries in Central America and the Caribbean.
Praising the idea as "very good creativity, " Maduro said that he hopes the two countries can further develop their economic, trade and investment relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ON PAR WITH U.S. IN KIDNEY, LIVER TRANSPLANT SURVIVAL RATES

TEXT.P: Taiwan can compete with the United States in terms of kidney and liver transplant survival rates, but it still has room for progress in heart and lung transplant operations, the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) said Tuesday.

According to BNHI tallies, the bureau paid about NT$900 million for 1,352 organ transplants between 2001 and 2004, of which 686 or 51 percent were kidney transplants, 402 or 30 percent were liver transplants, 212 or 16 percent were heart transplants and the remaining 52 or 3 percent were lung transplants.

The BNHI report showed that Taiwan kidney transplant patients' three-month survival rate was on average 98 percent; the one-year survival rate was 96 percent, and the three-year survival rate was 92 percent.
Compared with figures posted on the U.S.-based United Network for Organ Sharing, BNHI officials said Taiwan was on a par with the United States in terms of kidney transplant patients' survival rates.

On liver transplants, Taiwan patients' average three-month survival rate was 91 percent, compared to 88 percent for the one-year survival rate and 84 percent for the three-year survival rate. The levels were also compatible with U.S. rates and Taiwan even outpaced the United States in terms of liver transplant patients' three-year survival rate.

As for heart transplants, Taiwan's average three-month survival rate was 80 percent, one-year survival rate was 79 percent and three-year survival rate was 66 percent. While the three-month and one-year survival rates were roughly the same as the U.S. level, Taiwan was still behind the U.S. in the three-year survival rate.

Regarding lung transplants, Taiwan patients' average three-month survival rate was 58 percent, one-year survival rate was 40 percent and three-year survival rate was only 19 percent, which was less than half of the U.S. level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO SIGN FTA WITH All CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES: CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Managua, Nicaragua, Sept. 26 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China hopes to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with each of the members of the System of Central American Integration (SICA) as soon as possible, President Chen Shui-bian said in Managua Monday.

Chen attended the fifth ROC-Central America summit meeting Monday along with Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca Gonzalez, Honduras President Ricardo Maduro, and Panama President Martin Torrijos.

A joint communique was signed at the conclusion of the event, but the leaders of Panama and Honduras left early, and President Chen and the three remaining leaders signed the communique after the meeting. The SICA, launched in Feb. 1993, is comprised of Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama, all of them diplomatic allies of the ROC.
The communique reaffirmed support for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other major international organizations and forums.

The attending leaders were upbeat about Taiwan's democratic and economic achievements, and they stressed the importance of peace and security in the Taiwan Strait, urging both sides to solve their differences through dialogue.

The communique also said that the ROC hopes to sign FTAs with the SICA countries, and to make good use of Central America's potential given that the Central American Free Trade Agreement was signed with the United States.

The ROC government has already set up an inter-governmental agency team to promote public and private businesses to invest in Central America's traditional, hi-tech and strategic sectors to help economic development and increase employment to strengthen the integration of the SICA.

The communique also said that the ROC government is willing to help the SICA to promote tourism from Taiwan and related investments, and continue to promote a "Taiwan scholarship" program to help nurture talented people.

In a news conference after the signing of the communique, President Chen said that he and the heads of the state of the Central American allies are like brothers in a big family and that many of them had come to the meeting despite their tight schedules.
"Like the Mid-Autumn Festival and the Chinese New Year in Taiwan, everyone returns for a family reunion no matter how busy they are, " the president said.

He said that Honduras President Maduro originally told him that he would visit Taiwan in October, and asked if attending the meeting was imperative, but after hearing the way Chen had spoken of the coalition, Maduro decided to attend.
Torrijos also said over the phone that he would come to Managua for a meeting with Chen, the president said.
President Chen said that he wanted to tell his friends in Taiwan that a person has to "work hard for diplomacy as well as friendship."
El Salvador President Musa said that President Chen was affable, and he has good official and personal relations with him, and the first ladies of the two countries are also close.

Musa also said that President Chen, like him, was diminutive, but has big heart, and can be called "little big man," lauding Chen as a man of strong convictions and courage and an outstanding national leader of vision.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 14.85 points to close at 5,945.05.
The bourse opened at 5,929.87 and fluctuated between 5,966.97 and 5,905.44 during trading. A total of 2.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$55.11 billion (US$1.66 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks and machinery and electronics shares both moving up at 0.7 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks both moving down the most at 0.5 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 540 to 342, with 191 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF OF TEACHERS WANT TO HAVE THEIR KIDS STUDY ABROAD: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Local schools may be good enough for most people in Taiwan, but almost half of all elementary through high school teachers in Taipei responding to a recent survey are considering sending their children abroad for their education, pollsters said Tuesday.

In mid-September, the opposition People First Party (PFP) caucus at the Taipei City Council sent questionnaires to 828 teachers randomly chosen from the city's 20,000-plus elementary through high school teachers to explore their views on the domestic education environment. A total of 773 valid samples or 93 percent were collected.

Of the roughly 46 percent who said they have thought about sending their kids abroad for study, 56 percent pointed to the need to improve their children's competitiveness, while 30 percent thought that the education policy in Taiwan was poor, with 15 percent saying that their children are under too much stress trying to make grades high enough to allow them to enter better schools in the future.

About 52 percent said that they would like to sent their kids to the United States or Canada for schooling, while 26 percent chose countries in Europe, 12 percent preferred New Zealand and Australia, and 11 percent took China into consideration, according to the poll.

Huang Yiu-chung, a PFP whip at the caucus, said Tuesday that they found through the survey that 71 percent of the teachers are not satisfied with the existing education policy, while 67 percent are worry about a worsening domestic educational environment in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING, OPPOSITION PARTIES DENOUNCE EACH OTHER AFTER NCC SCUFFLE

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition party caucuses denounced each other following a scuffle on the legislative floor triggered by the opposition's insistence on putting to a vote the draft organic law of the National Communications Commission (NCC) Tuesday.

Lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan- green" camp ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), ran a gauntlet to commandeer the podium, the speaker's quarters and the central part of the meeting hall to block Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) legislators from speaking.

About 20 "pan-green" camp lawmakers grabbed Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's microphone and gavel, pounding his table with books and the gavel while shouting, "Dissolve the legislature, replace the speaker!"

As the stand-off went on, KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu shouted "Party of violence!" at DPP legislators, triggering a wave of blasts from bullhorns that both sides had prepared in violation of their own agreement, according to Wang, who said that if the vote couldn't take place in the afternoon, he would call off the meeting.

As the "pan-green" camp lawmakers occupied the speaker's quarters, other DPP lawmakers such as Chang Hua-kuan and Lan Mei-chin guarded the podium, and TSU lawmakers unfurled a banner that read "False reform to seize power; KMT-PFP toppling NCC, media future bleak."

As the "pan-green" lawmakers formed three cordons of defense against "pan- blue alliance" members who might seize an opportunity to speak from the podium, a second wave of clashes occurred at the other side of the legislative floor.

At a news conference immediately after the turmoil, KMT caucus Secretary- General Cho Po-yuan accused DPP Legislator Chuang Ho-tzu of attacking KMT Legislator Liao Wan-ju in the back, and PFP legislators Hsieh Kuo-liang and Sun Ta-chien were also roughed up by DPP lawmakers.

Chuang and Liao later sought medical attention -- Chuang was sent to National Taiwan University Hospital, and Liao was treated at the Legislative Yuan's medical service center for an injury to her face.

The KMT and PFP caucuses jointly denounced the "pan-green" camp's "violent filibustering" of the meeting, declaring that they "definitely will pass the NCC organic law within the day." The "pan-blue alliance" enjoys a majority at the legislature.

PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping, who was unable to speak on the legislative floor as she was pushed off the podium, said the DPP was boycotting the NCC bill in an attempt to safeguard underground radio stations that will serve as the DPP's propaganda machines during the year-end county, city and town elections.

Chao Yung-ching, DPP caucus convener, accused the major opposition parties of "forever changing the legislative agenda to include the draft NCC organic law and the draft law for promoting cross-Taiwan Strait peace."

"If they don't understand what the real public opinion is, people will certainly pass judgment on then, " Chao said, challenging the opposition to make a motion to disband the legislature so that the people will have a chance to reelect it.
On the NCC bill, Chao said the KMT and PFP insisted on adopting their version that will protect KMT-owned electronic media and enfeeble the NCC as an independent institution.

He said he had urged his colleagues to avoid physical scuffles and express their views in a rational manner. He also expressed the hope that both the ruling and opposition parties will sit down to negotiate a settlement of their differences about the NCC structure.

The "pan-blue alliance" wants the new organization to be formed by members appointed in accordance with political party seats at the legislature, and the "pan-green" camp opposed this as an "outdated" idea that will deprive the NCC of its professionalism and independence.

Besides, according to DPP caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai, the KMT and PFP slipped into their draft version a clause that will protect the future operations of KMT-owned China Television Company; if passed, the law will set back the nation's efforts to force political parties, the military and political powers to leave the media alone.

If the "pan-blue alliance" insists on using their "numerical violence" to pass the NCC bill, the DPP caucus will suggest that the Cabinet propose a "reconsideration" by the Legislative Yuan; if that also fails, the government should request the Council of Grand Justices to interpret the law according to the Constitution, Lai said.

However, the KMT's Hong Hsiu-chu cited the example of the Chen Shui-bian government appointing ideologically inclined members to the Central Election Commission and the Examination Yuan, which she claimed shows that the ruling camp does not enjoy "a bit of credibility among the people."
The KMT and PFP want the NCC to be staffed according to party proportions exactly to "get the government's hands off the media, " she claimed.
