DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON LONGWANG MAY AFFECT TAIWAN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Typhoon Longwang, the 19th typhoon this year, has increased its intensity to that of a medium typhoon and it will be clear in about three days whether it will affect Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported in a forecast Tuesday.

According to the CWB report, as of Tuesday afternoon, Typhoon Longwang's center was located at 21.7 degrees north latitude and 140 degrees east longitude -- about 970 km north-northwest of Guam. Its 150 km radius was moving west-northwest at 18 km per hour, packing center winds at 120 km per hour.
The typhoon is expected to change its direction slightly to northwest Wednesday, with the speed slowing down to 14 km per hour.

It is uncertain yet whether Typhoon Longwang, still 2,100 km from Taiwan, will affect the island because the high pressure over the Pacific Ocean is not stable. The situation will be clearer by Friday. If the typhoon continues to move toward Taiwan, a warning could be issued Sunday, according to the CWB forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CO-PROSPERITY' PROJECT TO CREATE 'WIN-WIN-WIN' SITUATION: MOFA

TEXT.P: A project President Chen Shui-bian unveiled in Nicaragua will create a "triple-win" situation for the government, the private sector as well as the allies of the Republic of China, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Michel Lu was referring to an announcement by President Chen Shui-bian at the fifth ROC-Central America summit meeting in Managua, Nicaragua, Monday that the government will set up a special fund of US$250 million for a "co-prosperity" project, envisioning a new investment cooperation climate between Taiwan and Central America.

The project, with money coming from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Executive Yuan's Development Fund, is aimed at encouraging Taiwan businessmen to invest in sectors with potential in Central America, and the ceiling for government investment will be 49 percent.
He said that under the program, the proposals will have to undergo a process of "negotiation and take into consideration whether they are strong sectors of Taiwan."

Lu said the effect of the government's encouragement of Taiwan businessmen to invest in diplomatic allies or other regions will hinge on the places, taking Central and South America and the Caribbean as examples to say that Taiwan businessmen's investments in the regions stand at US$1.7 billion.

He pointed out that faced with the trend of globalization and the launch of the Central America Free Trade Agreement and the expected formation of the Free Trade Area of the Americas, the business potential in the region is huge.

Lu said that the government must provide necessary incentives to encourage the private sector to pitch in technology and capital and the crux of the "co-prosperity" program is based on the same idea, hoping to help Taiwan businesses reach out to the world, expedite the transformation of businesses and diversify overseas investment risks.

The government will encourage the sectors that Taiwan excel in, such as the information and textile sectors, to invest, and will invite the allies to join, which he said will help the allies develop economically and create job opportunities, and help the allies to boost trade with the United States through the Central America Free Trade Agreement and the expected formation of the Free Trade Area of the Americas.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORP. CELEBRATES ITS 20TH BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: The government-run Central Deposit Insurance Corporation (CDIC) celebrated its 20th anniversary Tuesday at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Traditional dragon and lion dances kicked off the activity, which was attended by 150 dignitaries from foreign deposit insurance institutions. At the event, 23 CDIC employees were awarded for their 20-year service at the company.

Addressing the celebration, CDIC Chairman Tsai Chin-tsair stated that the company's history, beginning in 1985, indicating that the CDIC was jointly established by the Minister and Finance and the Central Bank of China with the goals of safeguarding the benefits of depositors in financial institutions, maintaining trust orders and promoting healthy financial operations.

To date, the company has guided 48 poorly-managed financial institutions around Taiwan to bow out of the market, Tsai said, describing the CDIC as the distinguished "firefighter" in the financial sector.

The celebration also saw the participation of several leaders of local financial holdings companies, including Mega Holdings Chairman Cheng Shen-chih, Fuhwa Financial Holdings Chairman Yen Ching-chang, as well as Huanan Financial Holdings Chairman Lin Ming-cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.008 to close at NT$33.282.
A total of US$746 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$33.254 and hit a high of NT$33.305.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October moved down 15 points to close at 5,935, with 29,561 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November moved down 19 points to end at 5,930, with 248 contracts traded, while December futures lost 10 points to finish at 5,930, with 14 contracts traded. March futures moved down 11 points to close at 5,930, with six contracts traded, while June futures moved up 53 points to close at 6,000, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,950 for October, 5,949 for November, 5,940 for December, 5,941 for March and 5,947 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

October TE futures moved up 0.55 points to close at 247.25, with 3,880 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 0.7 points to finish at 247.15, with 10 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 2.25 points to end at 247, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

October TF futures lost eight points to finish at 882.4, with 2,193 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures moved down four points to end at 885, with 15 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down five points to close at 884, with one contract transaction, while March TF futures lost nine points to finish at 881, with four contracts traded. June TF futures lost 11.8 points to close at 880, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' NIXES ARMS PURCHASE BILL FOR 30TH TIME

TEXT.P: "Pan-blue alliance" lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) used their majority to block the government's arms purchase bill from being put on the legislative agenda for the 30th time Tuesday.

Also blocked from discussion on the legislative floor were President Chen Shui-bian's nominations of Control Yuan members and two bills drafted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its " pan-green" camp ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , concerning political party assets.

After a vote by the Legislative Yuan's Procedure Committee, whose three conveners are William C.T. Lai (DPP) , Pan Wei-kang (KMT) and Lin Hui-kuan (PFP), several "pan-blue alliance"-initiated bills were put on the agenda of the legislature's next meeting.

These include the KMT-proposed draft amendment to the law governing relations between the people in Taiwan and in China. The amendments will affect direct transportation links between the two sides of the Strait. Another KMT-proposed bill concerns a revision of the law governing the organization of the Judicial Yuan.

A PFP proposal to legislate a law on flood control was also put on the legislative agenda to counter the government's similar proposal for requesting a special budget of NT$80 billion over eight years for the same purpose. Another PFP-initiated draft bill passed by the Procedure Committee deals with the Legislative Yuan's exercise of authority.

At the Procedure Committee, KMT and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) made a joint proposal to put amendments to the "319 shooting investigative commission" and the organization of the nation's court system on the meeting agenda for the second reading, provoking a walkout by DPP lawmakers.
DPP Legislator Lin Shu-fen accused the "pan-blue alliance" of showing contempt for the committee by trying to "smuggle" law bills and depriving the committee of its normal functions.
Hsu Kuo-yung, another DPP lawmaker, agreed with Lin by claiming that the "pan-blue alliance" act indicates that there is no more need for the Procedure Committee to exist.
"Why not just go ahead and abolish all committees [that are responsible for screening all law bills]? " he said, demanding that the KMT face the consequences of its own actions.

Huang Shih-cho, a TSU lawmaker, charged that the "pan-blue alliance" was trying to "seize power with majority violence" when it tried to ram the National Communications Commission (NCC) organic bill through the legislature.
Wu Yu-sheng, a KMT lawmaker, responded by declaring that there is only a majority vote, and no so-called "majority violence, " at the legislature.

By saying the opposition was using "majority violence" at the legislature, the ruling party was actually revealing its compunction about not following a democratic procedure to allow for a vote, he said.

The "pan-green" camp's obstreperous act of commandeering the speaker's quarters is obviously evidence of the ruling camp slapping the face of the lawmaking body, an act that should be denounced by all, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPTICAL DISC MAKERS MUST EXPAND TO SURVIVE: CMC CEO

TEXT.P: Optical drive and disc manufacturers must expand to survive in view of the ferocious competition in the industry, the head of a major local optical disc manufacturing company said Tuesday.

Speaking in an interview with CNA, CMC Magnetics Corp. Chairman Bob Wong said the optical media industry prospects have improved thanks to a combination of factors, including smaller players being kicked out of the market, surviving companies no longer "blindly" expanding production capacity and market demand remaining strong.

Noting that the optical media industry has a clear boom-to-slump cycle, Wong said the industry's well-bing hinges on the market supply and demand situation. In the past few years, Wong said, CD-R discs have been in oversupply because the market demand has shifted to DVDs.

The world demand for CD-Rs is estimated at around 9.5 billion units, but the quantity is expected to drop to the tune of between 8.5 billion and 9 billion. In contrast, the demand for DVDs has been on the rise, Wong said, adding that the global demand for DVDs amounts to 4 billion units this year, with the figure expected to grow further to 6 billion units next year.

There are now about 400 CD-R manufacturing firms around the world, but only 20 DVD makers because of the high technological barriers to production. At the moment, Wong said, only three companies are capable of producing double-layer DVDs and CMC Magnetics is the only one that can produce 8x double-layer DVDs.

According to Wong, the optical media industry has undergone structural changes in the past couple of years. One of the changes is the takeoff of the DVD market. With the CD-R demand shrinking rapidly and prices for petrochemical raw materials skyrocketing, many CD-R makers who have failed to shift into DVD production have been forced out of the market.
Wong said that as the PC material price accounts for 40 percent of the DVD cost, crude oil price hikes have seriously affected DVD makers' profit margins.
Nevertheless, Wong said, as PC producers in Thailand, China and Spain have expanded their production capacity, the room for PC prices to rise should be limited.
Wong predicted that PC prices will begin to drop in the fourth quarter of this year. This trend will help cut DVD production costs and contribute to market growth, he said.

Wong further said his company's earnings in July and August have covered all of its losses in the first half of this year and that its profits in September will hit an all-time high. "We believe our company's profits will grow by leaps and bounds from the second half of this year through next year, " Wong said.

Taiwan has been the world's biggest supplier of optical drives and discs for several years. A projected 105 million drives were produced by Taiwan manufacturers in 2004, according to the Taipei-based Market Intelligence Center (MIC) , with a production value worth US$3.6 billion.

The Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) , another market research firm based in Taiwan, estimated that Taiwan shipped 6.8 billion optical discs in 2004, with a total value of US$1.9 billion.

Taiwan accounts for a majority of the global output of the major optical disc formats: CD-R, 69 percent; CD-RW, 84 percent; DVD-R, 75 percent; CD-ROM, 47 percent; and DVD-RW, 62 percent, according to the IEK.

There are about 10 manufacturers of optical drives and 15 suppliers of optical discs in Taiwan. CD-ROM and CD-RW drives, and CD-R and CD-RW discs remain the bread-and-butter for most manufacturers. Because of thinning profit margins for CD-based products, leading Taiwan suppliers have been shifting focus to DVD rewritable drives and discs.
Some of Taiwan's top optical drive manufacturers concentrate on R&D and subcontract production to EMS companies.

Taiwan makers expect their monthly output of optical drives to increase by an average 27 percent in 2005. DVD drives account for more than half of suppliers' output, a trend that is expected to intensify in 2005. DVD dual drives, at the top of the line, account for 18 percent of total output.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE BUSINESSES EXPECT BRIGHTER ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: A total of 19 percent of businesses said they are optimistic about the economic prospects for the next three months, compared to 17 percent who said the opposite, according to the latest survey released Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The survey bodes well for the future, as the percentage of optimists are 2 percent more than that of last month, while the percentage of the pessimists are 6 percent less than that of last month.
Meanwhile, the percentage of those who believe the economic prospects will remain the same increased for 60 percent in August to 64 percent.
Based on this survey, the CEPD predicted that the country's economic performance will improve in the second half of this year unless oil prices surge significantly.

The slight optimism was based on the improvement in economic performance in August, which has seen the business revenue of the manufacturing industry increasing by 3.8 percent over the previous month, although it is 1.8 percent less than that of the corresponding period of last year.

Also, orders have increased by 2.4 percent over the previous month and by 4.7 percent over the corresponding period of last year, the equipment-utilization rate has increased by 1.4 percent over July and by 0.5 percent over the corresponding period of last year to 81 percent.
The average profit from sales is 5 percent, which is 0.2 percent more than the previous month and the same as the corresponding period of last year.

In light of the fact that the international economy continues to grow in defiance of rising international oil prices and the toll taken by hurricanes on the U.S. economy, the CEPD forecast brighter economic prospects for the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO NEGOTIATE NCC BILL IN NEAR FUTURE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng called off a meeting that was marred by ruling-opposition scuffles over the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) Tuesday, saying he will call a new round of consultations over the bill in the near future.

Wang said all party caucuses had agreed to follow regular procedures before the meeting began Tuesday, but ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers swarmed the speaker's quarters soon after the meeting started, breaking their commitment, violating the meeting rules and causing great harm to the legislature.

He said he will call another round of "substantive negotiations" between the ruling and opposition caucuses in the coming few days and he expressed hope that when the legislative meeting deals with the NCC bill again Oct. 11, all lawmakers will follow the rules.

On the question of calling in police to maintain order, as he had been demanded to do Tuesday, Wang said there are many ways to maintain what he described as the "dignity" of the legislature and calling in police is the worst of them.

He showed his displeasure over the fact that only DPP Policy Committee Executive Director Ko Chien-ming apologized for damaging the microphone on his table, while the DPP itself merely promised to compensate for damage to public property caused by its members.
He expressed "deep regret" that DPP lawmakers seized the speaker's quarters and the podium and called on the party caucuses to restrain their members so that the legislature can operate normally.

The scuffles erupted when opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers insisted on putting to a vote their version of the bill calling for appointing NCC members according to the percentage of seats each party holds at the legislature.

Premier Frank Hsieh said the NCC should be staffed by professionals and experts without any interference from political parties. He also expressed hope that the legislature will deliberate the NCC organic bill along with a bill on the Executive Yuan's organization.

Hsieh made the remarks after attending a Central Standing Committee meeting of the DPP, during which party leaders discussed the feasibility of giving up legislative filibustering and instead appealing directly to the people for support of the government version of the NCC organic bill.

Party leaders, including Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, denounced the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP for adopting an "outdated" idea about naming NCC members that runs counter to "world trends."

The Government Information Office (GIO) , whose mandate over the media will be taken over by the NCC, said the government's version of the NCC organic bill proposed that the premier's nomination of NCC members must win legislative approval to be effective.

Such a proposal is in complete accord with what GIO described as "the democratic trend in the world" that authorizes the parliament or legislature to monitor the operation of an independent government institution.
The government has never thought of dominating the nomination and appointment of NCC members, as some people have said it will do, the GIO claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRESH MILK AFFECTED BY DIOXIN IN TAIWAN PASTURE: STUDY

TEXT.P: High dioxin levels in Taiwan's pasture are posing a hazard to food safety and could affect the health of consumers who drink fresh milk, according to the results of a study released Tuesday.

The study, conducted by the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation and Tsinhua University from January to July, has found that dioxin levels in four varieties of grass -- kikuyu grass, nilegrass, pangola grass and corn silage -- in Taiwan's dairy farms reached between 1.28 nanograms per kilogram (ng/kg) and 2.25 ng/kg, far exceeding the 0.75 ng/kg permitted by the European Union.

The dioxin levels in local pasture are also much higher than those found in imported grass varieties, such as alfalfa hay, Bermuda grass and oat grass, which contain less than 0.3 ng/kg of dioxin, according to the study.

After researchers fed local dairy cows with imported grass, the dioxin levels in the milk from these cows gradually dropped from 2.98 picograms of the toxicity equivalent per gram of fat -- denoted as 2.98 pg TEQ/g fat -- to 1.75 pg TEQ/g fat. The EU's dioxin limit for fresh milk is 3 pg TEQ/g fat.
The study has established that grass fed to milk cows in local dairy farms is the main reason affecting the dioxin levels in the milk from these farms.
Dioxin, a known carcinogen, causes cancer, birth defects, diabetes, immune system abnormalities and many other adverse health effects if it accumulates in the human body in large amounts.

Commenting on the findings of the research, Liu Min-lung, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, urged the Department of Health and the Council of Agriculture to set standards as soon as possible to control the amounts of dioxin allowed for food products and animal feed in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA 3RD-MOST POPULAR STUDY DESTINATION FOR TAIWAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Australia has become the third-most popular destination for Taiwan students studying overseas, behind the United States and Britain, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Ministry of Education (MOE).
The statistics show that in 2004, 14,054 local students obtained U.S. student visas, 9,207 students got British visas and 2,246 got Australian visas.
Education officials ascribed the increased interest in Australia to the fact that it is an English-speaking nation with an education system compatible with that of Taiwan.

As a result, the International Education Expo sponsored by the MOE this year will begin Oct. 1 with a presentation in Taipei by the Australian Education Center, to be followed by presentations in Taichung and Kaohsiung.

According to statistics released by the Australian Education Center in Taipei, more than 300,000 foreign students enrolled in Australian schools in 2003, 75 percent of whom studied in universities, colleges and vocational schools. Business, management and information industry were the three fields most popular among foreign students.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI TO RESPECT GRAND JUSTICES RULING ON ID CARD FINGERPRINTING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will respect whatever ruling the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) metes out on the constitutionality of fingerprinting requirements set in the Household Registration Law, a senior official said Tuesday.

Vice Interior Minister Chang Wen-ying made the remarks a day before the CGJ was scheduled to announce whether the government can require local people to be fingerprinted when they pick up their new identity cards.

"Whatever the CGJ ruling will be, we'll respect it. The Ministry of the Interior will consistently uphold the principle of 'rule by law,'" Chang said, adding that the MOI will hold a news conference to explain its stance after the CGJ formally announces its ruling Wednesday.

The ministry was originally scheduled to begin issuing new forgery-proof ID cards July 1. But the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) filed for a Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) ruling May 30 on the constitutionality of the Household Registration Law that requires local citizens to have their fingerprints taken when they pick up their new ID cards. The DPP application was a response to mounting concern about possible human rights violations.
In view of the limited time available, the CGJ imposed a moratorium June 10 on the fingerprinting provision until it metes out its ruling. The CGJ held a two-day hearing on the issue in July.
Recent media reports said the CGJ will rule against the fingerprinting provision.

Another vice interior minister, Chien Tai-lang, who defended the fingerprinting provision in the July hearing, declined to comment on reports, saying only that the MOI will not express its stance until after receiving the CGJ's interpretation.

Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan said last month that the ID card renewal will be postponed until after the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township chiefs because local population offices will be too busy with preparations for the elections when the CGJ hand down its ruling.

Quoting the results of an MOI survey, Su said 14 cities and counties have suggested that ID card renewal be started Jan. 1, 2006, while the remaining cities and counties have recommended that the renewal be kicked off after Dec. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT DEADLOCKED OVER NAMING OF NCC MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties may attend a consultation meeting over the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) called by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng within two weeks, but their differences over how to appoint NCC members were still wide apart Tuesday.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus, said his caucus proposed the "Public Television (PTV) model" for staffing the NCC -- that is, before the premier nominates the members, their list would be discussed by all caucuses at the legislature.

The PTV's board of directors and supervisors have 11 to 15 members who are appointed by the premier, but before the appointment, they have to win a three-quarters majority vote of a screening committee whose 11 to 13 members are "impartial and respected members of society" recommended by the Legislative Yuan.
If the caucuses agree on the list, the premier will proceed to appoint the members, Chao noted. He did not say what should be done if the caucuses cannot reach a consensus over the nominations.

However, the Kuomintang (KMT) rejected the proposal, claiming that the ruling party is incapable of "self-restraint, " so the opposition could only resort to "the system" to keep anything inappropriate from happening.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said the NCC bill should have been passed by the end of last year, and yet the DPP has done nothing over the past half year except allowing the Government Information Office (GIO) to meddle in media operations.

The DPP is now filibustering the legislative meetings scheduled for dealing with the NCC bill in an attempt to kill it off -- an action that runs counter to President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promise in 2000, she claimed.
As to the composition of NCC, she said the KMT and People First Party proposed seating it with scholars and experts recommended by the parties, not by party members.

She noted that in the KMT and PFP proposal, party workers, state-run enterprise executives, elected officials who have run on party tickets and even those who have recently run but failed on party tickets are all excluded.
She called on the DPP to look at the "pan-blue alliance" proposal and not distort or select only the portions that fit its purposes.

However, William C.T. Lai, DPP caucus secretary-general, said the "pan-blue alliance" version of the NCC organic bill contains two provisions that would allow the KMT to keep running China Television Company and owning Broadcasting Corp. of China, something that is not acceptable to the public.
While the DPP seemed willing to return to the negotiating table, Cheng said the KMT will definitely "fight to the end" for its version of the NCC bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WARNS DPP: DON'T BLOCK NCC BILL AGAIN

TEXT.P: A legislative caucus whip of the opposition People First Party (PFP) warned legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday not to obstruct the proceedings of the organic bill of the National Communications Commission (NCC) and the bill promoting cross-Taiwan Strait peace again, threatening that if they do, "anything could happen."

Commenting on the chaos created by DPP legislators who surrounded the rostrum Tuesday and made legislative proceedings impossible, Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the PFP caucus in the legislature, said the PFP caucus will not rule out the possibility of fighting back in whatever manner it chooses if the DPP continues to use the same strategy to block the passage of the two bills.

Huang also said that for the sake of the Legislature's dignity, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng should have exercised his right to summon police to maintain order in the meeting hall, instead of having the proceedings adjourned.

Meanwhile, Cho Po-yuan, a whip of the opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus, told a press conference that DPP legislators breached the rules of conduct for lawmakers by occupying the rostrum and obstructing the proceedings and that they should be dealt with by the Disciplinary Committee of the legislature.

Cho described Tuesday's chaos in the legislature as a "disgrace" to Taiwan's democracy and lambasted the DPP as "unworthy" of its status as the ruling party. He demanded that the DPP apologize to the public for "treading the dignity of the legislature" under their feet.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, urged the KMT caucus not to refer the DPP legislators to the Disciplinary Committee because that would only make the situation in the legislature even more chaotic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST ONLINE UNIVERSITY TO BE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first degree-conferring online university will be launched Wednesday by the National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi, central Taiwan, but will not take in students until next year, a university official said Tuesday.

The university, to be founded according to guidelines just crafted by the Ministry of Education on remote teaching, will offer three master's degree programs in the preliminary stage, as well as six online courses, and 12 online courses with credits.

Touting it as a milestone in the country's education history, the Chung Cheng University said the on-line university will revolutionize local education by providing students with the choice to study at times and places they prefer and will make "going to school" a thing of the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESOLVE TO UPGRADE SELF-DEFENSE CRITICAL TO U.S. TIES: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must prove its resolve to upgrading its self-defense capability in its engagements with the United States, the nation's top representative to Washington, D.C. said Monday.

"How to prove our determination to beef up our defenses has become the most important and confusing issue in Taiwan-U.S. relations, " David Ta-wei Lee, the de facto Republic of China ambassador to the United States, said during a monthly news conference.

With the government's plan to procure three big-ticket weaponry items from the United States having been blocked by opposition lawmakers, Lee said many U.S. officials, congressmen and think tank scholars have questioned Taiwan's determination to upgrade its defense capabilities in the face of the mounting military threat from China.

As the United States is a stakeholder in Taiwan Strait security and stability, Lee said the United States looks forward to seeing Taiwan upgrade its defense capabilities. As to how to realize that goal, Lee said, the United States is willing to exchange views and cooperate with Taiwan in carrying out relevant projects.
Lee said it is hoped that Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can begin deliberating the long-stalled arms procurement package in a rational manner.

The Bush administration agreed in April 2001 to sell the robust arms package to Taiwan, which comprises eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. Taiwan's legislature has rejected putting it on the legislative agenda for more than a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Sept. 28, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Roman general Pompey the Great is assassinated as he lands in Egypt, stabbed to death on orders given by Egyptian king Ptolemy XIII.
551 B.C.: Confucius, Chinese philosopher, is born. Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek ordered in 1952 that Teachers' Day be observed on the anniversary of the birth of the great sage and teacher who has had a far-reaching influence on Chinese philosophy and culture.
1066: William I, Duke of Normandy, later known as "William the Conqueror, leads the Norman invasion of England after being promised the English throne by his cousin, Edward the Confessor. He defeated Harold at the Battle of Hastings and as king adopted a feudal constitution.
1864: A group of radicals from France, Germany, Italy, Poland and Britain meets in London and forms an international worker's association known as the "First International," to help unite the world's workers in revolution.
1895: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and microbiologist, dies at the age of 73. He founded modern microbiology, invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies and chicken cholera.
1898: Than Shih-tung, Yang Hsen-siu, Yang Jui, Lin Chang, Liu Kuang-ti and Kang Kuang-jen, who had played leading roles in the reform movement initiated by Kang Yu-wei and Liang Chi-chao, are executed in Peking by Empress Dowager Tzuhsi.
1900: Dr. Sun Yat-sen arrives in Japanese-controlled Taiwan, where he set up a secret society and directed an uprising at Hueichow in Kwantung Province.
1934: Brigitte Bardot, French actress and international sex symbol who first caused a stir in "And God Created Woman," is born.
1937: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution denouncing Japan's aggression in China.
1937: A million people gather at an evening rally in Berlin to hear Nazi leader Adolf Hitler and Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini deliver a message of "peace."
1969: ROC Economics Minister S. Y. Tao dies of illness in New York at the age of 49.
1975: A 15-member ROC delegation to the 22nd International Skills Competition returns with 12 medals.
1976: U.S. President Gerald R. Ford presents a carved American redwood plaque to the government and people of the Republic of China to mark the ROC's role in the U.S. Bicentennial celebration.
1977: A Japan Airlines DC-8, en route from Bombay to Paris, is hijacked by Japanese "Red Army" guerrillas and ordered to fly to Dhaka.
1978: John Paul I is found dead after only 33 days as Pope and is succeeded by John Paul II.
1978: A Taiwan Airlines passenger plane, en route from Taitung to Lanyu Island, crashes into the sea, killing all 10 people on board.
1982: U.S. President Ronald Reagan sends marines into Beirut on a peace-keeping mission after a Lebanese massacre.
1986: A group of political activists, including Fei Hsi-ping, meets at the Grand Hotel in Taipei and forms the Democratic Progressive Party.
1989: Ferdinand E. Marcos, former president of the Philippines, dies in exile in Hawaii at the age of 72.
1991: U.S. President George Bush proposes sweeping nuclear arms cuts surpassing the 30 percent reduction agreed on in Moscow earlier in the year following the "death of Soviet communism."
1994: The ferry Estonia, en route from Tallinn to Stockholm, sinks about 20 miles from the Finnish island of Utoe, resulting in the drowning of 909 people and marking the worst peacetime maritime disaster in European history.
1995: Rulers of the Chinese Communist Party approve an ambitious five-year plan promising an end to poverty, a better deal for farmers and poor island areas, and an overhaul of lumbering state companies.
1997: The Beijing-appointed Provisional Legislature in Hong Kong overwhelmingly endorses a new election law that critics say curtails democracy in the former British colony.
1999: Neil Bush, the third son of former U.S. President George Bush, arrives in Taipei, bringing with him 1.6 metric tons of medicine and medical equipment to contribute to relief work in earthquake-stricken Taiwan.
2000: Visiting ROC Vice President Annette Lu pays a call on Honduran President Carlos Roberto Flores Facusse for wide-ranging talks.
2001: The Ministry of Finance gives the green light to eight domestic banks to set up offices in mainland China. They are the United World Chinese Commercial Bank, the International Commercial Bank of China, the Land Bank of Taiwan, the First Commercial Bank, the Taiwan Cooperative Bank, the Hua Nan Commercial Bank, the Chang Hwa Bank and the Chinatrust Commercial Bank.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To attain to the sovereignty of the world, there are three important things necessary; they may perhaps be summed up in one: blamelessness of life."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN ST. KITTS FOR STATE VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Basseterre, St. Kitts, Sept. 27 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis Tuesday from Nicaragua for a state visit.

During the visit, Chen, at the head of a group of high-ranking officials and business leaders, will meet with the Caribbean nation's Prime Minister Denzil L. Douglas and pay a courtesy call to Governor General Sir Cuthbert Sebastian.
The president will also receive the Order of St. Christopher and Nevis from the governor general and sign a joint communique with the prime minister.
He will also preside over a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the opening of a sports center built with ROC government funding.
Chen, who is currently on a five-nation diplomatic tour in Central America and the Caribbean, is the first-ever ROC president to visit the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE OIL PRODUCTS TO SEE COMMODITY TAX CUT NEXT MONTH: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced in an Executive Yuan meeting Wednesday that commodity taxes for gasoline, diesel and fuel oil will be adjusted downward by 25 percent starting Oct. 1 for a trial period of three months.
The premier's announcement came amidst soaring world crude oil prices in recent months.
Hsieh said that on average, the commodity taxes for the three kinds of oil products will be cut by between NT$1 and NT$1.5 per liter.
With the cut, the premier said that consumer prices and wholesale prices are expected to decrease by 0.06 and 0.09 percentage points, respectively.

Although the commodity tax cut will affect tax revenues, the Ministry of Finance is still positive about reaching its tax revenue goal for this year, the premier said, adding that stabilizing consumer prices is the government's priority concern.

He said that if oil prices continue to soar during the three-month trial period, the Executive Yuan will then agree to allow the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to hike its petroleum prices after the three months.

The privately run Formosa Petroleum Corp. recently hiked its gas prices due to soaring international crude oil prices. Normally, the CPC follows suit, but it didn't on this occasion mainly because of government's concerns about placing a heavier burden on the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFUCIUS COMMEMORATED NATIONWIDE ON TEACHER'S DAY

TEXT.P: Local governments and cultural groups around the country held rituals at Confucius temples on "Teacher's Day" Wednesday to commemorate the great Chinese sage's 2,555th birth anniversary.

At Confucius Temple in Taipei, Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presided over a ceremony, with Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan burning incense and chanting an ode during the ritual to pay tribute to Confucius on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Eighty-six-year-old Kung Teh-cheng, who claims to be a direct descendant of Confucius and who has been present at similar rituals over the past 55 years since Confucius was first commemorated officially in Taiwan in 1950, was absent from the ceremony due to health reasons.

The commemorative ritual strictly followed ancient ceremonial rules, with elementary school boys performing a classical "Liu I" dance and eight academic representatives playing the role of ritual officials amid music originating in the Sung Dynasty.

After the ceremony, Ma gave away small gift parcels, including "wisdom cake" and a mini copy of "Lun Yu" (The Analects of Confucius) , to some 1,000 spectators, including many foreign expatriates, tourists and representatives from Japanese Confucian Analects promotional associations who have traveled to Taiwan exclusively for the occasion.
Meanwhile, another commemorative ritual was held at the Confucius Temple in Tainan City, southern Taiwan. The temple is the oldest and most representative of its kind in Taiwan.

Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lin Kuang-hua presided over the ritual, which featured not only the "Liu I" dance but also a traditional practice allowing the people to pluck the "hair of wisdom" from an ox in anticipation of learning from Confucius' teachings and becoming wiser.

Similar commemorative rituals were held at Confucius temples in major cities and counties around the country to honor the great sage and teacher who has had a far-reaching influence on Chinese philosophy and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORCYCLISTS ACCOUNT FOR OVER HALF OF TRAFFIC ACCIDENT DEATHS: MOTC

TEXT.P: More than half of those who died in traffic accidents in Taiwan in 2003 and 2004 were motorcyclists, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
More than 2,000 motorcyclists died in traffic accidents in each of 2003 and 2004, according to the MOTC statistics.
The statistics also showed that those in the 18-24 age group accounted for the largest share of traffic accident deaths.

The MOTC also reported that there were 1,138 traffic deaths in the first half of this year, down 10 percent from the figure for the same period a year earlier. At the same time, the number of traffic accidents increased by 9 percent to 72,000.
The main cause of traffic accidents in the first half of the year was driving under the influence of alcohol, according to the statistics.
The tallies also showed that traffic accidents occurred most frequently between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Motorcyclists accounted for 53 percent of all traffic accident deaths in Taiwan in 2003. The ratio was higher than those seen in the United States, Britain, France, South Korea and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN U.S. HOUSE REP'S TONE GETS HARSHER ON ARMS BILL DELAY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin, Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A longstanding pro-Taiwan U.S. congressman said Tuesday that those who have supported Taiwan in the U.S. Congress might review the extent of their support for the island if Taiwan prefers not to pass the special arms procurement budget bill.

Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , member of the U.S. House of Representatives and co-chair of the Taiwan Caucus in the House, made the harsh comments while attending a seminar held by the Heritage Foundation, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank.
"I believe that many members of Congress who have long supported Taiwan, including myself, will re-evaluate the degree of their support for the island if Taiwan does not pass the bill, " he said.
The bill has been stalled in the island's Legislative Yuan due opposition from the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party which holds a slight majority in the legislature.

Pointing out that the delays in passing the bill have brought Taiwan's military modernization to a standstill, the representative said that "this makes me feel very disappointed and is a major setback for me."

If Taiwan makes others feel that the island is weak, then China might take action against it, he also said, adding, that if Taiwan has strong and powerful self-defense capabilities, there will be less chance of it being involved in a military conflict.

He further said that the United States has commitments to various countries around the world and that Taiwan is only one of these countries, stressing that the island should be responsible for its own security.

Meanwhile, Chabot also called for the Bush administration to review its "one China" policy as the policy might lead Beijing to mistakenly think that it has sovereignty over Taiwan and can use force against the island to solve internal problems.
"The United States should give up its 'one China' policy as it is a dangerous fiction," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTD-RMB CONVERSION TO BEGIN IN KINMEN, MATSU FROM OCT. 3: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced Wednesday that conversion between the New Taiwan dollar and the Chinese currency renminbi will begin on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu from Oct. 3 on atrial basis.

Local residents of Kinmen and Matsu; Taiwan residents who can travel between the outlying islands and China's Fujian Province under the "mini three links" regulations; and Chinese citizens who are allowed to visit Kinmen and Matsu will be allowed to convert NT dollars into the mainland Chinese currency or vice versa at legal banking institutions on the two Taiwan-held islands, Hsieh said, adding that there will be a ceiling of 20,000 renminbi (NT$80,000) per transaction.

On whether and when the renminbi will be allowed to be listed on the foreign exchange lists of banks on Taiwan proper, Hsieh said that since Taiwan and China have not yet signed a bilateral currency clearance and liquidation agreement, the renminbi is not allowed to be exchanged, dealt or used as currency in Taiwan at the present time.

He urged Beijing authorities to return to the negotiating table with their Taiwan counterparts for talks on related matters so that the two currencies will be allowed to be converted freely to help facilitate people exchanges across the strait.

Meanwhile, Hsieh pointed out that the renminbi will be allowed to be exchanged in Kinmen and Matsu -- located only a stone's throw away from the Chinese mainland -- because there is a strong demand for the service there.

In addition, the impact on Taiwan's national security and its financial sovereignty of allowing the transactions on the two frontline islands will be lighter than of allowing such transactions on Taiwan proper, he added.

Responding to Hsieh's announcement, officials from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- said that allowing NTD-renminbi conversion in Kinmen and Matsu is a pragmatic policy designed to meet actual needs.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, said that since more and more people are traveling back and forth via the "mini three links" route -- between Kinmen and Matsu and the Fujian port cities of Xiamen and Mawei -- the total amount of spending by people using the route has risen too, making NTD-renminbi currency exchange services an "unavoidable necessity."
From Oct. 3, Fu said, people can convert NT dollars into reminbi and vice versa at the Kinmen or Matsu branches of the Bank of Taiwan and the Land Bank.
Local travel agencies and tourist hotels in Kinmen and Matsu will also be commissioned to offer currency exchange services, Fu added.

In a bid to help facilitate private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of Finance announced Feb. 28, 2004 that Taiwan citizens or foreign visitors entering Taiwan can bring a maximum of 6,000 renminbi into Taiwan per person.

DOC.HEADLINE: PURCHASING SUBS FROM E.U. 'NOT IMPOSSIBLE': ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy in Brussels said Wednesday at the Legislative Yuan that it is possible that Taiwan could turn to the European Union to try to purchase submarines for its military, but he added that "this possibility is very small."

Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the E.U. and Belgium, made the remarks during an interpellation session when opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chiang Hsiao-yen, a former foreign minister, asked him whether the island could turn to the E.U. to buy submarines as the arms procurement bill to buy a package of weaponry items, including submarines, from the United States remains stalled in the Legislative Yuan.

Claiming that he has never received instructions or anything else from Taipei to deal with matters related to the procurement of submarines since he became Taiwan's envoy in Brussels in July of last year, Chen, who returned to Taiwan recently for regular consultations, also said that Taiwan's military attache stationed in Brussels has never mentioned anything related to such a purchase. "Therefore, I actually don't know how to reply to the question, " he added.
However, he said that if the government were to ask him to collect any information regarding such a procurement, he would try to devise means to do so.

Also in response to the same question about whether Taiwan can purchase submarines from the E.U., the envoy said that "nothing is impossible in the world, " adding, however, that "he dares not say anything before doing something."

Taiwan has successfully purchased submarines from the Netherlands and Mirage jet fighters from France in the past despite the fact that many people had not believed that such purchases were possible, he further said.

Nevertheless, as the time and circumstances have changed, Chen said that it is worthwhile for Taiwan to consider whether the rise of China will make it more difficult for the island to purchase arms from E.U. countries in the future.

La Repubblica: Berlusconi: Government expenditure for next year around 25 billion euros.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi announced Tuesday that the government expenditure for the next year will be around 25 billion euros. He also expressed confident in the country's economic development in the coming year, assuring that it will be better than what is predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL DENIES TAIWAN WILL JOIN U.S.-JAPAN MILITARY EXERCISE

TEXT.P: Deputy Defense Minister Huo Shou-yeh said Wednesday it is unlikely that Taiwan will join the United States and Japan in a 100,000-troop military exercise next year, or a joint on-line military drill involving the three countries.

Huo made the remarks in reply to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen, who asked him to confirm a Mainland Affairs Council report that quoted Russian media as saying that the United States, Japan and Taiwan might stage a large-scale military exercise or a tripartite on-line drill next year.

The Q&A took place at a meeting of the National Defence Committee of the Legislative Yuan where Huo and other defence officials briefed committee members on the budget outlay for three major weapons the Ministry of Natioal Defense is proposing.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT'S PATHETIC ONLY U.S. DARES HELP TAIWAN GET NEW WEAPONS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Deputy Defence Minister Huo Shou-yeh told the legislature's National Defense Committee Wednesday that it is "quite pathetic" that only Washington "dares to help Taiwan acquire military weapons."

This is why Taiwan has no alternatives other than asking the U.S. Navy to approach European manufacturers to make submarines that are needed to boost Taiwan's defense capability, he noted. The U.S. has promised to sell Taiwan several submarines of a type not built in the United States for many years.

KMT lawmaker Ting Shou-chung alleged that "high-level" Americans might have been involved in the arms deal between the two governments and that Taiwan's government has been "dragged along by the arms dealers."

After hearing a navy headquarters' report on changes to the budget for purchasing three major weaponry items, including eight submarines that will cost NT$288 billion, ruling and opposition lawmakers agreed to propose setting up an appropriation committee at the legislature in anticipation of passing the arms budget bill.

However, the proposal, put forward by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Lee Wen-chung, the KMT's Liao Wan-ju, the Taiwan Solidarity Union's Ho Min-hao and others, was dropped after several committee members protested Huo's asking for leave from the afternoon meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-E.U. TIES PROGRESSING STEADILY: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Bilateral ties between Taiwan and the European Union have been progressing steadily over the past year, despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two sides, Taiwan's top envoy in Brussels claimed Wednesday.

Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the E.U. and Belgium, said that the E.U. headquarters have made announcements at least twice over the past year -- regarding the opening of direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese New Year holidays and Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

These announcements, according to Chen, underline the E.U.'s increasing concern over the peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and the E.U.'s ambition to elevate its influential clout in the international community. He made the remarks while making a report at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee on bilateral ties.

Chen said that boosting bilateral Taiwan-E.U. ties has been one of the priorities of Taiwan's diplomatic efforts, pointing out that in the E.U., there are 25 member countries, with a combined population of 450 million, contributing about one-fourth of the world's entire production value. These facts underline how important the E.U. is in terms of influence on international politics and global business and trade, he added.
Reviewing the development of Taiwan-E.U. ties over the past year, Chen claimed that these efforts have made headway at a steady pace.

In addition to growth in bilateral exchanges in trade, science-technology, education and culture, as well as tourism between the two sides, Taiwan's engagement with the European Commission, the executive body of the 25-member E.U., has also increased, Chen claimed.
The European Parliament has also resolved many times to reiterate its support for Taiwan and its concern over the cross-Taiwan Strait situation, Chen added.

Chen warned, meanwhile, that Taiwan should pay closer heed to talks between the E.U. and Beijing about establishing a comprehensive strategic partnership between them, a development that will unavoidably have an adverse impact on Taiwan.
He also made note of the fact that the E.U. is under intense pressure from some of its strongest members to lift its arms embargo on China, in place since the Tiananmen massacre of 1989.

Although the E.U. is unlikely to lift its arms embargo this year, Austria and Finland -- which will next year each hold for six months the presidency at the Europearn Council, the top decision-making body of the E.U. -- might turn the issue around under "certain external pressures," Chen warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMOOTH SAILING FOR TAIWAN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Basseterre, St. Kitts and Nevis, Sept. 27 (CAN) Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian described Taiwan Tuesday as a boat sailing on an even keel, as long as no-one rocks the boat.
Chen, who arrived in the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis earlier in the day, made the remarks during a cruise on the Caribbean with some of his entourage and reporters.
Assisted by Sheng Po-chi, the chief security officer at the Presidential Office who once commanded a submarine, Chen tried his hand at sailing a yacht for the first time.
Asked about his feelings at the wheel, the president said that "one needs to concentrate. We're on the same boat, as long as there is no rowdy noise and fighting, the boat will sail smoothly."

Su Tseng-chang, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who was accompanying the president on the cruise, also said that one should "ignore the rowdy noise of others. Just keep steadily forward single-mindedly and concentrate on taking care of the lives of all those aboard."
Asked about who is most suitable to take the helm of Taiwan in 2008, President Chen pointed out that that is up to the public.

St. Kitt and Nevis is the fourth country on Chen's five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean that has already taken him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua. Chen is the first ROC president to visit the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO MONITOR BIRD DROPPINGS TO KEEP AVIAN FLU AT BAY

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has stepped up efforts to keep avian flu at bay, including monitoring excrement dropped by migratory birds visiting Taiwan, COA Minister Lee Chin-lung said Wednesday.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Economics and Energy Committee, Lee noted that while Taiwan is free of bird flu, it is surrounded by nations affected by bird-flu.
Cases of avian flu in birds have been confirmed in Cambodia, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Laos, Pakistan, South Korea, Thailand and Vietnam.
The situation now is more severe, as flocks of migratory birds have begun to arrive in Taiwan to spend the winter, increasing the risk of a possible avian flu outbreak in Taiwan, Lee noted.
Fortunately, so far there is no evidence to suggest that the virus has been brought in by the feathered visitors, Lee added.

Lee made the remarks in response to an interpellation by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hung Yu-chin, who asked Lee to make sure the COA strengthens preventive measures with the arrival of the high-risk bird flu season. "If this epidemic disease, which can be spread from birds to humans, attacks Taiwan, it will be a calamity, at least for the country's poultry industry," Hung said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA STOPPING CONTAMINATED DUCK EGGS FROM ENTERING MARKET

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) took emergency measures Wednesday to stop allegedly contaminated duck eggs produced at a central Taiwan farm from entering the market.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung made the statement at the Legislative Yuan amid reports that duck eggs from a farm in Shenkang town, Changhua County were found to contain unsafe levels of dioxin, a known carcinogen, the second such incident in three months.
In June, duck eggs produced in Hsienhsi town, also in Changhua County, were found to have been contaminated by allegedly unsafe levels of dioxin.

The county's environmental bureau tested duck eggs from Shenkang farm Aug. 18 and Aug. 24 and found that of the five samples, two had toxicity of 7.34 pg TEQ/g fat and 7.83 pg TEQ/g fat, respectively, far exceeding the European Union's food safety limit of 3pg TEQ/g fat.
A picogram (pg) is one trillionth of a gram. One pg of the toxicity equivalent per gram of fat is expressed as 1 pg TEQ/g fat.
Lee said the authorities were holding all the ducks and 6,000 kg of duck eggs pending further checkups. If dioxin levels exceed safety limits, the birds and the eggs will be destroyed, he added.

As Environmental Protection Minister Chang Kuo-lung has excluded air and soil as contamination sources, the COA will check the feed used by the owner of the farm, but the results are not expected to come out until December.

Initial tests show that the feed used by the farmer, identified as Chang Chin-tze, contains two ingredients with dioxin levels of 2.31 pg TEQ/g fat and 0.773 pg TEQ/g fat, also surpassing EU's safety limit of 0.75 pg TEQ/g fat.
Chang claimed to have been using the same duck feed for six years.
In Kaohisung, officials visited the feed manufacturer, Mao Sheng Feed Company, and took two samples to be analyzed by National Cheng Kung University's Institute of Environmental Engineering.

The Environmental Protection Administration was informed by the county bureau Sept. 21 of its tests, but the EPA did not notify the COA until Sept. 27, triggering allegations that the delay has caused a lot of contaminated eggs to enter the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY VOWS TO CONTINUE REFORMS AT 19TH FOUNDING ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed to work toward its goals of reform as it celebrated its 19th founding anniversary Wednesday.
Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, made the remarks in the wake of a poll showing that the approval rating for the ruling party has fallen to a dismal low.

The party had not planned special celebrations Wednesday as President Chen Shui-bian is on a five-nation diplomatic tour of Central American and Caribbean allies and Su Tseng-chang, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, is accompanying him.

However, the party staged a celebration in the central city of Taichung Sept. 16, during which President Chen said that "reform is the road we must take. We must insist on continued reform of our political, economic and social systems to keep our vitality and competitiveness. Otherwise, we'll be ousted from office."
Cheng, faced with recent criticism from the public, said the party will take stock of all criticism and review all suggestions.

He was referring to a poll published by the China Times newspaper Wednesday that shows the DPP's approval rating as having fallen to a new low, while several social movement activists and academics also criticized the party for deviating from its ideals.

"The DPP is a party of reforms, and many of our ideals have been accomplished. Other goals of reform have yet to be achieved because the timing, conditions and political environment are not yet ripe, " Cheng claimed.
He said the DPP will not pass the buck but will reflect upon itself in sincerity and continue to work toward its reform goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPEFULS FOR 2008 ELECTION NEED TO WORK HARDER: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Basseterre, St. Kitts, Sept. 27 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said here Tuesday that the 2008 presidential hopefuls of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are not working hard enough and must make more effort if they want any chance of winning the election.

Speaking to Taiwanese reporters covering his 12-day state visit to five nations in Central America and the Caribbean, Chen said he is confident of the DPP's performance in the 2008 presidential election, as well as the December elections of mayors and county magistrates.
However, he admitted that the situation is "fluid" with regard to which political party might win the election because the event is still two-and-a-half years away.

Asked how the DPP will cope if the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presents party chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng as its presidential and vice presidential candidates, Chen said this is unlikely although he did not rule out such a possibility.

He claimed that the existing rivalry between Wang and Ma is not merely something between themselves, but also involves former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong and former President Lee Teng-hui.
He said a Ma-Wang ticket for the KMT in the presidential election would not be easy to achieve because there are "too many variables."
Asked to comment on a report that Soong might seriously consider running for Taipei mayor in 2006, Chen said the PFP is "testing the water."
The president, accompanied by an entourage of officials and business leaders, arrived in the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis Tuesday after visiting Guatemala, the Dominican Republic and Nicaragua.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for October slid two points to close at 5,933, with 25,048 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for November were unchanged to end at 5,930, with 215 contracts traded, while December futures grew 20 points to finish at 5,950, with 14 contracts traded. March futures moved up five points to close at 5,940, with eight contracts traded, while June futures rose six points to close at 5,940, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,935 for October, 5,930 for November, 5,930 for December, 5,935 for March and 5,934 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
October TE futures moved up 0.35 points to close at 247.6, with 4,041 contracts traded, while November TE futures gained 1.65 points to finish at 248.55, with 20 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

October TF futures moved up five points to finish at 887.4, with 2,206 contracts changing hands, while November TF futures gained five points to end at 887.2, with 27 contracts traded. December TF futures rose 3.6 points to close at 886.2, with two contract transactions, while March TF futures grew 3.2 points to finish at 886, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION HEADS KNOW ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE HAS TO PASS: PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Basseterre, St. Kitts, Sept. 27 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that a long-stalled arms procurement package has to be passed in the end, and opposition leaders and the United States know this "clearly."

President Chen made the remarks in Basseterre, St. Kitts and Nevis, on the fourth stop of his five-nation diplomatic tour of Central America and the Caribbean, when he spoke to a group of Taiwan journalists covering his visit.

He was referring to the three big-ticket items in the arms procurement package -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- which has been stalled for more than one year at the legislature.

The president's words came after the "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) used their majority to block the government's arms purchase bill from being put on the legislative agenda for the 30th time earlier in the day.

The president said that former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, PFP Chairman James Soong, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou all know "clearly that the arms procurement package has to pass, " and that the U.S. also knows clearly the whole story of the long-stalled package.
The president said that during his transit stop in Miami, Florida en route to Guatemala to embark on his diplomatic tour, he talked with an influential U.S. congressional leader by phone.

"The congressional leader told me that he will meet with U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld in the hope that the latter will send a letter to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to seek Ma's support for the arms procurement package," Chen said.

The president said that he thinks the U.S. congressional leader should also write to PFP Chairman James Soong because Soong has played a key role in blocking the package from being placed onto the legislative agenda for discussion.
Chen also said that his transit in Miami on Sept. 20 was the result of discussions with the United States.

He said that the U.S. has its own "strategic considerations." Chinese President Hu Jintao visited the U.S. before Chen made his transit stop and both were treated as Asian leaders, the president said, adding that Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi would probably be the next to arrive in the States.

He also said that his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, wrote him a letter about Lee's upcoming visit to the United States, but the president stressed that Lee will not be representing the government or Chen.
Reports have said that Lee will visit the U.S. next month. He will probably meet with Alaska Governor Frank H. Murkowski in Anchorage before flying on to New York, Washington, D.C. and Los Angeles.
Lee will give a speech at the National Press Club (NPC) based in Washington, D.C. on Oct. 20. He will also give a brief speech over a luncheon on Capitol Hill, reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 13.67 points to close at 5,931.38.
The bourse opened at 5,943.12 and fluctuated between 5,961.21 and 5,912.88 during trading. A total of 2.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.76 billion (US$2.02 billion).

TEXT.P: The one millionth Japanese tourist of this year is expected to enter Taiwan in late October or early November, the Tourism Bureau said Wednesday.
Statistics showed that Japanese tourists have made 718,000 visits to Taiwan as of the end of August, and that the arrivals have grown rapidly in the latter half of the year.

Tourism operators attributed the increased arrivals of Japanese to a number of factors, including the anti-Japanese activities in China over allegations of Japanese tampering of history in textbook on World War II atrocities early this year as well as Japan's territorial disputes with South Korea, which used to be a hot destination for Japanese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF GRAND JUSTICES FINDS ID FINGERPRINTING UNCONSTITUTIONAL

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices ruled Wednesday that the Ministry of Interior's plan to make fingerprinting mandatory for those applying for new ID cards is unconstitutional.

The Grand Justices said government agencies must have sound institutional and procedural measures to protect the fingerprints that would be gathered to meet the constitutional requirement for protecting people's information and privacy rights.

They said the right to privacy, although not listed in the Constitution, is a basic human right that is protected under Article 22 of the Constitution, which aims to safeguard private life from being intruded on and to ensure a citizen's autonomy over private data.

They stressed that in the event of a national necessity to collect and file people's fingerprints, a law must be legislated in advance to define the use of the fingerprints and to prohibit their use outside of the law.
Only two Grand Justices on the 15-member council put forward dissenting views on the controversy over suspected infringement of the measure on human rights and privacy.

The measure, adopted according to the household registration law and set to go into effect on July 1, was ordered suspended on June 10 after Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator William C.T. Lai and 84 others challenged its constitutionality by requesting a constitutional interpretation of the law.
Minister of the Interior Su Chia-chuan said his ministry will respect the ruling and drop the fingerprinting requirement.
The ministry will go ahead with its plan to change ID cards starting on Dec. 21.
The Grand Justices' decision was hailed by many groups and individuals, including the DPP legislative caucus and Vice President Annette Lu, who has voiced opposition to the measure from the start.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY DEFENDS BUDGET FOR SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense defended its budget for eight submarines in a report to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday, calling the price of NT$288 billion (US$8.65 billion) reasonable.

The ministry said in the report that the diesel-electric submarines offered by the U.S. to Taiwan are out of production in the United States. Therefore, to build the submarines, the report said, the U.S. has to set up a production line exclusively for them, in addition to getting the approval of its origin designers for export.
Taking into account of these factors, the defense ministry said, the U.S. estimates the price of the submarines at US$657 million, or NT$21.12 billion apiece.
If the cost of ammunition and training of crews are included, the price will increase to NT$288.03 billion and that is the price asked by the ministry in a special budget for the submarines.

The report disputes allegations that the price asked by the U.S. for the submarines is too high, saying that the price of the same class of submarines may vary with its building time, builders and even its buyers.

Citing a story published by Jane's Defense Weekly, the report said, the French sold its Scorpion-class submarines to Malaysia, India and Chile separately for prices ranging from US$580 million apiece to US$250 million apiece.

Although the U.S. has promised to sell eight submarines to Taiwan, the report said, it won't start the construction of them before Taiwan's legislature approves the budget for the deal, adding that the defense ministry will take pains to ensure that the price for the deal is not inflated if the legislature passes the budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITS TO THAILAND 'UNRELATED TO THAI LABORERS': PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Sept. 28 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh denied Wednesday that his visits to Thailand during his term as Kaohsiung mayor were related to the hiring of Thai laborers for the Kaohsiung rapid transit project.

In response to an allegation made at the Executive Yuan by Huang Chao-shun, a legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , Hsieh said during a tour of Taitung that Huang should present evidence to prove her allegations.
Hsieh did not say how many times he had visited Thailand while he was Kaohsiung mayor, but an aide admitted that Hsieh went there four times.

According to the aide, Hsieh used his first visit to gather information about the mass rapid transit system in Bangkok. During the second visit, he attended the inauguration of the Bangkok chapter of the Association of Friends of President Chen Shui-bian. The third visit was for the inauguration of the Association of Friends of Frank Hsieh in Thailand, and the fourth was to discuss an exchange program to acquire elephants from Thailand.

However, during an interpellation in the legislature, Huang said that Hsieh visited Thailand six times, and that during each visit he was accompanied by two foreign labor brokers from Taiwan who served as advisers to the Kaohsiung City Government.

The KMT legislator produced newspaper clippings and business cards gathered from Bangkok to show that one of the two brokers, Huang Su-cheng, is currently a member of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, and that her residence in Thailand not only serves as the Democratic Progressive Party's office in Southeast Asia, but is also the address of the Association of Friends of Frank Hsieh.

When the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) was preparing to hire workers for the project, its board of directors promised to adhere to the policy set by the Kaohsiung City Government that priority should given to domestic workers. However, critics say the KRTC ignored the policy by setting unreasonable hurdles to keep domestic workers away while hiring more than 17,000 Thai laborers through a broker.

The issue of who gave the order to favor the Thai laborers has been pursued heatedly by legislators of the opposition parties, as well as by the news media. Public prosecutors in Kaohsiung are also investigating accusations that hundreds of millions of new Taiwan dollars earmarked for wages to be paid to the Thai laborers have disappeared into mysterious accounts.

The alleged corruption was brought to light when Thai workers rioted in their living quarters in Kaohsiung County on Aug. 22 to protest the inhumane treatment by their employers and the manpower management company in charge of them.
