DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIFTH MOST COMPETITIVE ECONOMY IN THE WORLD: WEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked fifth in the world and first in Asia in terms of competitiveness, according the 2005 competitiveness rankings released by the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Geneva Wednesday.

Thomas Yeh, vice minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Taiwan's global ranking is one position lower than that of last year because of its not too good performance in macroeconomics environment, in which the country's rank has been downgraded from ninth place in 2004 to 17th place this year according to the assessment of the WEF.

Yeh attributed the downgrading to surging international oil prices and the domestic political struggles among different political parties that have dimmed the country's economic prospects and has fueled inflation concerns.
However, Yeh said, the WEF pointed out that Taiwan's performance in technological innovation is excellent, not least in mobile phones, personal computers and the use of advanced Web technologies.
According to the WEF report, Finland remains the most competitive economy in the world for the third consecutive year, followed by the United States, Sweden, Denmark, Taiwan and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Sept. 29, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Horatio Nelson, the British naval commander who became a national hero despite the scandal of his love affair with Emma, Lady Hamilton, is born. He won victories against the French in the Battle of the Nile and at Trafalgar.
1902: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading proponent of naturalism in fiction, dies at the age of 62, accidentally asphyxiated by charcoal fumes in Paris. His works include "Les Rougon-Maequart," a series of 20 novels, and "J'Accuse," a defense of Alfred Dreyfus.
1906: American troops return to Cuba after opposition to President Tomas Estrada Palma's government developed into open rebellion. A civil-military government, headed by Charles E. Maggon of the United States, ruled Cuba from 1906 to 1909.
1929: Yoshikazu Tanaka, Japanese politician and former prime minister, dies of a heart attack at the age of 65.
1938: The Munich Conference begins, attended by Neville Chamberlain, Edouard Daladier, Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini.
1941: A special Nazi death squad murders some 35,000 Russian Jews, including men, women and children, in Kiev, machine-gunning them systematically in Babi Yar ravine.
1944: The Chinese-American-British phase of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference begins.
1950: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur hands Seoul over to South Korean President Syngman Rhee.
1960: Russian leader Nikita Khrushchev heckles and thumps his desk during British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's speech to the U.N. General Assembly in New York.
1966: The Republic of China chapter of the International Chamber of Commerce is inaugurated in Taipei.
1970: Egypt's Vice President Anwar Sadat is sworn is as acting president after the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser the previous day.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Japan after Tokyo establishes diplomatic ties with Beijing.
1973: The ninth World Chinese Traders' Conference opens in Taipei, with more than 700 delegates from 55 countries and territories taking part.
1973: Vice Adm. George P. Steele, commander of the U.S. Seventh Fleet, arrives in Taiwan aboard his command ship USS Oklahoma for a four-day visit.
1975: A 10-member team leaves for the United States to take part in the Third International Karate Championship Tournament.
1975: A 30-member trade mission headed by Wong Yi-ting, director of the Board of Foreign Trade, leaves for South Africa.
1976: A broke Britain asks the International Monetary Fund for a US$3.9 billion loan, the maximum limit of its entitlement. Britain needs the money to prop up the ailing pound.
1981: A military plane crashes in Tehran, Iran, killing a group of military officers on board, including the country's defense minister.
1985: Republic of China decathletes Ku Chin-shui and Li Fu-en win a gold and a silver medal, respectively, at the Sixth Asian Track and Field Championships in Jakarta, Indonesia.
1986: The second round of the ROC-U.S. trade talks begins in Washington, D.C.
1988: The space shuttle Discovery is launched, marked the first space shuttle launch since the explosion of the Challenger shortly after takeoff in January 1986.
1990: U.S. Secretary of State James Baker meets Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach, the highest-level contact between the two countries since the Vietnam War.
1992: The ROC is granted observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), forerunner to the World Trade Organization. GATT also resolves to accept the ROC's application for entry into GATT under the designation "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen, and Matsu."
1999: The ROC and the Dominican Republic sign a joint communique in Taipei, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
2000: The Kuomintang Taiwan Provincial Committee passes into the pages of history after 60 years in existence.
2001: An opinion poll shows the majority of Taiwan's manufacturers with operations in mainland China support the "active opening, effective management" policy presented by President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "However excellent a system of moral truths appealing to supernatural authority may be, it is not verifiable by experience; what is not verifiable by experience cannot command credence; and what cannot command credence, the people will never obey."

DOC.HEADLINE: PATRIOT III PURCHASE SHOULDN'T BE AFFECTED BY REFERENDUM: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The purchase of Patriot III anti-missile batteries was approved in 1998 during President Lee Teng-hui's term of office and therefore should not be affected by the 2004 referendum, Deputy Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien said Thursday.

Tsai made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan National Defense Committee meeting when he reported his ministry's response to the controversy triggered by the defeat of the 2004 referendum initiated by the Chen Shui-bian government.

Tsai said the ministry was simply "continuing" a government policy by requesting a budget for purchasing Patriot III missiles, which were not listed in the referendum question. What was listed instead was the term "increasing anti-missile devices," he noted.

He acknowledged that the referendum was vetoed because less than 50 percent of eligible voters cast their ballots. Still, he pointed out, of those who voted, 7.4 million agreed with the government's proposal to increase anti-missile equipment for the armed forces, which he said makes it clear where mainstream public opinion stands with regard to the issue.
Moreover, Tsai said, the referendum law does not specify that the government cannot ask for legislative support for a bill or a budget to implement a project that has been vetoed in a referendum.

Therefore, he said he would like to ask the legislature to consider public opinion as well as the urgent need to boost the nation's defense capability, and support the government's request for buying Patriot III batteries.

The NT$140 billion budget for purchasing Patriot III anti-missile batteries has been moved to the ministry's regular annual budget from a special budget for three major weaponry items that include submarines and anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC OFFICIAL BANNED FROM LEAVING COUNTRY: PROSECUTOR GENERAL

TEXT.P: Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao said Thursday that Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) counselor Lee Chin-cheng, who has been under investigation for alleged involvement in an insider-trading scandal, has been banned from leaving the country before the case is closed.

Wu made the remarks following media reports that the former director of the FSC's Examination Bureau has been issued an immigration visa by the American Institute in Taiwan. Lee was transferred to serve as an FSC counselor after the alleged insider-trading scandal surfaced in July.

In reply to Legislator Chiu Yi's question during a Legislative Yuan Judicial Affairs Committee meeting, Wu said that Lee's case is being probed by the Anti-Corruption Center of the Taiwan High Prosecutor's Office and that Lee has since July been banned from leaving the country.
Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said the prosecutors will make their best judgment with regards to the case, adding that his ministry should refrain from making any comment.

FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng, who received a phone call from Lee Thursday morning, told another committee meeting at the legislature that Lee was applying for a U.S. visa because he needs to take care of his two daughters who are studying there.
Kong said that Lee did not tell him that he plans to move to the United States for good. "As far as I understand, Lee has been banned from leaving Taiwan," he added.
Lee was allegedly involved in a high-profile insider stock trading case known as the "Vultures" scandal.
Taiwan High Court prosecutors in July offended Kong by questioning Lee on suspicions that he tipped off a group that made large profits via insider trading.
Premier Frank Hsieh later had to come forward to quell a war of words between the prosecutors and FSC.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN ST. VINCENT FOR STATE VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Kingstown, Sept. 28 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian arrived in the St. Vincent and the Grenadines capital of Kingstown Wednesday for an official visit, making him the first ever serving Republic of China head of state to set foot in the East Caribbean nation.

Chen was accorded a red-carpet welcome complete with a 21-gun solute and full military honors. Local schoolchildren sang a popular Taiwanese folk song titled "Aspiring for Spring Wind" at the welcoming ceremony.
Thousands of St. Vincent citizens, waving ROC and St. Vincent national flags, turned out to greet Chen.
The Caribbean nation took half a day off to welcome Chen's arrival.

St. Vincent and the Grenadines is the final leg of Chen's current five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean. His tour has already taken him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DEBATE VICE DEFENCE CHIEF'S REFERENDUM LOGIC

TEXT.P: Both ruling and opposition lawmakers challenged Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien's argument Thursday that even though the 2004 arms purchase referendum did not receive enough voter participation to be considered valid, the government can still propose a budget for buying anti-missile equipment.

In a report to the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, Tsai said that because in the referendum people were asked to vote on "increasing anti-missile devices, " which is unrelated to a government policy adopted in 1998 to purchase Patriot III anti-missile batteries, the government would be merely "continuing" that policy by requesting a NT$140 billion budget for buying the anti-missile batteries.

The relevant question from the referendum was: "The people of Taiwan demand that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved through peaceful means. Should mainland China refuse to withdraw the missiles it has targeted at Taiwan and openly renounce the use of force against us, would you agree that the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons to strengthen Taiwan's self-defense capabilities?"

In response to opposition lawmakers' charge that he was using "twisted logic, " Tsai said an invalid referendum does not mean the government henceforth cannot push for a budget to acquire Patriot III missiles, and if that can be described as "twisted logic, " then he said he was "twisting it correctly."

People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chao Liang-yen pointed out that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has bound its own hands and feet, like a silkworm restraining itself in its own cocoon, by initiating a referendum that was invalidated.
Now, she said, the vice minister is demonstrating "a lawyer's traits" by "twisting the logic, " and when that isn't successful, he simply goes on to "play the rogue" with an eye-opening performance.

Even Tsai's fellow DPP lawmaker, Lee Wen-chung, joined the ranks of oppositionists, questioning him why in the first place should the government push for a referendum, which was supposed to make up for the shortfalls of representative politics, if in any way the government was to push a policy that would be invalidated in a referendum?
Lee suggested that if the ruling and opposition parties remain bogged down on the issue, they could request that the Council of Grand Justices give a legal solution.

Tsai told a DPP caucus meeting that if the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the PFP removed the Patriot III budget from the overall budget bill before putting it on the legislative agenda, the Ministry of National Defense will likely request a constitutional interpretation.

DDP Legislator Tang Huo-sheng said the arms purchase issue is now beyond the legislature's ability to solve. He suggested that DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang invite the leaders of all political parties for a meeting to break the impasse.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTENTIAL VISIT BY CHINESE OFFICIALS WOULD FOLLOW EXISTING LAW: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will neither waive legal requirements nor impose special barriers in dealing with applications by Chinese officials to visit Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks while delivering a report on the MAC's operations and progress in planning for direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait and a full-fledged opening of the door for Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.
After his report, opposition lawmakers asked Wu about the MAC's stance on two senior Chinese officials' possible visits to Taiwan.

According to media reports, Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Beijing-based Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and Chen Yulin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, may travel to Taiwan to attend an economic forum to be co-sponsored by Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China in Taipei in mid-December.
KMT Legislator Lee Ching-hua asked Wu, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner, whether the government would block the two Chinese officials from entering Taiwan to attend the forum.

"After China dared to allow Li Ao, an independent Taiwan legislator who is widely seen as a political gadfly, to visit Beijing and Shanghai, will we still hesitate to open our door to senior Chinese officials?" Lee asked.
To the best of his understanding, Wu said a large number of Chinese officials have already been to Taiwan.
Regarding Chinese officials' visit, Wu said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should communicate and consult first to ensure their travel safety in Taiwan.

"Otherwise, there might be risks. Early this month, Zhu Xiangdong, a deputy director of China's National Bureau of Statistics, died in Taipei while taking a hot spring bath. Zhu was here at the invitation of a local private university for academic exchanges without prior consultations with our relevant authorities," Wu said.

Noting that the government has yet to formulate a policy on the visit by Chinese officials of the level or stature of Jia and Chen, Wu said at present he could not answer such a hypothetical issue as to whether Jia and Chen would be granted visas to visit Taiwan.

Pressed by several other KMT and People First Party lawmakers, Wu said he himself would not oppose opening the door to Jia and Chen if their visits would not break any of Taiwan's existing laws and regulations governing cross-strait engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL TALKS A PREREQUISITE FOR NTD-RMB CONVERSION IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Making the Chinese renminbi convertible in Taiwan proper would first require official cross-strait talks, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday.
Premier Frank Hsieh announced the day before that new Taiwan dollar-renminbi conversion would be allowed on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu from Oct. 3 on a trial basis.

A group of opposition legislators asked Wu during a Legislative Yuan Home and Nations Committee meeting whether and when the renminbi will be allowed to be posted on the foreign exchange lists of banks on Taiwan proper.

Wu said that since Taiwan and China have not yet signed a bilateral currency clearance and liquidation agreement, the renminbi is not allowed to be exchanged, dealt or used as currency in Taiwan at the present time.

Opening of such a program that would have a far-reaching impact on Taiwan's national security and its financial sovereignty should not be conducted without adequate coping measures, Wu said, adding that currently Taiwan has not set out any timetable for this.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Christina Liu suggested that the MAC -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- work to have an article of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area amended so that a stipulation about "the signing of a cross-strait bilateral currency clearance and liquidation agreement" can be changed into "the building of a cross-strait bilateral currency clearance and liquidation mechanism."
Wu said that he would not mind if this proposal were to be passed by the Legislative Yuan if all legislators from the ruling and opposition parties agreed.
Even if this becomes law, Wu said, it would only be a law and the final implementation of the money exchange program in Taiwan would require cross-strait negotiations by officials from both sides.

Noting that Taiwan's Central Bank of China suggested long ago that the "agreement" wording be changed into "mechanism" to facilitate the implementation and Beijing has also expressed its consent, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lee Jih-chu said that the whole issue is now "stuck" with the word "agreement, " which has been insisted upon by the MAC.
Lee called for the MAC not to make itself "the greatest barrier" to the development of cross-strait economic and trade exchanges.

Rebuffing Lee's accusation, Wu said that financial and monetary liberalization toward China should be carried out gradually and in a safe manner. Taiwan has made enough positive movements over the past couple of years to help facilitate cross-strait exchanges and people in Taiwan should bear in mind what kind of "external situation" Taiwan is facing, particularly after Beijing passed its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, Wu added.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung lashed out at Beijing for continuously refusing to engage in talks with Taiwan's administration on the bilateral currency clearance and liquidation agreement issue.
Hsu said that it would be unlawful if the administration opens the renminbi to be converted in Taiwan before any relevant law is legislated.
According to Premier Hsieh, the NTD-RMB conversion program will be opened in Kinmen and Matsu conditionally.

Only local residents of Kinmen and Matsu; Taiwan residents who can travel between the outlying islands and China's Fujian province under the "mini three links" regulations; and Chinese citizens who are allowed to visit Kinmen and Matsu will be allowed to convert NT dollars into the mainland Chinese currency or vice versa at legal banking institutions on the two Taiwan-held islands, Hsieh said, adding that there will be a ceiling of 20,000 renminbi (NT$80,000) per transaction.

Hsieh stressed that the renminbi will be allowed to be exchanged in Kinmen and Matsu -- located only a stone's throw away from the Chinese mainland -- because there is a strong demand for the service there.

In addition, he said, the impact on Taiwan's national security and its financial sovereignty of allowing the transactions on the two frontline islands will be less than allowing such transactions on Taiwan proper.

In a bid to help facilitate private exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of Finance announced Feb. 28, 2004 that Taiwan citizens or foreign visitors entering Taiwan can bring a maximum of 6,000 renminbi into Taiwan per person.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WANTS TO HELP CONVICTED FORMER LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER IF HE RETURNS

TEXT.P: If convicted former legislative speaker Liu Sung-fan decides to return to Taiwan and accept his fate, the opposition People First Party (PFP) will try to get him released from jail on bail for medical treatment, a PFP whip said Thursday.

Huang Yi-chiao, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, made the remarks when asked to comment on news reports that Liu, who is in poor health and tired of hiding in the United States, wants to come back to Taiwan.

Liu, 74, served as president of the Legislative Yuan from 1992 to 1999 while the Kuomintang (KMT) was in power, but he joined the PFP in January 2000 and became one of its legislators-at-large after he was expelled from the KMT for supporting PFP Chairman James Soong during Soong's campaign for president.

Liu was sentenced to four years in jail and given a NT$30 million fine in September 2004 by the Taiwan High Court's Taichung Branch for corruption. The court found that, as chairman of the board at the Taichung Business Bank, Liu received NT$150 million in kickbacks from Tseng Cheng-jen, president of the Kuangsan Enterprise Group in return for granting illegal loans worth NT$1.5 billion to the group.

At the time of the sentence, Liu was attending the Republican Party convention in New York. He has remained in the United States ever since. The warrant issued for his arrest will be valid for 15 years.

Also commenting on the report about Liu's intention of coming back, Lai Ching-te, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, said Liu should not try to negotiate the terms under which he will do his time, acting as if he still has privilege.

He said that Liu should come back to Taiwan to serve his sentence, and that if he is found to have a health problem while he is in jail, the legal system may grant him bail for medical treatment based on humanitarian considerations.
Answering questions in the legislature, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin also said that Liu must be jailed first before he can apply for bail, which would be based on his need for medical treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE FLU VACCINES FOR ELDERLY TAIPEI CITIZENS FROM OCT. 3

TEXT.P: Citizens of Taipei City aged 65 or over will from Oct. 3 be able to get free flu vaccination, the Department of Health of the Taipei city government announced Thursday.

A spokesman for the department reminded elderly citizens that it takes two weeks for the vaccine to develop effective protection and that they should be well-prepared for the flu season, which usually begins in the second half of November and can persist through Christmas until February or March the following year.
The spokesman said that people 65 or older are given priority in getting free vaccine because they are a high risk group.
He added that the city government has prepared 170,000 doses of vaccine this year, based on the flu vaccination rate of 58 percent for the 65-and-over age group last year.
However, those who are allergic to egg protein or other ingredients in the vaccine should avoid getting the shot, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS ST. VINCENT'S ACHIEVEMENTS IN CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM
DOC.DATELINE: Kingstown, Sept. 28 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he looks forward to learning from St. Vincent and the Grenadines' experience in constitutional re-engineering during his current visit to the East Caribbean nation.
Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at a dinner party hosted by St. Vincent and the Grenadines Governor-General Frederick Ballantyne in his honor.

Noting that nationwide constitutional reform consultations in St. Vincent and the Grenadines in 2003 marked one of the most memorable episodes in the democratic development of British Commonwealth states in the Caribbean, Chen said Taiwan can learn from its Caribbean ally in planning its own second phase of constitutional reforms aimed at consolidating its young democracy.

Chen said the Presidential Office set up a constitutional reform consultative office Aug. 1 to push for extensive discussion on relevant topics and pool the wisdom of the private and public sectors with the ultimate goal of formulating a "timely, fitting and viable" constitution before his term ends in May 2008.

Heading an entourage of government officials and business leaders, Chen arrived in the St. Vincent and the Grenadines capital of Kingstown earlier in the day for an official visit, making him the first serving Republic of China head of state to set foot in the East Caribbean nation.

He was accorded a red-carpet welcome complete with a 21-gun salute and full military honors. Local school children sang a popular Taiwanese folk song titled "Aspiring for Spring Wind" at the welcoming ceremony.
Thousands of St. Vincent citizens, waving ROC and St. Vincent national flags, turned out to greet Chen and the nation took a half-day off to welcome him.

Chen met with the ROC embassy staff, members of an ROC technical mission, volunteers and alternative service diplomatic staffers at his hotel shortly after his arrival to ask about their work and boost their morale.

St. Vincent and the Grenadines is the final leg of Chen's five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean that has already taken him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis. He will make a brief transit stop in San Francisco on his way home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO PROTECT, DEFEND, PROMOTE CHILDREN'S RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Authorities from the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior urged the public Thursday to seek to protect, defend and promote the "10 rights" and welfare of all children in Taiwan.
Huang Pi-hsia, director of the Children's Bureau, announced that the last quarter of this year has been designated "children's rights season" in the country.

Defining the "10 rights" of children, Huang said children should have the right to life, to welfare and protection, to status, to family and growth, to equality, to social participation and representation, to play, to health, to education and to privacy.

They should also be entitled to the same basic human rights as the rest of society, Huang said, adding that parents should not treat their children as "property" to which they have the right to "appropriate" or "handle."
Instead, Huang said, children are the common assets of the country.

During the "children's rights season, " 26 public and private organizations will jointly sponsor 95 rounds of activities nationwide to educate adults and children alike as to the rights and welfare of children, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: No agreement on government budget bill among ruling coalition members.
Ruling coalition parties did not reach an agreement on the government budget bill for the next year after a 14-hour marathon meeting Wednesday. Issues on family aids and fiscal parole remain deadlocked. The Cabinet is to discuss the draft bill Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: For G.O.P., DeLay Indictment Adds to a Sea of Troubles
The indictment of Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader, on Wednesday was the latest in a series of scandals and setbacks that have buffeted Republican leaders in Congress and the Bush administration. The string of ethical issues so close together - including the indictment and continuing investigation of the Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff, who was close to Mr. DeLay, and the arrest of David H. Safavian, a former White House budget official who was charged with lying to investigators and obstructing a federal inquiry involving Mr. Abramoff - is a source of anxiety in Republican circles.
Wall Street Journal: Capitol Losses, House Leader Leader DeLay Indicted, Adding to Republican Woes
U.S. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay was indicted by a Texas grand jury for campaign- finance violations, shaking the capital's Republican leadership and aggravating fissures within the party that could unsettle its decade- long dominance of Congress. DeLay was charged with one count of criminal conspiracy for his party in an alleged scheme to funnel illegal corporate campaign contributions to Texas Republicans running for the state Legislature in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FAMILY'S ASSETS ALREADY PUT INTO TRUST: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The first family's assets have all been put into a blind trust and reported to the Control Yuan in line with the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, the Presidential Office said Thursday in a press release.

The Presidential Office issued the statement after a local media report quoted opposition People First Party Legislator Sun Ta-chien as alleging that first lady Wu Shu-jen did not honestly report her jewelry to the Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body.
The statement urged local media to refrain from giving prominent coverage to unfounded and unverified speculation.

Under Article 4 of the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, public functionaries, including the president and vice president, and the presidents and vice presidents of the five yuans, as well as political appointees and elected officials and representatives, must submit assets disclosure reports to the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY DENIES FLOOD-PREVENTION BUDGET IS PORK BARREL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long denied Thursday that an NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) special budget the government seeks for an eight-year flood-control program in a draft bill is pork barrelling intended to boost the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's election chances.

Testifying at a meeting held by the Economics and Energy Committee of the Legislative Yuan to screen the bill, Chen said the flood-control project is urgent and needs continuous funding if the target is to be achieved.

However, opposition legislators claimed that the planned budget is controversial because 74 percent of the funding would be spent in counties and cities under the ruling party's control, whereas only 26 percent would be earmarked for administrative areas under opposition control.
Debate on the bill is expected to be very heated, as more than 100 legislators have asked to present their views.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party is strongly opposed to the bill because they think the plan presented by the ruling party for such a huge budget is "too sketchy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DELEGATION VISITS MOSCOW
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A 20-member trade delegation headed by Chang Chun-hsiung, president of the Taiwan-Russia Association and a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, is currently on a trade promotion visit to Moscow.

During its visit, the delegation will attend the third Taiwan-Russian Cooperation Forum to discuss measures to promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation in energy resources research, trade, economic development and financial reform.
At the end of the forum, Taiwan and Russian companies will sign trade deals worth an estimated US$300 million.

Members of the delegation include Hsu Chih-jen, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, Taiwan Fertilizer Co. President Huang Ching-yen, Chinese Petroleum Corp. President Chen Pao-lang, Bank of Overseas Chinese Chairman Chang Sung-erh and Ho Lung-kuang, a Bank of Taiwan manager.

Speaking at a welcoming ceremony hosted by Chen Rong-jeh, Taiwan's top representative in Russia, Chang Chung-hsiung said the Russian representative office in Taipei presented a Russian national emblem to the Taiwan-Russia Association recently in recognition of the organization's efforts to promote cooperation between the two countries over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:
DeLay's Indictment Adds To Mounting GOP Woes; Conspiracy charges in Texas add to the gathering headwind that now threatens the Republicans as they look toward the 2006 elections.
Bad news often comes in bunches, but for a Republican Party that not long ago looked ahead to an unfettered period of growth and expansion, yesterday' s indictment of House Majority Leader Tom DeLay (R-Tex.) represented one of the most significant blows the party has suffered in a year replete with problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FINGERPRINTING ALL CHINESE' PROGRAM IN THE WORKS: MAC

TEXT.P: All Chinese citizens entering Taiwan, regardless of their status or purpose of visit, will be fingerprinted, Taiwan's top official in charge of China policy said Thursday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Chinese tourists and Chinese crew working aboard Taiwan fishing boats will also be fingerprinted upon entry into Republic of China territory starting in the near future.

Chinese citizens who come to Taiwan for settlement or reunion with family members have already been getting fingerprinted upon entry from Sept. 1, Wu said during a meeting held at the Legislative Yuan Home and Nations Committee on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Fingerprinting equipment has already been set up and tested at the country's two international airports and at the harbors on Kinmen and Matsu, which are used for shipping links with China.
Chinese people already living in Taiwan should also have their fingerprints taken while applying for renewal of their residence permits, according to MAC officials.

With Taiwan opening its doors ever-wider to people from China, Wu said, the number of Chinese people using false identity papers has become an increasingly serious problem for the authorities, prompting Premier Frank Hsieh to direct recently that a comprehensive fingerprinting system should be put in place.
Meanwhile, Wu noted, the issue of when Chinese tourists will be allowed to come to Taiwan for leisure trips hinges on the Chinese authorities.

Wu said that if the Beijing authorities are willing to engage in negotiations with their Taiwan counterparts, the issue of Chinese tourists holidaying in Taiwan can be settled within a matter of months.
But if there is no official cross-strait talk on the issue, a rumor that Chinese tourists will be allowed in before July 2006 is too optimistic, Wu added.
Wu lamented that so far there have only been "contacts" and "arrangements" across the strait on the tourism issue, with no official talks or negotiations in sight.

Responding to several legislators from the ruling Democratic Progress Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, who asked how the administration will control and manage the influx of Chinese tourists once the program is implemented, Wu said the MAC and relevant agencies, including the Ministry of the Interior, have drawn up a comprehensive package of regulations on the matter.

The regulations include restrictions on cash and assets carried by the Chinese tourists and on places they can go during their stays, Wu said, adding that they might also be required to remit personal guarantee deposits prior to their arrival.

DOC.HEADLINE: DANCERS NEED CASH TO PERFORM IN NATIONAL DAY RALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of senior Tao dancers from the island of Lanyu off the southeast coast of Taiwan are despondent, as financial constraints prevent them from going to Changhua in central Taiwan to show off their traditional tribal dances at a government-sponsored Oct. 10 Double Ten National Day party.

Hsien Chiayouli, director-general of the Langtao Community Development Association, said Thursday that a total of 40 Tao dancers have been invited to perform their unique and traditional "Brave Warrior Dance" and "Hair Dance" at the National Day rally.
The rally sponsor, however, allocated only NT$50,000 to the group, far less than the approximately NT$600,000 that the group would need for their four-day trip, Hsien Chiayouli said.

The group's trip would include round-trip flights from Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, to Taitung, flights from Taitung to Taipei and train rides from Taipei to Changhua, in addition to hotel accommodation and food, he added.
One angry dancer said scathingly that NT$50,000 is enough only for the 40 Tao people to fly to nearby Green Island. "We would have to swim the rest of the way," he added sarcastically.
Hsien Chiayouli called for help to facilitate the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO DRAFT MEASURES TO HELP FOREIGN WORKERS DEFEND THEIR RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will cooperate with the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to draft a package of measures to help foreign workers defend their rights and interests, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Thursday.

Shih made the remarks while delivering a special report at a Legislative Yuan Judicial Committee meeting on how foreign workers are treated under Taiwan's present judicial system and on the progress of investigations into a recent riot by Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system construction project.
Under the current Taiwan Criminal Code, Shih said, foreign laborers, no matter whether they are victims or perpetrators in a criminal case, should be treated same as their Taiwan counterparts.
"Our current criminal law and litigation procedures do not discriminate against foreign citizens," Shih said.

Claiming that the Aug. 21 riot by Thai workers indicated that the foreign laborers lacked legal knowledge and were unaware of their rights, Shih said the MOJ will draft feasible measures in cooperation with the CLA to help them protect their rights and interests.
The group of Thai workers rioted at their living quarters in Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan Aug. 21 to protest their inhumane treatment at the hands of their local management company, Huapan Co.

Shih said initial investigations show that the two senior Huapan executives -- Yen Shih-hua and his wife Wang Tsai-pi -- are suspected of racketeering in hiring and managing Thai workers working for the Kaohsiung MRT project. The couple have been detained for further questioning.

Acknowledging that foreign laborers have contributed a great deal to Taiwan's public infrastructure projects, Shih said prosecution authorities will be lenient toward any of the Thai workers who were only slightly involved in the Aug. 21 riot.
"They will not be indicted or have been offered deferred indictment, " Shih said.
Nevertheless, he said, the ringleader and those who played a major role in the violence will be dealt with in accordance with the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKER RESCUED AFTER BEING BURIED ALIVE FOR 26 HOURS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, Central Taiwan, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A 66-year-old worker buried alive for 26 hours in a well he was digging was rescued late Thursday.

Liu Ching-te was reportedly in good condition after firefighters worked continuously for 17 hours to pull him from a nine-meter deep hole. Doctors who treated him said they will try to prevent him from developing kidney failure or rhabdomyolysis -- the breakdown of muscle fiber resulting in the release of muscle fiber contents into the circulation.
About 12 hours earlier, the rescue workers dug out Liu's 63-year-old cousin, Chang Tien-szu.

The two workers began digging the well in Hsinshe township Wednesday. They were laying a cylinder when the sides collapsed, burying Liu. While Chang was trying to dig his cousin out, more earth crumbled and buried him too.

The construction firm Liu and Chang work for sent its own workers to the rescue, but after digging for almost five hours, they found the operation too difficult and decided to seek help from the local fire brigade.

After digging for about nine hours, the firefighters pulled Chang out. Eight hours later, as the digging continued, they heard Liu's cries from below. The rescue mission sped up their work and finally managed to pull Liu from the hole also.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAXI FUEL SURCHARGE TO BE CANCELED

TEXT.P: The government has decided to cancel the taxi fuel surcharge from Oct. 1 to help tide taxi drivers over their financial straits amid the current gasoline price upward spiral, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.
According to Cho, Premier Frank Hsieh reached the decision after meeting with representatives of major local taxi driver associations.
At present, a NT$2,400 fuel surcharge is imposed on each taxi cab per quarter to help finance highway and road maintenance and repair projects.

Taiwan currently has about 9,600 taxis. The cancelation of the taxi fuel surcharge will cost the national coffers an estimated NT$930 million annually, Cho said, adding that the measure is aimed at helping taxi drivers make ends meet in the face of soaring gasoline prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PCC TO SEND INVESTMENT-SOLICITING DELEGATION TO EUROPE

TEXT.P: The Public Construction Commission (PCC) will organize a delegation that will visit Europe in mid-November to seek investment from European business groups in Taiwan's infrastructure construction projects, an official said Thursday.
The investment-soliciting delegation, to be headed by PCC Vice Chairman Tsai Tuei, will be seeking European investment in a number of large infrastructure projects, the official said.

The projects on the drawing board include 34 sewer systems around Taiwan, land development in the vicinity of high-speed railway stations, mass rapid transit systems, renewal of an old railway station complex in downtown Taipei, an oceanography museum in Keelung and construction of a new theater in Panchiao, Taipei County.
Combined, the projects will be worth in excess of NT$100 billion, the official said.
The delegation of PCC officials and local business executives is scheduled to visit Germany, Belgium and France during its one-week or 10-day trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR SEPTEMBER 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, September 30:
10:00, The "908 Taiwan Nation Movement" will hold a news conference at National Taiwan University Alumni Hall in Taipei to announce its decision to push for a new Taiwan constitution by 2008.
10:00, Vice Education Minister Fan Hsun-lu will attend the 2005 "education-human rights" wedding ceremony in Tainan City.
13:30, The 21st Century Constitutional Reform Alliance will hold a seminar on an overall review of Taiwan's constitutional amendments over the past decades.
16:00, The Mainland Affairs Council will give a news conference at its headquarters in Taipei.
16:20, The Central Bank of China will hold a monthly news conference at its head office in Taipei.
16:30, A changeover ceremony for China Shipbuilding Corp. chairman will be held at the National Corporations Commission office in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, ST. VINCENT SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE
DOC.DATELINE: Kingstown, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC President Chen Shui-bian signed a joint communique with St. Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves Thursday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral cooperation, regional prosperity and world peace.

Chen arrived in the St. Vincent and the Grenadines capital of Kingstown Wednesday for an offiical visit to the Caribbean state. He delivered a speech to the Caribbean nation's parliament Thursday morning. He then signed the joint communique with Gonsalves.

In the joint communique, Chen said Taiwan will continue to assist St. Vincent and the Grenadines in economic development, while Gonsalves promised to continue supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other major world organizations.
On Wednesday, Chen said he looks forward to learning from St. Vincent and the Grenadines' experience in constitutional re-engineering during his current visit to the East Caribbean nation.
Chen made the remarks at a dinner party hosted by St. Vincent and the Grenadines Governor-General Frederick Ballantyne in his honor.

Noting that nationwide constitutional reform consultations in St. Vincent and the Grenadines in 2003 marked one of the most memorable episodes in the democratic development of British Commonwealth states in the Caribbean, Chen said Taiwan can learn from its Caribbean ally in planning its own second phase of constitutional reforms aimed at consolidating its young democracy.

Chen said the Presidential Office set up a constitutional reform consultative office Aug. 1 to push for extensive discussion on relevant topics and pool the wisdom of the private and public sectors with the ultimate goal of formulating a "timely, fitting and viable" constitution before his term ends in May 2008.

Heading an entourage of government officials and business leaders, Chen arrived in the St. Vincent and the Grenadines capital of Kingstown earlier in the day for an official visit, making him the first serving Republic of China head of state to set foot in the East Caribbean nation.

He was accorded a red-carpet welcome complete with a 21-gun salute and full military honors. Local school children sang a popular Taiwanese folk song titled "Aspiring for Spring Wind" at the welcoming ceremony.
Thousands of St. Vincent citizens, waving ROC and St. Vincent national flags, turned out to greet Chen and the nation took a half-day off to welcome him.

Chen met with the ROC embassy staff, members of an ROC technical mission, volunteers and alternative service diplomatic staffers at his hotel shortly after his arrival to ask about their work and boost their morale.

St. Vincent and the Grenadines is the final leg of Chen's five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean that has already taken him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis. He will make a brief transit stop in San Francisco on his way home.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Sept. 30, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1882: Water power is first used to produce electricity, at a plant on the Fox River near Appleton, Wisconsin.
1917: Park Chung Hee, South Korean president from 1963 until his assassination in 1979, is born.
1932: The Council of the League of Nations sends the Lytton report to both China and Japan, suggesting that Manchuria should be made an autonomous region after the Lytton Commission's investigation of the Shenyang (Mukden) Incident in northern China.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt announces a US$700 million New Deal aid package to help poor Americans.
1938: British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain returns to Britain after signing the Munich agreement with German leader Adolf Hitler, who had demanded immediate German occupation of German-speaking Sudentenland in western Czechoslovakia.
1941: Chinese troops win the second battle of Changsha, Hunan Province, defeating the Japanese invaders.
1949: Communist Chinese leader Mao Tse-tung formally becomes the chairman of the newly established People's Republic of China in Peking.
1954: The U.S. Navy commissions the first nuclear-powered submarine, the Nautilus.
1955: James Dean, American actor, dies in an automobile accident at the age of 24. His moody, rebellious persona in films such as "East of Eden" and "Rebel Without a Cause" made him a cult figure.
1961: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), comprised of 20 countries in Europe and the Americas, is formally established.
1965: A failed coup attempt begins in Indonesia when six generals are kidnapped. They are found dead Oct. 3.
1966: Bechuanaland gains independence from Britain as the Republic of Botswana, with Seretse Khama as its first president.
1967: The 13th conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens a two-day session.
1973: Gen. Donald V. Bennette, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: Japanese Emperor Hirohito and his wife leave for their first tour of the United States.
1975: The ROC government announces a price hike of NT$2 per liter on gasoline and petroleum solvents due to the fact that the price of crude has risen 10 percent.
1981: Yeh Chien-ying, chairman of the National People's Congress of mainland China, proposes to Taiwan a third cooperation plan between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party for peaceful national unification.
1985: Charles Richter, American seismologist, dies at the age of 85. The scale used to measure the magnitude of earthquakes was named after him.
1985: A former Communist Chinese militiaman, Shih Hsiao-ning, and a doctor, Chang Mu-chu, 27, meet the local press for the first time after escaping to Matsu by fishing boat from mainland China with a cache of arms Aug. 18.
1992: The United States withdraws from its military base at Subic Bay after the treaty allowing the United States to occupy the air base and Subic Bay Naval Station expires, ending close to a century of U.S. military presence in the Philippines.
1992: The presidents of mainland China and South Korea toast the end of the Cold War after the two countries sign a series of wide-ranging economic accords.
1993: A series of strong earthquakes rock three provinces in southwestern India, killing nearly 40,000 people.
1993: Yang Ming-teh, his wife Han Feng-ying, and their son Yang Yang, hijack a Sichuan Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives unanimously adopts a resolution expressing sympathy and support for Taiwan as the island struggles to recover from the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: Economic Minister Lin Hsin-yi recommends that the Executive Yuan stop construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear plant.
2001: The Taiwan affiliate of Germany's Siemens Group wins core contracts from Kaohsiung City for the development of the first mass rapid transport (MRT) system in southern Taiwan worth close to NT$170 billion (US$4.9 billion).
Confucius' lesson of the day: "However excellent a system of moral truths, appealing merely to worldly authority may result in the system not commanding respect; what does not command respect cannot command credence; and what cannot command credence, the people will never obey."

1981: Yeh Chien-ying, chairman of the National People's Congress of mainland China, proposes to Taiwan a third cooperation plan between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party for peaceful national unification.
1985: Charles Richter, American seismologist, dies at the age of 85. The scale used to measure the magnitude of earthquakes was named after him.
1985: A former Communist Chinese militiaman, Shih Hsiao-ning, and a doctor, Chang Mu-chu, 27, meet the local press for the first time after escaping to Matsu by fishing boat from mainland China with a cache of arms Aug. 18.
1992: The United States withdraws from its military base at Subic Bay after the treaty allowing the United States to occupy the air base and Subic Bay Naval Station expires, ending close to a century of U.S. military presence in the Philippines.
1992: The presidents of mainland China and South Korea toast the end of the Cold War after the two countries sign a series of wide-ranging economic accords.
1993: A series of strong earthquakes rock three provinces in southwestern India, killing nearly 40,000 people.
1993: Yang Ming-teh, his wife Han Feng-ying, and their son Yang Yang, hijack a Sichuan Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1999: The U.S. House of Representatives unanimously adopts a resolution expressing sympathy and support for Taiwan as the island struggles to recover from the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
2000: Economic Minister Lin Hsin-yi recommends that the Executive Yuan stop construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear plant.
2001: The Taiwan affiliate of Germany's Siemens Group wins core contracts from Kaohsiung City for the development of the first mass rapid transport (MRT) system in southern Taiwan worth close to NT$170 billion (US$4.9 billion).
Confucius' lesson of the day: "However excellent a system of moral truths, appealing merely to worldly authority may result in the system not commanding respect; what does not command respect cannot command credence; and what cannot command credence, the people will never obey."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MAKE DETOUR EN ROUTE BACK TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kingstown, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will make a detour to an unspecified country which does not maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan for a transit stop en route back to Taiwan from St. Vincent and the Grenadines, an aide to Chen said Thursday aboard the president's plane.

Since the flight from the St. Vincent capital of Kingstown to the unspecified country will take more than 10 hours, the president's return to Taiwan will be postponed by one day to Oct. 2, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said.
Huang told members of the media aboard the president's plane that as a result of the detour, President Chen will not make a transit stop in San Francisco en route home as originally scheduled.
"The U.S. authorities have been notified about the decision, and they have expressed their understanding," he added.
Huang further said that the stopover destination will be announced three hours prior to landing.

St. Vincent and the Grenadines was the final leg of Chen's five-nation, 13-day diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean which also took him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis. Chen and his entourage had made a stopover in Miami, Florida en route to Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MIGHT COOPERATE WITH SPAIN TO BUILD SUBS FOR TAIWAN: LE MONDE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The United States might cooperate with Spain to build submarines to sell to Taiwan, the French newspaper Le Monde reported Friday.

Washington has agreed to sell eight diesel-electric submarines to Taiwan, as well as six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, although the island's legislature has yet to pass the long-stalled arms procurement bill to buy the weaponry items.

According to the Le Monde report, both Germany and France, which have monopolized almost entire traditional submarine production in the global market, have said they do not want to build the submarines for Taiwan, reportedly due to concerns about irritating Beijing.

The French shipbuilding group DCN and the Spanish Navantia Group are jointly building Scorpio-class submarines for several countries, including Chile, India and Malaysia, and Spain intends to transfer part of that subs' technology for use in building a new type of S-80 submarine on its own.

The report said that the United States and Spain have been in contact and want to cooperate, with Washington expressing the hope that Spain can lower the price for construction of the S-80 class subs in order to be able to sell them to Taiwan in the future.
The newspaper also reported that the Navantia Group signed a contract with the U.S.-based Rockheed Martin Co. several months ago to equip the S-80 submarines' central combat system.

Nevertheless, the paper said that the Spanish authorities concerned have not yet confirmed any plans related to the export of the S-80 submarines to other countries. The four S-80 subs currently being built by the Navantia Group are all for the Spanish Navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL GOVERNMENT'S EXPENDITURES FOR 2006 WILL NOT GROW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that his administration will manage to keep the central government's expenditures from increasing for the next fiscal year and that all the spending will be for "the pursuit of individual, family, community and national health."

The premier made the remarks when he led Finance Minister Lin Chuan and Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Minister Hsu Chang-yao to report on the budget proposal for the central government for 2006 and the government's special budget proposal to expand public construction.

He said that government expenditures will be NT$1.5996 trillion in 2006, while revenue will be NT$1.4039 trillion, which will all be used to improve the government's finances so that the gap between expenditures and revenue will be cut to NT$195.7 billion, or the first time in seven years that the gap will be cut to under NT$200 billion.

Hsieh noted that world economic growth next year is expected to be similar to this year's growth and that Taiwan's foreign trade will maintain modest growth and that its economy will register growth of 3.2 percent.

He also said that he is cautiously optimistic about Taiwan's economy for next year, noting that various sectors are expected to maintain their competitive edge because of their investment in research and development and production of high value-added products.
In addition, the government will actively promote and expand public construction investment and flood-control projects in flood-prone areas, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-RUSSIA ENGAGEMENT NOT AFFECTED BY CHINA-RUSSIA MILITARY DRILLS
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Substantive bilateral engagement between Taiwan and Russia will not be affected by the joint military drills conducted by Russia and China recently, visiting Taiwan-Russia Association President Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday.

Instead, Taiwan is demonstrating its sincerity in making friends with Russia by signing more business contracts to further deepen bilateral ties between the two countries, Chang said during a cocktail party in Moscow.

Held prior to the contract signing ceremony was the third Taiwan-Russian Cooperation Forum, in which the 20-member Taiwan trade delegation headed by Chang exchanged views with officials from Moscow's public agencies as well as private groups on plans to promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation in energy resources research, trade, economic development and financial reform between Russia and Taiwan.
Chang and his delegation arrived in Moscow earlier this week. They are scheduled to head to St. Petersburg Friday for a visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE ACTIVISTS UNVEIL 'NEW CONSTITUTION' DRIVE

TEXT.P: The 908 Taiwan Nation Movement, a local pro-independence group, announced Friday that it will mobilize three million people to form a human chain around Taiwan on Feb. 28, 2008 to push for passage of a new "Taiwan Nation Constitution."

Wang Hsien-chi, convener of the movement, told a news conference that the 2004 "one million people human chain" activity helped President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party win re-election but that it failed to realize the goal of enacting a new constitution for Taiwan and changing the nation's official title from the "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."

"We now plan to hold an even larger-scale activity to drum up support for our goal of writing a new constitution for Taiwan by mobilizing three million people to join hands to form a circle around Taiwan on Feb. 28, 2008 ahead of the next presidential election, " Wang said, adding that the human chain activity will show the world the Taiwan people's resolve to formulate a new constitution and establish a new "Taiwan Nation."

Following the end of the human chain activity, Wang said, his group will throw support behind the presidential candidate who explicitly backs its cause and promises to implement the new constitution if elected. The next presidential election is scheduled to be held in March 2008.

Wang said since two pro-unification Taiwan opposition heavyweights -- former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- made high-profile visits to China earlier this year, more Taiwan people have leaned toward China.

Worse still, Wang said, the pro-China trend has become even more evident after charismatic Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou succeeded Lien as KMT chairman. Ma is widely seen as a shoo-in to win the 2008 presidential election.
Wang said his group will step up its "new constitution" campaign with a view to keeping the pro-unification KMT from reclaiming the nation's helm.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SCRAP 120 TUNA BOATS TO HELP CONSERVE STOCKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will reduce its tuna fleet by scrapping 120 ocean-going longliners within two years to help conserve the world's tuna stocks and related resources, officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Friday.

The government will spend US$4 billion (US$121.2 million) to offset dismantling of the vessels this year and next, in a bid to reduce Taiwan's tuna fishing capacity, officials from the COA Fisheries Administration said.

Although Taiwan is not a United Nations member, the country is resolute in supporting conservation measures called for by the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization's Committee on Fisheries in 1999 to reduce fishing fleets that contribute to overfishing, the officials said.
The decision has been made as Taiwan wants to do its duty as a member of the global village, as well as to help secure sustainable fishery resources for all, the officials added.
The scrapping of the boats will be mandatory and the vessels' licenses will be repealed automatically, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS WELCOMES REFERENDUM ON KRTS SCANDAL

TEXT.P: A leading member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that he would welcome a referendum proposed by an opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator to deal with the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit System (KRTS) scandal.

William Lai, DPP caucus convener at the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks in response to PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao's remarks that he will not exclude the possibility of holding a referendum or raising a motion at the legislature to request the resignation of the Cabinet to tackle the problems caused by the scandal.
The scandal, which has snowballed since a riot by Thai laborers working for the KRTS last month, has become a hot topic between the ruling and opposition parties at the legislature.

Criticising what he claimed is the KRTS' poor administration and corruption, Chang also blamed the DPP for its defense of the scandal and former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh for failing to take responsibility for overseeing the KRTS construction program.

Claiming that the scandal might cost the nation at least NT$20 billion, the legislator said that the "power of civic rights" must intervene in the investigation of the scandal, adding that he will also organize yet another investigation committee to probe the matter.
In response, Lai said that referendum is the best way to put civic rights into practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 108.62 points to close at 6,118.61.
The bourse opened at 6,053.59 and fluctuated between 6,118.61 and 6,047.2 during trading. A total of 3.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.62 billion (US$2.88 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and construction issues both at 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1 percent and cement stocks and foodstuff issues both at 0.9 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 703 to 238, with 136 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASSISTS PANAMA IN BUILDING DIGITAL AGRICULTURAL CENTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has financed the establishment of a computer center at an agricultural vocational school in the Panamanian town of Divisa as part of its efforts to help its Central American ally equip its agricultural sector with digital technology.

The digital training-oriented center was inaugurated Thursday at a ceremony that saw the participation of Panamanian Minister of Agricultural and Livestock Development Laurentino Cortizo Cohen, ROC Ambassador to Panama Hou Ping-fu, as well as Ke Jyh-sheng, president of the Taipei-based state-funded Institute for Information Industry.

The institute was commissioned to design and build the center, at which experts from Taiwan will be stationed to help develop a computer system for collecting agricultural information and train seed information technicians.
Ke said he hopes the facility will inspire the country to facilitate its development in the field of agriculture and other sectors with digital equipment and knowledge.

The ROC has been helping Panama in agricultural and livestock development through a technical mission that assists local farmers with modern skills and know-how. In recent years, the ROC government has tried to expand its assistance to other fields such as the information sector, according to Ho.
Besides Panama, Belize and El Salvador are also listed in the ROC's information assistance program, the ambassador said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS ANOTHER BAILOUT FOR HIGH-SPEED RAIL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the "most important task" is to get Taiwan's first high-speed railway launched as soon as possible and that an avalanche of problems could occur if the project is suspended now because of funding problems.

The premier also said he will be "responsible for major policies" and that he "supports the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) not because of THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing but out of "concern for the people."

Hsieh made the remarks amid media reports that Cho Jung-tai, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, admitted that Ing discussed with him Tuesday the capital problem and that the government will help the THSRC recruit an additional NT$7.5 billion to complete the project.

Fielding questions in the Legislative Yuan after reporting on the budget proposals for the central government for next fiscal year and the special budget proposals for the "new 10 major construction projects" program, the premier said that "all policy problems are referred to me, and yes, I agreed to it."

The China Aviation Development Foundation (CADF) and the China Technical Consultant, Inc. (CTCI) Foundation were instructed by the Executive Yuan to provide NT$4.5 billion and NT$3 billion, respectively, reports said.

Oliver F.L. Yu, vice minister of transportation and communications, confirmed that the CADF has changed its charter to allow for investment in major construction projects, including the high-speed railway, while the CTCI Foundation board chairmen have also passed the investment project.

The premier said that the investment by state-owned enterprises or government-controlled enterprise for the high-speed rail is around 12 percent of its total paid-in capital, far less than legal ceiling of government's investment in the project should not exceed 20 percent. The estimated NT$480 billion (US$14.77 billion) project is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.
He reaffirmed that the system is now 87 percent complete, and it is not time to review whether the original plan was flawed, the "important task is to get the system inaugurated as soon as possible."

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou noted that while the government claimed in the beginning that it would not spend any money on the project, it has continued to funnel in money along the way.
The high-speed rail construction project has deviated from the spirit of the build-operate-transfer model, causing "all to lose confidence in the project," Ma claimed.
Hwang Yih-jiau, a caucus whip of the opposition People First Party, lashed out at the government for not valuing the taxpayers' money.
PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should no longer deter the formation of five investigation committees, including one on the high-speed rail system.

The DPP legislative caucus said that national construction should be an across-the-party-spectrum task and that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP should not derail the high-speed rail project via political means, "causing Taiwan to go bankrupt."

William Lai, a DPP caucus whip, said that since Ing announced her support for President Chen Shui-bian during the 2000 presidential election, she has become the target of bashing from the "pan-blue alliance."

Lai also said that if the CADF could funnel its idle funds into the system, it will help the smooth inauguration of the system next year and will benefit the foundation, creating what he claimed will be a win-win situation.
Ing announced last month that the launch of the railway will be postponed for one year until Oct. 31, 2006.

She cited various factors, including the lack of progress in the construction, system tests and operation preparations. She was unwilling to identify where the faults lie but said that the Japanese Shinkansen train system is "more complex" than expected.
Ing claimed, however, that she is confident of achieving the new goal of launching the high-speed railway by October next year.
THSRC officials said construction of core mechanical and electrical systems have lagged behind schedule by more than 30 percent, affecting system tests and operation preparations.

The 345-km high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network that it is claimed will reduce travel time between Taipei and Kaohsiung to 90 minutes. The system will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities and will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON LONGWANG MAY HIT TAIWAN DIRECTLY SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Strong Typhoon Longwang, whose center was located about 1,100 km east of Taiwan at 5 p.m. Friday, may hit Taiwan directly Sunday, according to a forecast by the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The CWB said a sea warning for the typhoon is expected to be issued Friday night or early Saturday morning.
The CWB forecast indicated that with a radius of 200 km, Longwang, the 19th typhoon this year, is moving west at a speed of 19 kph, which is expected to increase to 23 kph Saturday.
The velocity of Longwang had gone over the threshold of a strong typhoon by Thursday night, with center winds reaching 51 meters per second, or 184 kph, and gusts of up to 63 meters per second.

Rain from Typhoon Longwang will begin to affect northern and eastern Taiwan Saturday. If the strong typhoon continues moving in its present direction, its radius will cover the whole of Taiwan Sunday.
However, there is still a slight chance that high pressure in the Pacific Ocean might cause the typhoon to veer from the predicted course, according to the CWB forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUPS EXTENDING HUMANITARIAN RELIEF TO CAMBODIANS
DOC.DATELINE: Poipet, Cambodia, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Hsu Yu-li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Five Taiwan charitable organizations are jointly offering humanitarian relief to the needy in a poverty-stricken border town in northwestern Cambodia.

The "Love of Taiwan" delegation, comprised of members of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) , the Field Relief Agency (FRA), Compassion International, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, arrived in Poipet, a town on the border with Thailand, Sept. 25 to deliver their humanitarian relief to the locals.
In two days, delegation members have offered free medical services to more than 700 people in Poipet, many of whom are victims of decades of bloodshed.

The delegation has brought with it some 600 kg of medication and medical aid materials, including wheelchairs, crutches, walking aids and white sticks for the blind, as many people in Poipet are victims of landmines that were planted secretly there when Poipet was a war zone.

Due to poverty and poor sanitary condition, many youths aged around 15 in Poipet weigh only between 20kg-30 kg, while many men, due to long-term coolie labor, suffer problems with their joints and most women have gynecological problems, according to TRMPC medical professionals.
In addition, a large number of Poipet residents suffer from sight problems, some of whom have suffered eye problems since their childhood, said an eye doctor with the TRMPC.

Sept. 26 was a "big day" for the Poipet locals, particularly the children and youths, because the town's first high school was inaugurated, thanks to FRA Secretary-General Yang Wei-ling's devotion and compassion to the Cambodian people over past several years.

Yang, a flight attendant-turned-philanthropist who founded the FRA seven years ago and has traveled to Cambodia at least twice each year for humanitarian relief work, helped establish the high school, the first of its kind in northwestern Cambodian, which is capable of allowing more than 1,000 youths to attend school free of charge.
Yang managed to raise US$120,000 to build the school, which offers junior and senior education for youths aged over 12.

Knowing that Cambodian teachers tend to give closer academic attention to their students in paid after-school classes in order to make extra money, Yang decided to pay the teachers at the high school salaries twice or three times higher than ordinary levels, hoping that they will focus their teaching on the new school.

Yang offered her gratitude to the Taiwan International Lions Club 300-A2 for a donation of US$80,000 to fund the hardware development in the new school and to Compassion International for donating 18 standard blackboards ready to be installed in the school's 18 classrooms.
The FRA will finance 80 percent of the cost of maintaining the school, including teachers' salaries, while Cambodia's education authorities will finance the remaining 20 percent, according to Yang.
Meanwhile, the FRA has also launched a campaign to have 500 bicycles donated to help children and youths in Poipet to go to school.

The school is not the only institution Yang has helped establish in Cambodia. She has established a library of Chinese books, all of which have been transported from Taiwan. She has also founded an orphanage and a vocational training center.

Believing that education is the best way to help people surmount poverty, Yang has continued to build schools in Cambodia and she even made the phrase, "Education changes a child's fate, " a motto of the new school.
