DOC.HEADLINE: AD HOC TEAM TO BE FORMED TO COORDINATE HIGH-SPEED RAIL ISSUE: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the Executive Yuan will form an ad hoc team to coordinate matters related to the high-speed rail system.

The premier made the remarks during an interpellation session when legislators' questions centered on reports that the Executive Yuan has instructed two foundations to invest NT$7.5 billion (US$230.77 million) in the cash-strapped Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) so that it can continue construction of the railway.

The team will handle such issues as possible difficulties of the high-speed rail project, on THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing's earlier remarks that she will step down the day the system is inaugurated, on whether to reorganize the board of directors, and the responsibility of the original shareholders of the multi-billion dollar project.
Noting that all the problems have been left over from past years, Hsieh said that "as long as I'm the premier, I have to take responsibility."
The premier also said the government will be more actively involved in the project.

He said the China Aviation Development Foundation (CADF) , which has been instructed to invest NT$4 billion according to reports, is not "sending the THSRC the money for free" and will benefit from the investment in the future.

He noted that the law stipulates that state-owned enterprises' investment in the high-speed rail project should not top a ceiling of 20 percent of the THSRC's paid-in capital, but the government has only invested around 12 percent so far because of the Legislative Yuan's earlier resolution that the government should no longer invest in the project.
The premier said that the CADF is not a state-owned enterprise, which shows respect for the legislature's decision.
He said that although the government encourages private investment, as the return of the system is slower, the recruiting of funds has not been smooth.

The government's contract with the THSRC stipulates compulsory buyout and if the construction of the system, which he claimed "is now 87 percent complete, " is disrupted because of a shortage of funds, he said the company will suspend work and the government will have to pay NT$300 billion for the remaining 13 percent of the work, which he said would not be worthwhile.
"Only avoiding the buyout of the system is in the best interest of the people," he claimed.

The 345-km high-speed railway is the nation's first major infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer system. The THSRC won the bid in September 1997 by promising that the government would have to make "zero" investment in the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HOSTS AUSTRONESIAN FORUM

TEXT.P: The 2005 Austronesian Forum opened in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Friday, with local officials in charge of indigenous affairs, officials and representatives from Austronesian countries and scholars in Austronesian cultures in attendance.

The forum was the first international event of its kind that the Kaohsiung City Government has hosted to boost friendships, exchanges and cooperation of Austronesian indigenous peoples. Austronesian is a family of languages widely dispersed throughout the islands of Southeast Asia and the Pacific.

Austronesian, meaning "southern islands, " has 10 primary subgroups, with nine of them found in Taiwan (the Formosan languages, unrelated to Chinese) and one ancestral to all other members of the family (Malayo-Polynesian languages).

The participants at the Kaohsiung forum include Icyang Parod, of indigenous origin, who is vice minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples, Dr. Wes Heber of the Department of Indigenous Studies at the First Nations University of Canada, as well as the ambassadors of Palau, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands to the Republic of China, and officials of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office, the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office and the Fiji Trade and Tourism Representative Office on the island.
Icyang addressed the opening saying Taiwan is planning to broadcast an indigenous people-oriented television channel this year, which will be the first of its kind in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OBLIGED TO ASSIST CHINA TO RISE IN POSITIVE MANNER: PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 29 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has an obligation to assist and push China to rise in a positive manner, one that protects the human rights of all Chinese people, ROC Premier Frank Hsieh wrote in an article carried in the Thursday issue of the Wall Street Journal.
"As two of the world's ethnic Chinese societies, China and Taiwan are not natural enemies, but cousins sharing deep historical and cultural ties," Hsieh wrote.
However, Hsieh stressed that Taiwan is more than just one of the world's Chinese societies.

"Taiwan is the first and only democracy among them. We, therefore, have an obligation to assist and push China to rise in a positive manner, one that protects and promotes the human rights of all Chinese people," Hsieh wrote.

Quoting President Chen Shui-bian, Hsieh wrote that China's emergence ought to be accompanied by a peaceful awakening and democratic development, thereby creating opportunities rather than risks for all humanity.
"We hope China's emergence can follow the path of peace and democracy," Hsieh added.
Noting that a clash between Taiwan and China is not inevitable, Hsieh wrote that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait still have the chance to achieve reconciliation and coexist.

"Even when China appears to be at its most threatening, Taiwan will continue to seek a win-win solution with China and not attempt to contain or suppress China's legitimate rise, " Hsieh wrote, adding that as long as China can respect Taiwan's existence, Taiwan has no need to stand in the way of its rise.
On the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II, Hsieh wrote, all Asian people prayed for the birth of a peaceful, democratic and prosperous new Asia.

"In this new Asia, a democratic Taiwan, a peaceful China, and all the other great Asian nations would coexist and rely on each other. In this new Asia, the Taiwan Strait would be the conduit for peace, not for war," Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: N.Y. Times Reporter Released From Jail; Miller to Testify In CIA Leak Probe.
New York Times reporter Judith Miller was released from jail late yesterday and is scheduled to testify this morning before a federal grand jury investigating whether any government officials illegally leaked the identity of CIA operative Valerie Plame to the media, according to lawyers involved in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN ABU DHABI 0N ONE-DAY TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Abu Dhabi Friday for a one-day transit stop on his way home after a five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, who is a member of the president's entourage, said the president will discuss defense and military cooperation with the United Arab Emirates (UAE) during his 29-hour layover.

President Chen will also discuss with UAE authorities other matters of mutual concern, including promotion of tourist exchanges, the opening of direct flight services between the two countries, the relocation of Taiwan's representative office from Dubai to the UAE capital of Abu Dhabi, and cooperation between Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. and its UAE counterpart in oil exploration.
President Chen and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Oct. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGISTRATION FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS BEGIN

TEXT.P: Aspirants around the island for city and county heads and councilmen as well as village and township heads registered at local election commissions Friday on the first day of registration for the Dec. 3 three-in-one elections.

The Central Election Commission said that the registration will last until Oct. 4, and that if the approaching typhoon, Longwang, is seriously affecting Taiwan at that time, registration will be extended for another day.
Several candidates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the hotly contested city and county races chose to register on the first day, hoping that would prove to be lucky.

In Taipei County, Luo Wen-jia, DPP candidate for Taipei County magistrate, kept a low profile. He was accompanied by his wife, Chiang Chao-yi, and a group of children and their mothers holding sunflowers to the election commission, hoping to highlight his policy of taking care of women and children.

In contrast, Chou Hsi-wei, the Kuomintang (KMT) candidate, registered with a large throng of supporters around him, stressing that if the KMT wins back the county magistrate after a 16-year hiatus, it will go on to win the 2008 presidential election.

As the year-end elections are generally considered the first major battle leading to the presidential election, many candidates, irrespective of their party affiliation, have solicited well-known figures to accompany them on their trips to register to boost their popularity.
Cheng Kuei-yuan, DPP candidate for Hsinchu City mayor, was accompanied by senior DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming.
Cheng said that although Hsinchu is credited as being Taiwan's silicon valley, its city development has stalled, and he vowed to build it into a cultural and high-tech city.
The incumbent, Lin Cheng-tzer, said that his campaign theme of "a garden city with peace and happiness, " will be a follow-up to his "clean administration and construction" four years ago.

Cheng Pao-ching, DPP candidate for Taoyuan County head, who is fighting an uphill battle against the incumbent, Chu Li-lun, was accompanied to register by his campaign manager, Tsai Ing-wen, DPP legislator and former chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
Cheng said that if he is elected, he will desalinate sea water and take a multiple-approach to get water to solve the persistent water shortage problem of the county.
"If I break my promises in two years, I'll step down to take responsibility," he vowed.
Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, accompanied by a large number of supporters, registered for reelection.

Cheng said that the approval rating of Hsinchu County tops all cities and counties, and it has the lowest unemployment and misery index, stressing that he will continue to work toward bettering the economy and wellbeing of residents.

Chiu Ping-kun, DPP candidate for Miaoli County magistrate -- a post that has long been dominated by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- said that he is fighting an uphill battle, but he will continue to work hard.

KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou also said Friday that the integration of the KMT and the PFP on fielding candidates for the elections has encountered hurdles, citing the examples of Keelung City and Miaoli County magistrates.

He said that KMT is sincere in wishing to integrate with the PFP, but it has nominated Liu Cheng-hung, who led other aspirants by a big margin in pre-nomination polls, and "the KMT doesn't have sufficient reasons to dismiss him now."
The integration of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), has also hit snags.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai of the DPP and TSU candidate Chien Lin Hui-chun both completed their registration for their candidacies for the southern city head.

Chien Lin was accompanied by TSU legislators Lo Chi-ming and Tseng Tsang-teng for the registration, saying that former President Lee Teng-hui had urged her to come forward, and she made the decision after a long deliberation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Times Reporter Free From Jail; She Will Testify Judith Miller, the reporter for The New York Times who has been jailed since July 6 for refusing to testify in the C.I.A. leak case, was released Thursday from a Virginia detention center after she and her lawyers reached an agreement with a federal prosecutor in which she would testify before a grand jury investigating the case, the publisher and the executive editor of the paper said.
Wall Street Journal: Credit Problem, Battle Over Academic Standards Weighs On For-Profit Colleges
For-profit colleges are booming. But a new fight between these upstarts and the education establishment raises a key question regarding the acceptance of degrees from for-profits. Traditional colleges rarely recognize the work do ne by students at for-profits, arguing their academic standards aren't high enough. So these students often have to start over if they want to go elsewhere to complete or advance their studies. With growing concern over the rejection of their students' work, the for-profit industry is pushing a bill that would make it more difficult for traditional colleges to reject course credits and degrees from their schools. It is now pending before Congress as part of broader higher-education legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA DENIES HE WILL HELP SPECIAL ARMS BUDGET BILL PASS

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) denied speculation Friday that he is prepared to let the long-stalled special arms procurement budget bill be listed on the legislative agenda for review.

Ma Ying-jeou, who is also mayor of Taipei, made the denial when asked to comment on an allegation by independent Legislator Li Ao that Ma has instructed one of his deputies, John C. Kuan, to set up a task force to study how to get the bill listed on the legislative agenda.
Ma stressed that the decision on whether the bill should be put on the agenda lies with the KMT's legislative caucus, which will have to form a consensus on the issue.

Li, a noted writer who has written more than 100 books, returned to Taiwan from a visit to China Friday. He vowed that he would make retaliatory moves against the KMT if Ma should let the bill slip onto the legislative agenda.

Another factor that makes the passage of the bill in the legislature unlikely is the obstruction by another major opposition party, the People First Party (PFP), which has vowed never to let the bill pass the Procedure Committee.

The Procedure Committee has blocked the bill 30 times in more than one year. The opposition lawmakers, who have a slight majority in the legislature, said the requested budget of NT$610.8 billion is too high and that the procurement should be funded through a regular defense budget rather than a special budget.

The government led by the Democratic Progressive Party plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

There has been speculation that the KMT has softened its opposition to the bill under pressure from the U.S. government and in consideration of the fact that the Ministry of National Defence agreed in September to list the financing for the Patriot anti-missile batteries in the regular budget, causing the proposed special budget in the bill to drop to NT$340 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOULD ALLOW MORE JOURNALISTS TO WORK IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese authorities should allow more media around the mainland to sent their journalists to Taiwan to report on different aspects and various fields, a spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the comment after China announced that it would extend the stays of Taiwanese reporters in China from one month to three months.

You explained that the move would do little to boost news exchanges between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait, saying the real meaning of media interactions is having a sufficient number of reporters stationed in Taiwan to write stories covering a wide range of fields and able to enhance mutual understanding of people on both sides.

He urged Beijing to give the greenlight for the Guangzhou-based Nanfang Daily and the Xinmin Evening News to post reporters to Taiwan as part of its "sincere efforts" to conduct cross-strait press exchanges in a positive manner.
Since Taiwan opened its door for the posting of Chinese journalists to cover events on the island in 2000, it has hosted 361 reporters from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PHILIPPINES AGREE TO EXPAND AGRICULTURAL, FISHERY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the Philippines signed a memorandum of understanding Friday on expansion of agricultural and fishery cooperation.

Taiwan's Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing and his Philippine counterpart, Representative Antonio Basilio of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, signed the document at the Council of Agriculture (COA) headquarters in Taipei, with Vice Minister of Agriculture Lee Chien-chuan and his Philippine counterpart, Salvador Salacup, looking on.

COA officials said that under the deal, the two sides agreed to organize working groups to deal with common investments and exchanges in the fields of food processing and marketing, as well as to build a communication system for resolving fishery disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED FOR TYPHOON LONGWANG

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea alert for strong Typhoon Longwang Friday night, warning ships to take extreme precautions if they have to operate in waters east of Taiwan.
The CWB said that if the typhoon continues moving in its present direction, a land warning for Taiwan will be issued Saturday morning.
The center of Typhoon Longwang was located at 22 degrees north latitude and 129.9 degrees east longitude at 8 p.m. Friday -- about 880 kilometers east-southeast of the eastern Taiwan city of Hualien.
With a radius of 200 km, the typhoon was moving west at 23 kph, with the direction expected to turn to west-northwest.
Packing center winds of 184 kph and gusts of up to 227 kph, Typhoon Longwang is expected to cover the whole of Taiwan Sunday, according to the CWB's forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN IN UAE FOR UNPRECEDENTED STOPOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Abu Dhabi, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian arrived in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) capital of Abu Dhabi Friday for a one-day transit stop on his way home after a five-nation diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean.
Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed Al Nahyan, a younger brother of UAE President Sheikh Khalifa Bin Zahed Al Nahayan, greeted Chen upon his arrival in the oil-rich Middle East country.

The UAE gave President Chen a red-carpet welcome. Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, ROC national flags were flown at Abu Dhabi International Airport. All of Chen's entourage and reporters were given courtesy treatment.
Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed Al Nahyan hosted a dinner at the hotel where Chen stays in honor of Chen and his entourage.
National Security Council Deputy Secretary-General Parris Chang flew from Taipei to Abu Dhabi to meet with Chen and his entourage.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, who is a member of the president's entourage, said the president will discuss defense and military cooperation with UAE authorities during his 29-hour layover.

President Chen will also discuss with UAE authorities other matters of mutual concern, including promotion of tourist exchanges, the opening of direct flight services between the two countries, the relocation of Taiwan's representative office from Dubai to the UAE capital of Abu Dhabi, and cooperation between Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. and its UAE counterpart in oil exploration.
President Chen and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Oct. 2.

President Chen and his entourage flew from the East Caribbean nation of St. Vincent and the Grenadines to the UAE for an unprecedented transit visit. The UAE diplomatically recognizes Beijing, but has maintained friendly substantive ties with Taiwan.

Tan Sun Chen made a low-profile visit to the UAE in April this year, and Sheikh Hamed Bin Zayed, who is in charge of UAE economic affairs, visited Taiwan in June during which time he met with President Chen.
President Chen was originally scheduled to make a transit stop in San Francisco, but dropped the plan and flew directly from St. Vincent and the Grenadines to the UAE.

St. Vincent and the Grenadines was the final leg of Chen's five-nation, 13-day diplomatic tour to Central America and the Caribbean, which also took him to Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, and the Federation of St. Kitts and Nevis. Chen and his entourage had made a stopover in Miami, Florida en route to Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, KMT FAIL TO COOPERATE IN ELECTIONS IN FOUR COUNTIES

TEXT.P: With the registration of candidates for the year-end elections of city and county chiefs, city and county councilors and chiefs of towns and urban townships formally beginning Friday, the two opposition parties in the pan-blue bloc, the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), still can't agree how or if to cooperate in some pivotal counties.

According to sources close to the two parties, the KMT and the PFP failed to agree on one joint candidate in the year-end elections of magistrates in four counties, and may give up attempts to cooperate all together.

The sources said negotiations between the two parties on joint candidates broke down almost from the start Thursday, when KMT officials couldn't agree with the PFP's request to support a PFP candidate in Miaoli County in return for its support for KMT candidates in the counties of Hsinchu, Ilan and Changhua.

The PFP asked for the KMT's support in Miaoli which it considers as its stronghold, but the KMT would not agree with the PFP's proposal because its candidate for the magistrate of Miaoli County, Liu Cheng-hung, insisted on staying in the race, stressing the legitimacy of his nomination.

Liu, who was chosen through a primary by the KMT, went to KMT headquarters asking for the party authorities' endorsement Thursday, claiming that he was the party's legitimate candidate and should not be sacrificed in political horsetrading.

Saying that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou promised that the KMT would back its members who were named through the proper mechanism as party candidates, Liu asked the party authorities to reiterate their support for him.
At the request of Liu, Liao Feng-teh, the director of the KMT's Organization Affairs Committee, declared in public Thursday that it is hard for the KMT to accept the PFP's proposal.
Disappointed by the KMT's outright rejection, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said it is a shame that the cooperation between the two parties failed because the KMT can't settle its internal disputes.

However, in Lienchiang County, the KMT agreed to support current Magistrate Chen Hsueh-shen, who is a PFP member, to seek reelection in exchange for the PFP's support for KMT candidate Huang Ming-hui in Chiayi.

The two opposition parties share the same supporters across the country's 23 counties and cities and neither of them can win the elections in most of the constituencies without the support of the other.
